WOODBINE AND DANFORTH

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/woodbine-danforth/docview/382616425/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: In comparison to properties averaging 16 or 17 feet wide and 100 feet deep, this one had the benefit of a spacious L-shaped lot more than 25 by 119 feet. "It's hard to come by all that land," Ms. [Linda Ing-Gilbert] says. "And it had a premium western exposure."

Full text:   52 Moberly Ave.
Asking price: $529,000
Selling price: $530,000
Previous selling price: $343,000 (2008)
Taxes: $2,759 (2008)
Lot size: 25 by 119 feet
Days on the market: one
Listing agent: Linda Ing-Gilbert, Re/Max Hallmark Realty Ltd.
With little inventory available across the city, buyers are quick to move on properties, such as this semi-detached house, which sold on the day it was listed by agent Linda Ing-Gilbert.
"It's just an indication of how crazy the market is," she says.
However, in comparison to properties averaging 16 or 17 feet wide and 100 feet deep, this one had the benefit of a spacious L-shaped lot more than 25 by 119 feet. "It's hard to come by all that land," Ms. Ing-Gilbert says. "And it had a premium western exposure."
The secluded grounds accommodate a long four-car driveway, garden shed and backyard surrounded by tall trees. "It was a Muskoka-like oasis in the backyard," the agent says.
The size of the property also allowed for a large two-storey plan with three bedrooms and three bathrooms, plus a rear addition off the kitchen with a powder room and double doors to the deck.
"It was fully renovated with a main-floor family room, which is in high demand," Ms. Ing-Gilbert says. "It's very rare to have that."
The sellers revamped the recreation room in the basement, which has one of two full bathrooms and a side entrance. In addition, new stainless steel appliances, air conditioning system and roofing were installed within the past year.
Other features include hardwood floors throughout, from the living and dining area to the bedrooms upstairs.
Local amenities include East Lynn Park, Danforth Avenue restaurants and subway access.

Stratford revival

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/stratford-revival/docview/382614695/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "I wanted to leave exposed the floor joists and boards from the upstairs because they were the kind of thing you don't see much of any more," Ms. [Marlene Colquhoun] says. "They are so beautiful, made of pine, and likely cut from the forests that surround Stratford."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Stratford+revival&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-04&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Stratford+revival&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-04&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Since Marlene Colquhoun raised the curtain on the renovation of her historical home, festival talents looking to rent have been knocking on her door, Deirdre Kelly writes
In a town where plot is king, Marlene Colquhoun's own Stratford story could be called stageworthy, especially as it is mainly theatre people banging on her door - literally - to experience it.
They include Simon Callow, the acclaimed British actor and director who last year rented a Gothic revival house owned by Ms. Colquhoun on Cobourg Street, a short stroll from the Tom Patterson Theatre where he was starring in his own one-man play inspired by the sonnets of William Shakespeare.
A local home and garden consultant by profession, Ms. Colquhoun had renovated the historic 1867 property so beautifully that Mr. Callow (Gareth in the film Four Weddings and a Funeral ) referred to it as "heaven on Earth" throughout his time there.
This year's tenant is Stratford Shakespeare Festival dramaturge Robert Blacker, no doubt also enjoying the 1,200-square-foot home's antique-laden interior and covered porch, where there is a divan for lounging or reading a book.
The attraction isn't hard to fathom.
After buying the house five years ago, Ms. Colquhoun wanted to preserve history, some of it her own, so she took care when renovating it to create an ambience imbued with drama, love and loss.
She had grown up in the neighbourhood - her grandparents once owned the property two doors down, where her father had been born and raised. And while she says she finds design influences in magazines and on trips abroad ("I have a good eye," she says, "I enjoy looking at things, and wherever I travel I'm obsessed with the architecture, the paint colours and the gardens"), in this case she drew inspiration from her own memories.
"I remember what the street looked like 50 years ago," she says, pouring glasses of lemonade recently on the home's veranda. "I wanted to recapture that moment in time."
The reason is largely personal: At the age of 12, she moved to New Brunswick from Stratford after the Canadian National Railway closed its shops there in 1964, causing many local families with deep roots in the area to leave town in search of work.
While out of province, she eventually married and raised three children, always dreaming to one day return to the place of her birth.
Seven years ago, her offspring having flown the nest, she finally felt free to make the move with her chiropractor husband back to Stratford, eventually chancing upon the Cobourg Street property.
"It had everything going for it," Ms. Colquhoun recalls.
"It had all the original windows, baseboards and doors. And it was authentically historic, having been designated by the Ontario Heritage Act."
The only thing missing, you might say, was Ms. Colquhoun's signature touch.
To get it, she and her husband completely gutted the home - the original baseboards and door casings removed and restored as part of the renovation - before rebuilding it from scratch.
Part of the redesign included installing new plumbing, wiring and heating ducts, as well as a new furnace, roof and interior joists to replace some that had started to rot.
The couple also removed a wall in the front hall to provide for a bigger entrance and make room for the addition of a main-floor powder room fitted with a refurbished drainboard sink that originally had been in the kitchen.
The ceilings on the main floor were already high (in excess of nine feet) and were kept intact while gaining embellishment in the form of exposed beams.
"I wanted to leave exposed the floor joists and boards from the upstairs because they were the kind of thing you don't see much of any more," Ms. Colquhoun says. "They are so beautiful, made of pine, and likely cut from the forests that surround Stratford."
The upstairs originally had three bedrooms plus a bathroom, but Ms. Colquhoun changed the floor plan to accommodate two bedrooms, each with its own ensuite bathroom.
In one of the new bathrooms, she recycled the old rolled rim cast iron tub that had been part of the original house when, more than a century ago, it belonged to Douglas McTavish, a schoolteacher.
Downstairs was an old sunroom that wasn't insulated and had fallen into disrepair. Ms. Colquhoun tore down a side wall to open it up to the kitchen, adding laundry facilities.
In the creamy white kitchen, she installed custom maple cabinetry as well as antique pine furniture - much of it locally sourced - and a chandelier original to the house.
"I believe that even in a small house it's important to create a feeling of luxury," Ms. Colquhoun says. "Each room has a chandelier, and I think making the entrance way larger instantly imparts a luxurious feel, as you feel bathed in air and space."
She and her husband lived in the home for two years before deciding to rent it out to guests of the Stratford festival.
They are currently renovating the house they recently bought next door, also a historic property.
She's just started the process and can't yet determine what the result will look like.
"I'm waiting to see what it wants to tell me," she says. "Often these old houses do that. They speak to you, letting you know just how they want to be."

Developer believed every Canadian should have a decent home

Author: Csillag, Ron

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/developer-believed-every-canadian-should-have/docview/382610116/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: He joined A.E. LePage as vice-president in 1960. Five years later, he, his boss and an associate formed Markborough Properties for the sole purpose of developing Meadowvale. The company went public a year later and Mr. [H. PETER LANGER] never looked back. "At first, builders would laugh at me," he recalled. They probably stopped laughing when Meadowvale became part of Mississauga and would go on to attract 600 companies. Once, while surveying the development from a helicopter, Mr.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Developer+believed+every+Canadian+should+have+a+decent+home&amp;author=Csillag%2C+Ron&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-29&amp;spage=S.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Developer+believed+every+Canadian+should+have+a+decent+home&amp;author=Csillag%2C+Ron&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-29&amp;spage=S.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   His signature project was Meadowvale, in Mississauga, an early planned community
Peter Langer embodied a rare mix of militaristic discipline and Mitteleuropean courtliness. Both traits came in handy in a storied five-decade-long career as one of Canada's most prolific real estate developers.
Mr. Langer rode the crest of Ontario's real estate boom from the 1940s through to the 80s, developing millions of square feet of residential, commercial and industrial properties, and serving on a slew of industry associations.
But his signature project was - and continues to be - Meadowvale in Mississauga, one of the first and most successful integrated, or "planned" communities in North America.
Once 1,200 hectares of barren farmland in the Town of Streetsville, which was folded into Mississauga in 1974, Meadowvale was inspired by the earlier planning success of the Don Mills community in northern Toronto, which integrated homes, offices, schools, industrial parks and shopping.
For Meadowvale's master plan, Mr. Langer envisioned those and more, and built them all: Complete head office campuses, recreation facilities, hotels, parks, even a conservation area with two man-made lakes, fishing, nature trails and bicycle paths.
To top it off, housing co-operatives and public housing projects with rents geared to income were mixed in with single-family homes. It was self-contained and architecturally controlled, meaning it was Mr. Langer's company, Markborough Properties Inc., that approved all the buildings in the development.
More than 40 years later, Meadowvale anchors the explosive growth of regions west of Toronto and remains a model for planned communities across North America. The key to its success, Mr. Langer told The Globe and Mail in 1984, was the interrelationship of business parks and residential areas.
"Companies wanted to know that there was a variety of housing types available so that staff could live nearby and even walk to work," he explained. "We created a network of parkland and trails enabling employees to go through the whole community without even crossing a major road."
Friends and family recalled an urbane, well-mannered man with rakish, leading-man looks and loads of quiet charm, but also a stickler for precision.
"He was an honest, sincere, dedicated man," recalled Mississauga's plain-spoken mayor, Hazel McCallion, a long-time friend. "He cared about people. He wasn't just a developer who built houses. He wanted to make sure all the amenities were in the community.
"You always knew you were dealing with a man who meant what he said and said what he meant."
His skills in diplomacy, management and organization were forged in the cauldron of European calamity. He was born in Vienna to a German mother and Czech father, a successful businessman who operated farms and coal mines and died when his son was 19.
As a teenager, Peter attended Viennese balls and belonged to the Austrian Home Guard, a conservative anti-Nazi group. When Austrian chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss was assassinated by Nazi agents in 1934, he served in the funeral honour guard.
But when the Nazis marched into Austria in 1938, Mr. Langer's name appeared on a blacklist. Using his Czech passport, he fled to Prague and from there to Paris. After two attempts, he was admitted to England in time to study agriculture at the University of Reading and anglicize his first name from Hans to Henry.
After only a year at school, war broke out. Mr. Langer signed up for service and was shipped to France with the British Expeditionary Force. But when the Germans broke through at Dunkirk, his unit retreated and he found himself back in England.
Half a world away in her native Toronto, Lillian Patterson had won acclaim for posing, at age 18, for a Coca-Cola poster. (The majestic cliffs and pounding surf behind the leggy pin-up girl holding the bottle were Ontario's Scarborough Bluffs.) A dancer, she went on to perform with the famous Bluebell Girls at the Folies Bergère in Paris.
Later recruited by ENSA (Entertainments National Service Association), she too was deposited in England by the war's twists and turns, and when Mr. Langer saw her perform in Wales, he quickly arranged an introduction. Six months later, in September, 1941, they were married.
With his bride doing classified photographic intelligence work at Canada House in London, Mr. Langer returned to soldiering and by 1943, was a lieutenant in Algiers. From there, he was made commandant of an Italian prisoner of war camp.
Serving under the U.S. 5th Army, he landed in Italy, where, by now a captain with proven skills in managing large situations, he was put in charge of hiring civilian labour. Within a year, 50,000 locals had been recruited to renovate factories and produce war materiel for the U.S. and Britain.
His negotiation skills were tested when Italy sought to conscript the workers into its own armed forces.
"I ended up trying to make peace between the chiefs of staff of the Italian army, navy and air force on one side, and the U.S. and Britain on the other," Mr. Langer told the Mississauga News in a 1986 profile.
Eventually, he was placed in charge of all civilian labour in northern Italy before being discharged from the British Army in 1946 with the rank of major. That same year, he and a growing family crossed the Atlantic on a banana boat to Canada.
Settling in east Toronto, Mr. Langer answered a newspaper ad in 1947 for A.W. Farlinger Real Estate, which specialized in industrial and commercial spaces. Within three years, he was general manager, and four years after that, a full partner with his name on the door. Farlinger and Langer branched out into residential developments and built the first air-conditioned office building in Toronto, at 801 Bay St.
He joined A.E. LePage as vice-president in 1960. Five years later, he, his boss and an associate formed Markborough Properties for the sole purpose of developing Meadowvale. The company went public a year later and Mr. Langer never looked back. "At first, builders would laugh at me," he recalled. They probably stopped laughing when Meadowvale became part of Mississauga and would go on to attract 600 companies. Once, while surveying the development from a helicopter, Mr. Langer spied a dimple in the landscape - a perfect spot for a lake, he thought. The five-hectare Lake Aquitaine was born.
Markborough became one of Canada's leading developers, with a hand in office buildings, hotels, industrial parks, shopping centres and planned communities across the country, in several U.S. states and in London, England.
In 1973, the company successfully fought off a fierce takeover bid from Campeau Corp. in Ottawa by bringing in the Hudson's Bay Co. as a competitive bidder. In 1978, Markborough became a wholly owned subsidiary of HBC.
When it was formed, the company had assets of $15-million. By the time Mr. Langer retired in 1986, it was worth about $3-billion. Together with the late Marco Muzzo of Erin Mills Developments and Bruce McLaughlin, who built much of Mississauga's city core, Mr. Langer became known as one of the city's big three developers.
His close work with governments resulted in a motto: "We have government interference but not enough government involvement." His own involvement was extensive: He served as president of the Toronto Real Estate Board, where he put in place new procedures on ethics; the Ontario Real Estate Association and Canadian Real Estate Association, and two terms as president of the Urban Development Institute.
His belief that every Canadian had the right to a decent place to live drew him to the Ontario Housing Corp., where he served for over 10 years; the Metropolitan Toronto Housing Development Corp., the Ontario Seniors Housing Corp. and the Ontario Student Housing Corp.
He made no apologies for being a workaholic. "You either work or you don't make any money," he once said. But it wasn't all toil.
Into his 60s, Mr. Langer drove a 1968 Dodge Charger 440 Hemi muscle car "at somewhat high speeds," his son Paul recalled with a laugh.
And a favourite story revolves around a business trip Mr. Langer made to Berlin around 1956. Teenage girls had surrounded the hotel because the actor William Holden was staying there, but he was unable to make an appearance.
When Mr. Langer walked outside, a colleague remarked loudly, "It doesn't matter. Clark Gable is here instead." Mr. Langer was instantly besieged and happily signed autographs.
H. PETER LANGER
Hans (Henry) Peter Langer was born in Vienna on March 15, 1916 and died in Toronto on Aug. 14, 2009 of natural causes. He was 93. His wife predeceased him in 1995. He leaves children Peter, Paul and Ann, and four grandchildren.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

CHINA'S ECONOMIC RECOVERY / Reading the tea leaves

Author: Hoffman, Andy; Milner, Brian

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/chinas-economic-recovery-reading-tea-leaves/docview/382609956/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The biggest threat facing China's economy is what happens when the funds from the stimulus package and government loans have been exhausted.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=CHINA%27S+ECONOMIC+RECOVERY+%2F+Reading+the+tea+leaves&amp;author=Hoffman%2C+Andy%3BMilner%2C+Brian&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-29&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=CHINA%27S+ECONOMIC+RECOVERY+%2F+Reading+the+tea+leaves&amp;author=Hoffman%2C+Andy%3BMilner%2C+Brian&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-29&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   THE GOOD A 7.9-per-cent growth rate is the envy of the West; stockpiling and infrastructure have driven the global rebound in commodity prices THE BAD Who's buying? Empty wallets in the U.S. and Europe and thrifty Chinese consumers threaten to choke off the comeback THE UGLY When will Beijing stop boosting inefficient state enterprises and open the credit taps to millions of aspiring entrepreneurs?
Investment banker Ken Courtis has his own personal gauge for determining the health of the Chinese economy, and it has nothing to do with often-questionable government statistics, an overheated stock market or soaring purchases of commodities.
If traffic is light enough that he can make it to five or more meetings a day in the usually choked streets of Beijing or Shanghai, and if people can actually fit him into their schedules, he knows business is bad. Conversely, if he can be squeezed into only two meetings a day, it means business is booming.
And these days? "At the moment, you can do three," says Mr. Courtis, a former vice-chairman of Goldman Sachs Asia. It's as good a signal as any that China's economy is on the rebound.
Reading the Chinese tea leaves has become a prerequisite for global business. Every reported statistic is carefully scrutinized, and every blip - whether up, down or sideways - has the ability to move equity, bond and commodity markets around the world. Quite simply, the planet is pinning its hopes of a recovery from the depths of the worst recession since the Dirty Thirties on China being able to sustain its surprisingly boisterous growth of recent months.
Yet no one, least of all the experts, is sure about the true state of the Chinese economy, or whether it has the ability to carry the rest of the world on its coattails.
On paper, China's economy is blowing the doors off the West. Despite sharply falling exports, it grew at an impressive 7.9-per-cent annual clip in the second quarter from a year earlier, according to government data, and a stunning 15 per cent from the first quarter of 2009. There are predictions China will overtake Japan to become the world's second-largest economy by 2010. Five years ago, that didn't seem likely until 2020 at the earliest.
But China's all-star performance comes with a major-league-sized caveat: Official data are notoriously unreliable. Even the most bullish analysts concede the GDP numbers are flawed. That's because the Chinese rely on lower levels of government to collect the data.
Local officials win promotions based on the figures they produce, so they have a strong incentive to exaggerate. Each level is eager to juice the numbers to please those above.
China's National Statistics Bureau recognizes this and typically cuts the tallied figures, which helps explain why, even in the official statistics yearbooks, the provincial and national figures rarely add up.
The official stats also fail to account for the enormous impact of China's burgeoning underground economy, which includes such services as restaurants and an army of small, illegal mining operations.
Such under-the-radar activity accounts for about 20 per cent of China's economy, says Scotia Capital China analyst Na Liu. But it never shows up in the figures of economic output. "It's like a major city in China never goes shopping, according to the GDP," Mr. Liu says.
Alternative indicators
To get a better read on the country's economic health, China watchers are increasingly turning to alternative indicators to supplement the government stats. They're tracking everything from electricity consumption to satellite images from Google Earth to make their calls on the economy.
What they're finding are reasons for equal measures of optimism and concern.
A massive four trillion yuan ($586-billion U.S.) stimulus package has spurred a deluge of domestic infrastructure projects. Looser credit conditions have spawned a record 7.4 trillion yuan in new loans in the first six months of the year - that's nearly a quarter of China's gross domestic product, and well in excess of the government's own target of five trillion yuan in new loans for the entire year.
As much as one-third of this cheap money has flowed straight into speculative investments in real estate, stocks and commodities. And at least another third has gone to shore up struggling businesses in a tough economic environment. But there has been enough government money sloshing around to trigger fresh growth - and to create furious demand for Western commodities, including copper, iron ore and oil.
But the infrastructure spending and access to easy credit will soon come to an end. And that is where things could get dicey for China's economy.
The government's moves have likely exacerbated the overcapacity and inefficiency issues that have plagued some of China's largest state-controlled industries, such as steel making, that have received the lion's share of the new business loans. At the same time, smaller, more dynamic and entrepreneurial businesses, considered vital to China's long-term economic transformation, have been largely shut out of the government's stimulus and lending schemes.
Meanwhile, long-dormant Chinese consumers have sprung to life amid the current economic renaissance. Sales of vehicles and appliances have soared with the help of government rebates. But domestic consumption won't be enough to sustain current domestic growth once the stimulus measures peter out, let alone drive the global economy the way the American consumer did for so many years.
Daniel Rosen, a partner with the Rhodium Group, a New York-based advisory firm, is concerned that the rest of the world has become complacent about China's growth and "too laudatory" about what China has done to contribute to global recovery.
While China has admirably handled the stimulus element of its economic plan, it has failed to address deep-rooted constraints on the domestic economy. The Chinese remain too reliant on exports: "They haven't made the jump to domestic consumption-driven growth yet," Mr. Rosen says.
Trying to decode the signals from China's hulking economy these days is no easy task. There are legitimate reasons to believe that a rebound is under way - but also signs that it may be fragile and unsustainable, once such vital props as unprecedented government spending and extremely loose monetary policy disappear.
COMMODITIES
No sector has benefited more from China's current financial might. China's aggressive purchasing has almost single-handedly driven an incredible rebound in copper prices and helped keep demand for iron ore and oil strong.
Amid the market meltdown last fall, China took advantage of low prices to stockpile copper in anticipation of the need for the metal used to make wire and pipe that would result from the slew of infrastructure projects. The buying also correctly predicted a pickup in housing construction.
"Looking at the commodities can give you a lot of confidence of where the economy is," says Mr. Liu of Scotia Capital, who specializes in tracking Chinese commodity data as a gauge of overall economic health.
Last winter, when much of the world was bearish on China amid economic statistics indicating a major slowdown due to slumping export demand, Mr. Liu turned exceedingly bullish.
"When everybody was so bearish and thought things were going in the toilet, I talked to local people [in China] and I understood that people were buying copper and molybdenum and coking coal. Talking to these people, you were able to understand the tide was changing even though the macro data was still negative," Mr. Liu says.
In the first six months of this year, China's consumption of refined copper jumped 48 per cent or 1.2 million tonnes. Even Chinese pig farmers have been jumping on the stockpiling bandwagon, storing scrap copper in their barns as a speculative investment.
China's massive steel industry has also picked up sharply, driving demand for iron ore and coking coal.
Mr. Rosen of The Rhodium Group agrees that commodities are a "fairly powerful" indicator, in part because the data is reliable. China's demand for foreign commodities can be correlated with export statistics from producing countries.
"There is no way for China to hide the supply and demand for things like iron ore and oil," Mr. Rosen says.
INFRASTRUCTURE
New roads, bridges, tunnels, railways - they're all getting the green light in China right now.
The bulk of China's $586-billion stimulus package is flowing to infrastructure and there's no shortage of projects. Scores of construction plans that had been delayed during the heady days of 2006 and 2007, when the government was actually trying to temper growth, have now been given the go-ahead.
"The stimulus has simply brought the future expenditures to the forefront," says Michael Deng, a China specialist with Canaccord Adams based in Calgary.
"The reason they can ramp up so quickly is because these projects had already been planned, but over a longer period. Now they are accelerating it."
Infrastructure initiatives create jobs, improve the standard of living in underserviced areas and keep China's economy growing. As long as the money keeps flowing, there's almost no end to potential projects to finance because of China's sprawling geography and underdeveloped system of roads and railways.
LENDING
Credit is easy to come by in China today. The record pace of loans has helped prop up struggling businesses and offered consumers and industry the funds needed to expand.
Loosening credit flows is exceedingly simple in China. Under the state-controlled banking system, Beijing doesn't ask banks to lend. It orders them to. So far, the stimulus has not stoked inflation. In fact, Chinese consumer prices have been falling.
The majority of the record 7.4 trillion yuan in debt doled out this year has gone to state-controlled companies instead of more-vibrant private firms that are expanding at a quicker pace.
Critics argue that China's banks are setting themselves up for a wave of bad debt in coming years that could shake confidence in the country's financial institutions. But others believe that most of the debt has been adequately vetted.
"A lot of the feasibility for the new loans was made years ago," says Scotia's Mr. Liu. "In the past few years, the Chinese government was fighting against overheating, so they killed a lot of legitimate investment projects."
Fears of a U.S.-style real estate meltdown driven by easy mortgages are also overblown, argues Mr. Liu. Chinese home buyers generally put down 30 per cent of a property's value. For a second home, they must put down 40 per cent.
THE TREND
Even if one doesn't believe China's economic stats, the trend can still be a friend. Most China watchers say the data is more than accurate enough to show the overall direction of the Chinese economy, and that is all that really matters.
"There is so much data on the Chinese economy today and so much is integrated with the global markets that while the headline statistical releases from Beijing do generate considerable debate about Chinese statistics, by and large people feel they can gauge the general direction of China's economic movement," Rhodium Group's Mr. Rosen says.
OFFICIAL STATISTICS
To put it simply, many of China's statistical indicators can be extremely opaque. Those that aren't, often don't add up. The most recent example came earlier this month, when first-half GDP figures released individually by China's 31 provinces were 10 per cent higher than the data released by the National Bureau of Statistics.
At a time when the world is looking to China as an engine of growth, the inconsistencies have become a continual source of embarrassment to the central government. Most analysts don't rely on the government-issued numbers.
Take the nearly-useless unemployment stats, for example. The Chinese version measures only local employment and completely ignores the vast numbers of migrant workers, who number about 150 million people - nearly five times the population of Canada. Beijing recently announced that nearly all of the more than 20 million migrant workers laid off earlier this year from their factory jobs had managed to find new jobs when they returned home. But the government didn't explain where it got such good news.
Even the Chinese media is doubting the data. China Daily, a state-backed English-language news outlet, quoted a poll recently that said 91 per cent of respondents are skeptical of the government official numbers, up from 79 per cent in 2007.
THE CONSUMER
Chinese shoppers are definitely spending more, with retail sales growth of 15 per cent in the first half of the year. But they remain frugal by Western standards. Chinese household spending as a percentage of GDP is about 35 per cent, half the U.S. level and well below even the Japanese ratio.
The consumer expansion roughly offsets the decline in export earnings, leaving stimulus spending and public sector investment to account for just about all the current growth in the economy. Private sector investment is noticeably absent, as might be expected when the most profitable part of their business, exports to Western consumers, has fallen off a cliff.
Government largesse is not the recipe for sustained consumer-led growth. That task belongs to the private sector and the jobs it is capable of creating, provided it has access to the capital needed to shift away from exports and ramp up production of goods and services targeted at the domestic market.
To replace its reliance on exports, China is going to have to boost household consumption to 50 per cent of GDP, a tall order in any economy. In China, it will require a dramatic shift of capital and resources that could take years.
"They can't turn themselves inside out overnight," says Mr. Courtis, the Hong Kong-based investment banker.
PERSISTENT OVERCAPACITY
The flow of easy credit to inefficient state-backed entities in sectors like steel and cement has been a setback to hopes of purging China's economy of its less-competitive companies. For China's economy to truly mature, more financing must be made available to small and medium-sized businesses and private companies. Instead, 70 per cent of all loans still go to state-owned enterprises.
Chinese officials said this week that they intend to curb overcapacity in steel and cement, which have expanded as a side effect of the stimulus package, the construction boom and easy credit.
These statements, however, exacerbated concerns that China's commodity consumption is slowing, and the so-called restocking process is now largely complete. Chinese steel prices are falling after months of gains. The head of BHP Billiton Ltd., the world's largest mining company, has warned of sluggish Chinese metals demand.
The fear now being voiced in some circles is that any significant Chinese cutback will send shock waves through world commodity markets and cause prices to crash again. China could, in fact, spur another downturn in resource-producing nations such as Brazil, Russia and Canada.
FEAR OF SOCIAL UNREST
The biggest threat facing China's economy is what happens when the funds from the stimulus package and government loans have been exhausted. The fledgling Chinese consumer can't do the heavy lifting for the global economy, which means that Western demand for China's exports will have to come to the rescue. "I would argue we're probably going to be seeing a W-shaped recovery," says Jennifer Richmond, senior China analyst with Stratfor, a global intelligence firm based in Austin, Tex. "Everything that they're doing really isn't long-term. They're still not addressing some of the root issues."
Within the corridors of power in Beijing, the darkest fear is that economic change will bring with it social instability. In the northeastern province of Jilin last month, a mob of steel workers beat an executive to death after he arrived to tell workers their factory was to be privatized in a takeover that would lead to job cuts.
The paramount need to maintain stability at any cost underlies every economic policy move. It explains why, for example, long before the global downturn, Chinese banks were providing cheap credit to anyone promising to employ people, no matter how shaky their business plan. And it is also the reason Chinese authorities have started fretting about asset bubbles.
The last thing Beijing wants is an inflation problem. "It's so hard to manage social stability when you've got inflation," Ms. Richmond says. "When people can't be fed, that's when you've got a problem."

BLOOR AND RUNNYMEDE

Author: Yu, Sydnia

Abstract: "[The street] only has a dozen or so homes," Ms. [Nutan Brown] says. "They rarely come up for sale because of their ... fabulous setting and location."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BLOOR+AND+RUNNYMEDE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-28&amp;spage=G.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 1 Harcroft Rd.
Asking price: $799,000
Selling price: $789,000
Previous selling price: $395,000 (1997)
Taxes: $5,512 (2008)
Lot size: 82 by 56 feet
Days on the market: five
Listing agent: Nutan Brown, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd.; co-op agent, Holly Chandler, Julie Kinnear Team, Royal LePage Real
Estate Services Ltd.
This detached, two-storey house sold quickly mainly based on the wealth of nearby urban conveniences and natural surroundings, agent Nutan Brown says.
The previous owner - like many neighbours - was a long-time resident on the short street, which is close to local eateries, businesses and live theatre along Bloor Street West, as well as nearly 400 acres of parkland.
"[The street] only has a dozen or so homes," Ms. Brown says. "They rarely come up for sale because of their ... fabulous setting and location."
The pie-shaped lot is also set on higher grounds than adjacent homes and filled out with gardens and mature trees.
"You really don't know that you're still in the city, because you're just immersed in these beautiful huge trees ... and you can actually see High Park," the agent says.
"It's so serene and tranquil that you forget that everything you need - like the subway, library and shops - are all within a five-minute walk."
The house was built about 80 years ago with a three-bedroom plan, though two bedrooms were combined to create a large one with access to a deck.
Rounding out the upper level is a second bedroom with his and her closets, and one of two full bathrooms.
Hardwood floors are in most areas, such as the living and dining rooms. The former features a wood-burning fireplace, and the latter was decorated with wainscoting.
The kitchen has a breakfast area and a walkout to the main deck.
Ms. Brown notes that the lower level is "completely above grade" with an extra bedroom, fireside recreation room and office with large windows and a side door to the patio.
Attached to the side of the house is a garage leading out to a private driveway.
Sydnia Yu

Remember shopping on Main Street?

Author: Belford, Terrence

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/remember-shopping-on-main-street/docview/382618933/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We did a lot of surveys and they found that time was one of the most precious things to people in the area," she says. "They wanted to be able to get in, shop and then get out quickly. We couldn't meet that need with a large enclosed regional mall."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Remember+shopping+on+Main+Street%3F&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-25&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Remember+shopping+on+Main+Street%3F&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-25&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Canada's outdoor 'lifestyle malls' aim to evoke the urban retail experience of 50 years ago - but in a deluxe way
Eddy Tarantino and Joseph Santeramo were increasingly concerned about the future. Their Barbuti Fine Men's Clothing had been a great success in Toronto's Bayview Village shopping centre since it opened 25 years ago.
They had a solid list of older repeat customers but the problem was they just were not getting the younger trade, Mr. Tarantino says.
"We needed to do something that put us on the leading edge, something that gave a new image and drew younger customers," he says.
The pair did two things. First they acquired the Hugo Boss line, and second they moved their store a couple of kilometres south and east to a new 1,850-square-foot premises in Toronto's first lifestyle shopping centre - the Shops at Don Mills.
It seems to have worked a treat.
"We now have a lot of walk-in trade," Mr. Santeramo says. "The strategy of being part of a new leading edge concept seems to be working."
New? Leading edge? For Canada, maybe. There is just one other lifestyle shopping centre in Canada - the five-year-old Park Royal Village in Vancouver. But the concept is decades old in the United States, where it spread from such sunny states as California slowly north to such cities as Cleveland and Columbus, Ohio.
In fact, calling it new and leading edge is a misnomer. What developers are doing is turning the clock back half a century to when a city's downtown main street was its hub for retail. The new Shops at Don Mills opened in April on the site of what was Canada's first shopping centre at Don Mills Road and Lawrence Avenue East. It is an attempt to duplicate what Toronto's Yonge Street once was.
It brings back the days when people drove to Yonge Street, parked their cars and walked from store to store, says Anne Morash, vice-president, development, for Cadillac Fairview Corp., which is the Shops at Don Mills' owner.
The centre has 101 stores aimed at the mid- to high-end market offering 450,000 square feet of retail space and a four-storey parking garage with 1,059 spaces. Eventually there will also be 1,300 residential units on the 40-acre site.
But the Shops at Don Mills is not just condos and commerce. There are also parks, water features and those grace notes one might have expected to find in the heart of any town or city.
"What Cadillac Fairview tried to do was re-create a typical downtown experience before those big box stores killed them," says Mary Mowbray, manager of the retail group at real estate broker Colliers International. "And so far it seems to be successful."
Tenants seem pleased. Ask Francis Argouin, marketing manager for Salomon Sports Canada of Markham, Ont. The international, high-end sports and recreation company chose the Shops at Don Mills to launch its first corporately owned store in North America.
Its 2,200-square-foot outlet opened in April. "We have been happy with traffic to date," Mr. Argouin says. "But the real test will be in the fall when people start sticking up for the ski season and buy outerwear."
One of the reasons both Barbuti and Salomon chose the Shops at Don Mills was the demographics of the trading area, they say, which is populated by families in the mid- to upper-income range with a high percentage in the 45-to-55 age group - well-to-do consumers with money to spend. The Shops have attracted other upscale retailers such as Anthropologie, which offers a one-of-a-kind shopping experience for the affluent professional woman.
The old Don Mills Shopping Centre, which was levelled despite protests from the community, had been on the site since 1955. The problem was that the structure was aging, the centre faced strong competition from other malls, and surveys showed that the average age of local residents was 45 but the average age of shoppers was 55, Ms. Morash says.
"We did a lot of surveys and they found that time was one of the most precious things to people in the area," she says. "They wanted to be able to get in, shop and then get out quickly. We couldn't meet that need with a large enclosed regional mall."
Cadillac Fairview looked south of the border for inspiration. But would an outdoor lifestyle mall fly in a city that seems to have but two seasons - winter and road repair?
"We looked for inspiration to Cleveland rather than Scottsdale," Ms. Morash says.
Cleveland, which shares a similar climate to Toronto's, has two lifestyle malls, and both are hugely successful, she says. "Our concern was not with snow affecting shopping traffic but with rain. We are used to shopping in snow and if it snows too much we just don't shop at all - not in enclosed malls or outdoor ones."
To beat the rain, 60 per cent of the Shops at Don Mills storefronts have canopies, and the walkway between the parking garage and the main shopping street is covered.
Ms. Mowbray says that as a retail consultant she would like to see a different mix of housing with perhaps condos on two or three levels above the shops. She also says the retail mix may focus too much on fashion and may not offer enough food alternatives.
"But I definitely think this is the coming wave in shopping centre development," she says.
Ms. Morash says Cadillac Fairview does indeed have others in the planning stages but will not say where they will be or when they might start construction.
"They seem to solve a broad range of problems," she says. While the Shops at Don Mills actually cost more than a regional mall to build - about $20-million - that was because of extras and attention to detail, Ms. Morash says. Future lifestyle centres may cost less.
They are also cheaper to operate and make better use of energy resources - no need to heat or cool large indoor spaces, just the retail outlets themselves.
"Personally I think this is the next wave for retailing," she says.

Dubai's desert theme park suddenly a mirage

Author: Schreck, Adam

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/dubais-desert-theme-park-suddenly-mirage/docview/382615706/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "At this point, it's kind of hard to sell," Bobby Sarkar, a real estate analyst at Al Mal Capital in Dubai, said of the Dubailand project. "Obviously it's not feasible currently."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dubai%27s+desert+theme+park+suddenly+a+mirage&amp;author=Schreck%2C+Adam&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-25&amp;spage=B.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dubai%27s+desert+theme+park+suddenly+a+mirage&amp;author=Schreck%2C+Adam&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-25&amp;spage=B.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Walk through the grand arched entrance of Universal Studios' Dubai theme park, and you step into ... wind-swept desert.
No Hollywood thrill rides, no ticket kiosks, no studio backlots. Even the guard house and the construction office sat empty during a recent visit.
The planned park is part of a vision by Dubai officials to turn a patch of sand on the edge of the Mideast city-state into Dubailand - a vast amusement complex twice the size of Walt Disney World studded with theme parks including Universal Studios, Six Flags and Legoland, along with resorts, the world's biggest shopping mall and the first golf course designed by Tiger Woods.
It is now unclear when or if much of it will ever get built. Dubailand has hit the harsh economic realities of the global downturn, much like the rest of Dubai, which once seemed unstoppable in its drive to build the biggest, the tallest, the most extravagant.
"At this point, it's kind of hard to sell," Bobby Sarkar, a real estate analyst at Al Mal Capital in Dubai, said of the Dubailand project. "Obviously it's not feasible currently."
Dubailand was conceived at a time when cash was readily available and the pint-sized emirate was expanding rapidly, building man-made islands, ever-taller skyscrapers and gleaming luxury housing. Now in the world economic crisis, easy credit has disappeared, and Dubai faces crippling debt and a glut of brand-new real estate. Thousands of foreign workers who flocked here seeking higher-paying jobs are pouring out of the city as layoffs mount.
"Was Dubailand a sound idea? In part yes," said David Camp, director at ERA Aecom, whose consulting firm was involved in early plans for the site. "But it got carried away, like most of Dubai."
Dubailand was launched six years ago as part of the emirate's push to more than double its tourism numbers to 15 million visitors by 2015. The hope was that their dollars, euros and riyals would keep the economy chugging ahead despite the emirate's dearth of oil reserves.
The project sprawls over more than 259 square kilometres of desert - bigger than Orlando, Fla., home of some of the most famous amusement parks in the United States.
A few parts have been built, including a humble outlet mall and a fairground open only during the cool winter months. A sales centre on the outskirts of the site touts what Dubailand is supposed to become, promising dinosaurs and spaceships, Spiderman and Shrek. Two live tigers prowl a glass enclosure next to the reception desk.
But much of what is promised appears to be stalled and running well behind schedule. One of the more extravagant ideas - an artificial snow park housed under a glass dome - has quietly disappeared from the project's website.
Dubailand senior vice-president Mohammed al-Habbai said in a brief written statement that "there is no change to the vision of Dubailand and we can reaffirm that all our projects will be developed and delivered to completion."
He gave no time frame, saying only that the project "was designed as a phased development to be built over a number of years."
Neither Dubailand nor its overall developer Tatweer made officials available for interviews.
The idle appearance of the Universal Studios site suggests it will not open next year as advertised at the sales centre. Universal Studios' parent NBC Universal, a unit of General Electric Co., referred questions to Tatweer, which said only that work was progressing.
Six Flags, the New York-based amusement park chain, said plans for its first Mideast park were "moving forward" but provided no additional information. The company filed for bankruptcy protection in June.
The Tiger Woods-designed golf course will not open as planned this year. Mr. Woods recently told The AP the project is delayed and is "out of my hands."
Dubailand said "consistent progress continues" at the course. Three of the 18 holes are completed, which it said confirms its commitment to the project.
Union Properties, a local company building the world's first Formula One theme park at Dubailand, said in March the racing-themed project would be pushed back a year to 2010 because of a lack of funding. Analysts at Mideast bank EFG-Hermes have speculated the project could be dumped altogether.
The opening of the Legoland park is expected to be pushed back two years from its original 2011 target, said Sally Ann Wilkinson, a spokeswoman for Merlin Entertainments Group, a British amusement park operator that contracted with Tatweer to build the park.
For the international brands, Dubailand must have looked like a great opportunity.
"Around Dubai, and I'm talking about a radius of more than 3,000 miles, there are no major theme parks. Given that, it is a good idea to have a world-class theme park in the Middle East," said former Dubai resident and amusement park enthusiast Stefan Zwanzger, who blogs about the industry at Thethemeparkguy.com. "I'm not sure it makes sense to build 10 or 11 theme parks at about the same time."
The deals were typically structured as licensing agreements that left the international companies with little financial risk, according to regulatory filings and analysts. Partnering companies in effect got paid while gaining a toehold in a part of the world with a booming population and little competition.
But industry observers say the slump could also be a blessing, giving Dubai a chance to rethink its priorities.
"What Dubai thought they'd done was create this everlasting growth market. ... The world was booming. Whatever crazy idea you came up with, people said 'yeah I'll buy it,"' said Mr. Camp, the consultant.

Fugitive from murder charges found dead, RCMP says

Author: O'Neill, Katherine; Colvin, Jill

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/fugitive-murder-charges-found-dead-rcmp-says/docview/382614784/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The tabloid press has feasted on details of the case ever since California law officials disclosed Mr. [Ryan Jenkins], a former VH1 reality-television contestant, was a "person of interest" in Ms. [Jasmine Fiore]'s murder.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fugitive+from+murder+charges+found+dead%2C+RCMP+says&amp;author=O%27Neill%2C+Katherine%3BColvin%2C+Jill&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-24&amp;spage=A.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fugitive+from+murder+charges+found+dead%2C+RCMP+says&amp;author=O%27Neill%2C+Katherine%3BColvin%2C+Jill&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-24&amp;spage=A.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Suicide suspected after body of reality-television contestant discovered in B.C. motel
Ryan Jenkins, the reality-TV contestant accused of killing his model ex-wife and stuffing her into a suitcase, has been found dead of apparent suicide, the RCMP said last night.
Mr. Jenkins's body was found in a room at the Thunderbird Motel in Hope, B.C., Sergeant Duncan Pound of the Mounties' border-integrity unit said from Surrey, B.C.
"At this present time, the investigation into the circumstances of his death is continuing, but preliminary evidence suggests that he took his own life," Sgt. Pound said in a statement.
Adam Curt, 19, a motel employee, discovered the body yesterday afternoon. He said that Mr. Jenkins had checked into the motel on Friday with a woman, but that staff had noticed suspiciously little activity over the weekend.
When he and the motel's manager went to check up on the occupants, they found Mr. Jenkins dead. He had hanged himself from the clothes rack in his closet.
"We opened up the door and there he was hanging by a belt."
He was wearing a blue shirt and blue jeans and looked as though he had been dead for several days, Mr. Curt said.
"It was pretty horrifying," Mr. Curt said. "It was pretty putrid."
Sgt. Pound said the local RCMP detachment responded to a call from motel employees reporting a deceased person early yesterday afternoon. Police would not say how long Mr. Jenkins had been at the motel or how long he had been deceased before his body was found. His identity was confirmed just before 5 p.m.
"Obviously this wasn't the resolution we were hoping for," Sgt. Pound said.
The announcement came just hours after the RCMP confirmed that Mr. Jenkins was, indeed, in Canada.
As early as Wednesday, officials on both sides of the border suspected Mr. Jenkins, a 32-year-old former Calgary resident, had illegally slipped into Canada, possibly by foot from Washington State to British Columbia.
The RCMP, which had received tips about the case as far away as Montreal and Toronto, had issued a Canada-wide arrest warrant for Mr. Jenkins, a real-estate developer and businessman who claimed to be a millionaire.
Mr. Jenkins hadn't been seen by police since he walked into a Los Angeles police station on Aug. 15 and reported his wife, Jasmine Fiore, a former swimsuit model, had gone out to run errands and get her nails done, but then never returned.
Earlier that day, the 28-year-old woman's naked, mutilated and beaten body was found in a dumpster in Buena Park, a city southeast of Los Angeles.
She had been stuffed in large, grey suitcase, and her fingers and teeth had been removed. Police officials were later able to identify Ms. Fiore by tracing the serial numbers on her breast implants. A preliminary coroner's report suggests she was strangled.
The tabloid press has feasted on details of the case ever since California law officials disclosed Mr. Jenkins, a former VH1 reality-television contestant, was a "person of interest" in Ms. Fiore's murder.
Popular gossip website TMZ.com has posted numerous photographs of the couple, who were married in Las Vegas in March after reportedly only knowing each other for two days (Ms. Fiore's mother has told reporters they had a stormy relationship and the marriage was later annulled).
TMZ also posted a video showing Ms. Fiore dancing in a bikini beside a pool earlier this month in Las Vegas. Mr. Jenkins shot the video and is heard saying: "God, I love my life. And I love my wife. ... Luckiest guy in the world, right here."
Last Thursday, Mr. Jenkins was charged with Ms. Fiore's murder.
Orange County District Attorney Tony Rackauckas said Mr. Jenkins was likely armed and has "the financial means to hide anywhere in the world."
With a report from The Canadian Press

Title: Fugitive from murder charges found dead, RCMP says

Publication title: The Globe and Mail; Toronto, Ont.

Pages: A.2

Dolphins' latest acquisitions: glitz, glamour

Author: Battista, Judy

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/dolphins-latest-acquisitions-glitz-glamour/docview/382616312/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "To create an experience for fans to go to a game, an experience the whole family can enjoy, is very important to bringing people out to the games, to make it the place to be. 'I've got to be there.' If you've been to a game recently, there was a lot of apathy."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dolphins%27+latest+acquisitions%3A+glitz%2C+glamour&amp;author=Battista%2C+Judy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-22&amp;spage=S.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dolphins%27+latest+acquisitions%3A+glitz%2C+glamour&amp;author=Battista%2C+Judy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-22&amp;spage=S.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The Miami Dolphins of last season were so devoid of star power that their promotional billboards featured an unsmiling image of a rookie head coach and the greying countenance of a front-office executive. During training camp this month, Bill Parcells, the old-school architect of the Dolphins, patrolled the sideline in polyester shorts.
Parcells may not earn any style points on Ocean Drive, but he was good enough to transform the Dolphins from a one-win team to a division champion last season.
That might have been Extreme Makeover: Gridiron Edition, but this season, as if the entire team had been Photoshopped, the Dolphins are going glam, with a new owner intent on turning them into the NFL's version of the Los Angeles Lakers, boldface-named fans and all.
The Dolphins unveiled their latest rebuilding effort a few weeks ago, not on the practice field, but rather on a fashion runway at an opulent private club best known as the site of a famous celebrity murder. A pop-art star and a rapper were the primary attractions as the sun set over South Beach that night.
A few weeks earlier in a mall, the Dolphins held a news conference that featured a blasting soundtrack and an appearance by Jennifer Lopez. That followed a casting call for singers to be hired by the team, a new team song, and a stadium renamed for a niche beer with a connection to a local icon.
"We have a lot of seats, and it's hard to get people to go to games because there are so many alternatives in these times," said Stephen Ross, the New York real estate developer who recently completed his purchase of the team.
"To create an experience for fans to go to a game, an experience the whole family can enjoy, is very important to bringing people out to the games, to make it the place to be. 'I've got to be there.' If you've been to a game recently, there was a lot of apathy."
Ross grew up in South Florida in the 1970s, during the Dolphins' halcyon days when they played at the Orange Bowl.
Those years remain the gilded era around here - the Don Shula Expressway is a traffic-clogged thoroughfare 37 years after his team completed a perfect season - but almost everything else surrounding the Dolphins has changed. The Orange Bowl was demolished last year, and the Dolphins' stranglehold on a fan's time crumbled long before that. Even in their best years since then, when Dan Marino was playing, the Dolphins struggled to fill every seat.
The things that make South Florida perfect for the Chamber of Commerce - beaches, golf courses, boats and beautiful people - make it tough for ticket sales. The University of Miami Hurricanes football team rarely sells out, even when it is in contention for a national championship. The Florida Marlins baseball team sometimes draws just a few thousand fans.
Former Dolphins owner H. Wayne Huizenga tried to assure success by hiring a conga line of football celebrities: Jimmy Johnson, Nick Saban and Parcells. Ross has moved aggressively to raise the Dolphins' profile by dressing it up in the equivalent of a designer frock.
He has brought in celebrity artists and songwriters: Romero Britto, who was introduced at the news conference at the South Beach mansion where the designer Gianni Versace was killed, will decorate parts of the stadium with his colourful paintings; Jimmy Buffett reworded his hit song Fins for the team, and the stadium has been renamed for the Land Shark beer owned by Buffett's company; and the rappers T-Pain and Pitbull are rewriting the team fight song.
Not everyone is convinced that such theatrics are necessary. Jim Mandich, who played for Shula's Dolphins and is now a local broadcaster, said that on road trips to the Giants, Steelers and Packers, he noticed "no Ferris wheels, no jugglers, no faces getting painted."
The quieter concern is that the cult of celebrity may alienate the Dolphins' dominant cult figure: Parcells. The announcement of the members-only game-day club at Land Shark Stadium mentions special sideline access, the type of thing Parcells would seemingly abhor. Parcells is not talking about any of the new ventures, but he is a fierce protector of the sanctity of his team.
Head coach Tony Sparano, a Parcells protegé, said he, Parcells and the general manager, Jeff Ireland, had been clear about the boundaries of the football team.
"If we win, I might sing," Sparano said.
Ross, with singer Marc Anthony sitting beside him, was quick to note that he was keeping his hands off Parcells's turf.
"I keep saying to people, 'What do you want me to do, start working with Bill Parcells?' " Ross said.
"Then for sure we won't be winning. All we're doing is all on the margins. Owning a football team is about winning. Fans really want to see you winning games."
Credit: New York Times

Room for guests and other treasured things

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/room-guests-other-treasured-things/docview/382615911/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "I think [Eric Drumm] thought this house would be a showcase for his family's antiques and heirlooms," says Mrs. Drumm.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Room+for+guests+and+other+treasured+things&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Room+for+guests+and+other+treasured+things&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 125 KINGSWOOD RD.
WHAT: A detached brick two-storey on a lush ravine setting in the Beaches. The faithfully restored Arts and Crafts-style house has four bedrooms and two bathrooms on a 50 by 130 foot lot.
ASKING PRICE: $1.299-million
TAXES: $7,944.30 (2008)
AGENT: Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd.
(Anne Wouters)
Two large weddings and a surprise 60th birthday party have taken place without a hitch inside this house, whose principal rooms are so generously proportioned that last year 54 people sat down comfortably for a marriage feast within the walls of the main floor living room.
To accommodate their guests, homeowners Jean and Eric Drumm had first stripped the room of all its furniture.
Still, the space sparkled thanks to built-in bookcases made of gleaming gumwood and ornate light fixtures that speak to the home's original Arts and Crafts design.
Faced with glass panel doors dating to 1917, the year the house was built for Clarence Robinson, owner of a luggage business of nearby Queen Street, the bookcases were the reason the couple first bought the house 20 years ago.
Mr. Drumm owns an impressive collection of first editions inherited from his late father, an Anglican minister.
Spanning the fields of English literature, philosophy and early Canadiana, the titles number in the hundreds. When looking for a house, the objective was to find one large enough to contain them, as well as several other prized possessions passed down through the generations on Mr. Drumm's side.
"I think Eric thought this house would be a showcase for his family's antiques and heirlooms," says Mrs. Drumm.
"The rooms were spacious enough to accommodate the large dining room table and hutch that he had inherited from his parents, and the bookcases could hold all his books."
For his part, Mr. Drumm was also taken by the age of the house, as it reminded him of the types of old homes he knew as a child in Hamilton, Ont.
"I think it was the style that appealed to me," he says. "I like older houses, and when I came to Toronto I moved to the Beach because it reminded me of the older style homes that I grew up with."
Mr. Drumm's passion for the past is reflected throughout his home which he and his wife have not only decorated with antiques - among them a family sampler dating to the 1700s - but took pains to restore to its original glory over the last two decades.
As the Drumms tell it, there were only four prior owners during the course of the home's history, with very little previously done in the way of renovations.
"It was very tired looking when we first saw it," says Mrs. Drumm.
"We undertook major renovations of the kitchen and the bathrooms. We also put in new electrical throughout, which meant we also did a lot of plaster restoration."
As well, the couple installed a new energy-efficient furnace, gas and electric fireplaces in the living room and downstairs family room and replaced all the old lead pipes with copper.
On the outside, they undertook extensive repair of a Japanese garden first planted in 1917, installing a wide outdoor staircase that leads to a stone patio on the bottom level, and introducing flowering plants and bushes along with a new sprinkling system.
On the inside, to preserve the home's historic character, they renovated with an eye to keeping most walls in place so as to safeguard cove ceilings that measure almost nine feet in height.
The exception was on the lower level where a small bathroom and adjoining broom closet were joined to make room for a walk-in shower.
The upstairs bathroom they gutted before adding all new fixtures as well as a vanity custom-made to match the home's Arts and Crafts style.
A personal touch was added in the form of a painted mural by local artist Elody Mobley depicting scenes from England's Kew Gardens, orchids and fronds and the Queen's freckled deer included.
