Cool. Casual. Cottage

Author: Brooke, Jeff

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/cool-casual-cottage/docview/382614788/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Mr. [Doug Harrison] and Ms. [Margaret Grottenthaler] were equally pleased. "The one thing we didn't want to compromise on with the architect was that wall of windows," Ms. Grottenthaler says. "I think that's what makes the cottage really unique."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cool.+Casual.+Cottage&amp;author=Brooke%2C+Jeff&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cool.+Casual.+Cottage&amp;author=Brooke%2C+Jeff&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Doug Harrison and Margaret Grottenthaler love their renovated Cabbagetown heritage home. But when they turned their minds to building a summer getaway house, the looks of yesteryear were banished
Doug Harrison and Margaret Grottenthaler own two houses that couldn't be more different. The Toronto couple and their two children live in a Victorian semi in the historic downtown neighbourhood of Cabbagetown. They've faithfully restored the towering but narrow row house, decorating it with furniture, accessories and architectural details that summon the grandeur and formality of 19th-century living.
Meanwhile, the family's summer home in Port Elgin, Ont., is a beach house with an unabashedly modern style, open concept, and West Coast feel. The sprawling cottage on Lake Huron, for instance, has a back wall that is entirely composed of floor-to-ceiling windows. Standing in the cottage's two-storey great room, gazing toward the beach and lake, it's hard not to feel like you're in Malibu, Calif., or Tofino, B.C.
The stark contrast is not lost on Mr. Harrison and Ms. Grottenthaler, two Bay Street lawyers who consciously created polar-opposite living environments to reflect their differing architectural interests - and the different pace of life inside and outside the big city.
"We have this Victorian, so why not go to the opposite extreme and do something that takes advantage of the landscape?" is how Ms. Grottenthaler explains their thinking. "Why not look out at the water? That's why we bought the property."
When the couple bought the property in late 2003, they intended simply to renovate the existing cottage, which sat on cinderblocks, by moving around walls and fixing the plumbing. But a harsh winter caused a stream on their land to swell and run amok. "The stream got diverted and basically flooded under the cottage," Mr. Harrison says. "The cottage was just floating, like in a lake. That summer, everywhere you walked was all spongy. We said, forget it."
The renovation plans quickly turned into demolition-and-rebuilding plans. But even then, the couple didn't have a clear idea what kind of cottage they wanted. Thorough and detail-oriented people, they bought hundreds of dollars worth of books and magazines on cottages, looking for ideas. At first, they favoured the kind of classic saltbox cottages you might find in Cape Cod or other parts of the U.S. Northeast and Eastern Canada: peaked, shingled roof, dormers, tongue-and-groove siding.
Then they met with Toronto interior designer Shelley Kirsch, who had earlier orchestrated the restoration of their Victorian city home, and she suggested a bold alternative. "I thought they were very beautiful," Ms. Kirsch says of the traditional cottages that Mr. Harrison and Ms. Grottenthaler first considered, "but having seen the site, I thought they needed to do something more modern and beach house, with the whole back being windows as opposed to punctuated by windows.
"I wanted the whole thing to have a horizontal quality to it, low-slung, and just generally the aesthetic to be more modern." As well, Ms. Kirsch wanted the couple's cottage experience to be the "absolute antithesis" of their city home life.
Mr. Harrison and Ms. Grottenthaler agreed, changing their search to magazines featuring West Coast architecture. They found some beach-house examples to emulate, and brought in Toronto architect Kevin Downey at Ms. Kirsch's recommendation.
Like Ms. Kirsch, Mr. Downey made the view a priority. He added two metres of fill beneath the cottage to raise it higher, thus giving anyone in the house an elevated and unimpeded view to the lake. "We had a simple mandate," Mr. Downey says. "We wanted to be bright and airy and informal and inviting, and we wanted to focus on the view."
The cottage was Mr. Downey's first experience creating a summer home, and he was pleased with the results. "It's a place I'd love to have myself."
Mr. Harrison and Ms. Grottenthaler were equally pleased. "The one thing we didn't want to compromise on with the architect was that wall of windows," Ms. Grottenthaler says. "I think that's what makes the cottage really unique."
The cottage is unlike any of the others located along a quiet, dead-end street that fronts the lake, and strikes a balance between being luxuriously appointed and casual in its vibe.
The bulk of the floor space is a 40-foot-by-20-foot space that contains the kitchen, dining room and lounge area. The scale is immense. The ceiling, finished in pine strips, soars more than 20 feet. The table in the dining room seats up to 14; a tangerine-orange sectional sofa can accommodate a couple of families.
The floor is, mostly, polished concrete throughout, with radiant heating beneath. Floor-to-ceiling built-in cabinetry, made of sanded oak, covers most of the interior walls. Even the door handles on the bathrooms and bedrooms are large - industrial in size and quality.
"I really wanted to give them the opposite of what they had in Toronto," Ms. Kirsch reiterates. "Big, wide, unfussy spaces, easy to clean up; broad views, letting the materials and the forms dictate the experience."
The five bedrooms are located at the ends of the great room. Two are on the south end, including the master bedroom, which has a door leading to a backyard patio, hot tub and an outdoor shower. Another two bedrooms, each belonging to one of the couple's grade-school-aged children, are located at the north end.
The fifth is the cottage's jewel.
Used as a guest room, it's on a second floor above the children's rooms, and from the outside bears a quaint resemblance to lighthouses seen along the Lake Huron shoreline. From the inside, meanwhile, it has the feel of a tree house: The windows look directly into a stand of firs growing in the backyard, between the house and the beach.
In total, the house can sleep 13 people - 17 if blowup mattresses and the sofa are put into duty - so it has become a magnet for visitors.
That suits Mr. Harrison and Ms. Grottenthaler just fine. They're very social people, and are fans of dinner parties. Having the cottage gives them more opportunity to spend time with their friends and relatives. "With the cottage, you can invite friends up for the whole weekend," says Ms. Grottenthaler, who has worked out a deal with her law firm to take summers off so that she and the kids can stay in Port Elgin throughout July and August. "We have company up almost every weekend," she says.
The couple recently held a 50th-anniversary party for her parents (everybody fit), and their children have had friends visit, too, for long stretches.
Mr. Harrison adds that the cottage has brought the family even closer together. "All four of us can be in the [Toronto] house and have no awareness of where the others are," he says. "Somebody's on the third floor, in a bedroom, in the kitchen, whereas here, it's one big space. We're together as a family."
The cottage doesn't always bustle, however. Ms. Grottenthaler says there is plenty of time for quieter, individual pursuits such as reading or, in Mr. Harrison's case, tidying up legal work in the cottage's office, which is located off the master bedroom and is equipped with high-speed Internet and other technological amenities.
But the highest-priority activity remains taking in the view. Whether sitting on the beach or in the cottage looking west out onto the lake, you can, as Ms. Kirsch says, be "hypnotized" by the water and the rolling waves that stretch to the horizon.
Extreme weather provides perhaps the most compelling show. "It's pretty dramatic when there are storms coming across the water, building on the horizon," Ms. Grottenthaler says. "You see the lightning marching toward you."
Ms. Kirsch adds that winter provides yet another visual feast. "You feel like you're in Iqaluit," the designer says. "You really feel like you're off the grid somewhere."
Which to Mr. Harrison and Ms. Grottenthaler is the whole point - being somewhere totally different from their 19th-century semi in the heart of the big city.
******
Where the sun sets on Lake Huron
When Toronto lawyer Doug Harrison tells his friends and colleagues he's headed to his cottage in Port Elgin, Ont., for the weekend, he's often asked, "Huh? Where's that?"
The beach town on Lake Huron in western Ontario is unfamiliar to many Torontonians, who are more aware of Muskoka, the Kawarthas or Prince Edward County as cottage destinations. "It's not on the radar," says Mr. Harrison. "It's amazing how many Torontonians don't know about it."
But the days of obscurity for Port Elgin and the neighbouring community of Southampton might not last much longer. "We're starting to notice more people from Toronto coming to the region," local real-estate agent Brad Angel says. "The Kawarthas and places like that have become quite expensive, and people are looking for alternatives."
Prices are lower along Lake Huron, although it's no bargain basement. Lakefront properties start at about $450,000, largely because there is such a tight supply. The area has always been popular with families from London, Guelph and Hamilton, and there's little ownership turnover. Cottages are often handed down through the generations.
If the lure of lower prices isn't enough of a draw, the natural beauty is. Wide, sandy beaches interspersed with rugged outcrops, as well as the vast expanse of Lake Huron, are compelling. "You just cannot get better sunsets than on the Lake Huron shore," says Mr. Angel, the broker of record for Coldwell Banker-The Property Shoppe.
Mr. Harrison's reasons for venturing three hours west of his Toronto home and office are more personal. He grew up in Hamilton, and his wife, Margaret Grottenthaler, is from Guelph.
They spent summers in their youth in and around Southampton, and rented cottages in the area as adults before buying their own land in 2003 and building a modernist beach house. "I think most people gravitate, when they get a cottage, to the area they experienced as children," Ms. Grottenthaler notes.
Port Elgin and Southampton are about a half-hour north of Kincardine, and an hour southwest of Owen Sound. Port Elgin, whose population includes blue-collar workers, white-collar types from the Bruce nuclear plant, and increasingly affluent cottagers, has a main street that's seen several new establishments open over the past couple of years, including a deli, a pair of yuppie-friendly coffee shops, an English pub and a swank Italian restaurant. Southampton has long had enough upscale shops and services to satisfy city folk.
Still, the area is relatively isolated, and Mr. Harrison and Ms. Grottenthaler hope that never changes. They prefer the slow pace and lack of modern trappings. "In Muskoka, you have to be much more industrious," Ms. Grottenthaler says. "You have to boat, you have to swim, you have to fix the dock. Here, you don't have to do anything. You just have to get out your lawn chairs and read a book." For many harried Torontonians, that might be the biggest lure of them all.
Jeff Brooke

BURNHAMTHORPE AND MARTIN GROVE

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/burnhamthorpe-martin-grove/docview/382614528/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Behind the backyard is Glen Park, which is essentially bound by the backyards of other homes. "It's pretty rare," Ms. [Terri Perras] says. "It's a huge green space with a new playground, splash pad and tennis courts."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BURNHAMTHORPE+AND+MARTIN+GROVE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BURNHAMTHORPE+AND+MARTIN+GROVE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 65 Westglen Cres.
Asking price: $919,900
Selling price: $870,000
Previous selling prices:
$460,000 (2007)
$300,000 (2002)
$205,000 (1995)
Taxes: $3,090 (2008)
Lot size: 30 by 145 feet
Days on the market: 31
Listing agent: Terri Perras, Coldwell Banker Terrequity Realty
Toward the end of winter, this 2,500-square-foot house was reduced from $919,900 to $888,000 in order to tempt "price sensitive" house hunters, agent Terri Perras says.
The tactic made the property harder to resist in comparison to 3,500- to 4,000-square-foot residences often built on 50-foot-wide lots within the Etobicoke community.
"It's a good deal for a brand new house in an area where most of the homes are either older bungalows about to be torn down or [new properties worth] over a million," Ms. Perras says. "It filled a nice niche."
Last year, a local builder completed the two-storey plan by expanding on the foundations of the original bungalow on the pie-shaped lot.
The current floor plan includes four bedrooms and four bathrooms, plus a lower-level bedroom and recreation room.
Notable finishes include nine-foot ceilings and pot lights on the main level, hardwood floors throughout, stainless steel kitchen appliances and a tiled laundry room upstairs.
According to Ms. Perras, the most memorable space is the 360-square-foot master suite in a private wing above the double garage, with a five-piece bathroom and his and her closets.
"People loved the size of the master," the agent says. "It was like your own little oasis."
There is a main-floor office and open living and dining area with a gas fireplace flanked by large art niches. Toward the rear is a kitchen and sitting area with a walkout.
"When you walk in the front door, you saw virtually the whole main floor, right through to the backyard," Ms. Perras says. "It had more of an urban feel."
Behind the backyard is Glen Park, which is essentially bound by the backyards of other homes. "It's pretty rare," Ms. Perras says. "It's a huge green space with a new playground, splash pad and tennis courts."

BLOOR AND BATHURST

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bloor-bathurst/docview/382613989/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "[The buyers] just loved the potential, they loved the size and loved the location," Ms. [Nutan Brown] says. "My clients will be converting it into a single-family home with a basement apartment."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BLOOR+AND+BATHURST&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 604 Manning Ave.
Asking price: $559,900
Selling price: $539,000
Previous selling price: $395,000 (2005)
Taxes: $3,654 (2008)
Lot size: 20 by 118 feet
Days on the market: four
Co-op agent: Nutan Brown, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd.
Looking for a renovation project in the Annex, agent Nutan Brown's clients decided this 2½-storey, semi-detached house was a worthy candidate in need of modern updates and decor.
Likely built during the 1920s, the roughly 3,500-square-foot residence was a rooming house comprising five bedrooms, five bathrooms and three kitchens, plus a finished lower level with a separate entrance.
The roofing and windows were recently replaced, but newer mechanical systems and interior finishes were needed.
"[The buyers] just loved the potential, they loved the size and loved the location," Ms. Brown says. "My clients will be converting it into a single-family home with a basement apartment."
The current setup has a main floor powder room and separate living and dining rooms.
An uninsulated sunroom was built off the kitchen. "Being able to just update and renovate it rather than add it is a huge bonus," the agent says.
The second floor houses a full bathroom and three bedrooms, including one with a two-piece bathroom, fireplace and balcony.
On the third floor, there are two bedrooms, a kitchen and bathroom.
The basement contains one bedroom, a full bathroom and kitchen.
At the back of the property, there is a double garage with laneway access. "It has private parking, which is always a premium," Ms. Brown says.
The subway, schools and Christie Pits Park are within walking distance, as well as local performance and movie theatres, shops, restaurants and cafes on Bloor Street.

THIS WEEK / HIGHLIGHTS

In tonight's second-season opener, 19 classmates from the 1988 grad class of Arizona's Chandler high school have been assembled at a swank resort in Kauai.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THIS+WEEK+%2F+HIGHLIGHTS&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=R.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THIS+WEEK+%2F+HIGHLIGHTS&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=R.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FRIDAY
AUGUST 21
COMEDY
Ron James: Quest
for the West
CBC, 8 p.m.
Ron James confirmed his rank as this country's top monologist with this hour-long special from last season. The pride of Glace Bay, N.S., James sets his sights on the western provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan. In his now trademark rapid-fire fashion, he serves up unique observations on the Calgary Stampede, gun control, the Grey Cup and Saskatchewan blizzards. He also delivers what may be the best impression of a prairie gopher ever put on film.
DRAMA
Ugly Betty
ABC, CITY-TV, 9 p.m.
The girl-power series wraps its third season with a two-hour finale rife with guest stars. For fans of the show, the big news is Christopher Gorham, who reprises his role as the bumbling Henry, Betty's former ex-fiancé, who returns at the precise moment that our heroine (America Ferrera) agrees to move in with her new beau, Matt (Daniel Eric Gold). Showing up in cameos as themselves: The View 's Joy Behar and Elisabeth Hasselbeck and tennis legend Billie Jean King.
BIOGRAPHY
Maria Callas: Living and
Dying for Art and Love
PBS, 9:30 p.m.
The tragic life and times of opera diva Maria Callas form the basis of this stellar BBC documentary. Comprised largely of archived performances from the fifties and sixties, the film parallels Callas's life with that of Floria Tosca, the primary figure in the Italian opera Tosca (and not coincidentally, one of Callas's most revered stage roles). The profile asserts that the famed soprano never recovered from her long-time lover Aristotle Onassis's marriage to Jackie Kennedy in 1968. The program includes interviews with several of the grand diva's friends, including Dame Judi Dench, opera impresario Alan Sievewright and filmmaker Franco Zeffirelli.
COMEDY
Becker
SunTV, 11 p.m.
Wander into this show any weeknight for a brief flashback of nineties sitcom nostalgia. Running on CBS from 1998 to 2004, the series starred former Cheers barman Ted Danson as Dr. John Becker, a crotchety medic plying his trade in the Bronx. Stories were split between the title character's medical office and the local coffee shop, which allowed for regular interplay with a handful of quirky support characters. In tonight's outing, Becker is left prone on his kitchen floor when his back goes out. Little-known fact: The show was co-produced by Mad Men creator Matthew Weiner, who also wrote many of the episodes.
******
SATURDAY
AUGUST 22
HISTORY
Ship of Ice
History, 7 p.m.
This program looks back at the icy remains of one of history's oddest naval experiments: the Second World War effort of Geoffrey Pyke, an eccentric but brilliant British engineer who conceived an indestructible ship made entirely of ice. The concept captured the fancy of Winston Churchill and Lord Mountbatten, who realized its advantages as a floating airfield in the frigid Atlantic Ocean. In concert with the Canadian government, the project went forward and a prototype was constructed and tested in Alberta's Patricia Lake.
DRAMA
Without a Trace
CBS, 8 p.m.
Devotees of this sturdy crime-procedural are likely still in mourning since CBS cancelled the show after seven seasons. But the network had to make room for the next generation of crime dramas such as The Bridge and NCIS: Los Angeles . Viewers who stuck with Without a Trace did so for one of two reasons: the lovely Poppy Montgomery as FBI profiler Samantha "Sam" Spade, or Anthony LaPaglia as the gruff and complex unit leader, Jack Malone. Tonight, Jack grudgingly agrees to search for his daughter's missing wastrel boyfriend.
SCIENCE
Guinea Pig
Discovery, 10:30 p.m.
Who is Ryan Stock and why is he doing those terrible things to his body? In the lowbrow vein of MTV's Jackass , this series follows the ex-circus performer as he submits his body to cruel and unusual punishment, presumably in the name of science. Accompanied by his fiancee, Amber Lynn, Stock tours Canada and the U.S. in search of new forms of self-torture. In tonight's show, he touches an arc of artificial lightning, tastes electricity, and dons a metal suit to absorb a million-volt shock. Kids, don't try this at home, or anywhere else.
******
SUNDAY
AUGUST 23
DOCUMENTARY
World's Tallest Woman
TLC, 7 p.m.
Meet Yao Defen, who at 7 foot 8 claims to be the tallest woman on the planet. The 37-year-old suffers from gigantism and the program does little to sensationalize her condition. Born to destitute farmers in China, she reached 6 foot 2 by age 11.Today, Chinese doctors are waiting to see if surgeries and treatments have halted Defen from growing even larger; her rare affliction brings with it heart disease, hypertension and osteopororis. Even though confined to a wheelchair, Defen remains in remarkably good spirits.
DOCUMENTARY
End of Suburbia
TVO, 8 p.m.
Written and directed by Toronto filmmaker Gregory Greene, this doc suggests the suburbs are quickly becoming unsustainable, courtesy of an unstable economy and rising oil prices. The post-war concept of suburban life was, of course, conceived in the era of cheap and plentiful oil; people working in the city could live a pastoral existence courtesy of a daily commute.
MOVIE
Strange Brew
Family, 9 p.m.
Released in 1983, this film was written by Dave Thomas and Rick Moranis, who were briefly lifted to pop-culture fame as the toque-wearing, beer-swilling brothers Bob and Doug McKenzie. Unlike the more recent deplorable cartoon spinoff, Bob & Doug , the movie had a budget, and a plot: An evil brewer (Max Von Sydow) creates a formula enabling him to control the minds of people who drink it. The affable hosers accidentally stumble on the plan and try to foil the madman's goal. Worth watching for the romantic line from Bob (Moranis): "If I didn't have puke breath, I'd kiss you."
DRAMA
Cold Case
CBS, 10 p.m.
Detective Lilly Rush (Kathryn Morris) investigates an unsolved murder from 1958. A young Ivy Leaguer (Johnathan Schaech) came up with the concept to develop affordable housing outside the city. Before the plan came to fruition, the man was murdered. The sudden reappearance of a woman with a connection to the deceased prompts Rush to reopen the case.
******
MONDAY
AUGUST 24
FOOD
Chuck's Day Off
Food Network, 7:30 p.m.
A former advertising executive turned gourmet chef, Chuck Hughes ran several of Montreal's hottest restaurants before opening his own eatery, Garde Manger, in 2006. The heavily tattooed gourmand has since merged the worlds of fine cuisine with his own predilection for the rock-and-roll lifestyle. Tonight's episode finds Hughes slapping together a morning-after breakfast for himself and his good friend, Robert. The menu includes Holy Mackerel Tortillas and a hangover shake known as the Resurrector.
DESIGN
Marriage Under
Construction
HGTV, 9 p.m.
Fascinating and real, this series follows the transition of real-life couple Gillian and Ed out of their cramped condo and into their first real home. The appeal, of course, comes from their contrasting personalities: Gillian is hyper, which seems in keeping with her planned career in real estate; Ed is more laidback and possesses great confidence in his abilities as a home handyman. In this episode, the couple have already found their dream home and are busily renovating the interior when they hit an impasse: Is it wiser to convert the tiny spare room into an office for Ed or a small bedroom for visiting family and friends? DRAMA
Law & Order:
Criminal Intent
NBC, CTV, 9 p.m.
In this rebroadcast from last season, detectives Nichols (Jeff Goldblum) and Wheeler (Julianne Nicholson) unravel a scenario of best intentions gone wrong in New York literary circles. The case involves a prominent poet who panics when private-foundation funding to his poetry journal is cut off. He sends his attractive female assistant and paramour to the foundation president in hopes of reversing the decision, but the young woman is soon found dead on the street. The ensuing investigation reveals a plotline far more sordid than anything penned by Edgar Allan Poe.
BIOGRAPHY
American Masters:
Nat King Cole
PBS, 10 p.m.
Nat King Cole was one of the most beloved performers on TV back in the fifties. The silky-voiced singer was also one of the decade's top-selling artists, though racial tolerance only went so far: When his weekly series The Nat King Cole Show debuted on NBC in 1956, the show aired without a single corporate sponsor; advertisers were afraid that viewers would be offended by an African-American man on television. The program is highlighted by archival clips of the late singer performing his classic hits, including Mona Li sa , Unforgettable and Smile .
******
TUESDAY
AUGUST 25
DRAMA
POWER PLAY
TVtropolis, 7 p.m.
On CTV from 1998 to 2000, Power Play is a great Canadian series that captured the essence of our national game and holds up on second viewing. The show cast Michael Riley (CBC's Being Erica ) as Brett Parker, a smarmy New York sports agent who inherited the post of general manager of fictional NHL franchise the Hamilton Steelheads. Filmed in Hamilton, the cast included Kari Matchett as Parker's corporate nemesis/love interest and Gordon Pinsent as the eccentric team owner. Tonight's episode, second-last in the series, has the Steelheads in the finals.
DRAMA
NCIS
CBS, Global, 8 p.m.
To see how a popular crime drama transitions into a spinoff, watch tonight's NCIS rebroadcast from last season, which sets up this fall's arrival of NCIS: Los Angeles . In the two-part storyline, the unexplained murder of a U.S. Marine takes NCIS stalwarts Gibbs (Mark Harmon) and McGee (Sean Murray) to the L.A. office, where they discover the murder has become a matter of national security. They join forces with special agent Callen, played by Chris O'Donnell, and Hanna, played by LL Cool J, who will reprise the same roles this fall. It's just that easy.
HISTORY
Zero Hour
History, 9 p.m.
The time-capsule series revisits the 1995 terrorist attack on the Tokyo subway. In frightening detail, the program recounts the five co-ordinated attacks releasing deadly sarin gas; a dozen people were killed, more than 50 severely injured, and more than 1,000 passengers had temporary vision problems. The attacks were attributed to a religious cult known as Aleph, which sought to instill the group's founder as the country's new leader.
REALITY
High School Reunion
MuchMoreMusic, 10 p.m.
Running two seasons on the now-defunct network The WB, this entertaining, low-concept reality show focused on graduating classes 10 years later - more than enough time for dreams to be realized or dashed. In tonight's second-season opener, 19 classmates from the 1988 grad class of Arizona's Chandler high school have been assembled at a swank resort in Kauai. Characters include ex-best-friends Heather (The Preacher's Daughter) and Lynette (The Snob), and Kara (The Homecoming Queen) and her ex-husband Tom (The Jock). Makes you feel better about your own high school days.
******
WEDNESDAY
AUGUST 26
BIOGRAPHY
The Achievers
Bravo!, 7 p.m.
The Hollywood profile series revisits the life of Gary Cooper, who created the persona of the strong, silent figure in American cinema. In a career spanning four decades and more than 100 films, Cooper won two best actor Oscars (for Sergeant York and High Noon ), but is perhaps better remembered for his portrayal of baseball legend Lou Gehrig in The Pride of the Yankees and his earnest roles in the Frank Capra-directed films Mr. Deeds Goes to Town and Meet John Doe . The cineaste experts interviewed in the program concur that Cooper was the last of his kind.
DESIGN
Stager Invasion
TLC, 7:30 p.m.
Back for a second season, Stager Invasion is hosted by professional stager Lisa Lynch, a high-energy type with a knack for sprucing up homes that have been on the market for a while. In most episodes, it's amazing to watch how quickly she transforms dowdy homes into residences worthy of a magazine photo spread. The first new episode tackles the case of Rose and her daughter Jennifer, who recently inherited Rose's childhood home. The price was right, but the old place is in dire need of an update. For starters, there's no front lawn and the interior is rife with sixties-era wood panelling. In one short day, Lisa and her staging team perform makeover magic.
Drama
Criminal Minds
CBS, CTV, 9 p.m.
A member of the Behavioral Analysis Unit turns lone wolf in this haunting rebroadcast from last season. The intense Dr. Spencer Reid (Matthew Gray Gubler) reopens the investigation into the murder of a young boy in Las Vegas that occurred years before. As new evidence comes to light, Dr. Reid makes a shocking connection to his own troubled childhood. The episode features a return appearance by the engaging character actress Jane Lynch ( Best in Show , The 40-Year-Old Virgin ) in the role of Reid's unstable mother.
DOCUMENTARY
Ken Burns: National Parks
- America's Best Idea
PBS, 9:30 p.m.
Remain calm, PBS viewers: This is not the full version of Ken Burns's latest documentary opus, but rather a sampler of the six-part series, which begins Sept. 27. Based on this brief glimpse, the 12-hour examination is in keeping with earlier Burns treatises on jazz, baseball and the Civil War. Most of the clips in the teaser are taken from the first episode detailing the origins of America's first national park: The sprawling and majestic landscape known as Yellowstone, which came into existence in 1872 as an act of U.S. Congress.
THURSDAY
AUGUST 27
HISTORY
Killing Hitler PBS, 9 p.m.
By now everyone knows about the failed attempt by Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg to assassinate Adolf Hitler in the late stages of the Second World War - the character was played by Tom Cruise in the feature film Valkyrie - but not many people realize some other German officers kept trying. Taken from historical records, this film chronicles the efforts of a British intelligence officer assigned to devise a plan for Hitler's assassination. Methods considered included sabotaging Hitler's private train and an assault on his refuge in the Bavarian Alps. The best option turned out to be a Polish marksman with no fondness whatsoever for the German leader.
DOCUMENTARY
This Beat Goes On
CBC, 9 p.m.Flashback to the seventies with this well-assembled documentary on Canadian rock music. Narrated by CBC Radio's Jian Ghomeshi, the two-part profile combines very cool archival footage of long-forgotten, homegrown bands - remember grooving to the likes of Prism, Trooper and the Kings? - with present-day reflections from artists who lived through the heady era. Also included are interviews with current Canadian artists like Sam Roberts and Serena Ryder. The second half of the film airs Sept. 3.
DRAMA Law & Order NBC, CTV, 10 p.m.
Newly situated on Thursday nights, the hefty crime procedural - which starts its 20th season next month - has been rebroadcasting some of its best shows from last year. Tonight, an NYPD officer with known money problems is killed by his fellow officers after taking hostages at gunpoint. When detectives Bernard (Anthony Anderson) and Lupo (Jeremy Sisto) dig deeper into the incident, they find valuable stolen memorabilia in the dead man's apartment, along with another dead body. The investigation leads them to the door of a local celebrity who claims to be the illegitimate son of a deceased president.
REALITY Crime 360 A & E, 11 p.m. Most outings in A & E's true-crime series are difficult to sit through, but tonight's show is even nastier than usual. In Cleveland, detectives Entenok and Armelli arrive at the scene of a brutal, senseless shooting that has claimed the lives of two adults and their four young children. The police locate two firearms and gradually piece together what appears to be a home invasion gone bad. Even scarier, the killer is still out there, somewhere.

'Mixed-use' condo to replace 1 Bloor project

Author: Fenlon, Brodie

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mixed-use-condo-replace-1-bloor-project/docview/382612654/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Garth Juriansz of Re/Max Realtron Realty, who also bought for himself at 1 [Bloor] and sold several units to clients, said he'd take his buyers elsewhere if Great Gulf starts anew with "inflated" prices. "It will be a significant mistake to throw all the people out and start again," he said.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Mixed-use%27+condo+to+replace+1+Bloor+project&amp;author=Fenlon%2C+Brodie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=A.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Mixed-use%27+condo+to+replace+1+Bloor+project&amp;author=Fenlon%2C+Brodie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-21&amp;spage=A.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: One of Toronto's largest home builders will start fresh and develop a new mixed-use condominium at the site of the 1 Bloor luxury condo project after buying the property from its cash-strapped developer.
Great Gulf Homes confirmed yesterday it will take ownership of the site from Kazakhstan-based Bazis International Inc. in mid-September, writing a new chapter in a cautionary tale of marketing hype, frenzied sales and the crush of the global credit crisis.
Toronto's real estate world buzzed with word of the sale, as realtors fielded calls from anxious buyers concerned about deposits and the future of the project - once envisioned as Canada's tallest residential building - at the corner of Yonge and Bloor Streets.
"An affiliate of Great Gulf Homes has entered into an agreement to purchase the property and it will be closing mid-September," said Bruce Freeman, executive vice-president of Great Gulf. "We are presently developing plans for a mixed-use project."
He declined to elaborate, saying more details would be released after the deal closes, but The Globe has confirmed the purchase is strictly for the land and does not involve the previous owner's obligations, contracts or design.
In a terse statement, Bazis said all buyer deposits are protected in an escrow account, as required under Ontario's Condominium Act. A spokeswoman said neither she nor Michael Gold, the developer's Canadian president, could comment further because of a confidentiality agreement.
Buyers lined up for days in 2007 when units in the planned 80-storey, $450-million skyscraper first went on the block. About 500 purchasers signed deals ranging from $400,000 to several million dollars. The average buyer has $80,000 to $120,000 invested.
Anna Cass of Royal LePage Your Community Realty was one of 1 Bloor's top sellers, and bought a unit for herself. To guarantee herself a piece of the project, she rented hotel rooms, dressed in disguise and hired students to camp out in the days before it went on sale.
Ms. Cass said people still want the prestigious corner location. She urged Great Gulf to "be fair" and consider 1 Bloor buyers first for its new project.
"If Great Gulf is smart ... they will offer all the agents and their buyers first crack and first discount, at a very good rate," she said.
Great Gulf has been involved in about 10 major condominium projects in the Greater Toronto Area in recent years.
Garth Juriansz of Re/Max Realtron Realty, who also bought for himself at 1 Bloor and sold several units to clients, said he'd take his buyers elsewhere if Great Gulf starts anew with "inflated" prices. "It will be a significant mistake to throw all the people out and start again," he said.
1 Bloor's problems began last fall amid the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis and credit crunch, when Bazis's partner in the land purchase, Lehman Brothers, went bankrupt. Mr. Gold sought new financing partners. In December, 2008, he stopped making payments on a multimillion-dollar loan.
Local lenders bought the loan, then tried to place the project in receivership.
Last month, Mr. Gold agreed to sell the property as part of a court-approved plan to keep it out of receivership.
Gerry Miller, a real estate lawyer and partner at Gardiner Miller Arnold, said it's uncommon in Toronto for a condo project that has been fully conceptualized and well sold to falter suddenly. However, he said he would have steered his own clients away from 1 Bloor. "It was too expensive and unlikely viable ... it was just too big, too grand," he said.

Reality TV star sought in model's death

Author: Wingrove, Josh

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/reality-tv-star-sought-models-death/docview/382622016/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "[Ryan Alexander Jenkins] is [Dan Jenkins]'s son, but he has nothing to do with any of Dan's companies. And he did not work for us," a woman answering the phone at the father's firm said yesterday. "He's got absolutely nothing to do with our company."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Reality+TV+star+sought+in+model%27s+death&amp;author=Wingrove%2C+Josh&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-20&amp;spage=A.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Reality+TV+star+sought+in+model%27s+death&amp;author=Wingrove%2C+Josh&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-20&amp;spage=A.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: L.A. woman's body found in suitcase in trash; she and Calgary man were briefly married
A Calgary real estate agent and reality-TV contestant is being sought by police in Southern California in connection with the death of former swimsuit model Jasmine Fiore, whom he married earlier this year in Las Vegas.
Ms. Fiore was last seen alive on Aug. 13 at a party in San Diego, which she attended with Ryan Alexander Jenkins, 32, her former husband. Nevada records show the pair married in March. The woman's mother, Lisa Lepore, said the marriage was annulled in May, although they later got back together.
Around 7 a.m. on Aug. 14, a body was found in a "very large suitcase" inside a dumpster in Buena Park, Calif., a Los Angeles suburb about 150 kilometres from the scene of the party, Buena Park police Lieutenant Gary Worrall said. The suitcase was found by a man rummaging for recyclables. Preliminary indications are that the victim was strangled.
Later that afternoon, Mr. Jenkins walked into a Los Angeles County Sheriff's office in West Hollywood and reported Ms. Fiore missing.
"He came to the station and provided a picture, gave a report," Lt. Worrall said. Officers called around, eventually connecting the body in the dumpster with the missing woman. "At that point, we were able to put the two together - that their missing was our deceased person."
But Mr. Jenkins had left the sheriff's office by then. Police haven't been able to track him down, and yesterday said the Canadian was a "person of interest" in the model's death.
"At this point, there's nothing we can point to that would make him a suspect in the crime, but he was the last person seen with her while she was alive, he reported her missing subsequent to her death, and we've been unable to contact him, which is suspicious to us," Lt. Worrall said. "We, of course, are concerned that he might go to Canada."
TMZ.com quoted Mr. Jenkins's publicist, who said Mr. Jenkins is "currently speaking to his attorney and will fully co-operate with the police in this matter. He is planning on meeting with them in the near future."
Buena Park police said Mr. Jenkins may have been driving Ms. Fiore's car, possibly with his Alberta licence plates. RCMP in Calgary have been alerted, but won't arrest anyone until a warrant is issued.
With no warrant, Mr. Jenkins would have been free to cross into Canada, RCMP Sergeant Patrick Webb said.
"It all depends on whether the steps have been done yet about if there's a warrant on his arrest," Sgt. Webb said.
In January, 2007, Mr. Jenkins was sentenced to 15 months of probation in Calgary on an assault charge, according to the Alberta Ministry of Justice.
Gossip and celebrity websites were buzzing yesterday with the news that Mr. Jenkins - a contestant on Megan Wants a Millionaire , in which a woman vies for the affections of purportedly wealthy men, in order to become a "trophy wife," and reportedly on I Love Money 3 - was being sought in connection with the death of Ms. Fiore, a former Playboy employee.
TMZ reported that Ms. Fiore sent a crude text message to a former boyfriend the night of her death, and that Mr. Jenkins had won I Love Money 3 and earned $250,000, although the series hasn't aired.
In his profile for Megan Wants a Millionaire , Mr. Jenkins took the nickname Smooth Operator and listed his worth at $2.5-million, and said he turned "player girls" into "princesses" and cheated on a woman only when he wanted to breakup with her.
VH1 yesterday scrapped the remaining episodes of Megan , "given the unfortunate circumstances," a statement said.
In Calgary, Mr. Jenkins's cellphone has been disconnected. Websites for two of the companies he said he was involved with - Concrete Equities and Townscape Developments - are offline. A woman at a third company, a real estate firm, said Mr. Jenkins left in April.
He'd been profiled in a local newspaper when he got into the real estate business, following in the footsteps of his father, Dan Jenkins, a Calgary architect.
"Ryan is Dan's son, but he has nothing to do with any of Dan's companies. And he did not work for us," a woman answering the phone at the father's firm said yesterday. "He's got absolutely nothing to do with our company."
She said the elder Mr. Jenkins was out of the country.
Ms. Lepore said Mr. Jenkins had his eye on making it big in Hollywood when he met her daughter, a former model who did an ad for Howard Stern's radio show.
"He had stars in his eyes," she said. "He was totally jazzed, like, being a star."

The small saviours of Canada's economy

Author: Carmichael, Kevin

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/small-saviours-canadas-economy/docview/382621834/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "If you're not growing, you're dying," says Mark Hanna, president of Leeza Distribution Inc. of Montreal. "If you're going sideways, you're dead," agrees Jeff Lem, president of qdata inc. in Markham, Ont. "If you think you are going to get killed, you get killed," adds Oren Nutik, president of MDS Power Inc. in Montreal.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+small+saviours+of+Canada%27s+economy&amp;author=Carmichael%2C+Kevin&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-18&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+small+saviours+of+Canada%27s+economy&amp;author=Carmichael%2C+Kevin&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-18&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The entrepreneurs who gathered recently in Ottawa are confident they can help lead the country out of the recession
Meet the people who say they will deliver you from recession - or die trying.
"If you're not growing, you're dying," says Mark Hanna, president of Leeza Distribution Inc. of Montreal. "If you're going sideways, you're dead," agrees Jeff Lem, president of qdata inc. in Markham, Ont. "If you think you are going to get killed, you get killed," adds Oren Nutik, president of MDS Power Inc. in Montreal.
None of the three are counting on shrinking, going sideways or getting killed - nor are many of the other 82 entrepreneurs who joined them at a conference in Ottawa last week.
The gathering of mostly Canadian business owners - hosted by the local chapter of the Entrepreneurs Organization, or EO, which has 7,000 members in 28 countries - was a window on a rarely discussed yet significant aspect of the global economy. The smaller businesses these entrepreneurs create and run account for 60 to 80 per cent of the jobs created in the United States, and companies with fewer than 50 employees represent a quarter of Canada's gross domestic product, according to government figures. When politicians go to the local chamber of commerce and extol small business as the backbone of the economy, they aren't blowing smoke.
"We should care about them because companies like that contribute a lot to innovation and job creation," said Becky Reuber, a professor of strategic management at the University of Toronto's Rotman School of Management who studies entrepreneurship and smaller businesses. "They will be very important in leading us out of the recession."
The entrepreneurs who gathered in Ottawa - and whose companies generate annual sales between $1.5-million and $45-million apiece - seem to think so. In co-operation with The Globe and Mail, the conference organizers circulated an informal survey to gauge the mood of participants after a year battling the deepest global contraction since the Second World War.
Most respondents said they believe the worst is over, and expect business to pick up in 2010. Most also said they had discovered new opportunities during the downturn. Asked whether they would start a new business today or wait, most said they would "jump in."
"It's the small and medium-sized businesses that will get us out of this," said Stephen Kearley, president of insurance broker Benson Kearley in Newmarket, Ont.
The optimism evident at the Ottawa gathering was possibly stronger than that shown by other small-business owners. The most recent confidence survey by the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, which represents 105,000 smaller and medium-sized enterprises, produced an index reading of only 58.6 in July, compared with 58.5 in June. A score greater than 50 indicates that owners who expect their performance to be stronger over the next 12 months outnumber those who predict it will be weaker.
"Despite the recent announcement from the Bank of Canada on the economy coming out of recession, SME [small and medium enterprise] confidence has not yet turned the corner," Ted Mallett, the CFIB's chief economist, wrote in the report.
While the slogan of the Ottawa conference was "Changing the World Through EO," the real mantra was voiced by Peter Thomas, founder of the Canadian unit of real estate firm Century 21, in an address that attendees couldn't stop talking about: Recessions are when money is transferred to smart people from dumb people.
The words of the former owner of a company that generated sales of $9-billion energized a group of people whose instincts are telling them they are about to receive healthy transfers from the dumb side of the ledger.
"This whole thing is fun," said Mr. Hanna, even though the recession is causing his sales to "flatten" at about $20-million after years of rapid growth. "It's a strategic game. That's the rush. There are no entrepreneurs inspired by safety."
Mr. Hanna, whose company distributes surface materials for countertops, is planning to move into floors. Mr. Nutik, who generates about $10-million in annual revenue by selling power-generating equipment, has hired a new sales manager to help bolster his presence in Latin America.
Blair Assaly, who runs a real estate company that owns 400 units in Edmonton, said he is "kicking a lot of tires" in Scottsdale, Ariz., where property values have sunk as much as 40 per cent.
Of course, the EO members who convened in Ottawa have felt financial pain. And while they are generally hopeful about their own prospects, some are less certain the broader economy is poised for recovery. "I didn't think [the recession] would last this long," Shelley Whatmore, president of Calgary-based TopFlight Asset Services, which sells refurbished cellphones, computers and other tech gear. Even though her profit is up because consumers are turning to cheaper goods, she is skeptical a rebound is imminent.
Mr. Assaly agreed. "My gut says it's not over yet. ... Until the consumer really starts believing, the recession isn't over."
Mr. Lem, whose qdata earns annual revenue of about $12-million selling software such as bar-coding gear, said he has managed to increase profit - but only through a lot of extra work. "The recession hit harder than we thought and more quickly than we anticipated," he said. He responded by pushing his sales team to try harder to sell qdata's services along with its equipment. The whip cracking is paying off: "We have slightly higher revenue, but we had to work twice as hard to earn that money."

No fuss, no muss, and no busts in Saint John

Author: Mayne, Lori

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/no-fuss-muss-busts-saint-john/docview/382618449/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "I've had so many people say to me, 'Oh, you arrived in Saint John just at the right time,' " says Ms. [Stephanie Turner], who had moved from Moncton.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+fuss%2C+no+muss%2C+and+no+busts+in+Saint+John&amp;author=Mayne%2C+Lori&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-18&amp;spage=B.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+fuss%2C+no+muss%2C+and+no+busts+in+Saint+John&amp;author=Mayne%2C+Lori&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-18&amp;spage=B.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 'Healthy' waterfront city takes it slow and steady, though Irving Oil's plans for a new headquarters could give it a boost
Stephanie Turner expected a blue-collar city when she moved to Saint John three years ago. Instead she found a cosmopolitan community and a career in commercial real estate.
"I've had so many people say to me, 'Oh, you arrived in Saint John just at the right time,' " says Ms. Turner, who had moved from Moncton.
More than 122,000 people live in the greater Saint John area. Home to Canada's largest oil refinery, the New Brunswick port city has been developing into an energy hub and has been diversifying its economy.
It's been bolstered by megaprojects in the area, such as construction of a liquefied natural gas terminal and natural gas pipeline and refurbishment at the Point Lepreau nuclear plant.
Ms. Turner, who works in commercial sales and leasing with Cushman & Wakefield LePage, says the market has been strong in her time in the city.
Observers are also optimistic about potential projects on the horizon: a possible second nuclear reactor at Point Lepreau and a world headquarters for energy giant Irving Oil Ltd. on the Saint John waterfront. A second Irving Oil refinery, though, has been shelved.
The Irving headquarters project would see construction of a new building that could house about 1,000 people. It would also incorporate a cruise ship terminal. The land agreement between the city, local port authority and company must be finalized, and some municipal and federal approvals are needed. The project would bring staff from several offices in Saint John under one roof.
Part of the reason the Saint John commercial market has performed well is because most development doesn't happen on speculation, Bill MacAvoy says.
"The development here has really been based on actual quantified need," explains Mr. MacAvoy, managing director for Atlantic Canada with Cushman & Wakefield LePage in Halifax. "What that leads to is a very balanced market."
Company surveys show the overall office vacancy rate in Saint John dropped to 5.2 per cent for the last quarter of 2008 compared with 8.2 per cent the year before. Mr. MacAvoy says much of the space taken up last year resulted from expansion of existing firms such as Irving Oil and call-centre software provider Genesys Canada.
The economic downturn has affected vacancy, which has since spiked upward: Overall office vacancy reached 10.1 per cent as of the second quarter this year.
Still, Mr. MacAvoy describes 10 per cent or less as a healthy market. He also says much of the space on the market represents subleasing: companies - especially those based outside the city - trying to cut costs by reducing their space and subleasing some of their premises.
This has happened in many major centres, according to a Cushman & Wakefield sublet report early this year. Two of the notable exceptions were Fredericton and Moncton, which did not see a change in sublet space from the last quarter of 2008 to the first quarter of 2009.
Mr. MacAvoy says Saint John has fared well on a relative scale.
"We're not concerned about the health of the Saint John market at all," he says.
The commercial market has also seen growth and diversification in retail. East Point Inc., a retail real-estate development company, has been creating East Point Shopping, an open-air plaza with more of a main street and upscale feel, on the city's east side.
The development has a dozen stores and services as well as a hotel and food outlets. More openings are planned early next year. About 450,000 square feet of building area have been developed with a total of 700,000 expected within about three years.
The centre's president, Troy Northrup, credits megaprojects in the region for boosting the local economy but also points out they could create long-term spinoffs. He says that more energy projects mean more demand for those involved in refurbishment and tune-ups, for example, and more reason for such firms to move to Saint John for good. "I think the future for Saint John is bright," he says.
While the commercial property market hasn't shown great peaks and valleys in more than 35 years, it has been evolving, says Ellis Levine, associate broker with Prudential Summit Real Estate. The economy has diversified into light industrial uses, and the service industry has expanded with IT, call centres and high tech.
With transformation has come higher expectations in terms of office space, Mr. Levine says. "There's been an upgrade in the facilities," he says, explaining tenants increasingly want amenities such as wireless communication, parking nearby and buildings that are really "up to snuff."
He notes as one example the opening last year of Somerset Square, a LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) registered office building. LEED buildings are constructed to rigorous standards overseen by the Canada Green Building Council.
Ms. Turner and Mr. Levine say construction hasn't been plentiful, however. Costs are high and vacancy rates aren't low enough. There have been some creative developments, such as the renovation of a block of heritage buildings into CenterBeam Place in the business district. But Saint John still has a plethora of heritage buildings with empty space on upper floors.
Mr. Levine notes that economic uncertainty has made it tougher for developers to get financing. He says banks used to want developers with tenants on line with five- or 10-year leases, but that's increased in some cases to 15.
Mr. Levine is also disappointed that the largest megaproject on the horizon, a second Irving Oil refinery, has been shelved. He knows of several projects that were set aside following that news.
"It's going to be stagnant until we see a major announcement of investment capital coming in here," he says.
Ms. Turner agrees the second refinery was the biggest project on the horizon.
But she says leasing work has been keeping her busy, with investors, particularly from Western Canada, looking for properties, and growth here tends to happen on a slower scale.
"We're the tortoise," she says.
****

DETROIT IS IN CRISIS... BUT IT HASN'T GIVEN UP

Author: Ibbitson, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/detroit-is-crisis-hasnt-given-up/docview/382618318/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "When you declare bankruptcy, you're saying to parents: 'We can't afford to educate your child,'" he said. It could turn the chronic leak of students out of the Detroit public school system into a flood.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DETROIT+IS+IN+CRISIS...+BUT+IT+HASN%27T+GIVEN+UP&amp;author=Ibbitson%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-18&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DETROIT+IS+IN+CRISIS...+BUT+IT+HASN%27T+GIVEN+UP&amp;author=Ibbitson%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-18&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: After the recession levelled its central industry, the city is forced to start from scratch, shifting gears to diversify its economy
jibbitson@globeandmail.com
28 PER CENT: Are unemployed in Detroit after the auto industry collapse
$350-MILLION: The city's deficit, even though it's not supposed to enter the red
450 HOMICIDES: Expected this year (Detroit's population is 912,000)
200TH PLACE: Out of 200, according to an index of best-performing cities
******
Mayor Dave Bing faced a room of silent anger as he addressed leaders of the roughly 50 unions representing 10,000 municipal workers recently.
Detroit is broke, he declared. It could be forced into the municipal equivalent of bankruptcy in October.
"You are talking about running out of cash in the next 60 to 70 days," he told reporters after the meeting.
"Time is not our friend, it is not our ally. If we go to receivership, all bets are off."
The United States may be emerging from a long and painful recession, but Detroit is mired in the depths of depression. Unemployment stands at 28 per cent. The city government is $350-million (U.S.) in the red on a $3.1-billion annual budget, and revenues for this year are down another $100-million. The city is at the epicentre of a state in crisis. The Michigan government's revenues for this fiscal year are now expected to fall at least $2.7-billion below previous worst-case projections for their $9.8-billion budget.
Unemployment statewide is above 15 per cent, the worst of any state in the country.
And what's bad for Michigan is bad for Ontario. The two economies are intimately intertwined, especially in the auto sector. More than one-quarter of all Canada-U.S. trade crosses the Ambassador Bridge between Windsor and Detroit each day.
But Detroit and Michigan haven't given up. Along the university research corridor - named in hopeful imitation of North Carolina's technology triangle - billions of dollars from government and private foundations are financing research in new technologies at state universities in Detroit, Ann Arbor and Lansing.
The principal focus is on alternative-energy research and, increasingly, on adapting automotive technology to biotechnology.
"Basically, if you can make a hood, you can make an elbow," explains Nancy Cappola, who works with an entrepreneurial development program at Detroit's Wayne State University.
There have been promising advances, there are exciting new startups. Will they employ millions of unemployed auto workers any time soon? No.
But their future is Detroit and Michigan's future.
If they succeed, Michigan can succeed. We don't know if they will. We only know they must.
Going for broke
The financial woes of the city are reflected on its streets. Much of downtown Detroit is a wasteland of vacant buildings and empty sidewalks, surrounded by blocks of boarded-up homes. Many of the people you encounter are homeless, raggedly in search of a handout, or at least a cigarette.
According to the postal service, as of March of this year, 20 per cent of the addresses in Detroit were vacant. In total, that's about 78,000 empty homes, twice as many as in 2005.
The city has the worst crime rate in the United States, according to most surveys. Detroit police are anticipating 450 homicides this year, within a population of 912,000. (The city's population in 1950 was 1.8 million.)
The Milken Institute/Greenstreet Real Estate Partners index of best-performing cities rates the greater Detroit area dead last in a survey of 200 cities, based on economic growth and job creation.
To forestall bankruptcy for Detroit, Mayor Bing wants city workers to accept a 10-per-cent pay cut and plans at least 1,000 layoffs, about 10 per cent of the city's work force. Thus far, none of the unions are bending.
Mr. Bing is also contemplating a broad range of cuts to city services, including discontinuing bus service on Sundays.
"The first thing we've got to do is get our arms around our costs," he maintained.
If bankruptcy were to happen, a receiver would replace the city government. All existing union contracts would be void. The receiver would have the power to cut city services until revenues are in line with expenses.
While police and fire services would likely be protected, public transit, garbage collection, city maintenance, services to the poor and much else would be cut back.
While that might seem a painful but necessary course, the long-term consequences could be even more damaging. As with any bankruptcy, Detroit would have a very hard time raising money through bonds, meaning it would have no funds for future projects such as bridges or sewers.
An excess of success How did things get this bad? The tale, as told by Lyke Thompson, director of the Center for Urban Studies at Wayne State, is familiar: The automobile industry was so successful through much of the 20th century that it suffocated all other economic activity, turning Detroit into a one-industry town.
But that left the government and economy exposed when foreign competition and corporate mismanagement brought down GM and Chrysler.
Now, he maintains, Detroit's and Michigan's future hinges on encouraging emerging entrepreneurs through a co-ordinated municipal, regional and state industrial-investment strategy.
"We have to demonstrate some collective intelligence," he said.
"You're not going to see a blossoming of hundreds of successful entrepreneurs in short order without a coherent strategy to support their investments."
He rejects utterly the notion that the United States or any other advanced economy can abandon manufacturing.
"An economy that stops making things and that relies instead on providing services, from taking in each other's laundry to lending each other money, is a society doomed to impoverishment," he said.
"You have to collectively decide to go after new manufacturing in new ways."
Prof. Thompson sees some evidence of such coherence among governments, universities, medical centres, private foundations and the other potential engines of diversification. "But we still have a long way to go."
The way out
Must Detroit fail? Has it declined too far to ever return to prosperity? The answer, perhaps, can be found across campus, at a new engineering research centre, filled with robotics labs and clean rooms, where researchers are conducting experiments in alternative energy, nano-science and biotechnology.
This despite savage cuts to university budgets from a straitened state government.
"We have a brilliant faculty who are out there in the market ... raising money for the College of Engineering," said Ralph Kummler, dean of Wayne State's College of Engineering.
It can be found at Tech One, housed in a formerly vacant building where the Chevrolet Corvette was designed, but which today incubates 98 entrepreneurial startups, including Asterand, which harvests waste tissues from hospitals and then makes them available for medical and pharmaceutical research.
It can be found at NextEnergy, a non-profit industry accelerator that works with businesses to develop commercially viable alternative-energy products.
Vice-President Joe Biden visited here earlier this month, part of the Obama administration's rollout of $2.4-billion (U.S.) in grants for electric-vehicle research. More than half of that money, $1.3-billion, will flow to Michigan.
Keith Cooley, president and CEO of NextEnergy, is confident that the foundations of a new economy for Detroit and Michigan have already been laid.
"It's going to take a little while to get wound up, but it will," he predicts.
There are even signs of life in the downtown. The Eastern Market thrives with local farmers on weekends. A few developers have taken over abandoned industrial buildings and turned them into loft condos.
According to one study, 83 per cent of new arrivals to Detroit have a college degree or higher.
Michigan remains a global leader in automotive-technology research, with a large pool of highly skilled engineers. The challenge is to use that resource to reinvent America's manufacturing base, and to make sure that enough of the jobs that flow from that reinvention remain in Michigan to restore the state's economy, along with a more confident sense of its future.
"In 10 years you will see a dramatic renaissance in Michigan's economy, driven by a renewable-energy environment," Keith Cooley at NextEnergy predicts.
Michigan's future, and possibly Ontario's, depends on him being right.
******
EDUCATIONAL BANKRUPTCY
Along with the city, the Detroit Public School system is also considering declaring bankruptcy.
DPS is losing 10 per cent of its student base annually to private schools, charter schools and suburban schools. It is $260-million (U.S.) in debt, and is mired in a corruption scandal. Seven people have been charged with embezzlement and other crimes as part of a continuing police investigation, and prosecutors warn many more charges are to come.
"What did surprise us is how rampant, how overt and how conspicuous and downright bold-faced the corruption is allegedly," Wayne County prosecutor Kym Worthy said at a press conference.
Arne Duncan, the U.S. Secretary of Education, has called Detroit's public schools a "national disgrace."
Earlier this year, Robert Bobb arrived as emergency financial manager, after the state government suspended many of the powers of the school board. So far, Mr. Bobb has closed 29 schools and announced 2,900 layoffs. He wants the Detroit Teachers Federation to accept a range of new measures in order to balance the books and reverse declining enrolment. The current requirement to lay off younger and more enthusiastic teachers while retaining older, underperforming teachers "is a huge issue for us," he said in an interview.
But Keith Johnson, president of the Detroit Teachers Federation, warns that declaring bankruptcy could destroy public education in Detroit.
"When you declare bankruptcy, you're saying to parents: 'We can't afford to educate your child,'" he said. It could turn the chronic leak of students out of the Detroit public school system into a flood.
John Ibbitson
Revision date: Wednesday, August 19, 2009

QUEEN AND LANSDOWNE

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/queen-lansdowne/docview/382628816/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It's a detached [house] ... for the price of what semis go for," she says. "It meant that it was a wider lot, so you get a bigger yard and parking at the back."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=QUEEN+AND+LANSDOWNE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-14&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=QUEEN+AND+LANSDOWNE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-14&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 20 Garden Ave.
Asking price: $499,000
Selling price: $540,000
Previous selling price: $483,000 (2006)
Taxes: $3,800 (2008)
Lot size: 27 by 127 feet
Days on the market: four
Listing agent: Julie Kinnear, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd.
This modest 1½-storey residence drew big crowds looking for an affordable property in a prime area of Roncesvalles Village close to schools, local shops and parks as well as friendly neighbours, agent Julie Kinnear says.
"It's a detached [house] ... for the price of what semis go for," she says. "It meant that it was a wider lot, so you get a bigger yard and parking at the back."
The more than century old Victorian cottage was topped up in the 1980s, so there is now 1,338 square feet of living space, including three bedrooms and two bathrooms.
"It was really meant for a couple or a couple with one kid," Ms. Kinnear says.
Classic details, such as its brick façade, decorative gable and covered porch, are complemented with new roofing and Thermopane windows. "It has great curb appeal," the agent says.
Inside, a new furnace was brought in, the plumbing and wiring were redone, and hardwood floors were recently installed in the second-floor bedrooms.
That includes the master suite, which was designed with dramatic vaulted ceilings and clerestory windows, along with an ensuite bathroom, walk-in closet and walkout to a private sundeck.
On the main level, the foyer is flanked by a guest bedroom and open living room.
Behind the dining room is a kitchen with slate floors and a walkout to a deck, fully fenced backyard and detached garage. Extra kitchen cabinetry, a new gas line and gas stove were added about two years ago.
The 819-square-foot basement contains a laundry area, open recreation room and separate rear exit.
