MADE FOR MOLLY

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/made-molly/docview/382624963/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "There's a lot of cooking and baking going on up here and our kitchens were always small and out of the way," [Molly Thom] says. "I wanted a kitchen where three people could cook because that's the fun - all the chopping and nattering."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=MADE+FOR+MOLLY&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-14&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=MADE+FOR+MOLLY&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-14&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: An award-winning cottage by architects Adam and Katja Thom 'lives lightly' on its rocky Georgian Bay site
In the best Georgian Bay tradition, long-time cottagers are fiercely protective of their secluded chunk of rock. They face down furious storms, dive unflinchingly into chilly water and maintain a rather casual relationship with bathing suits.
The Thom family embraces that heritage during summers on a long, slender island comprising slightly less than three acres of granite not far from Pointe au Baril.
Molly's Cabin, as the cottage has come to be known, measures approximately 1,000 square feet. It blends the customs of an old Georgian Bay camp with the ideals of a spare, modern dwelling.
Molly Thom spent a recent morning baking a pie of hand-picked blueberries as friends, grandkids and pets created a blur of activity inside and out. When a couple of fishermen motor by offshore, everyone pauses to stare.
"That's what happens when you're used to having the whole place to yourself," says Molly's son and co-designer of the cottage, Adam Thom.
Adam and wife Katja Aga Sachse Thom are the principals of Toronto-based architectural firm Agathom Co. The husband and wife team met while both were students at the Southern California Institute of Architecture in Los Angeles.
Their daughters, three-year-old Tilly and 10-month-old May, are spending much of the summer in this recently completed cabin, which is an extension of Thom family custom.
For many years, Molly and her kids spent their summers on Georgian Bay. They rented in different settings before they settled on a 100-year-old classic cottage and she purchased the property.
Renting allowed the family to experience many different parts of the archipelago, Adam says.
"Our favourites were always ... with the big water."
They all loved the old, timeworn cottage but the channel in front was a main thoroughfare for boats, which seemed to become bigger and noisier every year. So after a few years they began the search for a quieter spot.
The family decided on an island so out of the way that they are accustomed to going for days at a time without seeing any people other than each other.
The island has the big water on one side, a series of sheltered lagoons on another, and a wild, beautiful marsh nearby.
When the family purchased the property in 1999, it accommodated four small cottages. Those rundown buildings served for a time while the Thoms analyzed, debated and gradually narrowed their vision toward a shared ideal for a new dwelling.
They were "of a mind" about how to create a convivial cottage, Molly says, but they wrestled with choosing the perfect position.
"We had a hard time siting it," Adam says, explaining that there were advantages to each different scheme.
It was Adam who fixed on the notion of shifting the main cottage to the tip of the island, instead of rebuilding in the middle, where the original sat.
A feeling for how a building sits on the land may partly come from the influence of his father. The late Ron Thom is one of Canada's most acclaimed architects.
Adam has charted his own course in architecture, but as he regards the cabin from afar on a gentle canoe trip around the island, he reflects that he may have absorbed some of that special sense of landscape from his father.
After the family purchased the land, Adam spent three summers on the island before he gave in to a growing conviction that he had found a superior setting to the more obvious location for building.
"First I had to convince Katja," he says, adding that she quickly saw the merits of the new site. It was harder to persuade his mother.
"Molly went kicking and screaming. She had cherished spots already."
Still, she listened to her son, and once they had decided to shift the location to the extreme end of the island, the design presented itself, they all agree.
"The site told us the way the layout would be," Adam says.
In building techniques and dimensions, however, they drew from the local vernacular.
The new location achieves many things: The cottage is bordered by water on three sides. It sits very close to the shore so that light hitting the water is reflected back into the living room and people sitting inside can see and hear the lapping waves. A dramatic piece of granite juts up in front of the living room to provide a sense of shelter from rough weather and a natural screen.
"It kind of nestles you in it," Adam says of the building's position behind the vertical rock face. "Otherwise it's a very, very exposed part of the world."
In fair weather the family slides back the living room's glass windows to create a screened porch.
The location is the right choice, they all agree. Her son was absolutely right, Molly says now.
While the cottage is small, the architects found ways to make it seem as if there is lots of space. Having more than one entrance to the living room, for example, makes that room feel bigger. The flat ledge of granite outside the living room window gives the impression of an extended floor space.
Renting different cottages also allowed them to draw up a list of their most and least favourite features from each property.
"There's a lot of cooking and baking going on up here and our kitchens were always small and out of the way," Molly says. "I wanted a kitchen where three people could cook because that's the fun - all the chopping and nattering."
The cottage has one bedroom with its own exterior door so that an early-rising occupant can slip out for a swim without waking anyone sleeping inside. Guests can also continue the Georgian Bay custom of taking their flashlights and heading off to one of the original sleeping cabins.
Upstairs, a small loft provides an office space that allows the architects to take their work to Georgian Bay.
Molly got her wish for a large kitchen. Outside is a terrace that catches the early sun - just as she had at the previous cottage. She and her friends continue to enjoy the morning ritual of sitting at the picnic table with a selection of cookbooks.
"It was traditional to sit there in your white nightgown and straw hat and drink coffee for all hours while you plan menus," she says.
Their former century cottage also provided a starting point.
"We felt there was so much to be learned from that," Katja says.
For one thing, the oldest cottages were very simply made of wood, with only the most rustic of finishes. There was no drywall and no spa-style bathrooms.
"The inaccessibility really limits the materials you can bring to the site."
Still, the architects note, the cottage is a modern dwelling. The old camp cabins did not have walls made almost entirely of glass.
Katja had the idea of pulling down a corner of the roof to partly enclose the dining room. The design is reminiscent of a tent flap that breaks the wind and anchors the building from the exterior while framing the view of a natural rock garden from the interior.
"The beauty of the landscape can start right at the building. It's not all about bringing the distant view in," she says. "People used to build tents on platforms, so it's still part of the vernacular."
Inside, the wood walls and floors are made from reclaimed barn boards.
The cottage is off the electrical grid, with light, heat and tap water coming from a combination of solar energy, lanterns, propane lamps and a wood stove.
An outhouse has a composting toilet, which means the island doesn't need a costly and destructive septic bed.
The exterior of the cottage is built of Ontario white cedar.
"It's going silver as intended," Adam says.
The Ontario Association of Architects awarded Molly's Cabin with a design excellence award for 2009.
"The cottage represents the legacy of the simple little shed in an isolated island community but with a more exuberant, expressive form," the jury said in making the award. "It lives lightly on this site."
Eventually the younger generation will take over the cottage. Adam says that plan also figured into the design because he and Katja had to anticipate how their use of the island will evolve in years to come.
"I kind of felt this weird pressure for my future self," Adam says.
The youngest members of the family are already well-immersed in cottage ways. While May plays on the terrace, Tilly scampers across the rocks and paddles in the shallow water.
Katja says her daughter will start swimming lessons in the fall in preparation for many summers to come. Last year, her mother says, Tilly talked about the cottage all winter long.
"The people who love the cottage most are Tilly and her Granny."

THE BIG BUCKS ARE BACK

Author: Gold, Kerry

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/big-bucks-are-back/docview/382623268/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "There has been a correction," says Mr. [Jamie MacDougall]. "Between October and February I'd say is when the correction happened, and since then there have been significant sales. Depending on where you are looking, whether it's Shaughnessy or Point Grey or waterfront in West Vancouver, I'd say [a correction of] 10 to 15 per cent."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THE+BIG+BUCKS+ARE+BACK&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-14&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THE+BIG+BUCKS+ARE+BACK&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-14&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: After the 'correction,' the high-end market marches on. Kerry Gold reports
With the recent sale of the $6-million home once owned by former NHL player Russ Courtnall, realtors in the niche luxury market have hope that their market is rebounding.
The 9,560 sq. ft. home at 3120 Humber Road is located in Victoria's tony Uplands neighbourhood and features a 1,500-bottle wine cellar, movie theatre, seven bedrooms, eight bathrooms and five fireplaces. When the Courtnalls hosted the Courtnall Classic golf tournament to raise money for mental health care, their guests at the house included celebrities Kiefer Sutherland, Wayne Gretzsky and Pamela Anderson.
Both Russ and Geoff Courtnall have contributed to the renewed confidence in the luxury end of the Victoria market. A Victoria home once owned by former NHL player Geoff Courtnall sold previously in a private sale for $6.5 million, making it the highest price paid for a home in the Greater Victoria area so far this year.
"Everything seems to be selling better these last two months on the island here," says Scott Piercy, who opened the Sotheby's real estate office with fellow realtor James LeBlanc two years ago. "The change has come -- people are optimistic."
Because of its temperate climate and ocean views, Victoria is one of Canada's most desirable places to live, especially for retirees. Last year Sotheby's in Victoria sold 77 waterfront properties; this year, the luxury real estate agency sold 82.
"This year is our best year, without a doubt," says Mr. Piercy.
While international buyers continue as usual to scope the market, the purchasers have been mostly local, he adds.
In Vancouver, Sotheby's realtor Jamie MacDougall says sales have also picked up, despite the usually slow summer months.
"There has been a correction," says Mr. MacDougall. "Between October and February I'd say is when the correction happened, and since then there have been significant sales. Depending on where you are looking, whether it's Shaughnessy or Point Grey or waterfront in West Vancouver, I'd say [a correction of] 10 to 15 per cent."
The motivation to buy is a combination of low interest rates (a five-year fixed rate could be had for 3.69 per cent a month ago) and, compared to prices at the height of the market, there are deals to be had.
As an example of the type of deal out there, Mr. MacDougall says a West Vancouver house that was on the market for $5.8 million a year ago recently sold for $4.9 million. Geoff Courtnall's home may have sold for $6.5 million, but it was assessed at $7.2 million, making it a relative bargain.
Developers of high-end properties have had to adjust to the slowdown over the last year, but Victoria's multiple award-winning Abstract Developments has recently sold two of its luxury Edgecliffe Estate properties. The houses are priced between $2.5 million and $3.5 million and belong to the first new subdivision in the expensive seaside Oak Bay area in a decade, says Marketing director Todd MacKenzie. He says the company has evolved into building custom homes for clients rather than focusing on speculative properties, because there is less risk. With a custom home, typically the consumer has their own financing in place.
Abstract continues to develop high-end speculative properties, however. Its 16-unit West Coast style Terra Verde townhome development within walking distance of downtown Victoria is under construction, and there have been four pre-sales so far.
"There is some improvement in the $800,000 to $1.5 million market," says Mr. MacKenzie. "Why? Because rates are at an all-time low. And you probably have seen a 10 per cent correction in the prices of homes. People are starting to realize that it has hit bottom where we are."
Other than the correction to land prices, labour is also less costly than it was during the boom, making it possible for developers to adjust prices. And when a market corrects, it's always a better deal to move up, which is what savvy buyers already know. It's a matter of simple mathematics.
"When the market corrects 10 to 15 per cent, if you are moving up, you have won," says Mr. MacKenzie. "Because if you are selling a $1 million house and it's dropped to $900,000, and then you buy a $2 million house that you got for $1.8 million, you just made $100,000.
"For people moving up, this can be to their advantage."

'In Canada there is justice'

Author: Mickleburgh, Rod

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/canada-there-is-justice/docview/382611190/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Her parents are getting old," said Mr. [Lai Changxing]. "I don't want to talk any more about it, but she is innocent. She is only a housewife. Hers was just one of the names I put on the papers you have to submit when you form a company. Even though we are divorced, I still miss her. I don't know if we will ever see each other again."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27In+Canada+there+is+justice%27&amp;author=Mickleburgh%2C+Rod&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-12&amp;spage=A.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27In+Canada+there+is+justice%27&amp;author=Mickleburgh%2C+Rod&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-12&amp;spage=A.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Chinese fugitive says there is simply no chance of obtaining a fair trial in China
The short, stocky, former high-rolling peasant, cited by many as a major factor in this country's prickly relations with the People's Republic of China, says he would have been executed long ago if he had not managed to flee to Canada.
In a wide-ranging, no-holds-barred interview with The Globe and Mail this week, his first since news emerged of his ex-wife's return to China, China's most wanted fugitive admitted skirting the law by using loopholes to avoid paying taxes.
But Lai Changxing said there was simply no chance of obtaining a fair trial in China, where authorities accuse him of masterminding one of the largest Chinese smuggling operations in the last 50 years.
"In China, once the government presumes you are guilty, they arrest you, and that's it," said Mr. Lai, on the eve of the 10th anniversary of his dramatic flight to Vancouver with his then-wife and three teenaged children. "If I had not been in Canada, I would be dead by now."
As it is, despite Chinese government assurances that he will not be executed or physically harmed if sent back, Mr. Lai remains here - at least for the time being, thanks to a Federal Court of Appeal ruling that he could face torture back in China.
Mr. Lai claims the extent of his previous wealth and business operations has been exaggerated.
Nonetheless, he was once cock of the walk in the wild, booming city of Xiamen on China's southeast coast, swimming in dough, holding sway over a legendary pleasure palace known as the Red Mansion, and applauded by locals for helping old people and bringing in a professional soccer team.
But according to Mr. Lai, he did little more than many other enterprising private businessman during China's unrestrained economy of the 1990s, a time when Deng Xiaoping famously declared that "to get rich is glorious."
"I just wanted to make money," he said, noting that all the goods he imported were ordinary consumer products. No drugs, no weapons. "They were not harmful to society. But, like everyone else, you want to avoid taxes, if you can. What I did, I believe other people back then were doing as well.
"There were too many loopholes in the Chinese system. Everyone wanted to make lots of money. If there had been no loopholes, I believe I would have paid all those taxes." He added that most of his income came from real-estate developments, not from his lucrative import business.
Regardless of what he did wrong, Mr. Lai said, punishment he would face in China is out of all proportion to what took place. Nine alleged accomplices have already been executed, a fact that weighs heavily on the 51-year-old former millionaire with a Grade 4 education.
"They were not guilty. They had nothing to do with me. But the Chinese government said they were involved, so they had no chance. So many victims, so many families destroyed. Can you imagine?"
Mr. Lai's own family has been affected. Several members were jailed over their association with Mr. Lai. His older brother died in custody. And his mother-in-law was sentenced to two years in prison for sending 300,000 Hong Kong dollars to her three grandchildren in Vancouver, while Mr. Lai and his wife were being held at a remand centre.
Mr. Lai said he would gladly stand trial in Canada, where he can present his side of the case and, if found guilty, expect punishment along the lines of paying back taxes, a large fine, and maybe some time in jail.
In China, however, he was declared guilty long ago, with then-premier Zhu Rongji saying he should be executed three times over. Human-rights advocates have consistently decried the lack of accountability in China's judicial system. A report last year by the U.S. State Department said Chinese courts are particularly biased "in high-profile or politically sensitive cases."
Mr. Lai's continued presence in Canada is often cited by Chinese officials as an obstacle in the establishment of better relations between the two countries.
In an unexpected twist to the case, Ms. Lai's former wife and mother of their children, Tsang Mingna, recently went back on her own to China with the couple's 23-year-old daughter. Their two sons are still in Vancouver. Ms. Tsang had been charged as a co-conspirator with her husband. Her status now is unclear.
"Her parents are getting old," said Mr. Lai. "I don't want to talk any more about it, but she is innocent. She is only a housewife. Hers was just one of the names I put on the papers you have to submit when you form a company. Even though we are divorced, I still miss her. I don't know if we will ever see each other again."
These days, Mr. Lai's life is far removed from the good times in Xiamen. China has confiscated most of his money and possessions. He now lives a relatively bare-bones existence in a non-descript Vancouver apartment, surviving with the help of friends and some real-estate consulting. But he's alive.
"I miss my hometown, but I've been here 10 years. I'm used to it now. In Canada, there is justice."
He does not believe Chinese assurances that he will be allowed to serve out a long term in prison without harm. For the first year or two, because of media attention, nothing is likely to happen, Mr. Lai said. "But after that, I'll be gone. When I die, no one will really know."
In the meantime, now that he has a Canadian work permit, Mr. Lai says he is looking forward to, of all things, paying taxes. "Of course I will pay them. I will be very glad to pay taxes in Canada."

____________________________________________________________

Ambition gave way to a harsh reality: Pearce, Zafirovski

Author: Avery, Simon; Pitts, Gordon

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ambition-gave-way-harsh-reality-pearce-zafirovski/docview/382623684/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Nortel agreed to a settlement of nearly $2.5-billion (U.S.) - betting that the settlement would clear the way for Nortel's renewal. But several external forces began to play. The settlements left the company with "an extremely delicate and imperilled balance sheet" as the world economy tanked and the global credit market seized up. "The settlement put the company on the brink," Mr. [Harry Pearce] said.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ambition+gave+way+to+a+harsh+reality%3A+Pearce%2C+Zafirovski&amp;author=Avery%2C+Simon%3BPitts%2C+Gordon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-11&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ambition+gave+way+to+a+harsh+reality%3A+Pearce%2C+Zafirovski&amp;author=Avery%2C+Simon%3BPitts%2C+Gordon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-11&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The departure of Nortel Networks Corp.'s CEO and most of its board marks the effective end of the 124-year-old company. But the remarkable aspect is that Nortel lasted as long as it did, given its rapid descent from national hero to national disgrace.
"I knew when I joined the board it was high-risk," said Harry Pearce, who stepped down as chairman yesterday after four years as a Nortel director. The litigation lawyer - a former chairman of Hughes Electronics and a former vice-chairman of General Motors - said he was under no illusions when he came on board in January, 2005, after a major accounting scandal had pushed Nortel close to the brink.
"I knew it would produce enormous litigation exposure. I suspected it was going to be extremely expensive to settle all that."
That reflects the feeling within the current Nortel team - that they inherited a mess in terms of a weakened market, an accounting crisis and skeptical investors. The line from both management and board is: We made the best of a bad situation, but external events sealed our fate.
Mike Zafirovski said when he became CEO in 2005 that he felt there was a 30- to 40-per-cent chance Nortel would not survive. "You are not going to be losing market share in everything you have - with a B-minus credit, a weak balance sheet - and say it would be a guaranteed success," he said.
During the current economic crisis, it is common for managers to blame their predicaments on external events. Yet the question remains: Should the current board and management have done more to prepare for those events?
Mr. Zafirovski says he might have pressed harder to raise cash and increase the scale of Nortel so that it could compete with big international rivals. It came close to acquisitions, but the price was always too high, in his opinion.
When the financial meltdown hit global telecom markets last year, Nortel was already exposed. It was "devastating" to file for bankruptcy protection, Mr. Zafirovski said. "We moaned and groaned and said life is unfair. But there is a sense of pulling ourselves up by the bootstraps and saying, 'By God, we would do the best we can with a new set of cards.' "
For Mr. Pearce, that hand was already dangerously weak, including a devastating accounting scandal, that produced multiple financial restatements and the ousting of the company's leadership in 2004. It damaged Nortel's reputation, sapped management resources and left the company with a bill that was to prove too expensive for the coming environment, he said.
In early 2006, he and Mr. Zafirovski sat before a New York federal judge who had been appointed mediator for the shareholder class actions against the company. "We told him flat out, we had no real defence for these actions," Mr. Pearce said. "The conduct of that senior management team was such that in my professional view we had no defences. So our only defence was affordability. We could only provide the amount of settlement dollars that the company could ultimately afford and still survive."
Nortel agreed to a settlement of nearly $2.5-billion (U.S.) - betting that the settlement would clear the way for Nortel's renewal. But several external forces began to play. The settlements left the company with "an extremely delicate and imperilled balance sheet" as the world economy tanked and the global credit market seized up. "The settlement put the company on the brink," Mr. Pearce said.
At the same time, the communications gear industry started to consolidate into larger, global players, and Nortel realized it needed to grow quickly to compete. It tried unsuccessfully to make several acquisitions.
"We knew we had to grow. So we were simultaneously trying to do deals that made sense as we were trying to get everything in order. We came close to some transactions," he said.
Mr. Pearce and executives won't say which players they pursued, but one company that was widely reported as a target several years ago was Avaya Inc. The New Jersey-based company has since undergone a turnaround of its own and has bid $475-million for Nortel's enterprise unit.
Without a major acquisition, Nortel faced a bleak financial picture. As the economy crashed, the company needed quick access to cash, but then the credit markets froze.
The board was left with no other option but to try to sell an asset quickly.
"We didn't have a lot of time to raise a lot of cash once we understood that government support was unlikely, we didn't have any other alternatives. The credit markets were absolutely non-existent," Mr. Pearce said.
Last September, Nortel decided to put one of three divisions on the block. The metro ethernet networks unit makes optical gear for delivering multimedia content over local broadband networks and was one of the fastest-growing portions of the company.
It was a prized asset and several bids came in quickly, but some outsiders suspected that Nortel was close to filing for creditor protection and they offered less than the board was willing to accept.
The complexity of Nortel's situation made it hard for Ottawa to step in with support when the credit markets froze. But the company did seek assistance unsuccessfully once in creditor protection. "It's hard to fault the government," Mr. Pearce said.
The former chairman praises his fellow directors and especially his CEO for efforts over several extremely tense years. "It's sobering," Mr. Pearce added. "We did our best."
That is Mr. Zafirovski's view, too. After the court protection filing, he said he decided to stay as long as it took to stabilize the business. His departure was set in motion in April-May, he said, when it was decided that there should be a streamlining of management and the board in the third quarter.
About two weeks ago, management, board and the court-appointed monitor agreed there was "some elegance" in announcing the resignations at the same time as second-quarter financial results - which Mr. Zafirovski insists were "remarkable," given the circumstances.
But with Mr. Zafirovski gone, it remains to be seen what will happen to the heart and soul of Nortel, the engineers who develop its intellectual property. The multinational bidders for the Nortel units hope they remain - and Mr. Zafirovski insists this should happen.
"What's in it for brilliant engineers is the opportunity to do what they are doing, possibly on a large scale, in a larger theatre," he insists.
As for Mr. Zafirovski, he could see himself as a CEO again, but nothing has been lined up yet. He is ensured of no further compensation from Nortel. He must join other employees in trying to claim a severance package of, theoretically, two years salary.
But there is one sliver of good news. Mr. Zafirovski, who divided his time between Chicago and Toronto, put his Toronto condominium on the market and it sold in one day - at the list price. "At least there is the good news that the Toronto real estate market is progressing well," he said.
*****
HIGH HOPES
Then (2005):
"I'm convinced Nortel will be
a big winner again."
- Mike Zafirovski, Oct. 17, 2005, at a press conference announcing his appointment as president and CEO of Nortel.
Investors reacted with optimism, bidding Nortel's stock up 5.4 per cent to $4.10 on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
Now (2009):
"I am extremely proud to have been associated with this company. The board members and I came to Nortel because we really believed in the value of Nortel's people and technology. Although solid progress was made in many areas, at the end, the capital structure and legacy costs coupled with the economic downturn proved too difficult to surmount."
- Mike Zafirovski, Aug. 10, 2009, announcing his immediate departure .
Nortel's shares were de-listed in June, making them officially worthless. At their peak they traded at the equivalent of $1,245 a share.
Simon Avery

Leno's new prime-time show is a panicky manoeuvre by NBC

Author: Doyle, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lenos-new-prime-time-show-is-panicky-manoeuvre/docview/382620831/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: [Rick Ludwin] claims to have reams of research showing that viewers want comedy at 10 p.m. It's not clear if they wanted [Jay Leno]'s comedy or a sitcom. It's possible that the research is dubious. Ask Americans if they'd watch Leno at 10 p.m. and many would say "yes," because they know his humour from 17 years on

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Leno%27s+new+prime-time+show+is+a+panicky+manoeuvre+by+NBC&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-08&amp;spage=R.14&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Leno%27s+new+prime-time+show+is+a+panicky+manoeuvre+by+NBC&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-08&amp;spage=R.14&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Jay Leno says he feels good. Says he runs four miles a day and has lost a few pounds. Leno is on the stage, alone, facing several hundred TV critics. He makes a few jokes. Some are good. Some are lame. He's doing what he always does - he tries to charm with his quick wit and make friends by being self-deprecating.
It ain't working. Here's the truth - Jay Leno looks old and his act is tired. He even looks physically tired, showing all of his 59 years. On giant screens on either side of him are photos of Leno grinning, his massive chin prominent, and the makeup covering the lines on his smiling face is all too obvious.
What's absurd in this situation is that, at 59 and after 17 years hosting The Tonight Show , this affable, rather ordinary showbiz veteran is at the centre of a seismic shift in American network television. NBC is banking on Leno to successfully change the paradigm of prime-time TV. He'll host what is, so far, a vaguely defined talk show at 10 p.m. That's a prime-time hour - an hour when most people watch TV dramas. NBC believes it can compete by having Leno make jokes, do stunts and interview celebrities, live, five nights a week, 46 weeks of the year starting Sept. 14. NBC is in fourth place among the four U.S. networks. The Leno venture looks like a panicky, desperate manoeuvre.
To say that there is skepticism about the venture is a massive understatement. The competing networks are beside themselves with glee. It's open season on five hours of prime-time real estate, as CBS and ABC see it. (Fox doesn't air anything at 10 p.m.) NBC has surrendered in the drama wars.
As NBC sees it, mind you, Leno's show will be cheap to produce and the important matter is that he will boost ratings for local news at 11 p.m. For local news programs, NBC is saying Leno is "the hottest hand-off" in television.
This is a new business model in network TV. Even as local news gets fewer viewers, NBC is trying to accommodate local affiliates. Unlike a prime-time drama airing at 10 p.m., Leno's live show cannot earn a second bundle of money, in repeats or with DVD sales. Then there's the possibility of Leno undermining the popularity and profitability of The Tonight Show , which Conan O'Brien hosts now, and which airs 35 minutes after Leno is to close down his joke machine at 11 p.m. Who will stick around for it?
But there's another reason, too, one that's far more mundane and says more about cutthroat network machinations. Before Leno comes on the stage to charm critics, NBC executive Rick Ludwin comes on to explain everything. Or spin it, anyway. Asked if Leno won't undercut The Tonight Show , Ludwin is blunt: "The fact of the matter is had Jay not signed this deal with NBC, he'd be on another network, probably opposite The Tonight Show . And then, of course, we wouldn't have been able to control it, and it wouldn't have been friendly. In this scenario it is friendly."
Ludwin claims to have reams of research showing that viewers want comedy at 10 p.m. It's not clear if they wanted Leno's comedy or a sitcom. It's possible that the research is dubious. Ask Americans if they'd watch Leno at 10 p.m. and many would say "yes," because they know his humour from 17 years on The Tonight Show . It doesn't mean that they'll abandon CSI: Miami when it comes time to choose.
Leno is as cocky as anyone in his position could be. He scoffs at the idea that he's going to change the TV landscape and save NBC. "The network's on its own," he cracked. "Screw them! I'm not here to save them." But the confidence seems half-hearted and, frankly, the format for the show seems half-assed.
Most nights there will only be one guest and sometimes two. He won't sit at a desk. There will be "news correspondents" doing funny bits, just like The Daily Show with Jon Stewart . One correspondent will be NBC Nightly News anchor Brian Williams, known as a joker when off the news beat. Another is comic D.L. Hughley, who had a horrible light-news show on CNN a while back.
Leno is particularly enthusiastic about a recurring comedy routine he calls a "green-car challenge." This will involve celebrities racing electric or hybrid cars. Leno says Tom Cruise has shown interest.
But that's it for ideas and innovations. Comedy correspondents and celebrity car races. Both are old and tired ideas, and that still leaves a lot of time to fill in five hour-long shows a week. Over at CBS, as its executives implied earlier this week, they see NBC's Leno venture as insane. As CBS Entertainment President Nina Tassler said of the network's hot drama The Mentalist , which will compete with Leno: "It generates billions of dollars for us in revenue, between foreign sales, syndication." When you're talking billions, you're talking real money in this racket.
Leno ends his session with a stout declaration: "You know, you put your head down, you move forward and you try something new. And, right now, I would rather be doing this than The Tonight Show because I think this is an interesting challenge. It's more fun. We are doing things we couldn't do under the umbrella of The Tonight Show because it wasn't Tonight Show style."
It's a proud boast, meant sincerely, and Leno already looks fed up with the skepticism and the nagging questions. It's notable that he doesn't close with a joke. Perhaps because there's nothing funny about facing failure head-on.

When it comes to space solutions, one size doesn't fit all

Author: Belford, Terrence

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/when-comes-space-solutions-one-size-doesnt-fit/docview/382612072/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "First-time buyers are too concerned about just making the down payment, mortgage and monthly maintenance fees to worry about storage space," he says. "Besides most of them have yet to accumulate enough stuff to need storage."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=When+it+comes+to+space+solutions%2C+one+size+doesn%27t+fit+all&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-07&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=When+it+comes+to+space+solutions%2C+one+size+doesn%27t+fit+all&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-07&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Anyone who has ever lived in a condo - or an apartment - knows storage poses a challenge. If you live in a house, you just pile stuff away in the basement, the attic or the garage.
With a condo, however, there are none of these handy spaces to set aside things you may need in future or want to save in case someone else does. Where do you put the Christmas tree, the bicycle, the old rowing machine you thought you would use to trim down or the sofa that is still too good to relegate to a landfill?
The options boil down to three: buy a storage locker in your condo building - if any are still available; rent a cubicle in a public self-storage facility; or see if a friend or relative with a house or garage is willing to store your stuff.
I can't help you with the last one. My basement is full - same with my garage. But I can tell you what the experts say about the other two.
First, storage lockers in condo buildings. Five years ago the price of most new condos included both a storage locker and a parking spot. Those days are fast disappearing. Builders today generally sell storage lockers as separate items.
The cost can range from somewhere just north of $100 to $500 a square foot, depending on the project, says Mark Cohen, senior vice-president at the Condo Store Marketing Systems. At the same time, lockers are larger these days then they were five years ago.
"At one point the city demanded they be large enough to store a bicycle," he says. "So size grew from maybe three feet by five feet to four feet by six feet."
What you get is pretty basic, a cubicle walled by chicken wire or chain link fencing, tucked away in a basement level, although in more upscale projects, lockers have been moved to ground level.
"With quite a few new buildings nowadays they are located behind the lobby. The idea is to make them more accessible to cyclists," he says. "You would be surprised how many Bay Street lawyers cycle to work."
You should also know that there are never as many lockers as there are suites. Builders generally create enough for 60 to 70 per cent of the units and they usually don't sell all that quickly, Mr. Cohen says.
"They are eventually absorbed but it can take the resale market to finally sell them out," he says.
Part of the reason they are not hot ticket items is because some buyers, especially first-timers, are already squeezing nickels to cover down payments, closing costs and all the expenses associated with moving in. Laying out another $2,500 to $5,000 has a low priority. It is often only after living in their suite a while they realize it is storage-challenged.
Which brings us to rentals in self-storage facilities. On the plus side, they come in a range of sizes, are usually climate controlled, are open round-the-clock and have state-of-the-art security.
The downside is that they can be expensive if you need a locker on a long-term basis.
At the new Spaces Self Storage on Eastern Avenue just east of Broadview Avenue in Toronto, a five-foot-by-five-foot cubicle costs $69 a month while the largest (10 by 20) goes for $399. The most popular is probably the five-foot-by-10-foot storage unit, which goes for $155 a month, says Stuart Skeete, operations manager.
He says 60 per cent of Spaces' business comes from the residential sector but condos play a relatively small role. His customers are mainly home owners needing a place to store furniture for future use.
"We are, however, increasingly seeing local condo owners taking units for things like golf clubs and other recreational stuff they don't have room to store in their suites," he says.
Those who rent storage units are generally older and better off financially, says Mike Cowie who has three storage operations in the Greater Toronto area, all under the Self Stor banner.
"First-time buyers are too concerned about just making the down payment, mortgage and monthly maintenance fees to worry about storage space," he says. "Besides most of them have yet to accumulate enough stuff to need storage."
He also says that Canadians are less mobile than our counterparts south of the border and while they are great savers of stuff, their preference is to pack it into a basement or garage - theirs or someone else's.
"In the U.S. there is four square feet of commercial storage space for every man, women and child; in Canada there is just one square foot," he says.
Mind you that may change as the men and women who have bought condos in the past decade start the inevitable process of accumulating stuff. Your much loved but tired old couch just will not fit in a condo storage locker.

THIS WEEK / HIGHLIGHTS

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/this-week-highlights/docview/382610854/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Havana Boxing Academy, which has produced more than two dozen gold-medal winners in the past quarter-century. Located in a non-glamorous building on the city's outskirts, the academy begins training at a tender age - as young as nine in some instances - and gradually moulds the young athletes into fierce ring warriors. The champions of the future rise or fall at Cuba's National Boxing Championship - one of the country's biggest annual sporting events - but several coaches are concerned.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THIS+WEEK+%2F+HIGHLIGHTS&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-07&amp;spage=R.18&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THIS+WEEK+%2F+HIGHLIGHTS&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-07&amp;spage=R.18&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   FRIDAY AUGUST 7
DOCUMENTARY
Sharkbite Summer
Discovery, 8 p.m.
For reasons scientists still can't fathom, coastal areas in the U.S. and the Caribbean were plagued by shark attacks in the summer of 2001. TV and news media labelled it "Summer of the Shark" and beach alerts were issued. This report reenacts four of the most horrific incidents, including the story of Krishna Thompson, a Wall Street trader on holiday in the Bahamas who fought an attacking shark and survived. The program steers wide of the usual sensationalism - shark attacks were, in fact, lower than average that summer - but it is still grisly viewing.
REALITY
Jurassic Fight Club
History, 8 p.m.
Much loved by young males and fans of CGI technology, Jurassic Fight Club has become one of the most-watched programs on U.S. cable this year. Each episode features a forensic breakdown of what might transpire should two long-extinct species lock horns. Tonight's match-up pits the lumbering Gastonia - a massive beast covered in spikes -against the Utahraptor, the largest known member of the raptor family. Both prehistoric creatures are vicious fighters, though not without weaknesses: The Gastonia has poor vision, while the Utahraptor moves awkwardly.
MOVIE
Crossroads
MuchMusic, 9 p.m.
One of the lesser cinema highlights of 2002, this feature marked the start and finish of Britney Spears's acting career. Working from a script by Shonda Rhimes - who went on to create Grey's Anatomy - the story focuses on three childhood pals on the brink of graduating from a high school somewhere in Georgia. High-spirited Lucy, played by Spears, is planning for college and a double major in biology and chemistry; Mimi (Taryn Manning) is five months pregnant and aimless; and Kit (Zoe Saldana) intends to marry her boyfriend in California. Out of the blue, Mimi announces she wants to audition for a singing gig in California, which sets off a cross-country road trip. The story is lightweight after-school special fare.
HISTORY
Time Team America
PBS, 10 p.m.
Time Team America takes viewers inside archaeological sites with unanswered questions. Tonight's episode travels to Roanoke Island near the coast of North Carolina. The English sent the first group of colonists to the barren location in 1586, but when the British navy returned with supplies three years later, the settlement was empty. The Time Team America experts spend three days in search of clues and shed new light on where the people went.
***
SATURDAY AUGUST 8
DESIGN
Colin & Justin's Home Heist
HGTV, 7 p.m.
TV's most precocious design duo, Scottish-born Colin McAllister and Justin Ryan, know their stuff. Each episode takes them into a Canadian home in dire need of a design update and neither gent holds back his opinion during the blunt assessment stage. Tonight, the brash pair meet Cathie, a 47-year-old single woman still living in her parents' suburban domicile. The living room resembles a fifties-era hunting lodge, complete with leather curtains and stuffed pheasants. Colin and Justin perform a makeover miracle.
MOVIE
Finding Nemo
ABC, 8 p.m.
Anyone with children under 10 has likely seen this 2003 animated feature, but there's charm in viewing it again. Comic actor Albert Brooks is letter-perfect as the clownfish named Marlin, who loses his son Nemo (Alexander Gould) to a fishing net. Even more adorable is Ellen DeGeneres as Dory, a blue tang with short-term memory loss. Also worth noting is Oscar-winning actor Geoffrey Rush as Nigel the pelican and Willem Dafoe as the hard-edged fish named Gill. A rare mix of great voices, smart writing and brilliant animation.
MYSTERY
The Memoirs of Sherlock Holmes: The Three Gables
PBS, 9 p.m.
First broadcast in 1994, this movie stars the beloved Jeremy Brett as the inscrutable English sleuth. Elderly widow Mary Maberley (Mary Ellis) is being pressured to sell her estate and all her possessions. Her refusal is met with threats. As Watson (David Burke) dithers, Holmes deduces that the buyer is working for a wealthy dowager in search of a hidden manuscript. Based on an original tale by Arthur Conan Doyle, the twists in the story may surprise even the most ardent mystery fan.
***
SUNDAY AUGUST 9
BUSINESS
Inside American Airlines:
A Week in the Life
CNBC, 8 p.m.
Travel expert Peter Greenberg spent one week with a camera crew behind the scenes of American Airlines, which serves two million air travellers a week. He visited the control tower, where air traffic controllers perform the nerve-wracking ballet of instructing planes how and when to set down and take off. Greenberg also sneaks into an American Airlines boardroom and presses execs with a reasonable question: Why do some passengers pay $50 for a flight while others pay ten 10 times that for the seat next to them?
REALITY
Kendra
E!, 10 p.m.
The show follows the daily life of Playboy model Kendra Wilkinson, made famous for fawning over Hugh Hefner in the reality series The Girls Next Door . No less staged, this show follows bubbly Kendra after moving out of the Playboy mansion. Since then she got pregnant and engaged to a football player. On tonight's show, Kendra's mom is shocked to learn of Kendra's pregnancy, and refuses to condone the wedding.
RETRO
Animal House:
The Inside Story
A & E, 10 p.m.
Broadcast last year to commemorate the 30th anniversary of Animal House , this program is worth a second look. Reviled by reviewers, worshipped by the college crowd, Animal House established the frat-boy film genre and elevated Saturday Night Liv e player John Belushi to movie stardom, however fleeting. This retro-special interviews director John Landis and several of the film's stars, including Kevin Bacon and Karen Allen.
BIOGRAPHY
This is ... Victoria Beckham
Star!, 11 p.m.
The fabulous life of Victoria Beckham is explored in this tawdry if entertaining profile. The program touches briefly on her days as a Spice Girl (she was Posh Spice, you may recall) and her subsequent solo singing career, but there are more details on her marriage to soccer star David Beckham. Since their 1999 nuptials, Ms. Beckham has produced her own line of designer jeans, followed by jewellery, handbags, sunglasses and a fragrance called Intimately Beckham.
***
MONDAY AUGUST 10
REALITY
Cribs
MTV, 7 p.m.
An MTV staple since 2000, Cribs has conducted more than 200 tours of celebrity homes. Some of the visits are revealing (the episode showcasing Mariah Carey's New York penthouse was an appalling display of designer excess), while some are clearly orchestrated for the camera (rapper 50 Cent admitted that the three Ferraris in his garage were really loaners). Tonight's show is "All-Canuck," beginning with a tour of bad-boy hockey player Sean Avery's home, followed by visits with Spawn creator Todd McFarlane and former Kids in the Hall member Kevin McDonald. AWARDS
Teen Choice Awards
Global, Fox, 8 p.m.
Be prepared to surrender the converter to teen viewers for two hours tonight. Now in its 11th year, the annual awards fête is hosted by the Jonas Brothers, which will likely result in a spike in ratings. Besides the Jonas boyos, the show is scheduled to include a stage turn from the Black Eyed Peas. As in years past, the broadcast will bestow a dozen or so Teen Choice trophies - which resemble a surfboard - to hot young stars in film and TV. And in a sign of the times, a new category, Choice Twit, will honour the top celebrity Tweeter on Twitter.
DOCUMENTARY
Altered by Elvis
Bravo!, 9 p.m.
The Elvis legend lives on. This offbeat documentary profiles individuals whose lives were changed forever by Elvis Presley and his music. The subjects include a woman named Vicki, who talks about moving from Milwaukee, Wis., to Memphis, Tenn., just to be closer to Presley's aura. The strangest interviewee, though, is Larry Geller, Elvis's former hairstylist, who still seems bound to the past. Geller speaks of Presley in awestruck tones and proudly announces he was one of very few people to touch the King's dead body.
COMEDY
Chris Rock: Kill the
Messenger
HBO Canada, 9:30 p.m.
Chris Rock validates his rank as the best standup in comedy today with this special. Filmed during Rock's 2008 comedy tour, the special merges performances from London, Johannesburg and New York, edited into one seamless show. Pacing back and forth on stage, rarely taking a break, Rock discourses on the possibility of a black president (the show was taped before Obama's presidential victory last November), bottled water, minimum-wage jobs, the absurdity of high gas prices and people with annoying cellphone ringtones. His closing segment, in which he talks about sex between married couples, may be among the most honest assessments of relationships ever made by a comedian.
***
TUESDAY AUGUST 11
MYSTERY
Murder She Wrote
Vision, 7 p.m.
Genteel sleuth Jessica Fletcher, played by Angela Lansbury, tackles one of her most challenging cases in this third-season episode. Jessica comes to the aid of her nephew, Grady (Michael Horton), who's in a bind. Grady is working at a New York accounting firm with a dodgy reputation. One of the owners accused of "cooking the books" turns up dead and police designate Grady as the prime suspect. Jessica discovers that a homeless man known to sneak into the firm's offices in off-hours may have witnessed the murder.
SCIENCE
NOVA
PBS, 8 p.m.
The acclaimed science series looks back at the deadliest accident in aviation history. On March 27, 1977, on the Spanish island of Tenerife, two jumbo jets collided on a fog-enshrouded runway, resulting in the deaths of 583 people. The NOVA experts rewind the clock to several hours before the accident, which seems to have been a result of bad luck. One of the biggest factors in the crash was a terrorist bomb threat earlier that day at a nearby airport, which diverted most air traffic to Tenerife; the understaffed control tower in Tenerife was simply overwhelmed. The program also interviews several survivors and looks at the improvements made to runway safety.
NATURE
Against The Elements
Discovery, 9 p.m.
Originally produced for the U.S. Science Channel, this series runs the gamut of natural disasters - all caught on film. Tonight's show features footage of a spectacular fire at a fireworks factory, followed by scenes of a sailor sucked into an airplane engine and a tsunami wreaking devastation on a small town. The capper: clips of a skier being buried alive by an avalanche. DRAMA
Medium
NBC, 10 p.m.
Medium stars Patricia Arquette as Allison Dubois, a wife and mother of three young girls. Allison also possesses a hidden talent: She sees dead people, who come to her in dreams and reveal details of heinous crimes. Allison is regularly conscripted by local police to assist on tough cases. Tonight sees the return of the long-deceased FBI Agent Cooper (Kurtwood Smith of That '70s Show ) who sneaks back into Allison's dreams to pass on tips about a killer. For the first time, however, Allison is suspicious of the dead man's motives.
***
WEDNESDAY AUGUST 12
FOOD
Chef at Home
Food Network, 7 p.m.
Unlike many TV chefs, whose solitary goal seems to be promote their restaurants or cookbooks, Michael Smith has a genuine passion for all things food-related. In this show, he invites viewers into his home kitchen to school them on the preparation of uncomplicated meals. Tonight's episode is a personal affair. His young son Gabe has come down with a nasty cold, which inspires Smith to play doctor daddy. Leafing through his old cookbooks, he prepares homemade chicken soup and follows with comfort food, including warm bread pudding and matzo balls, and wraps up the meal with homemade brown-sugar ice cream.
COMEDY
Waiting for God
PBS, 7:30 p.m.
This BBC sitcom celebrates the golden years of several very British characters. Originally broadcast from 1990 to 1994, the series is set at an English retirement home and revolves around the principal characters of Diana Trent, a feisty retired photographer, and Tom Ballard, a former accountant on the lam from his dysfunctional family. In most episodes, the unlikely soulmates combine forces against the retirement home management, which seems intent on depriving the residents of all dignity. In tonight's show, Diana breaks her hip and must have an operation. Faced with the ignominy of attending her niece's upcoming wedding with a walker, she decides to derail the ceremony instead. For any age, that's thinking outside the box.
DOCUMENTARY
Wide Angle:
Victory is Your Duty
PBS, 10 p.m.
The Wide Angle cameras go inside the famed Havana Boxing Academy, which has produced more than two dozen gold-medal winners in the past quarter-century. Located in a non-glamorous building on the city's outskirts, the academy begins training at a tender age - as young as nine in some instances - and gradually moulds the young athletes into fierce ring warriors. The champions of the future rise or fall at Cuba's National Boxing Championship - one of the country's biggest annual sporting events - but several coaches are concerned. Some feel that the stepping-down of Fidel Castro last year was the beginning of the end of Cuba's boxing program. Time will tell.
LITERATURE
Speaking Volumes
Bravo!, 10 p.m.
Full marks go to this documentary celebrating the works of fiction writers from Newfoundland and Labrador. Directed by Ken Pittman, the film profiles rising talents like Lisa Moore, Wayne Johnston and Michael Crummey, whose work has struck a chord with literary devotees in Canada and all points abroad. The film interviews the authors and features scenes from their book readings. The short explanation for their success: Newfoundlanders are simply grand storytellers.
***
THURSDAY AUGUST 13
MOVIE
Camp Hollywood
Bravo!, 4 p.m.
Painfully real, this 2004 oddity goes inside Hollywood's infamous Highland Gardens Hotel, a rundown establishment known for aspiring actors. In ragged fashion, the film follows Canadian standup/filmmaker Steve Markle, who checks in for a two-month stay in the middle of "pilot season," the period when U.S. networks are casting for shows. Along with his new neighbours, Markle attends audition after audition and is turned down flat. Markle also trains his camera on several of the Highland's longtime residents, some of whom have been waiting for their big break for over a decade. A touching mix of pathos and showbiz surrealism.
DOCUMENTARY
Somali Pirate Takedown: The Real Story
Discovery, 9 p.m.
The whole world watched and waited last April when a handful of Somali pirates seized the cargo ship Maersk Alabama, which was en route to Kenya. The crisis ended a few days later when the three remaining pirates were shot dead by U.S. Navy Seal snipers while holding captain Richard Phillips hostage onboard a lifeboat. This special recounts the rescue mission in detail and features the first broadcast interviews with Captain Phillips and other members of the crew. DOCUMENTARY
On a Wind and a Prayer
PBS, 9 p.m.
Now here's a war story not found in most history books: During the height of the Second World War, the Japanese military were developing deadly ballistic missiles attached to balloons for use against American targets. The devices, known as "Fugo" balloons, were hydrogen-powered and carried payloads capable of mass destruction; there were also plans for the balloons to carry biochemical weapons. The military experts interviewed in this program estimate the Japanese released 9,000 of the weapons into the Pacific Jet Stream, with the long-range goal of reaching the U.S. The really scary part: There are apparently more than 600 still out there somewhere, and many are still active.
REALITY
LA Ink
TLC, 10 p.m.
Tattoo artist Kat Von D is the reason to watch this reality show about the body-art subculture. This series follows her struggles to operate High Voltage Tattoo, a studio in downtown Los Angeles. The show has a steady realistic feel and in one episode last season, Kat broke a Guinness World Record by tattooing 400 people in 24 hours. In tonight's episode, Kat airlifts in tattoo artist Dan Smith to run the studio while she heads to New York to promote her new fragrance line. Without Kat's strong presence, however, the place quickly becomes a Lord of the Flies scenario.

Done Deals / CARLTON AND PARLIAMENT

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/done-deals-carlton-parliament/docview/382610840/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Victorians in Cabbagetown do tend to be dark," Mr. O'Brien says. "This one was exceptionally bright."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Done+Deals+%2F+CARLTON+AND+PARLIAMENT&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-07&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   455 Ontario St.
Asking price: $829,000
Selling price: $795,000
Previous selling price: $740,000 (2007)
Taxes: $5,744 (2009)
Lot size: 20 by 122 feet
Days on the market: 12
Listing agent: Michael O'Brien, Bosley Real Estate Ltd.
Agent and local resident Michael O'Brien has seen several updated Victorians in Cabbagetown, but this is semi-detached version had a more memorable makeover than the rest.
"That was an incredibly glamorous renovation," the agent says. "And it had a couple of really unusual features."
That includes a 30-foot-long hall lined with glass block windows and a third-floor loft with a skylight, a Juliet balcony and a screened-in porch with an exit to a sundeck.
"Victorians in Cabbagetown do tend to be dark," Mr. O'Brien says. "This one was exceptionally bright."
The second-floor den was opened up and given a new bay window, "which was unusual," the agent says. "So that brought in a lot of light."
Outside the century-old residence, water, heating and an upper-level loft space is available in a two-storey coach house. "Those are extremely rare," Mr. O'Brien says.
Back in the house, vintage details include decorative mouldings and an elaborate archway in the main hall, as well as more than 10-foot-high ceilings.
Hardwood floors throughout stop short of the slate in the kitchen and family room. The former also has granite countertops, while the latter features a skylight, wood stove and patio doors. "It felt more like an outdoor room," Mr. O'Brien says.
Rounding out the main floor is a powder room, formal dining room and living room with a gas fireplace.
The second floor has two full bathrooms, including an ensuite.
The unfinished basement has a walkout.

'Korean girls ... the Devil's Playground!' And Toronto wonders why it's hated

Author: Fotheringham, Allan

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/korean-girls-devils-playground-toronto-wonders/docview/382627049/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "French Girls. Always open. Jacqueline Misa Gabrielle Melody Bella Rayne. Hiring Ladies & Drivers 19+" And "Nighttime is the right time @ the Devil's Playground, Toronto's party headquarters! Cold beer, hot women. Up to 30 Beautiful Girls (19+) Available to Entertain You!"

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Korean+girls+...+the+Devil%27s+Playground%21%27+And+Toronto+wonders+why+it%27s+hated&amp;author=Fotheringham%2C+Allan&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-01&amp;spage=F.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Korean+girls+...+the+Devil%27s+Playground%21%27+And+Toronto+wonders+why+it%27s+hated&amp;author=Fotheringham%2C+Allan&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-08-01&amp;spage=F.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Mackenzie King told us that the trouble with Canada was that it had too much geography and not enough population. A land masse larger than that of our southern neighbour, but only one-tenth its population.
That, the political scientists say, is why nothing binds this country together; there's no common theme.
They are wrong. There is a common theme, a link to all of us. It is the hatred of Toronto.
For many Canadians, Toronto is still the place that has all the banks. All the corporate head offices. All the television headquarters. All the magazines. The only national newspapers. All the smartest figures, all the best-paid personalities, all the powerful people, live in Toronto.
Reeling from a six-week garbage strike and a recession-sparked spike in unemployment, Toronto complains that it no longer deserves such criticism. The mighty has fallen.
Has the Centre of the Universe really learned its lesson?
As it happens, this scribbler is well equipped to find out. Born in a Saskatchewan hamlet of 26 souls and raised in small-town B.C., I was the No. 1 product of the Hate Toronto world.
Then, at 58, I finally gave in to filthy Toronto money and landed on Yonge Street.
Now I have been here long enough to realize that, while Toronto may plead with the rest of the country to stop hating it, in fact the feeling is mutual. Toronto is hypocritical.
Toronto dismisses Ottawa as a village populated by politicians, press and swivel servants. The West has dumb dirt farmers, elevated only by Calgary, while beyond the Rockies, everyone is a wacko.
Eastward, we have Quebec, which should really speak English, and the Maritimes, the destination for all those unemployment cheques.
In short, Canada is changing but Toronto's attitude toward it is not.
If you want some concrete evidence that the city of the CN Tower says one thing and does another, consider this: According to its Yellow Pages, Toronto the Good supports 274 churches.
But visit a local newsstand. Even the convenience stores of Rosedale, its richest enclave, offer as well as The Globe and Mail, National Post, Toronto Star, Toronto Sun, a thick weekly tabloid called Now.
It is free and boasts on its front page of having survived "27 independent years." It has coverage of Toronto city hall. A page on cycling. It has a serious piece on science fiction.
It invites readers to public consultations on city-wide zoning bylaws. It covers astrology, "health wart resisters" (whatever they are), movies, stage openings, food and drink and politics - everything that is going on in town.
Now is a serious business. Its masthead page tells us the editor-publisher has a vice-president, creative director, art director, senior designer and director of production services.
It is free, of course, because it survives on advertising. It has all the movie ads, rentals and real estate, golden retriever puppies, acting classes and The Pillow Fight League, "looking for eight, entertaining, athletic outgoing females with personality to join the roster! TV deal on horizon."
The masthead also lists a controller, a systems analyst, four marketing executives, a human resources manager, a payables co-ordinator and four designers.
And page 142 offers ads: "Pretty Asian and Caucasian girls 19+ wanted for busy agency. Earn what you're worth!" And "Urgent! Hiring female escorts 18+ Make up to $7,000 per week!"
There are, in all, 102 employees listed on Now's masthead. Plus 23 names lumped together under "delivery."
Page 147: "$45 Hot Brunettes & Blondes @ Toronto's newest & hottest massage!" Not to mention "Gorgeous Korean girls 19+ $40 for 30 mins."
There are, in the Greater Toronto Area with all its massive suburbs, some six million residents.
But the city itself has just over two million, half of whom are women with little interest in information such as that on page 150:
"French Girls. Always open. Jacqueline Misa Gabrielle Melody Bella Rayne. Hiring Ladies & Drivers 19+" And "Nighttime is the right time @ the Devil's Playground, Toronto's party headquarters! Cold beer, hot women. Up to 30 Beautiful Girls (19+) Available to Entertain You!"
The ads are in full colour, decorated with boobs and buttocks. "Victoria Park & Danforth Area. Dino-mite special 40 mins ... Only $80 F/S"
Let's say the one million Toronto men can be broken down into roughly equal groups: one-third who are under 20 and not available plus one-third who are over 50 and not interested.
That leaves a target audience of about 300,000. What a coincidence: Now claims to have "321,000 weekly readers - verified audit circulation."
So the Yellow Pages may contain 274 churches, but the 16 full pages of sex-trade advertising in Now show that Toronto also supports at least 388 houses of prostitution.
Is that not hypocrisy?
To contact Toronto journalist and author Allan Fotheringham, visit www.drfoth.com

____________________________________________________________

With the fate of 1 Bloor in doubt, just one plea: not another a parking lot

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/with-fate-1-bloor-doubt-just-one-plea-not-another/docview/382615035/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The Bloor-Yonge site, at the heart of Toronto's urban geography and historical sense of itself, could also become merely the setting for a condominium spire no better than what was proposed for it in the first place. Architect Roy Varacalli's design of 1 Bloor East, as the 80-storey luxury condo project is called, has gone through a few iterations, all of them routine, none inspiring. Toronto deserves better.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=With+the+fate+of+1+Bloor+in+doubt%2C+just+one+plea%3A+not+another+a+parking+lot&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=With+the+fate+of+1+Bloor+in+doubt%2C+just+one+plea%3A+not+another+a+parking+lot&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   jmays@globeandmail.com
The mighty hotel and condominium tower proposed for the southeast corner of Toronto's Yonge and Bloor streets crossing appears to be doomed. Amid a snowstorm of legal paperwork last week, Bazis International, the Kazakhstan-based developer of the high-rise, blaming hard times, seemed on the brink of surrendering the vacant lot. The potential buyer has so far not been named. It could be the consortium of local creditors that has been publicly battling Bazis the past few weeks.
What the new owner will do with the site has not been announced. But certain scenarios, most of them gloomy, come to mind.
It could be the location of a new tall building as numbingly mediocre as the existing office towers on the north side of the intersection. But if the local consortium gets the property, this may not come to pass: The financier leading the charge against Bazis is Gary Berman, who is also an organizer of the annual Pug Awards for worst and best new Toronto architecture. Mr. Berman certainly knows something about good tall-building design and what makes a good city - though how much artistic influence he has over his business partners, if any, is unknown at this point.
The Bloor-Yonge site, at the heart of Toronto's urban geography and historical sense of itself, could also become merely the setting for a condominium spire no better than what was proposed for it in the first place. Architect Roy Varacalli's design of 1 Bloor East, as the 80-storey luxury condo project is called, has gone through a few iterations, all of them routine, none inspiring. Toronto deserves better. We are living in a remarkably inventive, vivid moment in the history of international skyscraper design, and Toronto's most famous intersection would be an ideal location for a stellar expression of this lively artistic thinking.
The most dismal outcome of this affair would be a new parking lot. Over the past decade, Toronto real estate developers have done a good job of ridding the city of these eyesores, and the idea of actually adding one is, or should be, unthinkable.
But almost as bad as a parking lot would be the use suggested this month in the Toronto Star by urban affairs columnist Christopher Hume. His notion: a new square, sponsored by some civic-minded plutocrat or corporation to save our cash-starved city the bother. This public square would be, in Mr. Hume's view, an opportunity for city hall (which, he correctly notes, has played a puny role in Toronto's so-called cultural renaissance) "to redeem itself and revitalize Bloor and Yonge."
"If we can have a Four Seasons [Centre for the Performing Arts]," Mr. Hume asks, "why not a Royal Bank Square, a Hudson's Bay Plaza, Thomson Place, Weston Way or Pizza-Pizza Piazza?"
One reason is that the scheme wouldn't work.
Busy, controversial Yonge-Dundas Square succeeds not because the place lends vitality to the surrounding area, but because it effectively draws on the dense urban vigour that surges all around it. A Milky Way of electric signs, electronic billboards, a large theatre complex, a host of shops and restaurants, Eaton Centre, Ryerson University, dozens of residential towers in the neighbourhood: All these magnets attract energy, excitement and population to the district, hence into Yonge-Dundas Square. The Bloor-Yonge intersection, on the other hand, is a windy, lifeless wasteland, and that fact will not be changed by turning its southeast corner into a glorified vacant lot.
Another and more important reason is that the last thing downtown Toronto needs is another open-air public space.
We need density, far more people in the urban core, and the multiplication of places for these people to live, work and play. That means more safe, beautiful and liveable skyscrapers, fitted out with a mix of residential and retail uses, especially along the most important inner-city avenues.
Whatever quibbles I have with the design of the 80-storey behemoth Bazis International intended to put up, the building would have brought a much-needed wallop of human density to the corner of Bloor and Yonge. One version of the plan featured, in addition to the condo units and hotel up above, a multiscreen movie theatre and ample retail at street level. These items, too, would have been welcome as added attractions to the structure and as added resistance to the increasingly unsustainable outbound pull of suburbia.
The world financial crisis was bound to hurt Toronto. The probable collapse of the 1 Bloor East project is not the first local real-estate casualty of the international turmoil and it may not be the last. But this event will serve some higher purpose if it provokes new, substantial public discussion about the city we want and are willing to fight for.

DAYS ON THE MARKET: 21
LISTING AGENT: Boris
Kholodov, Royal LePage

In a nearly decade-old building at the corner of Richmond and Sherbourne streets, this one-bedroom plus den unit was a magnet for first-time buyers, says agent Boris Kholodov.
The ninth floor suite offers almost 700-square-feet of living space inside and extra room outdoors.
"It is a typical unit for the building, except it had a very nice balcony ... which is something that not many suites in the building have," says Mr. Kholodov.
The open concept residence is "decorated nicely" with built-in shelves in the principal room, a breakfast bar in the kitchen, and laminate and ceramic floors throughout, Mr. Kholodov states.
For privacy, there is a master bedroom with a walk-in closet.
The unit also comes with a four-piece bathroom and en suite laundry facilities, plus a locker and underground parking.
Each month, $338 pays for utility costs and upkeep of common areas, such as the gym and rooftop terrace. "The maintenance fee is quite low," adds Mr. Kholodov.
Local amenities include the subway, shops on Queen Street and recreational amenities at Moss Park. "The location is more and more in demand," says Mr. Kholodov.
