New Canaan in Muskoka

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/new-canaan-muskoka/docview/382612803/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "There's not too much within the cottage that has changed," says Mr. Stephens. "But everything you see on the property has evolved over the years."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=New+Canaan+in+Muskoka&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=New+Canaan+in+Muskoka&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Inspired by the Modernist designs of the Harvard Five, John and Margaret Stephens decided in 1959 to bring sophisticated architecture to Lake Rosseau. The home is little changed fifty years later
1033 SEGWUN PLACE,
MINETT, ONT.
WHAT: A vintage four-bedroom cottage with 510 feet of shoreline on Royal Muskoka Island in Lake Rosseau. The 2,272-square-foot cottage is on the market for the first time since it was built in 1959.
ASKING PRICE: $2.695-million
TAXES: $11,434.83 (2009)
AGENT: Chestnut Park Real Estate Ltd. (Paul Crammond)
Royal Muskoka Island is a rather grand name for a collection of pleasant cottage properties on Lake Rosseau, but the name stands as a reminder of the island's storied past.
"There is a lot of history on the island," says Craig Stephens, who has been visiting the family cottage there all of his life. "There was a history there before I was born."
From the time its doors opened in 1901, the Royal Muskoka Hotel drew tycoons and socialites from their summer homes all around the lakes.
Built on Royal Muskoka Island by Muskoka Navigation Co., the hotel had its own golf course and formal dances on Saturday nights. But on May 18, 1952, the Royal Muskoka burned to the ground. After the fire, the landmark hotel was not rebuilt and the land was eventually divided into lots and sold.
Craig Stephens' parents, the late John and Margaret, bought one of those lots in 1957. Four other lots were purchased by Craig's uncles and his grandmother.
Soon the various family members had cottages under construction on the island, but John and Margaret struggled to find a plan that they liked.
Then, in 1958, Margaret Stephens picked up a copy of Better Homes and Gardens and decided that the house featured on the magazine's cover would make an ideal Muskoka cottage. The Stephens contracted with a local builder to build the cottage, following the plan in the magazine, in 1959.
"I think they were the last to build," Mr. Stephens said during a recent interview.
After his mother died in 2008, Mr. Stephens came across the magazine, which she had kept all of that time.
The house that so impressed Ms. Stephens was the home of renowned U.S. architect John Black Lee, who built the house for his own family home in New Canaan, Conn.
After World War II, a group of modernist architects known as the Harvard Five established New Canaan as a centre of modern architecture.
Philip Johnson, who was perhaps the most celebrated of the group, built his famous Glass House there.
Mr. Lee joined the firm of Harvard Five member Eliot Noyes in 1949 and then went on to establish his own practice in New Canaan. He designed several houses in New Canaan, including two for his own family.
The house that the Stephens family admired is known as Lee House 2 and still stands in New Canaan. The design received an Award of Merit from the American Institute of Architects.
In Better Homes and Gardens , writer Neil Kuehnl described the virtues of the house: "Every once in a while, we discover a house that offers a startling amount of useful space - far more than its size or cost suggests. Usually it has a simple plan and clean, uncluttered lines. Such a house recalls a basic, centuries-old building fact: that simplicity and well-organized space nearly always go hand in hand."
Mr. Kuehul went on to say: "This house is just a rectangle - with four corner bedrooms, two baths, and a large central area designed for family living. That's all ... no halls, no stairways, no extra ups, downs, or sideways about it."
The house, the article explains, combines post-and-beam construction to create openness in the main living area, with conventional construction used in the bedrooms. In the centre of the house, the roof is raised above clerestory windows.
Many of the hallmarks of New Canaan design, including kitchens that open into family rooms and sliding glass doors that create slide-away walls, are incorporated into the Muskoka cottage. Such elements have become standard features of residential design.
Meanwhile, home and cottage owners in North America have come to favour design elements - such as spa-style bathrooms - that the New Canaan folk didn't envisage.
That's a dilemma that has created tension in Connecticut and elsewhere as the preservationists try to protect significant architecture while new buyers renovate or raze the architectural legacy.
Mr. Crammond says some potential buyers of the Minett cottage have wondered about enlarging the bathrooms or expanding the cottage. Because of the dwelling's character, he believes it would be a great shame to tear it down and rebuild. Regulations would prevent any new building from being erected so close to the water, he adds.
The sunroom, he notes, is about 31 feet from the water.
"You couldn't do that now."
Mr. Stephens says his mother was delighted with the way the cottage turned out. The open living space was ideal for hosting parties and gatherings of the many cousins and aunts and uncles who congregated on the island.
The Stephens added to the original design with a screened porch facing the water. Then, in the 1970s, they had the porch enclosed with sliding glass doors to create a sunroom.
Mr. Crammond calls the kitchen "the world's largest galley kitchen".
Mr. Stephens says its openness allowed anyone preparing food to remain part of the social scene.
The four bedrooms each stand at a corner of the house, giving each bedroom a view in two directions.
Today the cottage looks much as it has for years.
Mr. Stephens says a strong adherence to tradition is built into the culture of Muskoka, where 100-year-old cottages still have the original furniture.
"There's not too much within the cottage that has changed," says Mr. Stephens. "But everything you see on the property has evolved over the years."
The family built an oversized boathouse, a detached garage and a boat port with sundeck above.
The point of land includes a sand beach area, deeper granite shore and gentle terrain.
Mr. Stephens says his parents deliberately left as many trees standing as possible and left the forest floor untouched.
"You could say that they were environmentalists in that they respect Muskoka for what it was and they taught us to respect it."
The younger Mr. Stephens moved permanently to Muskoka several years ago. He and his siblings have decided to sell the property because it no longer suits the expanding family.
Mr. Crammond says sales are picking up in Muskoka this year after a dismal 2008.
"The market was basically frozen last year."
Listings are up this year, he says, because some cottages that didn't sell last year are still available.
On Royal Muskoka, the Stephens recently cut the price by $300,000 to $2.695-million, Mr. Crammond says, "indicating that the family would like to sell this year, not 2010".
Revision date: Saturday, August 01, 2009

Full text:   52 CORINNE CRES.
ASKING PRICE: $325,000
SELLING PRICE: $340,000
TAXES: $2,524 (2008)
LOT SIZE: 45-by 113 feet
DAYS ON THE MARKET: one
Listing agent: Heather
Lemieux, Royal LePage
Connect Realty
This war-era bungalow listed at $325,000 was a summertime rarity - a property affordable for first-time buyers, says agent Heather Lemieux.
That's likely the reason she got seven offers for the Scarborough residence on the first day.
"There's definitely a lack of inventory, especially in that price range," says Ms. Lemieux.
It also helped that the three-bedroom house was updated in areas like the eat-in kitchen and two full bathrooms.
"The house was very well maintained by the long-time owners," says Ms. Lemieux. "You could tell that [the neighbours] maintained their homes very well as well, so that definitely added to the curb appeal."
The combined living and dining room features crown mouldings and hardwood flooring that extends into the kitchen. There is a semi-circular breakfast bar with storage underneath. "It was quite unique," adds Ms. Lemieux.
Above-grade windows illuminate a secondary kitchen, workshop and fireside family room on the lower level, which can be entered from a separate side entrance. "You could very easily convert the basement into a basement apartment," Ms. Lemieux says.
Outside, there is a wide driveway to the carport and a private backyard with a garden shed and a large deck with some shade from a birch tree.
The surrounding area is a safe one with parks in every direction, as well as local schools, libraries and public transit, including the Scarborough RT and GO Train stations. "It's a quiet area," says Ms. Lemieux.

Done Deals / RUNNYMEDE AND ANNETTE

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/done-deals-runnymede-annette/docview/382612255/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "The main floor family room was a very huge attraction," Ms. [Nutan Brown] says. "Most homes do not have that kind of addition in the Bloor West Village area."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Done+Deals+%2F+RUNNYMEDE+AND+ANNETTE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=G.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Done+Deals+%2F+RUNNYMEDE+AND+ANNETTE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=G.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   227 GILMOUR AVE.
ASKING PRICE: $674,900
SELLING PRICE: $650,000
PREVIOUS SELLING PRICE: $492,000 (2006)
TAXES: $3,150 (2008)
LOT SIZE: 25 by 120 feet
DAYS ON THE MARKET: 18
LISTING AGENTS: Nutan Brown and Anil Khera, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd.
This detached, two-storey house has a rear addition that made it much larger than it appears, which is a big asset when the home is compared to other west-end properties nearby, says agent Nutan Brown.
"[The previous owners] took what was a typical Upper Bloor West Village home and expanded it to a size that would accommodate a family very nicely," she says.
The expansion allowed for a new lower level studio, a second floor master bedroom with an ensuite powder room and Juliet balcony and an extra space off the kitchen with a walkout to a deck.
"The main floor family room was a very huge attraction," Ms. Brown says. "Most homes do not have that kind of addition in the Bloor West Village area."
The wiring, plumbing, heating and cooling systems were also updated, the roof replaced and interior gutted and remodelled by another owner within the last decade.
Modern finishes within the 1940s house include hardwood floors and pot lights in the open living and dining area, stainless steel kitchen appliances and broadloom in the lower level recreation room.
The main bathroom services the three bedrooms upstairs.
Other assets include three-car parking accessed from a lane, a private back yard and a front garden with native plants and perennials. "It's a beautiful showpiece of colours," says Ms. Brown.
Local amenities include parks, schools and places of worship, as well as High Park and Bloor Street shops and subway further south.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THIS+WEEK+%2F+HIGHLIGHTS&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=R.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=THIS+WEEK+%2F+HIGHLIGHTS&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-31&amp;spage=R.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   FRIDAY
JULY 31
REALITY
Ghost Hunters
OLN, 7 p.m.
Ghost Hunters follows the ghost-busting exploits of Jason Hawes and Grant Wilson, two average guys who spend their days working as plumbers for Roto-Rooter. At times the series has drawn heat from parapsychologists scornful of the show's blue-collar methodology and tendency to sensationalize, but each episode is usually worth watching for the ghost story. Tonight's a good one: On Halloween, the ghost hunters check into Colorado's infamous Stanley Hotel, best known as the inspiration for Stephen King's novel The Shining . Their first stop is a guest room that sets their ghost-detecting gizmos spinning.
DRAMA
Southland
NBC, 8 p.m.If you missed Southland during its brief debut run last spring, take advantage of a second chance. The edgy police drama focuses sharply on cops working the beat in Los Angeles. The series was notable for marking the TV return of Ben McKenzie, formerly of The O.C ., who demonstrated strong acting chops as the rookie uniform cop Ben Sherman. In a rebroadcast of the pilot, the new kid is shocked at shortcuts taken by his training officer partner (Michael Cudlitz) and contemplates quitting the LAPD midway through his first shift. His fellow officers, meanwhile, investigate the disappearance of a young girl.
HUMOUR
Kenny vs. Spenny
Showcase, 9 p.m.
Kenny vs. Spenny features long-time friends Kenny Hotz and Spencer Rice competing in various juvenile challenges - to wit: who can smoke the most pot? - after which the loser is subjected to some form of humiliation. Tonight's double-shot presents two typically absurd contests: First, the boyos compete to see who can wear a dead octopus on his head the longest; the second show is a 10-mile road race - which might be an ordinary challenge except for Kenny tricking Spenny into believing his mother has died.
DOCUMENTARY
Life + Death in Kandahar
CBC Newsworld, 10 p.m.
First broadcast on the fifth estate , this report takes viewers inside the NATO trauma hospital in Kandahar province. Operated by Canadian medical volunteers, the unit is one of the busiest trauma hospitals in Afghanistan, treating hundreds of patients a day. The most gut-wrenching medical emergencies are those children severely injured by roadside bombs. A grim reminder of the casualties happening daily in Afghanistan.
SATURDAY
AUGUST 1
SCIENCE
The Nature of Things
CBC, 7 p.m.
This program follows Albertan mechanical engineer Brian Fleck as he charts the progress of the car of the future. His quest takes him to the congested freeways of Los Angeles and later to Italy, where two green-minded students have co-founded the Vehicle Design Summit.
DRAMA
Law & Order:
Criminal Intent
NBC, 8 p.m.
Former West Wing regular Janel Moloney delivers a strong guest turn in this standout episode from last season. Moloney plays the long-suffering wife of a minister mired in a web of deception regarding the murder of a celebrity doctor. The NYPD detectives assigned to the case believe she's keeping quiet about her husband's activities, and make her the focus of their investigation.
SCI-FI
Tin Man
Space, 9 p.m.
First shown in 2007, this six-hour miniseries puts a bleak sci-fi spin on The Wizard of Oz . Zooey Deschanel plays D.G., a bored Kansas waitress transported via tornado to something called the "Outer Zone" (O.Z., get it?). Her new friends include the Tin Man (Neal McDonough) - a former cop imprisoned in a metal suit - and a scarecrow figure called Glitch (Alan Cumming) who has had half his brain surgically removed. Not dark enough? Hamilton native Kathleen Robertson is well cast as the horribly evil witch Azkadellia, who wants to plunge all of Oz into pitch-black darkness.
REALITY
Survivorman: Labrador
OLN, 10 p.m.
Hardy survivalist Les Stroud braves the unforgiving region of Labrador. By the end of the first day, he's seriously worried about hypothermia, and inclement weather is making it nearly impossible or him to follow the trail.
SUNDAY
AUGUST 2
REALITY
Ty's Great British
Adventure
ABC, 8 p.m.
Extreme Makeover: Home Edition host Ty Pennington crosses the pond in this special edition of the series. His destination is the seaside town of Portreath located in southwest England. What was once a bustling port and popular tourist destination has become a rundown mess, particularly the local park in the town centre. Previous plans to spruce up the park have fallen apart. Ty and his reno team arrive and immediately set up a revitalization plan. But townsfolk are put off by Ty's gung-ho approach - and there's no money in the town coffers for the project.
SCI-FI
Defying Gravity
ABC, CTV, 9 p.m.
New show alert: Defying Gravity is described in press materials as a "sexy, provocative space thriller set in the very near future"; similar wording was used to launch the original Star Trek back in 1969. The series follows eight astronauts from five nations onboard the starship Antares, which has embarked on a six-year mission. The crew includes a flight engineer, a geologist (Laura Harris) and ship commander (Malik Yoba). The story veers between the past, showing the ship's crew in training, and the present, as the ship hurtles toward Venus. In the opener, the Antares leaves Earth and there is immediate suspicion that the journey is being controlled by forces beyond mission control.
DOCUMENTARY
Marilyn: The Last Sessions
CBC Newsworld, 10 p.m.
This documentary is based on tapes recorded with the late actress during psychoanalysis sessions in the months before her death on Aug. 5, 1962. The tapes, which Monroe made with Freudian psychoanalyst Ralph Greenson, were destroyed years ago, but this program assembles her rambling thoughts from the doctor's "nearly verbatim" notes. The results are hardly surprising: Monroe is depicted as a desperately insecure soul, but the program is more interesting for the late star's perspective on writers Truman Capote, Arthur Miller and, yes, the Kennedys.
MONDAY
AUGUST 4
MUSIC
Sugarland: Live on
the Inside
ABC, 8 p.m.
The vocal duo of Jennifer Nettles and Kristian Bush burst onto the country scene in 2004 with the bestselling album Twice the Speed of Life and have since sold a staggering seven-million CDs (yep, country fans still buy CDs in the U.S.); they've also collected enough Grammys and Country Music Awards to fill a king-size pickup truck. Filmed at an arena in Lexington, Ky., this special is a greatest-hits affair that airs the night before the release of Sugarland's live concert CD.
DRAMA
Once a Thief
TVtropolis, 10 p.m.
Lasting one brief, not particularly memorable, season, this series is worth revisiting as a Canadian TV curiosity. Spun off from a popular TV movie, the series cast Sandrine Holt as Li Ann Tsei, a member of a ruthless Chinese crime family who fell in love with handsome thief Mac Ramsey (Ivan Sergei). Somehow the two end up in Canada working for an elite crime-fighting unit under the direction of Victor Mansfield (played by Nicholas Lea, ex of The X-Files ). The lightweight stories always played second fiddle to solid action sequences, which are in evidence as Mac is "adopted" by a gang of jewel thieves.
FOOD
Ultimate Cake-Off
TLC, 10 p.m.
Spinning off from the success of TLC's Cake Boss - currently the highest-rated food show on U.S. cable - this new cooking competition airs with a sneak peek tonight before starting its weekly run on Aug. 31. In each episode, three contestants meet a corporate client requiring a mammoth cake for a special event, which range from an aquarium's new shark exhibit to a July 4th celebration. The rules stipulate each cake must be at least 1 ½ metres tall and look magnificent. The contestants have nine hours to assemble their masterpieces and the winner takes away $10,000.
DOCUMENTARY
Captured on Film: The True Story of Marion Davies
TCM, 11:30 p.m.
One of Hollywood's most tainted legends receives a rightful homage. The star of both silent films and talkies, Marion Davies was a gifted actress with a flair for comedy. Away from the camera, she was famous for nearly four decades as the "kept woman" of publishing magnate William Randolph Hearst, who refused to leave his wife. (Their affair was largely brought to light by Orson Welles's 1941 film Citizen Kane , a not-so-thinly veiled look at Hearst's life that depicted Davies as a talentless shrew.) Narrated by Charlize Theron, the program includes clips from Davies's most celebrated films and shows her uncanny skill at impersonation.
TUESDAY
AUGUST 5
DOCUMENTARY
Road to Baleya
Bravo!, 7 p.m.
Cliché as it sounds, the language of music really does transcend boundaries and cultures. This documentary details the enduring friendship between Malian musician Mansa Sissoko and a quartet of Canadian musicians who travel to Mansa's home village of Baleya for recording sessions, which are orchestrated by Canuck Lewis Melville. Post-recording, the group of friends journeys to some remote villages in Mali's hill country, where malaria has taken a deadly toll in recent years. A remarkable, touching film.
DOCUMENTARY
Korea: The Unfinished War
TVO, 8 p.m.
Done by renowned filmmaker Brian McKenna, this four-part series rewinds what is still referred to "the forgotten war." Although the focus is the first major military conflict in the atomic-bomb era was actually shot in North Korea - a rare occurrence - and talks to American and Canadians who fought side by side, and to former Korean soldiers who faced them. Tonight's chapter reopens the long-standing allegations that U.S. forces made quiet use of bio-warfare weapons.
REALITY
1,000 Ways to Die
Spike, 9 p.m.
How on earth does Spike keep coming up with these shows? Skewing to the cable channel's way-manly demographic, this series recreates bizarre deaths normally restricted to the back pages of small-town newspapers. In tonight's show: A construction worker is buried alive in gravel; an amateur entomologist dies from a black-widow bite; and one poor soul tumbles to death in an industrial dryer. The show tries to attach some degree of decency by including interviews with scientists and safety experts, but the more likely thing that keeps people watching is that most common of human reactions: At least it wasn't me.
TRAVEL
Stephen Fry in America
TVO, 10 p.m.
British actor and TV presenter Stephen Fry is a delight in this rambling, six-part travelogue. Travelling primarily by London cab across the U.S., Fry covers all 50 states in the series, and his boyish enthusiasm for all-things American never wavers; his interaction with a handful of New Jersey mob-wannabes is among many highlights. In tonight's show, Fry spends time in Maine with several seasoned fishermen, one of whom teaches him how to hypnotize a lobster before cooking it. Ain't that America?
WEDNESDAY
AUGUST 5
BIOGRAPHY
The Achievers: Bette Davis
Bravo!, 7 p.m.
This profile explores the life of Bette Davis in rich detail, and points out a little-known fact: Although Davis was a Broadway star, her transition to film was far from easy. Her earliest films for Universal were flops; her movie career came later, when Warner Bros. wisely teamed her up with James Cagney and other rising stars. The film touches on Davis's storied personal life - once widowed and thrice-divorced, she raised her children as a single mother - and includes clips from her most beloved films, including All About Eve and Whatever Happened to Baby Jane ? She was one of a kind.
RETRO
TV's 50 Funniest Phrases
NBC, 8 p.m.
Hosted by 30 Rock 's Jane Krakowski, this special counts down TV's top catchphrases from the past half-century. The most obvious phrases surfaced in the top 10 - including "Yada yada yada" from Seinfeld ; "D'oh!" from The Simpsons ; and "How you doin'?" from Friends - but the blogosphere heated up the day after it was first aired with people noting some of the more glaring omissions: "Dy-no-mite" from Good Times , and "Whatchoo talkin' about, Willis?" from Diff'rent Strokes . Neither can be considered a classic, but a mention would have been nice. And ranking "It's going to be legendary" from How I Met Your Mother in 10th place added insult to injury. Classic-TV fans are so sensitive.
NATURE
Day of the Shark 2
Discovery, 8 p.m.
This sequel to the Discovery Channel special Day of the Shark follows more foolhardy types who still believe a lightweight aluminum frame is the smartest way to get up close to the deadly ocean creatures. As in the first special, it's most entertaining when their best guesses are proved wrong. Among the harrowing moments: A great white breaks through a shark cage, trapping two divers inside; a shark attacks a former Navy Seal in Florida; and a bull shark terrorizes a spear-fishing party in the Bahamas. Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water.
REALITY
Property Virgins
HGTV, 9 p.m.
On the stress scale, buying a new home is up there with getting married or undergoing a serious medical procedure. This show follows real-estate agent Sandra Rinomato's efforts to put first-time buyers into the right home. In tonight's episode, Erin and Karl, a young couple still living with Erin's parents, want to buy a farm that's postcard-perfect. But there's more idealism than realism in their fantasies of country living. Rinomato sits them down to broker a compromise.
THURSDAY
AUGUST 6
CONSUMER
Marketplace
CBC Newsworld, 7:30 p.m.
Have you been taken in by The Seven Sins of the Marketplace ? In this special edition of the series, host Erica Johnson relates the seven sins - Addition, Omission, Creation, Salvation, Assurance, Persuasion and Deception - and shows consumers how they can steer clear of such sneaky tricks. It's not wise, for example, to listen to the sales pitch of natural-gas suppliers who offer locked-in rates that promise to knock thousands off your annual energy bill. It never works out that way, of course, but a sucker is born every minute.
COMEDY
30 Rock
NBC, CITY-TV, 8 p.m. and
9:30 p.m.
TV insiders say 30 Rock will again sweep the best-comedy categories at September's Emmys, and why wouldn't it? Try to think of a funnier woman on TV today than Tina Fey, or a more complicated sitcom figure than Alec Baldwin as a vainglorious network exec. Tonight has two grand shows from last season. The first guest-stars Carrie Fisher as Liz's writer idol, who is a complete bust on The Girly Show . In the second, Jack is forced to hand out pink slips, which he's briskly efficient at.
DOCUDRAMA
Police Women
of Broward County
TLC, 9 p.m.
This unscripted series follows four female police officers working out of the Broward County Sheriff's Office in Florida: Andrea, a single mom assigned to the elite street-crimes unit; Julie, a detective with three kids who handles sex crimes and missing-persons cases; Shelunda, a rookie whose twin sister is also on the force; and Ana, a 29-year-old mom with a solid record busting drug dealers. Each episode in the 10-part series is split between the women working the mean streets and at home with the family.
REALITY
Crime 360
A & E, 10 p.m.
This true-crime series lives or dies, so to speak, by the complexity of the case, and tonight's is a puzzler. Veteran New Jersey investigators Tom Cassidy and CJ Dominic arrive at a homicide scene on a quiet residential street to find a body riddled with bullets in a smashed-up van. But forensics experts can't pinpoint where the shooting took place. Through dogged police work, they discover the man is associated with dodgy criminal types, but there appears to be no motive. As the detectives peel away the layers of the victim's life, they discover the shocking truth.

A PQ Leader, from the manor borne

Author: Tu Thanh Ha

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/pq-leader-manor-borne/docview/382614025/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The 41-acre estate in the leafy community of Île-Bizard had been a target of mockery by comedians who liked to depict Ms. [Pauline Marois] as a chatelaine out of touch with regular people.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+PQ+Leader%2C+from+the+manor+borne&amp;author=Tu+Thanh+Ha&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-30&amp;spage=A.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+PQ+Leader%2C+from+the+manor+borne&amp;author=Tu+Thanh+Ha&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-30&amp;spage=A.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Long saddled with an aristocratic reputation that hurt her electoral prospects, Parti Quebecois Leader Pauline Marois has put her controversial Montreal stone mansion up for sale, asking $8-million.
The 41-acre estate in the leafy community of Île-Bizard had been a target of mockery by comedians who liked to depict Ms. Marois as a chatelaine out of touch with regular people.
Though she hails from modest origins, Ms. Marois's patrician manners and marriage to financier Claude Blanchet became such liabilities that, during a by-election campaign in 2007, she invited a television crew to her cottage to show how frugally she lived.
The ploy backfired because it drew more attention to the Île-Bizard house, which the couple calls La Closerie, a quaint French expression for a small, enclosed property.
The couple is embroiled in a libel suit against The Gazette for an article that raised questions about how the couple obtained a zoning exemption that enabled them to build the mansion on land reserved for farming.
The house is "a true oasis," according to the real-estate listing for the seven-bathroom, 12,000-square-foot building, which comes with a Jacuzzi and heated pool.
"This very elegant French villa style property is located on an immense riverfront estate. The remarkable copper roof, the local fieldstone siding and the abundant fenestration give this house a very particular charm."
Ms. Marois is selling her house because she wants to move to her electoral riding of Charlevoix to be closer to her constituents, since her children have grown and left the house, spokesman Pascal Monette said.

Opposition mounts to resort near Squamish

Author: Atkinson, Cathryn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/opposition-mounts-resort-near-squamish/docview/382616429/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "With the expansion of the Sea to Sky highway [for the 2010 Winter Olympics] we're in the path of urban sprawl. Thinking that we will not change is unrealistic," he said. "The flavour I've had from the community is that we've been trying to replace a loss in commercial-tax revenue because of industries leaving."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Opposition+mounts+to+resort+near+Squamish&amp;author=Atkinson%2C+Cathryn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-28&amp;spage=S.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Opposition+mounts+to+resort+near+Squamish&amp;author=Atkinson%2C+Cathryn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-28&amp;spage=S.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Proposed development raises ire of environmentalists and local snowmobilers, but others say new source of jobs would be welcome
An unlikely umbrella organization of 42 businesses and groups, binding together snowmobilers and dirt bikers with environmentalists, store owners and fishing enthusiasts, has been set up in opposition to a proposed four-season resort development just north of Squamish, B.C.
On the other side are the supporters of the Garibaldi at Squamish resort plan, including the local chamber of commerce, real estate developers and construction firms who say that without it, the town of 15,000 will turn into a commuter satellite of Vancouver.
Brohm Ridge, the proposed location of the resort, juts out like a shoulder from Mount Garibaldi, the spectacular peak north of Squamish. Wildflowers and clear creeks dominate the proposed village site, 1,100 metres up the mountain.
The ridge has million-dollar views of surrounding ranges and glaciers, with the long fjord of Howe Sound stretching into the distant Pacific toward Vancouver, 65 kilometres to the south.
The 3,238-hectare proposal includes a 25-lift ski hill, two golf courses, development near two popular lakes and the construction of about 5,500 condominiums, a hotel and housing units. With a capacity of 22,500 beds, it will more than double the current population of Squamish, but be a third the size of the resort at Whistler, another 50 kilometres north.
Around 70 protesters turned up at a recent Squamish district council meeting to treat assembled TV cameras to signs with slogans such as "Don't pass G@S," and calling the resort proposal a "land grab."
Kimberley Martin, owner of the Funky Monkey Boutique, has been selling T-shirts in support of the protests. She said the issue of business being taken away from the centre of town to an outlying resort area is secondary to her concerns about environmental impacts.
"I don't believe [the resort] is sustainable or viable. I feel there should be more energy or effort in developing already used sites rather than pristine wilderness," she said.
A snowboarder for 19 years, Ms. Martin said turning an area already used by outdoor enthusiasts into a formal resort smacked of elitism. She also believes it would negatively affect fish-rich streams in its search for water to sustain 15,000 skiers a day or maintain golf courses.
Darren McCartney of the Squamish chamber of commerce disagreed, saying the chamber accepted the resort plan "conditionally" so long as sensible environmental planning was in place along with community involvement in how the project evolves.
"With the expansion of the Sea to Sky highway [for the 2010 Winter Olympics] we're in the path of urban sprawl. Thinking that we will not change is unrealistic," he said. "The flavour I've had from the community is that we've been trying to replace a loss in commercial-tax revenue because of industries leaving."
Supporters of the resort say it would revive the former blue-collar town after a decade of watching traditional forestry industries leave.
Brent di Mazzo, owner of Hard Rock Construction, said he supported the resort because the community lost major employers such as Interfor, Woodfibre's pulp mill and BC Rail. And while 1,700 opponents signed a petition against the resort, he said, many more support it, though less vocally.
"The town is dying and turning into a bedroom community. We need a good, clean industry, which is what I think [Garibaldi at Squamish] is trying to be."
Mr. di Mazzo said the district has lost millions in tax revenue.
"I think we need the tax base. There are weeds growing in the cracks in the sidewalk and no money to patch the roads," he said.
And then there are the jobs, which he said were badly needed.
"I'm in construction and there is at least a 10-year build. I may benefit from this or I may not, but I've got three boys and I know they need jobs in the long term."
Mr. di Mazzo thinks a referendum on the subject would provide the best indication of local support or antipathy.
Squamish Mayor Greg Gardner is not entertaining a referendum at this stage, but has been studying a fiscal-impact study commissioned by the district on the resort's potential.
"I'm impressed with the quality of debate so far ... It's a large issue and there would be positive and negative impacts. The province is proceeding with [the assessment process], and their stated reason is to encourage economic activity through tourism, but we still have a lot of unanswered questions," he said.
B.C.'s Environmental Assessment Office will submit its report on the environmental viability of the project to the provincial government in early August, and a response from the ministry is expected around mid-September.

Blowing bubbles in China

Author: Milner, Brian

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/blowing-bubbles-china/docview/382616298/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "They have to do it through these policy measures of pushing bonds onto the banks, because they're not enforcing any new risk evaluation," said Ms. [Jennifer Richmond], who closely monitors China's bank practices. "They can't afford to, because ultimately they're going to want to use the banks again to lend like they've been doing in the first half of the year."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Blowing+bubbles+in+China&amp;author=Milner%2C+Brian&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-28&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Blowing+bubbles+in+China&amp;author=Milner%2C+Brian&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-28&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: When the global recession hit China, Beijing ordered the country's banks to lend. And lend they did.
Now the drive to stimulate its domestic economy through easy monetary policy and aggressive banking has triggered dangerous unintended consequences, including a new wave of troubled loans and bubbles in the stock and property markets that threaten to blow up in Beijing's face.
If unchecked, China's vaunted recovery from the global slowdown will be in serious jeopardy.
So far, the credit bubble is producing a contradictory response from a government more worried about unleashing social unrest than about the potential damage to its economy or financial system from bad lending practices, analysts say.
The government "somewhat wants to rein in some of this lending," but has few regulatory tools at its disposal, said Jennifer Richmond, senior China analyst with Stratfor, a global intelligence firm based in Austin, Tex.
Beijing is also likely to maintain the lending spree at least until Oct. 1 - the 60th anniversary of the Communist regime and an important symbolic date - because the government fears triggering a wave of factory closings and subsequent widespread unrest if the money dries up.
New government measures announced yesterday include tighter controls on large bank loans exceeding five million yuan (about $790,000), closer supervision and a requirement that "fixed-asset investment loans" be doled out in ways that benefit the real economy. And in a belated move to soak up excess money and slow the flood of credit, the People's Bank of China has ordered certain overly aggressive commercial lenders to purchase 100 billion yuan worth of short-term bonds. The banks have until mid-September to pay for them.
"They have to do it through these policy measures of pushing bonds onto the banks, because they're not enforcing any new risk evaluation," said Ms. Richmond, who closely monitors China's bank practices. "They can't afford to, because ultimately they're going to want to use the banks again to lend like they've been doing in the first half of the year."
Loan growth exploded in the first six months, totalling a record 7.4 trillion yuan. That's nearly a quarter of China's gross domestic product and well in excess of the government's own projected quota of five trillion yuan for the entire year.
There is little doubt much of this cash has found its way into booming urban property markets and red-hot equities. The Chinese stock market has soared 88 per cent so far this year. Yesterday, when Sichuan Expressway Co. became the first new listing on the Shanghai Stock Exchange's main board in almost a year, trading was so frenzied that officials had to twice call halts.
In Beijing, house prices soared an average of 27 per cent in the first six months of the year, and Hong Kong property loans are at their highest level on record.
Analysts estimate that at least a third of all new bank lending is being funnelled into stocks or real estate speculation. Another third is going just to keep struggling businesses running day to day in a tough economy, rather than for infrastructure or other economic improvements.
Many of the loans at the local level are motivated by politics, rather than economics, say analysts, who fear another flood of bad loans will emerge from shoddy or corrupt bank practices. The chief government watchdog has promised stricter regulation, but analysts say it has little ammunition to rein in practices the government itself has encouraged.
"Many financial institutions pursue business growth, but are weak in risk management; highlight prelending examination but neglect after-loan supervision; or stop loan management at superficial levels," the China Banking Regulatory Commission said yesterday. The regulator is urging banks to earmark parts of large fixed-asset loans to, for example, the companies making or selling equipment and materials for projects, rather than turning over the whole sum to the borrower.
Most of China's impressive first-half growth of 7.1 per cent, annualized, stems from investment. This is not a recipe for a strong economic recovery of the sort that China boosters believe will lead the world out of a prolonged slump.
"The government is trying to stimulate the heck out of the economy by forcing banks to lend. And then they tell them to do it responsibly. You can't really do it responsibly, because it's not driven by normal demand," said Vitaliy Katsenelson, director of research with Investment Management Associates in Denver and a long-time critic of China's growth strategy.
"They're putting on the brakes while pushing on the gas at the same time. And you can't do that."

Building in a box

Author: Lanktree, Graham

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/building-box/docview/382614969/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Sustainable design is a large part of Müvbox's mission. "The base unit is 100 per cent self-sufficient," Mr. [Daniel Noiseux] says, "but I aim to take every finished unit off the grid in the next five years." Right now solar panels provide almost 40 per cent of Müvbox's energy, and customers can choose from among many cost-saving green options, he says.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Building+in+a+box&amp;author=Lanktree%2C+Graham&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-28&amp;spage=B.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Building+in+a+box&amp;author=Lanktree%2C+Graham&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-28&amp;spage=B.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Design for portable restaurant has venture capitalists salivating around the world
Although it doesn't have any big guns or transform into a tank, if you mistook this cherry-red maritime shipping crate in Montreal's Old Port for a futuristic robot you wouldn't be far off.
Powered by two rooftop solar panels, in only 90 seconds every morning this slickly decorated steel box unfolds its walls and two shady awnings to create a 28-seat terrace. Then it's up and running: a largely self-sustaining, portable gourmet seafood restaurant.
It's called Müvbox, and since launching in early June it's rocketed around the globe via design blogs and websites. The response has bowled over its creator, Daniel Noiseux, founder of Montreal's Pizzaiolle restaurant chain.
"I'm trying hard to keep my head," he says. "Venture capitalists from Geneva called three times this week, and we've had interest from Greece, Asia, and one e-mail from Russia simply said, 'I want 100 units, how much!?' "
The buzz, Mr. Noiseux suspects, is because his creation marks combined evolutions in street food, portable real estate and sustainable design.
Although similar in size to a chip wagon, every day Müvbox's fully enclosed kitchen offers up local Quebecois delicacies such as Iles de la Madeleine lobster, clam chowder and foie gras.
But Müvbox is essentially a prototype. Mr. Noiseux's intention is to sell units customized to the needs of entrepreneurs and businesses, be it a mobile restaurant, retail or demo space. "Say, if a local chef wanted to run a mini-restaurant close to Toronto Film Festival events," he says.
A base unit costs $150,000 and has mechanized walls, flooring made from recycled tires, ecologically friendly lighting and solar panels. Then it's ready to be tricked out by Mr. Noiseux's crack team of designers and architects.
To create Müvbox, Mr. Noiseux approached Montreal design studio Sid Lee, which worked on branding, market research and the company website, then brought in architects from Ædifica who came up with solutions for folding walls and sourced environmentally conscious materials. It took 18 months of collaboration, but now Mr. Noiseux says one unit can be built in six to eight weeks.
Each shipping container is recycled from one of more than 700,000 discarded annually in North America.
Sustainable design is a large part of Müvbox's mission. "The base unit is 100 per cent self-sufficient," Mr. Noiseux says, "but I aim to take every finished unit off the grid in the next five years." Right now solar panels provide almost 40 per cent of Müvbox's energy, and customers can choose from among many cost-saving green options, he says.
Connected to this idea of self-sufficiency is the fact that "a container is all about mobility," Mr. Noiseux explains. Müvbox can be operated for a season, then packed up and stored without a trace. But how receptive will cities be to these steel boxes dotting the urban landscape?
In Montreal you won't find a single chip truck or hot dog stand because of a near total ban on street food dating from the 1960s. Müvbox has sidestepped these rules since the quays of the Old Port are managed federally.
What the city does allow, however, is for vendors to set up during such events as Jazz Fest or Just For Laughs. "Müvbox answers a question nobody asked," Mr. Noiseux says, "and opens the way for the city to reconsider the rules."
If it's a question of hygiene this gourmet restaurant exceeds expectations. Its kitchen offers meals made with fresh local ingredients, from its lobster right down to its cheese and ice cream.
Since Toronto's new street-food program brought ethnic treats to its sidewalks this summer, Mr. Noiseux has had his eye on the paved plaza of the Sugar Beach project near the foot of Jarvis Street. A new urban space like this would be the perfect place to set up shop, he says.
For now, Mr. Noiseux is closing a deal on the first three units, which he's glad will remain close to home in Quebec City and Montreal.
This fall he plans to take the demo unit on the road to trade shows in Chicago and Cologne.
"In the short term we're set on growing locally," he says, "but this box was meant to go around the world."

HOPE ON THE HORIZON

Author: Ebner, David

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/hope-on-horizon/docview/382613426/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Mr. Black and Platinum don't have dreams of editorial expansion. Mr. Black's papers are mostly the no-frill variety, and there are no plans to resurrect the Union-Tribune's Washington bureau, which was shuttered last year. "In a perfect world, you have bureaus in several places but that perfect world isn't going to happen, I don't believe, where you have money to burn in editorial," Mr. Black said in an interview.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=HOPE+ON+THE+HORIZON&amp;author=Ebner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-27&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=HOPE+ON+THE+HORIZON&amp;author=Ebner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-27&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: While few see a profitable future for newspapers, David Black's belief in the business is unshaken - witness the publisher's newest attraction: beaten-down big city dailies. David Ebner reports
David Black has a boat named Esperanza - "hope," in Spanish. Many would say the name would be better suited for his business strategy, one pinned firmly on the future of newspapers.
He loves details, isn't flashy and likes a good yarn, much like the 158 publications put out by Black Press Ltd., a motley collection of generally small papers mostly in British Columbia and Washington state. He runs them lean - and they make money.
About a year ago, the ever-ambitious Mr. Black (no relation to the one-time media baron now jailed in Florida) was on the expansion hunt. And so was Platinum Equity LLC, a conglomerate out of Los Angeles, a specialist in rejuvenating businesses that have hit hard times and owner of everything from telecommunications to fibreglass and crane rentals.
In March, with Mr. Black on board as an investor and adviser, Platinum Equity bought The San Diego Union-Tribune, a 141-year-old paper where advertising revenue had fallen 40 per cent in the past three years as the California city was ravaged by the burst real estate bubble and by recession.
It is here David Black sees a future for newspapers. He believes in an old-fashioned recipe, that a local paper has a unique role for advertisers, especially the likes of furniture stores and auto dealers. There is value in a full-page ad, even for beaten-down city papers. When the economy comes back, papers will get back on their feet too, the idea goes.
Mr. Black and Platinum don't have dreams of editorial expansion. Mr. Black's papers are mostly the no-frill variety, and there are no plans to resurrect the Union-Tribune's Washington bureau, which was shuttered last year. "In a perfect world, you have bureaus in several places but that perfect world isn't going to happen, I don't believe, where you have money to burn in editorial," Mr. Black said in an interview.
The 63-year-old isn't so much a newspaper man as a businessman running newspapers. Making money is the challenge he relishes, and he continues to make it when many others in the industry are failing. Born in Vancouver, educated in engineering at University of British Columbia and business at University of Western Ontario, Mr. Black bought his first newspaper in 1975 when he was 29, the tiny Williams Lake Tribune in the central interior of British Columbia.
More than three decades later, from his headquarters in Victoria, Mr. Black watches the industry suffer. Losses pile up at print publications and no one makes money online - or has a good idea where a profit will eventually come from, because everything is given away free and advertising revenue doesn't support it. Big-name papers are failing in the United States and bleeding in Canada.
Now, with bondholders in charge of CanWest Global Communications Corp., a re-ordering of this country's media landscape looms as some analysts predict the media giant will sell its 13 dailies and 26 community newspapers.
Mr. Black could be a key player.
Black Press is projected to be profitable this year - annual revenue of about $500-million and 2.8 million in circulation - and he often further bolsters his position through partnerships.
Earlier this decade, he sold 19.4 per cent of Black Press to Torstar Corp. to expand his company. In 2006, he worked with Onex Corp. on what turned out to be a failed attempt to buy two Philadelphia dailies (Mr. Black demanded cuts the union didn't want; those papers this year went into bankruptcy protection).
And, this year, working as an individual, rather than through Black Press, he's in San Diego with Platinum.
Few see a profitable future for newspapers. The Union-Tribune sat for sale for almost a year as other papers, like the 146-year-old Seattle Post-Intelligencer, went out of business. Warren Buffett, whose Berkshire Hathaway Inc. owns a stake in Washington Post Co., said in May he would not pay any price for most papers and forecast the possibility of "unending losses."
Mr. Black's belief in the business is unshaken. This is a business cycle, severe, but not a whole new world, he said, particularly for community/suburban papers and small-town publications that make up Black Press, businesses that are better insulated from digital media. As for large urban dailies, he believes their costs are too high, given that websites such as Craigslist.com have gutted classified ad revenues.
"The Internet no doubt has had an effect, and will have an effect, for community papers, but I don't think it's an enormous effect," Mr. Black said. "Community newspapers are still the best place for retailers to advertise. They get the most response for their dollars.
"For the big metros, it's different. They were living off their classifieds. They have to reinvent themselves."
Louis Samson, Platinum's principal on the San Diego deal, was introduced to Mr. Black through an investment banker. Mr. Samson and Platinum had been looking for the right newspaperman to work with. The connection with Mr. Black was immediate, and strong.
Mr. Samson admired Mr. Black's business acumen and his record at Black Press, where budgets are kept tight and products are straightforward. There are not overly ambitious, they do what they do well, which generally is local news in a small community or suburb.
"David looks at problems differently, always thinking about the next move," says Mr. Samson. "From a business standpoint, he's willing to think about how to reorganize things."
In newspapers these days, reorganize means cuts: wage cuts, staff cuts, pension cuts. It is what Mr. Black did in Akron, Ohio, where Black Press bought the well-regarded Beacon Journal in 2006 for $165-million (U.S.). The editorial staff was slashed by a quarter - 40 out of 161 - after the deal closed.
Though Mr. Black said the paper is still making money, Black Press has had to take a $100-million writedown on the investment, which pushed partner Torstar to reduce the value of its stake in Black Press to a glaring zero.
Mr. Black and Mr. Samson are realists. They see the commoditization of information. They know profit margins will be lower than in the past. "You have to make it profitable and put it in a position to thrive," Mr. Samson said.
For Mr. Black, a father of four, with three grandchildren, this push toward big-name newspapers might have never happened. He might have been half-retired, sailing and golfing, but in 2005, personal tragedy struck. His wife, Annabeth, who worked closely with her husband in the running of Black Press, was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. A year later, she was dead and Mr. Black's parents also died around the same time.
"I threw myself in the business," Mr. Black recalled. "I didn't know what else to do."
He made the Akron deal and then in 2007 battled Quebecor Inc. for Osprey Media Income Fund's 54 papers in Ontario but ceded the deal when partner Torstar balked at raising the bid.
"David's got a great nose for making money and he's fearless doing it," said friend Robert Prichard, a former chief executive officer of Torstar and Toronto Star publisher who himself was battered by the business during his time at the helm.
"He's always pushed himself to go further, and farther. He's never afraid of a fight, and fights to win."
The Platinum connection could foreshadow what happens in the Canadian media business. Banks aren't keen to lend money to buy newspapers, so it is private equity money that analysts believe will be a force in the shakeout of the industry. Platinum, run by 44-year-old billionaire Tom Gores, one of the youngest on the Forbes rich list, owns about two dozen businesses, with estimated total revenue of $13.5-billion. Platinum's latest push is to buy part of Delphi Corp., the bankrupt auto-parts maker.
Mr. Samson said Platinum has looked at most newspaper assets that have come up for sale and wouldn't limit its hunt to the United States.
Unlike earlier, flamboyant Canadian media barons - including Izzy Asper, the patriarch who built CanWest and died in 2003, or the aristocratic Conrad Black - David Black is a shy, smart college-professor type. He speaks softly, is content to keep a low profile, likes the quiet on the water when sailing.
In business, he hits hard when there's an opening. And a bunch of openings could emerge shortly.
While Mr. Black does see better prospects at smaller papers, he is interested in larger ones, too. "I'm fairly agnostic [about size]," he says.
"Where there are opportunities, there are opportunities."

Crushing on the County

Author: Sanati, Mercedeh

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/crushing-on-county/docview/382617476/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: According to [Frederic Picard], size and geography bind the County and set it apart. "Niagara has 25 years of growing experience and more than a hundred wineries," he says. "We're a young region and the newest Designated Viticulture Area in Ontario." More established County estates such as Closson Chase Vineyards, founded in the late 1990s by esteemed viticulturist Deborah Paskus (a pioneer of the new County terroir), have been joined by the award-winning vintages of Huff, Waupoos...

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Crushing+on+the+County&amp;author=Sanati%2C+Mercedeh&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-25&amp;spage=T.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Crushing+on+the+County&amp;author=Sanati%2C+Mercedeh&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-25&amp;spage=T.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The food, wine and cheese are getting even better - and now, a prominent guidebook is directing crowds of oenophiles to the region
Even whipping wind and ominous clouds threatening to burst didn't keep eager visitors away from Prince Edward County winery tasting rooms on a recent Saturday. At Waupoos Winery, Huff Estates and the County Cider Company, staff juggled an onslaught of visitors impervious to the weather and eager to test County wares.
Prince Edward County, with its mix of family-owned wineries, creative chefs and chic art galleries, is officially on the hit list of weekenders from Toronto to Montreal: With the inclusion of 13 of its wineries in Andrew Brooks's definitive wine-tour guide, Crush on Niagara , the rustic island will no longer be known only for its beaches and fertile farmland. Yet, with its dreamy landscape and laid-back vibe, the County can't help but pay homage to its rural roots, making it a perfect place to escape the city in style.
Wedged in the "golden triangle," within two to three hours' drive from Toronto, Montreal and Ottawa, Prince Edward County has an enviable position. Blink, however, and you may miss it. "I drove that stretch of the 401 from Toronto to Quebec countless times and never realized that along the way there was a bridge leading to another world," says Henriette Labelle-Campbell, events manager at The Waring House Inn in Picton.
Two decades ago, Labelle-Campbell and her husband crossed that bridge and invested in a summer home. Eventually they decided to make a permanent move, and they haven't looked back. "When we settled in the County in 1998, it was a rural community with very few amenities for tourists. If you hadn't eaten dinner at a local diner by 8 p.m., then you were out of luck."
These days, there is very little chance of going hungry after dark. The Waring House is home to Amelia's Garden, a fine-dining restaurant that is a favourite with locals. Executive chef Luis de Sousa's five-course tasting menu features seasonal dishes that are paired with locally produced wines. (A timely offering right now: Baby Blue pie made with in-season local blueberries and rhubarb and an oatmeal-cinnamon streusel topping.)
The Waring House is one of more than 20 designated stops on the Taste Trail, a self-guided route that links some of Prince Edward County's finest restaurants, artisanal food producers and wineries. Consider it a delectable connect-the-dots game that introduces visitors to the island's epicureans.
One path leads from Picton eastward along County Road 8. The scenery shifts between undulating fields rich with apple orchards and pristine vineyards on one side to stunning inlets on the other. There's no clutter in sight, and the crisp breeze over the water adds an air of calm.
A sign points to the Fifth Town Artisan Cheese Company, an environmentally responsible producer of cheese made with fresh, local goat and sheep milk. Owner Petra Cooper, co-founder of the Ontario Cheese Society, is considered a visionary. Fifth Town's production facility is the first in North America to earn the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) platinum designation, and it won the 2009 Ontario Premier's Award for Agri-Food Innovation Excellence.
Since opening two years ago, Fifth Town has revived the tradition of cheese-making in the County and Cooper has single-handedly taken charge. "It's all about the chemistry," she says. "I'm in the caves every day checking the cheese to make sure that everything is just right." Her formula seems to be working. Cape Vessey, Fifth Town's first hard cheese, won Grand Champion Goat Cheese at the 2008 Royal Winter Fair.
Cooper is not the only County up-and-comer. Torontonian Mark Bartkiw, a photographer by profession, has unveiled an organically grown pick-your-own vegetable, fruit and flower farm in Big Island. "My wife and I had always fantasized about living in the country, but we didn't intend to farm when we moved here three years ago," Bartkiw says. "After living here for a year, I was so inspired by the land."
In addition to the pick-your-own product, Bartkiw has a market stand that has become a daily stop for residents and day trippers. Community kinship is a cornerstone in Prince Edward County. "There is a great deal of collaboration between businesses here. People really work together to help deliver an outstanding experience to visitors," says Karin Potters, owner of Pinch Gourmet, a shop that sells everything from locally produced sausage to organic smoked salmon to hand-baked oat biscuits. Potters's husband, Michael, is owner and head chef at Harvest restaurant. Of the many wines featured on the Harvest menu, locally grown labels are in abundance, including those by Frederic Picard of Huff Estates.
According to Picard, size and geography bind the County and set it apart. "Niagara has 25 years of growing experience and more than a hundred wineries," he says. "We're a young region and the newest Designated Viticulture Area in Ontario." More established County estates such as Closson Chase Vineyards, founded in the late 1990s by esteemed viticulturist Deborah Paskus (a pioneer of the new County terroir), have been joined by the award-winning vintages of Huff, Waupoos and Norman Hardie Winery. One of the latest estates to make its mark is Redtail Vineyard, Canada's first off-grid winery, which produces up to 700 cases a year.
And it's not just food and wine producers who are chipping in. Prince Edward County's arts scene is also emerging. Its jazz festival is expanding, it has a vibrant theatre program, and the Arts Trail - a route of more than 20 artists and galleries around the island - is gaining exposure. Visitors can stop in at a variety of exhibition spaces, from Mad Dog Gallery, in a renovated timber-framed barn, to the new Oeno Gallery, housed in a contemporary light-filled space on the grounds of Huff Estates.
Oeno co-owner Carlyn Moulton moved to the County in 2004. Like other big-city transplants, she can't imagine living anywhere else. "It's a real place," she says, "not just one fabricated for tourists."

No way to fuhgeddaboutit. FBI bust of mayors, rabbis in New Jersey raises eyebrows

Author: Sinclair, Stewart

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/no-way-fuhgeddaboutit-fbi-bust-mayors-rabbis-new/docview/382617293/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "New Jersey's corruption problem is one of the worst, if not the worst, in the nation," Ed Kahrer, who is in charge of the FBI's white collar investigative unit, said following the arrests. "Corruption is a cancer that is destroying the core values of this state."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+way+to+fuhgeddaboutit.+FBI+bust+of+mayors%2C+rabbis+in+New+Jersey+raises+eyebrows&amp;author=Sinclair%2C+Stewart&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-25&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+way+to+fuhgeddaboutit.+FBI+bust+of+mayors%2C+rabbis+in+New+Jersey+raises+eyebrows&amp;author=Sinclair%2C+Stewart&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-25&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: When Frank Hague died, more than 50 years ago, the long-time mayor of Jersey City left behind an estate valued at $10-million (U.S.). Although his salary never topped a few thousand dollars a year, he managed to accumulate most of this fortune while in office - quite literally.
Mr. Hague sat behind an antique "partners" desk, which he custom-fitted with a drawer that could be extended outward, into the laps of his visitors.
Those who had come seeking favours would place an envelope of cash in the tray, and then push it back.
In other states, Mr. Hague would be reduced to a historical footnote by now, the relic of a bygone era in which political strongmen were allowed to flourish. In New Jersey, however, he continues to serve as a role model, the spiritual godfather to a mind-boggling parade of elected officials who have been tarred by scandal.
On Thursday, police arrested three state mayors as part of a wide-ranging investigation into money-laundering and corruption. In total, 44 people - including five rabbis - were charged with an assortment of crimes, from accepting bribes to harvesting organs.
Even by the sordid standards of New Jersey, where sleazy dealings have become so commonplace that even the governor publicly jokes about them, this week's FBI crackdown left people slack-jawed.
"New Jersey's corruption problem is one of the worst, if not the worst, in the nation," Ed Kahrer, who is in charge of the FBI's white collar investigative unit, said following the arrests. "Corruption is a cancer that is destroying the core values of this state."
Popular culture, from television series like The Sopranos to films like On The Waterfront , has long fetishized New Jersey as a playground for furtive kickbacks, shady politicians, and mobsters of all stripes.
The question is: Why here? Why does New Jersey, more than any other state, seem to have cornered the market on corrupt officials?
"I think there is a culture in the state which, if it does not promote corruption, certainly tolerates it," said Bob Ingle, a veteran reporter and co-author of The Sopranos State , a book that chronicles New Jersey's seamy political past. "In Indiana, if you hold two public jobs it's a felony. In New Jersey if you hold two public jobs, you're a slacker."
Tolerance is an understatement. Billy Musto, a former mayor of Union City, was re-elected in 1982, just one day after he was jailed for racketeering.
Over the past eight years alone, more than 130 New Jersey officials have been charged with crimes.
The structure of politics in New Jersey makes it unusually susceptible to these kinds of problems. There is a tradition here of incredibly powerful municipal governments - there are 566 self-governing communities in the state - and incredibly weak state governments. And despite the corruption, many citizens are reluctant to change the system and consolidate political power at the regional or state level.
"Mayors have a lot of power, and because of this, all of the development rules and planning has to be done at the local level," said Ingrid Reed, a professor at Rutgers University.
"And many local governments are so small that they don't have professional staff."
The indictments handed down by the FBI on Thursday could have been lifted from an episode of The Sopranos .
Two years ago, police nabbed a real estate developer named Solomon Dwek for allegedly attempting to pass a fake cheque for $25-million. Mr. Dwek agreed to become an informant, and then, wearing a wire, offered bribes to dozens of elected officials, including the mayors of Hoboken and Seacaucus.
At the same time, Mr. Dwek asked several prominent members of a local Syrian Jewish community, including five rabbis, to help him launder his money so that he could conceal his assets. In a grisly sidebar, Mr. Dwek asked one man, Levy-Izhak Rosenbaum, a suspected organ peddler, if he could help him procure a kidney. Mr. Rosenbaum allegedly told him he had been harvesting and selling organs for years.
Even Mr. Ingle, a student of New Jersey corruption, was stunned by the indictments.
"Body parts selling is rare, even for New Jersey," he conceded. "I'm used to seeing police bring [arrested politicians] in in one bus. But this was three buses."

A former TV anchor's retreat

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/former-tv-anchors-retreat/docview/382616676/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We wanted something that looked like it belonged here," says Mr. Trueman. He describes the style of the house as "the kind of thing that lined the St. Lawrence all the way to the sea in the late 1700s and early 1800s."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+former+TV+anchor%27s+retreat&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-24&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+former+TV+anchor%27s+retreat&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-24&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Peter Trueman used to read the evening news. Now, bird watching headlines a tranquil retirement on Amherst Island
So often on a Friday afternoon, Peter Trueman reminisces, he seemed to be dashing out of the studios at Global TV in order to get to the dock at Millhaven, Ont. From there, he would catch the ferry to Amherst Island.
"I would get on the boat and just feel the cares of the world sliding off my shoulders."
It wasn't long before the prominent news anchor decided that he preferred the serenity of Amherst to the broadcast studio.
In 1988, Mr. Trueman gave up his high-profile career in television to move full-time to the island with his wife, Eleanor Trueman.
At the time, Mr. Trueman was well-known across Canada as anchor for 15 years of the Ottawa-based World Report newscast. Before that, he worked for the Montreal Star and Toronto Star and Canadian Broadcasting Corp. during a career that saw the family re-locate 17 times.
Now, after more than 20 years in one place, the Truemans are ready to downsize and settle in the nearby town of Kingston, Ont. for a time.
Their house is currently co-listed for sale with Carolyn McIntire Smyth of Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd., Johnston and Daniel Division and Dave and Diane Hieatt of Royal LePage ProAlliance Realty. The asking price is $589,000.
The Truemans discovered Amherst Island while on a journey by boat down the Rideau River en route to the United States. They harboured in Stella Bay and took time to explore the island, which measures about 20 kilometres long and 5 kilometres wide, with Lake Ontario to the south and the north channel of the Bay of Quinte to the north.
The Truemans were immediately captivated by the bucolic farmland, stony beaches, and the tiny hamlet of Stella, which seemed virtually unchanged since the 1930s.
"We loved the ambience."
The couple purchased five acres of land on the south shore with 435 feet of shoreline on Lake Ontario.
"What we were both looking for was that water horizon - the hard, blue line of that horizon," Mr. Trueman said during a recent tour of the property, gesturing out towards the lake.
The couple chose plans for a house modelled after the historic two-storey inns that were once common in the area. An upstairs balcony and lower porch extend along the front façade.
"We wanted something that looked like it belonged here," says Mr. Trueman. He describes the style of the house as "the kind of thing that lined the St. Lawrence all the way to the sea in the late 1700s and early 1800s."
The custom-built house has four bedrooms and three bathrooms. A large living room has windows looking out on three sides.
The kitchen has views across the water towards smaller Nut Island.
"Doing the dishes is not really a trial," says Ms. Trueman.
The dining room overlooks green lawns and farmer's fields. The couple's three children and 11 grandchildren often gather there.
Upstairs, a bedroom and sitting room were designed as a separate suite. Today Mr. Trueman uses the sitting room as his office.
A cherry tree outside the window is laden with fruit.
"It had 7 cherries on it the first year," says Ms. Trueman. "It has certainly made up for it since."
The Truemans spend much of their time outdoors. Ms. Trueman paints watercolours and Mr. Trueman has made a hobby of photographing the island's scenery and wildlife.
"It's hard not to," he says.
The island is on a migratory bird route. The Truemans report sightings of tundra swans, Great Blue herons, goldfinches and yellow warblers. Species of owls include Boreal, Great Horned, Long-eared and Great Grey.
Deer, coyotes and foxes also abound.
The first year, Mr. Trueman says, "we found ourselves running from window to window."
Lake Ontario is very popular with sailors, while the more sheltered Bay of Quinte on the other side of the island also attracts sail and speed boats. The Truemans sometimes take a canoe or kayak out from the rocky beach at the foot of their bluffs, but the ride can be wild.
"You treat Lake Ontario with a lot of respect."
The island's 400 or so residents include farmers, cottagers and people who commute to work on the mainland.
"We all know each other," says Mr. Trueman. "We recognize each other by our cars."
There is a local farmer's market on the island, and the shops, restaurants, theatres and attractions of Kingston are a ferry ride and a short drive away.
United Empire Loyalists were the first to settle on the island in the 1790s. Then, immigrants from Ireland began farming. Many of those living on Amherst today are descendants of those early families from the Ards Peninsula in Ireland.
Ms. McIntire-Smyth also lives on the island. She's related to the family which operated Stella's renowned cheese factory, founded in the 1860s.
"Amherst Island cheese was sent all over North America and to England," she says.
One measure of the compact size and long-established history of Amherst Island is a guide to local attractions, in which the history and architectural details of singular houses and farms are described.
Even individual sheep are named. Icicle, for example, lives on a farm established in 1850. The highly personable sheep gives a "high five", bestows kisses and loves to roam freely, according to the guidebook.
The astonishingly-detailed account by island resident Judith Harrower also includes anecdotes about the occupations, lifestyles, ancestors, mortgages, marriages, offspring, political affiliations, paint colours and foibles of generations of island residents.
Ms. Harrower provides quirky stories of an array of local characters, including a grandmother who stood up to attackers and saved the family's wealth during the Rebellions of 1837.
An abandoned house nearby is identified as the former home to a bachelor who took his potatoes to bed with him in winter to keep them from freezing.
Ms. McIntire-Smyth says that kind of lore is typical of the island's culture because so many families have deep-set roots.
Mr. Trueman has continued his journalism career while living on Amherst Island. He has written newspaper columns, taken to the airwaves again on local radio and hosted a television series called Great Canadian Parks.
The latter he calls "the best job I ever had".
"The worst part of that was missing summers on the island," Mr. Trueman says. "This place has been a wonderful haven."
