BLOOR AND SOUTH KINGSWAY

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bloor-south-kingsway/docview/382615953/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It's a really short walk to Bloor Street, but it's still really tucked away," he says. "It's quite beautiful that way."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BLOOR+AND+SOUTH+KINGSWAY&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-24&amp;spage=G.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BLOOR+AND+SOUTH+KINGSWAY&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-24&amp;spage=G.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 143 Deforest Rd.
Asking price: $959,000
Selling price: $970,000
Previous selling price: $445,500 (1999)
Taxes: $5,923 (2008)
Lot size: 45 by 110 feet
Days on the market: 11
Listing agent:
Theodore Babiak, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd.
This two-storey house is close to a busy street, but few would know it standing on the professionally landscaped grounds overlooking a small park at the end of the cul-de-sac, agent Theodore Babiak says.
"It's a really short walk to Bloor Street, but it's still really tucked away," he says. "It's quite beautiful that way."
Adding to the picturesque setting are perennial flowers and a flagstone pathway encircling the south-facing backyard.
About 20 years ago, a previous owner - local architect, Ronald Raanan Matthews - altered the 1940s house to make the most of its scenic surroundings and sunny exposures.
There is a large sliding door to a steel beam framed deck off the family room and a heated solarium off the fireside living room.
Skylights are installed in two out of three full bathrooms and one bedroom upstairs, while triangular, greenhouse-style windows protrude from three other bedrooms.
"The light in this house is fantastic," the agent says.
Within the past decade, the sellers gave the 2,168-square-foot house new roofing, updated wiring, and stainless steel kitchen appliances, among other things.
The cosmetic makeover consisted of freshly painted interiors, leaded glass French doors in the office, and new hardwood, carpeting, ceramic tile and granite finishes throughout.
"In every part of the house, there were things that were done to update the place," Mr. Babiak says. "It was really a carefree home."
Other notable features include custom cupboards in the eat-in kitchen, built-in speakers in several rooms and a master bathroom with heated floors, a glass shower stall and built-in storage.
In the refinished basement, there is a recreation room with a home theatre system and side exit, a powder room and access to a revamped garage.

____________________________________________________________

Limestone house on a hill gets the full treatment

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/limestone-house-on-hill-gets-full-treatment/docview/382615634/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "The setting is spectacular," Mr. [Jim Brunow] says. "There are views in every direction including the Big Head River Valley, the Niagara Escarpment and Georgian Bay. On a clear day you can see all the way to Christian Island."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Limestone+house+on+a+hill+gets+the+full+treatment&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-24&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Limestone+house+on+a+hill+gets+the+full+treatment&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-24&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Built in 1860, heritage home sucked up both time and money in a thorough renovation
137292 Grey Road 12
What: A landmark limestone house set on 100 acres of softly rolling hills near Meaford, Ont. Besides the 2-storey main residence, the property includes a large barn in pristine condition, presently used for storage, as well as a small guest cottage presently being rented out to out-of-towners on sabbatical.
Living space: 4,000 square feet
Asking price: $2.75-million
Taxes: $2,012 (2009)
Agent: Clairwood Real Estate Corp. (Sherry Rioux)
Jim Brunow worked as a government accountant before retiring in 2006 to pursue his hobby of restoring century-old Ontario homes.
The latest of these, where he now lives full-time with partner Sue LaVigne, is a Georgian style house perched high on a hill with unobstructed views of the Niagara Escarpment and Georgian Bay.
"The setting is spectacular," Mr. Brunow says. "There are views in every direction including the Big Head River Valley, the Niagara Escarpment and Georgian Bay. On a clear day you can see all the way to Christian Island."
Originally built in 1860, the main residence is made of hand-hewn limestone, a specialty of Scottish settlers who settled there in the late 19th century on crown land they received as United Empire Loyalists.
So many Scots emigrated to the area that the rise of the Niagara Escarpment where the house is located is called Scotch Mountain. There, "the soil is as fertile as any found in St. Vincent Township," says Mr. Brunow, quoting from a local history book published by the St. Vincent Heritage Association.
His house is also mentioned in the book, with a description of the original owner, one James Storey who heralded from Roxburghshire, Scotland. Unfortunately, little more is known of him.
But the elegant layout and harmonic proportions of his four bedroom, three -bathroom house suggests he may have been a man of considerable pride and taste.
Proof lies in some of the original details that Mr. Brunow discovered when he first bought the house in 1993, including a hand-carved banister on a pine staircase leading from the front foyer up to the second floor.
Having only four previous owners, the house had not undergone many changes over time, a situation both good and bad according to the present homeowner.
Good, because it allowed Mr. Brunow, a stickler for historic detail - most of the lighting and plumbing fixtures, including a copper claw foot tub with oak trim, were all fastidiously sourced from antique sales and shows across the province - to determine what the house must have first looked like.
Bad, because it was run down, and required large amounts of both time and money to whip it back into shape.
As Mr. Brunow explains it, the house had to be gutted and rebuilt, with the remaining original detail supplemented by reproductions created by local craftsman, including oversized clear pine trim, plaster cornice mouldings, solid wood doors and solid brass hardware.
The pine floors were restored and all the stonework repainted.
Besides a new roof, Mr. Brunow also built a new two-storey addition onto the back of the house that now houses a sunroom.
On the upper floor, the addition makes room for an expanded (19- by 20-foot) master bedroom with cathedral ceilings, heated floors and sunken ensuite with windows opening onto a mature hardwood forest.
While the house now has two furnaces, the renovated kitchen also features a new $6,000 cast iron wood stove that provides added warmth in winter.
Also in the kitchen, local carpenter Kim Hall, from nearby Thornbury, Ont., has created a large central island made of wood distressed to look as if it were original.
Mr. Hall also made the wooden window frames, each one hand carved, basing their thickness on what had originally been in the house.
"I've always appreciated the quality and craftsmanship of century homes in Ontario," Mr. Brunow says.
"Restoring this home was a labour of love."

City will refund fees paid for camps, lessons

Author: Lewington, Jennifer

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/city-will-refund-fees-paid-camps-lessons/docview/382618248/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Councillor Case Ootes (Ward 29, Toronto-Danforth), spokesman for the right-leaning Responsible Government Group, said there was no reason to cancel the July 6 meeting "other than he [Mr. [David Miller]] did not want to have his NDP caucus cross the picket line."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=City+will+refund+fees+paid+for+camps%2C+lessons&amp;author=Lewington%2C+Jennifer&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-23&amp;spage=A.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=City+will+refund+fees+paid+for+camps%2C+lessons&amp;author=Lewington%2C+Jennifer&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-23&amp;spage=A.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: But property-tax rebate ruled out
CITY HALL BUREAU CHIEF
Toronto residents will receive refunds for children's day camps, swimming lessons and leadership programs cancelled because of the city workers strike.
At a city hall press conference, Mayor David Miller ruled out a rebate on property taxes that help pay for city services suspended since the strike by Locals 79 and 416 of the Canadian Union of Public Employees began June 22.
"We won't be doing that," he said.
More details of the city refunds are expected to be released today.
As for possible relief on garbage collection fees - a new pay-as-you-throw system is in its first full year of operation - Mr. Miller said no decision has been made.
"There are a number of alternatives we could pursue," he said.
As well, the mayor announced a special council meeting at city hall for Aug. 5 and 6 to deal with about 50 "truly urgent" items left in limbo when a July 6 council meeting was cancelled because of the strike.
But if the labour dispute is settled before Aug. 5, Mr. Miller said he would scrap the two-day session and hold a full council meeting the following week.
Leading the list of "urgent" items is the selection of a private sector investor, possibly the real-estate arm of a major pension fund, to refurbish of city-owned Union Station.
Council would also be asked to approve final plans for the Sony Centre condo, clearing the way to complete renovation of the Sony Centre for the Performing Arts, dark for the past year.
Some of the mayor's council critics have clamoured for a meeting with a wider agenda, including a mandatory freeze on a 2.4-per-cent cost of living raise for councillors and a debate about the ongoing strike by 30,000 civic workers.
Councillor Case Ootes (Ward 29, Toronto-Danforth), spokesman for the right-leaning Responsible Government Group, said there was no reason to cancel the July 6 meeting "other than he [Mr. Miller] did not want to have his NDP caucus cross the picket line."
At his press conference, Mr. Miller said the city's medical officer of health had ordered pesticide spraying of Campbell Park and a pickup of illegal garbage dumped at Bluffers Park, both stymied by pickets.
If the work cannot be carried out, the mayor said the city would seek court injunctions.
Neither the mayor nor spokesmen for the two CUPE locals had much to say about the progress of talks on new contracts to replace those that expired Dec. 31.
As of yesterday, the city reported that 824 unionized workers had asked to cross the picket lines and return to their jobs.
Approvals have been given for 597 so far.
***
Strike refunds
For which programs
will the city refund fees?
The city says it will return fees for all city-run day camps, swimming lessons and leadership programs cancelled because of the strike.
The city's FUN Guide lists hundreds of summer camp programs at more than 230 locations throughout the city, with many costing hundreds of dollars per session.
The guide also lists summer swimming programs for all ages at more than 80 pools throughout the city, which cost about $30 to $70 per week.
Leadership programs include babysitting training and other courses, such as Leaders in Training and the Youth Advisory Council.
The city began processing refunds on Monday and says those who are entitled to them should receive refunds by the end of July. Check bank and credit card statements as well as the mail for cheques.
Will the city refund fees for permits?
All other refunds, including fees paid for city permits, will be dealt with once the strike ends, the city says.
How will the city return advances paid to daycares?
Refunds for child-care fees paid in advance will be made as an adjustment to families' accounts, and invoices will be sent once centres reopen.
Will the city provide partial property tax refunds?
No.
Will the city refund garbage fees?
The city has not made a decision about whether it will refund garbage fees, but the mayor says he is considering options.
Jill Colvin

Vancouver ousts Calgary as Canada's highest net worth city

Author: Scoffield, Heather; Ebner, David

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/vancouver-ousts-calgary-as-canadas-highest-net/docview/382619204/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "The difference in Vancouver is it's more diverse than a lot of areas in Canada," Mr. [Sebastian Albrecht] says. "Calgary has oil. Toronto is finance. Here, there's a lot of creativity. I'm amazed how some people make money here."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vancouver+ousts+Calgary+as+Canada%27s+highest+net+worth+city&amp;author=Scoffield%2C+Heather%3BEbner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-20&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vancouver+ousts+Calgary+as+Canada%27s+highest+net+worth+city&amp;author=Scoffield%2C+Heather%3BEbner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-20&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Vancouver has stolen Calgary's crown as the city with the highest net worth.
In a soon-to-be-published database that looks at how Canadians handled their wealth during the rapid change of fortunes that marred 2008, Environics Analytics exposes profound changes in the way people approach their wealth.
Canadians have seen their nest eggs shrivel, beefed up their savings, scaled back their borrowing, and embraced caution, an abrupt change in attitude that will likely persist, says Catherine Pearson, vice-president of Environics Analytics in Toronto.
Generally, the research, which crunches and dissects numbers from 80 different sources and goes into deep local detail, found that the richer Canadians were, the harder they fell.
"The more money you have, the more you have to lose," Ms. Pearson said.
In Calgary, net worth fell as the value of household investments plunged and debt climbed.
In Vancouver, though, consumers saved more and real estate fared better last year.
Net worth, which measures someone's assets minus debts, dropped 6.2 per cent for Canadians as a whole last year. But Calgary residents saw their wealth plunge 12.3 per cent, while Vancouver's residents were able to hang on to much of their riches. There, net worth fell just 3.1 per cent between December, 2007, and December, 2008.
Now Vancouver's residents have taken first place for household net worth, while Calgary has fallen to second place.
Vancouverite Sebastian Albrecht rode that Pacific wave. He has a lot of his money tied up in real estate. And it's these investments - with prices down less than 10 per cent from their peak last year - that has made the city surrounded by mountains and ocean the richest in Canada, supplanting the country's energy capital Calgary.
Mr. Albrecht bought his first condo a decade ago, after university. He stretched himself - and slept in a sleeping bag on the floor for a couple months in the unfurnished home.
A decade later, he lives in a $600,000 home that he bought two years ago for $500,000 and also owns - and rents out - a $350,000 town home and a $300,000 condo. He has some money in stocks, but only about 10 per cent of his net worth.
Born in the city, an entrepreneur at heart, the 34-year-old worked in IT and then started a clothing import-export business and dabbled in real estate - until he became a realtor himself three years ago, a perch from which he sees a cross-section of Vancouver and the people who generate the city's wealth. From movie makers to junior mining players, it is a diffuse mix.
"The difference in Vancouver is it's more diverse than a lot of areas in Canada," Mr. Albrecht says. "Calgary has oil. Toronto is finance. Here, there's a lot of creativity. I'm amazed how some people make money here."
Vancouver's net worth per household is an average of $575,826, while Calgary's is $569,926, the research shows.
Compare that with Newfoundland, where household net worth is typically $140,706, or even to Ontario, where average household wealth is $354,968.
Most of Calgary's losses stemmed from a plunge in the value of investments held by households, such as stocks, bonds and mutual funds. At the same time, Calgarians took on large liabilities in the past year, and Calgary is now the home of the most heavily indebted people in Canada. Albertans in general have 30 per cent more consumer debt than the average Canadian, the research shows. And the mortgage debt of many young people has soared.
"Perhaps they simply haven't realized the fact that the heady boom days are now over," the researchers said in their analysis.
Vancouver residents, on the other hand, were able to mitigate their exposure to the ravages of the recession by increasing savings, and by benefiting from more stability in the housing market in 2008.
The survey doesn't cover 2009. In the first six months of this year, prices for existing homes were down 8.6 per cent in Vancouver from the same period of last year, and 9.8 per cent in Calgary, resale statistics show.
Perhaps because they're less wounded than the rest of the country, British Columbians are piling back into the stock market faster than elsewhere.
But people in Quebec and Ontario are gun-shy, and are stashing away any extra money they have in safe places. Quebec households in particular have low credit card debt, and boosted their holdings of sure-thing guaranteed investment certificates by 5 per cent over the course of the year. Deposits in banks and credit unions have risen 4.9 per cent.
People in Ontario, where the recession has hit hardest, increased their term deposits by 15.3 per cent and increased their debt loads by just 3.0 per cent - much less than the national average increase of 8.1 per cent.
"Hats off to Ontario households for being fiscally responsible," the researchers said.
Still, Ontarians were paying dearly for such debt. Residents were using 7.1 per cent of their disposable income to pay interest charges - 20-per-cent higher than the national average of 6.3 per cent. In Alberta, servicing non-mortgage debt ate up just 6.1 per cent of discretionary income, despite the rising debt loads.
Indeed, Albertans' discretionary income was higher than anywhere else in the country, at $53,237 per household. That was 29-per-cent higher than second-place Ontario.
The oil-rich province may have been hammered by the global recession, but households still have plenty of wealth. "Alberta's got the spending power," the researchers conclude.

Hollywood loves this big-screen chameleon

Author: Schneller, Johanna

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/hollywood-loves-this-big-screen-chameleon/docview/382618167/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: 's run for a third week. "I don't know if it's the record for the longest we've shown one film, but it's close," he said. "We're getting nice feedback, though people do snicker when they see the artificial mountains."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hollywood+loves+this+big-screen+chameleon&amp;author=Schneller%2C+Johanna&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-18&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hollywood+loves+this+big-screen+chameleon&amp;author=Schneller%2C+Johanna&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-18&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: With small-town charm and film-friendly tax perks, Rockport, Mass. is getting plenty of screen time, whether it's playing itself or not
jschneller@globeandmail.com
I spent last week in Rockport, Mass., which initially seems as far from Hollywood as you can get, both geographically and psychologically. Settled in the 1620s, it's a former fishing village northeast of Boston on the tip of Cape Ann. It boasts 238-year-old twin lighthouses on Thacher Island, and granite from its quarries helped build Chicago and New York in the 1800s. It's now full of quaintly rickety fish shacks, art galleries and ice-cream shops, and the empty quarries have become spookily sensual swimming holes. But the more I hung around, the more I realized that Hollywood's tentacles reach, and are eagerly embraced, everywhere.
My first tipoff was the poster on the Little Arts Cinema, which is normally a haven for subtitled European fare. But for the last two weeks, the theatre has been showing The Proposal , the paint-by-numbers romantic comedy starring Sandra Bullock and Ryan Reynolds that's grossed $115-million (U.S.) so far. The theatre's answering machine informs callers that the movie was "filmed last year in Rockport, and shows nightly at 7 and 9."
My second clue was running into Adam Sandler on a Sunday morning at a breakfast joint called Charlie's, which is usually more famous for its Portuguese sausage and anadama bread (a local specialty made with molasses) than its clientele. It turns out Sandler's in town shooting Grown Ups , a comedy scheduled for 2010 about five friends who reunite 30 years after their high-school graduation for a Fourth of July weekend. It's a wonder we didn't see more cast members, since they are legion, including Salma Hayek, Steve Buscemi, Kevin James and enough Saturday Night Live alums to form their own reunion.
My third hint was the Perfect Storm map that directs visitors to sites around Rockport and its neighbour Gloucester where the 2000 movie, starring George Clooney and Mark Wahlberg, was filmed. It's a tragedy, about real-life local fisherman whose names, sadly, are now inscribed on a Gloucester monument commemorating "they that go down to the sea in ships." But that hasn't dissuaded the tourists - they continue to come in such numbers that the Cape Ann Chamber of Commerce hung the map in its lobby.
Hollywood is invading because Massachusetts is inviting it to. The commonwealth dramatically upgraded its tax credits in 2006, giving filmmakers back 25 cents for every dollar they spend, with no pre-authorization and no caps. They're also exempt from sales tax on any production-related purchases made in the state. As a result, 25 major movies have been filmed in Massachusetts in the past three years including Ghosts of Girlfriends Past (shot in the Crane Estate, the same place where Jack Nicholson lived in The Witches of Eastwick ) and The Proposal .
I found it odd, however, that Rockport has embraced The Proposal so whole-heartedly. Though some of its landmarks appear on screen - including Motif No. 1, a red shack covered in buoys - the film isn't set there. The story takes place in Sitka, Alaska; snow-capped peaks have been CGI'd behind the fishing boats.
But Bob Hastings, the executive director of the Cape Ann Chamber of Commerce, set me straight. "Everyone loved having the film here, with Betty White downtown and so on," he said. Whenever Cape Ann appears on screen, whether it's playing itself or not, it sees a rise in "after-fact tourism" from travel-minded audiences savvy enough to stick around to spot the location in a film's closing credits. And then there's all the lovely dough the filmmakers spend while shooting.
" Grown Ups paid a lot of money to rent a city property in Essex, and on top of that they completely renovated it," Hastings said. "And the stars all rent homes on the water, which they pay top dollar for, tens of thousands of dollars." Actors like shooting here, he added, because "residents think it's fun, but they're not overwhelmed. There's no autograph seeking."
Bullock did make local headlines in April 2008 when the car she and her husband, Jesse James, were riding in through Gloucester was hit by a native, 64-year-old Lucile Gatchell. No one was hurt, but Gatchell, who blew more than twice the legal limit on the Breathalyzer, was arrested and charged with operating under the influence. Crowds lined Main Street to watch Bullock film one scene, largely because she got to drive up it the wrong way. And Arnie Morton, who runs the Little Arts Cinema, just extended The Proposal 's run for a third week. "I don't know if it's the record for the longest we've shown one film, but it's close," he said. "We're getting nice feedback, though people do snicker when they see the artificial mountains."
During Sandler's breakfast outing, Charlie's was packed; people waiting for tables wrote their first names on a whiteboard, and the line stretched out the door. Sandler's party of 11 (his two kids, plus his wife, nanny and various relatives) was right behind my party of five, and he was waiting like everybody else.
Well, not quite like everybody else. When Sandler went to put his name on the board, the woman ahead of me called out, "I gotcha, Adam," and wrote down his full name, "Adam Sandler," with a flourish. Then her husband took a picture of it on his cellphone - the whiteboard, not the actor.
In the restaurant, Sandler seated himself against a wall so it was hard for people to get at him, but in the parking lot with his restless kids, a stream of fans hit him up for cellphone photos.
I was momentarily impressed by our teenaged waitress, who bustled around him coolly. But then I saw her recognize him: She stood stock-still and stared at him for a full minute.
The truth is, for all its scrappy history, Rockport is like everywhere else in the United States, subject to the siren song of the silver screen. Hollywood is so pervasive in American culture, and the air its celebrities breathe seems so rarefied, that ordinary mortals can't help but delight in accidental encounters with stars - or in merely standing in the spot where one recently stood. When you're in the same place as Them, you can believe that your life is the same as Theirs, if just for a moment.
"A friend of mine had the good fortune of being on a stationary bike at the YMCA right behind Salma Hayek," Hastings said. Who could argue with the joys of that?

Star's kitchen a cut above

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/stars-kitchen-cut-above/docview/382619653/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "I'm all about sharp knives, and I sharpen them all myself," said the 50-year-old thespian recently as he cut through a mango with lightening speed, in preparation for lunch. "I go through the back door of restaurants around town asking to cut their knives. I try to practice, whenever and wherever I can. I use a sharpening stone soaked in water. It's not easy. But it's fun - if you like that kind of thing."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Star%27s+kitchen+a+cut+above&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-17&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Star%27s+kitchen+a+cut+above&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-17&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Is this a dagger I see before me? No, but Shakespearean actor Colm Feore has lots of other sharp things in his kitchen. Deidre Kelly reports Is this a dagger I see before me? No, but Shakespearean actor Colm Feore has lots of other sharp things in his kitchen. Deirdre Kelly reports
Actor Colm Feore has a thing for sharp, pointed objects.
In Macbeth , which he is currently starring in at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, he hallucinates about daggers, and in Cyrano de Bergerac , he thrusts swords into enemies and barbed words into the ears of dolts.
But this is all child's play in comparison to the quantity and variety of knives that this blade of the stage wields inside his own home, located in Stratford. There, in a large, open-concept kitchen designed to accommodate the full range of his far-reaching culinary skills - his other passion - Mr. Feore performs some of his more dexterous acts with a vast array of cutting utensils kept inside custom-made beech drawers.
Among them are carving knives, paring knives and melon slicers, serrated knives for bread and Yanagi knives for sushi. There are also ham-fisted cleavers and thin filleting knives, stub-nosed knives to spread butter and thick-bladed knives to shuck oysters.
All are honed to within an inch of their metallic lives and no wonder, when it is Mr. Feore doing the sharpening. Call it his backstage job.
"I'm all about sharp knives, and I sharpen them all myself," said the 50-year-old thespian recently as he cut through a mango with lightening speed, in preparation for lunch. "I go through the back door of restaurants around town asking to cut their knives. I try to practice, whenever and wherever I can. I use a sharpening stone soaked in water. It's not easy. But it's fun - if you like that kind of thing."
And Mr. Feore clearly does, making knives something of a hobby (shopping the world for them, and happy to get knives as gifts), if not an obsession.
When he goes to someone's house, he doesn't bring a bottle of wine as much as his own knives, wrapped inside a soft-cover, roll-up carrying case. These he calls his travelling knives, which he also takes to Los Angeles when making one of his many films: "The bottom line is you go to someone's house, and you want to cook, and they hand you a 50-cent knife. I mean, it just can't work."
To minimize these encounters of the dull kind, Mr. Feore often plays it safe by cooking at home where he knows the kitchen is as sharply efficient as one of his steel blades.
He designed it mostly himself, in consultation with local architect Michael Wilson, who built an addition onto Mr. Feore's vintage Arts and Crafts house (where an outdoor pool once was) in order to accommodate everything his exacting client wanted in this room of his own.
This included a heated travertine floor, three fridges of various sizes, including one in a central island with a black marble countertop, and a 60-inch-wide, stainless steel Viking double-oven range, equipped with six burners and rolled steel on which Mr. Feore flips his made-from-scratch pancakes - a skill he says he learned on the set of the 2002 television miniseries, Trudeau .
While he shares the 1917 house with his three children and wife Donna Feore, the Stratford director who this season directed her husband in Cyrano (past collaborations include the 2006 production of Oliver! ), the kitchen is his domain: "I do all the cooking here. Donna doesn't cook, if she can help it, at all."
Her main contribution lies in the choice of an original porthole, taken from the docks of Montreal, as a window that looks out from the kitchen into the side foyer. "Donna likes round windows," says Mr. Feore, adding that the design element is repeated elsewhere in the four-bedroom, three-bathroom stone house with a fenced-in, landscaped garden. He likes them too, he says, especially at Halloween when he uses the porthole to "pull a Richard Dreyfus," while vocalizing the theme from Jaws .
The Feores have owned the house for 12 years, but didn't start the renovation until 2002. It took a year to complete, with the actor and his family moving across the street to a friend's house to wait it out. The result is a room that Mr. Feore calls "not too formal, but very functional," with high vaulted ceilings and windows for walls to enhance what he calls "an indoor/outdoor feel."
Ms. Feore enjoys conducting business at home, and so the kitchen enlarges into a big dining and family room (with a study area for the kids) where she and as many as six festival colleagues can sit around the dining table, thrashing out plans for a new production.
Mr. Feore feeds them all, and happily: "It gives me a sense of purpose," he says.
You think this Gemini Award-winning actor, known for his star turns in the likes of the box-office hit Bon Cop, Bad Cop and the TV-series 24is joking.
But then he fixes you with his razor-sharp gaze and you know to listen up.
"Cooking keeps me out of trouble, and it keeps me engaged in something creative," he continues, speaking slowly as he places slices of fruit around a wedge of French chocolate on offer as dessert.
"But cooking is apart from what I do where I have to take direction and go to work, and please other people. Here," he says, his knife poised in the air for emphasis, "I please myself. I make things up, come up with my own inventions."
And without fear of a bad review.
Mr. Feore adds, not putting too fine a point on it: "If people don't like the food, they don't have to eat."
Touché.
Revision date: Monday, July 20, 2009

Building on history

Author: Hadani Ditmars

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/building-on-history/docview/382619447/se-2?accountid=14656

"One of our goals in designing the mixed-use space," Mr. [Mark Ostry] says, "was to foster a sense of the alley as an urban gathering place."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Building+on+history&amp;author=Hadani+Ditmars&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-17&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Building+on+history&amp;author=Hadani+Ditmars&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-17&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: At the now complete Terminus Hotel, Acton Ostry Architects meet the challenge of melding modern living spaces with a historic frame
For many years, the old Terminus Hotel building on Water Street in historic Gastown stood like a piece of installation art. Gutted by a fire in 2000, all that was left was its 1901 façade, supported by steel columns that backed onto a vacant lot marked by crater-like excavations. Bordered to the south by Blood Alley, once a thriving commercial laneway turned hangout for the area's destitute and drug-addicted, the Terminus had already weathered the great fire of 1886 and turn-of-the century demolition before its more recent brush with mortality.
But the Terminus is nothing if not building as neighbourhood metaphor. And so just as neatly as Gastown has morphed from derelict to designer darling, with a string of new retail and restaurant options lifting the area out of its nineties slump, so too has the Terminus risen from the ashes of its former incarnations.
Developed by Vancouver-based Salient Group together with the remains of the next door Grand Hotel, it has emerged as a slick new mixed-use residential project designed by Acton Ostry Architects, with interiors by David Nicolay of Evoke International Design.
The historic Water Street entrance remains the same, with original columns in place, and it leads into a narrow corridor where original tin ceiling panels are displayed gallery style.
But, says Mark Ostry, whose firm is also designing the adjacent mixed-use residential project Garage and mixed-use commercial Alhambra, both built on the bones of venerable buildings: "We wanted to avoid anything that smacked of faux heritage. Architecture should be an expression of current culture, of its time and place."
The challenge with the project, he says, was to manage the tension between the need to respect the heritage of the building and, at the same time, to maximize density. To a certain degree this was facilitated by the interior having been completely gutted by the fire, but keeping the original façade meant that interior dimensions were often dictated by the existing structure.
To that end Mr. Nicolay, who worked closely and collaboratively with Mr. Ostry, had to be inventive with the vary narrow - 10-foot-wide units whose dimensions were set by the north-facing turn-of-the-century bay windows. (Some south-facing units that overlook Blood Alley - they benefit from a new façade built of reclaimed brick - did not have the same constraints.) The trick with the units overlooking Water Street, Mr. Nicolay says, was to play with textures and dimensions.
Just as Mr. Ostry strived to maintain the "granular" nature of the building's façade, delineating exterior space by setting back south-facing windows on the old Grand Hotel side so the building wouldn't read as single homogeneous unit, so too has Mr. Nicolay differentiated long narrow interior spaces with individual details.
While each of the 46 units has a different floor plan, many feature three-foot-wide 18-foot-long bathrooms that run the length of the entrance way. To avoid having the interior read as one continuous narrow corridor, each segment of living space has its own character, with the overall effect being a sense of calm procession.
One second-floor unit, for instance, begins with a bedroom space and built-in cabinetry that is followed by the narrow bathroom. But at this juncture the flooring changes from linear strand walnut to sand-coloured porcelain tile that also runs up the wall. The bathroom doors are frosted tempered glass. The transition into the kitchen and living space is marked by a return to walnut flooring and steel countertops with a white glass backsplash that lights up.
To address the challenge of having only one natural light source in a narrow space, Mr. Nicolay used concealed soffit lighting to illuminate the interior.
A two-storey unit plays with levels and dimensions. An entrance lobby reveals the 16-foot ceiling to the left that contrasts with the lower ceiling supporting the second floor. The result is a kind of compressed space that proceeds through the kitchen area and then steps up a few feet into a living area that reveals the full height of the ceiling once again - offering a luxurious sense of spaciousness.
It also offers a bird's-eye view of Blood Alley and the building's south-facing ground-floor space - the site of a new tapas bar by local entrepreneur Sean Heather, whose nearby Salt charcuterie bar is one of many local businesses helping to inject new life into the area. "One of our goals in designing the mixed-use space," Mr. Ostry says, "was to foster a sense of the alley as an urban gathering place."
Several storeys up, an as yet unsold 1,700-square-foot penthouse wows with its curtain wall glazing, phenomenal city view and private roof garden.
"The space is very flexible," says Mr. Ostry, noting that most of the occupied units function as living and working spaces for artists.
An adjoining communal room and roof garden offer a social area where residents can gather for a shared meal or a coffee.
Mr. Ostry cites the forward thinking of Salient Group developer Robert Fung, who "could have easily turned this into a million-dollar apartment."
But, he says, "you have to create community by design. It's a conscious decision."
The roof garden features reclaimed brick from the original building as well as extensive landscaping - with local drought resistant plants. And the view is extraordinary. From the edge of the new Woodward's building to the tip of the old Sun Tower, to the turn of the century façades on Pender Street and the backside of Arthur Erickson's Portland Hotel - it reads like an historical civic panorama.

Planetarium offers U of T world of expansion

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/planetarium-offers-u-t-world-expansion/docview/382619096/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Dr. [David Naylor]'s first winner, the university, acquired a property that is apparently needed for expansion. It's hard for me to see how the tiny planetarium site will ease the U of T's shortage of office and teaching space - But never mind: If university officials are glad to get this little patch of land, I'm happy for them.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Planetarium+offers+U+of+T+world+of+expansion&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-17&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Planetarium+offers+U+of+T+world+of+expansion&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-17&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The last plan to build a high-rise beside the ROM was scrapped. Let's not mess up a second chance
jmays@globeandmail.com
In a real-estate deal, earlier this year, that left many parties cheering, the Royal Ontario Museum (ROM) sold off the McLaughlin Planetarium site, on the south end of the venerable institution, to the University of Toronto. "This is a win-win-win for the U of T, the ROM and the public," university president David Naylor told Globe columnist John Barber at the time.
Dr. Naylor's first winner, the university, acquired a property that is apparently needed for expansion. It's hard for me to see how the tiny planetarium site will ease the U of T's shortage of office and teaching space - But never mind: If university officials are glad to get this little patch of land, I'm happy for them.
The second winner in Dr. Naylor's scenario was the museum, which netted $22-million from the sale. Having ended its recent $270-million expansion some $85-million in the hole, the ROM could certainly use the money.
Dr. Naylor's inclusion of the "public" in his list of winners, however, bothers me. I am not at all sure that the public interest has been well served by the sale. Furthermore, I believe that a remarkable opportunity to enhance Toronto's urban fabric, and the fabric of the university, could very well be lost.
To understand the nature of this loss, we have to go back four years, to the time when ROM director William Thorsell announced his intention to raise a residential tower on the planetarium site. This building, as proposed by the Toronto architectural firm of Brisbin Brook Beynon, would have had two components, a 40-storey luxury condominium block atop a five-storey, 35,000-square-foot annex to the museum.
The outcry against the tower came fast and furious, from the university as well as residents in the ROM neighbourhood. The objections were less to the specific design than to the very idea of putting up a tall building on the edge of the university precinct. To its opponents, the structure would be an impudent contradiction to the scale of the university's St. George campus, which is largely (but by no means exclusively) composed of low- to mid-rise structures. But for its principal designer, Brian Brisbin, the tower would serve as a beacon and landmark, giving a focus to the sprawling campus. The end of the affair came after a raucous public meeting in late 2005, when the ROM, admitting that the opposition was overwhelming, withdrew the scheme.
Now that the U of T controls the site, there is only the faintest chance that the tower plan will ever be revived. I believed in 2005 that the ROM's cancellation of the project was a mistake, and I believe in 2009, for the same reasons, that the university will be wrong to ignore the merits of putting up a tall building on the rubble of the mothballed planetarium.
My reasons are not complicated. If the university in fact needs more space for its activities - and I have no doubt that it does - then a mixed-use tall building, developed in a private-public investment partnership, could be an efficient, cost-effective way to get it. The planetarium site offers the university a gleaming opportunity to expand, though upward instead of outward - an attractive option, or so it seems to me, in light of the tight circumstances of the St. George campus, which is hemmed in on all sides by well-rooted neighbourhoods and institutions.
My main reason for believing the university should press on with a new mixed-use tower plan, however, has less to do with square footage than with the potentially ennobling effect of such a scheme on the city and the campus. The U of T is one of Canada's great research universities, famed for its contributions to science, the professions and the humanistic disciplines. A tall building, designed and constructed according to the highest standards, could be a visible expression of the university's stature and standing, emblazoned on the city's skyline.
It would have to be a very special building, of course; but there is nothing standing in the way of it being exactly that. Though Toronto has seldom been a beneficiary, the last decade has been a golden age of innovative, exciting skyscraper design, like nothing seen since the heyday of romantic tall buildings in the 1920s. An international competition co-ordinated by the university could attract the brightest and most talented skyscraper designers in the world, enriching the local conversation about building tall and well, and eventually giving the city and the campus a soaring structure that would declare their commitment to the best contemporary ideas of beauty, sustainability and urban form.
In buying the planetarium site, the U of T has acquired an outstanding opportunity. I hope they don't throw it away.

Full text: FRIDAY
JULY 17
DRAMA
The Outer Limits
Showcase, 7 p.m.The spirit of the creepy TV anthology lives in this filmed-in-Canada series. First broadcast on the U.S. cable channel Showtime, the show was an update of the original Outer Limits that aired in the early sixties. Tonight's show is a standout: Character actor Joe Pantoliano, best remembered from his stint as the mobster Ralph on The Sopranos , plays Stan Harbinger, a popular radio host with a reputation for debunking the supernatural. After a caller claiming to be possessed by aliens sets himself afire, Harbinger is haunted by ghostly images - and the man's distinctive triple heartbeat. Scary stuff.
MOVIE
How I Won the War
PBS, 8 p.m.Released to theatres in 1967, this movie drew notice for the presence of John Lennon in his first and only film acting role (other than Beatles films). Set during the Second World War, the black comedy stars Michael Crawford as British Army officer Lieutenant Earnest Goodbody, the ineffective leader put in charge of a fighting troop inexplicably known as the 4th Musketeers. His charges include Lennon as the lowly Musketeer Gripweed and Roy Kinnear as Musketeer Clapper. The film's anti-war sentiment is evinced in the group's meaningless activities and the platoon's repeated attempts to frag their commander. Not a classic, but Lennon is a surprisingly good actor.
CRIME DRAMA
Heartbeat
TVO, 9 p.m.Set in 1960s Yorkshire, Heartbeat began airing on ITV in 1992 and lasted 18 seasons; on more than one occasion the show earned higher ratings than Coronation Street - no small feat on U.K. television. In tonight's show, the disappearance of a local teenager leads police to suspect her American boyfriend, who was desperately trying to avoid deportation.
FOOD
Chef Abroad
Food Network, 9:30 p.m.Chef Michael Smith is the reason to watch this whimsical series seeking out exciting food experiences around the globe. In this episode, he ventures into the California kitchen of the Internet giant known as Google, where 10,000 meals are served each day. Smith adheres to the local food-prep rules - all ingredients must come from within 150 miles of the company - and adds several new menu items that have the Web-surfers buzzing.
SATURDAY jULY 18
BIOGRAPHY
Role Model: Gene Wilder
TCM, 7 p.m.
This biography of Gene Wilder is a remarkable film. The format has Alec Baldwin sitting down for an extended interview with the famed comic actor, who considers himself "semi-retired". The conversation covers the high points of Wilder's film career, including The Producers and co-writing and starring in Young Frankenstein . More touching are Wilder's memories of wife Gilda Radner, who died from ovarian cancer in 1989.
MOVIE
Wilby Wonderful
CTV, 8 p.m.Filmed on location in Shelburne, N.S., the story follows several residents of a small island named Wilby. Quirky locals include the aggressive real-estate agent Carol (Sandra Oh) and her rugged police-officer husband, Buddy (Paul Gross). Also tossed into the mix is a pre- Juno Ellen Page as the confused teen Emily and Maury Chaykin as Wilby's windbag mayor. The film follows the characters in the days leading up to Wilby's annual festival.
DRAMA
Intelligence
CBC, 10 p.m.Unlike many Canadian-made dramas, Intelligence holds up. Lasting two seasons, the show follows two intertwining storylines: Ian Tracey plays Jimmy Reardon, a likable guy making millions wheeling and dealing high-grade marijuana; Klea Scott is Organized Crime Unit director Mary Spalding, who offered Reardon prosecution immunity in exchange for his work as a police informant. In tonight's first-season episode, Reardon obtains a truckload of phony ATM machines to help him launder his drug money. The bad move: putting his shiftless brother in charge of the operation.
SUNDAY JULY 19
MOVIE
The Wizard of Oz
CBC, 5 p.m.
Holding up astoundingly well for a 70-year-old story, The Wizard of Oz remains the consummate family experience. Viewing the 1939 classic has become a TV tradition, of sorts. Parents who grew up watching Dorothy, the Scarecrow, Tin Man and the Cowardly Lion trip down the yellow brick road now pass the torch to their kids. Watch it again for the grand performances and such beautiful tunes as Over the Rainbow -voted the greatest movie song of all time by the American Film Institute.
DOCUMENTARY
MegaStructures
TVO, 7 p.m.
It's a safe bet this series is used as a teaching tool in postsecondary courses on architecture and design. Each episode is a detailed primer on a construction project of enormous scope. Some are famous and functional (ie: the Hoover Dam), others are frivolous (the Palm Islands of Dubai). Tonight: The man-made marvel of the Channel Tunnel, the 50.5 kilometre underground rail line that links England and France. The program details the engineering challenges and reveals the fierce competition between the two countries to complete the project.
DRAMA
Desperate Housewives
ABC, A, 9 p.m.
From last season, it's an episode that seems geared toward lean economic reality. Hard times hit Wisteria Lane and the principal Housewives are feeling the pinch. Normally ditzy Susan (Teri Hatcher) is forced to take a job, but full-time work is not a good fit. Slow sales force Lynette (Felicity Huffman) to consider selling the pizzeria. And impish Gaby (Eva Longoria Parker) blackmails her hubby's boss into giving him a big bonus.
CRIME DRAMA
Without a Trace
CBS, CTV, 10 p.m.
Actress Nicholle Tom, who played a precocious kid for several seasons of The Nanny , guests as Molly Simons, an online journalist who switched from writing celebrity gossip to hard-hitting exposes. When she disappears, family and co-workers point to an allegedly corrupt politician recently skewered by the reporter. Senior agent Jack Malone (Anthony LaPaglia) has a different theory.
MONDAY
JULY 20
CRIME DRAMA
Law & Order:
Criminal Intent
NBC, CTV, 9 p.m.
The teaming of Detectives Wheeler (Julianne Nicholson) and Nichols (Jeff Goldblum) gave this crime-drama a boost last season. Two years ago CI was relegated to the NBC-owned USA Network - the TV equivalent of being sent to the minors - but the show has returned strongly on the mother network. Tonight: A former Olympic medalist and employee of the Belgian consulate is found shot in the head. The investigation leads the detective duoto the Olympic site selection committee.
COMEDY
Two and a Half Men
CBS, 9 p.m.The simple format of has made Two and a Half Men a constant fixture in syndication, and the show benefits greatly from flawless casting: Neurotic non-alpha male Alan is a role made for Jon Cryer, still every bit as needy as when he was Ducky in Pretty in Pink ; sleazy womanizing brother Charlie is played by Charlie Sheen. Tonight, Alan moves out, then moves back, and a lesson is learned. COMEDY
Futurama
Teletoon, 9 p.m.
The only animated series to measure up to The Simpsons , Futurama is a faithful half-hour time-killer. Both series were created by Matt Groening, but Futurama presents more fanciful scenarios -it's set in the year 2999 . And like The Simpsons , the show can devote an entire story to one character without breaking pace. Tonight the foul-tempered Bender joins the robot mafia, but is taken aback at his assignment: robbing his employers at Planet Express.
REALITY
Dating in the Dark
ABC, CITY-TV, 10 p.m.
Starting tonight, it's a new spin on Love Connection . Billed as a "sexy social experiment," the series format is a doozy: Three single men and three single women are placed in separate wings of a house. While forbidden from seeing each other in the light, the two groups are allowed to mingle in complete darkness; they can't see each other, but viewers can watch via infra-red cameras. Near the end of every episode, each participant will describe what they believe to be their dream-lover to a police sketch artist. And when everyone comes into the light, each person has to make the decision whether to pursue the romance, or move on. Ain't love grand?
TUESDAY july 21
BIOGRAPHY
Like Each Day Was Your Last: A Journey with
Justin Hines
Bravo!, 7 p.m.
The name Justine Hines may not sound familiar, but you know his voice. The 27-year-old singer from Newmarket, Ont., has recorded two albums that have received healthy radio airplay and recently sang There's No Place Like It in a TV commercial for Tourism Ontario. Hines suffers from a rare genetic joint condition called Larsen's syndrome, which keeps him wheelchair-bound. This program recounts Hines's career dating back to his first big break - singing the national anthem at a Toronto Raptors game - and follows him on his first international concert tour. He's a true inspiration.
REALITY
Hell's Kitchen
Fox, CITY-TV, 8 p.m.
The sixth edition of the reality cooking series has a Canadian connection: The top prize is the head chef position at the posh Araxi Restaurant in Whistler, B.C., just in time for the Olympic Winter Games. The two-hour premiere drops the 16 amateur chefs into chef Gordon Ramsay's gruelling culinary boot camp. In a slight rules tweak, the signature dish challenge will now be a team challenge, pitting men against women. But couldn't they have included at least one Canadian contestant?
DOCUMENTARY
Child Genius 2
TVO, 9 p.m.
A follow-up to the acclaimed program Child Genius , this sequel series tracks the progress of some very gifted kids. Each of the child prodigies is now 13 and each appears intent on impressing the world in his or her own unique way. The driven Aimee practises piano seven days a week and recently won a prestigious music competition. Home-schooled Michael is writing his fourth novel while simultaneously expanding his interests in ancient Greek and particle physics. And his friend Dante is far beyond his years in his comprehension of neuroscience.
COMEDY
Hope & Faith
CMT, 10 p.m.
Go ahead and laugh, but I like this show. First shown on ABC from 2003 to 2006, the low-key sitcom starred ex- Murphy Brown mainstay Faith Ford as Hope - a married homemaker with three kids - and Kelly Ripa as her sister Faith, a former soap-opera star whose character was bumped off. Both women are talented comic performers and their chemistry is augmented by simple sitcom scenarios. Tonight, country star Clint Black guest stars as Hope's former high-school beau who comes for a visit. Does Faith take a shine to the hunky cowpoke? You really don't have to ask, do you?
WEDNESDAY July 22
REALITY
Wipeout
ABC, CITY-TV, 8 p.m.
They say no one ever went broke underestimating the taste of the American viewing public, and here's your proof. A ratings success in its sophomore season, Wipeout puts foolhardy contestants through the world's largest extreme obstacle course. The show is promoted as some sort of ersatz athletic contest, but what really keeps viewers coming back are the face plants. Tonight, the players include a substitute schoolteacher and a clumsy chef, who compete in three decidedly non-Olympic events: the log roll, wedge turntables and fender benders. Be amazed and amused at how seriously the contestants take the competition.
HISTORY
Time Team America
PBS, 8 p.m.
Launched two weeks ago, this new series follows a team of scientists and historian into the trenches of intriguing archeological sites. Tonight, they travel to scenic New Philadelphia, Ill., to dig for the remains of the first American town founded by former slaves. Historical evidence reveals New Philadelphia was created by ex-slave "Free Frank" McWorter way back in 1836. The Time Team pulls out all stops to find remains of the pre-Civil War schoolhouse where African-American children learned to read and write in freedom.
REALITY
Toddlers and Tiaras
TLC, 10 p.m.
A surprise hit last January, this TLC reality series focuses on child-beauty-pageant contestants and their stage parents standing in the wings. The program airs sans narration, presumably to maintain objectivity, but most of the parents shown on the first season were extreme cases. The format holds in the second-season opener, which is filmed at the Universal
Royalty pageant in Austin, Tex., where roughly 100 young contestants elbow each other for the $1,000 top prize. The fan favourite: Cameron Fletcher-Cantu - already a pageant veteran at seven years of age - but the judges are also eyeing six-year-old fraternal twins BreAnne and AshLynn.
TALK SHOW
The Hour
CBC, 11 p.m.
A rebroadcast from last season features an engaging chat with TV and film veteran Garry Marshall. The Bronx-born Marshall is best known as the man who created Happy Days for television and the director of such big-screen hits as Pretty Woman and The Princess Diaries . He's also no slouch as an actor and recently appeared in the film remake of Escape from Witch Mountain and even provided a guest voice on a memorable episode of The Simpsons (he played a carny-type promoter named Larry Kidkill). Host George Stroumboulopoulos helms a lively chat with the Hollywood legend.
THURSDAY JULY 23
FOOD
Restaurant Makeover
Food Network, 8 p.m.
Imagine if you were allowed to make menu suggestions and improvements to your favourite restaurant - and they listened! Each outing in this popular Food Network series challenges two culinary hotshots to revamp a flagging eatery. In this episode, chef David Adjey and designer Glen Peloso are airlifted in to help a couple named Edward and Natasha, who are struggling with a restaurant called Jonathan's. The couple inherited the place from Natasha's father, along with all the usual headaches. Despite the prime location, the menu is a mish-mash and nobody's eating there. Adding more pressure: The couple are expecting their first child, and the baby fund is the only money available for renovation. Dare they take the risk?
COMEDY
Samantha Who?
ABC, 8:30 p.m.
ABC has officially pulled the plug on this offbeat sitcom after two rocky seasons. Launched in 2007, the show starred former Married ... with Children regular Christina Applegate as a woman who suffers a hit-and-run accident and comes out of a coma with retrograde amnesia; she was fully functional, but had no memories of her past. In the last show, Samantha's best pal Andrea (Jennifer Esposito) is set to marry a gay pro-basketball player. At the same time, Samantha has to choose between her ex-boyfriend Todd (Barry Watson) and the eccentric billionaire Winston Funk (Billy Zane). After this show, Samantha Who? goes straight to DVD.
DRAMA
Doc Martin
PBS, 8 p.m.
Devotees of this endearing British comedy-drama take note: Filming has already commenced on a fourth season, which will air early next year. For now, fans will have to be content with old episodes and love is in the air with tonight's outing. Dour Dr. Martin Ellingham (Martin Clunes) suddenly finds himself pursued by the glamorous hotel-owner Carrie Wilson (Louise Delamere) and the lovely Louisa (Caroline Catz). At least one of his admirers loses interest when Doc Martin runs over her dog.
MOVIE
Childstar
Bravo!, 9 p.m.
Canadian filmmaker Don McKellar held true to his indie-film roots with this breezy 2004 feature. McKellar directed and co-wrote the story and assigned himself the pivotal role of Rick, an aspiring documentarian reduced to working as a limo driver. Rick's life becomes chaos when he chauffeurs around a spoiled preteen TV star named Taylor (Mark Rendall), in Toronto to shoot his first movie. When Taylor runs away from the film set, Rick turns mentor and father figure. Worth watching for Alan Thicke as the young star's TV-sitcom father - a role not far removed from his old days on Growing Pains .

China's economic growth comes with risks

Author: Batson, Andrew

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/chinas-economic-growth-comes-with-risks/docview/382623724/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The government is already trying to fine-tune its stimulus to reduce the risk of bubbles. As U.S. housing prices slide, China's are rising at a 10-per-cent annualized pace, fast enough for some to declare a new real-estate boom. The Shanghai stock market's benchmark index has gained 75 per cent this year, closing yesterday at a 13-month high on some of the heaviest trading since 2007.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=China%27s+economic+growth+comes+with+risks&amp;author=Batson%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-16&amp;spage=B.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=China%27s+economic+growth+comes+with+risks&amp;author=Batson%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-07-16&amp;spage=B.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Sustainability of state-driven rebound will be critical for global recovery
China's economy has turned around with startling rapidity in recent months, with factory output, bank lending and commodity imports all accelerating on the back of the government's massive stimulus program. The next challenge for authorities is sustaining that growth and keeping emerging problems at bay while weaning the world's third-largest economy off state funding.
The sustainability of this state-driven growth spurt is a critical issue for the global economy. The success of China's massive stimulus has been a rare bright spot in the worst global downturn in a generation, with all advanced economies expected to contract this year. A lot rides on Beijing's ability to overcome a decline in exports, bolster its domestic economy, and avoid stirring a new bubble in the housing market.
"China will be among the first countries to lead the global economy out of this recession," said Hans Timmer, director of the World Bank's economic forecasting department. Developing countries such as China are becoming a bigger driver of global growth as U.S. households cut back consumption and boost savings, he said.
Economists estimate that China's economy likely expanded by close to 8 per cent from a year earlier in the second quarter, up from 6.1 per cent in the first quarter. The official figure is scheduled to be announced early today in Beijing.
When measured in the same terms as other major economies - an annualized quarter-on-quarter comparison - China's growth in the second quarter could be on the order of 15 per cent, some private economists estimate. Even if the surge moderates in coming quarters, many analysts say China will very nearly meet its target of 8 per cent growth for all of 2009.
China has rebounded after authorities used the state-controlled banking system to engineer one of the most dramatic monetary expansions in history. Banks have issued twice as much in new loans so far this year as in the first half of 2008, and China's money supply is now expanding at nearly triple the rate in the United States. The credit boost has helped to restore confidence, and the activity it supports is, at least in the short term, good news for home builders, car makers and suppliers of commodities like copper.
But the government's strategy also carries risks. The flood of easy money into the economy could be spilling over into markets for stocks and real estate, and inflating fresh bubbles. Any buildup in bad loans and dud projects could weigh down growth and public finances. Also, the economy's dependence on government-driven investment and credit mean that any policy hiccups could derail the pickup in confidence.
"I do think there is a distinct and rising risk of an asset bubble and fluctuation in growth," said Wang Tao, China economist for UBS. "In addition to short-term stimulus, there needs to be medium-term thinking about changing the growth model," Ms. Wang said.
The government is already trying to fine-tune its stimulus to reduce the risk of bubbles. As U.S. housing prices slide, China's are rising at a 10-per-cent annualized pace, fast enough for some to declare a new real-estate boom. The Shanghai stock market's benchmark index has gained 75 per cent this year, closing yesterday at a 13-month high on some of the heaviest trading since 2007. The record surge in China's official reserves of foreign currency, which hit $2.132-trillion (U.S.) in June, was driven partly by renewed inflows of capital from abroad chasing strong growth. Economists estimate such "hot money" totalled $30-billion to $50-billion in the second quarter.
At the same time, China must take longer-term costs into account. As other countries are doing with their stimulus efforts, China is borrowing from future growth to support the economy today. But the implicit debt the authorities are taking on by supporting bank loans and local government projects is several times larger than the official budget deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product this year. That will leave it less ammunition to stimulate the economy again - even as it becomes clear that lending and investment can't sustain their hectic pace.
Officials recognize that. "An improving trend in the economy does not mean that this difficult period is over," Premier Wen Jiabao told a meeting of economists and business people last week. China will continue stimulus policies while also undertaking structural reforms to support longer-term growth, he said.
One reason why officials are reluctant to start phasing out the stimulus is weak demand for China's exports, which are down 22 per cent so far this year. Despite official concern about unemployment, the small businesses that account for most jobs remain starved for credit even amid the boom. The benefits of the stimulus program have so far been concentrated in the state sector, which employs only about 20 per cent of the national work force.
"The current recovery is mainly based on a short-term rebound in inventories, which is not the same as a trend recovery," the State Information Center, an official think tank in Beijing, said in a report last week. "The material basis for an economic recovery would be the beginning of a new round of large-scale investment in capital equipment," the analysts said, urging Beijing to do more to support private-sector investment.
The best hope for a sustained investment boom may lie in China's strong housing market this year. Although home sales collapsed for much of last year, confidence started to return after the stimulus plan. Residential property sales were up 50 per cent in June alone. More importantly, developers have resumed building homes, encouraged by easy financing conditions and rising sales. The latest data show construction starts were up 12 per cent from a year earlier in June, marking the first increase after 11 straight months of decline.
Although slower than the 20-per-cent to 30-per-cent gains of recent years, the improvement is welcome, because construction drives demand for steel and many other industries, such as home appliances. If demand from the housing sector can keep Chinese factories humming, they will in turn be able to invest in expansion, which would drive economic growth.
Yesterday, U.S. Commerce Secretary Gary Locke reiterated Washington's argument that further liberalizing China's markets and allowing its currency to appreciate would help boost consumption.
"If China allowed for greater flexibility in its exchange rate and further opened up its domestic markets for imports and foreign direct investment, it would accelerate the world's return to growth," Mr. Locke said in Beijing.
Credit: Wall Street Journal
