____________________________________________________________

Heritage projects suffer collateral damage in downturn

Author: Gold, Kerry

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/heritage-projects-suffer-collateral-damage/docview/382632958/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Through the heritage building rehabilitation program, the city approved a record amount of transfer density. Marco D'Agostini, the city's senior heritage planner, estimates that if all approved projects are completed, there is potentially 1.5 million square feet of bonus density that would be for sale. That figure is part of the reason the city put the heritage building rehabilitation program on hold in 2007, and has kept it on hold. Mr.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Heritage+projects+suffer+collateral+damage+in+downturn&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-08&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Heritage+projects+suffer+collateral+damage+in+downturn&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-08&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Robert Fung has turned some of Vancouver's worst eyesores into high-end housing. But the financing model he used to cover the added expense of saving the city's grand old buildings has run into a brutal new reality
Developer Robert Fung stands on Water Street in Vancouver's Gastown, surveying a row of heritage buildings that comprise one of the city's most beautiful streetscapes.
They represent some of the city's oldest buildings, and each of them had been long neglected until Mr. Fung came along and restored them as work, retail and condo spaces.
"He's the poster child of heritage," says Heritage Vancouver president Don Luxton.
But with the downturn in British Columbia's property markets, Mr. Fung now sees himself tied to a complex financing model that no longer works.
The Alhambra building, circa 1887, anchors Water Street, the most historic block in the city. It is part of Mr. Fung's $60-million, three-phase, five-building project that involves "a high level of heritage restoration." The condo building Terminus, once on Heritage Vancouver's Top Ten Endangered Sites list, is the first phase. The heritage building, with its sleek, uniquely modern interior, is finished and mostly occupied. The Garage condos next door, once the location for the city's first jailhouse, will be complete by November.
The Alhambra itself is a three-building, retail-office complex with an historic interior courtyard that wraps the corner of Carrall Street, and it is far from complete. Nearby, on Hastings Street, Mr. Fung has the mixed condo-retail heritage buildings the Paris Block and Annex, which are not quite sold out and finishing construction next year.
Mr. Fung celebrated an official opening party recently for his nearby Flack Block, a fully restored heritage office building at Hastings and Cambie streets that now recalls its former glory of 1899. Over the years it had become a derelict haven for heroin users in an area still rife with drug problems.
Mr. Fung says his work on in the area not only saves buildings, but revitalizes the local economy and gives residents a serious morale boost.
As he surveys his work, Mr. Fung appears his usual serene self, despite the setbacks that have occurred over the last couple of years. His Trapp Block heritage project in historic New Westminster is "on hold." The Terminus had been sold out - until some of the owners couldn't complete their purchases due to the economic downturn. It means several of the units are still for sale.
"Of course I'm worried about the downturn," he says. "The Terminus building was sold off, and we've received some of the suites back. I only planned to sell it once."
As well, heritage restoration costs significantly more than building new from the ground up, which is why Mr. Fung depended on city incentives for his Gastown projects. Aside from grant money, he has relied on millions of dollars in bonus density transfers to fund the six heritage projects in the area. The practice allows Mr. Fung to sell unused density from his projects to another developer, in order to cover the high cost of heritage restoration. The density cannot be sold, however, until the projects are completed.
More than anybody, Mr. Fung made use of the incentive. To put it in perspective, Mr. Fung says there is about 500,000 square feet of transfer density currently banked by the city. His share is 400,000 square feet - and in this market, nobody is looking to buy.
"We have satisfied the need to create some investment in the area, we've satisfied the need to save buildings and to create more economic diversity in the neighbourhood," he says. "At the back end, we also need to sell this density to pay the bank back - not being able to do that is a huge problem."
It could get much worse.
Through the heritage building rehabilitation program, the city approved a record amount of transfer density. Marco D'Agostini, the city's senior heritage planner, estimates that if all approved projects are completed, there is potentially 1.5 million square feet of bonus density that would be for sale. That figure is part of the reason the city put the heritage building rehabilitation program on hold in 2007, and has kept it on hold. Mr. D'Agostini says its future is under review and a report will go before city council next month. The program includes façade grants and property tax exemptions, which Mr. D'Agostini expects council to continue. It's the transfer density that is the sticking point. There is simply too much density banked for it to be absorbed into the market.
The sale of density to offset the cost of heritage restoration is a market-driven tool that's been used effectively for years, says Mr. Luxton of Heritage Vancouver. It is, he says, the best tool heritage advocates have to protect historic buildings. In 2003, the policy was extended to include the neglected historic neighbourhoods of Chinatown, Gastown and the Downtown Eastside. It stimulated more than $400-million in heritage development in those areas, including the Woodward's building, which is currently under construction and nearing completion.
"The density bank worked really, really well for many, many years," Mr. Luxton says. "But in 2006 it just went right over the top. Part of the reason was several large projects came on stream all at once, including Woodward's and the Evergreen Building [in Cole Harbour] - and whamo . There was nowhere to put all that density."
"No one had anticipated things would slow down quite so much," Mr. D'Agostini says.
"Robert has got carrying costs, and they have realized the projects, they've done them, and they've got bills to pay to contractors and everybody. It's part of the reason they proceeded with the projects, because they could sell the density and recover the costs," Mr. D'Agostini says.
"You could say those developers knew what they were getting into, but at the same time we want to make sure we are trying to be helpful wherever we can. We can't force another person to buy density ... there is only so much we can do as well."
The city can help by not banking more density until equilibrium has been achieved, he says. "If we keep creating more density, it will, I think, have a significant impact on the value of any density that's been created. We may completely devalue the tool."
As the largest holder of banked density, Mr. Fung simply wants the city to make the program work. He recognizes the city is attempting a solution, but he says it is slow in doing so.
As well, he believes the city could do more for developers like him who played a vital role in restoring old neighbourhoods. He argues that even in the strongest real estate market, the city controls the absorption of the density. The city controls the value and amount available for transfer, as well as zoning laws that would make transfer of that density possible.
"They pay the developers for daycare by giving them density, so they should be taking density from us and doling it out with other packages of amenities to other developers," Mr. Fung suggests. "Otherwise, they compete against us.
"It bothers me that there's not more energy put into making the system healthy and recognizing that the city, in doing this, has led a lot of people down the garden path. But the stroke of a pen is all it takes to make it work properly.
"I'm hoping what will change is a recognition that the program as it exists is non-functional," Mr. Fung says, "and has been very unfair to the people who've made it successful for the city."

BABY POINT

Full text: 71 BRUMELL AVE.

Days on the market: 94
Listing agent: Nutan Brown, Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd.
The major factors in the sale of this two-storey house were its premium location and modern look, agent Nutan Brown says.
In terms of its location, most buyers were attracted to its quiet setting northwest of Jane Street and Baby Point Road, within steps of parkland along the Humber River, public transit and schools.
"It's a very child-friendly neighbourhood," Ms. Brown says. "It's on a small ... street, so there's minimal local traffic."
The 1930s home underwent cosmetic improvements, structural modifications and mechanical updates over the past two years. That included a new ductless air conditioner unit, refinished hardwood floors and two remodelled bathrooms, among other things.
"It a beautifully renovated property in absolutely move-in condition," Ms. Brown says. "The house was virtually gutted."

Despite all the changes, the foyer, fireside living room and three bedrooms upstairs retain some original details.

There is a separate entrance to the basement, where there is a sauna off the bathroom and a recreation room with ceramic floors and above-grade windows.

A man with the rezoning touch

Author: Belford, Terrence

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/man-with-rezoning-touch/docview/382641759/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We see it as the way of the future," says RioCan president Edward Sonshine. "Steve knows exceptionally well what can be done with urban properties and how to create substantial value through the rezoning process. I always told him he stayed practising law too long and this is what he should be doing."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+man+with+the+rezoning+touch&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-05&amp;spage=B.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+man+with+the+rezoning+touch&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-05&amp;spage=B.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Innovative investment fund led by a master at winning property change approvals has some big-name backers
He developed a reputation as Toronto's top legal wizard for helping clients gain rezoning and development approvals.
And now Stephen Diamond is putting that track record to use in a new venture: an innovative real estate investment fund that instantly drew the backing of some of the biggest players in Toronto's real estate sector.
Even in the midst of the economic meltdown, he and his backers say they have faith in both the vision and the timing.
Mr. Diamond's Whitecastle New Urban Fund - launched last fall with $70-million raised from big industry players including RioCan Real Estate Investment Trust and Sterling Silver Development Corp., as well as Mr. Diamond's own family venture capital firm - is a real estate investment fund with a distinct difference. Its aim is to identify urban properties in Toronto where the zoning can be changed to permit much higher use, shepherd those zoning changes through the complicated approvals process, and then either sell the property at a substantial gain or develop it on its own or with partners.
The fund has already made its first acquisition: a block of century-old storefront buildings with extra land behind them on the southwest corner of Yonge and St. Joseph streets in Toronto. Once rezoned, the plan is to restore those storefronts to their former glory, providing 35,000 square feet of prime retail space, and then build a 49-storey, glass-walled condo tower behind them.
What promises to be Mr. Diamond's competitive edge is his successful career as a municipal affairs lawyer. For 20 years, he was the go-to guy when developers needed a deviation from the official plan, increases in permitted density or a change in zoning for projects.
First with his own firm, Diamond Fairbarn, and then with McCarthy Tetrault LLP, Mr. Diamond stick-handled city council approval for super projects in Toronto such as the Four Seasons Hotel & Residences at Bay and Yorkville streets and Minto Midtown at Yonge and Eglinton.
He has guided his clients through the mangrove swamp of zoning and official plan changes such projects required, and patiently negotiated a consensus among stakeholders, such as ratepayer groups, local merchants, city planners and ward councillors. He has brokered deals that allowed heights well beyond previously established official limits, and persuaded city council to increase density to the levels where developers could build projects that turned a solid profit. His work on behalf of developers helped to change the face of the city.
Mr. Diamond grew up surrounded by key players in the development industry. His father was A.E. Eph Diamond, founding partner and later chairman of Cadillac Fairview Corp. and one of the most respected men in Canadian real estate.
Mr. Diamond, 57, flirted briefly with retirement when he left his partnership at McCarthy Tetrault two years ago. His wife got tired of him using her computer and told him to get out of the house and find an office, he says with a laugh.
He did indeed find one with his younger brother Carey, 54, who runs the family firm, Whitecastle Investments Ltd. Then he went much further by launching the new fund.
His vision and his reputation as the master of rezoning applications were so strong that the fund was oversubscribed within days. Units were snapped up by some of the leading names in development.
RioCan, one of Canada's largest shopping mall developers and the country's largest REIT, took a $10-million stake, and Sterling Silver, which has a substantial portfolio of apartment buildings and develops industrial and commercial space, also took a sizable chunk (it will not disclose how much), as did Whitecastle Investments. The remainder went to other private investors. The minimum stake was $2-million.
"We see it as the way of the future," says RioCan president Edward Sonshine. "Steve knows exceptionally well what can be done with urban properties and how to create substantial value through the rezoning process. I always told him he stayed practising law too long and this is what he should be doing."
Sterling Silver president Ronald Faust is equally full of praise.
Mr. Diamond "has this ability to work through extraordinarily complicated situations like with the Four Seasons project. He has this wonderful commitment to quality and a terrific insight into what the city wants. That makes all the difference in projects like this," Mr. Faust says.
"He knows 100 per cent what can be done. We have wanted to work with him for some time and this is a great opportunity. Steve is simply a class act."
A class act with a concept that promises to reap considerable financial rewards. Whitecastle projections call for investors to earn a return on their investment of at least 15 per cent a year over the fund's seven-year lifespan.
Perhaps even more important, they get first call should the fund decide to sell its newly rezoned properties or take in development partners.
"It will provide us with a feeder stream for new urban projects, something we are very interested in," Mr. Sonshine says. "The fund is also very strong because it has terrific cash-rich investors."
Cash-rich and solidly supportive investors play a vital role in the success of the fund, Mr. Diamond admits, especially in these days of a severe credit crunch.
While the fund's approach is to purchase properties with perhaps a 20-to 30-per-cent down payment, and a vendor-take-back mortgage for the balance, it has a commitment from its partners to provide financing should the vendor balk at offering a mortgage.
"We think the resources we have now are enough to do between five and eight projects over the life of the fund," Mr. Diamond says.
He is not concerned about the current global recession. In fact, what seemed like a good idea when the economy was booming may prove an even better one when it is sagging.
"The rezoning process will take about two to three years. By the time it is done and we are ready to sell or develop the site, today's tough times will very likely be behind us," he says.
"When recovery comes, we think there will be solid built-up demand for both residential and retail because almost no new projects will be launched during the recession."
Mr. Sonshine agrees. "There is always a risk with land. If projects like the St. Joseph one were coming on stream today, there would be no market for them," he says.
"But I think the timing - two to three years for the rezoning - is going to work perfectly for us."

Why a 'positive second derivative' isn't all positive

Author: Blackwell, Richard

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/why-positive-second-derivative-isnt-all/docview/382638644/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: It's the same idea as when you are running. The rate of change of your position (your velocity) is the first derivative. Your acceleration (the rate of change of the rate of change of your position) is the second derivative. If you are still running fast, but you are decelerating, your first derivative is positive but your second derivative is negative.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Why+a+%27positive+second+derivative%27+isn%27t+all+positive&amp;author=Blackwell%2C+Richard&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-05&amp;spage=B.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Why+a+%27positive+second+derivative%27+isn%27t+all+positive&amp;author=Blackwell%2C+Richard&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-05&amp;spage=B.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I keep hearing economists say that some indicators are showing a "positive second derivative." What does that mean?
It is a mathematical term, and there's nothing like a little mathematics to make economics even more fun.
When you take an indicator, such as the level of manufacturing, and look at its rate of change, that is the first derivative. If manufacturing is slowing down, its first derivative is negative.
The second derivative is the rate of change of that rate of change. So when manufacturing is still slowing down, but not as quickly as before, the second derivative is positive.
It's the same idea as when you are running. The rate of change of your position (your velocity) is the first derivative. Your acceleration (the rate of change of the rate of change of your position) is the second derivative. If you are still running fast, but you are decelerating, your first derivative is positive but your second derivative is negative.
What does that mean for measurements of the recession?
Several measures show the economy is still shrinking, but not as fast as before. So the second derivative is positive.
A real turnaround won't happen, however, until the first derivative is positive for several indicators. That happens when the numbers actually start to improve, not just get worse more slowly.
Yesterday, we saw some real gains in U.S. construction spending and pending home sales. Those "first derivative" increases helped propel the markets to big gains.
Why are the U.S. home sales numbers released yesterday called "pending"?
The numbers, from the National Association of Realtors, are pending because a contract to sell a house has been signed but the deal has not closed yet and money has not changed hands. Once the closing takes place, a month or two after the contract is signed, each deal becomes part of the NAR's actual home sales numbers.
In Canada, the monthly home sale figures we see from the Canadian Real Estate Association are similar to the NAR's "pending" numbers.
CREA - and local real estate boards across the country - count a sale as taking place when an offer to purchase is accepted without any conditions.
The boards say they don't wait until closing because the timing varies from house to house, and the data are not as easily gathered at that point.

Title: Why a 'positive second derivative' isn't all positive

Publication title: The Globe and Mail; Toronto, Ont.

Pages: B.4

Publication year: 2009

Publication date: May 5, 2009

Section: Report on Business: International

Publisher: The Globe and Mail

No shame in self-promotion

Author: Boesveld, Sarah

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/no-shame-self-promotion/docview/382639556/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "I don't just sit down and say, 'Hi, I'm Dawn, I'm looking for a job,' " she says. "I don't think that works; I think that's using people."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+shame+in+self-promotion&amp;author=Boesveld%2C+Sarah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-04&amp;spage=L.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+shame+in+self-promotion&amp;author=Boesveld%2C+Sarah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-04&amp;spage=L.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Looking for work takes more than pounding the pavement in these tough times
Dawn Montgomery is a savvy saleswoman. Her product? Dawn Montgomery.
The Hamilton job hunter has her own slogan, which says she "always goes the extra mile." The last four digits of her phone number spell her first name. She stacks her arms full of half-page flyers and slaps them on the windshields of parked cars. Sometimes she rides the rails and hands mini-resumes to commuters in the Greater Toronto Area. She'll strike up conversations with them in hopes they have a lead.
"I don't just sit down and say, 'Hi, I'm Dawn, I'm looking for a job,' " she says. "I don't think that works; I think that's using people."
What does work in her job search, she says, is self-promotion. She has been at it for three months, since losing a data-analysis gig in January. It hasn't yet landed her work, but she has noticed results. Almost 20 people have called saying they picked up her card. "Twenty people now know about me who didn't before," she says. "I'm getting my name out there."
As the unemployment rate continues to rise and the competitive job market takes hold, more exasperated job hunters have become shameless self-promoters. They're airing commercials on local TV stations, slapping their faces on billboards, and placing creative "employment wanted" ads in community newspapers and niche magazines.
Such in-your-face exposure can lead to results, experts say. But, they caution, there's a fine line between being a savvy marketer and just looking desperate.
Done right, self-promotion can be a job hunter's salvation, says Jim Geraghty, president of Happen, a Canadian executive networking group. It's often the attention-grabbing key to the invisible job market: employers who are hiring but don't want the onslaught of resumes a public posting invites.
"You really don't have an awful lot to lose," Mr. Geraghty says. "The bottom line is you're looking to separate yourself from your competitors and anything that helps you do that, assuming that it's done in good taste, would be more effective than not doing it."
He's seen people take the "trinkets and trash" approach, printing their name and number on pens and key chains and handing them out. One job applicant attached a bag of peanuts to the corner of a resumé with a note saying, "Will work for peanuts."
"If someone came to me and said 'I want to try this,' I would certainly suggest another strategy," Mr. Geraghty says.
Sharon Irwin-Foulon has also seen some pretty wild attention-grabbing tactics. The director of career management at the University of Western Ontario's Richard Ivey School of Business recalls an applicant who wrote a cover letter in the form of a wedding invitation.
"It was something like, 'This person is marrying the company name.' They can be pretty cheesy," she says.
If you don't understand your audience, you risk being remembered for all the wrong reasons, she says. "If you were applying to a bank, the flyers and a video [resumé] would speak to a lack of information or knowledge of who your audience is."
Job hunter Newman Mallon tried to target his search when he posted a "job wanted" ad in Marketing Magazine, an industry publication. After being laid off by a photo-ID equipment company in April, 2007, Mr. Mallon looked for work the traditional way but came up with little more than a three-month contract. Exasperated, he took out an ad last October that read, "Egads! 512 resumes and 16 months later, still very little work!"
"It was attention-getting," he says, though it didn't yield many results. "I wasn't looking for pity or anything. I'm just making it known that I was open to something that would work."
Mr. Mallon also built a website for himself, which many interviewers asked about.
A Web presence is perhaps the most effective form of self-promotion in a tech-savvy world, says Bruce Firestone, entrepreneur-in-residence at the University of Ottawa's Telfer School of Management (and founder of the Ottawa Senators hockey team).
"Many of the employers I work with today will not hire anybody that does not have a blog," he says.
Employers these days are bored by the standard resumé and crave a bit of spark, especially when the market is so dreary, says David Perry, an Ottawa-based headhunter and co-author of Guerrilla Marketing for Jobhunters .
"It's amazing what you have to do to get someone's attention," he says. "Everybody in these resumes talks about how creative they are, how dynamic and blah, blah, blah. Well, I'm from Missouri, show me."
A self-promotional job hunt isn't desperate, he says, it's creative and necessary.
Ms. Montgomery, for one, says she's had little luck with job boards and cold-calling companies. But on the commuter train last Thursday, she met a Hamilton charity manager who urged her to apply for a fundraising job. She also met the vice-president of a large recruiting organization who promised special attention for her resumé if she forwarded it to him. After handing out more than 300 of her cards, she was tired but cheerful.
"The fact remains that I'm getting noticed," she says.
And about a month ago, Paul Copcutt plucked one of Ms. Montgomery's cards, featuring her photo and a list of skills, off a community board at his local bank. The branding consultant in Dundas, Ont., was looking for administrative help and decided to call her. Ms. Montgomery is working on a quote for him, and if all goes well she'll have a job, he says.
"I like innovative ways of going about promoting yourself," he says. "The only other people you see sticking up cards are real-estate agents. I just thought that was a little bit different."

Title: No shame in self-promotion

Place for summer fun must look the part

Author: Richardson, Sarah

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/place-summer-fun-must-look-part/docview/382636553/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Perhaps I belonged to a quilting circle in a previous life, because something has to explain my deep affection for handmade quilts. When I was in my 20s and my girlfriends were starting to collect designer handbags I was, you guessed it, buying antique quilts at auction (don't laugh). Fortunately for me I still love my quilt collection (and I don't think I've seen any of them toting a 1990's handbag lately).

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Place+for+summer+fun+must+look+the+part&amp;author=Richardson%2C+Sarah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-01&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Place+for+summer+fun+must+look+the+part&amp;author=Richardson%2C+Sarah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-01&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Made for sunny days and lounging at the water's edge, your recreation home needs a playful decor
srichardson@globeandmail.com
Cottage bedrooms offer a unique and refreshing take on style. As a spot that is only used in the warm summer months one need not consider four-season comfort and opt instead for bright, sunny style.
With this in mind I decided to dial up the colour quotient and fill all my cottage bedrooms with perky prints and sassy shades reminiscent of what you'd discover in a country wildflower garden. My decision to embrace all shades of the rainbow doesn't mean I opted for a kaleidoscope extravaganza (after all, this is where I retreat to find calm and tranquillity and don't want to feel like my cottage is part of Doug Henning's stage set).
After seeing some of the rooms I've designed over the years, you might assume that my bedroom would be dressed entirely in shades of white (ecru, oyster, alabaster, snow, parchment and vanilla to name a few). But I decided to step out of my comfort zone and dive into the paint box for this project.
The right red
My husband, Alexander, loves red about as much as I love white. I had carte blanche on the design of the entire cottage and got everything I wanted, so I knew he'd appreciate it if there were a scheme that really represented him amidst the sea of signature SR style. I decided to give red a shot in our bedroom.
The challenge is to make red feel right for summer. It's a fiery colour that is often used to create an atmosphere of warmth, which I really didn't need. For me, the right shade is more tomato soup than cherry and more faded than fire truck. I opted for fabrics that had a sun washed look and tempered their warm tones with a healthy balance of cool denim blues and crisp whites to make it feel breezy and light.
What's under the bed?
In our cottage, there's no need to worry about monsters hiding under the beds: there's no room for them! Since we are tight on space I wanted to make the most of every usable inch. Instead of letting valuable storage space go to waste, I chose a king size bed frame with six giant storage drawers for our bedroom, and tucked trundle beds under the twin bed frames in the kids room. We can stash and stow lots of stuff in our drawers, and two extra little ones in the kids bedroom. Now that's what I call efficient use of space.
Bucket brigade
Cottage living requires multiple quick changes through the course of a day. From cool mornings to mid-day heat, swim time to nap time and every hour in between, it seems someone always needs a change of outfit. I like it when everything is easy to find (and easy to put away) so hooks and buckets are a recurring design solution for casual living. With hooks mounted low on the wall a brightly coloured metal bucket can be hung up and instantly provide an easy stashing spot for everything from bathing suits to books.
Newer isn't always better
The latest is often the greatest, but not when it comes to cottage furnishings. To get the most authentic "cottage" look I turned to a handful of local dealers to outfit my space in vintage treasures. While the beds are new, just about everything else that fills these rooms is of the pre-loved persuasion. Quilts, lamps, dressers, side tables, desk, chairs, stools, textiles and tchotzkes all had a previous life before they made it to our island. The character and patina inherent in these pieces helps bring a sense of history and charm to our new cottage. The fact that they come from local merchants and cost a fraction of what I'd pay to buy new is just the sprinkles on my sundae.
Quilting bee
Perhaps I belonged to a quilting circle in a previous life, because something has to explain my deep affection for handmade quilts. When I was in my 20s and my girlfriends were starting to collect designer handbags I was, you guessed it, buying antique quilts at auction (don't laugh). Fortunately for me I still love my quilt collection (and I don't think I've seen any of them toting a 1990's handbag lately). You can easily find new quilts that are colourful and fun and compliment your room scheme, but they cost at least as much (if not more) than the vintage variety, and don't have the same charm. You'll likely never find a pair that match so focus instead on finding specimens with complimentary colours and patterns and make the mix and match look part of the focus. Always be sure to inspect a vintage quilt before you buy it and only buy pieces in good condition or else you'll be starting up your own quilting bee to try and repair them.
Floor show
Summer is a season for barefoot elegance and nothing feels better underfoot than painted wood floors. They are easy to sweep up, glisten in the light, and allow the introduction of yet another summery hue to your design scheme. The key to successful floor painting is to ensure you use the right materials, and never cut corners on the prep work. Oil-based floor enamel gives the most enduring finish and high gloss shine, plus it can be mixed in any colour you dream of. Be sure to sand the floor well to allow the paint to adhere to the boards. If you are starting with a raw wood floor, cut the paint by 25 per cent with mineral spirits for the first coat so that it penetrates the wood and provides a lasting base. Sand between coats to remove any dust particles, and don't stop till you have a gleaming and beautiful finish (three coats is a good rule of thumb). As the promise of summer draws nearer, I can almost feel my bare feet gliding across those pretty painted floors.
Sarah Richardson is host and co-producer of Design Inc. on HGTV and principal of Sarah Richardson Design (sarahrichardsondesign.com). Sarah's Cottage can be seen on HGTV Tuesdays at 9 p.m.

Adding a certain je ne sais quoi

Author: Deck, Kelly

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/adding-certain-je-ne-sais-quoi/docview/382636477/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: People spend thousands on sparkly new chandeliers. That's all well and good: They're well suited to sleek, polished interiors. But if you're looking to enhance the relaxed eclecticism of a West Coast interior, it's hard to do better than the tarnish and opacity of a French chandelier.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Adding+a+certain+je+ne+sais+quoi&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-01&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Adding+a+certain+je+ne+sais+quoi&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-05-01&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Old France and modern B.C. make an odd pairing - but it works
kdeck@globeandmail.com
Mamie Angus and Sherry Killam have probably the worst job I've ever heard of. Every year or so, the Vancouver women go to France and, staying in small inns, travel the countryside, buying scads of antiques, drinking wine and eating cheese as they go. Rough, eh?
Then the women bring all the booty home, install it in a warehouse showroom and throw open the doors. Everything gets bought up in a few weeks. I'd heard the buzz about these shows for the past couple of years but, until recently, hadn't made it out to see one.
Although the show sounded like high times, I had low hopes of finding anything for my clients. In my limited experience of French antiques, I've found them ornate and stuffily formal. But I was pleasantly surprised. Their collection includes everything from hand-embroidered linen sheets to pressed steel stools and chairs from the Second World War era. Although many of the pieces are very different, they're united by an aura of being weathered.
This feeling of battered authenticity is what makes them perfect complements to West Coast interiors. The objects themselves are older than the homes on the West Coast, of course, but the bond between them exists is in their absence of pretension. The French have a different way of expressing it: the pieces are dans son jus - in their own juice.
Here are my four favourite items from this year's show, and a few hints, for those so inclined, on how to incorporate them into your home.
Antique mirror, $1,000+
If there's just one French country antique in your future, a mirror is where you should spend the dough. It takes on the patina of age - scratches, chips and discolourations forming a physical record of the places it has been and indignities it has suffered. No human being of a certain age can be immune to charm like that.
The eccentricity of the glass gives mirrors like these their soul. Any French piece made before 1850 is likely to be mercury glass, whose finish gives a mottled reflection of great texture and depth. For this reason, install your mirror where it will be noticed. You don't want it in liminal spaces such as a hallway, and don't hang it over your bed. Put it instead over the powder room vanity or a Lucite table at the front entrance. The mirror needs to be somewhere where its surface can be studied and appreciated.
Crystal chandelier, $2,000+
People spend thousands on sparkly new chandeliers. That's all well and good: They're well suited to sleek, polished interiors. But if you're looking to enhance the relaxed eclecticism of a West Coast interior, it's hard to do better than the tarnish and opacity of a French chandelier.
The pieces are most interesting against a utilitarian backdrop - a modern white kitchen or bathroom - where the chandelier's opulence can play with the spirit of austerity and efficiency. There's just one rule: Since you're splashing out with the chandelier, dial down the amplitude everywhere else.
In a kitchen application, hang one or two chandeliers over the island or central table. A modern table of teak, walnut or ash will anchor this design scheme with its warmth. The best chairs will be light, modern and functional.
In a dining room application, you'll want similarly to avoid indulgence. Ornate wallpapers, jewel-coloured velvets and lacquered furnishings give everything the whiff of being overperfumed. An understated dining table will give the chandelier room to breathe. Balance everything out with swooping dining chairs upholstered in linen, and on the walls put a textured wallpaper or unsaturated paint colour. The goal is to create negative space around the marquee furnishing as a way to enhance its form.
carved armoire, $8,000+
Historically, when a French countryman had a daughter, he commissioned a craftsman to make marriage armoire from wood. Each piece is unique because it was the commissioner's wealth that dictated the degree of carved detail. The ones I like best are not ornate, though, but the more modest pieces with their marks of imperfection. I'm a sucker for weary underdogs.
The challenge with bringing the armoires into your home is their size. They are, on average, three feet wide, two feet deep and six feet tall. If you need extra space for one, you can often find it in the master bedroom. Position the piece in the room so that its face can be appreciated. In the corner, on an angle, is a nice solution because it hides the armoire's bulk.
Caution and restraint are the watchwords for the remaining furnishings: Bulky pieces such as a four-poster or sleigh bed will cramp the room. Your preference should be for things that refer to the armoire (cubes of alder wood as side tables, say) or that add a modern flair to the room (such as a slim chrome and white-leather bench).
Rolled steel table, $5,000+
It's seems strange to say, but even with all the more quaint and lovable pieces, this plain steel table is my collection favourite. At first glance, I found it lacklustre, but the more I looked at it, the more I fell in love with its flawless proportions.
Made in the late 1920s, when industrialization was taking over from the tradition of local craft, the table would have been used in a factory. It's surprisingly slim, and its subtlety makes it a poor match for a room full of many finishes and colours. It will be happiest surrounded by lots of white space, as in a kitchen or an art studio.
A piece like this can't be paired with upholstered seats: It will make them seem bulky. Choose instead a chair equal in utility, something modern in moulded fibreglass or plastic - in a bold colour if you want to punch up the whimsy. Overhead, I'd recommend an industrial light fixture - something that shows the workings of the bulbs.
What do you think of the pieces? I don't have room in my apartment for the table and I certainly don't need an armoire, so this time I left with a modest set of antique keys. They sit proudly on my bedside table next to a favourite porcelain bowl.
But I'll certainly have my ear to the ground for the next sale. Then, I'm not leaving without a chandelier.
French Country Antiques can be reached at www.frenchcountryantiques.org or 604-730-7124

Where others saw swampland on Lake Simcoe, Hungarian immigrant saw the Lagoon City resort

Author: Abbate, Gay

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/where-others-saw-swampland-on-lake-simcoe/docview/382653728/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It was the fallout of the recession," said Stan Meek, who served 14 years on the company's board of directors. "It was really because there was a high concentration of mortgages with Confederation Life Insurance," Mr. Meek said. "When Confederation went under, there was a huge cash call."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Where+others+saw+swampland+on+Lake+Simcoe%2C+Hungarian+immigrant+saw+the+Lagoon+City+resort&amp;author=Abbate%2C+Gay&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-28&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Where+others+saw+swampland+on+Lake+Simcoe%2C+Hungarian+immigrant+saw+the+Lagoon+City+resort&amp;author=Abbate%2C+Gay&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-28&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 'He was a true entrepreneur,' his son says. 'He saw opportunities to make money everywhere.'
After the Canadian consulate in Budapest twice rejected his application to immigrate, Andrew Zsolt was determined to find out why. After all, he had arrived for his interviews clean-shaven and dressed in his Sunday best. And he had a newly minted degree in civil engineering. He cultivated a source in the consulate and found his answer: Canada was looking for farm labourers, not engineers.
Thus, on his third try, he showed up dressed in scruffy clothes, unshaven and with dirt under his fingernails. He told the interviewers that he would work on his aunt's farm near Kitchener, Ont., picking strawberries if he was approved. He was.
That determination and resiliency in the face of obstacles became a hallmark of his life in Canada. Mr. Zsolt arrived in Toronto in 1949 with five dollars in his pocket, speaking no English, but with big dreams.
Within a year, he was working as a professional engineer with The Foundation Co. of Canada. Nine years later, he formed Inducon Development Corp., taking it from a one-man operation to a multimillion-dollar group of companies.
"He was a true entrepreneur," said his son, Tom. "He saw opportunities to make money everywhere. He had a very good nose for real-estate business."
Mr. Zsolt was above all a visionary and an artist whose masterpiece was Lagoon City, a resort town he created on Lake Simcoe in Ontario.
"Lagoon City was the actualization on a grand scale of the place where he lived as a child. Siofok had a canal system and a shared communal beach," said his wife, Jean.
Mr. Zsolt was shocked that Ontario had no resort towns and he decided to build one in the European tradition.
He understood the need to preserve precious farmland, so he purchased a dead peat bog and unusable swampland, seeing their potential. In 1962, he began the lengthy process of acquiring local and provincial planning permits.
"People thought he was crazy," his son said. "But he never quit."
Over the years, he bought more property as funds permitted, eventually accumulating 647 hectares.
He dug a world-class marina for large boats, built 13 kilometres of canals and constructed 3,000 homes, a mix of single-family residences, condominiums and townhouses, all with access to a shared beach. He believed that everyone in the town, not just a privileged few, should have beach access. He also built a yacht club and the Harbour Inn and Resort Club, Canada's first time-share.
Mr. Szolt began his business empire by buying a few lots on which to build houses. He then focused on the suburbs around Toronto, where he foresaw growth potential.
He is credited with creating the industrial-mall concept, now a prominent fixture in Southern Ontario. He undertook small projects and progressed to large office parks, including the Cosmopolitan Corporate Centre, Metro West Corporate Centre and Canada Airway Centre.
Andrew Zsolt inherited his entrepreneurial spirit from his parents, Ernest and Josephine, who started several businesses in Hungary, including a chain of small movie theatres. His passion for building and design came from his father, who was a master builder.
The youngest of three children, he grew up in Siofok, a small town on Lake Balaton near Budapest. It was on this lake that he developed a lifelong passion for sailing.
He studied civil engineering at the Technical University of Budapest and did not experience the direct impact of the Second World War until 1944, when Germany occupied Hungary during his final year of study. Anticipating a victory over the Allied forces and a subsequent need for engineers, Germany transferred fourth-year engineering students from Budapest to Germany. However, with the Allies bombing Germany, Mr. Zsolt was unable to continue his education.
In the meantime, he struggled to survive, scrounging for food and keeping on the move to avoid the Allied bombing. He left Dresden just two hours before the town was bombed.
When the war ended, he found himself in the Russian zone of Germany and decided to make his way to West Germany. He was on foot until, ever resourceful, he swapped a found Swiss watch for a car. As he and several friends neared the West German border, the car ran out of gas. They made a dash for the border, pushed the car down a hill and then got inside and coasted to freedom.
Mr. Zsolt eventually enrolled at the Technical University of Munich, receiving his degree in 1948. His plan to return home was sideswiped by a letter from his mother telling him not to come because life under the Russians was not safe. He also learned that the Russians had killed his brother. Heeding his mother's advice, he decided to emigrate.
Once in Canada, he picked strawberries at his aunt's farm, as he had said he would, and taught himself English. Shortly after his arrival, friends introduced him to Veronica Hetenyi, a nurse from Richmond Hill, Ont., whose parents had emigrated from Hungary. They married in 1952 and had five children, one of whom drowned in 1962 when he was 3. Veronica died in 1975.
In the late 1970s, Mr. Zsolt met Jean Shaver McManus, a business consultant sent by her firm to help Inducon with a project. They were both single parents, each with four children. When they married in 1980, Mr. Zsolt built an addition to his home to give each of his new children a bedroom. "He was a very brave man to contemplate this merger," Jean said.
Mr. Zsolt's business empire eventually crashed. In 1992, hit by the recession and burdened with a huge debt, Inducon Development Corp. declared bankruptcy and its assets were liquidated.
"It was the fallout of the recession," said Stan Meek, who served 14 years on the company's board of directors. "It was really because there was a high concentration of mortgages with Confederation Life Insurance," Mr. Meek said. "When Confederation went under, there was a huge cash call."
Lagoon City would have been even grander had Inducon survived the recession. Mr. Zsolt had planned to add an 18-hole golf course, several hotels and shopping facilities.
But the loss of his business was just another obstacle to overcome. "A lesser man would have been destroyed, having built a huge company and managing millions of square feet. But he never stopped," his wife said.
At 70, he set about starting a new career. Building in Hungary was booming and he obtained the Stanley Doors franchise for that country. When he sold the business in 2002, he had 26 distributors working for him in Hungary.
Five years ago, he was diagnosed with a progressive debilitating disease. His condition worsened quickly in March after the sudden death of his son John in a snowboarding accident.
ANDREW ZSOLT
Andrew Zsolt was born April 7, 1923, in Budapest. He died at his Toronto home on April 15, 2009, of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. He was 86. He leaves his wife, Jean, seven children and 14 grandchildren.

From Fortune 500 to Mr. Mom

Author: Kershaw, Sarah

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/fortune-500-mr-mom/docview/382650473/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It was a big part of my identity; it's who you are. It's humbling - you start showing up and you're the only dad at the school. It took me a long time to fill in the blank when people asked me what I do, not to be able to say 'I work for a Fortune 500 company.' If people ask, I'll answer, but I won't put it out there."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=From+Fortune+500+to+Mr.+Mom&amp;author=Kershaw%2C+Sarah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-27&amp;spage=L.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=From+Fortune+500+to+Mr.+Mom&amp;author=Kershaw%2C+Sarah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-27&amp;spage=L.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Former high-powered executives are finding themselves out of work and stepping into more traditionally female roles
As the 3 p.m. bell rang recently at the local elementary school, there were some unusual faces in the crowd of mothers and nannies outside: a half-dozen or so fathers, part of the growing ranks of unemployed men in this affluent New York suburb.
As they waited to whisk their children off for after-school snacks and play dates, these men, veterans of some of the most demanding, highest-paying professions in the country, exchanged news of their kids' activities, extending what one father, Jerry Levy, called the "secret dad handshake."
Mr. Levy, 46, who lost his job at a hedge fund last summer, greeted Andrew Emery, 45, who worked in insurance and has been unemployed for a year.
They are among the 5.1 million people across the United States who have lost jobs in a recession that has put more men than women out of work, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labour Statistics.
In Pelham Manor, unemployed fathers can now be seen at elementary school and grocery stores, or walking with children along the quiet streets, taking their places, by necessity, in the largely women's world of child care, housework and school life.
Tom Imperato, 62, whose real estate business has been devastated, discovered that there is no line at Costco at 11:30 a.m., now that he does the food shopping for his wife and nine-year-old twin daughters.
Mr. Levy joined the Parent Teacher Association and immediately noticed that he tends to tackle matters with a bluntness honed in the financial industry, while the women, whether stay-at-home mothers or professionals, he said, communicate more diplomatically.
Mr. Emery went from rushing past his children in the morning on the way to work and saying goodnight by phone to being a full-time father whose wife is the breadwinner. Along with the family dog, Bollo, he seems omnipresent here.
Susan Gilbert, principal of Siwanoy Elementary School, recently called her teachers to a meeting to discuss the implications of all the fathers showing up for pickup.
"There are dads on the lawn I've never met before," Ms. Gilbert recalled telling her staff at the 300-student school. "We've got kids who are feeling stressed. There are a lot more issues. There's more aggression, more sadness. We have to be cognizant that there are families that may be going through things that we are not aware of."
The new prevalence of fathers around town is bittersweet for mothers, teachers and others. On the one hand, the PTA can use all the help it can get from men with financial expertise at a time when the proposed school budget is under enormous pressure. And women are happy to see stay-at-home husbands building closer relationships with their children. But one little-spoken effect is an uneasy feeling that these highly successful men are facing the pain and potential shame of being out of work.
"A man is supposed to hunt and gather and bring home and provide, and when they don't, that goes to their identity," said Jane Robbins, a PTA member. "If they can find some solace in being the parent, if they can take that out of it, God bless them."
For Mr. Emery, who was a senior member of his firm, there have been plenty of days over the past year when he wakes up and says to himself, "Ugh, not this again." He quit his job last year ahead of expected layoffs, optimistic that he would soon find work. Now, with his savings evaporating, he said he regrets that he didn't wait to be laid off so that he could collect unemployment; the maximum weekly benefit in New York State is $405 (U.S.), with $25 added recently by the federal government.
His wife, Lea, works full-time as the deputy director of a nearby art museum, but the couple is facing the cold fact that they cannot sustain their lives in this village on her salary alone.
"To go from the 24-7, high-end deal-making prestige of working for places that are written about in newspapers to this, it took a long time to get comfortable," said Mr. Emery, who had also worked for the insurance company Chubb for 20 years.
"It was a big part of my identity; it's who you are. It's humbling - you start showing up and you're the only dad at the school. It took me a long time to fill in the blank when people asked me what I do, not to be able to say 'I work for a Fortune 500 company.' If people ask, I'll answer, but I won't put it out there."
Like other out-of-work fathers here, he said that unemployment, while wrenching, has also forced him to find opportunity in dramatically altered lives that involve spending long hours with the children. At school recently, Mr. Emery collected Alison, 8, and Aidan, 5, grabbing their knapsacks and walking to the family's Dutch Colonial-style home. "Alison, have you got homework?" he asked his daughter.
But one uncomfortable aspect of his new life, Mr. Levy said, is a certain loss of power. "At work, you are used to everyone listening to you - assistants, accounting, the middle office, sales coverage and outside vendors," he said. "But try to get your four children to listen to you."
He has zealously bounded into the PTA, becoming its liaison to the Pelham Board of Education on financial matters. Recently, he announced his candidacy for a seat on the school board, a move applauded by several long-time PTA members.
"I hope all these good guys who need good jobs find them," said Gina Fidele, a PTA president. "But I also hope that maybe this taste of what it's like to be more involved - not just taking the kids to school, but really helping to organize and direct the policies in the community. I hope they are having some experience that they'll find engaging and that they'll want more of it, even when they have that career back."

PREFAB LIVING

Author: Hadani Ditmars

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/prefab-living/docview/382657771/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: This is merely Mr. [Tony Robins]' prêt-à-porter collection. His couture items are his custom-designed range of prefabs. At work on four large custom designed homes destined for Tofino, the Gulf Islands and the Sunshine Coast, Mr. Robins' design prowess shines through his technique. The prix de Rome award winner responds organically to specific sites with great effect.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=PREFAB+LIVING&amp;author=Hadani+Ditmars&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-24&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=PREFAB+LIVING&amp;author=Hadani+Ditmars&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-24&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Architect Tony Robins is ramping up production at his Surrey plant, looking to feed a renewed interest in cost-effective prefabricated houses
Architect Tony Robins leans in close to inspect a kitchen cabinet that carpenter Ben Scott is finishing.
The mitre - the 45-degree-angle edge - has to fit just so and, like so many other projects in Mr. Robins' 30-year Vancouver-based career, God is in the details.
Of course, it's helpful that the architect, builders, sanders and table saws are all in the same place. For this is no ordinary building site. It's the headquarters of Mr. Robins' newly minted company Preform Construction, which is producing rather extraordinary prefab houses, 10 units at a time.
Here, at a 20,000-square-foot manufacturing plant in an industrial area of Surrey, B.C., chosen for its proximity to river barges for easy transport, Mr. Robins' simple yet sophisticated vision of modular prefabs is unfolding at an impressive rate: roughly two months from start to finish for a basic unit.
"We've had over a 130 inquiries already," says the architect, who recently revealed his design for a 500-square-foot unit in a palette of steel, glass and wood to an enthusiastic audience at a B.C. home show in Vancouver.
While his Japanese-style minimalism and industrial aesthetic - exemplified by the Robins-designed restaurant Watermark on Vancouver's Kits Beach - appeals, he admits that his inspiration for the prefabs was born of an innate sense of practicality. While designing a house for a remote site near Tofino, he realized that prefabs would be one way of reducing the costs of barging in equipment, workers and materials.
And his timing was perfect. In these recessionary times, there is a renewed interest in cost-effective prefabs. Mr. Robins' units also feature the appealing equation of pragmatic equals green equals smart design.
"It worked out that practical considerations that were to our advantage in terms of cost-cutting also turned out to be very green solutions," Mr. Robins says.
Using local suppliers, for instance, means there is less cost and a smaller footprint for materials, as does the use of recycled woods. A green roof helps increase insulation and reduce energy consumption, and a warmboard in-floor heating system runs at a lower temperature than normal. And since Mr. Robins had to maximize space in the small, 500-square-foot base units, he designed 10-foot-high ceilings and extensive glazing to create a sense of light and openness. He also lowered the bathroom ceiling to create storage and a mechanical space that was just the right size for an instantaneous water heater.
The prefab's many smart features are also inherently green. A monitoring system, for instance, allows owners to control heating and electrical systems remotely by computer.
But before Mr. Robins can design a unit for a client, there are some initial practical considerations. Getting the shipping company to drive the road to the site, for example, is key, to make sure there aren't any obstacles to transporting the house from the barge to the site.
The next step is to work with the client to determine exactly what they want. For the basic units, there is an array of choices to be made among materials, appliances and finishes that affect price and style.
Inquiries have come in as to whether these units could be converted into float homes or laneway housing, but for now most of them are intended for more remote, vacation home type sites.
But this is merely Mr. Robins' prêt-à-porter collection. His couture items are his custom-designed range of prefabs. At work on four large custom designed homes destined for Tofino, the Gulf Islands and the Sunshine Coast, Mr. Robins' design prowess shines through his technique. The prix de Rome award winner responds organically to specific sites with great effect.
A home for a jewellery designer overlooking a 100-foot cliff on Pender Island is a simple yet elegant paean to the power of landscape. Its Japanese proportions and extensive glazing make it a small jewel in itself, reflecting and embracing the sea and sky.
A 6,000-square-foot home destined for Tofino, with its elongated rectangular lines, speaks to both the ruggedness and beauty of its surroundings, its steel columns and local recycled cedar siding softened by a glass-sided infinity pool.
It's hard to believe these are prefabs at all, and that they originate here in this unassuming factory. But Mr. Robins' love of craft, attention to detail and precision make this an ideal arrangement. The relationship between builder and architect is unusually intimate and especially satisfying.
"There was a moment," recalls Mr. Robins wistfully, "when we finished the first unit and Mike [Dykstra, his principal builder] and I just stood there looking at it. It was a perfectly made piece that we'd overseen from start to finish, working together. We couldn't stop smiling."
More prefab
Additional photos of Mr. Robins' homes can be seen at globeandmail.com

MODCABIN FEVER

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/modcabin-fever/docview/382655356/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Designed by Margaret Graham and Andre D'Elia, partners in the Toronto firm Superkül Inc., this cedar-clad cottage, completed last year, has already been weathered down by the winter wind and snow to an attractive silvery grey. Other aspects of the material palette, such as the elegant, modestly scaled fireplace of dry-laid ledge limestone, help smooth the house's visual relationship with its vivid natural context.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=MODCABIN+FEVER&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-24&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=MODCABIN+FEVER&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-24&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Superkül's Georgian Bay home makes an argument for inspired cottage design
With the Victoria Day holiday less than a month away, many Toronto cottagers are eagerly looking forward to the May afternoon when they can flee the city for the first time this year and disappear among the beautiful islands and lakes of Ontario's northland.
Where they end up will be a matter of taste and budget. It may be something along the lines of the rustic pitched-roof shacks that small-town ministers and teachers put up for themselves in the early years of the past century. (This would certainly be my preference.) Or, less fortunately, it may be a monster home that appears to have been helicoptered in from some Toronto suburb.
For one Toronto family of four, however, the destination will be a getaway house in sharp contrast both to the traditional cottage and to the recently fashionable (and always awful) cottage-country mansion. It's a low-slung modernist house perched on a rugged 18-acre granite island in Georgian Bay - radical in inspiration, refined in detail, snugly positioned on its rocky, exposed site.
Designed by Margaret Graham and Andre D'Elia, partners in the Toronto firm Superkül Inc., this cedar-clad cottage, completed last year, has already been weathered down by the winter wind and snow to an attractive silvery grey. Other aspects of the material palette, such as the elegant, modestly scaled fireplace of dry-laid ledge limestone, help smooth the house's visual relationship with its vivid natural context.
Still, the cottage stands out vigorously from all that surrounds it and declares its freedom from the architectural traditions of the region. There is no decoration, no references to old-fashioned buildings, nothing to distract from its contemporary feel and character. The project is composed of two rectangular blocks set down parallel to each other, and separated by a walkway, on a spacious cedar deck boosted above the rocks. These blocks are also separated by use: one for the living room and dining area and kitchen, the other for bedrooms. The roofs slope upward along the lengthier axes of both elements, terminating in high walls opened by large windows.
The arrangement and size of the windows is especially interesting. Unlike more conventional Georgian Bay cottages, braced against the sometimes savage weather that surges across the district, Superkül's house is open to nature in all directions and at all times of the day, encouraging wide views through tall windows of water, rock and sky. In their classic formulations of what they believed, architectural modernists always argued strongly against dark, opaque walls, which shut out light and air, and for lightness and transparency. This silvery, glassy house, then, is a modernist dream come true, though raised in a wilder part of the world than the old modernists ever designed for.
But the forthright rejection of local architectural traditions by Ms. Graham and Mr. D'Elia raises again certain questions that often come to mind when thinking about construction in Ontario's superb cottage country. Are local traditions, which come out of those humble, pitched-roof shacks I mentioned, really so bankrupt that a whole new approach to building is called for? Is modernism an appropriate style for buildings in the landscape of Tom Thomson and the Group of Seven?
To the first question, I would answer no. Creative cottage-country architects will always be ransacking the built heritage of the past for ideas and putting them to work in cottages that blend in well with traditional designs. In these pages and elsewhere, I have written about very successful cottage designs that have emerged not from a renunciation of the past, but from a fruitful dialogue with it. I know the thing can be done.
Answering my second question is slightly more complicated. The real enemy of good sense and good art in cottage country, after all, is not the thoughtful, imaginative building, whatever its style. Superkül's new house on Georgian Bay, for example, is an intelligent and sensitively designed building, and for that reason it is a welcome piece of architecture. Never mind that it is cast in a modernist idiom. It works.
The curse of cottage country, rather, is the city or suburban home that has been heedlessly plunked down up north without serious thought about either the landscape or any cultural precedents, whether traditional or modernist. I have seen some of these monstrosities sprawling gracelessly over their properties by the water's edge. It appears that no municipal agency, or anything else, can stop their construction. Until someone takes responsibility for the aesthetics of cottage country, I fear that these eyesores will continue to proliferate.
Until then, we should appreciate clients who take the trouble to hire good architects, such as Ms. Graham and Mr. D'Elia, to provide them with holiday homes in the north. With any luck, the results will be enrichments of Ontario's architecture of escape.
Can't get enough
Superkül?

DAYS ON THE MARKET: six
Listed for less than $160,000, this one-year-old bachelor pad was such an attractively priced package that local renters were convinced to take out a mortgage to get it, agent Malcolm Austin says. "It's more or less the same as paying rent," he says. "If the market does go up ... you're building equity."
Part of a stacked condominium townhouse complex, the unit has a street-level entrance that opens into a living space of more than 500 square feet.
There are laminate floors throughout, a balcony overlooking a quiet, tree-filled green space, and a kitchen completed with ceramic tile finishes, stainless steel appliances and a breakfast bar.
"Most things in this price range are in pretty tacky condition, but these [units] are quite new," Mr. Austin says.
The suite comes with a four-piece bathroom and laundry facilities, as well as a locker and two parking spots in the garage. A monthly fee of $123 pays for common elements.
Another highlight is the property's location, just minutes from Highway 401, shopping centres, a hospital, library and public transit.

The 1,233-per-cent tax solution

Author: Brethour, Patrick

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/1-233-per-cent-tax-solution/docview/382654382/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: There is a long trail of events that led the community of Campbell River, B.C., to boost TimberWest's tax bill to $1-million from $75,000, a decision that the city council is now backing away from. (That sum alone wouldn't be fatal to TimberWest, but if all the forestry towns on Vancouver Island were to follow suit, the resulting bill would absorb one-third of the company's earnings.)

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+1%2C233-per-cent+tax+solution&amp;author=Brethour%2C+Patrick&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-24&amp;spage=B.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+1%2C233-per-cent+tax+solution&amp;author=Brethour%2C+Patrick&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-24&amp;spage=B.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: pbrethour@globeandmail.com
Bigger property tax bills are never fun, but less so when you find out about it from a reporter's telephone call - and much less so when you find out that your tax tab is rising by 1,233 per cent.
TimberWest Forest Corp. TWF.UN-T was at the receiving end of that call, and that tax grab, last Friday. TimberWest's Stephen Bruyneel tries to be diplomatic in describing the company's reaction, but even so he acknowledges there was shock. After the shock wore off, the next thought was - why?
There is a long trail of events that led the community of Campbell River, B.C., to boost TimberWest's tax bill to $1-million from $75,000, a decision that the city council is now backing away from. (That sum alone wouldn't be fatal to TimberWest, but if all the forestry towns on Vancouver Island were to follow suit, the resulting bill would absorb one-third of the company's earnings.)
The somewhat complex rationale for Campbell River's move was that TimberWest is turning some of its forestry lands into real estate developments, so the company should pay tax on its entire portfolio of forest land as if it would shortly become condos.
The simple fact, however, is that the municipal politicians in Campbell River, and in many other struggling resource sector towns in B.C., haven't come to grips with the inescapable reality that the boom times of the forestry industry are gone, and unlikely to return.
So the old ways of taxing the local forestry company in the first, last and every instance simply will not work any longer. That outdated attitude has already killed some players in the forestry sector - witness Skeena's death grapple with Prince Rupert earlier this decade - and will kill again unless B.C. towns (and the province) move to end the decades-long practice of hitting forestry firms with high taxes in order to keep residential levies low.
That brings us back to Campbell River and TimberWest. For years, the city had been talking with another large forestry firm, Catalyst Paper Corp., about cutting an outsized tax bill. That company had already negotiated a modest tax break, seeing its bill fall to $5.2-million last year from $5.9-million in 2004. But Catalyst was pushing for a much larger tax reduction, in Campbell River and three other Vancouver Island communities. All told, Catalyst wanted to slash its tax bill to $6-million from an estimated $23-million.
It was a reasonable enough position: Catalyst chief executive officer Richard Garneau pointed out in a January letter that his company has been subsidizing low residential taxes, with homeowners in the community of North Cowichan paying only $100 a year, on average, after taking into account a provincial tax rebate. Mathematically speaking, Mr. Garneau is impeccably correct.
Politically speaking, however, the picture is not quite as clear. Forestry companies, for example, don't vote, and don't turn up at council meetings to shout mean words into microphones. Mr. Garneau didn't exactly help his cause, either, in his January letter, in which he issued a brusque ultimatum: "Therefore, on July 1, 2009, Catalyst intends to pay only for the cost of municipal services it consumes in each of the four municipalities, estimated to be approximately $1.5-million per community, or $6-million in total, down from $23-million. We really have no choice."
Yes, there were talks between Catalyst and municipal governments before and after the letter. But any hope of a quiet resolution that mayors could then sell to voters disappeared the moment the ultimatum became public. As a result of Catalyst's push to slash its tax bill, Campbell River and other municipalities have been scrambling to plug the hole in their budgets - including the short-lived proposal to raise TimberWest's tax bill by an astonishing 1,233 per cent.
TimberWest has reached a compromise that will see it pay a higher rate of tax on lands that are imminently headed for real estate development, with Campbell River agreeing to expedite zoning approvals. But the incident underscores the air of unreality that still pervades the logging towns of British Columbia, an assumption that forestry companies can pick up the tab for everybody else. What's to be done?
In the long term, the only real solution is to increase residential taxes substantially - not an easy sell in a recession. But the alternative is to hold the line on industrial levies, and watch as punitive taxes axe the forestry industry.
