Lenders jockey for pole position

Author: McNish, Jacquie

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lenders-jockey-pole-position/docview/382663089/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Creditors of Circuit City's Canadian chain, The Source, found themselves in a cross-border tug of war about the terms of a $1.3-billion DIP loan that was arranged for the U.S.-based retailer by a syndicate of its existing banks led by Bank of America. When The Source's Canadian creditors began to read the small print, "the plot thickened," said Fasken's Mr. [Aubrey Kauffman], who represents one of the subsidiary's suppliers.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lenders+jockey+for+pole+position&amp;author=McNish%2C+Jacquie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-22&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lenders+jockey+for+pole+position&amp;author=McNish%2C+Jacquie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-22&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Creditors get their elbows out when 'DIP' lenders jump to the front of the queue
jmcnish@globeandmail.com
***
AbitibiBowater Inc. ABH-T had every reason to believe it was one of the lucky ones.
Strapped for cash to pay $6-billion (U.S.) of debts in a sputtering newsprint market, the crippled giant still had what it took to win the attentions of one of the world's most prominent lenders. Earlier this month, GE Capital was so convinced of AbitibiBowater's long-term future that it was finalizing a $600-million emergency infusion, known as a debtor-in-possession or DIP loan, to sustain a company headed for bankruptcy proceedings.
If signed, AbitibiBowater would have landed a rare major DIP loan at a time when conventional lenders have all but disappeared from corporate bailouts.
But it wasn't to be. Two weeks ago, with no warning, GE Capital pulled the loan off the table and faded away like ink on a newspaper. The abrupt retreat left AbitibiBowater with little choice but to cede what it described in court documents as "extraordinary" rights to a set of replacement DIP lenders. The generous terms are the latest in a series of power grabs by bankruptcy lenders that have triggered a handful of messy and time-consuming creditor battles.
"He who controls the DIP controls the process these days," said Aubrey Kauffman, a restructuring specialist with Fasken Martineau DuMoulin LLP.
AbitibiBowater lost virtually all of its negotiating leverage with potential DIP lenders when GE Capital left it stranded.
"That jolted everybody," said one person close to AbitibiBowater.
After what sources described as five frantic days and nights of talks with potential lenders including Goldman Sachs & Co., AbitibiBowater and its legal team at Stikeman Elliott LLP and Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison LLP were unable to strike a replacement deal with conventional lenders.
Instead, it was forced to tap two of its major investors - Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. and Avenue Capital Group - and the Quebec government for a total of about $300-million in DIP loans. If certain conditions are met, the company can borrow as much as $700-million.
A voluminous 252-page credit agreement negotiated by Fairfax's lawyers at Torys LLP and Shearman Sterling LLP and Avenue Capital's New York firm Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP essentially vaulted the two investors from a lowly perch as largely unsecured creditors to high-ranking lenders with the right to effectively veto most major decisions, such as asset sales.
Restructuring loans have been a lucrative business for decades for adventurous lenders such as GE Capital and CIT Group. DIP lending pays high interest rates, rich fees and, typically, the loans rank ahead of most other debts.
Defaults are rare on DIP loans, but lenders have largely pulled away from the market because of fears that losses will rise as the global recession deepens. Moody's Investors Service has become so concerned about DIP loans that it recently started to rate them to reflect the risks of possible defaults.
Against this backdrop, most companies don't have much choice but to swallow tough terms demanded by those willing to wager a DIP loan.
These days, most troubled companies can raise DIP loans only from a short list of affiliated companies, existing investors and, in some cases, governments that are willing to protect their existing investments or political interests by lending emergency funds.
"The only people who are willing to come forward are people who already have a vested stake in the company and want to preserve their interests through a DIP loan," said Robert Chadwick, a Goodmans LLP lawyer who represents a number of AbitibiBowater bondholders.
These loans don't always sit well with other creditors, some of whom are pushing back against what they call overgenerous loans. The result is heightened tension between creditors, and delays for managers who are racing against the clock to right their corporate ships in turbulent waters.
Dutch-based petrochemical giant LyondellBasell Industries found itself in the middle of an international bank shoving match when it negotiated a record $8-billion (U.S.) DIP loan with a syndicate of banks in January to tide it through bankruptcy court proceedings. At least one bank, ABN Amro, was so infuriated that it threatened to walk away from the bailout because it argued that the big DIP loan weakened its claim to company assets set aside as collateral for its $3.4-billion loan.
Other unsecured creditors were so angered that some made moves to claim assets from LyondellBasell affiliates that were operating outside court protection. The mess has kept LyondellBasell and its lawyers busy in a variety of courts seeking orders to stop the creditor raids.
Creditors of the company that owns the Philadelphia Inquirer started complaining when they read the fine print in a $25-million (U.S.) DIP loan and discovered that the lender, a real estate developer, protected the job and pay raise of the company's chief executive officer, Brian Tierney. Shortly after the company won protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, Mr. Tierney agreed to give up his raise.
Creditors of Circuit City's Canadian chain, The Source, found themselves in a cross-border tug of war about the terms of a $1.3-billion DIP loan that was arranged for the U.S.-based retailer by a syndicate of its existing banks led by Bank of America. When The Source's Canadian creditors began to read the small print, "the plot thickened," said Fasken's Mr. Kauffman, who represents one of the subsidiary's suppliers.
What the creditors discovered was that the U.S. parent had agreed to hand the DIP lenders the right to seize most the assets of the healthy Canadian unit. The arrangement earned a rare rebuke from a court-appointed monitor and an Ontario judge set aside a portion of Canadian assets to protect local creditors.
Orestes Pasparakis, an Ogilvy Renault LLP lawyer who represented Bank of America in the Circuit City filing, defended the terms of the U.S. DIP as the necessary price of a loan that was urgently needed to keep a troubled retailer operating. In the end, the U.S. parent was forced to liquidate, but he said the DIP loan, which has been fully repaid, allowed the healthier Canadian unit to keep paying its bills while it restructured. "The Canadian stores would not have had the luxury of exploring its options had it not been for that loan," he said.

Title: Lenders jockey for pole position

Amsterdam's new headquarters of hip

Author: Forman, Janet

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/amsterdams-new-headquarters-hip/docview/382643752/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Still, the old kitchen supply store Duikelman may be the clearest barometer of the neighbourhood's change. Open since 1940, it's crammed with utensils evolved from Holland's lactose- and caffeine-laced cuisine, such as a two-handled cheese knife akin to a miniature whipsaw and a no-fail milk foamer shaped like a fishnet. But these days demand from de Pijp's new house-proud residents has spawned two branches.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Amsterdam%27s+new+headquarters+of+hip&amp;author=Forman%2C+Janet&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-18&amp;spage=T.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Amsterdam%27s+new+headquarters+of+hip&amp;author=Forman%2C+Janet&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-18&amp;spage=T.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   In open-minded Amsterdam, where stolid burghers welcomed the Sixties and ladies of the evening ply their trade alongside tulips and the Night Watch, commerce has long cohabited easily with the avant-garde. Over the past few years, the Dutch blend of enterprise and innovation has galvanized two unlikely neighbourhoods. The Eastern Docklands near Central Station, once a 19th-century cargo port, is becoming a laboratory for contemporary architecture and city living, and De Pijp, an immigrant quarter just south of the central city, is drawing young professionals and the boutiques that love them.
De Pijp
In the 1980s, de Pijp was a rough-around-the-edges home to newcomers from more than 100 countries. At the tail end of the 1960s, when I lived in a studentenhuis nearby, it was known as a place to find cheap ethnic eats, flea market stalls peddling Second World War memorabilia, and a few working girls. ( De Pijp - "the pipe" - is also Dutch slang for the male organ.) Recent construction of a subway line, set to open in 2013, has kick-started development, spurred by a torrent of young financial types seeking reasonably priced real estate in this space-starved city.
"Six years ago, when my friends and I came to Amsterdam to study, this was a rare neighbourhood close to the centre that students could afford," says 27-year-old Cyril Vink, an information technology industry headhunter and son of a close friend from my student days. De Pijp has got livelier over the past few years, he notes, with bars and restaurants replacing Middle Eastern groceries.
"I've seen property values shoot up nearly 400 per cent in the last few years," says Vink, who like many of his real-estate-savvy peers has combined several small flats here into a roomy loft.
In the past generation, little seems to have changed at de Pijp's century-old flea market, Albert Cuyp Market, where most of the 300-plus vendors appear to be hawking the same melange of second-hand dinner jackets, herring and chocolate genitalia as they were in 1969. But now traditional establishments such as De Peperbol, a spice-crammed booth emitting the heady aroma of a Dutch East India Company ship, co-exists with newcomers such as Bazar Amsterdam, a trendy Middle Eastern spot transformed with hand-painted Iranian tiles from an old church into a coolhunter's idea of the Thousand and One Nights .
Nightlife throbs around the central square, Gerard Douplein. Here, tables spilling out of cozy "brown bars" such as Het Paardje - which lacks tobacco-stained walls, thanks to a recent smoking ban - mingle with the overflow from posh establishments such as WynBar. It's a tangle of beer, wine and bonhomie around an eccentric sculpture built from discarded cookie moulds.
Aging aunties are celebrated at the kitschy bakery café De Taart van m'n Tante - My Auntie's Cake - where young style-makers take tea on overstuffed chairs amid a field of fake tulips, flanked by a spun-sugar Elvis wailing on his confectionery guitar, and a freshly baked Superman saving a gumdrop metropolis. Aspiring Hansels and Gretels can stay at a bed and breakfast, Cake Under My Pillow, which is less messy than its name implies.
Still, the old kitchen supply store Duikelman may be the clearest barometer of the neighbourhood's change. Open since 1940, it's crammed with utensils evolved from Holland's lactose- and caffeine-laced cuisine, such as a two-handled cheese knife akin to a miniature whipsaw and a no-fail milk foamer shaped like a fishnet. But these days demand from de Pijp's new house-proud residents has spawned two branches.
The Eastern Docklands
On the other side of Central Station, a futuristic version of Venice is rising on wind-whipped man-made islands abandoned in the 1970s when Amsterdam's cargo port moved out of the city.
While restaurants and boutiques are sprouting on the wharves of several European cities, including Dusseldorf and Hamburg, the socially conscious Dutch saw even grander possibilities including city homes for families, accessible living for seniors and studio space for artists. Along these canals, young parents on bikes with kiddie seats outnumber tattooed hipsters.
This zone is also a playground for young architects - who are ripping neglected factory buildings open to the light and reimagining the Renaissance-era canal house in distressed metals and glass. These repopulated islands are connected by fanciful bridges shaped like arching cobras or a flock of soaring birds, and their wharves are lined with a crazy quilt of houseboats, from sleek pleasure cruisers to gritty work vessels draped with wildflowers.
KNSM-laan, a street once favoured by squatters, now thrives with design stores anchored by the renowned interior design studio Pols Potten, the lighthearted lifestyle store Sissy-Boy Homeland, a multicoloured explosion of children's clothing and games at Keet in Huis, and Arrival/Departure with its fresh take on mid-century fashions - like a vampy Swing Era-style dress from the retro label Stop
Staring.
For fine dining, Jamie Oliver's Fifteen, which like its London sibling takes on at-risk youngsters as apprentices, is flourishing in a warehouse hung with crystal chandeliers. While the white-tablecloth section serves a four-course set menu, the less formal trattoria offers free choice of vibrant dishes sourced from local farms, including rich lamb shoulder ragu with rosemary and palate-twisting desserts such as panna cotta with rhubarb and prosecco-mascarpone ice cream.
An iconic place to spend the night is the Lloyd Hotel, a commanding monument to early Amsterdam School architecture - the Dutch version of art deco. This unorthodox establishment offers one-star bath-in-the-hall accommodations alongside sprawling five-star suites with unusual amenities, such as a grand piano or a bed that sleeps eight.
Yet my ballroom-size five-star room with 25-foot windows had the distinction of being both dramatic and less than comfortable. With its double bed moored in a corner like a foundering ship in the ocean and a loo boasting 1920s atmosphere with amenities to match, this particular accommodation was a bit too redolent of its past lives as a clerk-filled shipping office and a dorm for errant juveniles. Next time, I'll go for a stylish one-star ($160) that bears few traces of its days as a post-Second World War detention centre for Dutch collaborators.
Still, the lure of the Lloyd is less in its billets than in its distinctive clientele, an eclectic mix of European creative types who gather around a communal table for farm-style breakfasts of yeasty baguettes, crackling croissants and homemade cakes before heading upstairs to the hotel's Cultural Embassy, a clubby hotline to Amsterdam's music and art scene.
But which neighbourhood will nurture the next wave of hopefuls arriving with a sketch pad and dream? Amsterdam's intrepid town fathers have started rolling out the welcome mat in the Red Light District, converting former bordellos into studio space for clothing stylists and jewellers with the help of celebrated design firms such as Droog and Moooi.
And after that? As avant-garde boutiques blossom between shop windows displaying more corporeal pleasures, Amsterdam's once iconic smoking coffee shops may look so endearingly antiquated the next generation may feel compelled to launch a preservation movement on their
behalf.
******

Hogtown needs a taste of Big Apple attitude

Author: LeBlanc, Dave

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/hogtown-needs-taste-big-apple-attitude/docview/382645543/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Andrew Berman will do until then. As executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, he's been speaking for the New York University-owned buildings since 2003, when he wrote a four-page letter to the Landmarks Preservation Commission asking that Silver Towers be awarded landmark status. With true New York attitude, Mr. Berman threw around phrases such as "stylish" and "visually sensual" about the 1960s I.M.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hogtown+needs+a+taste+of+Big+Apple+attitude&amp;author=LeBlanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-17&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hogtown+needs+a+taste+of+Big+Apple+attitude&amp;author=LeBlanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-17&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   "Hey, I'm walkin' here!
I'm walkin' here!"
- Ratso Rizzo,
Midnight Cowboy , 1969
Attitude: It's what makes New York great. Dustin Hoffman's sad sack Rizzo had it. So did Robert De Niro's psycho Travis Bickle or Joe Pesci's "goodfella" Tommy DeVito. The average guy driving a hack or the lady at the corner dry cleaners has even more.
If New York buildings could talk, they'd have it too: "You got a problem with concrete, Toronto guy? Are we too harsh for your namby-pamby sensibilities? Well get over it!" That's what a trio of 30-storey towers in Greenwich Village would say to us if they could.
Andrew Berman will do until then. As executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, he's been speaking for the New York University-owned buildings since 2003, when he wrote a four-page letter to the Landmarks Preservation Commission asking that Silver Towers be awarded landmark status. With true New York attitude, Mr. Berman threw around phrases such as "stylish" and "visually sensual" about the 1960s I.M. Pei-designed brutalist towers; he had the chutzpah to remind the commission that the "monolithic" complex was the product of mid-century urban renewal practices (also known as slum clearance), which, in essence, erased the existing street grid and created a "superblock."
In most cities, these are things to be ashamed of, are they not?
"The reality is, we have big eyes and a broad understanding of what is good design and what makes our neighbourhood work and it's not limited simply to 19th-century townhouses," says Mr. Berman, 40, who is no doubt responsible for getting landmark recognition for dozens of charming townhouses, too, since his appointment to the GVSHP in 2002. "We understand how some of the great works of architecture in our neighbourhood contribute ... very significantly to the history of urban design nationally and internationally."
The commission agreed. Last November, the three towers, the space between them and most of the superblock - including original landscaping and an enormous concrete Pablo Picasso sculpture - became a protected landmark.
The successful "weaving" of disparate design and programmatic mandates from multiple bureaucratic layers had much to do with the decision to landmark the complex. In the early 1960s, legendary urban planner Robert Moses assembled three Greenwich Village city blocks into one superblock and gave it to NYU for campus expansion. Neighbourhood opposition over the loss of affordable housing forced the university to use just two buildings for faculty housing and give over the third to villagers to run as a co-op. For design credibility, Mr. Pei and associate James Ingo Freed were selected in 1966 and Norweigan sculptor Carl Nesjär was brought in to execute the construction of the 60-ton concrete Bust of Sylvette, an enlargement of a sculpture by Picasso.
While Silver Towers may strike the casual observer as just another set of unremarkable concrete slabs, that Mr. Pei was able to arrange the buff-coloured, poured-in-place towers in a pinwheel plan, animate them via deep-set windows, pay homage to the existing street grid with "visual thoroughfares" (like our own Alexandra Place by Jerome Markson, Klein & Sears and WZMH) and thoughtfully consider the pedestrian experience means that there is much more than meets the eye. It's a delicate solution to shoehorning modernism into "one of the oldest neighbourhoods in New York City," says Mr. Berman. "That's what makes this complex so worthy of recognition."
Which is not to say the idea didn't meet with resistance. NYU, for instance, was "vehement" in their opposition at first and came around only after the writing was on the wall; a few LPC members couldn't wrap their heads around why such an anti-Jane Jacobs complex should be celebrated until they were schooled in Modernism 101; still other critics accused the GVSHP of sneakily using heritage as a shield to prevent redevelopment the site...until they gazed upon the list of architectural luminaries supporting the landmarking effort.
"Obviously this is relatively new ground," explains Mr. Berman. "I think there's going to continue to be resistance to a lot of this kind of architecture, but hopefully this designation makes it a little bit easier to understand and accept that concrete high rises do not necessarily equal bad architecture and urban renewal does not necessarily equal bad architecture - in fact in some cases it equals great architecture."
So, what about all that great Toronto concrete architecture? Since Mr. Berman admits his job would have been "much, much harder" had Silver Towers not been designed by a legend (with a legendary artist's work in the courtyard), he suggests other cities warm up with projects by name architects first, then follow with local firms. Obviously, John Andrews's 1965 Scarborough College is an excellent place to start, as is the University of Toronto's 1973 Robarts Library by New York firm Warner Burns Toan & Lunde (with local good guys Mathers & Haldenby), which would then pave the way for buildings such as Peter Dickinson's 1958 tower at 14 Blevins Place in our very own slum-clearance project Regent Park (listed but not designated), and, perhaps, Clifford & Lawrie's early-70s Manulife Centre on Bloor St.
"Things that we treasure now," finishes Mr. Berman, "for generations were really reviled -whether it's art deco architecture or Victorian architecture; this is part of an ongoing and constant process."
A process that sometimes takes an attitude adjustment.

DONE DEALS: PAPE AND DANFORTH

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/done-deals-pape-danforth/docview/382644484/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: LISTING AGENTS: Lindsay and Melanie Wright, Re/Max Hallmark Realty Ltd.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DONE+DEALS%3A+PAPE+AND+DANFORTH&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-17&amp;spage=G.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   568 PAPE AVE.
ASKING PRICE: $399,900
SELLING PRICE: $405,000
PREVIOUS SELLING PRICES: $363,000 (2006)
$320,000 (2006)
$230,500 (2002)
TAXES: $2,459 (2008)
LOT SIZE: 18 by 100 feet
DAYS ON THE MARKET: four
LISTING AGENTS: Lindsay and Melanie Wright, Re/Max Hallmark Realty Ltd.
Within a span of four days, multiple offers were submitted for this semi-detached residence in the north section of Riverdale.
Perennial gardens surround the two-storey house, which contains three bedrooms upstairs and two full bathrooms, plus a finished basement that was previously rented for $750 a month.
There is a living room and a formal dining room decorated with an imitation fireplace and stained glass windows.
The floors are hardwood, except in the updated kitchen, which has bamboo floors and counters made from wood salvaged by a local company.
Off the rear is a door to a stairwell with an exit to the yard and stairs to the lower level, where there is a carpeted bedroom and open living area with kitchen facilities along one wall.
There is no private parking, but the property is in a premium location within steps of schools, the Pape subway station, Danforth Avenue shops and Withrow Park.

Full text:   ART & MUSEUMS

Should clothes make amends? With Regeneration Gap (an exhibition of three installations using great piles of tossed-away clothing), Winnipeg artist Charzewski comments on North American consumer culture, overstuffed landfills and the fabrication, as it where, of history. LITERARY AND LECTURES
What's Wrong With Our Newspapers
"Once the reader came to the newspaper because he had few other places to go; now it must go to him." Newspaperman Louis B. Seltzer wrote that in 1956, when circulation and ad revenue was at a peak. More than 50 years later, with the industry in freefall, a panel including award-winning author-journalists Peter C. Newman and Linda McQuaig opine again about print. Today, 7:30 p.m. $10. This is Not a Reading Series
Jake is frustrated by the constant companionship of his bouncy sister Louise, and yet he's still courteous as he pleads for privacy. Louise, Please! , an award-winning children's book from writer Frieda Wishinsky and illustrator Marie-Louise Gay, is presented along with Our Corner Grocery Store , new from author Joanna Schwartz and artist Laura Beingessner, about a girl who spends a marvellous day at her grandparent's shop. IT'S A VENGEFUL DAY IN THE NEIGHBOURHOOD

Author: Bielski, Zosia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/vengeful-day-neighbourhood/docview/382646089/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "In some cases, there is no law, and in other cases, there's a law but it's very hard to enforce," said Mr. [Peter Bruer], adding that neighbour disputes "boil down to the fact that people don't respect each other."Bill Saundercook, the city councillor in Mr. [Ralph Scala]'s ward, deals with feuding neighbours three times a week. The most recent squabble involved water drainage between two houses.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=IT%27S+A+VENGEFUL+DAY+IN+THE+NEIGHBOURHOOD&amp;author=Bielski%2C+Zosia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-16&amp;spage=L.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=IT%27S+A+VENGEFUL+DAY+IN+THE+NEIGHBOURHOOD&amp;author=Bielski%2C+Zosia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-16&amp;spage=L.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Innocuous incidents can escalate into all-out assaults that lead to legal bills, health issues, marital strain - even force people from their dream homes. Zosia Bielski reports
As Jacqueline Desjardins's garage leaned precariously over her neighbour's lawn, the man would stand by watching, and laugh.
Later, the 74-year-old Sudbury woman would find her car scratched up, a spare tire slashed. Used oil containers appeared next to her well. And then there were the two-by-fours: Buried near the wobbly garage, they were spiked with thick, four-inch-nails that jutted upward. But things really heated up when her 78-year-old husband, Lucien Desjardins, accused his neighbour, Ahti Blick, of trying to run him down with his car.
The incidents were noted by Ontario Superior Court Judge Paul Kane this month when he fined Mr. Blick and Maija Blick $57,000 in damages for trying to sink the Desjardins' garage by digging trenches and running water underneath it with a garden hose.
It was the culmination of a feud that began decades earlier, pivoting entirely around the small garage: The Desjardins said it sat 17 inches from the lot line; the Blicks believed it encroached on their property. After many fruitless calls to police, Ms. Desjardins attempted to sell the house, but the notorious dispute meant no one was buying.
"It's not so much the digging that bothered me," Ms. Desjardins said. "He was standing there laughing at us."
The case highlights the exasperation of victims of neighbour rage, which in the worst of cases can force people from their dream homes, leave them with staggering legal costs and cause serious health issues, as well as marital strain.
Post-traumatic stress, anxiety, depression and loss of appetite were just some of the ailments suffered by Ralph Scala's neighbours on Quebec Avenue in the west-end Junction area of Toronto. There, Mr. Scala's seven-year reign of terror against 26 locals involved hired goons, as well as a tombstone and roadkill strewn on the lawn of one elderly victim.
Although Mr. Scala pleaded guilty to 49 charges and was banned from the area for three years, the damage was done: The neighbours' victim impact statements revealed intense fears of reprisal.
For nearly two years, the neighbours of Wychwood Park, an exclusive Toronto enclave, were similarly traumatized. Routinely, residents who parked on a narrow street had all four of their tires slashed. Neighbours were stunned when they learned Albert Fulton, the local archivist and Neighbourhood Watch leader, had been arrested. (After reports of the charges surfaced, Mr. Fulton committed suicide.)
Although the cases are extreme, each began innocuously enough, with what one neighbour perceived as a grave slight on the part of the other.
But such matters can quickly escalate, said Peter Bruer, manager of conflict resolution services at St. Stephen's Community House in Toronto, where 50 volunteer mediators help bickering neighbours talk it out face to face.
"We've seen situations that have driven people out of their homes. It could start with a leaky eavestrough that ices up somebody else's walkway."
Typical issues include parking, fences, garbage, flooding downspouts and barking dogs - or something that simply "gets under their skin." Although St. Stephen's receives roughly 500 calls a year, one-third of which are referred by police, just 100 make it to the meeting stage because one party is usually more keen than the other.
"In some cases, there is no law, and in other cases, there's a law but it's very hard to enforce," said Mr. Bruer, adding that neighbour disputes "boil down to the fact that people don't respect each other."Bill Saundercook, the city councillor in Mr. Scala's ward, deals with feuding neighbours three times a week. The most recent squabble involved water drainage between two houses.
"I can point to a troublemaker pretty much on every street in my ward that neighbours call and complain about. It's the cranky old man that's stealing the children's ball when it comes on his lawn or someone trying to get back at their neighbour by building their fence higher than they can," Mr. Saundercook said.
The councillor usually begins negotiations by phone. Failing that, he goes in person: "If I pay a visit to one, I pay a visit to the other."
As neighbours will tend to hastily call in lawyers and bylaw-enforcement officers, Mr. Saundercook finds himself cautioning them against full-scale attacks.
His advice: "You see your neighbours way more than you see your own family. If you decide to escalate a matter that might be trivial in its outset, then just do that with your eyes wide open."
To help prevent arguments from intensifying, Toronto's Municipal Licensing and Standards (which handles 110,000 calls annually) ran its 130 investigators through alternative dispute resolution training in 2006. The program gives officers better tools to mend grudges.
While private property can "increase the energy" because owners have invested money and time, Mr. Bruer says St. Stephen's also gets many calls from renters and roommates "driven crazy by the close proximity of somebody else's lifestyle that interferes with their lifestyle."
As urban density intensifies, feuding neighbours may become a liability for real estate agents as well.
"If you know that the neighbour's a crank, you have to say they're a crank," especially when representing the buyers, said Toronto broker Chander Chaddah. "Clients are owed full disclosure of any information that you as a practitioner may be in position of that could have an impact on their decision making. ... It's part of our code of business practices."
When Mr. Chaddah took prospective buyers to a client's home on Quebec Avenue, the street where Mr. Scala terrorized his neighbours and where his incapacitated mother still lives, the buyers grew worried: Mr. Scala may return in three years. (Police have told neighbours to keep their surveillance equipment at the ready and keep detailed notes on suspicious activity.)
As for the Desjardins, they will once again square off against the Blicks on April 25, this time for court costs. The families are still neighbours, but the Desjardins have installed three security cameras.
"I get up in the morning and I say to my husband, 'What is today going to bring?' " Ms. Desjardins said. "We never know."

Gentrification meets low-income housing

Author: Stueck, Wendy

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/gentrification-meets-low-income-housing/docview/382647928/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: On a recent sunny day, one of the window tables at Waves was occupied by Wendy Pedersen, a vocal housing activist who's fought market condo developments and led gentrification tours of the neighbourhood. Introduced to Mr. [Cyrous Sharifpour], Ms. Pedersen urged him to make the shop welcoming to everybody, not just the well dressed or well heeled. As the conversation went on, police officers lined up for lattes and an unshaven man with a ponytail sat quietly at the counter looking out at the street.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Gentrification+meets+low-income+housing&amp;author=Stueck%2C+Wendy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-15&amp;spage=A.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Gentrification+meets+low-income+housing&amp;author=Stueck%2C+Wendy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-15&amp;spage=A.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Owner of new coffee shop, with social housing upstairs, is betting on Downtown Eastside's future
There are plate-glass windows at a new coffee shop on the corner of Main and Cordova in Vancouver's Downtown Eastside.
There are no bars on these windows, as there are on those of a convenience store across the street. The stretch of glass might seem foolhardy in a neighbourhood with one of the highest property-crime rates in the city. Or it could be seen as a calculated risk, given that the Vancouver Police Department's Main Street station is across the street.
For Cyrous Sharifpour, the windows are a symbol.
"When you put bars up, you make things frightening," says Mr. Sharifpour, the franchisee at this location. "You make it a fearful environment for the customer."
Opened in March, this Waves - the 14th for the chain, founded in 2005 - is a bright, upscale place, with polished tables and free wireless. Startup costs for the turnkey operation were about $350,000.
And it's one of several businesses that have moved to the area in recent months, betting on the neighbourhood's future even as they fuel worries about gentrification.
Bean Around the World has a location on Gore Street, near two new condo projects. Tenants in Woodward's project on Hastings Street will include London Drugs and Nesters, a B.C. grocery chain. Les Amis du Fromage has opened its third retail outlet, and adjoining bistro, on East Hastings Street. Waves has another outlet nearby at Main and Pender.
There have been no more problems with crime or vandalism at Waves stores in the Downtown Eastside than anywhere else in the city, says founder Kami Rahmati. He'd snap up any property he could, if he could afford it.
Others have had the same idea. Developer interest put so much pressure on real-estate prices that the province stepped in, buying more than 20 single-room occupancy hotels in the Downtown Eastside since 2007 to protect low-income housing.
The Waves site used to be home to Vic's, a diner featured in television series Da Vinci's Inquest . The second floor of the two-storey building contained rooms rented by the month.
In 2003, Vancouver film director William Vince bought the Waves site and two other buildings in the same block in an ambitious plan to nurture the local arts scene. Mr. Vince, best known for directing the 2005 Oscar-nominated film Capote , died last year. The William Vince Foundation runs from offices in District 319, a restored movie house, and focuses on causes championed by Mr. Vince, including film and sports programs for kids.
For a while, the floor above Waves was used for office space. Community activists pushed the building's new owners to turn it back into low-income housing. Last month, the 11 rooms reopened as social housing, run by Atira Women's Resource Society and reserved for women 45 and older.
Waves has a 20-year lease, comprising a 10-year initial term and two, five-year options to renew. Atira has a three-year lease with an option to renew for another three-year term.
For now, the upscale newcomer coexists with its less glamorous neighbour. But in terms of long-term tenure, the coffee shop is more secure than the women upstairs.
On a recent sunny day, one of the window tables at Waves was occupied by Wendy Pedersen, a vocal housing activist who's fought market condo developments and led gentrification tours of the neighbourhood. Introduced to Mr. Sharifpour, Ms. Pedersen urged him to make the shop welcoming to everybody, not just the well dressed or well heeled. As the conversation went on, police officers lined up for lattes and an unshaven man with a ponytail sat quietly at the counter looking out at the street.
He can sit there as long as he wants, Mr. Sharifpour said.
"I have not had to ask anyone to leave," he said.

Now here are a few shows you can complain about

Author: Doyle, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/now-here-are-few-shows-you-can-complain-about/docview/382646887/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: As Fox's reality TV exec Mike Darnell pronounced, "For six years, it's been skinny-minis and good-looking bachelors, and that's not what the dating world looks like." As the critic for The Washington Post, a wonderful woman, put it, "Fat chicks have needs, too; Fox wants to be there for them."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Now+here+are+a+few+shows+you+can+complain+about&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-15&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Now+here+are+a+few+shows+you+can+complain+about&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-15&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   How's it goin'? I'm doing pretty well, myself. Yeah. For sure.
No, I'm not fat, by the way. The other day, because I noted that the vast majority of characters on Harper's Island are obscenely thin, some people wrote to me and said, you know, I was just bitter. Because I must be overweight or huge and ugly. Revenge of the chortling skinnies kinda thing, I guess. I'm trim. So shut up.
Which reminds me. Coming soon from Fox (of course) is More to Love , a reality show featuring a group of "curvy women" who compete - just like you see on The Bachelor - for the affections of one charming guy whose attractions are described as "a big waist and an even bigger heart." Already, Fox is trawling the United States for what it calls "eligible plus-sized women" who want to go crazy on TV for some grinning dude.
As Fox's reality TV exec Mike Darnell pronounced, "For six years, it's been skinny-minis and good-looking bachelors, and that's not what the dating world looks like." As the critic for The Washington Post, a wonderful woman, put it, "Fat chicks have needs, too; Fox wants to be there for them."
Indeed. I'm telling ya here - the hits keep coming. There are many, many reality TV shows out there and more are coming. Some are incredibly crude. Many are cruel, obnoxious and foisted on a public that wants to be simultaneously shocked, titillated and appalled.
But we don't have to watch them. No sirree. Me, when not paying close attention to my diet and exercise, I'm a tad fed-up. I'm sick and tired of all the moaning about reality TV shows that are obviously in poor taste. Guess what? You don't have to watch them. Somebody else might watch, but getting all hoity-toity and condemning television, is pointless and ridiculous. Look, if you're going to be all fuss-budget and upset, there's no need to go out of your way to find these shows.
You want to be outraged? Here are some examples of reality TV shows that can irritate you. Then you can avoid them.
Fox (of course) is steaming ahead with Someone's Gotta Go , a reality series in which real, actual people who work in real, actual workplaces, bicker and debate about who should get fired to cut costs. Then the person is actually fired. You are probably wondering why people would agree to participate. Easy: There might be a shortage of job opportunities, but there is no shortage of people who just want to be on TV.
The Cougar is already running on the U.S. cable channel TV Land. "One older woman, 20 younger men. Watch as she narrows her choices and ultimately chooses one lucky man to be her soul mate." Yes, it follows fortysomething real-estate sales person Stacey Anderson, mother of four, as she chooses from among a group of smirking young men in their 20s. Several are younger than one of her sons. Coming this summer on The CW channel is the six-episode Hitched or Ditched , which is about couples who have been dating for years, and are given an ultimatum to either get married within the week, or just break up.
Oh yeah - People magazine claims that Nadya Suleman, known as "Octomom" since she gave birth to eight children a few months ago, will "probably sign a deal very soon to feature her and her family of 14 children in a reality TV show." Apparently Octomom has met with four production companies and will meet this week with certain network execs. It is reported that ideas being discussed are "episodes chronicling such themes as Suleman learning to drive a 14-passenger van, going on a date or having a big family Thanksgiving or Christmas."
There you go. Enjoy or avoid. Your call.
adoyle@globeandmail.com
*****
Also airing
Great Performances at The Met: Lucia di Lammermoor (PBS, 9 p.m.) This production stars what is called "the Met's brightest star," the dazzling Anna Netrebko. Soprano Netrebko, returning to the Metropolitan Opera stage for the first time since giving birth to a son in September, takes the demanding title role - a young woman driven to madness by love and politics. Piotr Beczala co-stars as Lucia's head-strong lover Edgardo. As dramatic as all get-out.
Shrink Rap (Documentary, 9 p.m.) is the most peculiar of talk shows. The host/inquisitor is former actress Pamela Stephenson, now a registered psychotherapist in Los Angeles, married to actor Billy Connolly and known sometimes as Dr. Pamela Connolly. In this series of in-depth interviews, made for British TV, she uses her psychological skills to interview the famous, often about highly sensitive topics. In this episode she talks to Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York. Stephenson discusses Ferguson's long-established rebellious nature and her difficult transition into the royal household. She also talks about her problems with her weight and self-image. The most commonly asked question in the series is "You really didn't get much nurturing as a child, did you?"
The Jon Dore Television Show (Comedy, 10 p.m.) reaches its season finale tonight. Dore's comedy is an acquired taste. His tactic is to play the moron who stumbles upon truth and reality. It's beyond deadpan, this style. In this episode, Dore delves into the world of drugs. He starts from the position that all drugs are bad. Then he interviews real people and learns, amazingly, that sometimes drugs can help people. Is it funny? Go figure. J.D.
Check local listings.

ERNEST (ERNIE) ALFRED MAY

Author: May, Terry

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ernest-ernie-alfred-may/docview/382648063/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: [Ernie] met his future wife, Phyllis, on his way to a party on Christmas Day. In 1942, he was called up to work in the coal mines. Ernie's first job was to tend to the "pit ponies" that pulled tubs of coal from the pit face.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=ERNEST+%28ERNIE%29+ALFRED+MAY&amp;author=May%2C+Terry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-14&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=ERNEST+%28ERNIE%29+ALFRED+MAY&amp;author=May%2C+Terry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-14&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Husband, father, grandfather, coal miner, aircraft assembler, appraiser. Born Nov. 13, 1924, in Kingston upon Hull, England. Died Sept. 26, 2008, in Richmond Hill, Ont., of a heart attack, aged 83.
Ernie was born into a working-class family in northern England, and was raised by his mother Mary. He never knew his father, who had left the family shortly after he was born. His brother Ted, five years his senior, was charged with much of his care as Mary had to work to support the family. Even though most of Ernie's childhood was spent during the Depression, some of his fondest memories were of those times.
Ernie was in his final year of high school when the Second World War broke out. He was transferred from Hull, which was a target for German bombers, to the nearby seaside town of Scarborough. He and his classmates would often explore the local beaches, occasionally coming across sea mines that had washed ashore. The Home Guard would be notified and shoot at the mine until it detonated, much to the delight of Ernie and his friends.
After graduation, Ernie moved back with his family in Hull and began working. It was a bleak time, as food was rationed and the intensity of the nightly air raids increased. Ernie's home was damaged by a bomb that levelled a row of houses across the street. He and the neighbours spent the rest of the night digging survivors out of the rubble.
Ernie met his future wife, Phyllis, on his way to a party on Christmas Day. In 1942, he was called up to work in the coal mines. Ernie's first job was to tend to the "pit ponies" that pulled tubs of coal from the pit face.
In 1946, Ernie married
Phyllis, and with work difficult to come by, they decided to immigrate to Canada. With no particular destination in mind they settled in Toronto, as that was where their flight had landed.
Despite starting off with only a suitcase and a few dollars, by the early 1950s they had built a home in North York. It was during this time that Ernie worked at his favourite job, as a riveter for Avro. The next few years were exciting as he helped assemble the Arrow. Unfortunately, he lost his job along with 14,000 other Avro employees on "'Black Friday," the day the federal government cancelled the project.
Ernie, Phyllis and their son Terry moved north of Toronto and Ernie began selling real estate. His final job was as a property appraiser for Revenue Canada.
After Ernie retired, he enjoyed travelling with Phyllis to the Caribbean, American Southwest and back to England. He stayed active into his later years with photography, tending to his garden and playing with his grandson, Andrew. Whereas many people work at only one or two professions during their lives, he excelled at several.
Terry May is Ernie's son.
submissions:
lives@globeandmail.com

Africans are escaping the worst of the global crisis

Author: G. Pascal Zachary

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/africans-are-escaping-worst-global-crisis/docview/382651806/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Another factor working in Africa's favour is its private companies' and consumers' low dependence on borrowed money. People tend to pay cash for goods and services, however costly. In the United States, loans for cars and homes - loans that now aren't being paid back - are the major factor behind the financial crisis. In Africa, very few people borrow money for such purchases.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Africans+are+escaping+the+worst+of+the+global+crisis&amp;author=G.+Pascal+Zachary&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-11&amp;spage=A.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Africans+are+escaping+the+worst+of+the+global+crisis&amp;author=G.+Pascal+Zachary&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-11&amp;spage=A.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The United States suffers rising job losses. Britain nationalizes its banks. Once high-flying small economies such as Ireland, Hungary and Iceland break down. Even robust China and India are experiencing slower growth, curtailed ambitions and broken dreams.
Yet, in sub-Saharan Africa, there are few hints of the global financial crisis that is consuming the capitalist world.
In fashionable African cities, residential home prices remain stratospheric. A typical Western-style house in Kampala or Accra, for example, now costs an astonishing two to three times the price of a comparable home in Cleveland or other cities in the American heartland. While home prices are crashing from Madrid to Dublin and Miami to Los Angeles, African prices remain near or at record-high levels.
African banks, meanwhile, are rock-solid compared to their debt-heavy counterparts in the United States and Europe. While international bankers went bust by making legions of bad loans, African bankers stuck to earning profits the old-fashioned way: paying very little to depositors, and earning a big "spread" by buying guaranteed government debt, which yielded healthy returns.
Even government deficit spending, long the bane of Africa, seems positively puny compared with the massive debts that the United States and some European countries face.
And yet there are good reasons to believe that it is just a matter of time before Africa and its people experience the ill effects of the global crisis. From Ghana to Kenya, governments are having increased difficulty in raising money for infrastructure projects and selling official debt.
Foreign investment in sub-Saharan Africa, which reached record levels in recent years, is retreating, which is evidence of investor caution, not any underlying lack of optimism about the region. And exports of raw material to China, India, Europe and the United States, a key factor in Africa's recent growth surge, may suffer simply because the global slowdown means less consumption everywhere.
All of these factors suggest that an African financial bust is possible.
Popular equity investments, such as shares in the telecommunications firm Safaricom, are already trading at unexpectedly low levels. If real estate prices were to fall dramatically, a chain reaction could occur, taking down big and small investors alike, and over time causing wide suffering to ordinary Africans.
Even assuming stability in real estate prices, the global crisis surely will cause a fall in remittances by Africans working good jobs in Europe, the United States, Canada, Australia and the Middle East.
Immigration itself may even slow dramatically, depending on the length and depth of the economic slowdown. Fewer Africans working in rich countries will automatically translate into less money circulating in African countries.
The decline in remittances, however, cuts both ways. Remittances have long spurred inflation in many parts of Africa. A Ugandan doctor working in Norway, for instance, cares little about the cost of a beer in Kampala. He is also willing, and able, to pay more than a local doctor for services and, of course, a home in Uganda. Fewer remittances flowing into Uganda could mean less economic activity - or simply lower prices.
The financial meltdown in the United States, which incubated the global crisis, is either coming under control or threatening to mutate into a new, more virulent form that could destroy not only America's paper economy of trading and brokering, but also its real economy of goods and services.
President Barack Obama, acting as if the latter scenario remains likely, is betting on large-scale government spending to prop up the real economy. If his administration succeeds, the chances that Africa will remain relatively unscathed will grow.
Even if Obama fails, however, Africans should escape the worst of the global crisis, for both good reasons and bad. The good reasons have to do with African self-reliance and a growing awareness among scholars and policy makers that trade within the region - especially between urban and rural Africa - will ultimately deliver enormous benefits.
Another factor working in Africa's favour is its private companies' and consumers' low dependence on borrowed money. People tend to pay cash for goods and services, however costly. In the United States, loans for cars and homes - loans that now aren't being paid back - are the major factor behind the financial crisis. In Africa, very few people borrow money for such purchases.
Africa's cash-based economy has, in the past, constrained development. After all, by allowing people to spend more than they have, borrowed money can fuel growth. But today, the continent's pay-as-you-go practices are a powerful defence against financial contagion.
Another way of looking at Africa's paradoxical economic position is to admit that the region's historical marginalization within the international financial system, so costly in times of global plenty, is proving to be an unexpected benefit when the wealthiest of the world are sick unto death.
G. Pascal Zachary is the author of
Married to Africa: a Love Story.

Awkward prosperity on Prairies

Author: Robertson, Patricia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/awkward-prosperity-on-prairies/docview/382651846/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "If only we had a Starbucks for the young people to congregate," I said to my partner, Grant, on the weekend. "I guess they'll have to start their own coffee row!" he laughed.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Awkward+prosperity+on+Prairies&amp;author=Robertson%2C+Patricia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-10&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Awkward+prosperity+on+Prairies&amp;author=Robertson%2C+Patricia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-10&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Saskatchewan-based writer
I was at my local Hometown Foods last week when I bumped into a friend looking for the "new" James Bond film, Quantum of Solace . (Out here in the sticks, we don't always get into the city to see a new release, so the $1 movie rental aisle sees some pretty good action on weekends.)
Our casual conversation turned to the absurdly healthy state of Saskatchewan's economy - as it always seems to these days.
"I'm busier than ever," he proclaimed.
"Can you believe our GDP growth leads the nation?" I replied, feeling the kind of back-smacking kinship the bailed-out wealthy must enjoy after cashing a healthy bonus cheque from AIG.
My friend then confessed that a Saskatchewan relative, who now works in Toronto, recently told him that many folks out East thought we didn't "get" the recession and we kept spending, hiring and buying houses anyway.
"They thought we were too stupid to realize there was a worldwide recession going on," he laughed. (Saskatchewan had the highest increase in wholesale, retail and new vehicle sales in the country.)
I guess it's a small consolation to assume that Saskatchewan's misguided residents are stupidly overspending than to admit that Ontario has lost its economic clout to a mere bunch of sodbusters-turned-carpetbaggers.
In this once downtrodden Next Year Country, there was ample room for economic growth; it just took the right circumstances to set things in motion.
Our real estate was once as undervalued as singer-songwriter Ron Sexsmith, our natural resources remained as chaste as the Jonas Brothers, and our skilled youth were consigned to a grim life in the apocalyptic Alberta tar sands.
In a complete about-face, Saskatchewan's provincial job recruiters are gathering frequent-flier miles heading back and forth to seek more skilled labour in Ontario. "It's hard to get good help these days," we moan as we settle into our hot tubs clutching a craft beer out of the new aluminum cooler.
In a bid to keep our Vegas-style roll going, our provincial government recently introduced income tax cuts and infrastructure spending to ensure we continue to win at the tables. Hell, we even played host to three big lottery winners in March. Will there be enough stretch limos to ferry our nouveau riche around to overpriced Eagles concerts?
Next door, Friendly Manitoba is in the same "socially awkward" state of prosperity. As the Red River miraculously receded last week, those giddy optimists just announced a new football stadium for their Blue Bombers.
There aren't any foreclosure signs on my hometown streets - just new condos. In fact, we've had a flock of arrivistes move to Wakaw recently, pushed out by mounting urban house prices in nearby Saskatoon. Our humble streets are lined with bored young moms pushing strollers. These shack-wacky women loiter in front of the post office with their designer glasses and Lululemon yoga pants, looking very out of place in our pragmatic farm town.
"If only we had a Starbucks for the young people to congregate," I said to my partner, Grant, on the weekend. "I guess they'll have to start their own coffee row!" he laughed.
For those of you who must ride out the downturn in your own distressed region, watch for our own Robert Kurosaki-esque infomercial titled Rich Farmer, Poor Farmer.
"Act now! You, too, can learn the recession-beater secrets it took Saskatchewan farmers a century to perfect. Make your own fashionable flour-sack dresses, learn to 'put up' cucumbers, dig a root cellar and ferment your own dandelion wine," it would blast from your television with the intensity of a Ponzi-scheme pitch.
As for me, I've got my eye on some cheap real estate in sunny Scottsdale. Call me an insensitive Saskatchewan carpetbagger if you must, but I can't seem to stupidly stop spending.

____________________________________________________________

It will take time to get real-estate market back to balance

Author: Stirton, Kerry

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/will-take-time-get-real-estate-market-back/docview/382651476/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: In interviewing [Jonathan Litt] on the issue of U.S. and global real estate prices, and the conditions required for a gradual renewal of confidence, one's sense of caution tends to intensify. Mr. Litt is the founder and portfolio manager of the aptly named Land and Buildings Investment Management, which is focused on commercial real estate and real estate related equities.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=It+will+take+time+to+get+real-estate+market+back+to+balance&amp;author=Stirton%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-10&amp;spage=A.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=It+will+take+time+to+get+real-estate+market+back+to+balance&amp;author=Stirton%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-10&amp;spage=A.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Some early signs of improvement in market psychology have started to take hold over the past three or four weeks. We have observed upbeat equity trends, improving liquidity in some important debt markets, a solid G20 meeting, retreating gold prices and even the beginnings of some asset-backed security issuances supported by the Term-Asset Backed Securities Loan Facility - most notably the recent bond issuance by Ford Motor Credit.
But while there are some emerging positives as this recession matures, the causal centre of the crisis in the United States - real estate - has still not been restored to full health. Some cogent reasoning suggests we could still have two to three years of adjustments ahead; particularly in the commercial side of the real estate sector, now that the residential sector has led the market downward and has already taken large lumps.
Two leading thinkers on the U.S. real estate bubble and its attendant effects, one a top-ranked real estate analyst and fund manager, the other a Nobel laureate economist, say we are probably a meaningful distance from an ultimate trough in valuations and a positive economic rebound. To various extents, their logic suggests that reallocations of investment monies, and moves to take on riskier investment positions, should continue to be made only cautiously from this point - at least until greater price stability appears to have returned.
Jonathan Litt: Top-ranked U.S. Real Estate Analyst and Fund Manager
In interviewing Jonathan Litt on the issue of U.S. and global real estate prices, and the conditions required for a gradual renewal of confidence, one's sense of caution tends to intensify. Mr. Litt is the founder and portfolio manager of the aptly named Land and Buildings Investment Management, which is focused on commercial real estate and real estate related equities. Prior to Land and Buildings, he was senior global real estate strategist at Citigroup, where he was responsible for property investment strategy, and where he led the No. 1 institutional investor, All American Real Estate Research Team, for eight years.
As the real estate bubble expanded in the mid-2000s, Mr. Litt sent bubble gum machines to his clients, symbolically telling them to avoid excessive valuations on commercial real estate debt. Scorned by many at the time, he and his clients have since watched the asset class tumble, and he remains highly skeptical about the current valuations in all major real estate asset classes, but particularly in commercial real estate where he thinks U.S. values will come down another 20 to 25 per cent. His portfolio is positioned accordingly.
Mr. Litt cites three main reasons for his negative outlook:
First: Historical commercial real estate values since 1970 have averaged yields of 9 per cent. In times of economic contraction and tight financial markets, those yields have been in the 10- to 12-per-cent range. Yet we are in the 9-per-cent range at the current time (on trailing Q4 results), and we are in a recession - a period where vacancies are rising, leases are not being renewed and spending is down. In Mr. Litt's opinion, this suggests yields on real estate values should be more like 10 to 12 per cent; implying potential drops in REIT (commercial real estate investment trust) prices of 20 per cent. He estimates this could take "two to four years, or even longer for the direct commercial real estate market to reprice, which will adjust more slowly than the publicly traded market."
Second: As pointed out in the chart, there is an enormous approaching wall of debt maturation in commercial real estate - some $600-billion in just the next two years. And because most lenders know that many of their real estate debtors are in trouble and could default if their debt lines were shut down, many are choosing instead to extend the term of the loans, deferring the ultimate repayment of principal into the future. The resulting accumulation of maturities, in already over-levered property companies, could mean that, instead of the typical 15 to 20 per cent of outstanding commercial debt being retired each year (of the approximate $3-trillion outstanding), we could find ourselves in a position where as much as 60 per cent of that debt load was coming due in the same 12- to 18-month time frame. That, too, would stress the system and potentially foster greater default rates and lower prices.
Third: Mr. Litt's perspective on the length of time that could be required to get the private real estate market back to equilibrium conditions has also been shaped by the previous downturn. Publicly traded property assets readjust relatively quickly and then have the advantage of lower leverage and access to equity capital to exploit new valuations, while private properties take years to find a new price level. He thinks a similar pattern could be repeated this time around.
"Our fundamental view is that the unprecedented real estate valuations of the 2005-2007 time period will take several years to unwind. Cheap and plentiful debt, along with rose-coloured glasses, drove the boom. It could take four to five years for the private real estate markets to find a bottom in valuations and fundamentals. Publicly traded property companies will likely be part of the solution to the dearth of capital."
Emphasizing the speed at which public property companies readjust to a new equilibrium price, Mr. Litt indicates that careful buyers can find some attractive investment opportunities in that sub-sector:
"In the early 1990s, it took six years for the direct real estate market to fall 31 per cent; however, the public property companies fell 34 per cent in less than 18 months and delivered 36 per cent and 60 per cent total returns in the following 12 and 24 months, respectively. Some investors will want to participate in the distressed sale of commercial property."
As to residential U.S. real estate, for some similar reasons, Mr. Litt believes we could see some additional falloffs in selected geographic markets of as much as 20 per cent - a number much worse than consensus - especially where markets have not already been hit by huge 40-per-cent-style drops. But he admits that the local profile of a community, and its particular pricing history, is relevant to the end game on house values. Also on the positive side, mortgage rates are low, and this can ultimately help valuations.
That said, the links among real estate, banking and consumer strength are where the problem really arises. Although the U.S. government is supporting loan renegotiations and foreclosure-prevention in general, this fund manager's concern is that these policies will only stretch out the overall financing adjustment process; putting the United States at risk of cloning Japanese-style, 1990s types of zombie banks. He is not alone in this view.
Vernon L. Smith: Professor of economics and 2002 Nobel laureate
Mr. Litt's cautionary perspective on real estate trends and the connection to the fundamental health of the consumer-driven economy finds additional support in the published thinking of 2002 Nobel laureate in economics, Vernon L. Smith, as he ruminates on the chances of a potential long-lasting recession. While not finally concluding that this is where we are heading, and readily admitting that economists can get it wrong on these issues, Mr. Smith thinks there is a material chance of an elongated structural malaise:
"We economists were wrong: Even when traders in an asset market know the value of the asset, bubbles form dependably. ... Over the past 18 months as housing prices have fallen, millions of homes became worth less than the loans on them, huge losses have been transmitted to lending institutions, investment banks, investors in mortgage-backed securities, sellers of credit default swaps, and the insurer of last resort, the U.S. Treasury. ...
"The events of the past 10 years have an eerie similarity to the period leading up to the Great Depression. ... In 1920, residential mortgage debt was 10.2 per cent of household wealth; by 1929, it was 27.2 per cent of household wealth. The causes of the Great Depression need more study, but the claims that losses on stock-market speculation and a monetary contraction caused the decline of the banking system both seem inadequate. It appears that both the Great Depression and the current crisis had their origins in excessive consumer debt - especially mortgage debt - that was transmitted into the financial sector during a sharp downturn. ... It appears that we're witnessing the second great consumer debt crash, the end of a massive consumption binge."
We've had a real estate bubble, a technology bubble, then another real estate bubble to deal with, in just the past 20 years. Some patience and balance now seems in order, lest Mr. Litt be forced to send out more "gifts" to his clients.

Bidders preparing offers for Montreal Canadiens

Author: Gordon, Sean; MacGregor, Roy

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bidders-preparing-offers-montreal-canadiens/docview/382653157/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Ronald Monet, a spokesman for BMO, said "we cannot comment on any rumours relating to the Canadiens, but can only reiterate that BMO Capital Markets has the mandate to evaluate the Canadian assets of the [George Gillett] family so as to maximize their value."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bidders+preparing+offers+for+Montreal+Canadiens&amp;author=Gordon%2C+Sean%3BMacGregor%2C+Roy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-08&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bidders+preparing+offers+for+Montreal+Canadiens&amp;author=Gordon%2C+Sean%3BMacGregor%2C+Roy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-04-08&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Potential bidders have been poring over the Montreal Canadiens' books for several weeks as part of due diligence procedures that could eventually lead to a deal to sell all or part of the storied team, sources say.
A source with knowledge of the behind-the-scenes machinations involving the Canadiens told The Globe and Mail that the process has been continuing since early March. There have been continued and strident denials from the current ownership that a decision has been made to sell the franchise, but it has emerged that would-be buyers are being asked to submit formal offers this week.
According to Radio-Canada, which cited unnamed sources in Quebec's corporate milieu, several groups have already signed confidentiality agreements with the Bank of Montreal's investment banking arm, with a view to examining the Canadiens' finances in detail.
The network reported that 10 groups, including billionaire businessmen Stephen Bronfman of Claridge Investments Inc.; Joey Saputo, son of cheese magnate Lino Saputo; and Guy Laliberté, founder of Cirque du Soleil, have signed the pacts.
Formal bids are to be tabled by 5 p.m. tomorrow and as many as 50 potential purchasers have been identified by the bank advisers, the network reported.
Majority owner George Gillett, who owns 80.1 per cent of the team, recently retained BMO to evaluate his Canadian holdings - which include the team, the Bell Centre arena, and a concert production firm - with a view to "profit maximization" strategies that could eventually involve a sale of one or more assets.
The news that Mr. Gillett had brought in the investment bankers was first reported by the Montreal newspaper La Presse on March 23; he subsequently told the Associated Press the move was about "estate planning, it has nothing to do with any decisions to sell any assets" and that persistent media reports amounted to an invasion of privacy.
Mr. Gillett couldn't be reached for comment late last night, but Canadiens vice-president Donald Beauchamp said the story is substantively similar to the La Presse revelations.
"The partnership with BMO is a confidential partnership, and we won't comment on it," said Mr. Beauchamp, who declined to confirm or deny the veracity of the latest reports.
Ronald Monet, a spokesman for BMO, said "we cannot comment on any rumours relating to the Canadiens, but can only reiterate that BMO Capital Markets has the mandate to evaluate the Canadian assets of the Gillett family so as to maximize their value."
Since the banking and financial crisis worsened last year, Mr. Gillett, an old hand at heavily leveraged business acquisitions (he also filed for bankruptcy in the early 1990s before rebuilding his business), has been beset by talk he is in financial distress.
But sources close to the Denver-based ski resort tycoon, who made his fortune in meatpacking and television stations, insist those reports are exaggerated.
Nevertheless, the Canadiens - which Fortune magazine estimates are worth $335-million (all figures U.S.), third-highest in the NHL - are an eminently sellable asset.
Though no local buyers stepped up when the team last went on the market nine years ago, there appears to be plenty of interest this time around, which is sure to delight the team's Quebecois fan base.
And given Mr. Gillett, who was initially viewed with suspicion by the Habs nation, paid a relatively modest $180-million for the team and the arena, he stands to make a substantial profit.
It could come in handy.
Mr. Gillett and Texas businessman Tom Hicks jointly own British soccer giants Liverpool FC, and are trying to refinance nearly $470-million in debt they used to purchase the team before a July deadline.
Mr. Hicks has also indicated he is looking at selling minority stakes in his sporting properties, which include the NHL's Dallas Stars and Major League Baseball's Texas Rangers.
Though former Habs great Serge Savard, now involved in a privately held commercial real estate company, said earlier this week he would be interested in buying the team if it were for sale, Radio-Canada said his name doesn't figure on the list.
