A training ground for killing machines

Author: Ryan, Andrew

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/training-ground-killing-machines/docview/387303384/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: with friends. "He'll still play that game occasionally, but he lost interest," says [Gillian Findlay], a hint of relief in her voice. "For him, it was a passing thing."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+training+ground+for+killing+machines&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-06&amp;spage=R.21&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+training+ground+for+killing+machines&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-06&amp;spage=R.21&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In the ever-expanding universe of video games, the big bucks are in blood and guts.
Some kids get hooked on Guitar Hero , but the vast majority of gamers today spend more money - and time - on shockingly graphic search-and-destroy video games. Turning every violent teen male fantasy into reality, these games have a simple primal theme: kill, and kill again. And then keep killing.
Rated M for Mature, violent franchise entries such as Gears of War , Grand Theft Auto and Call of Duty are the top sellers in the billion-dollar video-game industry, which last year made more money than the movie and music industries combined. Video games have become the new killing fields for today's young male gamer.
But at what cost? The issue of impressionable minds falling too deeply into the world of video-game violence is treated very seriously in the report titled Top Gun , airing on tonight's the fifth estate (CBC, tonight at 9 p.m.).
Written and hosted by Gillian Findlay, the hour-long program updates a high-profile story from last fall. News media swarmed upon Barrie, Ont., where hundreds of people were searching fields for a missing teen named Brandon Crisp. The story ran nationally, and on CNN, because 15-year-old Brandon had run away from home when his parents took away his Xbox gaming system; he had become obsessed with the video game Call of Duty , and was playing all hours of the day and night. Brandon was so enraged, said his parents, that he took his backpack and left on his bike, which he hadn't ridden in years.
A $50,000 reward was offered. People searched three weeks before Brandon's body was found at the base of a tree, barely five kilometres from his home; he died of injuries consistent with a fall.
The tragic discovery ended the story for most people. Findlay's report expands upon the sadly short life of Brandon Crisp, which required investigation of the violent video-game business itself. Filming the story held personal resonance for Findlay, the mother of a 16-year-old male with his own gaming system.
"As a parent, I was shocked by how little I knew about this world," says the CBC news veteran. "The violence of these games is so real and beauty of the graphics is almost overwhelming. You can see how seductive these games can be to teenage players."
In an exclusive interview with Brandon's parents, taped between the time of his disappearance and the discovery of his body, the extent of their son's video-game obsession is revealed.
A nice kid, a good student and a decent hockey player, Brandon's slight size caused him to drift away from athletics at age 12 and gradually ease into the world of video games. Brandon would never play in the National Hockey League, but in the role-player universe of Call of Duty , he was a killing machine. The sense of power can be euphoric. "Some kids are simply more susceptible than others," says Findlay. "The game became a place for him to succeed."
Brandon was particularly talented at Call of Duty , reveals one of his young friends, and in the weeks before his death he was climbing the circuit of the online version of the game. The confiscation of his game system kept him from training for an upcoming tournament, so he left home.
Brandon Crisp was not an isolated instance. In an interview, a rural family therapist reveals he is treating more cases of video-game addiction these days, and that parents are at wits end in dealing with it. Findlay talks to a child psychologist about the long-term impact of exposing young minds to the sustained video-game violence. "We haven't taken it as seriously as we should," he warns.
Digging deeper into the video-game culture, Findlay interviews a spokesperson from one of the big game manufacturers - she refuses comment on the Brandon Crisp case - and the CEO of Major League Gaming, operators of the site gamebattle.com, wherein gamers from all over the world engage in organized competition.
"In many ways, MLG operates under the radar," Findlay says. "There is nothing online to weed out the younger kids."
MLG also operates big-ticket tournaments, with substantial cash prizes going to those players with the best killing skills. Findlay sits down with the members of a Canadian team of professional gamers, who receive sponsorship from a cola company. Video games are a full-time career for the four twentysomethings, who have gamer names like G-Spot and X-Factor; one admits to playing 16 hours a day, possibly accounting for the group's collective fixed gaze.
"When we talked to them, we had large monitors playing video-game footage as background, and you could see it: They couldn't take their eyes off the screens," says Findlay.
While typically objective, the fifth estate episode will likely rattle some viewers, particularly those parents who suspect their own children might be addicted to violent role-player games (hours of muffled gunfire and explosions from your child's bedroom are a dead giveaway). Along with the usual adolescent vices, video-game violence has almost become a rite of passage for kids today.
Like many other male teens, Findlay's son went through his own phase of playing Call of Duty with friends. "He'll still play that game occasionally, but he lost interest," says Findlay, a hint of relief in her voice. "For him, it was a passing thing."
Check local listings.
Ryan's picks
FRIDAY
Siegfried and Roy:
The Magic Returns
They're back. Airing on the ABC newsmagazine 20/20 , this report updates viewers on the lives of the flamboyant duo. The German-born illusionists were a Las Vegas institution of two decades standing when their act was cut short by a horrific incident in late 2003: Midway through a live performance, Roy Horn was bitten savagely on the neck by a white tiger named Montecore. Horn took years to recover and doctors predicted he would never walk again, let alone perform onstage. ABC reporter Elizabeth Vargas visits the compound where Siegfried and Roy have spent most of their time since the attack. . Tonight's special will include clips from their farewell show last weekend at the Bellagio Hotel. The tiger used in the performance is none other than Montecore himself.
ABC, E!, 9 p.m.
MONDAY
Dancing with the Stars
It's back. The eighth campaign of the TV dance competition returns with the same simple format that has made it the second most-watched program on network television (behind American Idol , of course). The star-hoofers hail from all over the entertainment map. From the sports world, former NFL linebacker Lawrence Taylor will strut his stuff, as will Olympic gymnastic Shawn Johnson. From the music business, there's former Go-Go's singer Belinda Carlisle, rapper Lil' Kim and singer Jewel. The acting world is represented by Denise Richards, David Alan Grier and Gilles Marini, famous for a shower scene in the Sex and the City movie.
ABC, A, 8 p.m.

A lender's latest fear: Chinese bankruptcies

Author: Santini, Laura; Cheng, Jonathan

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lenders-latest-fear-chinese-bankruptcies/docview/387364431/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: For lenders doing business in China and contemplating insolvency proceedings, "you don't go there unless you have to," said David Kidd, head of restructuring at the Hong Kong office of U.S. law firm Allen & Overy.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+lender%27s+latest+fear%3A+Chinese+bankruptcies&amp;author=Santini%2C+Laura%3BCheng%2C+Jonathan&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-05&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+lender%27s+latest+fear%3A+Chinese+bankruptcies&amp;author=Santini%2C+Laura%3BCheng%2C+Jonathan&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-05&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Foreign investors who rushed into China in recent years now fear the nation's insolvency laws could leave them with nothing
Foreign lenders who rushed into China in recent years are watching nervously as a number of companies there teeter on the brink of insolvency. Their worry: The nation's bankruptcy laws may leave them with virtually nothing.
Several big Western investors - Citigroup Inc. , hedge-fund manager Citadel Investment Group LLC , Credit Suisse Group and CLSA Capital Partners - are seeking to get back between $100-million and $200-million (U.S.) in loans extended to a Chinese steel maker, according to people familiar with the matter. While they might recoup some of the money under a restructuring, a liquidation could wipe out the loans, one of these people said.
The company, FerroChina Ltd. , a maker of galvanized steel, didn't return phone calls or e-mails seeking comment.
Investors are also nervously watching China's real-estate markets, where ratings firm Standard & Poor's said this week a number of troubled companies pose default risk.
Meanwhile, holders of $1.2-billion in debt issued by Asia Aluminum Holdings Ltd. are considering a buyback offer that would shave nearly three quarters of the value off their debt, if not more. The Chinese company said yesterday that bondholders would get less than 4¢ on the dollar if the offer fails and the company was immediately liquidated.
For lenders doing business in China and contemplating insolvency proceedings, "you don't go there unless you have to," said David Kidd, head of restructuring at the Hong Kong office of U.S. law firm Allen & Overy.
The problem: China offers virtually no road map for overseas investors facing a liquidation or restructuring. A new bankruptcy law went into effect in June 2007 that laid out procedures for companies forced into liquidation. But the courts have yet to indicate how they view claims from foreign investors.
"The key thing is the new law hasn't been tested to any extent," said Tony Stringer, head of corporate debt in Asia-Pacific at Fitch Ratings.
Fitch warned yesterday that investors need to pay attention to how bond offerings from China are structured. It cited weak corporate governance at some closely held companies, as well the presence of domestic lenders willing to step in with their own help, knocking foreign debt holders further down the ladder.
China is seen long-term as a booming market for debt investors. According to Thomson Reuters, Chinese companies have issued $2.8-billion in U.S. dollar-denominated corporate bonds since 2005, though issuance dropped last year as the credit crisis worsened and many companies began issuing bonds in the local currency.
Lending in China has taken other forms. In the now-ailing property sector, for example, hedge funds lent capital to private developers in the hopes that these fledgling companies would later sell shares to the public, allowing them to cash out once debt was converted to equity.
But others during the boom times were skeptical. Murky recovery procedures contributed to the small number of leveraged buyout deals done in China over the years. In a management-led buyout three years ago, Asia Aluminum turned to public investors rather than the syndicated-loan groups that typically sponsor leveraged buyouts.
In China, borrowers often pledge shares as collateral in an offshore entity. In return, foreign lenders agree to provide loans that are subordinated to senior credit extended by mainland lenders. But a bankruptcy could leave those collateral shares worthless.
China has managed to avoid major hits from bad loans from real estate and other investments that have hurt Western lenders, and its economy is still growing. Still, a number of companies in weakened industries or dependent on the slowing export market have been hit hard by the global downturn.
Standard & Poor's, in a report this week on potential defaults in China's real-estate industry, said Neo-China Land Group (Holdings) Ltd. presents a 50-50 chance of default in the next six months. The company couldn't be reached yesterday for comment.
In January, the company missed an interest payment on $400-million in corporate bonds, though it later repaid bondholders during the 30-day grace period. Although it has about $2-billion Hong Kong ($258-million) in cash on hand, the company has two payment obligations that exceed that amount coming up this year, according to S & P.
Juliet Ye contributed to this article
Credit: Wall Street Journal

Hitting the streets

Author: Pachner, Joanna

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/hitting-streets/docview/387321001/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: According to Doug LePatourel, a Colliers representative in Vancouver, the [Kiehl]'s store, at 1025 Robson, is one of the 10 best units on this strip. One reason is that it's next to a courtyard, creating a pseudo corner location even though the store is mid-block. "Corners offer higher exposure because you get more frontage and the potential to wrap signage around," he says.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hitting+the+streets&amp;author=Pachner%2C+Joanna&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-05&amp;spage=10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hitting+the+streets&amp;author=Pachner%2C+Joanna&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-05&amp;spage=10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In 2004, Kiehl's, an upscale cosmetics company, decided to add a Vancouver location to the downtown Toronto store it had opened a year earlier. Because Kiehl's eschews advertising in favour of product sampling and word of mouth, it wanted a high-visibility storefront in a neighbourhood where regular passersby might make repeat visits.
The company asked the location advisory services arm of Colliers International to evaluate prospective sites based on area demographics, traffic patterns and nearby retailers. While Statistics Canada census reports provide much of this information, commercial real estate firms can help retailers isolate the most relevant criteria in graphs and maps that compare various neighbourhoods or locations. Major chains do such granular analysis as a matter of course but, according to Mary Mowbray, manager of the retail group at Colliers, small retailers rarely seek it out. "It would be very useful for many independents," she says. "But a lot of businesses think all they need to do is find an available site."
In the Kiehl's case, the preliminary research focused the search on a busy stretch of downtown Robson Street. "You almost think of it as an outdoor mall," says Kristin Armstrong, general manager of Kiehl's Canada. With pedestrian traffic comprising professionals living in the area, downtown workers, and tourists coming off buses and cruise ships, the location seemed well-suited to Kiehl's needs. But before signing a lease, the retailer wanted to dig deeper. Here's what it found out.
*****
THE NEIGHBOURS
Retailers look for both competitive and complementary stores. In Kiehl's case, the latter were a more important factor. "They wanted retailers around in which they could imagine their customers shopping," says Mowbray. Freedman Shoes, a popular independent chain, and Lululemon were two stores likely to attract consumers interested in Kiehl's products. As for nearby rivals like Aveda and Lush, Mowbray says Kiehl's wasn't concerned as long as its location was more prominent.
THE ADDRESS
According to Doug LePatourel, a Colliers representative in Vancouver, the Kiehl's store, at 1025 Robson, is one of the 10 best units on this strip. One reason is that it's next to a courtyard, creating a pseudo corner location even though the store is mid-block. "Corners offer higher exposure because you get more frontage and the potential to wrap signage around," he says. Kiehl's liked this roughly 1,000-square-foot unit so much that it waited more than a year for the previous tenant's lease to expire. That tenant, Lush, didn't want to move. But, says LePatourel, "we made it worth their while."
THE VIBE
The 1000 and 1100 blocks of Robson Street are the sine qua non of Vancouver retail, in part because, as with all good retail areas, they balance large and small stores, and the posh and quirky. "There's a progression in retail development," says Mowbray. Certain businesses (restaurants, high-end clothing stores) tend to locate together partly because of zoning, drawing more established players in the category. "But if those streets lose the interest of small retailers, they lose the energy," she says.
THE SALES
Knowing the sales per square foot at nearby stores helps a retailer estimate its own potential business volume. While malls track this data and make it available to prospective tenants, sales information on street locations is difficult to obtain, says Colliers' LePatourel. But major realtors collect it from their clients, affording them rough estimates of neighbourhood business by category; for example, the designer-boutique stretch of Bloor Street West in Toronto averages $700 to $900 in sales per square foot. Colliers' dozen or so Robson clients provided enough info to serve as a sales gauge for Kiehl's.
THE TRAFFIC
Block-by-block traffic figures provide a snapshot of how busy the street is at different times of day. While both the Thurlow and Burrard intersections have relatively high pedestrian and vehicle numbers, their peak times differ: Burrard and Robson is busiest in late morning and at lunchtime, while Thurlow packs them in during morning and afternoon rush hours. But retailers can go further, to find out, for example, how many cars drive in the curb lanes (from which they can park more easily), the number of bicyclists, and the volume of pedestrians on each side of the street. This last detail can be vital for retailers whose sales correlate to times of day: A coffee shop wants lots of passersby in the morning, while a takeout joint will care more about the evening trade.
HOW KIEHL'S FOUND ITS 'HOOD
In 2007, Colliers surveyed the options for a second Kiehl's store in Vancouver. This time, it focused on three mall locations within 10 minutes of at least 100 existing buyers, as Kiehl's wanted to tap repeat business by getting closer to its customers (represented by red dots). This density map was among the tools Colliers produced.
Demographics
This map was accompanied by a detailed demo analysis within a radius of one, three and five kilometres of Kiehl's existing store. The size, age and income of the local population all matter, but most retailers don't stop there. Children's clothing stores, for example, want to be near young families while home-improvement outlets cozy up to homeowners.
Customer density
Using the retailer's data, a location adviser can not only map where customers live, but can graph public transit and major arteries to show accessibility. In this map, for example, Kiehl's can see that transportation options make Oakridge Centre a better bet for tapping existing customers than Richmond Centre.

Complementary

9 Daniel Chocolates

Teflon T.O. skirts worst - for now

Author: Barber, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/teflon-t-o-skirts-worst-now/docview/382661152/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We're certainly suffering," he added, "but it's like there's this bubble over the city." Housing prices have dropped, but not nearly as much as they have in Vancouver or even Calgary.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Teflon+T.O.+skirts+worst+-+for+now&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-03&amp;spage=A.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Teflon+T.O.+skirts+worst+-+for+now&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-03&amp;spage=A.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The Canadian economy shrank by 3.4 per cent in the last three months of 2008, as you probably know by now. But did you know that last December produced record revenues for the Toronto Parking Authority? Or that ridership on the Toronto Transit Commission continues to climb, and is now at least 3 per cent higher than it was in January, 2008?
And what are we to make of the fact that cranes still stubbornly swing above so many building sites downtown? The national economy was collapsing like a media stock in January when the developers of the 66-storey Shangri-La condominium bought an ad (thanks, guys) to proclaim their acquisition of a $408-million loan to build the thing, which they are now doing.
Even if he wanted to help Toronto, which is doubtful, Finance Minister Jim Flaherty could never hope to create such a potent and focused stimulus as that. But the Shangri-La is only one of several large developments actively under construction in downtown Toronto. Just as surprisingly, applications to build more continue to flood into city hall.
Some projects have been quietly shelved or delayed, but only one of them - a specialized office building that is part of the MaRS research centre - has stopped in mid-construction. So far, there is no 21st-century equivalent of the notorious Adelaide Street "stump" that stood for more than a decade as testament to the speculative excess of the 1980s. Instead, a renewed Bay-Adelaide Centre is now preparing to welcome its first tenants.
The last big real-estate bust arrived in one fell swoop. Long-established industry giants disappeared in a matter of months. This one is slinking into town on tippy-toes.
"I believe that Toronto is in the best shape of any city in North America," said developer Stephen Diamond, who has been involved in both the Shangri-La and the 55-storey Four Seasons project in Yorkville, which also began construction in the face of the worst national economy in 40 years. "Buyers are closing, projects are going ahead and there are still people buying units."
"We're certainly suffering," he added, "but it's like there's this bubble over the city." Housing prices have dropped, but not nearly as much as they have in Vancouver or even Calgary.
Few observers, including Mr. Diamond, expect the bubble to last. But for the time being, at least, it certainly sets the city apart.
Many point to the site of One Bloor East - the super-tall apartment building that incited a buying frenzy when it was proposed at the height of the boom - as a crucial test. The project stalled when its major lender, Lehman Brothers of New York, went bust last fall. But developer Bazis International is still active at city hall, having agreed last week to pay more than $1-million to acquire a laneway adjacent to its site.
The company's consistent refusal to respond to media inquiries about the project's status invites suspicion. But as of now, the project's a go. So are two similar projects on Bloor Street West, currently under construction. Last week, Bazis submitted an application to build another one on property it owns across from the Royal Ontario Museum.
Nobody expects Toronto's resiliency to survive the macroeconomic shocks that are sure to arrive as a result of the global financial crisis. In the meantime, though, private investors continue to pump billions of dollars into the local economy.
jbarber@globeandmail.com

Vancouver building permits fall with economy

Author: Bula, Frances

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/vancouver-building-permits-fall-with-economy/docview/387313982/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "There seems to be a bit of a bottom in prices," said Mr. Poettcker, who has been through six housing market crashes during his career. For the industry to really get moving again, though, he said, "it will take a better match-up of buyers and sellers."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vancouver+building+permits+fall+with+economy&amp;author=Bula%2C+Frances&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-02&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vancouver+building+permits+fall+with+economy&amp;author=Bula%2C+Frances&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-03-02&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: But industry may be turning a corner, experts say
Vancouver building permits - the sign of health in the local construction industry and an important part of the city budget - plunged in January to half the previous year's number.
Only 34 new residential units were built in the city that month, according to the finalized summary from the city's director of licences, Will Johnston, which was distributed to councillors late last week.
That grim news means that Vancouver is now projecting to get only half of its normal $25-million in fees related to development this year - a scenario that's being echoed to some degree in other Lower Mainland municipalities.
But Vancouver's finance committee chair and many people in the development industry say the region may be turning a corner.
"The February numbers will inform us more and so will March, but we may have seen the worst of it," said Councillor Raymond Louie, who is monitoring the numbers for signs that the city should tighten its budget belt even more.
There is a sign of hope: Development consultant Bob Ransford said the company he works for will be putting in an application to develop 900-1,300 units in Vancouver's Collingwood Village on the far eastern side of the city. That site, now single family homes that have been assembled by the Waterfront Group, would become part of the dense new neighbourhood that has been developed there over the past decade.
"We know it will take some time to get it approved, but they're optimistic that that the market will return," said Mr. Ransford. Although the company isn't making any construction commitments, even putting in an application requires paying significant fees to the city.
Mr. Ransford and others familiar with the development industry say they are hearing through the grapevine that there are signs of life in the housing market. More people are starting to appear at presentation centres and "people are writing deals," said Mr. Ransford.
The development company Amacon recently moved forward another step with its commitment to building a condo project at Homer and Smithe called the Beasley, which required a very large cheque for the city.
Al Poettcker, the head of the province's development industry association, said there are signs that sellers and buyers are beginning to come to terms with a new, lowered price for condos, at around $500 a square foot. In Vancouver, downtown condos had been selling, prior to the crash last year, for anywhere from $800 to $1,200 a square foot.
"There seems to be a bit of a bottom in prices," said Mr. Poettcker, who has been through six housing market crashes during his career. For the industry to really get moving again, though, he said, "it will take a better match-up of buyers and sellers."
For the past several months, developers haven't had a clear idea of what people are willing to pay, since most developers were reluctant to lower prices and, as a result, consumers simply sat on their hands.
But once the two sides establish a meeting point on prices, that will encourage developers to start looking at deals again, Mr. Poettcker said.
However, they may have to finance them differently. Many buyers are reluctant now, even at good prices, to make a commitment to a unit that might not be built for two or three years.
"The old model was pre-sales. But in a falling market, it's hard to get people to commit.
"We have to find another way to land developments than that," Mr. Poettcker said.
Developers may have to put in more of their own equity, something they had moved away from doing, or find interim financing while they are building.
"We have developers who are very well financed and who are ready to move ahead," he said.
Like many in the development industry, he believes B.C.'s real-estate market is fundamentally healthy. There isn't a lot of extra inventory and the economy is relatively healthy.
"The vast majority of us still have jobs," Mr. Poettcker said.
"There are a lot of people who are on the sidelines right now. They have down payments and they're waiting. As soon as they sense the prices are right they're going to step up."

Stopping the press

Author: Waldie, Paul; Robertson, Grant

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/stopping-press/docview/382662543/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We knew that closure was the most likely option and that it was a very real possibility," Mr. [John Temple] said. "It's a very complicated business situation and it's just not an attractive situation for a buyer to get involved with."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Stopping+the+press&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul%3BRobertson%2C+Grant&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-28&amp;spage=A.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Stopping+the+press&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul%3BRobertson%2C+Grant&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-28&amp;spage=A.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Weak economy, changing consumer habits and online competition brew perfect storm for media companies
When John Temple was delivering copies of The Province to homes in his Vancouver neighbourhood during the 1960s, he thought the newspaper business would go on forever.
Now Mr. Temple, the editor and publisher of Denver's Rocky Mountain News, isn't so sure.
The "Rocky" published its last edition yesterday, marking the end of a 150-year-old institution that got its start covering the Civil War and won four Pulitzer Prizes in the past decade. The owner, E.W. Scripps Co., put the paper up for sale a couple of months ago, and when no buyer emerged, the company closed it down.
Yesterday, as he headed to the newsroom to watch 215 staffers clear out their desks, Mr. Temple said many were in tears, some were angry and others simply numb. "I think it will take a while to absorb the loss and what it means," he said.
Mr. Temple has been a reporter or editor for more than 20 years, in Denver, Toronto and New Mexico, and he has never seen the newspaper industry in such bad shape.
"We're in a period of sort of wrenching destruction," he said. "We're going to see the collapse of many newspapers."
A weak economy, changing consumer habits and competition from the Internet have brought several media companies to their knees. This week alone the owners of three large U.S. newspapers, including the Philadelphia Inquirer, filed for bankruptcy protection; CTV announced plans to close two television stations in Ontario; Canwest Global Communications Corp., owners of the Global TV network, faced a deadline by its lenders and won a two-week reprieve; and Torstar Corp. announced a $211-million quarterly loss and shook up its management ranks.
All that as the owners of several other large U.S. newspapers, including the Chicago Tribune and Los Angeles Times, are already in bankruptcy protection, Canwest has said it may close stations in five cities, and media outlets everywhere - including The Globe and Mail, which is owned by CTVglobemedia - have laid off staff.
The situation is so dire, CTV recently offered its station in Brandon to public broadcaster CBC for $1. The CBC declined.
"I think that we have reached a crisis mode," said Don Mumford, a regional CTV manager who runs the station in London as well as the two that are set to close in Windsor and Wingham, Ont. All three are part of CTV's "A" channel network that also includes stations in Victoria, Ottawa and Barrie, Ont.
"I never thought that I would be in a position where I was closing TV stations," said Mr. Mumford, a 30-year veteran of the TV business.
He said that during the 1960s and 1970s, owning a local TV station was a licence to print money. There were few competitors, fewer distractions and profits poured in.
"In London there was only one TV station, CFPL, and the only other stations that would penetrate into the market would be CKCO in Kitchener, and that's it," he said.
Things began to change in the early 1980s with the advent of cable TV, which brought new channels. As cable grew and other stations began to penetrate the market, the London station began to struggle financially, as did the others. "I can tell you that since about 1990, for sure since 1997, these three stations have not made a profit," he said.
The stations survived because the owner, Baton Broadcasting and later CTV, was still making money from its stations in Toronto, Vancouver and Montreal, and could afford to subsidize the smaller ones. All that has changed. "What you're seeing in the last five years is revenue and audiences now being eroded for all TV stations, including Toronto and Vancouver and Montreal," he said.
In fact, CTV told the federal broadcast regulator yesterday that it expects to lose $100-million from its conventional TV stations in 2009. And in a memo to employees yesterday, CTV Chief Executive Officer Ivan Fecan said all the "A" channels are facing a "grave" situation.
"When we bought the A's, they had never made money. We hoped to turn this around and this year achieved a major increase in their ratings. Despite this, the A's will continue to lose money," Mr. Fecan said. "It is because the business model for conventional television is now broken."
Long-time Wingham TV anchor Bryan Allen fears the departure of the local station may barely cause a ripple in town.
"The closing of the signal here, the shutting down of the transmitter, is really procedural because for all intents and purposes, [the station] hasn't existed since the early 90s really."
Mr. Allen now hosts a local AM radio show in town. When he threw the lines open to callers to discuss the shutdown this week, there were no takers. "Old timers realize this is really the end now," he said. "But it will hardly be noticed."
He remembers a time when the town, with a large broadcasting operation serving a population of about 3,000, boasted it was a radio and television capital of Canada. "There used to be a sign at the edge of town stating that," he said. "Those signs have been taken down a number of years ago."
Mr. Fecan and others in the industry say the only solution is to give networks the ability to add fees to customer cable bills just like specialty channels do, such as TSN or Bravo.
However, the industry's proposal to charge 50 cents a month has been turned down twice by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission, which has said the networks haven't made a strong enough case.
Mr. Temple paints a similar picture of decline in Denver, where the Rocky and its crosstown rival, the Denver Post, once sold more than 1.1 million copies combined on a Sunday. By 2001, the papers had to join forces to cope with flagging financials and formed a joint company to run their business operations while keeping the newsrooms separate. But that didn't stop the bleeding.
Weekday circulation for both papers sunk to 210,000 from 300,000 and the Sunday circulation fell to 600,000. As the economy sank last year, advertisers cut back or shifted their spending, resulting in a $100-million drop in help wanted and real estate ads. Last year the Rocky lost $16-million and in December, Scripps put it up for sale.
"We knew that closure was the most likely option and that it was a very real possibility," Mr. Temple said. "It's a very complicated business situation and it's just not an attractive situation for a buyer to get involved with."
The Rocky may not be the only paper to shut down. Hearst Corp. has said it will close the San Francisco Chronicle unless major budget cuts are imposed or a buyer is found. The company is also prepared to close the Seattle Post-Intelligencer if it can't be sold.
Mr. Temple said newspapers must radically transform how they do business if they hope to survive. They may have to sell stories online much like iTunes, where readers pay a small monthly fee and receive only stories on topics that interest them. And they have to break down old barriers between editorial and advertising departments and get both to work together. "We're still stuck in 'well that's not how we do things.' Sorry, that ain't going to cut it any more if you want to survive," he said.
Local ownership might also be a solution, according to some workers at CHCH in Hamilton, one of the stations Canwest has put up for sale.
A group of employees, including news anchor Donna Skelly, are trying to cobble together a plan to buy the station. The proposal, which is still being formulated and will be taken to the CRTC and to Canwest in the coming weeks, would see the station operated as a local news and variety station, stripping out all of the U.S. programming that makes up prime time.
Ms. Skelly said the city needs to keep the station to retain a local identity. She fears the demise of the station will see stories go unreported, like the 2006 case of a Hamilton man who had been waiting a year to have a piece of his skull reattached. After David Malleau's story was told on TV, he was able to get into the hospital for surgery.
The proposal is based on operating the station much like the CFL's Saskatchewan Roughriders, which are community-owned. The CHCH group is meeting with the team's executives in the coming weeks to discuss how that model could be adapted.
"Why not come up with a radical model, and not have to generate a massive profit, simply cover our costs," Ms. Skelly said. "It is radical, but it's better than what is there now."
She believes a local TV station could be operated on a smaller budget, if the operations don't have to devote heavy resources to buying rights to the top-rated shows out of Hollywood. The proposal has been met with a groundswell of support from the community, Ms. Skelly said.
"We would still produce great news and quality news, but do it within a realistic budget ... It could be the new model for local television," Ms. Skelly said. "Stakeholders in the community would sit on the board and we would report back to them."
Like Ms. Skelly, Mr. Temple believes communities need strong news organizations. "There's got to be a place for stories and local storytelling. People have a hunger for it and I believe we'll figure it out."
When asked what he plans to do now that the Rocky is closed, Mr. Temple replied: "I have no idea. I want to stay in journalism, but I just don't know what kinds of possibilities are open to a person like me."
CHAPTER 11 CLUB
Four newspaper companies have filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since December, though their newspapers continue to operate. Here are some details:
TRIBUNE CO.Filed: Dec. 8
Dailies owned: Los Angeles Times, Chicago Tribune, The Baltimore Sun, South Florida Sun-Sentinel, Orlando Sentinel (Fla.), The Hartford Courant (Conn.), The Morning Call of Allentown, Pa., Daily Press of Newport News, Va., and Spanish-language Hoy L.A. and Hoy Chicago Debt: $13-billion (U.S.), most from complex buyout in which real estate mogul Sam Zell took the company private in 2007. Had $7.6-billion in assets at time of filing. Generates enough cash that it likely could have made upcoming debt payments, especially with planned sale of the Chicago Cubs, but concluded reorganization necessary for long-term sustainability.
STAR TRIBUNE HOLDINGS CORP.
Filed: Jan. 15
Newspaper owned: Star Tribune of Minneapolis
Debt: $661-million, largely from 2007 acquisition from McClatchy Co. by investors led by Avista Capital Partners. Had assets of $493-million as of Dec. 31. Began skipping interest payments in June to conserve cash, and filed for bankruptcy protection after failing to win concessions from unions. Newspaper has asked bankruptcy judge to cancel its contract with printers union; seeking $20-million in annual cost reductions from all unionized employees, $10-million from nonunion employees.
JOURNAL REGISTER CO.
Filed: Feb. 21
Dailies owned: New Haven Register (Conn.), The Middletown Press (Conn.), The Register Citizen of Torrington, Conn., Daily Local News of West Chester, Pa., Delaware County Daily Times (Pa.), The Mercury of Pottstown, Pa., The Times Herald of Norristown, Pa., The Trentonian of Trenton, N.J., The Reporter of Lansdale, Pa., The Phoenix of Phoenixville, Pa., The Oakland Press of Pontiac, Mich., The Macomb Daily of Mount Clemens, Mich., The Daily Tribune of Royal Oak, Mich., Morning Sun of Mount Pleasant, Mich., The Record of Troy, N.Y., The Saratogian of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., The Oneida Daily Dispatch (N.Y.), Daily Freeman of Kingston, N.Y., The News-Herald of Willoughby, Ohio, The Morning Journal of Lorain, Ohio.
Debt: $692-million. Had assets of $596-million as of Nov. 30. Forbearance agreement with lenders letting the company skip interest payments recently expired. Company already has sold two Connecticut dailies and closed several weeklies. Prior to filing, company reached agreement with most of its lenders to cancel its stock and become a private company controlled by its lenders.
PHILADELPHIA NEWSPAPERS LLC
Filed: Feb. 22
Newspapers owned: The Philadelphia Inquirer and Philadelphia Daily News.
Debt: About $390-million, largely from 2006 purchase from McClatchy by investors led by former advertising executive Brian Tierney. Initial loan terms include requirement that newspapers earn higher profit each year, an increasingly difficult feat.

Full text:   3000 LAKE SHORE BLVD. W., UNIT 2
ASKING PRICE: $384,900
SELLING PRICE: $379,900
TAXES: $2,371 (2008)
DAYS ON THE MARKET: eight
LISTING AGENTS: Irene Kaushansky and Philip Brown, Keller Williams Advantage Realty
Irene Kaushansky and Philip Brown distributed thousands of flyers and bought several ads in local papers to give this townhouse the extra exposure it needed to seal a deal within a matter of days.
In the complex at the time there were at least five or six units that had been lingering on the market for close to three months, says Ms. Kaushansky. "And we sold first."
Built in 2003, the three-storey unit is the largest model available in the building, with a roughly 1,600 square foot plan, including two bedrooms and three bathrooms, plus direct access to a double garage.

The previous owners frequently entertained guests on the ground floor where there is a powder room and carpeted dining room that could be used as an office or third bedroom.
On the second level, hardwood floors in the open principal room stop short of the ceramic in the eat-in kitchen. The kitchen is outfitted with stainless steel appliances, a breakfast bar and a walkout to the deck.
On the top level, the second bedroom has a walk-in closet, and the master suite contains a wall-to-wall closet and access to one of two full bathrooms.
The monthly condo fee is $178.

How high is too high? Four Seasons may find out

Author: Belford, Terrence

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/how-high-is-too-four-seasons-may-find-out/docview/382664934/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Mr. [Louis Tinker], however, reflects sunny good humour. "It's a challenge," he says. "Frankly, I am excited about working on this project. We will be helping decide how high is too high and how dense is too dense."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=How+high+is+too+high%3F+Four+Seasons+may+find+out&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-27&amp;spage=G.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=How+high+is+too+high%3F+Four+Seasons+may+find+out&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-27&amp;spage=G.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   How tall is too tall when it comes to new condominiums? Just how far can we push intensification by expanding upward instead of outward? If an 80-storey condo at Yonge Street and Bloor Street is dandy, then how about at Avenue Road and Bloor Street?
Those questions frame a three-sided wrestling match over the future of the existing Four Seasons Hotel at Avenue Road and Yorkville Avenue. Menkes Developments wants to tear down the 23-storey hotel and in its place build twin towers - one 44 storeys and the other 48 storeys.
Local residents, businesses and groups with an interest in architecture and historic preservation are vocal in their opposition. They raise objections ranging from the shadows the towers will throw on nearby streets, through the disruption construction and later occupation by residents will create, to how the towers will detract from the view of Queen's Park looking north along University Avenue.
In the middle, trying to find a solution, is city planner Louis Tinker.
"What we want to do is achieve the city's overall goals in areas such as intensification but not at the expense of all other factors such as quality of life and the potential impact on the neighbours," he says.
Developers facing opposition from various special interest groups is nothing new. Not in my backyard continues to be the rallying cry when it comes to many projects, especially those affecting long-established neighbourhoods. This one, however, seems to be almost in a class by itself.
The tale starts in 1969 when the Four Seasons was built. At the time, nothing in the area was supposed to rise above the seven-storey Hazelton Lanes immediately to the north. In fact, the official plan still calls for height restrictions of just 46 metres at Bloor Street and Avenue Road and 18 metres on Yorkville Avenue.
City council, however, granted an exemption to the hotel for reasons of economic development. Since then, a number of other high-rises have sprung up nearby but none higher than 23 storeys.
About four years ago, Kingdom Properties, which owned the existing hotel, put it on the auction block. Menkes had bid on it but lost out to a third party. When that buyer did not go ahead with its plans for the site, Menkes stepped in, bought the hotel and hired Peter Clewes of architectsAlliance to design a showstopper of a luxury hotel-condo project.
And that he did: Two slim towers rising from a three-level podium occupying a chunk of land that runs from Cumberland Street to Yorkville Avenue. Set just 12 metres apart, the towers would soar 178.5 metres at their tallest point and represent coverage of 16.85 times the surface of the site, about double the 8.7 times coverage the zoning currently calls for.
When the plans were unveiled, the criticism started. While there were good reasons to voice objections over things such as the shadow the towers would cast over nearby streets from just after 9 a.m. until just after 11.30 a.m. and whether towers of that height were appropriate in an area where the tallest neighbour barely reached half as high, the one that received the most attention was the impact the towers might have on the view of Queen's Park.
"It comes down to what kind of city we want to have," says Catherine Nasmith, an architect, president of the Architectural Conservancy of Ontario and editor of a fortnightly newsletter called Built Heritage News. Her concern is that those towers will stick up like a sore thumb over the east wing of Queen's Park and destroy the serenity and visual sense of balance: They would be a kind of view pollution to a historic vista.
"Look at Ottawa. Both views of Parliament Hill, from the Ontario and Quebec sides, are protected," she says. "We should do the same thing for Queen's Park. Just because we can build something does not mean we should."
The upshot is that after five deputations spoke at a Feb. 9 meeting of the Toronto and East York Community Council meeting - a subcommittee of city council, which rules on and makes recommendations about development in those former cities - Mr. Tinker tabled a report on the project. The councillors voted to let Mr. Tinker go back to Menkes and see if the project could be reshaped in ways to overcome what his report saw as deficiencies.
Mr. Tinker says Mr. Clewes has indeed worked on two alternatives for the site. Mr. Clewes says he is perfectly happy to work to overcome objections but the final word must come from his client, Menkes.
"The subcommittee passed the planning report but the attitude at the meeting was very negative to the whole project," he says. "Nobody really wanted to hear what we could do."
Mr. Tinker, however, reflects sunny good humour. "It's a challenge," he says. "Frankly, I am excited about working on this project. We will be helping decide how high is too high and how dense is too dense."
tbelford@globeandmail.com

Build Toronto is the big stick council's dogs should chase

Author: Barber, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/build-toronto-is-big-stick-councils-dogs-should/docview/382660095/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The board is staffed accordingly, beginning with vice-chair Blake Hutcheson, who cut his political teeth as chair of the influential blue-ribbon panel that first recommended the city "monetize" its scattered and disorganized real-estate portfolio. Apart from one token union rep and triple-token Brigitte Shim (architect, female, visible minority), the rest are white, middle-aged developers just like Mr. Hutcheson.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Build+Toronto+is+the+big+stick+council%27s+dogs+should+chase&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-26&amp;spage=A.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Build+Toronto+is+the+big+stick+council%27s+dogs+should+chase&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-26&amp;spage=A.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Councillors assailing Miller appointments missed the point - again
The cross-eyed coon dogs of city council reliably barked up the wrong tree this week as they followed the scent of Chicago-style patronage in the increasingly Chicago-style government of Toronto Mayor David Miller. Their big catch was noting that five out of the 12 citizens appointed to Invest Toronto, a new agency with a vague mandate to promote the city, had made contributions to the mayor's 2006 re-election campaign.
Duly noted, but so what? None of the 12 is being paid, and the board has no particular authority or spending power.
It is an open opportunity for engaged citizens who want to make a difference, which is the same group most likely to make political donations.
Twelve out of 12 on that board would barely be news. In the annals of municipal patronage, five is lily white.
The real news is that there is not one identifiable Miller supporter or contributor among the eight real-estate professionals who were appointed this week to the board of Build Toronto, another new agency, but one with a specific mandate and the powers to match.
One is a talk shop filled with politicos. The other is chop shop filled with non-aligned technicians focused on a single task: turning the city's extensive land holdings into free-flowing cash. With its own revenue, beginning with rents from an initial grant of 30 city-owned properties, Build Toronto is custom-designed to bulldoze political resistance to suburban intensification.
Public land outside the core has laid fallow for too long because local politicians prefer parking lots to apartment buildings, according to Councillor Kyle Rae, a pro-development downtowner also appointed to Build Toronto's developer-dominated board.
Each year, Mr. Rae said, he and two fellow downtown councillors, Pam McConnell and Adam Vaughan, help to add $40-million to the city tax base by expediting approvals for development in their wards. In his view, Build Toronto is the big stick that will swing the same kind of deals in the NIMBY suburbs.
Michael Walker's worst nightmare?
"Exactly!" Mr. Rae enthused.
Give Councillor Walker credit for recognizing the threat as his witless colleagues assailed the blameless appointees to Invest Toronto.
The record of Build Toronto's founding now includes an official reply to a series of written questions posed by Councillor Walker to determine the extent of the agency's powers.
Taken as a whole, they succinctly confirm his suspicion that it will be largely immune from council control.
The board is staffed accordingly, beginning with vice-chair Blake Hutcheson, who cut his political teeth as chair of the influential blue-ribbon panel that first recommended the city "monetize" its scattered and disorganized real-estate portfolio. Apart from one token union rep and triple-token Brigitte Shim (architect, female, visible minority), the rest are white, middle-aged developers just like Mr. Hutcheson.
The mayor played a lead role in picking both boards, according to Councillor Rae, who sits on both in his capacity as chair of the city's economic development committee.
With Build Toronto, he said, the aim was to draw directly on top private-sector expertise - and to pay for it. Unlike the appointees to the board of fuzzy Invest Toronto, those appointed to Build Toronto will be paid $500 a meeting, the vice-chair twice that.
One of the two new agencies is a pure patronage play, innocent in its transparency and, indeed, potentially helpful in some sunny future.
But the one that matters now is all business, as the baying hounds will soon discover.
jbarber@globeandmail.com

TED DELANEY, 77: PRIVATE BROADCAST PIONEER

Author: Langan, F F

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ted-delaney-77-private-broadcast-pioneer/docview/382666273/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Ted used to joke that he had been thrown out of more places than most salesmen had visited," said Ted Stuebing, a former vice-president of news at CFTO. "He was, in my opinion, responsible for the early success of CFTO because he worked so hard to sell the station."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=TED+DELANEY%2C+77%3A+PRIVATE+BROADCAST+PIONEER&amp;author=Langan%2C+F+F&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-25&amp;spage=S.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=TED+DELANEY%2C+77%3A+PRIVATE+BROADCAST+PIONEER&amp;author=Langan%2C+F+F&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-25&amp;spage=S.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Early sales effort helped launch CFTO, later he was key innovator
The career of Ted Delaney, CFTO's original sales manager, mirrored the rise of private Canadian broadcasting and the CTV network.
CFTO became Toronto's first private station when it went on the air on Dec. 31, 1960. But that was preceded by a battle over who would own its licence. Some of the applicants for what was seen as the richest prize in Canadian broadcasting included The Toronto Star, Canadian media mogul Jack Kent Cooke and Britain's Granada Television.
The winner was Baton Broadcasting, owned by the Bassett and Eaton families. Their partners included Ted Rogers and the licence application's front man, Joel Aldred, a Canadian radio and TV announcer. Mr. Aldred sold his holdings in the first year, worried that the station was struggling.
Mr. Delaney came to the rescue. He had valuable experience in television sales, having worked at CHCH in Hamilton, Canada's first private TV station. He was tireless in beating down doors to sell commercials, then an unusual commodity in an advertising world hooked on print and radio.
"Ted used to joke that he had been thrown out of more places than most salesmen had visited," said Ted Stuebing, a former vice-president of news at CFTO. "He was, in my opinion, responsible for the early success of CFTO because he worked so hard to sell the station."
Ted Delaney was born in Ottawa, the son of Irish immigrants, but the family moved to Barrie, Ont., when he was young. His father took care of a large estate on Lake Simcoe owned by a British family who spent summers there.
After high school, Mr. Delaney sold cars, then got a job in broadcast sales. He worked at a Barrie radio station and local TV station CKVR. He graduated to the larger market at CHCH before joining CFTO as sales manager.
In 1966, when Murray Chercover left as CFTO's vice-president of programming to become executive vice-president of CTV, Mr. Delaney added that title to his own.
That was the same year that the Board of Broadcast Governors - the forerunner of the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission - agreed that the CTV affiliates could buy the network. CTV carried 64 hours a week of programming and CFTO produced the bulk of its Canadian content.
As head of programming for CFTO, Mr. Delaney was involved in many major decisions, including buying the first colour TV cameras at a private station. That was three months before the official launch of colour television in Canada on Sept. 1, 1966.
He also spearheaded the expansion of production facilities at CFTO through the station's subsidiary, Glen Warren Productions. By 1977, it was, according to the Canadian Communications Foundation, the third-largest TV production facility in the world, with 400 full-time employees.
"In addition to producing many programs for CTV, CFTO now became an attractive option for U.S. producers wanting to create product for the 7-8 prime access time period, which could no longer be programmed by the U.S. networks," Bill Dulmage wrote in the history section of the Canadian Communications Foundation website.
"Over the next few years, the series which were crafted to qualify as Canadian content so they could play on CTV stations included The Barbara McNair Show , The Ray Stevens Show (a summer replacement for The Andy Williams Show on NBC), Rollin' On The River and half The George Kirby Comedy Hour ."
The ratings at CFTO made the station the richest broadcast property in Canada. When "people meters" were introduced in the late 1980s, Mr. Delaney was over the moon that on one of the first nights the audience was accurately measured, the station had a 37-per-cent share of Toronto viewers.
For decades, Mr. Delaney and another CFTO executive, Larry Nichols, were responsible for the day-to-day running of the station, according to a colleague who worked with them. Mr. Delaney also worked on many side projects, including organizing an annual telethon for the Hospital for Sick Children.
One of the key programming areas was local news. Among other things, it was classified as Canadian content, as well as being a money-maker. Although other people ran the news operation, Mr. Delaney was behind many of the strategic decisions, including making it the first Toronto television station to offer an evening newscast seven days a week. CFTO's local newscast is still the leader in the Toronto market.
In 1988, Mr. Delaney and CFTO were involved in a real-life drama. By this time, he was executive vice-president of the station, the highest non-family member in the organization still owned by the Eatons and Bassetts. There was a bitter 12-week lockout at CFTO, and when it was over about a third of the striking technicians took a buyout package.
Mr. Delaney retired from CFTO in the early 1990s.
EDWARD JOSEPH DELANEY
Edward Joseph Delaney was born in Ottawa on Aug. 29, 1931. He died of cancer at Unionville, Ont., on Feb. 17, 2009. He leaves his wife, Joan, his children, Sandra, Sheila, Sean and Sharon, and his sisters, Peg and Eileen.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

Forsake that prime-time woe for some great trash

Author: Ryan, Andrew

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/forsake-that-prime-time-woe-some-great-trash/docview/382663267/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The Week the Women Went (CBC, 8 p.m.) sallies forth, in a way, as one of CBC's top-rated shows. Holding weekly in the 750,000-viewer range, the reality series explained entirely in its title skews strongly to a female audience; clearly there are women out there who enjoy watching men look like big dumb oafs. The Homer Simpson scenarios continue in tonight's sixth chapter of the TV experiment filmed in the small Nova Scotian town of Tatamagouche last year. No women, gotta do the work, eh?

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Forsake+that+prime-time+woe+for+some+great+trash&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-25&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Forsake+that+prime-time+woe+for+some+great+trash&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-25&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   One mustn't dwell on the negative in these hard times. No less an authority than Dr. Phil himself warns of the health risks attached to stinkin' thinkin' and regularly tells viewers of his daytime talk show to get outside for a walk now and then.
Dr. Phil also suggests people take pleasure in the small things in life, like watching Dr. Phil, or any other TV program that might provide a fleeting hour of escapist entertainment. More sound medical advice, but there's little regard for the easily depressed in tonight's TV lineup. Most of what airs on Wednesday night is only going to make you feel worse. Like Wednesday's child, the hump-night schedule is full of woe. Midweek prime time is the zone of the network crime drama, with Life (NBC, 9 p.m.) the better than usual suspect.
Life is a decent cop show, driven by British actor Damian Lewis's portrayal of Charlie Crews, a police detective once framed and sent to prison, then made a millionaire in compensation for being wrongly convicted. Like every other network cop show, Life is also relentlessly grim.
Tonight, Crews and his new partner (Brent Sexton) are called to a grisly crime scene: the murder by impalement of a ladies man with an abiding affection for pigeons. Don't ask. The investigation leads into the world of low-rent contract killers.
Over on the still highly rated Criminal Minds (CBS, 9 p.m.), the profiler team tracks another contract killer, this one a sexy lady who poses as a call girl to knock off executives. Bodies are turning up in hotel rooms all over the city.
Further police-procedural unpleasantries unfolds on CSI:NY (CBS, CTV, 10 p.m.) - the CSI team try to reunite a human eyeball with its owner - and on Law & Order (NBC, A, 10 p.m.), which has a story about a stockbroker who dies after a bad lunch - a pretty obvious attempt to cheer up viewers.
The only thing more depressing than the cop shows on Wednesday night is the ongoing chronicle of Lost (ABC, CTV, 9 p.m.), still growing its own mythology as it draws to a close. Does anyone know or care about what's happening on Lost any more? Tonight's show is a Locke episode, so enjoy if you're still paying attention.
It's perhaps wiser these days to find a program that will take your mind completely off world events, or your own dwindling stock portfolio. Colour me sheepish, but lately I'm more drawn to the easy viewing of MuchMoreMusic.
Besides being the only Canadian showcase for wonderfully awful eighties music -Everybody Wang Chung Tonight! - the channel has several fine original series, most notably Where You At, Baby? (MuchMoreMusic, 8 p.m.).
Host Matt Wells displays proper fan respect toward once-famous pop icons. He has hung out with Vanilla Ice, fly-fished with Huey Lewis and shopped for produce with ex-Loverboy front man Mike Reno (who appears not to have missed any meals since hanging up his headband). Tonight, Wells catches up with Dee Snider, former lead singer of the eighties metal group Twisted Sister. He's still got it.
Yet more entertaining is Confessions of a Pop Idol (MuchMoreMusic, 9 p.m.). Duplicating the style of other VH-1 reality shows such as Celebrity Rehab and its spinoff Sober House , the concept brings together former teen male heartthrobs -including The Blue Lagoon star Christopher Atkins, Dance Fever host Adrian Zmed and Brian Austin Green, who played Tori Spelling's boyfriend on Beverly Hills, 90210 - and houses them together in a Los Angeles mansion.
The pretense is that the show is part of a comeback for the faded stars, most of whom have some hard miles on them. The show fairly drips pathos, but how much empathy can you have for a former Baywatch lifeguard?
Tonight, the aging man-hunks are marched through a popular paparazzi zone - of course, none of the photographers knows who they are - followed by a career pep talk from Scott Baio, better known as Chachi from Happy Days . Later, there's a test of their thespian skills in a community-theatre production for underprivileged kids. Work is work, as they say.
For some people, the guiltiest pleasure is found in the lurid tales of True Hollywood Story (E!, 10 p.m.). Still dishing dirt in its second decade, the tabloid-style E! series tonight airs a new profile of Donald Trump, the real-estate tycoon whose TV fame continues to inexplicably expand, courtesy of The Celebrity Apprentice .
Unlike most True Hollywood episodes, this is a Trump-sanctioned profile, which becomes rather evident in his opening statement: "I'm the most well-known person in the world!" - according to recent polls, he claims.
Trump's heavy hand is all over the tale, which brushes by his upbringing and digs up old feuds with Rosie O'Donnell and Martha Stewart. Borrowing everyone else's Trump punchline, he now makes his own jokes about his infamous hair-helmet.
The program touches sparingly on his various marriages and personal life, but in a rare show of candour, The Donald admits that he has, on occasion, made some very bad business mistakes that cost him millions of dollars.
Now, don't you feel a little better?
Check local listings.

The Week the Women Went (CBC, 8 p.m.) sallies forth, in a way, as one of CBC's top-rated shows. Holding weekly in the 750,000-viewer range, the reality series explained entirely in its title skews strongly to a female audience; clearly there are women out there who enjoy watching men look like big dumb oafs. The Homer Simpson scenarios continue in tonight's sixth chapter of the TV experiment filmed in the small Nova Scotian town of Tatamagouche last year. No women, gotta do the work, eh? One man panics when he runs out of clean dishes. A sluggard father has unruly kids and goats running around the house. In a Jerry Springer-type twist, one of the abandoned men misses his lady fair and mother of his children so much, he contemplates asking her to marry him, on their eight-year anniversary. Ain't love grand?
America's Ballroom
Challenge (PBS, 9 p.m.) is the flip side of Dancing with the Stars , which incidentally returns on March 9. The PBS documentary was filmed at the world's biggest ballroom-dancing competition in Columbus, Ohio. The annual event attracts thousands of dancers from teens to seniors. The winning couples in each division come together for one grand finale dance-off for the title of America's Best Ballroom Couple. No massive cash prizes or celebrity hoofers here, just lovely ballroom dancing. A.R.
