____________________________________________________________

Canada's 'safe' ways seen from a new angle

Author: Deck, Kelly

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/canadas-safe-ways-seen-new-angle/docview/382654554/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: If there's one thing, design-wise, I'm bringing back with me from my trip, it's not to worry about hazards. It's a renewed faith in the beauty of simple objects, natural materials and the work of human hands.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canada%27s+%27safe%27+ways+seen+from+a+new+angle&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-06&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canada%27s+%27safe%27+ways+seen+from+a+new+angle&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-06&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A harrowing adventure off the coast of Bali prompts a fresh perspective on the limits of design
A month ago, I was on a commuter boat that sank in the Lombok Strait about a kilometre off the coast of Bali, Indonesia.
I and 40-odd other tourists were travelling from the island of Gili Meno to Bali when our boat struck something. We had only about five minutes to gather what we could before the 40-foot vessel went down.
I took my passport, credit cards, and reading glasses out of my backpack and put them in a small canvas purse. The boat tipped sideways and we stepped off it into the water. It took me about an hour to swim to shore. When the surf threw me up onto the beach, I was exhausted and shocked, but otherwise fine.
The accident put a few things into perspective. The usual items: working less, spending more time with loved ones, staying in better health. Perhaps not surprisingly, for the remaining fortnight of the trip I found myself circumspect and contemplative.
It may sound phony to say that a personal near-tragedy put me in mind of the differences between Balinese and Canadian approaches to interiors and architecture, when it could have put me in mind of, say, the differences in their boating-safety standards.
But the more I thought about it, the more alike those two subjects seemed.
The day after the accident, I arrived at Nick's Hidden Cottages in Ubud, a foothills town an hour inland of Denpasar, the capital. It was late afternoon. The hotel sits in a strip of rice paddies bordered by a busy street on one side and a canyon on the other.
Nick's didn't have a grand entrance, or even a paved driveway. To reach it, I walked down a narrow, raised path that wended through the rice fields. The paddies were the colour of new grass; at sunset, they reflected coral, violet, and pale pink. The air was sweet with the scent of vegetation and incense.
The thing that struck me, staying in that cottage of chiselled red brick with its hand-hewn mango-wood door, was how natural the buildings and design were. But that's not to say plain: Everywhere was breathtaking detail - on the statues and doorframes, for example. I saw this level of beauty and workmanship many places in Bali. Although intensely laboured over, Balinese design retains an essential simplicity. The place seemed unprocessed, as fresh food is unprocessed - field near to plate.
Canada, on my return, seemed more complicated and more processed - and not just for the Gyproc and big-box retailers and fluorescent lights. Vancouver is often accused of sterility, and if it's true of our broad avenues and glass towers, it may also be true of our interiors.
In Canada, we have fiercely regulated building codes, and, accordingly, ours is a legalistic approach to physical space. Two dominant dynamics seem to be at play. The first is the anticipation of problems before they occur - doing things like illuminating stairways with LED lights. The second is the way we redress problems after they occur. It's difficult to stand on a Canadian street or in a Canadian kitchen and ignore the degree to which its form is the result of litigation. Someone slips on a driveway, someone gets sued. Someone scalds himself with a kettle, someone get sued.
Back in a lounge in the raucous tourist quarter of Kuta Beach, I looked over my mojito to a sensationally angular steel staircase with a series of polished stone landings. I started counting the reasons it could never pass inspection in Canada: the open treads were a tripping hazard, for one, and the outside railing lacked sufficient vertical support. I ticked them off. In a choreographed accident, someone descending the stairs could slip beneath the railing and fall eight feet to the concrete floor below.
In Canadian design, one of the overarching concerns is What Might Happen. We have tremendously talented architects, designers, and engineers, but we don't get to see the outer limits of their creativity. Often, our homes and cities function so well we scarcely notice them.
Bali, in contrast, seems charmingly ad hoc. Alleys wide as a house at their mouth narrow inexplicably to shoulder width. The island's ubiquitous white-tiled floors are terrifyingly slippery when wet. (Presumably, people tread on them with caution.) When it rains, whole sections of sidewalk are removed to provide easy drainage for overflow. (People, I hope, don't walk into holes.)
This isn't the sentimental argument of a girl just back from holidays that Canada should be as improvised an environment as Bali is. There are aspects of that island - its beaches, which wear a fresh coat of garbage each morning; its roads, on which it's possible to drive into hot-tub-sized potholes; its air, which above the streets is thick with oil smoke and motorcycle exhaust - that could benefit from a little Canadian hypersensitivity to threat.
But if there's one thing, design-wise, I'm bringing back with me from my trip, it's not to worry about hazards. It's a renewed faith in the beauty of simple objects, natural materials and the work of human hands.
There were no fatalities or serious injuries in the sinking, and after everyone was collected, we were taken to a police station.
It was clear to many of the travellers what was to be done: apprehend negligent operators, file official reports, contact insurance companies. I felt the same way. The police appeared flustered to have a pack of angry Westerners on their hands.
Then, a well-dressed local pulled up in the flashiest car I saw on the island - a sparkling black BMW sedan with chrome wheels. Shaking the chief's hand, he took out of his pocket a thick bundle of bills. I smiled. There are problems and there are solutions, and he was the solution. It was then I said goodbye to my new friends and took my leave of the police.
Canada is designed to keep us pretty safe. And that safety has its rewards - and its costs.
Kelly Deck is the director of Kelly Deck Design, based in Vancouver, and the host of Take it Outside on HGTV.
***
kdeck@globeandmail.com

Forestry firm to sell, develop Island property

Author: Stueck, Wendy

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/forestry-firm-sell-develop-island-property/docview/382654052/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "When you're talking about sites that might nearly wrap around a community and contain a watershed, that clearly is more than selling an acre here and an acre there," said John Hendry, TimberWest's vice-president of real estate.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Forestry+firm+to+sell%2C+develop+Island+property&amp;author=Stueck%2C+Wendy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-06&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Forestry+firm+to+sell%2C+develop+Island+property&amp;author=Stueck%2C+Wendy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-06&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: TimberWest hires condominium expert in bid to earn more from land holdings
For the past two years, TimberWest Forest Corp. has talked about generating more value from its private land holdings, which amount to about 11 per cent of Vancouver Island by land mass.
Now, the company is stepping up those efforts, giving its real estate division its own name - Couverdon - and tapping Bob Rennie to help sell and develop its portfolio.
Mr. Rennie, whose name is nearly synonymous with condominium towers and whose firm is selling the financially troubled Olympic Village project in Vancouver, says Islanders should not expect a flood of high-rise, high-end developments.
"That urban luxury, one-size-fits-all market is exhausted on Vancouver Island," Mr. Rennie said in an interview this week at TimberWest's offices.
"That's really an old-economy model."
It's too early to announce what kind of projects could result from Mr. Rennie's involvement, he and TimberWest say. Couverdon may sell land outright or set up joint ventures. It could take a year or more before any deals are struck.
Mr. Rennie's role was worked out over the past few months. His company, Rennie Marketing Systems, will take on marketing, planning and design for TimberWest's real estate portfolio under the Couverdon name.
That portfolio comprises about 54,000 hectares - about 17 per cent of the 320,000 hectares of island property owned by TimberWest - that consultants in 2007 pegged as having "higher and better use" potential and includes parcels from Victoria to Campbell River.
In the past, TimberWest would on occasion sell land piecemeal. That approach won't work when the company is flogging thousands of hectares at a time.
"When you're talking about sites that might nearly wrap around a community and contain a watershed, that clearly is more than selling an acre here and an acre there," said John Hendry, TimberWest's vice-president of real estate.
"The idea that we should keep the same attitude to land in very important locations around the edges of urban centres - you can't really do it."
TimberWest no doubt hopes to tap Mr. Rennie's flair for marketing. The company in 2007 launched an on-line auction of some properties, but it wrapped up the same year with only one property being sold.
Over the past year, TimberWest has been talking to planners and councils in several communities, including Campbell River, aiming to strike deals that benefit TimberWest and gel with local land-use plans.
TimberWest is pursuing its real estate plans as the forestry industry is in a tailspin. Mills have closed and thousands of forestry workers are unemployed. Contractors who still have jobs are cutting logs, many of them from TimberWest land, that are largely being shipped out of the country for processing.
Near Victoria, a move by Western Forest Products to take its land out of tree-farm licences and sell it to a developer has resulted in a raging controversy over land use and government oversight over forestry lands. Conservation groups worry that agricultural and forestry land being swallowed up by development as a result of TimberWest land sales.
TimberWest's real estate holdings are not under tree farm licences. Although it says forestry will remain its prime business, TimberWest is recasting itself as a land-management company.
It closed its last mill, the Elk Falls sawmill in Campbell River, in May, 2008, and over the past few years moved from employee to contract logging crews.
Community-driven development could help replace some of that lost industry, says Mr. Rennie, who was overwhelmed with his first helicopter tour of the company's holdings and isn't fazed by the prospect of wading into Island politics, environmental battlefields and logging towns.
He likens it to balancing competing interests of developers and social groups in the Woodward's project, aimed at revitalizing Vancouver's Downtown Eastside, where everyone involved had passionate interest in the outcome.
"You look at the holdings of TimberWest - they own everybody's backyard," Mr. Rennie says.

In the Gulf, the truth about the economy might be found in counting cars

Author: Khouri, Rami G

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/gulf-truth-about-economy-might-be-found-counting/docview/382660430/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The current economic recession is a moment that cries out for an Arab leader who can speak truthfully to his people on the issues of the day that really matter, including how many abandoned cars may be parked at the airport. I suspect that the chances of this happening in the emirates and sheikdoms of the Gulf are probably higher than in any other Arab region - if the Gulf's self-image of pioneering, orderly, humane national development is a fact rather than mostly an image.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=In+the+Gulf%2C+the+truth+about+the+economy+might+be+found+in+counting+cars&amp;author=Khouri%2C+Rami+G&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-02&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=In+the+Gulf%2C+the+truth+about+the+economy+might+be+found+in+counting+cars&amp;author=Khouri%2C+Rami+G&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-02-02&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Editor-at-large of the Beirut-based Daily Star
Here's my definitive litmus test for the resilience and depth of Dubai as a place that can continue to expand economically after weathering the current global economic recession: How many abandoned cars are actually parked at the Dubai airport?
In a land of superlatives and seemingly endless hyper growth, the scale of the stories circulating about the number of abandoned cars at the airport is equally gigantic. In the past few weeks in Beirut, Abu Dhabi and Dubai, I have heard friends and acquaintances report authoritatively that, variously, 15,000 or 10,000 or 6,000 cars have been parked and abandoned at the airport by their foreign owners. These people lost their jobs, did not have enough money to complete their car payments, and found the easiest way out was to park their car at the airport and leave town for good.
The variety of stories circulating about this little drama is matched by the range of reports one reads and hears in the Gulf about the real state of the local economies in Abu Dhabi, Qatar, Dubai and other emirates - from deep disaster, to a manageable two-year recession, to a simple little blip on the charts that will see economic growth only drop slightly from 9 to 6 per cent, or something of that magnitude that totally removes any impact of a global economic collapse, miraculously detouring around these enchanted lands.
The abandoned cars are a good barometer of two important dynamics: Some core, critical facts and figures about their economies are simply not known to the public, but at least the gap in verifiable data is bridged by splendid rumours.
Foreign and local investors need to know the truth about these economies that have grown so impressively, in large part due to surplus oil wealth shifting into speculative investments in real-estate projects. If investors have doubts about the economic facts of these sheikdoms and emirates, they will quickly send their money to other markets where the facts are known. Investors do not mind bad news about economic losses or retrenchment. What they despise and fear is being left in the dark about economic realities.
Also, providing accurate, verifiable information about the realities of the economic downturn in the Gulf may be the first major "political" test these countries face in modern times. They can cement relations between citizens and their state on the basis of something more enduring than short-term materialism. If they can speak honestly to their own citizens and provide them with a clear, comprehensive picture of current conditions and expected trends, they will have enriched the entire Arab world with an example of true pioneering development and state-building that is much more meaningful than a shopping mall or a Hummer showroom.
We need one Arab government - just one - that will react to the global and regional economic recession by speaking the truth to its people, disclosing real unemployment rates, debt buyouts, contraction or expansion trends, and other such things. I have not seen such an example to date, but I suspect that the first Arab government that musters the courage to speak honestly will reap a reward of rare and incalculable proportions: the trust of its people.
I would like to hear one sheik, emir, king, sultan, president-for-life, or wise and vanguard-beloved leader of the dazed and pulverized masses explain the true extent of the crisis that is upon us, and ask for citizen participation in weathering the storm and generating ideas for coming out of it in decent shape.
The various emirates throughout the Gulf region that have grown at breakneck speed in the past three decades are having to adjust to supply-and-demand economic realities after living through nearly four decades in which they thought that they operated by different rules.
These statelets have enjoyed sufficient income to keep their citizens living happily for the most part, and also to offer jobs to millions of guest workers, while generating spectacular speculative investment opportunities for all those who dared to gamble. Now that the speculative bubble has burst, citizens, guest workers and rootless investors alike need some accurate news about just how bad or manageable things really are.
Anybody can be a popular leader by offering endless commercial contracts when the oil wealth is flowing non-stop. But only real leaders succeed when times are hard, oil income is down and economies are shrinking, and they maintain their credibility by telling their people the truth about the difficult times.
The current economic recession is a moment that cries out for an Arab leader who can speak truthfully to his people on the issues of the day that really matter, including how many abandoned cars may be parked at the airport. I suspect that the chances of this happening in the emirates and sheikdoms of the Gulf are probably higher than in any other Arab region - if the Gulf's self-image of pioneering, orderly, humane national development is a fact rather than mostly an image.
Rami Khouri is director of the
Issam Fares Institute for Public Policy and International Affairs at the American University of Beirut.

Living it up at the Hotel Continental

Author: McLaren, Leah

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/living-up-at-hotel-continental/docview/382664558/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Yet, from the inside, there is something unsettling about this hotel, with its cavernous rooms, carved-wood ceilings and cheap semi-gloss vases full of carnations and cabbages. In the evenings, bats swoop from the eaves outside my window, gobbling insects in the smog. Frommer's dismisses it as "an aging cathouse" and, while I didn't come here for luxury but to commune with the ghost of my literary hero, I have to agree.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Living+it+up+at+the+Hotel+Continental&amp;author=McLaren%2C+Leah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-31&amp;spage=L.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Living+it+up+at+the+Hotel+Continental&amp;author=McLaren%2C+Leah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-31&amp;spage=L.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   When I ask the local girl selling books on the street corner in Saigon if she has any copies of Graham Greene's The Quiet American, she jumps up from the curb and smiles. "You watch my books?" she asks, indicating a pile of dog-eared Lonely Planet Guides (Laos, Thailand, Cambodia) bound together with twine. I tell her sure and she spins off around the corner, skinny legs flying, returning 10 minutes later with a slim, shrink-wrapped Penguin Classic, for which I pay her the extortionate price of $8 (U.S.).
I haven't read The Quiet American (or any Greene for that matter) since university, when I went through a seriously pretentious phase of drinking neat scotch while imagining myself sweltering under a mosquito net in a war zone. Thankfully it didn't last long. I was, after all, a 20-year-old English lit major, not a middle-aged lapsed Catholic with a dead marriage back in England and a penchant for "local colour." Still, The Quiet American , which tells the story of a group of expatriates in Saigon before America's involvement in the Vietnam War, was my favourite. I remember it as cynical, brilliant, astonishingly prescient and, frankly, a lot fatter than this skinny little volume in my hand.
Back in my room at the Hotel Continental, where most of the events in the novel take place, I pull a carved rosewood chair out on to the crumbling balcony overlooking the Saigon Opera House and remove the plastic wrap. The book, as it turns out, is a pirated copy. It appears to have been photocopied onto newsprint and bound into a rudimentary facsimile of the iconic Penguin Classic cover, its text shrunk even smaller than the diminutive original and running cockeyed on the page.
For a moment, I feel badly that Greene's estate is not getting royalties and consider chucking the book army of motorbikes below. But then I think: What would Thomas Fowler, the novel's cynical, opium-addicted British war-correspondent hero, do? And the feeling passes.
I take a swallow of Saigon beer and begin reading. Suddenly I am in the grip of Greene fever all over again. I love this town and its chilled-out take on chaos - the carts of dried squid and families of five hanging nonchalantly off a single motorbike. I wish I had a concubine to bring me my opium pipe. I wish I had the urge to see a priest.
Greene, after all, is the reason I came to the Continental in Saigon (officially known as Ho Chi Minh City). While booking a cheap beach cottage on an island in the south, I came across several travel websites that said he had lived here (in Room 214 or 210, depending on whom you believe) and, on the spur of the moment, booked myself in for a couple of nights just to see what it was like.
If Greene's (now somewhat hackneyed) prewar vision of Vietnam as a beautiful, unobtainable and tragically misunderstood woman is to be believed, the Hotel Continental adds another seedier layer to the vision.
Much older and more affordable than its opulent colonial cousin - the Majestic - down the street, the Continental is an elegant whitewashed building on a main square of Dong Khoi and the city's pre-eminent historic colonial landmark.
And yet, from the inside, there is something unsettling about this hotel, with its cavernous rooms, carved-wood ceilings and cheap semi-gloss vases full of carnations and cabbages. In the evenings, bats swoop from the eaves outside my window, gobbling insects in the smog. Frommer's dismisses it as "an aging cathouse" and, while I didn't come here for luxury but to commune with the ghost of my literary hero, I have to agree.
It clearly has been a while since the American press corps ("noisy, boyish and middle-aged, full of sour cracks," as Greene unfondly remembers them) gathered in this deserted courtyard bar to gossip and drink, but, amazingly, none of the staff remembers the author - or his legacy. When I hold up the cover of the book, the lady at the front desk smiles blankly and shakes her head in confusion.
I go upstairs to my lair, take out my laptop and go to Literarytourist.com, a reputable website, to settle the debate once and for all. "Built in 1928, the Majestic Hotel offered opulence much closer to the life Greene enjoyed as a wealthy and famous novelist than to the seedy back alley rooms inhabited by Tom Fowler, Greene's protagonist in The Quiet American ," the website reads. "Perhaps Greene liked the Majestic because he was safely insulated from the dangers of the street."
The same street, ironically, where young girls are now selling illegal copies of Greene's own novel. And then there's me. A misguided literary tourist, longing to taste the authentic Saigon of my feverish imagination, yet even on my nerdy quest, unable to afford the real thing.
Does it even matter whether my hero set a battered Oxford in the Continental, so long as his imagination did? As a writer, isn't it the perception of place that I'm after, rather than the replication of history itself?
I take another Saigon beer from the mini fridge and step out on the crumbling balcony, overlooking the street where, just as in 1955, "the girls in white silk trousers bicycled home down the Rue Catinat." Then I remember: It's now called Dong Khoi.
This creaky old hotel may not have been good enough for Greene, but it's good enough for me. It's got to be. It might be Vietnam but I still can't afford the Majestic.
lmclaren@globeandmail.com

Ratatouille, it's not

Author: Hammer, Kate

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ratatouille-not/docview/382658826/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: After a lengthy cleaning process that was lauded by health officials as "very thorough," the Loblaws grocery will likely re-open for business Monday. But, like Chinatown, it will likely suffer from a lingering "ick" factor.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ratatouille%2C+it%27s+not&amp;author=Hammer%2C+Kate&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-31&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ratatouille%2C+it%27s+not&amp;author=Hammer%2C+Kate&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-31&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   With the spotlight on Loblaws and its moment of pesky infamy, all eyes are on the city's vermin population
If dog is man's best friend, rat is the friend that drops in uninvited and just won't leave. And it likes dim sum.
In the past two years, more than a third of Toronto restaurants and grocery stores fined for pest infestations and then closed by the city's public-health inspectors have been located in Chinatown.
How it became a rodent hot spot is a chicken-or-the-egg dilemma.
By all estimates, the area surrounding the intersection of Spadina Avenue and Dundas Street is a prime slice of rodent real estate. Large, open grocery stores, small crowded restaurants, crumbling buildings and aging infrastructure offer all the basic amenities essential to a small, furry, mammalian scavenger lifestyle.
But the heavy infestation discovered in a Loblaws grocery store near the Annex suggests the problem may be pervasive throughout the city, and supports the argument that increased scrutiny in the wake of a few high-profile sightings has sealed Chinatown's reputation as a rodent haven.
After a lengthy cleaning process that was lauded by health officials as "very thorough," the Loblaws grocery will likely re-open for business Monday. But, like Chinatown, it will likely suffer from a lingering "ick" factor.
Rats can gnaw through concrete, spread dangerous bacteria through their excrement, and viruses through their fleas. The inventory of diseases they can spread includes salmonella, E. coli and bubonic plague.
Mice are less destructive but equally infectious; their feces carry potentially fatal hantaviruses that can infect human lungs upon close contact. Unfortunately, their small size and affinity for the indoors means they often scamper amongst us, and our fresh produce, undetected.
And those squirmy, scaly pink tails are just plain gross.
In the age of cellphone cameras and YouTube, few nibblers go unnoticed, and their images are often shared with a few thousand friends. (Footage of nearly two dozen rats frolicking through a joint Taco Bell and KFC store in Manhattan has been viewed by millions.)
In February of last year, photographs of rats scurrying about floured countertops inside Dumpling House on Spadina Avenue were posted on a local news blog. Then, in October, a large rat was photographed only a few doors away, in the window of Happy Seven Restaurant, perched beside a Toronto Public Health inspection "pass" sign. That rat was also featured on the blog.
"This is a natural situation. Where you have people, you have rats," said Victor Wong, executive director of the Chinese Canadian National Council, whose offices are located in the heart of Chinatown. "If you applied the same level of scrutiny in other areas where there are food markets and restaurants, you would find very similar results."
The Loblaws infestation is not the first one in its neighbourhood to achieve infamy. In 2000, a pair of passersby photographed mice nibbling through the cellophane of sandwiches inside the Shakespeare Café, west of Spadina Avenue on Bloor Street West. The pictures were published in this newspaper, and the café was closed by health inspectors a short time later.
And yet, pest-control-related closures remain relatively rare in that part of the city.
A few blocks south, a long, narrow store in Kensington Market, Cheese Magic, filled with teetering towers of creamy brie and tart cheddars, was closed last year when inspectors found evidence of a rodent incursion, among other infractions. The owner, Ping Chiu, said inspectors found small amounts of mouse poop within the walls of the 100-year-old building her store has occupied for more than two decades.
In the years since the city reduced garbage collection from twice a week to once a week, she has been engaged in an endless battle to keep furry scavengers from infiltrating her store. "It's hard to prevent that because there's always holes and cracks in the building - in all the buildings around here," she said.
Ms. Chiu pays an exterminator to visit her store once a month, and for a private company to collect her garbage four times a week. But human scavengers riffle through her recycling and steal her garbage bags, leaving piles of waste in the streets beckoning to the pests she devotes so much effort to trying to expel.
Though she believes that Chinatown's reputation is somewhat deserved, Ms. Chiu also feels it has become exaggerated by public health's increased scrutiny.
The chances of becoming ill after eating at an establishment that has become infested are "fairly low," said Greg Baumann, vice-president and senior scientist for the National Pest Management Association.
Rats "have a tendency to collect near humans because we provide them with everything they need," he said. "Because they are so efficient and such a well-designed tool, they also make a formidable enemy."
There are, however, success stories. While the house mouse, M us musculus ,has been just as successful as we have at spreading and populating the Earth, there are two parts of the world that are nearly entirely rat-free: Antarctica and Alberta. The former benefits from a frigid climate and tiny human population, while the later has implemented a more militant approach.
The species of rat that frequents our grocery stores, Rattus norvegicus , or the brown rat, is not native to North America. It landed with settlers on the east coast near the end of the 18th century and began a migration west. By the time the first brown rats reached the western border of Saskatchewan in the early 1950s, the Albertans were ready for them.
More than 63,000 kilograms of arsenic trioxide were spread over farms and buildings between Medicine Hat and Provost, between 1952 and '53, according to an Alberta agriculture report.
The Rocky Mountains to the west and an army of pest-control inspectors in municipalities to the east have helped keep the province nearly rat-free. Rats are illegal either as pets or as pet food in Alberta, and the penalty for keeping them is a $5,000 fine. Laboratory rats, domesticated descendants of the brown rat, can, however, be kept by zoos, universities, colleges and research institutions.
By international standards, Toronto's rodent problem remains relatively minor. Some estimate New York City may be populated by as many rats as it is humans.
One way to be doubly sure your favourite takeout restaurant is rodent-free is to stroll by at night and peer in the window.
Be sure to bring a camera.
***
Chinatown is not the only hot spot
Far from the narrow streets of Chinatown, many establishments have been caught with heavy or chronic pest infestations. And the list of offenders can be surprising.
Signs of an infestation alone are usually not enough for a health inspector to close a restaurant, but the infestation uncovered at The Keg Steakhouse and Bar at 927 Dixon Rd. in Etobicoke last year was deemed critical, and the restaurant was closed immediately.
Two inspections at the Double Choc Donut Bakery on Garyray Drive in North York last year revealed evidence of infestations. The store was closed in February, 2008, but received a conditional pass on an inspection earlier this month because of inadequate pest-control methods.
A Manchu Wok food-court vendor on The West Mall in Etobicoke was closed and fined $1,125 in March of 2007 after evidence of a serious insect infestation was uncovered. The vendor was fined again in April, 2008, for inadequate pest-control methods, but received a full pass when health inspectors visited again last week.
Perhaps most alarming is the number of sushi restaurants that have been closed in the past 18 months with pest control-related infractions. Sushi Star Restaurant on Spadina Avenue, Sakura on McCaul Street, and Yonge Ichiban Sushi on Finch Avenue East have all been shuttered for brief periods by public-health inspectors.
Kate Hammer

Title: Ratatouille, it's not

____________________________________________________________

Struggling Spain highlights euro zone's plight

Author: Jimenez, Marina

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/struggling-spain-highlights-euro-zones-plight/docview/382661938/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The chattering classes in Spain aren't, however, lobbying to go back to the peseta. Spain has been the single largest beneficiary of the European Union, receiving $245-billion (U.S.) over the last decade. (The country helps form the acronym PIGS, along with Portugal, Italy and Greece, for the resources they have soaked up.)

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Struggling+Spain+highlights+euro+zone%27s+plight&amp;author=Jimenez%2C+Marina&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-30&amp;spage=B.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Struggling+Spain+highlights+euro+zone%27s+plight&amp;author=Jimenez%2C+Marina&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-30&amp;spage=B.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   For more than a decade, Spain's economy was one of the most dynamic in Europe. La reina de la fiesta created one-third of all jobs in the euro zone, its growth fuelled by consumption and a sustained boom in the construction sector. Barcelona was the new Paris, its gastronomy, design and architecture full of bravado and elegance.
But when the real estate bubble burst and the global economic crisis hit, the fifth-largest economy in Europe suddenly became one of the most troubled.
The country now faces its deepest recession in 50 years. The Bank of Spain released figures this week showing a fall in economic output in the last two quarters, and forecasting a 2-per-cent contraction for 2009. There are as many as 800,000 unsold homes on the market, and unemployment is at 14 per cent, expected to hit 20 per cent by 2011.
Some analysts wonder whether being tied to a single euro zone monetary policy will hamper the country's ability to recover. The Spanish government cannot devalue its currency or lower interest rates to stimulate growth.
Instead, it is hamstrung by the European Central Bank, which recently dropped interest rates by half a percentage point to 2 per cent. The ECB, however, ruled out another cut yesterday, even as the International Monetary Fund called for further action and predicted economic activity would contract by 2 per cent in the euro zone.
Europe's other large economies are also struggling. Germany posted unemployment of 8.3 per cent yesterday, and in France, where unemployment is 9.8 per cent, an estimated one million workers marched to protest President Nicolas Sarkozy's handling of the crisis.
But Spain, which has had above-average growth for the last decade, has fallen fastest and farthest. This week, on the popular TV show I have a Question for you , Prime Minister Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero urged viewers to consume local goods and said the economy isn't just about money but is a state of mind.
"Our unemployment is higher because most of our growth was in construction and those workers are harder to re-employ. Our economy isn't as competitive as France and Germany so it's harder for us to export," said Emiliano Carluccio, who puts out the Bulletin of Inflation and Macro-economic Analysis at Madrid's Carlos III University.
Some political commentators are now suggesting that Spain, as well as Greece, may face internal pressure to abandon the euro as their currency. The Maastricht Treaty, which established the single currency in 1999, contains no legal route for a country to leave the euro, but that doesn't mean it couldn't happen.
The chattering classes in Spain aren't, however, lobbying to go back to the peseta. Spain has been the single largest beneficiary of the European Union, receiving $245-billion (U.S.) over the last decade. (The country helps form the acronym PIGS, along with Portugal, Italy and Greece, for the resources they have soaked up.) If Spain devalued its currency, its foreign debt would increase in real terms by at least 20 per cent and it would likely default. "It is completely crazy and nobody is considering this possibility," Mr. Carluccio says.
Barry Eichengreen, an economist at the University of California at San Francisco, says monetary union is harder when the shocks hitting the member economies are asymmetric. "When times were good, nobody ever said 'it's bad to be in the euro zone.' "
The British experience shows how a national currency and monetary policy can help an economy adjust. Facing the effects of a global recession and a burst housing bubble, the Bank of England cut interest rates to the lowest level ever, 1.5 per cent. The pound has also dropped in value to below parity against the euro, which will help British exports.Spain's vulnerability also relates to its lack of productivity. It is the only country in the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development where productivity fell between 1991 and 2005, largely owing to its labour-intensive tourism and construction sectors. The construction sector accounted for 9 per cent of the country's gross domestic product - twice as big a share as in other big European countries - and tourism, 11 per cent. The country should focus on structural reforms, invest in secondary education, and diversify into value-added sectors, Mr. Carluccio said.
Spain's current-account deficit is roughly equivalent to 10 per cent of its GDP, which means the country is consuming more foreign goods and services than it is selling.

Why sexy veggies and girly gridiron games get bumped

Author: Doyle, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/why-sexy-veggies-girly-gridiron-games-get-bumped/docview/382661958/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Meanwhile, NBC has declined to air a commercial made for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) during the Super Bowl. The commercial, which I have seen and enjoyed, is definitely "pro-veggie," as it is described in news reports.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Why+sexy+veggies+and+girly+gridiron+games+get+bumped&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-28&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Why+sexy+veggies+and+girly+gridiron+games+get+bumped&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-28&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Serious news today: The Lingerie Bowl has been cancelled.
The producers of the event, Lingerie Bowl VI, which was expected to air as a pay-per-view special during halftime at this Sunday's Super Bowl, failed to agree terms with a suitable venue this year. If I understand correctly, the Lingerie Bowl was scheduled to take place at a clothing-optional section of Caliente Resorts in Florida, but there was a helluva ruction about the appropriateness of holding an event that involved women wearing skimpy clothes at a place that's a haven for people wearing no clothes at all. A matter of principle, and all that.
The nail in coffin for Lingerie Bowl VI came when Caliente Resorts issued this statement: "Caliente is a luxury clothing-optional resort. We ran into conflicts with the Lingerie Football League wanting more areas of our resort restricted to clothing required than we could accommodate." See, the lingerie-clad players were uncomfortable doing their thing surrounded by fellas who are buck naked. That's the gist.
Mind you, it's easy to read the reality behind this baloney. If there was a real demand for Lingerie Bowl VI, it would be airing as usual. Obviously, there isn't.
Meanwhile, NBC has declined to air a commercial made for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) during the Super Bowl. The commercial, which I have seen and enjoyed, is definitely "pro-veggie," as it is described in news reports. It has been pulled from the broadcast by NBC Universal's advertising standards department because it "depicts a level of sexuality exceeding our standards." The brief ad, which was intended to carry the slogan: "Studies Show Vegetarians Have Better Sex," involves lingerie-clad models showing their enthusiasm for vegetables. One sequence shows an actress rubbing her pelvic area with a pumpkin. What she does with asparagus is even more interesting. NBC says it couldn't possibly air this material. PETA says, "PETA's veggie ads are locked out, while ads for fried chicken and burgers are allowed, even though these foods make Americans fat, sick and boring in bed."
Again, it's possible to see the real story here - a cash-strapped NBC is nervous about lurid footage of lingerie-clad ladies having their way with vegetables. It won't take the dough for the sexy veggie spot.
People, I put it to you that these two news items from the TV racket are signs of the new seriousness that is part and parcel of the current economic apocalypse. On the day that Barack Obama was elected, I pointed out that a new seriousness was supposed to wash over the United States, like a sobering acid rain after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. And it never happened then, or in the years after. Instead, the frivolity increased. All that coverage of Paris Hilton and reality TV series about well-known floozies and flibbertigibbets. Seriousness was not the option chosen.
Now, on the cusp of that culture-defining event in the U.S., the Super Bowl, here it comes. The U.S. popular culture gets a makeover. As it must. There has been giddy optimism about the Obama era, but the economy is on the brink of ruin. The present is funereal and the future is indistinct and unsettling. The time for responsibility and obligation is now. The time of the floozies has passed. The seriousness is here.
Members of the heterosexual male species in the U.S. will be obliged to drool over lingerie-clad models while looking at the undergarments section of the Sears catalogue. It's the Great Depression all over again. Serious news.
The Week the Women Went (CBC, 8 p.m.) is not something I can tell you much about. The advance DVD of tonight's episode carries only the sound of the aye-tiddly-aye theme music. No dialogue or voice-over can be heard. Perhaps this is a new CBC gimmick: "Viewers: Guess what the people are saying!" Anyway, far as I can gather, the second season of the series, which began last week, chronicles what happens when 200 wives, mothers, sisters and daughters pull out of Tatamagouche, N.S., for a week of pampering at a resort in New Brunswick. The men have to do the domestic stuff: the chores, the kids. Last year's series, set in a small Alberta town, was deeply depressing about the awfulness of men.
Check local listings.
jdoyle@globeandmail.com

AMERICAN IDOL (Fox, CTV, 8 p.m.) is something we need to keep an eye on - news has broken that Simon Cowell has been cursed by a witch doctor after she was voted off during the first-round auditions of the similar show Britain's Got Talent .
THE FIFTH ESTATE (CBC, 9 p.m.) is really, really racy this week. Hana Gartner casts a cold eye on online, virtual adultery. Apparently, one of the great social ills of our time is Second Life, an Internet fantasy game that allows users to create a fantasy version of themselves, meet others and socialize, travel or engage in romance. Gartner introduces us to two women, "ordinary suburban moms" who fell in love with their fantasy life and lovers. If fact, they abandoned their families to meet the man behind their fantasies. You can find out if the real thing measured up.
WILD DOCS: JELLYFISH
Invasion (Newsworld, 10 p.m.) is all about that curse of the beach holiday, the jellyfish. See, they live in every ocean on the globe, thriving in both the Arctic and the tropics. Yes, the jellyfish populations are on the rise. The program exposes the crisis.
J.D.

____________________________________________________________

$1.3-billion shake-up rocks chilled-out Snowmass

Author: Knowles, Lori

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/1-3-billion-shake-up-rocks-chilled-out-snowmass/docview/382673615/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Snowmass's grandness continues, with its streams of mogul runs on the ski area's west side at Campground and Sam's Knob, to the east at the intermediate Elk Camp, and above The Burn along what's called The Cirque. The latter is a ring of above-treeline, powder-filled, double-black diamond steeps with curious names like Hang On and AMF (Adios My Friend).

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%241.3-billion+shake-up+rocks+chilled-out+Snowmass&amp;author=Knowles%2C+Lori&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-24&amp;spage=T.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%241.3-billion+shake-up+rocks+chilled-out+Snowmass&amp;author=Knowles%2C+Lori&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-24&amp;spage=T.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Drop down on Runway 15 on a sunny day at the Aspen/ Pitkin County Airport and four Colorado ski mountains will be gleaming before you like the jewels on a wealthy Aspenite's fingers. Aspen Mountain (Ajax) is there to the east, with its sleek, double-black-diamond peaks and one of the world's chicest towns at its feet. Aspen Highlands is to the southeast, with its retro runs, pounding bumps, and posse of hard-driving locals. Buttermilk is nearly due south with its green circle strollers and rock 'n' roll terrain parks. And there, to the southwest, lounging lazily in the sun is Snowmass, the most chilled-out of them all.
Broad, rolling, dotted with groves of glittering aspen trees, Snowmass has always offered a vibe different to its three more frenzied Aspen siblings. Absent have been the flashbulbs of Aspen Mountain's paparazzi, the tumult of Buttermilk's parks 'n pipes - home to the Winter XGames - and the incessant fear inspired by the Highlands' steep slopes. Instead, Snowmass opens its cushioned arms wide to welcome you and rocks you into relaxation with its seamless lifts - including an $8.8-million super chair new this season - its ski-in/ski-out accommodation, and its moderate pistes. It has always taken visiting skiers, regardless of their ability or the heft of their wallets, about two seconds to feel right at home on this unpretentious, pillow-comfortable mountain.
Not much has rocked Snowmass's relaxed world for nearly 40 years, until this season. When the chairlift bullwheels started turning in December, a $1.3-billion addition to the Snowmass base made its debut - 100 new ski-in/ski-out residences, a handful of upscale restaurants and nightclubs at the base of Fanny Hill which, frankly, threaten to shake up Snowmass' notoriously sleepy disposition.
The village expansion has been rocky and years in the making. Those who valued Snowmass' quiet and lack of pretence fought the changes. Canada's currently troubled Intrawest Corp. took the lead on the project with partner Aspen Skiing Co. (ASC) early in this decade, only to sell out abruptly in 2006 to Related WestPac, one of the largest private real estate companies in the U.S. By the time of the sale, Intrawest had alienated those Aspen locals who strenuously opposed the size, height and density of Intrawest's development plans and what they called the company's "penny-pinching." After paying a reported $208-million, Related WestPac forged ahead with Intrawest's intentions, anyway. Its first condominiums at Hayden Lodge and Capitol Peak Lodge are now open. While WestPac has plans to drop another $2.5-billion on two more Snowmass neighbourhoods by 2011, some projects were suspended last fall due to the credit crunch.
Through it all the company has held fast its commitment to creating what it calls "environmentally-conscious and pedestrian-oriented, smart-growth designs." ASC's Aspen/Snowmass resort is certified as a green company - the first of only two ski resorts in the U.S. to achieve this recognition (the other is Jackson Hole, Wyoming). And it is the only snow-sport resort in the country to have a green building policy. As a result, WestPac endeavoured to have these additional buildings certified by the U.S. Green Building Council. Planners have incorporated bike paths, walkways and a gondola into the design to cut down on vehicular traffic and building products will consist of 20 per cent recycled material.
The designs are decidedly sleek - a style WestPac calls "mountain-modern." Most buildings will be green certified, including The Little Nell five-star residence opening in 2010, and the Viceroy Hotel.
All this money and the hullabaloo of development has not changed the feel of skiing Snowmass. Mercifully, the mountain's bones are still intact.
Despite its size - 1,268 skiable hectares, 1,343-metre vertical drop all served by more than 20 lifts - it doesn't take long to figure out how best to ski the mountain. Elk Camp. Sam's Knob. Campground. The Big Burn. Like a handful of cards, they're fanned out easily before you at the start of each day. Up one lift, down an easy piste, up another lift and into some trees. Pop out, slide over a snowbridge and into some well-padded bumps. Before you know it, it's time for lunch.
Most skiers' introduction to Snowmass is Fanny Hill, a beginner slope kids and newbies to Aspen learn to ski on. Fanny Hill's multi-coloured sky cabs - kids call them The Skittles - move people up and down this easy slope, accessing the condos that scale steadily up its borders. From Fanny Hill, skiers can ascend higher on a series of high-speed chairlifts to the peak at 3,813 metres - one of the highest lift-served points in Colorado's Rockies.
Up there, the Big Burn is the ski area's most easily-accessible, big mountain run. The Burn is vast swaths of wide-open skiing, with the odd pod of low-rise evergreens scattered about which, like slalom gates, give you something to ski around. Its sparseness was caused by a massive fire in the 1880s which, depending who you talk to, was sparked either by Ute Indians trying to drive out white settlers, or the other way around. Either way, at this altitude, the trees have been extremely slow to grow back, leaving an impressive stretch of piste so broad that in a week you likely won't ski the same path twice.
Snowmass's grandness continues, with its streams of mogul runs on the ski area's west side at Campground and Sam's Knob, to the east at the intermediate Elk Camp, and above The Burn along what's called The Cirque. The latter is a ring of above-treeline, powder-filled, double-black diamond steeps with curious names like Hang On and AMF (Adios My Friend). In a good snow year - Snowmass' annual average snowfall is 762 centimetres - the skiing along these headwalls ranks up there with Whistler/Blackcomb's expert fare. Endless runs into the tightly-knit Hanging Valley Glades - with maverick names like The Edge and Free Fall - can fill in overnight with dry, chest-deep snow and give you the ride of your life after avalanche blasting in the morning.
What's nearly unmatchable, though, is Snowmass's cheery weather. It's typical for storms to sweep into Aspen's valleys at night, dump snow, then blow out by morning. The sky can smile an innocent blue by 10 a.m. after a vicious night, leaving skiers to ride the powder in the sunshine.
Back at its newly expanded base, the jury's still out on the effect of the addition of several swank new hotels. On the one hand, more choice of lodging may mean more affordable accommodation; Snowmass' unique ski-in/ski-out accommodation has always been highly in-demand and rarely deal-friendly. On the other hand, more lodging means more people, which would translate into more skiers on the mountain's typically and blissfully calm terrain.
What's for certain, however, is the continuation of the ease and variety of Snowmass runs. Slap your boards on at the bottom of Fanny Hill, ride the gondola over to Elk Camp or a chair to the top of Sam's Knob and you'll be treated to the same effortless, pillow-soft skiing riders have experienced here for decades. Forget the blinding glint off those well-polished jewels and the designer duds you spotted in the ritzy town of Aspen. The pistes of Snowmass will continue to ski more like your grandpa's big leather chair, with its warm supple feel, rolling expanse and faint hint of pipe smoke.
Lori Knowles is editor
of Ski Press Magazine.
Pack your bags
GETTING THERE
Air Canada and United Airlines offer direct flights from Toronto and Calgary to Denver, then on to the Aspen/Pitkin County Airport in Aspen.
GETTING AROUND
Most Snowmass lodgings offer free shuttle services to and from the Aspen airport. Call ahead to arrange pick-up.
WHERE TO STAY

CAPITOL PEAK LODGE Brush Creek Road, Snowmass Base Village; 970-922-5550; www.capitolpeaklodge.com. Condo units from $200 to $1,272.

Home Depot bows out of bid for new location at Queen and Portland

Author: Lewington, Jennifer

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/home-depot-bows-out-bid-new-location-at-queen/docview/382665812/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We determined it was not the right time for us to open," Home Depot manager of public relations Tiziana Baccega said yesterday. "We would have loved to have been there."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Home+Depot+bows+out+of+bid+for+new+location+at+Queen+and+Portland&amp;author=Lewington%2C+Jennifer&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-23&amp;spage=A.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Home+Depot+bows+out+of+bid+for+new+location+at+Queen+and+Portland&amp;author=Lewington%2C+Jennifer&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-23&amp;spage=A.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Big-box retailer Home Depot has cancelled its long-held dream of a downtown store - to the delight of some local critics - but talks are already under way for other tenants for the mixed-use development at Queen and Portland streets.
"We determined it was not the right time for us to open," Home Depot manager of public relations Tiziana Baccega said yesterday. "We would have loved to have been there."
Despite Home Depot's pullout, developer RioCan Real Estate Investment is confident construction is on track for a project that features a five-storey residential component over three storeys of retail.
"We should still be able to start by late spring, pending the finalization of leasing we are working on," said Fred Waks, chief operating officer of RioCan, the largest real-estate investment trust in Canada.
"We are very pleasantly surprised as to the amount of interest we have on the site," he said. "There is not a national grocery store that has not contacted us in the last 24 hours."
He confirmed that Home Depot paid $11.5-million to terminate its lease for 75,000 square feet of space.
RioCan already has tenants for about 16,000 square feet, with a major grocery store and other retailers as candidates for the former Home Depot space. Mr. Waks expects to wrap up negotiations with new retail tenants in two to three months.
Tribute Communities, RioCan's partner for the 90-unit condominium, has sold 55 units (or 61 per cent of the project).
An early critic of Home Depot's plans for a downtown spot said yesterday she is "relieved" that a suburban-style home improvement centre is no longer in the works.
"It was the wrong end-user for that neighbourhood," said Kristyn Wong-Tam, who owns XEXE Gallery on nearby Richmond Street and lives in the area. She hopes RioCan will seek out smaller-scale retailers, including a food store and boutique-style tenants.
Councillor Adam Vaughan (Ward 20, Trinity-Spadina), worried about the chilling effects of the downturn, said "construction isn't halted and that is the most critical thing for that stretch of Queen Street."

Islanders' arena plans caught in red tape

Author: Shoalts, David

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/islanders-arena-plans-caught-red-tape/docview/382722537/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: [Charles Wang] did not respond to a request for comment, but an Islanders spokesman said the owner cannot proceed until he receives approval for the entire project. Wang says the only way he can recoup the money he is losing on the Islanders - reportedly approaching $20-million a year - is through the profits on the entire project.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Islanders%27+arena+plans+caught+in+red+tape&amp;author=Shoalts%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-21&amp;spage=S.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Islanders%27+arena+plans+caught+in+red+tape&amp;author=Shoalts%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-21&amp;spage=S.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Town awaits impact assessments
The New York Islanders and owner Charles Wang are trying a familiar squeeze play in hopes of pushing through a massive real-estate project that includes a rebuilt arena - but local politicians say they are bound by law not to rush their approval.
The Islanders owner and his partner, real-estate developer Scott Rechler, want to rebuild Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum and build a sports, entertainment, business and housing project on 100 acres around the arena. It is estimated the development would be worth between $3-billion and $4-billion (U.S.).
The project was approved by Nassau County but cannot proceed until the Town of Hempstead signs off - which might only happen after a long series of studies of the environmental, health and other impacts of the project.
Wang, who wants to break ground on the project this summer, turned up the heat on the town last week, when the Islanders announced they will play a preseason game next September at the Sprint Center in Kansas City. Kansas City officials are aggressively lobbying for an NHL team to play in their new arena.
Wang did not come out and say the game was a test of the Kansas City market. But there was no shortage of anonymous team sources in the local media who did.
The Islanders also announced they will hold the first eight days of their 2009-10 training camp in Saskatoon. They will play two preseason games at Credit Union Centre on Sept. 19 against the Calgary Flames and Sept. 20 against the Edmonton Oilers. However, it is not unusual for NHL teams to hold part of their training camps in other cities.
NHL commissioner Gary Bettman called out Hempstead politicians on his satellite radio show last week. But town officials say nothing can be rushed. At present, the project is in the middle of environmental-impact studies.
Kate Murray, the supervisor and chief executive officer of Hempstead, said yesterday that Wang and Bettman can make all the noise they want about moving the team but it will not speed up the process.
Murray said rushing the project to approval "would suggest that I would be willing to break state laws to circumvent the environmental processes that by law we must go through."
Murray said she told Wang several times over the past five years that if he would proceed with the arena redevelopment first it could be approved quickly. Then the approval for the rest of the project could follow at its own pace.
As an existing building, the Coliseum would not require a long study for environmental, health and traffic concerns. But new projects do and this is where the process slows down, even though the county issued its approval a few years ago.
Wang did not respond to a request for comment, but an Islanders spokesman said the owner cannot proceed until he receives approval for the entire project. Wang says the only way he can recoup the money he is losing on the Islanders - reportedly approaching $20-million a year - is through the profits on the entire project.
"That is a business decision [Wang] made," Murray said. "Sometimes there is a feeling among hockey fans that somehow I am delaying this. But because he chose to tie the arena development to the real-estate development, he has to live with the time frame.
"He knows it and he is making that decision."
Town officials also point out that even though Wang was approved as the developer of the site by Nassau County in 2001, he never submitted an official request to develop the land with the county until 2005. Hempstead did not receive its official application from Wang until December of 2007.
Murray said she cannot give an estimate of how long all of the necessary approvals will take because several local and state agencies are involved. Wang hoped to start this summer, but his supporters now think he will be lucky to break ground in 2010.

Florida financier, and millions, missing

Author: Waldie, Paul

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/florida-financier-millions-missing/docview/382676800/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: So when Mr. [Arthur Nadel] didn't show up for work at his office in Sarasota, Fla., on Wednesday, Mr. [Neil Moody] got worried. Within hours, Mr. Nadel's family found an apparent suicide note and alerted police. The next day police located Mr. Nadel's green Subaru at the Sarasota airport.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Florida+financier%2C+and+millions%2C+missing&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-20&amp;spage=B.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Florida+financier%2C+and+millions%2C+missing&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-20&amp;spage=B.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Neil Moody thought Arthur Nadel was such a decent guy he not only went into business with Mr. Nadel but also gave him roughly $12-million (U.S.) to invest.
So when Mr. Nadel didn't show up for work at his office in Sarasota, Fla., on Wednesday, Mr. Moody got worried. Within hours, Mr. Nadel's family found an apparent suicide note and alerted police. The next day police located Mr. Nadel's green Subaru at the Sarasota airport.
Since then, the FBI and the Securities and Exchange Commission have joined local police in trying to find Mr. Nadel and figure out what happened to the roughly $350-million he managed through his company, Scoop Management Inc.
"He has disappointed a lot of people," Mr. Moody said yesterday in an interview from his Sarasota residence. "As far as I know he's still at large and believed to be somewhere in the U.S."
Mr. Nadel, 75, is the third investment fund manager in seven months to vanish after leaving a suicide note.
Last June, hedge fund manager Samuel Israel disappeared the day he was supposed to report to prison to begin serving a 20-year sentence for a $400-million fraud. Police found his car on a bridge about 90 kilometres north of New York City with the words "suicide is painless" written in dust on the hood. Police arrested his girlfriend, who confessed she helped Mr. Israel pack a camper with belongings and a motor scooter. Mr. Israel spent about three weeks in a campground in Massachusetts and then surrendered to local police, driving up to the station on the scooter.
Earlier this month, Indiana investment adviser Marcus Schrenker jumped out of an airplane over Alabama in an apparent fake suicide attempt. He sped away on a motorcycle that he had previously stashed, but was found at a campground in Florida. Mr. Schrenker faces several lawsuits alleging he owes investors and others more than $9-million.
While it's not clear what has happened to Mr. Nadel, Mr. Moody and others say he was a pillar of the local community.
He and his wife, Peg, donated to a wide variety of causes, including Habitat for Humanity and the local YMCA, which has said it had $1.1-million invested with Mr. Nadel. Last weekend, the couple attended a gala fundraising event at Circus Sarasota, which runs educational programs for children in addition to putting on performances.
Mr. Nadel, a lawyer by training, was a real estate developer in New York before moving to Florida in the 1990s. There are reports he ran into legal problems in New York and was disbarred.
He and Ms. Nadel started Scoop in 1999. Mr. Moody worked with Mr. Nadel since 1999 and he said there was no indication anything was wrong until last Wednesday. In fact, investors routinely received statements showing annual returns of between 8 and 12 per cent.
"He didn't show up and his wife came into the office around 11 expecting him to be there and he wasn't," Mr. Moody said. "My family is out a minimum of $12-million."
On Saturday, Mr. Nadel's family released a statement saying Ms. Nadel and other employees of Scoop "have just learned that they, along with many others who have invested money with Art, have been victimized by his unauthorized actions."
The family added that it is co-operating with police.

Bye-bye, schadenfreude

Author: Houpt, Simon

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bye-schadenfreude/docview/382671038/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: So far, according to local brokers not involved in the building, not a single place has gone to contract. [Maurice Mann] and his partners began fighting. Six weeks ago Apollo Real Estate Advisors, the holder of the second mortgage, made a capital call of $22.7-million. [Lev Leviev], a friend of Vladimir Putin, pushed to remove Mann as the project's general manager.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bye-bye%2C+schadenfreude&amp;author=Houpt%2C+Simon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-19&amp;spage=R.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bye-bye%2C+schadenfreude&amp;author=Houpt%2C+Simon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-01-19&amp;spage=R.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: New York apartment buildings are like Russian families: The happy ones are all alike, but as Tolstoy might have written if he lived amid the economic plunge of 2008-09(-10?), every bad real-estate deal goes bad in its own way.
Once upon a time, the Apthorp on the Upper West Side was a happy place. Built in 1908 by the Astors to resemble Florence's Pitti Palace, the 12-storey limestone pile on the south side of West 79th Street is one of the few apartment houses in New York to occupy an entire city block, stretching from Broadway to West End Avenue. It boasts an interior courtyard that spurs envy among passersby, who peer past the heavy gates guarding its three-storey vaulted entryway into an exclusive interior garden courtyard. Its apartments were built to be unusually expansive, to make apartment life as attractive to rich families as living in a brownstone. In the sixties and seventies, artists began flocking there, attracted to the space even if the neighbourhood was a little run-down. Lena Horne, George Balanchine and Joseph Heller were residents.
Best of all, it was rent-controlled. So what if that led to breath-taking abuses of rental law?
Two years ago, the screenwriter Nora Ephron penned a lighthearted piece for The New Yorker about falling in love at first sight with her Apthorp apartment, which she moved into in 1980. (Part of the 1986 comedy-drama Heartburn , which she wrote, was filmed in the building.) Her rent was $1,500 (U.S.) a month, after an up-front payment of "key money" to the previous tenant of $24,000. Kate Nelligan, the Canadian actress, reportedly paid $285,000 to a previous tenant when she signed her lease in 1991. Some years ago, Cyndi Lauper successfully argued in court that her rent be reduced from $3,250 to $507.
As the neighbourhood went upscale in the 1990s, the building's management began wresting some of the units out of the rent-control category and handing them over to other celebrities and network executives who could afford $10,000 a month or more. Conan O'Brien, Rosie O'Donnell, Al Pacino and the 60 Minutes correspondent Steve Kroft moved in. Toxic antipathy boiled up between management and long-time residents.
For years, an uncomfortable detente persisted until the fall of 2006, when the Apthorp owners washed their hands of the whole mess and sold the building for $426-million to Maurice Mann, a local landlord, who took out a mortgage of $385-million with Anglo Irish Bank. When one partner backed out at the last minute, he brought in the diamond billionaire Lev Leviev. Mann pledged to keep the place a rental, though no one believed him, and sure enough by the following year he announced it was going condo.
The good news? Residents would have first crack at buying their apartments. The bad news? They were going to cost about $3,000 a square foot, or about $6-million for the average Apthorp spread. That was more than the cost of 15 Central Park West, the heralded new Robert A.M. Stern building near Columbus Circle where Denzel Washington, Norman Lear and Sting bought units.
Eye-popping restoration plans were drawn up (according to The Observer: hand-cast lion-head tap spouts, and powder rooms outfitted with onyx fixtures), for which Mann and his partners took out an additional $135-million mortgage, bringing their total leverage to $520-million. A cheesy promotional film was shot, and Mann began trying to sell the units.
You know how this ends. Or maybe not.
So far, according to local brokers not involved in the building, not a single place has gone to contract. Mann and his partners began fighting. Six weeks ago Apollo Real Estate Advisors, the holder of the second mortgage, made a capital call of $22.7-million. Leviev, a friend of Vladimir Putin, pushed to remove Mann as the project's general manager. When Mann wouldn't back down, with other lenders circling and with Apollo threatening foreclosure, Leviev insisted they take their dispute to arbitration. But while that might normally be a smart way to settle their differences, the original agreement between Mann and Leviev calls for them to submit any irresolvable dispute to a beth din, or rabbinical court.
The problem? Mann wants to take the case to a Conservative Jewish beth din; Leviev insists it be an Orthodox panel of rabbis. At last report, Leviev's lawyer said he was going to ask the State Supreme Court to tell them which beth din they must use.
A couple of years ago, during the boom times, a tale like this would have been greeted by the rabble with unfettered glee. For those who couldn't participate in the rocketing economy, there was also the pleasure of watching oversized egos shrivel in failure. But the reporting over the Apthorp dispute, from the Times to the local real-estate blogs, is muted and joyless, as if even the usual catcallers are realizing they too might be caught in an economic whirlpool not of their own making. Without schadenfreude , what on earth will this city do for fun?
Credit: shoupt@globeandmail.com
