Full text:   share their favourite books of the year
SETH
It's Chris Ware's The Acme Novelty Library , number 19 (Acme Novelty Library). Though this small oblong hardcover is in fact a periodical of sorts, and does contain a serialized segment of a much longer work in progress, do not allow these facts to prevent you from purchasing it. The story within its covers is entirely self-contained and fully satisfying as a complete work. If the number 19 were not displayed on the spine you would have no idea whatsoever that this is but a small section in a grand work to come. And a remarkable work it is.
The "graphic novel" is broken into two parts. In one half we observe William "Woody" Brown, a failed science-fiction writer/high school English teacher as he reflects back on a disastrous first love that has shaped (or perhaps misshaped) his entire adult life. In the other half of the story, we read Woody's first science fiction novella, The Seeing Eye Dogs of Mars. The two halves mirror each other and produce a work of remarkable complexity and emotional impact. A work about time and memory and how the past never really vanishes and how we are shaped by hurt. Ware also pulls off a very difficult stunt: He lets us know that Woody has written a excellent and well received science fiction story and then he has the bravado to produce that story for us to read - and yes, it is terrific.
As with all of Ware's works, the book is exquisite in its design, its drawing and its production. The real genius is in the storytelling techniques Ware uses - breaking every action down to its smallest gesture - revealing the subtle power of the comics medium in the hands of a master cartoonist. This is, hands down, the best "comic book" you will read this year. I think it might simply be the best book, period.
Seth is a Toronto-based cartoonist. His new book, George Sprott: 1874 - 1975, will be published in the spring.
ROSALIE ABELLA
The most mesmerizing novel I read this year was Lawrence Hill's The Book of Negroes (HarperCollins). I found it historically and rhetorically magnetic all the way through and it left a powerful imprint when I'd finished. Magnificent.
In non-fiction, I revelled in Wilfrid Sheed's The House That George Built (Random House), a wonderful mix of fact and anecdote about the magical musical landscape George Gershwin, Irving Berlin, Cole Porter, Duke Ellington, Hoagy Carmichael and others created and inhabited. And for sheer fun, I loved Christopher Buckley's wry Supreme Courtship (Twelve), about the politics behind filling an American Supreme Court vacancy. Fiction, of course...
WILLIAM BRYANT LOGAN
Last New Year's Day, I was at a party where I met a philosopher. After expressing my surprise and pleasure at his existence - I thought such jobs had been outsourced to the economists - I told him about my delight in reading Jacques Maritain. The real world is not the world of objects, taught Maritain, but rather the world of subjects. This was the most freeing piece of news I'd got in years.
"If you like Maritain," responded my philosopher acquaintance, "you should read Gabriel Marcel."
"Who?" I asked. Never heard of him.
Well, I've heard of him now. Two volumes of his 1949-50 lectures at Aberdeen University were published in 1951 as The Mystery of Being . In the same year came the chilling Man Against Mass Society . You can find an introductory selection of his essays published as Creative Fidelity (Fordham University Press, 2002).
Marcel goes Maritain one better. There are two ways to experience the world, he writes, either as a problem or as a mystery. A mystery is by its nature not resolvable. "A problem," he writes, "is something I run up against, something that bars the way. A mystery, however, is something in which I find myself involved."
Marcel invites us into real relationship to others not as a virtuous or moral thing, but as our only way into the real world. As human beings, he writes, "We are always in a situation." We cannot step outside of it. We cannot grasp or say what anything finally means. On the other hand, we can meet, experience and meditate, the more the better.
Marcel was a well-known dramatist and a gifted musician, as well as a philosopher, so his writing is not easy, but neither is it dry and dull. He often will write a sentence that I chew on for weeks. For example: "Whatever can be catalogued is an occasion for despair."
Or "Existence, strictly speaking, is not conceivable."
Or "I must somehow make room for the other in myself."
I am looking forward to this New Year's Day, in the hope that my philosopher acquaintance will be there again. I will embarrass him with effusive thanks. And who knows what he will give me next?
William Bryant Logan is an arborist in Brooklyn, N.Y., and the author of Oak: The Frame of Civilization and Dirt: The Ecstatic Skin of the Earth.
DAVID MIRVISH
We are not here to be happy. We are here to be of service.
If this was ever said to you, even in jest, while growing up then, Good To a Fault, by Marina Endicott (Freehand Books) is the perfect read for you.
What motivates our good behaviour? Are we in fact selfish in our choices to do good? Are we seeking recognition for our good deeds?
A wise friend said: Do your work; expect nothing in return; celebrate your accomplishment and start again. If you choose to do a good deed, good for you. I loved the book.
The Man Who Made Vermeers: Unvarnishing the Legend of Master Forger Han van Meegeren , by Jonathan Lopez (Harcourt) is a fascinating account of how the trade in fake Dutch art was conducted between the two Great Wars.
In the 1960s, we still believed that van Meegeren was a clever man who duped Hermann Goering and a gullible art world. This book looks deeply below the surface and chillingly exposes a Nazi sympathizer. Most frightening is Goering's pronouncement, "The People can always be brought to the bidding of the leaders, that is easy. All you have to do is tell them they are being attacked and then denounce the pacifists for lack of patriotism and exposing the country to danger. It works the same in any country."
David Mirvish is producer
of Mirvish Productions.
BUFFY SAINTE-MARIE
My pick is The Female Brain by Dr. Louann Brizendine (Broadway Books). Talk about a conversation starter! Did you know that all fetuses start off female? Or that until very recently, the only brains that had been studied had been male? Seems like everybody just assumed that female brains were the same as male brains, only a little smaller and a little bit broken. Not so. Both are perfectly designed for the survival of the owner and the species to which we belong. In my opinion, both would work together better if their owners read The Female Brain .
I've bought this book over and over and always bring a copy as a giveaway when I travel.
Buffy Sainte-Marie is an Academy Award-winning Canadian First Nations musician, composer and activist.
LAURA LIPPMAN
With books, as in the relationships of my youth, I can never decide if I ask for too much or too little. I want a good story, well told, with characters who seem recognizably human. Is that so much to ask? Sometimes, it seems that way. Even though I didn't read anywhere near enough in 2008, I read enough to have two solid favourites: I See You Everywhere , by Julia Glass (Pantheon), and Ms. Hempel Chronicles , by Sarah Shun-lien Bynum (Harcourt). And I'll throw in The Great Man , by Kate Christensen (Anchor), one of my favourite books of the last 10 years, but I was late to this 2007 title, which I chanced on in a used bookstore in New Orleans. Ask me for my favourites a year from now and there will inevitably be an "older" book among them.
All three of these books belong to a very specific sub-subgenre of literary fiction of my own devising, which I define as the why-can't-we-have-more-books-like-these subgenre. Smart, well-constructed, elegantly written and capable of genuine, organic surprises. As I said, I ask for too little, I ask for too much, but I cling to my standards because sometimes I find exactly what I want.
Laura Lippman is the author of the award-winning Tess Monaghan series of mysteries. She lives in Baltimore.
COLIN & JUSTIN
It's summer, 2008, and we're at Toronto's Sony Centre to see Leonard Cohen, and we're doubly excited because Joni Mitchell is sitting two rows behind. Precisely à l'heure , the curtain sweeps back and out walks our favourite musician, suited somberly in dark grey and wearing a pork pie hat. His set proves to be a veritable religious experience and the entire theatre hangs on his every lyric. As his melancholic voice lifts and falls, a glassy-eyed audience of worshippers is lost in his musicality. There's a standing ovation after every song and when he recites a poem called A Thousand Kisses Deep , the hall falls silent. This man is spiritual beyond belief. Amen.
After the show we call our friend Cherri Campbell, and almost weep as we tell her how awesome the evening has been. The next day, she sends us a copy of Cohen's Book of Longing (McClelland & Stewart), and as we leaf the pages we're suddenly back in the Sony Centre. You see, as far as we're concerned, a good book should take you somewhere. It should puzzle, excite or inspire. Or it should simply remind you of something wonderful. Reading Book of Longing , as we've done time and time again, is an emotive reminder of that wonderful evening in Cohen's company.
Perfume: The Story of a Murderer , by Patrick Suskind (Vintage) is one of those books to which you just can't help returning. Dark, disturbing and incredibly well written, it's a gaudy tale of horror, yet it avoids obvious "slasher" shock tactics in favour of a deep, developing terror from one man's obsession to explore the sense that is his very raison d'être, the sense of smell. This book, while simultaneously grotesque and picturesque, is a literary masterpiece and we absolutely love it - if, that is, "love" is a suitable word to describe such a dark tale.
We're both inspired by pop culture and product packaging and Pet Shop Boys: Catalogue by Chris Heath (Thames & Hudson) is a beautiful tome about brand identity, product design and graphics. And it's a jolly good reminder of a really great pop band. Annie Leibovitz at Work (Random House) not only showcases much of the celebrated photographer's best work, it also offers a chance to look behind the lens at a woman who is every bit as fascinating as the subjects whom she so beautifully captures.
Colin McAllister and Justin Ryan are the hosts of the HGTV program Colin & Justin's Home Heist and the authors of Colin & Justin's Home Heist Style Guide.
THEODORE DALRYMPLE
The Trial of Frederick Bywaters and Edith Thomson , edited by Filson Young (William Hodge & Co), is a 1923 entry in the Notable British Trial series, which ran from 1905 to 1959 in a completely unchanged format, and was one of the greatest publishing ventures of the past century. There are few greater pleasures than snuggling up to a fire while reading the transcript of the trial of the rococo criminals that Britain used to produce. This trial, a great cause celèbre , filmed and the subject of many novels, is among the best. Mrs. Thompson was hanged because she had written letters to her lover asking for advice on how to poison her husband with ground glass and suchlike. Bywaters eventually stabbed her husband to death and was hanged too.
Theodore Dalrymple is a British cultural critic and retired physician, and the author of, most recently, Not With a Bang But a Whimper: The Politics and Culture of Decline.
GEORGE A. COHON
Donald R. Keough is the former president of the Coca-Cola Company. He's been a personal friend for over 30 years and his The Ten Commandments for Business Failure (Portfolio) is a classic.
The foreword was written by Warren Buffett. Bill Gates, on the front of the jacket, says "Don's commandments for failure will teach you more about business success than a whole shelf full of books." Jack Welch says, "A must read for every leader."
It is, perhaps, the best business book that I have ever read. I highly recommend it to readers of all ages.
Keough says that if you quit taking risks, you will be sure to fail. If you are inflexible, you will be sure to fail.
If you assume infallibility, you will be sure to fail. If you don't take the time to think, you will be sure to fail.
If you put all your faith in experts and outside consultants, you will be sure to fail etc., etc.
George A. Cohon is founder
of McDonald's Canada and
McDonald's Russia chairman.
MONIA MAZIGH
Earlier this year, I read the The Yacoubian Building (Harper Perennial) by Alaa Al Aswany, an Egyptian author. I couldn't stop comparing him to a modern-day Arabic Emile Zola.
I am fascinated by his description of the daily contradictions in Arabic life, and the tendency of the Arab world to withdraw into itself, sometimes consciously, but for the most part completely unaware. His descriptions also carry contradictions, seemingly both subtle and detailed, bringing me back to my own childhood and youth in Tunisia, another Arab country, different in so many ways, yet so compellingly similar.
Al Aswany uses "the building" as an allegory or microcosm of Egyptian society, where the liberal, formerly wealthy, aristocratic, educated class co-exists with the conservative, popular and poorer classes.
In the world he creates, the zealous, young, inexperienced, and economically disadvantaged meet the rich, the debauched and the moderate, while the atheist lives under the same roof as the corrupt man who has turned into a religious politician.
Al Aswany depicts this amalgam of characters with humour, but also with the eyes of a connoisseur and the skills of a social surgeon.
The Egypt he describes is a modern and frank Egypt, without the sugar coating of its once famous soap opera TV series, the utopian complexities of its theorists or the Puritanism common in Eastern culture.
Monia Mazigh is the author of Hope and Despair: My Struggle to Free My Husband Maher Arar.
RANDY BACHMAN
I read a lot of "airplane" adventure soft-cover books, which are quite similar. But once in a while I read something significant. The Ghost Map , by Steven Johnson (Riverhead), tells the story of London's great cholera epidemic in 1854, of the lack of sanitation and the living conditions, and of the detective work in sourcing the cause to one well that polluted the city and killed hundreds of thousands. A true look into the conditions and perceptions of health and sanitation in that time period, which is also reflective of the whole world. I found this book riveting as I know London very well; it was like reading about my own neighbourhood.
Musician Randy Bachman(The Guess Who, BTO) is host of the CBC Radio program Randy's Vinyl Tap .
CRAIG BOYKO
I doubt that writing books is much like giving birth. Nor are books themselves much like children or babies - except perhaps in one respect.
Sometimes, when passing by someone else's pram, we cannot help but stare down in delight and sigh dreamily, "Oh, what a DEAR; I wish he were MINE!"
Trenchant, hilarious, brilliant, with not a single word out of place, Nigel Dennis's 1949 A Sea Change (Houghton Mifflin) is the best book I have read all year. I wish I had written it.
Craig Boyko is the author of the short-story collection Blackouts.
MELISSA FAYE GREENE
Darwin's On the Origin of Species will celebrate its 150th anniversary next November and the public sphere will fill with accolades and retrospectives. David Quammen's The Reluctant Mr. Darwin: An Intimate Portrait of Charles Darwin and the Making of His Theory of Evolution (Norton), accompanied by his coffeetable edition of On the Origin of Species (Sterling), ought to be at the top of everyone's list. Readers curious about the original theory can approach the bushy-browed, fierce-bearded, self-deprecating, garden-pottering old hermit himself.
He accidentally spent eight years hunched over tweezers and microscopes in the minuscule, sexually ambiguous world of barnacles; he tried to conceal from his dear Christian wife the fact that he beheld a materialistic law-driven world of vast splendour; and he was nearly trumped by a younger man in publishing his revolutionary insights. Shy, fumbling, hoping to please his tyrannical father, heartsick at the deaths of three of his 10 children, interminably suffering from digestive complaints, shunning the spotlight while coveting it, Quammen's Darwin is knowable, sympathetic and clearly, clearly, one of the few true giants of human history.
Melissa Fay Greene is a writer and journalist living in Atlanta, Ga. Her most recent book is Last Man Out, the story of the 1958 mine disaster in Springhill, Nova Scotia.
DAVID THOMSON
I have three choices.
Literary Nevada , edited by Cheryll Glotfelty (University of Nevada Press). Forgive and forget that a few of these 831 pages are by me, this is an invaluable introduction to the writings on the state and condition known as Nevada, the place where America has experimented on everything from biblical wilderness to gambling and from toxic nuclear waste to the fastest growing city in the U.S. The range of writing goes from Mark Twain and John Muir to Hunter Thompson and Samny Davis Jr. Nearly every entry brings a surprise and a sense of emptiness and moral chaos. We are all Nevadans now.
Ever, Dirk: The Letters of Dirk Bogarde , edited by John Coldstream (Weidenfeld & Nicolson). Bored with acting and sometimes seeming weary of life, Dirk Bogarde made himself a writer. He managed prim, tidy memoirs and novels. But in his letters he became himself - wicked, gossipy, swish, observant, cruel and tender. A lot of the letters come from his homes overseas, full of petty worries and rotten spelling. But the sense of jittery life is as rich and sly as his best acting. A delightful surprise and compulsive reading.
Me Cheeta (Fourth Estate). Without the apparent or acknowledged help of any human hand, here is the life story of the 76-year-old Cheeta - the long-suffering and story-telling chimpanzee who was part of Tarzan's family in the good old days of Hollywood. The format is a treasury of opportunities for scandal and the writing is consistently funny. Did Cheeta really write it himself? Well, he's a semi-retired abstract painter in Palm Springs now, but the taste for monkey business never goes away.
David Thomson is a film critic based in the United States and the author of more than 20 books, most recently "Have you Seen ...?": A Personal Introduction to 1000 Films.
SEAMUS O'REGAN
Anthony De Sa's Barnacle Love (Doubleday Canada) spans the old fish markets of Portugal to the young streets of Toronto in a collection of tenderly written short stories that, in total, tells of a painful, disillusioned immigrant experience. But De Sa also does us a historical favour by beautifully capturing the days when Portuguese fishermen invaded the nooks and crannies and churches of St. John's - leaving young schoolboys like me pondering over their legacy of rusted park signs saying "Keep Off the Grass" in Portuguese.
Seamus O'Regan is co-host of Canada AM on CTV.
ADRIENNE CLARKSON
For me, it's William Wilberforce , by William Hague (HarperCollins). Wilberforce was a rare bird: He grew up wealthy, the scion of a merchant family in Hull. After meeting William Pitt the Younger at Cambridge, the two proceeded into the House of Commons together at the age of 23. Wilberforce's moral integrity and purity of spirit in the destruction of the greatest evil he saw mankind perpetrating - slavery - makes for a deeply moving and human account of one life well-lived for a single purpose.
Adrienne Clarkson is former Governor-General of Canada.
MICHAEL ADAMS
John Ralston Saul's A Fair Country (Viking Canada) is an intellectually engaging effort to reframe our view of the relationship between aboriginal peoples and Canadians who have arrived (or been born to migrants) over the past four centuries. Saul's reading of history suggests that a more respectful, even egalitarian relationship existed between aboriginal peoples and European newcomers during the first couple of centuries before the period of de facto cultural genocide from which we are now only haltingly emerging.
Being a pollster, I naturally surveyed the opinions of my First Nations, Metis and Inuit friends and colleagues, and found unanimity among them that this book intrigued them, and did not, as I had feared, give unintentional offence with its provocative declaration that "We are a Metis civilization."
Aboriginal peoples are one of Canada's most rapidly growing demographic groups. Now at 1.2 million, they are close to the numbers estimated to have been here when Jacques Cartier first set foot on this land. An even larger number of us (1.8 million) claim aboriginal ancestry and both these numbers have been growing in recent censuses more rapidly than new births, suggesting that we are in fact witnessing a renaissance of aboriginal identity in this country - an emerging spirit that Saul is sensing. His book's quickly achieving bestseller status also suggests he is tapping into an inchoate sense among non-aboriginal Canadians that we should be rethinking the stereotypes we learned in the history books of our youth and that are reinforced every few months by the relentless bad-news stories in the media. Maybe - maybe - Saul has begun the dialogue that will create a powerful new national narrative (the Greeks called it mythos) to reframe this relationship from one of ignorance and racism to that of equality and respect.
Michael Adams is an author and president of the Environics group of research and communications consulting companies.
HAL WAKE
It was impossible for me to choose a single book out of the many fine ones I have read this year, so I've decided to write about two pages of wondrous, luminous prose by a master of the craft.
I've read them more than a hundred times over the last decade and return to them several times a year. They are pages 16 and 17 in my paperback edition of Marilynne Robinson's magnificent novel Housekeeping (HarperCollins).
The passage begins, "One day my grandmother must have carried out a basket of sheets to hang in the spring sunlight, wearing her widow's black, performing the rituals of the ordinary as an act of faith."
What follows is depiction of the grandmother's relationship with her departed husband, Edmund. In two long paragraphs, Robinson engages in a profound meditation on the meaning of life and love and death and rebirth, in a prose voice that is by turns poetic, incantatory, allusive and almost biblical. Robinson does more in two pages than many novelists accomplish in entire books.
Hal Wake is artistic director of the Vancouver International Writers Festival
SUSAN JUBY
Jhumpa Lahiri's second collection of short stories, Unaccustomed Earth (Knopf Canada), was the book that moved me the most in 2008. Each story put me in awe of her powers as a writer and reminded me of that the short form often contains the biggest stories. The well-educated Bengali-Americans who populate her pages are so specific a group that it's astonishing to realize that they transcend that specificity to offer us insights into what it means to grow and survive as human beings in the 21st century. Writers can put this one on the aspirational section of the bookshelf.
Susan Juby is author of Getting the Girl and Alice, I Think.
GEORGE MURRAY
Stephen Galloway's The Cellist of Sarajevo (Knopf Canada) turns the camera lens slightly away from the centrepiece of a legendary news story and drills down into the intimate lives of people struggling to survive in a divided, besieged city. Desperation, danger, compassion and beauty all mingle to create one of the most compelling reads of 2008. I was really surprised not to see it on every fiction award shortlist. This is that rare kind of book that transcends its subject matter and will outlast the fashions of our day.
The Letters of Ted Hughes (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) is a well-curated volume of correspondence that gave me something new from a poet I know intimately: a sense of his doubt. From Hughes's earliest fumblings toward poetic success, to his troubled marriages and the horror and self-loathing he experienced around the deaths of his wives, to the raising of his children, and finally his crowning as the grand man of English letters - the book creates a narrative that acts as a wonderful counterpoint to available biographies. The entire read is worth it for the description of his meeting with the Queen. It's the first book of letters I've ever read that I couldn't put down.
Poet George Murray runs the literary website bookninja.com.
RAWI HAGE
Jacques Poulin's minimalist and philosophical novel Spring Tide (Archipelago Books) is a delicate and heart-wrenching contemplation on the necessity of solitude, the consequences of words and the tides of time. Poulin's prose is as simple, calm, deep and recurring as the waves that carry the protagonist's lover. In its wonderment and profound simplicity we are reminded of Le Petit Prince 's little planets and celestial encounters with machines, animals and faraway humans. Sheila Fischman's translation is magnificent, skillful and considered as always. Quebec's literature at its finest.
Rawi Hage's most recent novel is Cockroach. His De Niro's Game won the 2008 International IMPAC Dublin literary award.
MAG RUFFMAN
It's only fair to state my bias. I hate books without a happy ending. So I usually only read self-help and business books, hoping that I'll be the happy ending. This year I found one fiction book I loved. Ian Thomas's The Lost Chord (Manor House) is a metaphysical nail-biter that I started on a Saturday afternoon and didn't put down until midnight Sunday. It shows a breadth of imagination and a curly-minded originality that kept me engaged emotionally and intellectually without food or drink for about 20 hours. Thomas is renowned as a musician and for being the brother of an even more famous guy (comic Dave Thomas), but his novel is so unusual and thought-provoking that I think he deserves huge attention from readers with a taste for unconventional thinking.
My favourite self-help book this year is a mind-bender of indescribable scope and magnanimity. Money and the Law of Attraction , by Esther and Jerry Hicks (Hay House), is about how your thoughts affect your prosperity. It had a happy ending; my company doubled its revenue in 2008.
Mag Ruffman is a TV personality, newspaper columnist and publisher of We're All in This Together - Red Green: The Man Behind the Character and Vice Versa.
MARINA ENDICOTT
Resolutely refusing to choose between the wonderful books of my Canadian friends, I offer you Michael Chabon's The Yiddish Policemen's Union (HarperCollins), a noir detective story set in a Jewish homeland created in Sitka, Alaska in 1948 - but the lease is up. I read it while moving from the place I'd lived longest in my life, lying on the floor in the almost-empty house: perfect circumstances for this beautiful, broken-hearted book about displacement and yearning, some kind of salvation, and chess.
Marina Endicott's Good to a Fault was a finalist for the 2008 Scotiabank Giller prize.
IRSHAD MANJI
Any new book that grabs my overworked students gets my vote as a 2008 favourite. This year, we have a tie.
American philosopher Susan Neiman compels critical thinking on the Left - where most of my class sits - with Moral Clarity: A Guide for Grown-Up Idealists (Harcourt). A happy Democrat who refuses to become a brainless Obamabot, she offers insights into savvy and ethical activism. Among the lessons that rocked my class: Today's liberals make a dangerous mistake in downplaying the threat of Islamism out of hatred for George W. Bush, since the first people to suffer under Islamist regimes are women and minorities - the very constituencies liberalism is supposed to serve. Sounds obvious, but to a generation steeped in polarized politics, it's a freaking revelation.
As is Arthur Herman's Gandhi and Churchill: The Epic Rivalry That Destroyed an Empire and Forged Our Age (Bantam). Eviscerating empire? Great start. Beyond the title, though, lies Herman's bigger score. He manages to make the iconic Gandhi utterly, sputteringly human - a dreamer who ran a contest in the local newspaper to name his fledging movement; a leader who repeatedly failed to ignite the movement for which he's now famous; a populist who couldn't have been less popular among his own for many years; a barrister who began donning his hallmark rags for the sake of image. Far from being disillusioned, my students could finally relate to the untouchable Mahatma, in whose false starts they see their own hopes for changing the world.
And one day, because of writers such as Neiman and Herman, these global citizens will transcend the limits of identity to realize they can also learn from a white guy like Churchill. Idealism, indeed.
Irshad Manji, author of The Trouble with Islam Today, is a professor of leadership at New York University.
IAN KERSHAW
Two books that I have particularly enjoyed and admired recently deal with important aspects of the Second World War, and lie close to my own interests.
Laurence Rees's World War Two Behind Closed Doors: Stalin, the Nazis and the West (BBC Books), is arguably the author's finest book to date and accompanies the gripping television series of the same title. Rees has uncovered new material in Soviet archives, casting fresh light on Stalin's relations with Churchill and Roosevelt and how decisions were taken at the pinnacle of Allied war leadership.
There are some unpleasant surprises for admirers of the Western leaders whose cynical, dirty dealings with Stalin are exposed.
But what choice did they have? An enemy's enemy was a friend. As Churchill himself put it: "If Hitler invaded Hell, I would at least make a favourable reference to the Devil" - almost a metaphor for the Soviet Union and its leader. Rees writes in fine style and interweaves into the often dramatic narrative the personal stories, drawn from numerous interviews with contemporaries who paid the price of those decisions and have moving, frequently horrific, experiences to recount. As unholy moral compromises of the western leaders with Stalin's inhumanity are laid bare, the important question which the book raises - and leaves open - is whether even the most just war can ever be fought with clean hands.
Previously unknown sources also enable Andrew Roberts, in his brilliantly written and fascinating Masters and Commanders. How Roosevelt, Churchill, Marshall and Alanbrooke Won the War in the West (Penguin), to make an important new contribution to the history of strategy in the Second World War - a remarkable achievement since, as he tells us, the topic brings up 1.64 million hits on Google. A chance find in the Churchill Archives Centre in Cambridge led him to the contemporary handwritten notes of a minor official in the cabinet office, Lawrence Burgis, who illegally retained the detailed record he kept of cabinet meetings - accounts far more informative than the bland official minutes. Many other collections of private papers have also been trawled to produce this vivid and impressive story of the relations - often laden with conflict though of momentous consequence in the strategic decisions that eventually emerged - of four individuals who were crucial to the waging of the war in the West.
This splendid book centres on the question of how personality affects historical change. The answer is plain: when all account is taken of structural determinants in history, key individuals played roles that were unique and indispensable.
Ian Kershaw is a British
historian whose works include
a definitive two-volume biography of Hitler, reissued this
year in a single-volume
abridgement.
DES McANUFF
Of my readings this year I was most tempted to recommend Michael Ondaatje's Divisadero (McClelland & Stewart), his exquisitely innovative novel rivalled only by Colm Tóibín's The Master (McClelland & Stewart), a breathtaking portrait of Henry James that could have been written by the man himself. That is my sneaky way of recommending three books instead of one.
But I finally settled on Bill Bryson's brief but superb Shakespeare: The World as Stage (HarperCollins), a kind of anti-biography of the Bard. Bryson's book follows the publication of Stephen Greenblatt's Will in World , Peter Ackroyd's Shakespeare: The Biography , James Shapiro's A Year in the Life of William Shakespeare: 1599 and a slew of other books on Shakespeare published in the last few years.
Bryson's book is suitably short as he takes on the challenge of writing about how little in fact we know of Shakespeare. The few confirmed facts leave him remaining one of the great literary mysteries of history. But somehow Bryson makes this patchwork portrait absolutely satisfying by debunking all the self-interested theories that have gone into concocting the fictional figure of the great dramatic poet. Royalists, Baconists and various other theorists (who would have us believe that Shakespeare did not in fact write his own plays) all fall at Bryson's feet.
At the same time, one is left with a surprisingly clear impression of Shakespeare, in the same fashion that one can see the shape of the invisible man when he appears in a rainstorm in the old black and white film.
This is a great book - one that a reader is compelled to consume in a single sitting. I speak from experience.
Des McAnuff is artistic director of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.
JOSEPH BOYDEN
The jacket drawing of John Ralston Saul's A Fair Country (Viking Canada) is both simple and wonderfully complex. To anyone who recognizes the Anishnabek worldview of Turtle Island, the illustration is a perfect summation of Saul's thesis. Canada is, indeed, a Metis nation. Saul's carefully constructed and illuminating argument offers us a new way of viewing ourselves, an argument with roots that stretch back centuries before Confederation. Our ties to the aboriginal, Saul argues, are far stronger than our ties to the European.
Clearly, this makes some more than a touch uncomfortable, even angry, which will certainly lead to good debate. And isn't that the point of a great book? There's no denying Saul is one of our nation's most lucid, commanding and progressive thinkers.
It's the rare book that offers its readers epiphanies that are at once startling and obvious. These Aha! moments are to be cherished. A Fair Country will change the way we view ourselves as a nation.
Joseph Boyden's novel Through Black Spruce won the 2008 Scotibank Giller Prize.
JIAN GOMESHI
As a piscavore and an aspiring good-eater, Taras Grescoe turned my world around this year. His Bottomfeeder (HarperCollins) is a compelling and entertaining read. Gresoce travelled the globe for over three years in the search of an ethical seafood meal. His easiest and safest rule of thumb (er, fin) is to avoid the big predators - tuna, swordfish - in favour of those found at the bottom of the seafood chain: sardines and mackerel.
I cannot shake this book. I can no longer eat tuna because some types are almost extinct and others full of mercury. Most salmon is routinely fed with meal from ground-up carcasses. On the positive side, Grescoe says the fish in McDonald's Filet-o-Fish sandwiches is actually ethically-sound pollack. My mother used to tell me that McDonald's was nasty. Times change.

Assessments 'unrealistic,' but McGuinty won't act

Author: Lewington, Jennifer

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/assessments-unrealistic-mcguinty-wont-act/docview/382709209/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "There's nothing municipalities can do; if it's unrealistic, it's unrealistic," said Bob Topp of the Coalition After Property Tax Reform. "Some people are going to have huge increases way out of line with what their properties are now worth."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Assessments+%27unrealistic%2C%27+but+McGuinty+won%27t+act&amp;author=Lewington%2C+Jennifer&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-18&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Assessments+%27unrealistic%2C%27+but+McGuinty+won%27t+act&amp;author=Lewington%2C+Jennifer&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-18&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Municipal property assessments issued this fall are "unrealistic" given the dramatic drop in the real-estate market, Ontario Premier Dalton McGuinty admitted yesterday , but he made no move to spare homeowners across the province.
By contrast, British Columbia Premier Gordon Campbell last month announced a freeze of property assessments at 2007 levels to help people cope with the turbulence in property values, putting off new valuations until late next year.
At a year-end news conference yesterday, Mr. McGuinty instead called on municipal governments to recognize that the assessments are out of date as they prepare local property tax bills next year.
"You would hope that municipal councils would act reasonably and responsibly given the circumstances and recognize that that perhaps was an unrealistic assessment," he said.
His comments came as the market for resale homes in the Toronto area showed deeper weakness in figures released yesterday by the Toronto Real Estate Board. The average sale price in the Greater Toronto Area dropped to $360,652 in the first half of December, down from $404,707 in the same period last year. In Toronto, the number of transactions dropped to 619, a decline of 56 per cent from the same period last year.
The Premier's remarks drew fire from opposition spokesmen and taxpayer groups, while Toronto officials expressed puzzlement.
"The comments of the Premier were ridiculous and show how far out of touch he is with the experience of Ontario families in an era of declining home values," said Conservative finance critic Tim Hudak, noting the Jan. 1 assessment was based on values a year ago when prices were high.
He and others said the onus now is on the province to direct its property-assessment agency to scrap the 2008 assessment, the first in several years, and start fresh in 2009.
"There's nothing municipalities can do; if it's unrealistic, it's unrealistic," said Bob Topp of the Coalition After Property Tax Reform. "Some people are going to have huge increases way out of line with what their properties are now worth."
Opposition parties charged that the Liberal government created the problem by freezing assessments for several years prior to the 2007 Ontario election - to avoid a backlash from homeowners - and then scrapping annual assessments in favour of a four-year cycle.
"Now people are hit with what, in effect, was a three-year combination all at once that doesn't reflect current economic circumstances," New Democratic Party Leader Howard Hampton said.
In Toronto, budget chief Shelley Carroll said the city "can only act on what is," namely current data from the Municipal Property Assessment Corporation.
She added the Premier's comments "don't indicate what he intends to do about [a possible change in assessment], and only he can do something about it."
Meanwhile, she said, the city still plans a "nice, modest" property tax of between 2 and 4 per cent next year.
Mr. McGuinty dismissed suggestions about capping rates, saying his government introduced a four-year phase-in to ease the impact of assessments on homeowners.
Credit: CITY HALL BUREAU CHIEF; With files from Karen Howlett and The Canadian Press

VAN JOHNSON, 92: ACTOR

Author: Kuchwara, Michael

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/van-johnson-92-actor/docview/382680130/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Lucille tried to cheer me up, but I just couldn't seem to laugh," he oce said. "Suddenly she said to me, 'There's Billy Grady over there; he's MGM's casting director. I'm going to introduce you, and at least you're going to act like you're the star I think you will be.' "

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=VAN+JOHNSON%2C+92%3A+ACTOR&amp;author=Kuchwara%2C+Michael&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-13&amp;spage=S.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=VAN+JOHNSON%2C+92%3A+ACTOR&amp;author=Kuchwara%2C+Michael&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-13&amp;spage=S.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Wartime box-office star was the bobby soxer's heartthrob
He found stardom playing soldiers and sailors in wartime movies and then returned to Broadway 50 years after starting out there as a hoofer in a chorus line. Van Johnson's boy-next-door wholesomeness made him a popular box-office attraction in such films as 30 Seconds over Tokyo , A Guy Named Joe and The Caine Mutiny.
With his tall build, handsome, freckled face, red hair and sunny personality, he starred opposite Esther Williams, June Allyson and Elizabeth Taylor and others during 20 years under contract to MGM.
During the height of his popularity, Mr. Johnson was cast most often as the all-American boy. He played a flier who lost a leg in a crash after the bombing of Japan in 30 Seconds Over Tokyo . He was a writer in love with a wealthy American girl (Ms. Taylor) in The Last Time I Saw Paris . He appeared as a post-Civil War farmer in The Romance of Rosy Ridge .
The son of a real-estate agent, he grew up in seaside Newport. From his earliest years he was fascinated by the touring companies that played in local theatres, and after high school he announced his intention to try his luck in New York. He arrived on Broadway in 1934 with $5 and a straw suitcase.
At first he landed him nothing but chorus jobs and went to Hollywood for a bit part in the 1940 movie Too Many Girls . He was signed to a Warner Bros. contract but got dropped after making Murder in the Big House . He was about to return to New York when Lucile Ball, whom he knew on Too Many Girls , invited him to dinner.
"Lucille tried to cheer me up, but I just couldn't seem to laugh," he oce said. "Suddenly she said to me, 'There's Billy Grady over there; he's MGM's casting director. I'm going to introduce you, and at least you're going to act like you're the star I think you will be.' "
The result was a contract with MGM and a small part in The War Against Mrs. Hadley. He next appeared with Lionel Barrymore as Dr. Gillespie's New Assistant , (1942), and as Mickey Rooney's friend in The Human Comedy.
His break came with Irene Dunne and Spencer Tracy in the wartime fantasy A Guy Named Joe . It was, however, almost wiped out by tragedy.
On April 1, 1943, his DeSoto convertible was struck head-on by another car. "They tell me I was almost decapitated, but I never lost consciousness," he once recalled. "I spent four months in the hospital after they sewed the top of my head back on."
Filming was postponed for his recovery, after which MGM cashed in on his new stardom with with such titles as The White Cliffs of Dover, Two Girls and a Sailor, Weekend at the Waldorf, High Barbaree and Three Guys Named Mike .
Regarded as a heartthrob by bobby soxers - he was called "the non-singing Sinatra" - Mr. Johnson married only once. In 1947 at the height of his career, he eloped to Juarez, Mexico, to marry Eve Wynn, who had just divorced his good friend Keenan Wynn four hours before.
The marriage produced a daughter, and ended bitterly 13 years later. "She wiped me out in the ugliest divorce in Hollywood history," Mr. Johnson told reporters.
By all accounts, his wife had begun to question his gender. "I was in love with Van, but I wouldn't have married him if I'd known he was a homosexual," she told writer Scott Eyman in Lion of Hollywood , a study of studio boss Louis B. Mayer.
Mr. Johnson's vogue faded by the mid-1950s, and film roles became sparse, although he did have a comeback with Janet Leigh in 1963, Wives and Lovers .
Around that time, he returned to the stage to play Damn Yankees in summer theatres at $7,500 a week, followed by a two-year contract to star in The Music Man in London. He took the job, he said, "because the phone didn't ring. Because the film scripts were getting crummier and crummier."
For the next 30 years, he was one of the busiest stars in regional and dinner theatres, and then in 1985 he returned to Broadway in La Cage aux Folles , the hit musical.
VAN JOHNSON
Van Johnson was born Charles Van Dell Johnson in Newport, R.I., on Aug. 25, 1916. He died Dec. 12, 2008., at an assistant-living centre in Nyack, N.Y. He was 92. He leaves his daughter, Schuyler.
Credit: Associated Press

Economic storm erodes Monaco's building dreams

Author: Reguly, Eric

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/economic-storm-erodes-monacos-building-dreams/docview/382741442/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The recession rolling across Europe threatens to damage more than Monaco's development plans. The country's main annual magnet for the rich, famous and beautiful, the Monaco Grand Prix, the Formula 1 race that has run since 1929, could become a shadow of its former self as racing teams cut back. Honda just pulled out of F1 and the industry is rife with rumours that Renault of France is next.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Economic+storm+erodes+Monaco%27s+building+dreams&amp;author=Reguly%2C+Eric&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-12&amp;spage=A.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Economic+storm+erodes+Monaco%27s+building+dreams&amp;author=Reguly%2C+Eric&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-12&amp;spage=A.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Financial backing dries up for plan to expand cramped haven of the superrich onto a huge platform in the Mediterranean
Monaco's 5-per-cent solution has been diluted to nothing by the financial crisis.
The tiny, and exceedingly crowded, principality formally revealed this week that the plan to thrust the country into the sea - adding 5 per cent to its size - has been abandoned. The announcement came a day after Monaco's Prince Albert II told the news agency AFP that "In the current climate, it would be irresponsible to launch a project of this scale."
Few residents seemed surprised, or particularly upset, that the project had been cancelled. "With the financial meltdown, the Middle East consortiums that were behind this project were obviously suffering," said David Mongeau, the former CIBC mergers and acquisitions chief who is now chairman of Avington Financial. "And Monaco is a perpetual construction site. The last thing we needed was another few years of dust and dirt."
With 33,000 residents jammed into slightly less than two square kilometres, Monaco has the highest population density of any sovereign state in the world. To create elbow room, the country has had two choices: build vertically or extend its territory into the Mediterranean. In the late 1970s, it added 20 hectares - equivalent to 16 per cent of its surface area - through a sea extension called Fontvieille, now home to the AS Monaco Football Club and the International University of Monaco.
It wasn't enough. The world's rich, seeking tax-free status, kept arriving by the yacht-load and Monaco devised a second sea extension. At the end of 2006, it announced a short list of candidates to compete for the "coastal urbanization project," with an estimated cost of as much as EUR10-billion, or $16.5-billion.
The two architects who had made the competition's short list were Britain's Sir Norman Foster, who redesigned the Reichstag in Berlin, and the American Daniel Libeskind, who designed the crystal at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto. No fewer than five development and construction consortiums were in the running, including Qatar's Barwa Real Estate, whose partners included Canadian engineering firm SNC-Lavalin.
Albert's environmental concerns ensured that the project, covering 275,000 square metres, would be an epic engineering feat. The Prince, who was the opening speaker at last week's UN Environmental Program conference on migratory species in Rome, did not want to fill the water with rubble to make the peninsula.
The idea instead was to make a one-kilometre raised platform, resting on pontoons and blocks up to 50 metres deep.
The project's cancellation was partly due to environmental worries. "I would in any case want to ensure myself that the effects on the environment would be as limited as possible," he told AFP.
The recession rolling across Europe threatens to damage more than Monaco's development plans. The country's main annual magnet for the rich, famous and beautiful, the Monaco Grand Prix, the Formula 1 race that has run since 1929, could become a shadow of its former self as racing teams cut back. Honda just pulled out of F1 and the industry is rife with rumours that Renault of France is next. If several teams pull out, the Monaco race, the F1 circuit's most glamorous event, will lose much of its appeal.
Another problem is the yachting crowd. Monaco has always been the Mediterranean's top harbour for the superrich and their superyachts. Recently, the yachting market has been propelled by Russian millionaires and billionaires. They are shedding wealth quickly and the harbour could look at lot less cluttered next summer.
The good news for the locals is that fewer millionaires milling around might translate into lower prices for everything from champagne to condos.
"Its hugely expensive living here," Mr. Mongeau said.

Homeowners in search of cold comfort

Author: Holmes, Mike

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/homeowners-search-cold-comfort/docview/382679410/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: I think it's the best possible insulation on the market - no question. Spray foam is effective over all at creating that complete thermal break in the building envelope. It covers everything, so there's no possibility of cold spots, voids or settling. There is no air movement between outside and inside, so there's no possibility of condensation and, since it's inorganic it won't allow for mould growth.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Homeowners+in+search+of+cold+comfort&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-12&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Homeowners+in+search+of+cold+comfort&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-12&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: With so much to choose from, materials have to be judged on their merits
I talk a lot about insulation - that's because it's important. Good insulation is absolutely key to reduced energy costs and better indoor air quality.
I recently had an e-mail from Becky asking about what insulation to use when building a new home. She'd prefer to not use fibreglass, and instead use the most natural, "healthiest" material.
What do we mean by "healthy"? Are we talking "healthy" from an indoor air point of view? Or healthy for the earth - as in green production and installation? All types of insulation - if you consider they cut down on energy use - are "green," but some are better than others.
For an insulation to be "good," it needs to give you energy savings. It needs to be inorganic so it won't allow for mould growth. It can't absorb moisture or it'll compress and lose its ability to insulate. And it shouldn't harm your indoor air quality with minute particles that circulate through the heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems.
Insulation is measured in "R-value" - that is the material's resistance to heat loss. The higher the number, the better the material insulates. The building code specifies the minimum R-value for attics and walls. But R-value alone won't tell you what is the best insulation. Heat loss is just one factor to consider.
The real concern is air movement. You might have R-40 insulation in your attic, but if you have air leakage because of a poor vapour barrier, you will have problems - problems with heat loss and with condensation.
BATT INSULATION
This comes in blanket-like pieces that are placed between the studs of your walls. Most often it's made from fibreglass or mineral wool.
I've also used blue jean insulation. It's made from recycled denim jeans that have been treated with Borax. It's "green and clean," but really hard to find since there aren't many manufacturers of it around.
Batt insulation must not be compressed, since the trapped air in the fibreglass or mineral wool adds to the insulation value. Crush it or squeeze it into a cavity and you lose R-value.
I don't know how "healthy" fibreglass or mineral wool is. I don't think I'd like to breathe it, based on how itchy it is when it gets on your skin or into your eyes. Particles of batt insulation can negatively impact your indoor air quality.
LOOSE FILL
This comes in fibreglass and mineral wool, as well as cellulose. Loose fill or blown insulation needs to be applied by a professional. The installer has to do it right - blowing it evenly and to the right depth. I don't know how often I've seen loose fill insulation that's been blown randomly into an attic space, covering all the soffit vents and cutting off the ventilation in the attic. This is a huge problem, and it can lead to ice dams and the deterioration of your roof.
RIGID INSULATION
I use rigid all the time in basements. It's a great product for that use. The polystyrene foam board is strong and provides the thermal break you need on basement floors and walls to eliminate the condensation that leads to mould.
Rigid insulation is non-organic, doesn't hold moisture and isn't a food source for mould.
SPRAY FOAM
I'm a huge fan of closed-cell spray foam insulation. It wins on all counts - energy efficiency, indoor air quality and environmentally. It's also its own vapour barrier (though you should check with local municipalities. Some inspectors still want to insist on a vapour barrier, though they shouldn't.)
There are two main kinds of spray foam - polyicynene and polyurethane. Both must be applied by a specialized installer. Some CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons) are used in production and they off-gas for a time after application. All spray foam insulation is now being changed over to use eco-friendly propellants.
I think it's the best possible insulation on the market - no question. Spray foam is effective over all at creating that complete thermal break in the building envelope. It covers everything, so there's no possibility of cold spots, voids or settling. There is no air movement between outside and inside, so there's no possibility of condensation and, since it's inorganic it won't allow for mould growth.
Walltite ECO is newest development in spray foam. You've seen me using the blue spray foam (it's now purple, and it's better). The formulation includes recycled plastic, renewable content, and the blowing agent is zero-ozone depleting.
Walltite Eco is the first closed-cell spray foam insulation to have EcoLogo certification - the most widely recognized third-party audit and environmental certification. So, for my money, it's the most healthy, effective and environmentally friendly insulation out there.
Mike Holmes is the host of Holmes on Homes on HGTV. For more information, go to www.holmesonhomes.com
Credit: mikeholmes@holmesonhomes.com

Deft remake puts loan shark Scrooge on a London housing estate

Author: Taylor, Kate

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/deft-remake-puts-loan-shark-scrooge-on-london/docview/382680146/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Can conservation tourism hasten that day? CNN also unearths one inspiring story of ecotourism, explaining how a recovering Rwanda is now making strenuous efforts to save its mountain gorillas, thanks in part to tourism dollars. On the other hand, the thrill of cage diving, in which tourists pay to see great white sharks up close from the security of a cage attached to the side of a boat, is controversial.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Deft+remake+puts+loan+shark+Scrooge+on+a+London+housing+estate&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Kate&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-11&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Deft+remake+puts+loan+shark+Scrooge+on+a+London+housing+estate&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Kate&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-11&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: To judge from 19th-century texts such as A Christmas Carol , the Victorians did a bit of shopping on Christmas Eve and then took a single day off to celebrate a holiday they marked with one special meal and a few small gifts. At our house, the four-year-old pasted a lengthy wish list to the fridge weeks ago and the tree went up last weekend. The local supermarket has had its decorations up since November and, with two whole weeks to go until Christmas, the television schedule is awash with holiday programming. You can navigate your way around the carol concerts and Christmas movies yourself, but I will draw your attention to A Christmas Carol (VisionTV, 9 p.m.) because it is a rather clever update of the classic that easily moves the morality tale to an impoverished housing estate in contemporary London.
Eddie Scrooge (Ross Kemp of EastEnders ) is the local loan shark who is spending Christmas Eve rebuffing a pair of begging street kids, repossessing a single mum's TV set, collecting his weekly payment from a couple of arthritic pensioners who can't save enough to buy a stair lift and declining his nephew's dinner invitation as he dismisses Christmas as the day "the stupid and the bone idle join forces to celebrate the birth of catalogue shopping." He does at least agree to give his bookkeeper Cratchit the afternoon off so he can spend it in hospital with a son who has cystic fibrosis.
Scrooge is soon visited by the ghost of his business partner, Jacob Marley (Ray Fearon of Coronation Street ), who was recently gunned down in a stairwell, and warned to expect more visitors. The Ghost of Christmas Past - Scrooge's old dad pops up on the TV screen - takes him back first to his sorry childhood and then to the day exactly a year before when his girlfriend, a nurse in the local emergency room, dumped him because she could not stand his job. (The only new plot line here is a romantic one as the reformed Scrooge tries to win her back.) Marley reappears to show him Christmas Present in the shape of the small holiday joys experienced by the single mum and the pensioners on the one hand, and the perilous condition of the street kids on the other. And finally a mysterious, silent child appears to show Scrooge his own cold and lonely death.
The deftest part of this remake, written by Peter Bowker and directed by Catherine Morshead, is the way it twists the time-travel device à la Groundhog Day so that Scrooge keeps repeating the events of Christmas Eve over and over - from the repossessed TV set and a suddenly collapsing stack of Christmas trees to the rescue of the street kids - until he finally gets it right. The ending is, of course, moralistic and sentimental, entirely in keeping with the ghostly original.
For real chills, try considering instead the prospect of zoonotics, animal viruses that can infect humans and do so at growing rates because of population density, global travel and the increased hunting of bush meat due to rising food prices. Tonight, CNN is delivering this year's instalment of Planet in Peril: Battle Lines (CNN, 9 p.m.), concentrating this time on the tension between humans and wildlife, and the four-segment news documentary opens with its scariest tale. Anchor Anderson Cooper and medical correspondent Sanjay Gupta follow this really alarming story to Cameroon and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where, among other places, they visit a community that has been infected with the sometimes-fatal monkey pox, probably through contact with the animal's blood when it was being butchered.
The good news here comes in the form of Nathan Wolfe, a dedicated epidemiologist who is tracking such contact on the principle that if you can recognize viruses quickly, it may be possible to stop another HIV from spreading. Impressively, all the hunters CNN encounters in the bush are taking blood samples from their kills to pass on to his research project.
The program then follows broadcast journalist Lisa Ling from Costa Rica to Taiwan as she tracks the legal and illegal fishing of sharks solely so their fins can be used for soup in Chinese restaurants. (The still-living finless bodies are sometimes dumped back into the sea to sink to the bottom and die.) It looks like only a matter of time before a public relations campaign for the fish would make the ecologically disastrous delicacy verboten.
Can conservation tourism hasten that day? CNN also unearths one inspiring story of ecotourism, explaining how a recovering Rwanda is now making strenuous efforts to save its mountain gorillas, thanks in part to tourism dollars. On the other hand, the thrill of cage diving, in which tourists pay to see great white sharks up close from the security of a cage attached to the side of a boat, is controversial. Alarmed South African surfers allege the practice of chumming - attracting the sharks by trailing blood and bait in the water - is training them to equate humans with food. Interestingly, a researcher interviewed here says she finds no evidence that chumming is making the sharks more aggressive, and the story feels slim compared with the other three. You have to wonder if it made the cut mainly because Cooper, accompanied by a tour operator who regularly swims unprotected with the sharks, decides to go diving for his viewers without benefit of the cage.
Check local listings.
John Doyle returns on Tuesday.

Montreal not content to contain itself

Author: Loverseed, Helga

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/montreal-not-content-contain-itself/docview/382682488/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "In our business, there's often a time lag between supply and demand," explains Serge Dubreuil, president of Logistec Stevedoring Inc., one of the largest cargo-handling companies at the Port of Montreal. "We've noticed a drop, for example, in the export of recycled paper. It was going to China to be turned into packaging but now that the demand for Chinese-made goods has weakened, the demand for the paper has gone down as well."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Montreal+not+content+to+contain+itself&amp;author=Loverseed%2C+Helga&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-09&amp;spage=B.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Montreal+not+content+to+contain+itself&amp;author=Loverseed%2C+Helga&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-09&amp;spage=B.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: This major shipping gateway has a $2.5-billion, long-term plan to handle a bigger share of international trade
The global economy might be slowing down and with it international trade, but so far it is having little effect on the Port of Montreal - one of the main North American gateways for goods transiting Eastern Canada and the U.S. Midwest.
Container traffic is particularly strong: Preliminary data compiled by the Washington-based American Association of Port Authorities show that for the first eight months of this year, container traffic through Montreal grew 10.1 per cent from a year earlier.
Not only is the port thriving, it is upgrading and expanding its facilities for anticipated growth, having launched a $2.5-billion infrastructure project - Vision 2020 - that will unfold over the next 12 years with a goal, among others, of tripling the port's container capacity to the equivalent of 4.5 million 20-foot container units.
"We're running out of space," says Patrice Pelletier, president and chief executive officer of the Montreal Port Authority (MPA). "The effects of the economic downturn could impact us in 2009, but these downturns are always cyclical and we want to be ready when the markets start coming back.
"We have to keep looking ahead," he adds. "This is a long-term project. Let's face it, people aren't going to stop eating or buying things that they need for the house."
The port, which is open year-round, sprawls along 25 kilometres of Montreal's waterfront. The downtown complex comprises four container terminals, 15 transit sheds for non-containerized general cargo (steel, forest products, food) and dry bulk (fertilizer, sugar, copper, road salt), storage space for 15 million barrels of liquid bulk (petroleum products) and a terminal capable of holding 260,000 tonnes of grain.
Vision 2020 is being implemented in four phases, of which the first is already under way. The first two will streamline and reorganize existing infrastructure - remodelling old buildings, utilizing empty parking lots, converting underutilized spaces into container terminals and so on.
Phases 3 and 4 will see the building of new terminals, either in Montreal East or at Contrecoeur, 40 kilometres down the St. Lawrence Seaway, to expand container capacity. The exact location and financing are yet to be worked out.
According to Mr. Pelletier, part of the $2.5-billion financing will come from the private sector, as well as the port's own reserves, with $450-million to $650-million expected to be provided by the federal government. He points out that infrastructure projects of this size are typically financed over many years and thus have little exposure to short-term fluctuations in the market.
"We're taking an attitude of prudent optimism," Mr. Pelletier says. "We know that we must build on the essential infrastructure because it's important for the future development of Canada, not just Montreal."
Once completed in 2020, the port's makeover is expected to create 41,000 jobs and generate $3.4-billion in revenue, officials say. That doesn't include construction: Phases 1, 2 and 3 alone are expected to generate $740-million in gross domestic product and 10,000 jobs, they say. The port's activities and related spinoffs already account for 18,200 jobs, either directly or indirectly across the country; in 2007, MPA's profit was $8.4-million on operating revenue of $81.7-million.
Contributing to the Port of Montreal's profit is revenue from the cruise industry. Part of the port complex includes Alexandra Pier, a cruise ship terminal, which, along with the rest of the port, is slated for redevelopment. The berths are close to downtown and cruise passengers can walk into the heart of Old Montreal with its many tourist attractions, but the MPA, taking its cue from other cruise destinations, want them to linger and spend money in the port area.
At present, there is little to induce anybody to hang around the terminal buildings, which are basically a couple of unprepossessing sheds. Future plans under Vision 2020, however, include constructing a modern recreational and tourism complex with boutiques, restaurants, entertainment venues and the like, to create an attractive destination both for out-of-towners and for local residents.
Determining the exact footprint of that area of the waterfront will be decided next year, according to Mr. Pelletier. The timing is good. Cruise traffic along the St. Lawrence River is growing. This year, 25 cruise ships carrying 32,100 passengers called at the port, and based on forward bookings, 2,000 more passengers are scheduled to arrive in 2009. The revamped Alexandra Pier is expected to attract many thousands more.
In the meantime, while the Port of Montreal is enjoying a bumper year, cargo shipments might slow in 2009. Fluctuations in the rates of exchange between the Canadian dollar and other currencies affect the levels of international trade. Moreover, there tends to be a delayed reaction to the ups and downs of an economy and the flow of goods.
"In our business, there's often a time lag between supply and demand," explains Serge Dubreuil, president of Logistec Stevedoring Inc., one of the largest cargo-handling companies at the Port of Montreal. "We've noticed a drop, for example, in the export of recycled paper. It was going to China to be turned into packaging but now that the demand for Chinese-made goods has weakened, the demand for the paper has gone down as well."
"That being said, we've picked up business from other regions of the world, such as South America, where some economies are still growing and, right now, our cargo terminals are at capacity.
"From our point of view, an expansion to the port is well overdue. We have to look ahead, well beyond what is happening right now."
*****
Fraught with freight
The Port of Montreal's success, in the face of economic malaise, in large part hinges on that old real estate adage - location, location, location.
It's healthy cargo traffic is a result of its geographical position and the speed with which it can process goods coming to and from the almost 90 countries with which it does business. Cargo shipped via Montreal from Germany, for example, takes just less than 10 days to reach Chicago, compared with almost 12 days via New York. Because Montreal is so far inland - 1,600 kilometres from the Atlantic coast - it has the edge over many of its Eastern Seaboard competitors.
An integrated transport and distribution system also contributes to the port's competitive edge. The Montreal Port Authority owns 100 kilometres of railway (including rolling stock) that connect to its berths and terminals and which, in turn, feed into the networks of the two major Canadian railways. Moreover, the port's customer base is fairly diversified.
It is not reliant on one major market such as the United States or China - two of the countries most affected by the current economic meltdown - and imports and exports are almost equally balanced, with 55 per cent of goods leaving Canada and 45 per cent coming in. Helga Loverseed
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

____________________________________________________________

Tribune girds for possible bankruptcy filing

Author: Berman, Dennis K; Ovide, Shira; Karnitschnig, Matthew

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/tribune-girds-possible-bankruptcy-filing/docview/382745511/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: One of Tribune's most pressing concerns: By the end of the year, the company is likely to be in violation of debt terms that limit borrowings to nine times its adjusted profits. The ratio stood at 8.3 at the end of the second quarter, before Tribune reported an 83-per-cent decline in operating profit for the three months ended Sept 28.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Tribune+girds+for+possible+bankruptcy+filing&amp;author=Berman%2C+Dennis+K%3BOvide%2C+Shira%3BKarnitschnig%2C+Matthew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-08&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Tribune+girds+for+possible+bankruptcy+filing&amp;author=Berman%2C+Dennis+K%3BOvide%2C+Shira%3BKarnitschnig%2C+Matthew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-12-08&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Tribune Co. is preparing for a possible filing for bankruptcy court protection as soon as this week, according to people familiar with the matter, in another sign of trouble for the newspaper industry.
In recent days, as Tribune continued talks with lenders to restructure its debt, the newspaper-and-television concern hired Lazard Ltd. as its financial adviser, as well as legal counsel for a possible trip through bankruptcy court, according to people familiar with the matter.
A Tribune spokesman said the firm doesn't comment on rumours or speculation. Tribune owns eight major daily newspapers, including the Los Angeles Times, Chicago Tribune and Baltimore Sun, and a string of local TV stations.
A spokesman for investment bank Lazard didn't respond to a request for comment.
Tribune's actions underscore the distress enveloping newspaper publishers. Their businesses are being battered by dwindling advertising sales, and they are carrying debt loads that are unmanageable under current market conditions. Insiders expect some papers will need to fold or seek protection from creditors to reorganize in coming months.
Tribune has been on wobbly footing since last December, when real-estate mogul Samuel Zell led a debt-backed deal to take it private. Tribune so far has stayed ahead of its $12-billion (U.S.) in borrowings with the help of asset sales. Now, however, dwindling profits are tightening the noose.
The company's cash flow may not be enough to cover nearly $1-billion in interest payments due this year, and Tribune owes a $512-million debt payment in June.
One of Tribune's most pressing concerns: By the end of the year, the company is likely to be in violation of debt terms that limit borrowings to nine times its adjusted profits. The ratio stood at 8.3 at the end of the second quarter, before Tribune reported an 83-per-cent decline in operating profit for the three months ended Sept 28.
Violations of such debt covenants have become commonplace for newspaper companies as profits have ebbed in recent months. Lenders so far have been willing to give the companies a pass in exchange for higher interest rates and other concessions, but Tribune has little wiggle room. Terms of the company's debt already are so loose and its financial standing so unsteady that a covenant waiver may not help.
To be sure, a restructuring outside of bankruptcy court remains an option for Tribune. Executives have indicated previously that the debt talks are amicable, and it remains possible the two sides can agree to rework the firm's borrowings on their own, as other newspaper publishers are doing.
Tribune's hiring of Lazard, meanwhile, brings it a firm experienced in debt restructuring, and one that has become a go-to adviser for newspaper firms in financial distress.
Even as its financial performance worsens, Tribune has some options. A sale of its Chicago Cubs baseball team is under way, and Tribune owns valuable stakes in businesses including the cable TV channel Food Network.
Tribune already has auctioned off pieces of the company, including the Long Island, N.Y., daily Newsday to raise cash. Now, however, frozen credit markets have depressed sale prices. Selling off more newspapers may not be a viable option because buyers are scarce and Tribune may be better off holding onto the profits from its papers.
Credit: Wall Street Journal

We wish you a merry giftmas

Now, she's getting the retrospective treatment at Manhattan's New Museum of Contemporary Art, and this is the companion volume to that show (which closes Jan. 11).
