Bilingual degree reflects spirit of Montreal

Author: Fine, Philip

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bilingual-degree-reflects-spirit-montreal/docview/382685032/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: One of the program's two academic directors, HEC's Louis Hebert, had been lecturing at the Richard Ivey School of Business when he was approached by HEC Montreal to manage an EMBA program. He wanted the venture to reflect Montreal society and to do that, he said "bilingualism was a must," adding that a two-language program reflects the city's life.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bilingual+degree+reflects+spirit+of+Montreal&amp;author=Fine%2C+Philip&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-18&amp;spage=E.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bilingual+degree+reflects+spirit+of+Montreal&amp;author=Fine%2C+Philip&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-18&amp;spage=E.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Rather than compete in a limited market, two universities join forces in a win-win program for business leaders
The new McGill-HEC Montreal EMBA, in many ways, resembles a Montreal conversation. Just as the bilingual francophone and anglophone will jump from one language to the other, the new joint program between McGill University and the école des Hautes études Commerciales de Montreal will provide a lecture in French one day, a guest speaker in English another, and discussions, projects and exams in the language in which the student or professor feels more comfortable.
One of the program's two academic directors, HEC's Louis Hebert, had been lecturing at the Richard Ivey School of Business when he was approached by HEC Montreal to manage an EMBA program. He wanted the venture to reflect Montreal society and to do that, he said "bilingualism was a must," adding that a two-language program reflects the city's life.
It was the relatively small international market for EMBA programs that convinced Dr. Hebert in 2003 that his school needed to team up with McGill's Desautel Faculty of Management.
"There were too many risks that we would end up as two competitors," said Dr. Hebert, who said local recruitment would also be at risk, since both schools keep in contact with many of the same companies from where students can be drawn.
For HEC Montreal, a joint program with the anglophone university would offer them access to the wider English-speaking market and allow them to use the teachings of internationally known management expert Henry Mintzberg. McGill, through its new affiliation with HEC, would be more in touch with the francophone business sector and have access to an institution that counts 260 faculty members, a giant when compared to its 60 professors.
Dr. Hebert, who actually wrote his thesis on joint ventures in the corporate sector, saw that the mismatches in the two institutions would have to be smoothed out. HEC Montreal is a self-standing institution with a Université de Montreal affiliation, while Desautel is essentially a faculty within a university.
In 2004, senior administrators, including the dean of Desautel, were quickly on board and by 2005 a memorandum of understanding was signed and, then, this September the first classes began.
Professors and students must be comfortable in both English and French, and courses are taught usually in the mother tongue of the professor.
For Jan Schoningh and Michèle Meier, two students enrolled in this debut year of the 15-month program, being able to speak in the language in which they're most comfortable makes perfect sense. Ms. Meier says it's very freeing, while Mr. Schoningh calls the idea of a bilingual EMBA "very open-minded."
McGill's Alain Pinsonneault, the program's other academic director, appropriately enough for his role in this two-university program, earned an MSc degree from HEC and taught there from 1990-99 before moving to McGill. The joint program gives students that same type of dual affiliation, offering diploma seals from both McGill and HEC Montreal.
The average age of the students is 42, with work experience averaging 18 years. Half the 36 enrolled students hold the role of VP in their organizations.
That type of experience is something that Mr. Schöningh appreciates and what helped draw the former hotel manager and now vice-president of development at real estate company Homburg Canada Inc. to the program.
"In a classroom with people who are 27 or 28 years old, even if they're super smart, it does not replace 10 to 15 years of management experience."
The fees for the program are $65,000, prompting the 43-year-old Mr. Schoningh to remark that some men who hit middle age often buy a sports car, while he bought himself time in an EMBA program. Joking aside, he says he looked long and hard for something that would give him more depth than the summer programs in which he had previously enrolled and put him in the same room with people who had real-life business experiences.
The program offers four-day modules every month, from Thursday to Sunday, with two residential modules of 7 and 10 days. The second residential module takes place abroad in either Latin America or Asia.
Ms. Meier, 37, general manager of corporate affairs at Groupe Aeroplan, calls the monthly four-day modules a "brilliant compromise" since she could not imagine herself finding the time to tackle a four-year degree.
"It's a way to find a balance between family, work and school."
Participation is key. Students must bring real work issues into class and must apply what they learn in the "real world" to implement change in the workplace. That means students bring their experience to class and then bring their lessons to work.
One of the ways that's done is through shadowing. Students pair off and shadow each other during five-day visits to each other's workplace. It is a two-fold exercise in which participants get feedback from their observer, and observers reflect on themselves as they observe.
The program uses faculty from both McGill and HEC Montreal as well as guest lecturers, one recent one being Power Corporation's Paul Desmarais.
*****
DEGREES CAN BE BI-NATIONAL, TOO
While its bilingual nature makes the McGill - HEC Montreal EMBA unique, it's not the only joint Executive MBA program in the country. Three others in Canada not only bring two or more universities together, they also bring two or more countries together.
NYU Stern-LSE-HEC Paris
New York University Leonard N. Stern School of Business, the London School of Economics and Political Science and the HEC School of Management Paris teamed up in 2000 to create the TRIUM Global Executive MBA. Aimed at senior executives, it combines business with socioeconomic and political context. TRIUM students participate in six intensive modules, held at NYU Stern, LSE and HEC Paris, as well as in two international locations chosen annually for their relevance to current global business issues.
Cornell-Queen's
Cornell-Queen's Executive MBA has Queen's School of Business and the Johnson School at Cornell University in New York combining forces. The 18-month program gives the student the chance to earn both a Queen's and a Cornell MBA. The program is offered in five Canadian cities and 12 in the U.S. Upon completion, Canadian graduates have the option to work in the U.S. for one year, with the possibility of extending their visa status.
Kellogg-Schulich
The Kellogg-Schulich EMBA program brings together the Schulich School of Business at York University and the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. It is North America's first cross-border executive MBA. Officially launched in January, 2002, the Kellogg-Schulich EMBA has classes at both schools, with the option of studying abroad at several partner institutions.
Philip Fine

BURGLED!: How did they get in?

Author: Cheney, Peter

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/burgled-how-did-they-get/docview/382683129/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Like many wealthy people, the Bronfmans have a high-end security system with live monitoring. The security firm was Avante, which provides everything from video surveillance to highly specialized services: When an Avante client goes on vacation, company staff take them to the airport, then pick up their mail and newspapers every day, to reduce the number of people who know that they are not home.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BURGLED%21%3A+How+did+they+get+in%3F&amp;author=Cheney%2C+Peter&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-15&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BURGLED%21%3A+How+did+they+get+in%3F&amp;author=Cheney%2C+Peter&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-15&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: How did thieves sneak $1-million worth of jewellery and a 100-kilogram safe out of the Bronfman mansion? Peter Cheney makes like a cat burglar and prowls for answers
The online crime map of Toronto looks like something from CSI : Digitized visuals are dotted with small yellow marks, each indicating the scene of a burglary in the past week. Some communities look like yellow pincushions, but not south Forest Hill, where monitored alarm systems, video surveillance and private security guards are the order of the day.
This week, a rare yellow dot appeared on the neighbourhood's online map.
Behind that dot is a unique criminal saga that has raised the hackles of some very wealthy people and shown just how far an enterprising thief can go. Last Saturday, some time between 7:30 and 10:30 p.m., a burglar (or burglars) made their way to the home of Paul and Judy Bronfman, scaled a wall, got through a second-storey window and made off with a safe that contained more than $1-million in jewellery.
The haul included a flawless, six-carat diamond and two Stanley Cup rings won by the Montreal Canadiens in the 1970s (the Bronfman family used to be part owners of the team). Although many burglaries aren't even reported, let alone investigated, the Bronfman case is getting the full-court press.
Toronto police have assigned detectives from the major crimes unit, and the Bronfman family has retained a high-powered private investigator who was formerly assigned to the Toronto homicide squad.
The Bronfman robbery raises serious questions about what the rich (and the rest of us) can do to protect ourselves from burglary. Crime researchers say there were 8,774 reported burglaries Toronto-wide last year.
The actual number would be far higher because some victims either can't be bothered to report the event or are concerned that it will raise their insurance premiums.
There are many factors that raise your chances of being robbed. Being rich is one of them. Although they are known as very private people, the Bronfmans' sheer wealth puts them on the radar of prospective thieves.
Mr. Bronfman is prominent in the Canadian film industry and is the scion of one of Canada's richest families. His father and uncle founded Brascan Corp., one of the country's most powerful conglomerates. Mr. Bronfman and his wife live in a 22,000-square-foot home on a closed street in Toronto's elite Forest Hill district. They have three children, aged 17, 19, and 21, and attend a large number of philanthropic functions; two nights before the burglary, they were at an awards dinner hosted by the Canadian Coalition of Christians and Jews.
For a high-end thief, couples like the Bronfmans become a criminal research project. "These aren't your average thieves," says Chris McGoey, an L.A.-based security expert whose clients include prosperous business people and celebrities. "These people knew what they were looking for."
Mr. McGoey has consulted on a long series of similar, targeted robberies in the U.S. Some have involved well-known celebrities who lost millions in jewellery and artwork. In almost all cases, Mr. McGoey says, the crimes were committed with inside knowledge that allowed thieves to defeat elaborate security systems and locate the most valuable items without delay.
Like many wealthy people, the Bronfmans have a high-end security system with live monitoring. The security firm was Avante, which provides everything from video surveillance to highly specialized services: When an Avante client goes on vacation, company staff take them to the airport, then pick up their mail and newspapers every day, to reduce the number of people who know that they are not home. Avante chief executive officer Manny Mounouchos says thieves can pick up information from countless sources. "A limo driver might mention that he took them to the airport, and the word goes out," he says. "The more people who know what you're doing, the less security you have."
Mr. Mounouchos says his company's security systems use the best technology in the business. They don't come cheap: Avante recently quoted a $400,000 security system for one Toronto homeowner, and the company's most popular monitoring package runs approximately $4,200 a year.
Police sources say the Bronfmans' security system included door and window contacts, glass-break and motion sensors, and an array of remote-controlled video cameras. The entire system was connected to Avante by a wireless link that would send an alarm signal directly to a BlackBerry in one of the company's dispatch vehicles. But on the night of the Bronfman robbery, all of this technology was rendered useless because the alarm was deactivated.
Although police won't say why the system wasn't on, sources familiar with the investigation say the Bronfmans and their children had gone out for the evening, but staff members were in the home at the time of the robbery.
"Nobody heard a thing," said Toronto police detective Frank Lazzaro, an investigator assigned to the case.
Although investigators refused to disclose details, sources say members of the Bronfman household staff have been questioned about the robbery. (None of the staff has been implicated or identified as suspects.)
Police are also canvassing pawn shops and known jewellery fences. Detective Liz Benoit of the major crimes unit said the high-profile nature of the jewellery stolen from the Bronfmans may lead to it being channelled to underground collectors. It may also be broken down, she said, so that the precious stones are less identifiable.
"We're considering every option," she said.
Police say there is little doubt that the robbery involved extensive planning. Other crime experts agree. "This is anything but a standard break and enter," says Irvin Waller, a criminology professor at the University of Ottawa who has studied the crime of burglary extensively. Prof. Waller has written several books, including one that examined robbery patterns in the city of Toronto.
As part of his research, Prof. Waller went to Canadian prisons to interview convicted thieves, and came away with a picture of a sharply divided criminal world. At one end of the spectrum was the garden-variety break-in artist, who typically came away with a DVD player, some cheap jewellery or, if he was lucky, some cash - the only robbery commodity that fetches 100 per cent of its nominal value.
At the other end of the spectrum was the rare and elusive professional burglar. Prof. Waller said these burglars reminded him of airline pilots, with a professional attitude and an expert sense of risk. Many had spent years studying building construction and alarm systems, and followed workout routines and diets that kept them in peak physical condition. To avoid jittery fingers, some avoided alcohol and caffeine for several days before a robbery.
"They were professionals," Prof. Waller said. "There was nothing careless about them." Despite the Bronfmans' efforts to keep a low profile, there are numerous people familiar with their home and routine, including household staff, maintenance workers, and construction workers employed on the lot next to their house.
"It's hard to imagine all the sources of information," Prof. Waller says. "The word goes out."
High-end burglars employ techniques that would amaze many homeowners. Blane Nordahl, an American burglar who specialized in robbing silverware in the Hamptons, Kennebunkport and other old-money enclaves, read Architectural Digest and the Robb Report to identify targets. He also went on guided tours of historic homes and contacted local real-estate agents, posing as a wealthy prospective buyer.
Mr. Nordahl committed hundreds of robberies, and was able to evade detection by a wide array of alarm systems, including motion detectors. He was also noted for his foresight when it came to forensics. To avoid leaving fingerprints, he wore cotton gloves. After a telltale footprint gave away his identity to police, he began wearing different sizes of shoes on every job, and disposing of them immediately.
Whether that level of criminal ingenuity was brought to the Bronfman robbery remains to be determined. Forensic unit officers have examined the scene, but police haven't indicated what evidence, if any, was found.
The stolen jewellery was stored in a Gardex safe on the second floor. The safe, which weighed an estimated 100 kilograms, was removed from the scene, and has not been recovered.
"My feeling is that it's an inside job," a police source said. "Someone knew something."
*****
How not to get robbed:
Tips from the experts
* Don't feature your home in architecture or lifestyle magazines. Some thieves read them to scout locations.
* Don't tell people you're going on vacation.
* Hire a securities expert while you're away to minimize proof of your absence.
* Apply security laminate film to your windows. This prevents a burglar from cutting or breaking the glass to open the window.
* Install bars on main-floor windows.
* Install solid-core or metal doors at all entrance points.
* Equip doors with heavy-duty deadbolt locks with a one-inch throw bolt and reinforced strike plates with three-inch screws that penetrate into the wooden door frame.
Peter Cheney

Chinatown reno adds a splash of daring

Author: Gold, Kerry

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/chinatown-reno-adds-splash-daring/docview/382745105/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We're only selling three units, and there's really no competition," he shrugs, seated in a Chinese bakery next to the site. "What I'm offering is really unique. So I'm not really competing with the other sellers in the city. No one else has done it."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Chinatown+reno+adds+a+splash+of+daring&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-14&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Chinatown+reno+adds+a+splash+of+daring&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-14&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Clear-bottom penthouse pool will provide dinner-time entertainment
The market timing might seem off, but the first luxury condos are arriving in Vancouver's working class Chinatown.
If all goes according to plan, by the summer of 2009, developer Cam Watt's vision for the high-end, $6-million restoration of the nearly 100-year-old Keefer Building will be realized.
Architects George Sharp and Charles Thompson built the Edwardian style building at 135 Keefer St. in 1910. The architects were most famous for designing Vancouver's landmark art deco Burrard Street Bridge. The warehouse originally built for the Vancouver Gas Company is currently undergoing a massive restoration that will combine its heritage façade with a sleek, contemporary wood-brick interior.
The four-storey building on the 25-foot-wide lot will be given an additional top floor and converted into four deluxe lofts, each occupying an entire floor. A large, pre-existing courtyard that runs up the east side of the building has made it possible to construct condos that are open to daylight, with optional patio access on each floor. On the bottom floor will be retail, including a small martini bar that will cater to the area's growing young condo market.
As to whether he's worried about the current real estate downturn, Mr. Watt - who plans to occupy the opulent penthouse of the Keefer Building - appears unfazed.
"We're only selling three units, and there's really no competition," he shrugs, seated in a Chinese bakery next to the site. "What I'm offering is really unique. So I'm not really competing with the other sellers in the city. No one else has done it."
The price range of the 2,400-sq.-ft. apartments is $1.69-million to $3.9-million, a price tag that reflects features such as private indoor/outdoor courtyards, a unique elevator car storage that operates by remote control, private elevators to the suites, and a penthouse unit that has a 40-foot-long, clear-bottom swimming pool. The roof-top pool was designed by the same Colorado company that made the water tank in which stunt artist David Blaine submerged himself for seven days a couple of years ago.
Inside the penthouse suite, the clear-bottom rooftop pool will operate like a massive overhead display, particularly when someone is swimming in it.
Mr. Watt, whose company is Two By Four Developments, got the idea for the pool from a friend. Architects, a structural engineer, and a local pool designer spent three months researching the possibility. The cost of the acrylic pool, including shipping, was $80,000. But that price tag was trifling compared with having to negotiate with the city for their plans for the first interior clear-bottom pool.
"There is nothing going across the pool to hold it up," explains project architect Chris Woodford. "There's a really big steel beam that runs down its sides and it kind of hangs there. For a residential application, this is not done often, or ever."
The cost of the two-level, four-car elevator was approximately $140,000, which isn't as expensive as underground parking, Mr. Watt points out. As well, says Mr. Woodford, it keeps extra cars off the crowded streets of Chinatown.
The Keefer is Mr. Watt's first condo development. He is a house developer and successful entrepreneur who co-founded the Canadian Springs bottled water company.
He commissioned architect Gair Williamson, who has spent most of his career in London, England, but earlier in his career designed Toronto's Princess of Wales Theatre.
He has already worked on several heritage buildings in the area, but none of them, he says, are as high-end as The Keefer.
Mr. Williamson says the project is about saving a heritage building that had stood vacant, filled with pigeon feces, and rotting for the last decade. He says it's not about gentrifying an area that has long been filled with single-room occupants, which is an ongoing concern in the impoverished and struggling downtown eastside. (The project was undertaken with incentives from the city's Heritage Building Rehabilitation Program, such as bonus building density.)
"This project got through the heritage program because it was very clear it was not hurting any housing stock," he says. "There's nothing you could do with this project except for what Cam is doing.
"If it wasn't for someone stepping up and doing this sort of thing, it would have been knocked down."

Real estate gets the Obama boost

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/real-estate-gets-obama-boost/docview/382701913/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Benjamin Tal, senior economist at CIBC World Markets, predicts that Toronto house prices will continue to soften in the coming months as the Canadian economy remains stalled. But he adds that Canada does not have the subprime mortgage crisis that has hammered the U.S. housing market. "It is a correction but it's not a disaster," he says of the Canadian real estate market. "It's not a freefall."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Real+estate+gets+the+Obama+boost&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-14&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Real+estate+gets+the+Obama+boost&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-14&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A positive vibe rubs off
Has the "Barack effect" taken the chill off Toronto's housing market?
While the United States basks in the warm glow of a new president-elect, many Toronto real estate agents have noticed a pickup in sales in November after a truly dismal October.
Jeffrey McCann, a real estate agent with Sutton Group-Bayview Realty Inc., says Barack Obama's rise to the Oval Office appears to be one reason people are feeling more sanguine.
"There's definitely more momentum in the market," he says. "I think there has been so much negative news out there that anything positive has no border."
So much anxiety pervaded the market last month, he says, that people were afraid to spend money on almost anything. "I'm not even talking about real estate - I'm talking about people stopping at the local coffee shop."
Deirdre Kutasi of Coldwell Banker Terrequity Realty works with a lot of first-time buyers, who often borrow from their retirement savings accounts to make a down payment. Many clients were dismayed to see the size of their potential down payments shrink with the losses in the stock markets.
"Consumer confidence was really low. It made some buyers afraid to go through with deals," says Ms. Kutasi.
She isn't sure if the U.S. election has had a direct impact here, but she does believe that some prospective buyers have been soothed by seeing North American stock markets rebound from their October lows.
"I think a lot of people are getting their confidence back and starting to put together some offers."
Ms. Kutasi also says many clients are realizing that Toronto's housing market has some immunity from the economic woes in the United States because of strong immigration levels here and the urge of many suburban commuters to move closer to the centre of the city.
Cheri Dorsey McCann of Sutton Group-Bayview Realty believes people who are waiting for prices to fall further are missing an opportunity to troll for bargains now. The Bank of Canada has cut interest rates, listings are brisk and potential buyers are scarce.
"They [buyers] need to get it. They're very nervous."
With so many house-hunters thinking the same way, she says, bidding wars have all but dried up. For the first time in many years, people who go in with an offer are often able to negotiate a reduction in the listing price.
"They don't have the competition, they don't have the multiples, they don't have the fighting."
She points to a house she listed this fall near the Cricket Club with an asking price of $2.9-million. After about eight months, it sold for $2.1-million.
Ms. McCann points out that the buyers not only paid $800,000 less than asking, they saved on the land-transfer tax as a result.
Another house she listed for $625,000 on St. Germain Avenue now has an asking price of $559,000.
The irony, Ms. McCann says, is that so many potential buyers plan to stay on the sidelines for a few months, she foresees a return to bidding wars when people crowd into the market all at once.
"If everyone waits until the spring, we'll be back in multiple offers."
While some sellers have the luxury of waiting for a good offer, some homeowners are under pressure to sell, she adds. Perhaps they have to move because of a baby on the way, a marriage break-up or a job relocation. Or they may have bought another property before the market fell into the doldrums.
When those homeowners cut their asking prices, it will have a cascading effect in the neighbourhood because even sellers who are not desperate will feel they have to match the lower prices.
"When one person reduces, they all reduce because you're fighting for the next offer," Ms. McCann says. "They're not desperate, but they have to lower their price to compete with the person who is."
The agent says that buyers who want to move up or to downsize are putting their houses on the market first and then looking around for something else to purchase.
"They know that once they've sold, they can buy at a very attractive price. People are upgrading because they feel they can buy their dream home for a lot less."
Ms. McCann also sees good opportunities in the market for investment properties. The rental market is hot, she notes, because so many people have been putting their plans to buy on hold.
She recently helped one client buy a house listed for $695,000. The client pays about $2,200 a month in mortgage costs but collects $3,000 a month in rent.
"They have someone else paying off their mortgage."
Benjamin Tal, senior economist at CIBC World Markets, predicts that Toronto house prices will continue to soften in the coming months as the Canadian economy remains stalled. But he adds that Canada does not have the subprime mortgage crisis that has hammered the U.S. housing market. "It is a correction but it's not a disaster," he says of the Canadian real estate market. "It's not a freefall."
Mr. Tal is not predicting a plunge in prices, and he cautions that the broad market data can be easily misinterpreted.
The 13-per-cent decline in Toronto's average selling price reported for October, compared with the same month last year, is likely a distortion, he says.
Mr. Tal points out that the market in October, 2007, was particularly robust because people were rushing to strike deals before the implementation of the city of Toronto's land-transfer tax.
"It's possible that the 13-per-cent, year-over-year drop was really an exaggeration. Statistics can be very dangerous."
Mr. Tal notes that the market appears to be frozen at the moment as buyers stand still. But he expects the spring market to return to a healthy balance between buyers and sellers.
"By spring, we could see a more balanced market," he says. "This will be a much more relaxed buyer."

Will political humour survive the vote? Oh, you betcha

Author: Doyle, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/will-political-humour-survive-vote-oh-you-betcha/docview/382686637/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: What followed was priceless. Utterly crazy TV. Asked about the famous shopping binge, [Sarah Palin] declared, "We hadn't really pursued that until we were sorta gittin' criticized." There was an explanation for the shopping, of course. Then, in an act of breathtaking sucking-up, [Greta Van Susteren] told Palin that she had looked into this allegation that Palin didn't know Africa was a continent, not a country.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Will+political+humour+survive+the+vote%3F+Oh%2C+you+betcha&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-12&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 'Now the real story begins." That's the slogan Fox News is using to promote its coverage of the Barack Obama presidency. It's going to be "fair and balanced," of course. "No spin," that kind of stuff.
People, fear not. There are four glorious years of U.S. all-news coverage and TV comedy shows coming. It is going to be mental.
For instance, one night last week, Jon Stewart told a giddily amused TV audience, "Sarah Palin has been tagged and reintroduced into the wild." Oh no, she hasn't. Governor Palin is on CNN today. Wolf Blitzer will anchor The Situation Room from Florida where the Alaska governor is attending the Republican Governors Association conference. The interview will air throughout the three hours of The Situation Room (CNN, 4 to 7 p.m.) today. Then, Palin is on Larry King Live (CNN, 9 p.m.). On Monday night, Palin was on the Fox News Channel. Greta Van Susteren, who, as any sentient being who watches Fox (that'd be you and me) can tell, is Sarah Palin's No. 1 fan, gazed into the camera and said, "We're live from Anchorage ..." As if that were just the most peachy thing.
What followed was priceless. Utterly crazy TV. Asked about the famous shopping binge, Palin declared, "We hadn't really pursued that until we were sorta gittin' criticized." There was an explanation for the shopping, of course. Then, in an act of breathtaking sucking-up, Van Susteren told Palin that she had looked into this allegation that Palin didn't know Africa was a continent, not a country. Van Susteren said she had "grilled" her informant, and the allegation was totally untrue. It was liking watching two mall rats talk about the rumour mill at school. And it was sublime.
A good deal has been written recently about the possibility of declining ratings for the all-news channels and the lack of political-comedy material for Jay Leno, David Letterman and others, including Jon Stewart. There have been expressions of skepticism about the viability of Stephen Colbert and his satiric shtick of mocking right-wing ranters, such as those who populate Fox News.
It's all nonsense. As Fox News defaults to its best position - attacking everything "liberal," slamming the "mainstream media" and acting as both outsider and the unofficial opposition to Obama - it's all going to get gloriously manic. And funny. Colbert will have a rich vein of self-righteous blather to mine. Obama doesn't have to do much except attempt to reverse some of what George W. Bush wrought, and a whole new war erupts, with an especially tantalizing front in the comedy arena. The political comedy can only get better.
And as for Jon Stewart (who has Bill O'Reilly from Fox News on his Friday show), all you have to know is that a newspaper in Oklahoma, The Sapulpa Daily Herald, did not report that Obama won the presidential election in its Wednesday edition last week. However, a paragraph on the front page noted that the majority of local voters opted for John McCain. Some readers protested outside the paper's offices, and one said, "I think that's just blatant racism." The paper's publisher defended the decision, saying Obama's victory was not a local story. Oh joy that such an America exists.
On CNN today, according to a news release, Blitzer plans to ask Sarah Palin "whether she plans to remain in the national spotlight." Oh please. Wild moose couldn't drag her away. And a good thing that is.
The fifth estate (CBC, 9 p.m.) is excellent tonight. It's an exposé of sorts - an in-depth look at how Canada, mainly Ontario, is failing to make many efforts to produce alternative energy sources. In fact, in many cases, Ontario seems determined to block attempts to move away from traditional energy sources.
The program opens in Germany, where Bob McKeown interviews Hermann Scheer, called "Europe's Al Gore." He's a politician who is leading the way to increase Germany's reliance on wind and solar power. To date, 15 per cent of Germany's energy comes from such renewable sources. Scheer has been to Canada and, apparently, is awed by the potential for use of wind and solar power here, but mystified by the inaction and lack of foresight. As McKeown discovers, anyone here who tries to challenge the conventional energy industry meets a brick wall. Among others, we meet a farmer in Ontario who can generate enough energy to power 350 homes but has been continually thwarted in his attempts to harness that energy.
Check local listings.
*****
Also airing tonight
GENERAL IDEA: ART, AIDS, AND THE FIN DE SIÈCLE (TVOntario, 9 p.m., on Human Edge ) is a wonderful, rich and textured look at the trio of young Canadian artists who formed the collective called General Idea in the late 1960s. Gay, irreverent and drenched in the art-theory that would later fuel the punk movement, they were more honoured in Europe than at home. In the 1980s, one of their iconic creations was their own twist on Robert Indiana's LOVE artwork, replacing the letters in LOVE with those in AIDS. Two members of General Idea died of AIDS in 1994. Annette Mangaard's documentary is a superb celebration of the genius of General Idea.
THE 42ND ANNUAL CMA AWARDS (ABC, 8 p.m.) is, of course, "Country Music's Biggest Night." You're darn tootin' it is. Brad Paisley and Carrie Underwood will unite to host it. Brooks & Dunn, Kenny Chesney, Alan Jackson, Miranda Lambert, George Strait, Sugarland, Taylor Swift and Keith Urban will perform. Ain't no Democratic victory gonna stop this hillbilly hoedown. J.D.
Credit: jdoyle@globeandmail.com

Emerging market funds to be unveiled

Author: Won, Shirley

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/emerging-market-funds-be-unveiled/docview/382687702/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Unlike the Mackenzie fund, which will invest in all of Africa and the Middle East, the Franklin Templeton fund focuses on securities of 12 countries in the Middle East and North Africa, or the so-called "MENA" countries.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Emerging+market+funds+to+be+unveiled&amp;author=Won%2C+Shirley&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-11&amp;spage=B.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Emerging+market+funds+to+be+unveiled&amp;author=Won%2C+Shirley&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-11&amp;spage=B.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In the midst of the current bear market, two Canadian companies are launching mutual funds next Monday that will invest in the frontier emerging markets of Africa and the Middle East.
Mackenzie Financial Corp. is marketing Mackenzie Universal Africa & Middle East Class, while Franklin Templeton Investments Corp. has the Franklin MENA Fund.
It is impossible to foresee whether stock markets will go lower, but "the entry point" in the region now will make sense over the longer term, suggested David Feather, president of the fund arm of Mackenzie Financial.
The region's markets are appealing because they have a low correlation to global capital markets, including emerging markets, Mr. Feather said yesterday. "Africa and the Middle East are dominated by local money rather than global capital flows."
Unlike the Mackenzie fund, which will invest in all of Africa and the Middle East, the Franklin Templeton fund focuses on securities of 12 countries in the Middle East and North Africa, or the so-called "MENA" countries.
While people assume the MENA region is an oil and gas play, that is not the case for the Franklin Templeton fund, said Stephen Fiorelli, vice-president of marketing strategy for Franklin Templeton.
The manager sees opportunities in real estate and construction, logistics and transportation, fertilizers and financials, Mr. Fiorelli said.
That fund will be run by Dubai-based Algebra Capital, which is 25-per-cent owned by Franklin Templeton's parent. The Mackenzie fund will be run by Investec Asset Management based in Johannesburg.
Independent fund analyst Dan Hallett acknowledged that it "could be an interesting time" now to invest in these regions for those who believe they have long-term growth potential.
But it's tough for many investors to do so given that they have seen emerging indexes plunge about 65 per cent from last fall's peak to the recent trough, Mr. Hallett said.
Credit: FUNDS REPORTER

Why Intrawest faces an uphill battle

Author: Ebner, David

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/why-intrawest-faces-uphill-battle/docview/382685885/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "There's no sense of urgency, people are waiting for some stability," said Hugh O'Reilly, former mayor of Whistler and a sales manager for Honua Kai at Intrawest's Playground Destination Properties.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Why+Intrawest+faces+an+uphill+battle&amp;author=Ebner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-10&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Why+Intrawest+faces+an+uphill+battle&amp;author=Ebner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-10&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A year ago, when real estate agent Michelle Diehl sold a three-bedroom condo near the mountain town of Steamboat Springs, Colo., for $295,000 (U.S.), the property had been on the market for only six days, and the buyers were so eager that they put up the money for the place sight unseen.
It's not so easy selling real estate in Steamboat Springs any more. Now, Ms. Diehl is trying to sell a similar condo that's in better shape, and is listed at a lower price - but has been sitting on the market for months.
"It's a different time," she says.
For Intrawest ULC, which set off the real estate frenzy when it bought the Steamboat Springs ski resort in late 2006, the swift and radical reversal is hitting hard.
As recession grips North America, consumers have little confidence in the economy and are slashing spending. Plans for fancy ski trips costing thousands of dollars to destinations such as Steamboat in Colorado or Intrawest's Whistler-Blackcomb in British Columbia are among the first luxuries to get axed - never mind buying real estate there.
So, instead of expanding Steamboat Springs in the model of Whistler to better compete with glitzy Colorado rivals Aspen and Vail, the Vancouver-based resort developer and operator and is playing a defensive game instead.
The difficult business outlook pushed talks to refinance $1.7-billion of Intrawest debt to just hours before the money came due on Oct. 23, with Intrawest owner Fortress Investment Group LLC scrambling to get the deal done.
The debt was taken on in 2006 when Fortress bought Intrawest for $1.8-billion in a highly leveraged buyout, using a two-year term loan at 6.4 per cent to finance the takeover.
Details of the refinancing were not released but Intrawest's debt had been yielding 9 per cent in the market.
Negative after negative is piling on Intrawest. Interest payments are up. Visits to ski areas this winter are set to fall. Resort real estate is moribund.
Intrawest owns 10 winter resorts in North America and one golf resort, places where it also has real estate. It has broader real estate operations in locales such as Hawaii and California's Napa Valley through its Playground Destination Properties Inc. arm. Finally, Intrawest owns boutique travel businesses, including Canadian Mountain Holidays Inc., the world's No. 1 helicopter-skiing operation.
In all areas, Intrawest is feeling stress, from its heli-ski business, where a single trip starts at $975 (Canadian) per day, to Whistler, where the local tourism office predicts the number of visitors this winter to town will slump to about 900,000 from roughly one million a year ago.
The company, and other businesses in Whistler, have reacted quickly. Intrawest, for Whistler and other domestic properties, immediately sought to capitalize on the plunging Canadian dollar, marketing more in the U.S., in Washington State for Whistler and New York State for Mont Tremblant, located north of Montreal.
At Whistler, the company is heavily marketing next month's opening of an ambitious and eye-catching $52-million gondola that connects mid-mountain hubs on Blackcomb and Whistler, crossing the valley between the two mountains.
Intrawest is also playing up cheaper airfares, offering bigger discounts for booking early and pressing its long-time visitors not to skip regular winter trips.
"Even in these challenging times, they're not taking that trip to Whistler or Mont Tremblant off their list," said Andy Wirth, chief marketing officer at Intrawest.
Skiers may still come to ski but real estate is in trouble across Intrawest's portfolio and the focus is filling up rooms with vacationers rather than selling new properties.
In Destin in northwest Florida, Intrawest has a beach and golf resort called Sandestin. Susie Kirkland, who has been a realtor for almost 40 years in the region, said she has never seen such a difficult market.
"We have no shortage of properties," said Ms. Kirkland of Re/Max Southern Realty.
In Hawaii, Intrawest is opening the first of two buildings at Honua Kai on the beach in Maui in January. The first sold out quickly in 2006 but the second is not yet fully sold and the market is frozen, leaving the company to focus on a smooth opening instead of thinking about potential expansions.
"There's no sense of urgency, people are waiting for some stability," said Hugh O'Reilly, former mayor of Whistler and a sales manager for Honua Kai at Intrawest's Playground Destination Properties.
"It's a message you're hearing everywhere. People are not in a buying mode of any sort."
While the outlook for Intrawest is weak, the privately held company should be able to manage through the recession, according to past public results.
In the post-9/11 travel slump in the winter of 2001-02, Intrawest revenue from its resort operations fell 1.4 per cent to $485-million (U.S.). But real estate prices were rising at the time and company revenues in total were up for fiscal 2002.
More recently, in fiscal 2006, just as Fortress was buying Intrawest, the resort company saw its overall revenues fall for the first time in at least a decade, slipping to $1.61-billion from $1.62-billion as real estate revenue had a rough year, down 22 per cent to $489-million from $628-million.
Rival Vail Resorts Inc., owner of five ski hills led by Vail Mountain in Colorado, and real estate, is much like Intrawest, facing precisely the same business challenges. Yet in early October, debt-rater Moody's Investors Service Inc. raised its rating on Vail debt by one notch.
Jacques Ouazana, a Moody's analyst, said obvious negatives are real estate and the recession - but added that mountains inspire fanaticism among skiing and snowboarding enthusiasts. So while people might not make long trips for their fix, places like Vail and Whistler will still draw crowds even in tougher times.
"The local customers represent a safety net for these companies," Mr. Ouazana said.
*****
Intrawest retrenches
The company, which calls itself an operator of "experiential destination resorts," is involved in businesses ranging from high-end ski resorts such as Whistler-Blackcomb to real estate in Hawaii. The recession will hit both and Intrawest is trying to respond.
Numbers
* 9 million: Number of skier visits to Intrawest resorts, more than any other North American operator
* 2 million: Skier visits at Whistler-Blackcomb
* 60 million: Number of skier visits in the United States in the 2008 winter season, a record
* 58 million: Estimated number of skier visits for the 2009 winter
* 12 per cent: Estimated decline in visitors to Whistler for the 2009 winter
What Intrawest is doing
Moving quickly: Has been promoting cheaper Canadian dollar to Americans since early October.
Offering more discounts: Booking early now saves customers 35 per cent at Whistler, up from 30 per cent last year.
Shifting markets: Dollars on advertising are being pulled closer to home, such as Whistler focusing more on Washington State and less on Britain.
Going to those you know: Heavy marketing to customers who have visited before.
Focusing on existing assets: In real estate, Intrawest is working to rent space that already exists rather than planning new projects to sell.
Sources: Intrawest ULC, Tourism Whistler, National Ski Areas
Association

Looking for leadership

Author: Bula, Frances

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/looking-leadership/docview/382719896/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Mr. [Dean Fortin] has said that what he's offering on that issue is experience, plus "a little less conversation and a lot more action." Mr. Fortin, who used to run a non-profit organization dedicated to helping kids get off the street, said he's been frustrated with the slow pace set under Mr. Lowe.Mr. Reid also promises more action on homelessness, but says that can only come from someone with a "new approach and new energy."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Looking+for+leadership&amp;author=Bula%2C+Frances&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-08&amp;spage=S.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Looking+for+leadership&amp;author=Bula%2C+Frances&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-08&amp;spage=S.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: People throughout B.C., in towns big and small, are facing big problems: crime, homelessness and economic turmoil among them. And now they have to decide who to trust to lead them out of it all
Frank Leonard has knocked on many doors in his 22 years of running for council in Saanich, a city north of Victoria on Vancouver Island. He's heard nearly every question in the book. But the one he's getting this year, ahead of the Nov. 15 civic elections, is a little different: "Are you sure you want to be mayor?"
What it means is: "Are you sure you want to have to steer the ship when there's an economic hurricane blowing and no one knows what's going to happen next?"
B.C.'s 160 cities, towns and villages were already facing challenges when candidates started campaigning earlier this fall. Homelessness, the lack of affordable housing and pressures from turbo-powered development are hitting larger or rapidly growing cities hard.
In smaller and rural cities and towns, it's the loss of industry jobs and general economic doldrums that predominate. Crime is a persistent problem in all of them, with suburbs that had previously been seen as safe havens now dealing with gang murders and rampant grow-ops.
Then the economic storm hit, prompting candidates to scramble together promises to keep a firm hand on the budget and keep taxes down. Premier Gordon Campbell also threw a curve into their campaigns by announcing, just two weeks before election day, that he would freeze all property assessments - the basis for how city property taxes are calculated.
That move has bemused city councils and property appraisers alike, since it doesn't actually change how much people pay in property taxes. But it does raise a small expectation in the minds of beleaguered owners that there might also be a tax freeze. That's causing some chaos, says NDP MLA Bruce Ralston, who used to be a Surrey councillor.
"He's totally confused everyone for no discernible purpose," Mr. Ralston said. He has no idea whether that means councils will face angry taxpayers if cities are forced to raise taxes.
But whatever the impact next year, the Premier's move has added one more cloud to a darkening sky in a tough and somewhat peculiar year.
For one thing, the plethora of elections far and wide will have an impact on civic voting. After the federal election and two Vancouver by-elections in October - not to mention the drama-filled national balloting in the United States this month - there is an expectation of voter fatigue. "I suspect we're heading for one of the lowest turnouts ever," speculated Dean Fortin, who is running for mayor in Victoria.
In addition, those elections in Canada, combined with the economic problems, also tapped out contributors, especially developers who are often the biggest donors to civic campaigns.
And they removed a number of candidates from the scene. Several council members, such as Squamish Mayor Ian Sutherland and City of Surrey Councillor Judy Higginbotham, ran in the federal election and, because of the timing, couldn't also run in city elections without looking as though they were hedging their bets.
Another group of well-known mayors, including Herb Pond in Prince Rupert and Terry Lake in Kamloops, also announced they wouldn't be running because they were going to run for the B.C. Liberals in the May, 2009, election.
That has resulted in a dearth of candidates in some places. About one-quarter of the province's mayors will be acclaimed - the same proportion as in 2005, but this time the acclamations hit some larger cities and towns around the province. They included the city and district of North Vancouver, the smelter town of Trail and B.C.'s premier surfing town, Tofino.
Despite the general expectations of a low turnout, there are signs in at least some cities with hot-button issues that next Saturday's elections are going to attract a healthy number of voters - perhaps a consequence of the excitement generated by the American election, some analysts say. Vancouver's first advance poll on Wednesday attracted a significantly higher number of voters than the same advance poll three years ago - about 3,500 compared to 2,000 in 2005.
"We're assuming people picked up election fever from last night," said Trout Lake polling station supervisor Raymond Milne, the day after U.S. voters turned out in large numbers to elect Barack Obama as president.
While no B.C. city has candidates anywhere near the stature of Mr. Obama, many voters face a similar choice to the one Americans confronted - between the status quo and change, experience and new approaches. In stormy times, they will decide who they think is best able to lead them to a safe harbour, from the field of candidates still willing to take on the job.
KEY CITIES BY FRANCES BULA
VANCOUVER
This campaign is rapidly developing more hairpin turns than a hiking trail in the Rockies.
Five weeks ago, the campaign in Vancouver started out with a focus on homelessness. Both Peter Ladner, the mayoral candidate for the governing Non-Partisan Association, and Gregor Robertson, the challenger from the new centre-left Vision Vancouver, said it was their priority.
But Mr. Robertson, a former NDP MLA, promised change and new leadership on the issue, saying Mr. Ladner was part of a council that had done little on it.
Then Mr. Ladner moved on to make his priority - at first - crime, but then, as the economic winds shifted, the budget. He promised a cap on tax increases and said the city needs his experience to weather the tough times ahead.
All those issues got tossed out when controversy erupted over the fact that Mr. Robertson had not paid his fine for having a one-zone ticket when he was travelling over two zones on SkyTrain.
But all of that was overtaken on Thursday, when news erupted in The Globe and Mail that the city of Vancouver had given a secret $100-million loan to the developer building its Olympic village.
That prompted Mr. Robertson to accuse Mr. Ladner of shoddy financial leadership.
No one can begin to predict where the final week of this race will go.
2005 turnout: 32½ per cent of 407,040 eligible voters
VICTORIA
It's not often that civic-election candidates get arrested during their campaigns, but that's been one of the highlights of Victoria's race. That's because several homeless people entered as candidates, in a year where homelessness has taken centre stage.
But the main candidates, after long-time mayor Alan Lowe called it quits this year, are Dean Fortin, a veteran councillor, and Rob Reid, a businessman who runs a sporting-goods store.
Homelessness, already an issue in the city, moved to centre stage when a B.C. judge ruled recently that the homeless could not be arrested for sleeping in city parks if they had no shelters to go to. That has resulted in ongoing tussles with police, who continue to arrest them if they stay past a certain hour.
Mr. Fortin has said that what he's offering on that issue is experience, plus "a little less conversation and a lot more action." Mr. Fortin, who used to run a non-profit organization dedicated to helping kids get off the street, said he's been frustrated with the slow pace set under Mr. Lowe.Mr. Reid also promises more action on homelessness, but says that can only come from someone with a "new approach and new energy."
"We need to move forward with some timelines," he said. He also emphasizes the need to partner with the province as a solution.
2005 turnout: 26 per cent of 64,000 eligible voters
PRINCE RUPERT
Other cities worry about growth and development. That's not Prince Rupert's problem, which has seen its population shrink by a quarter in the past decade. Instead, the big focus in this city's election campaign is on its current and possible future economic woes.
It has lost industries and jobs, as commercial fishing has declined and pulp mills and sawmills have closed. It's also struggling with significant debt that built up when the mills folded and didn't pay their back taxes.
The mayoral race here is a match between two former mayors.
Jack Mussallem, a former government administrator, was mayor from 1996 to 1999. Don Scott, a retired accountant, was mayor from 1999 to 2002. Both say their priority is working on Prince Rupert's financial situation.
"The municipality has been grappling with hard times," Mr. Mussallem said.
But Mr. Mussallem is talking about much more radical action than Mr. Scott. He says the city needs to economize, must keep any tax increase to a minimum, and should look at selling some of the property that it's holding.
Mr. Scott says that, before doing anything drastic, he would set up three forums in the next 12 to 18 months on economic development, social issues and culture. "I did that nine years ago and we did find some solutions," Mr. Scott said. 2005 turnout: 46 per cent of 9,000 eligible voters
CHILLIWACK
This onetime agricultural community at the eastern end of the Fraser Valley used to be far from city problems. Now, its big issues are crime, homelessness and sprawl.
Crime has hit the Fraser Valley hard in the past few years, as murder, mayhem and drug operations have moved out of the central city. "There's been a lot of gang activity and emerging gang culture here," said mayoral candidate Sharon Gaetz, a onetime church minister who has been a councillor for 11 years.
That was brought to the fore only a couple of months ago, when a real estate agent was slain at a house in one of the area's upscale new developments. "This has put a lot of fear into people," said Ms. Gaetz.
Her plan: Keep striving to shut down local grow-ops. Ms. Gaetz also says she would push for longer sentences for criminals to keep them off the streets.
Her main opponent, about-to-be-retired real estate agent Wayne Massey, agrees that crime is a priority and he doesn't criticize Ms. Gaetz's platforms. Instead, he says that someone like himself with connections in the business community, who knows how to manage and lead people, would be an advantage to the city.
The third candidate is Norm Smith, a former Green Party member who has been campaigning to protect agricultural land. 2005 turnout: 14.7 per cent of 50,381 voters
KELOWNA
This city in the B.C. Interior used to be renowned for its beaches, its fruit orchards and its vacation appeal. It's now a booming city that's added 20,000 residents in the past 10 years and the pressures from that kind of growth have brought out a record number of council candidates.
They were spurred on by a recent battle over approving a plan to dramatically increase density in the downtown and allow 27-storey towers.
Mayor Sharon Shepherd is unlikely to lose her seat unless her second-time challenger, Kim Ouellette, gets far more than the 115 votes she did in 2005.
But there are 36 people competing for eight council spots. With four current councillors not running again, the new councillors will define the city's future direction.
One new candidate, John Zeger, gathered thousands of signatures opposing the downtown plan.
Angela Reid, who runs a consulting company for green-business development, was also opposed to the plan. She says she wants Kelowna to absorb development in a way that's good for both residents and the environment.
But businessman Perry Mack said he would have voted for it because it was visionary. Mr. Mack said there are some council candidates who think they can somehow preserve the city as it was in the 1940s.
2005 turnout: 31½ per cent out of 82,080 eligible voters

Log homes go high-tech

Author: Rand-Watkinson, Elizabeth

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/log-homes-go-high-tech/docview/382767666/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: This meant that some ceilings were flat while the home's main ceiling was cathedral. In the flat-ceiling areas he used spray-in Icynene foam insulation to achieve an R-50 value. In the cathedral log ceiling with the extra-deep trusses, he used a six mil (600 gauge or 0.15 mm) vapour barrier and R-44 batt insulation. In the basement walls, he added floor-to-ceiling R-20 batt insulation.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Log+homes+go+high-tech&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Log+homes+go+high-tech&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Latest equipment, materials bring dwellings into the modern age
The first snow of the year appeared on Oct. 21 in my neighbourhood and my first thought was, "Great. Six more months of this." Then, to compensate for that soul-destroying thought came an image of a roaring wood fire set in a snug and toasty log ski chalet.
The imagery was helped along by an e-mail I'd gotten about a new log house in the Kawarthas possibly being the first such structure in Canada to receive an Energy Star rating. That means it's between 20 and 30 per cent more efficient than conventional homes. Take that, Old Man Winter!
This particular house was custom-made for a couple who own a lakeside plot near Bobcaygeon, Ont. Getting it to the point where it warranted the Energy Star rating was a collaborative effort driven by the homeowners' commitment to reducing their carbon footprint. They'd purchased a log-house kit manufactured by Confederation Log Homes, also based in Bobcaygeon, with the intent of making it as energy-efficient as possible. Once the structure was erected, they hired local builder R. Moore Homes to take it to the next level.
I spoke with Mike Murphy, president of Confederation Log, about what his product offers in terms of energy-efficiency and learned that there are several construction elements that contribute to it.
One is the size of timbers used. His company sells two sizes: six inches thick by 12 inches high or eight inches thick by 12 inches high. (The logs can be either northern white pine or western red cedar.)
This makes for a very thick wall whose natural thermal mass holds the heat. Other log-home companies use smaller logs and compensate for the reduced thermal mass by manufacturing a double-log wall with an air cavity that can be insulated.
The Confederation Log kits also include extra-deep roof trusses whose additional depth provides space for maximum insulation.
The log-joining system is another major factor, one that relates directly to air-tightness, an Energy Star requirement. The cutting of log joints and notches is controlled by computer, as opposed to the logs being handcrafted on site. The result is an extremely tight and consistent fit between logs.
Highly energy-efficient windows and doors complete the building envelope. When the Bobcaygeon house was completed, a door-blower test confirmed less than 1.75 air exchanges an hour. The Energy Star standard is 2.5.
To get the house to the finished stage, enter R. Moore Homes, based in Lindsay, Ont. I spoke with Glen Maidens, project manager for the company and a certified Energy Star builder. His company has always built to the R-2000 standard, so he knew how to meet the homeowners' requirements for their log home.
He explained that a small portion of the home had gabled ends and a loft that were built with standard studs and trusses.
This meant that some ceilings were flat while the home's main ceiling was cathedral. In the flat-ceiling areas he used spray-in Icynene foam insulation to achieve an R-50 value. In the cathedral log ceiling with the extra-deep trusses, he used a six mil (600 gauge or 0.15 mm) vapour barrier and R-44 batt insulation. In the basement walls, he added floor-to-ceiling R-20 batt insulation.
An additional factor that contributed to gaining the energy rating was the heating and cooling system. The home is heated with a forced-air tankless hot water system with a propane-powered boiler, and it has a heat-recovery ventilator as well.
The HRV keeps the air moving, which is important in an air-tight house. It draws outside air in and exhausts stale indoor air, recovering up to 70 per cent of the heat from the air it expels.
The home is cooled with an energy-saving 14 Seer air-conditioning unit. All appliances are Energy Star rated, as is the lighting, which uses compact fluorescent bulbs.
What does all this cost? Mr. Murphy estimates that with a 2,000-square-foot log-home kit and the interior finishing of the Bobcaygeon home, expect to pay between $300,000 and $400,000, excluding the cost of the land.
For more information on Confederation Log, see www.confederationloghomes.com or call 1-877-462-5647; for R. Moore Homes, see www.rmoorehomes.com or call (705) 328-2992. To check out spray-in foam Icynene insulation, see www.icynene.com.

City stands guard over industrial land

Author: Raymaker, Derek

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/city-stands-guard-over-industrial-land/docview/382766404/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We took a crack house and whorehouse out of existence [in preparing the Benjamin Moore site]," he says. "We are embraced with open arms outside of the GTA for revitalizing these sites to standards that haven't been seen in local residents' lifetimes. In Toronto, we get stonewalled."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=City+stands+guard+over+industrial+land&amp;author=Raymaker%2C+Derek&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=City+stands+guard+over+industrial+land&amp;author=Raymaker%2C+Derek&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In the 1989 movie Field of Dreams , an Iowa corn farmer, Ray Kinsella, hears mysterious voices blowing through the corn stalks, saying, "If you build it, they will come."
The voices tell Kinsella to build a baseball diamond in the middle of the corn field so that some of the game's great and long-dead stars, such as the disgraced Shoeless Joe Jackson, can once again play on some fantasy plain.
Kinsella's neighbours think he's nuts, and his family isn't to crazy about it either, but he listens to the voices, and after a few twists, it turns out okay, because that's how things worked out in Hollywood blockbusters in 1989.
City of Toronto planners appear to be listening to similar voices, drifting through the halls of Nathan Philips Square, whispering, "If you keep it, they will come back."
In this case, they are referring to some of the industrial buildings around Keele Street and St. Clair Avenue, as well as in a few other pockets in the city. Toronto's official plan - and the planners and councillors who fuss over it as if it were the Magna Carta - supports the concept that even complexes that are vacant and rotting should continue to be zoned industrial in case companies want to restart operations and require workers.
But as manufacturing jobs dry up and tougher environmental standards and expectations come into play, it is increasingly unlikely that heavy, or even light, industry will come back to 100-year-old buildings or the contaminated lands where they once stood.
Late last month, the Ontario Municipal Board rendered a decision that backed up the city's protection of industrial lands. The OMB, the court of last resort on development applications, denied a proposal by Terrasan Corp. to build two high-rise condominium buildings on Lloyd Avenue. The site on the southeast corner of Keele and St. Clair is occupied by a former Benjamin Moore paint facility.
Terrasan president and CEO Louie Santaguida is still smarting over the decision, which was especially difficult to swallow because the company had struggled for three years to make the development palatable to the city.
"For three years we made every effort to accommodate the city," he says. "The local community is totally in favour of more residential and there was no employment on that site in over 12 years."
In its effort to win over the city, Terrasan altered the project from purely residential to mixed-use, and spent millions of dollars cleaning up the site, according to Mr. Santaguida. (The company's expertise is in environmental remediation and redevelopment of contaminated sites.)
"We took a crack house and whorehouse out of existence [in preparing the Benjamin Moore site]," he says. "We are embraced with open arms outside of the GTA for revitalizing these sites to standards that haven't been seen in local residents' lifetimes. In Toronto, we get stonewalled."
It's true that in bygone days, the area was an industrial powerhouse, with slaughterhouses and food processing predominating but with other types of operations as well.
In the past decade, however, the slaughterhouses on the southwest corner of Keele and St. Clair have been replaced by the massive Stockyards Centre with Home Depot, Canadian Tire, Rona, Staples and Future Shop. On the northeast corner, Tribute Communities built a successful multiphased community of semis and townhouses. And just south of the intersection, closer to the Junction neighbourhood, Options for Homes is building a two-tower condo complex.
There is still some industrial activity in the area, but most of it is on a small to medium-size scale, such as auto repair facilities.
A majority of city councillors contend that Toronto is lacking in the supply of industrial lands (or as they call it, employment lands), and have been forceful about protecting them in the faint hope of luring jobs back to the central part of the city.
But the city is also going against the wishes of residents in the Keele and St. Clair area; they embraced the Terrasan project and want to see more of these properties converted to residential use.
The OfficeforUrbanism, a design consultancy, just finished an extensive study of the St. Clair corridor to advise the city on how best to map out development priorities after the completion of a rapid-transit streetcar line currently under construction.
"What we found in our study is that there was an enormous push by residents to have industrial lands converted to residential," OfficeforUrbanism partner Janet Keesmaat says. The firm advised the city to study the employment-land issue more deeply as to what constitutes industrial employment in the 21st century.
"Sometimes employment lands are intensive in terms of machinery, but not in the number of jobs," Ms. Keesmaat says.
With the improved transportation the rapid-transit line should provide, St. Clair would be a candidate for increased residential development.
"Having higher density where you have rapid transit should be paramount," Ms. Keesmaat says. "St. Clair meets that test."
Manufacturing companies aren't moving back to Keele and St. Clair. The Terrasan site, having been kyboshed, will now sit empty, waiting for the day when a Nissan or Magna will magically appear out of fairy dust to plant 600 new jobs in a vacant lot where taxes are relatively high and residents do not want the disruption of factories.
Credit: draymaker@globeandmail.com
