An idyllic setting, a storied past

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/idyllic-setting-storied-past/docview/382758387/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "This guy built this beautiful house on land that wasn't his," says Mr. [Bill Cowan]. "It's built like a fortification."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=An+idyllic+setting%2C+a+storied+past&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=An+idyllic+setting%2C+a+storied+past&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Likely dating back to the 1700s, one of the oldest houses in Prince Edward County seeks a new buyer. The sheep are waiting
Even among the long-standing houses of Prince Edward County, Shannon House is fabled: It may be the oldest 1n the county. It may have belonged to a French Count and fur trader. It possibly dates to the mid-1700s.
That's the historic lore, but the home's more recent past is almost as colourful.
Des Marcille spent his boyhood summers in the limestone house on Waupoos Island. Sometimes the family would arrive in the spring to find sheep from the neighbouring farm had found their way into the house during the winter.
"The sheep would climb up on the couches," Mr. Marcille recalled on a recent return to the island.
Sheep still figure prominently in the landscape around Shannon House.
Bob Fleguel is a farmer who purchased several hundred acres and a few grand old farmhouses from the Oblate order of missionaries two years ago. All told, Mr. Fleguel and his wife, Erin Roughan, own 560 acres of the 840-acre island.
The couple legally severed a parcel of 3.75 acres surrounding Shannon House and have listed the property with an asking price of $599,000.
The house's green lawns slope down to 620 feet of shoreline along Smiths Bay in Lake Ontario.
Behind the house, Mr. Fleguel's ewes graze over much of the island. The farmer figures he has about 1,600 ewes. Another 1,800 or so lambs swell the population in the spring.
Waupoos Island is located in the township of North Marysburgh, just across the water from the hamlet of Waupoos on Prince Edward County. It's a five-minute boat ride from Waupoos Marina to the island.
There, broker Gail Forcht of Chestnut Park Real Estate Ltd. is selling a rare tranquillity.
"The island has a feeling that one cannot put into words," says Ms. Forcht. "It's like stepping out of a boat into a magical place where time has stood still."
Clients who have made the boat trip over have told her that the rolling hills and sheep-dotted landscape reminds them of England.
The main road around the island - an unpaved track known as the King's Highway - barely makes a dent in the lawn of Shannon House. At one time the road led to a house, but all that remains of that building is the foundation.
"It's essentially a legal road, but nobody uses it," says Mr. Fleguel. There's nowhere to go."
Bill Cowan is a local amateur historian who has made a hobby of studying the area's oldest landmarks. He can't say with certainty when Shannon House was built because a land surveyor from Kingston didn't make it over to the island when he set out the lots in Marysburgh in 1783.
The island was owned and occupied by the Mississauga Indians until 1856, Mr. Cowan says, and the European immigrant farmers were squatters.
Mr. Cowan has found ample information about a Joseph Monteney, who was a fur trader living on the island in the 1700s. The story goes that Mr. Monteney was originally from Normandy. He settled first in New York State, married Margaret Frank, and fathered five children.
Intriguingly, Mr. Cowan says, many historical references mention a Count Monteney. The gentleman could well have been a member of the French nobility who fled his native country during the years' of persecution before the French Revolution, the historian believes.
In any case, Joseph Monteney gravitated to the St. Lawrence as the fur trade expanded. He settled on Waupoos Island and traded with the Indians for their fur pelts. First he built a log cabin, and later a house made of limestone gathered from the surrounding fields.
"This guy built this beautiful house on land that wasn't his," says Mr. Cowan. "It's built like a fortification."
Whenever it was built, the house was certainly standing when an Irish immigrant named Alexander Shannon arrived on the island around 1818. Some reports say that Mr. Shannon found the house abandoned, says Mr. Cowan, while others suggest he purchased it from the Monteney family. Official records have the Shannon family as the first registered owners.
Mr. Cowan says that a local writer named Archie Lamont wrote in the early 1900s that the Shannon House was probably the oldest in the county.
The historically-designated house is set into a hill that gradually slopes down to Smiths Bay.
The structure is approximately 35 feet wide by 25 feet deep with walls that are almost three feet thick. It's two-and-a-half storeys at the front and one-and-a-half storeys at the back.
Inside, the seven-bedroom house has a large living room with stone walls, a beamed ceiling and large wood-burning fireplace. Upstairs, floors are made of wide pine planks.
While the house has been updated over the years, Ms. Forcht suggests a new owner may want to upgrade the windows. Some of the rooms have been finished with drywall.
Because of the home's heritage designation, the exterior must remain unchanged, she adds.
Mr. Marcille's mother, Lea Shannon Marcille, was born in the house. She was a pupil at the Waupoos Island School in 1899, and returned as a teacher in 1910. She taught there again in 1948 and returned yet again in 1966 to work as the last teacher before the island school was closed.
Mr. Marcille remembers helping on the farm while his mother was teaching. For many years, he says, the stone house was rented out to vacationers during the summer.
Today, the island remains just about the same, with Mr. Fleguel's sheep and a few cottagers in residence.
Local authorities won't allow any more houses because they don't want to maintain the road, says Ms. Forcht.
"What's here is here."
Mr. Fleguel says the island doesn't have much of a social scene. The seven or so families that spend summer weekends there mostly reside at the eastern end of the island.
"We all meet at the dock," he says of the government-owned main dock that acts as community hub.
Perhaps the most highly-anticipated source of entertainment for local residents is Mr. Fleguel's annual spring trek across the ice with all 1,600 ewes.
The farmer puts some pebbles in a bucket and rattles it around a bit. The sound makes the more experienced ewes think he's carrying a pail of vittles and they begin to follow him.
"Once you've got 10 of them coming, you've got all of them coming."
Mr. Fleguel leads the ewes from his farm in the county over to the island where they give birth to their lambs in the spring and stroll around in the summer. The walk only takes about an hour.
"A lot of people want to see that, but the fact is, it's over pretty quick."
When the grass runs out in late November, Mr. Fleguel takes the sheep back across the water by barge. That process takes all day, he says, because he can only fit about 200 animals on the barge at a time.
By the standards of Waupoos Island, Prince Edward County across the gap is bustling. Bus tours visit the wineries and tourists pick apples at the farms. Cheese producers, celebrity chefs and entrepreneurs are launching new ventures. Proposals to install energy-producing wind farms in some areas are polarizing opinion in the community.
Ms. Forcht says the island makes an ideal get-away. For many years the Oblate religious order farmed on the island and operated a summer camp for disadvantaged families.
She adds that Shannon House would provide a serene location for a family haven or a yoga retreat, among other things. The crystal-clear water and sandy bottom provide an ideal spot for swimming, she says, and the area is well-known for sailing.
"I just feel like grabbing a chair and a book - and I don't get to do that very often."
Credit: cireland@globeandmail.com

Decorating that won't break the bank

Author: Deck, Kelly

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/decorating-that-wont-break-bank/docview/382688583/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Alas, in your living room, it's not a crucial one. Unless your pastimes are illicit or you're an amateur projectionist, there isn't any need for your living room drapes to block out all the light. You just need them to look pretty. And that's where dummy panels come in.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Decorating+that+won%27t+break+the+bank&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Decorating+that+won%27t+break+the+bank&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-07&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Here are a few clever tactics for stretching your design dollars
With the global economy now at 7 o'clock of a hangover morning, this is the time for orange juice and quiet voices, not bright chatter about renovations and pricey home decor.
That's okay: Interior design is all about limitations - financial, structural, electrical - and designing a home on a budget means knowing where to splash out and where to rein in. Luckily, most designers have a few tricks for creating a professional look without breaking the bank. Here are a few I can share with you.
Deck the walls
The first trick is the most obvious one: paint. Changing the colour of your walls is cathartic and fresh paint breathes new life into your home. Don't restrict your work to the wall proper: cleaning up your trim, baseboards and repainting the doors will complete the job and the look. Warm greys, soft linens, and cool ivories are among my favourite colours these days.
Keep in mind that the "designer" paints, prettily marketed and packaged though they are, cost up to 40 per cent more than the brands professional painters use every day - General Paint or ICI, say. It's not an extra expense that will impress a visitor to your home. Besides, if you're in love with one of the designer colours, you can ask a technician to colour-match it in less expensive paint - just be sure to buy extra for touch-ups and the all-important second coat.
Be a dummy
Designers know that draperies add instant polish and sophistication to a room, especially spaces that tend toward the classical and traditional. But custom drapes for your average living room window require as much as 24 yards of fabric, plus the lining, labour and hardware. Using decent mid-market linen, for example, will cost you about $4,000. It's an investment.
Alas, in your living room, it's not a crucial one. Unless your pastimes are illicit or you're an amateur projectionist, there isn't any need for your living room drapes to block out all the light. You just need them to look pretty. And that's where dummy panels come in.
Dummy panels, for the uninitiated, are drapes that don't close. They flank either side of the window and, although they're often only a few inches wide, they're an excellent way to create a mood.
On the average window, dummy panels need one-third of the fabric that functioning drapes do. (Tip: Request a flannel layer between the decorative fabric and the lining; it'll make the dummy panel look full and luxurious.) As for material, silk, linen and cotton velvet are all well-priced and come in a multitude of colours. When the budget is tight, I go straight to the plain raw silk and choose a neutral colour that can stand the test of time. Using this fabric, panels for an average window run about $1,200.
Don't blow your budget on drapery hardware. Select a simple metal rod that is no less than one inch in diameter. Anything smaller looks chintzy and spindly. Keep the finials (those end-of-rod balls) simple - crystals and fleurs-de-lis are not in the budget, and, hopefully, not in the look.
Forgo bed for board
When the Dow is again riding high and we've weathered the "worst economic crisis since the Great Depression," the timing for a deluxe bedroom will be better. At that time, I'll counsel you to get French linens, a custom chaise, and, best of all, a mahogany four-poster bed. In the meantime, you can update your sleeping area with a sophisticated though much less expensive option: an upholstered headboard.
You can have a headboard made at any upholstery shop; most dealers can show you a number of styles. I stick to pared-down shapes - squares or soft curves, sometimes with brass tacking. The key is to request a style that attaches to the wall and allows your mattress and bed frame to rest easily against it.
An upholstered headboard requires little fabric (three to five yards), so choose a bold pattern or bright colour to infuse vitality into a bedroom.
Get artfully cheap
Art and images give a home personality, and a savvy designer will never let the walls go bare. It's ideal to have original artwork in the home, but there are tasteful and attractive alternatives to juicy new oil paintings on every wall.
On a recent project, we went to the city archives and purchased digital files of photographs taken in the 1900s ($11 a photo). We had them printed and framed in simple black frames with big ivory mattes (finished dimensions were 48 by 52 inches). The resulting pieces hung in the entrance of the home, looking elegant and substantial. They fill the space with local history and cost us a tenth of what a series of paintings would have.
Another inexpensive and poignant solution we recently effected involved an old Winnie-the-Pooh book we found in an antique market. It was seven bucks. We had our 12 favourite pages framed in a delicate gold on an archival matte, and installed them in a little girl's room, six on each wall.
Having a comfortable home isn't a matter of throwing money at everything. While for some things, there's no two ways about it - to have the sumptuousness and elegance you want, you have to shell out.
But for other things, money isn't the highest good - a sense of style is better, and so are some crafty tricks. It isn't how much you've got, after all, it's what you do with it.
Kelly Deck is the director of Kelly Deck Design, based in Vancouver, and the host of Take it Outside on HGTV.
Credit: kdeck@globeandmail.com

As prices tumble, homeowners best prepare for the long haul

Author: Barber, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/as-prices-tumble-homeowners-best-prepare-long/docview/382688669/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The results put an end to the talk. Instead of the new tax, Ms. O'[Neill] blamed media reports from the United States for "unduly" affecting confidence in the local market. "There's no question that in Canada the economic fundamentals to support a healthy housing market remain in place."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=As+prices+tumble%2C+homeowners+best+prepare+for+the+long+haul&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-06&amp;spage=A.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=As+prices+tumble%2C+homeowners+best+prepare+for+the+long+haul&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-06&amp;spage=A.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Home sales in the Greater Toronto Area fell 35 per cent this October compared with sales a year earlier, according to the Toronto Real Estate Board. Prices fell 10 per cent over the same period, leading the industry to acknowledge the existence of a deep slump in the market.
"Consumer confidence is critical to the housing market and it appears that consumer uncertainty has been prevalent in today's market conditions," board president Maureen O'Neill said in announcing the numbers.
The decline is evident across the region, with the average home price dropping to $352,974 from last October's $394,646. Prices and sales both dropped most quickly inside city limits, where the average price dropped 13 per cent, to $376,896 from $434,022, and sales fell 38 per cent.
But no region was immune. Sales dropped 32 per cent in the 905 suburbs and the average price there was down 8 per cent compared with a year ago, to $364,142 from $336,049.
Realtors in Western Canada reported similar price drops. The Real Estate Board of Greater Vancouver played up buying opportunities after it saw a 55-per-cent dive in housing prices from this time last year. The Calgary board reported a 26-per-cent drop in metro sales during the same annual period.
Toronto-area houses are also sitting on the market much longer, according to the board, with the average one taking more than a month to sell.
The latest numbers appear to have persuaded real-estate professionals that the market is in a deeper slump than they had been willing to admit.
The Toronto board dismissed early evidence of decline as the result of excess snowfall at the beginning of the selling season. Subsequent declines were attributed to the new municipal land-transfer tax.
Last week, board spokesman Von Palmer told The Globe and Mail the October figures would show the negative impact of a land-transfer tax that came into effect in February, repeating a concern expressed by Ms. O'Neill earlier in the month.
But the results put an end to the talk. Instead of the new tax, Ms. O'Neill blamed media reports from the United States for "unduly" affecting confidence in the local market. "There's no question that in Canada the economic fundamentals to support a healthy housing market remain in place."
Another tactic the board had used in recent months to minimize evidence of decline was to compare current sales with those posted two years ago, in 2006. In that context, current drops in sales and prices can look more like a return to normal after an exceptionally buoyant 2007. The current figures are "indicative of a return to a more-balanced market," according to the board.
But are they? Sales last month were 25 per cent lower than they were in the same month two years earlier, according to the October report. Prices were 1 per cent lower compared with October, 2006, and they are steadily trending downward. It's a precarious form of balance.
Torontonians will quickly recover their appetite for residential real-estate once they realize how healthy the local market actually is, according to Ms. O'Neill.
"Earlier this year the International Monetary Fund undertook a study of housing markets in 17 countries and found that Canada was one of only two nations in which house prices are supported by the economy," she said. "There's no doubt that real estate will continue to be a solid long-term investment in our country."
Emphasis on "long term." In the meantime, watch out.
Credit: jbarber@globeandmail.com
Revision date: Friday, Nov. 7, 2008
CORRECTION: The number of residential property sales in Vancouver was 55 per cent lower in October than a year earlier. Due to an editing error, incorrect information appeared yesterday.

Title: As prices tumble, homeowners best prepare for the long haul

Publication title: The Globe and Mail; Toronto, Ont.

Pages: A.16

Full text:   Gracious in defeat, the Republican presidential candidate delivers a remarkably conciliatory concession speech
John McCain's "Straight Talk Express" ran out of gas last night, stalled by economic gloom, a deeply unpopular Republican president and a running-mate most Americans deemed unfit for high office.
The 72-year-old Arizona Senator lost what is likely to be his final White House run, urging thousands of supporters gathered at a posh Phoenix resort to embrace the country's first black president.
"Senator Obama has achieved a great thing for himself and for his country," Mr. McCain said in a remarkably subdued and conciliatory speech.
Mr. McCain urged his sometimes cheering, sometimes booing, faithful to unite around their new president.
"We have come a long way from the old injustices that once stained our nation's reputation and denied some Americans the full blessings of American citizenship."
Mr. McCain also praised Alaska governor Sarah Palin, who did not speak, as a great campaigner and an "impressive new voice in our party."
And he called his candidacy, "the great honour of my life."
Mr. McCain lost, and lost big, in key battleground states that he needed to win, including Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida. And he ceded states Republicans have owned for years, including Virginia in the East, and Colorado and Nevada in the West.
Mr. McCain's quest was always a long-shot. But his Hail Mary choice of Ms. Palin as his running mate may have sealed his fate. Exit polls suggest the vast majority of Americans didn't think Ms. Palin, the first woman ever on a Republican ticket, was ready to be Vice-President, let alone a heartbeat away from the presidency.
Mr. McCain and his supporters gathered at the lush Biltmore Resort and Spa for what was billed as a victory party.
As early returns began to come in, even the most faithful were second-guessing their candidate's campaign as they listened to country music legend Hank Williams Jr.
Lou Stall, 68, a Phoenix lawyer, faulted Mr. McCain for not being a "consistent conservative" in the mould of Ronald Reagan, and for backing the $700-billion (U.S.) bank bailout.
"That was a chance for him to sayno," Mr. Stall said. "He wasn't as strong as he could have been."
Ann Heins, a retired real estate agent from Tempe, Ariz., said Americans always "vote with their pocketbooks," and with the economy slumping, Mr. McCain had trouble getting out from under George W. Bush's shadow.
Mr. McCain may also have regrets. He faced stiff headwinds beyond his control, including the tanking economy and Mr. Bush's dismal approval ratings, but other problems were of his own making:
* The financial crisis: Mr. McCain made an awkward declaration in September that the "fundamentals of the economy are strong," as the country lurched toward recession, and large swaths of the banking system headed for collapse. * Joe the Plumber: Mr. McCain made the Ohio man, who had a chance encounter with Mr. Obama, a symbol of how the Democratic candidate would raise taxes and bring socialism to Washington. It turns out Joe's not a licensed plumber, owes back taxes to the state and would be a winner under Mr. Obama's tax plan. And his name isn't Joe. It's Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher.
* Money: Unlike Mr. Obama, Mr. McCain accepted federal matching funds, thereby limiting how much he could spend through much of the campaign. Figures through mid-October showed Mr. Obama has spent roughly $240-million on television and radio ads. That compares with a combined $195-million by the McCain campaign and the Republican National Committee.
Even though his White House bid is over, Mr. McCain won't be leaving Washington. He'll continue to sit as a senator. He isn't up for re-election until 2010.
Even before most of the country had voted, Ms. Palin was speculating about her political future. After stopping by the Mocca Moose for a cup of coffee after voting yesterday in her hometown of Wasilla, Alaska, Ms. Palin told a local reporter that if she got involved in national politics again it would not be "so much partisan," according to Politico.com.

Full text:   Gracious in defeat, the Republican presidential candidate delivers a remarkably conciliatory concession speech
John McCain's "Straight Talk Express" ran out of gas last night, stalled by economic gloom, a deeply unpopular Republican president and a running-mate most Americans deemed unfit for high office.
The 72-year-old Arizona senator lost what likely is his final White House run, telling thousands of supporters in Phoenix that "the failure is mine, not yours."
Mr. McCain delivered a remarkably conciliatory and subdued concession speech. "I wish Godspeed to my former opponent, who will be my next president," said Mr. McCain, whose home state of Arizona was still too close to call as he spoke.
Mr. McCain lost, and lost big, in key battleground states that he needed to win, including Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida. And he ceded states Republicans have owned for years, including Virginia in the East, and Colorado in the West.

Mr. McCain and his supporters gathered at the lush Biltmore Resort and Spa for what was billed as a victory party. He watched early returns from the Goldwater suite, named after the late Barry Goldwater, a five-term Arizona senator and failed 1964 presidential candidate. The tony hotel has special meaning for Mr. McCain. He and wife Cindy were married here.
As early returns began to come in, even the most faithful were second-guessing their candidate's campaign as they listened to country music legend Hank Williams Jr.
Lou Stall, 68, a Phoenix lawyer, faulted Mr. McCain for not being a "consistent conservative" in the mould of Ronald Reagan, and for backing the $700-billion (U.S.) bank bailout.

Ann Heins, a retired real estate agent from Tempe, Ariz., said Americans always "vote with their pocketbooks," and with the economy slumping, Mr. McCain had trouble getting out from under George W. Bush's shadow.
Mr. McCain may also have regrets. He faced stiff headwinds beyond his control, including the tanking economy and Mr. Bush's dismal approval ratings, but other problems were of his own making: - The financial crisis: There was Mr. McCain's awkward declaration in September that the "fundamentals of the economy are strong," as the country lurched toward recession, and large swaths of the banking system headed for collapse. * Joe the Plumber: Mr. McCain made the Ohio man, who had a chance encounter with Mr. Obama, a symbol of how the Democratic candidate would raise taxes and bring socialism to Washington. It turns out Joe's not a licensed plumber, owes back taxes to the state and would be a winner under Mr. Obama's tax plan. And his name isn't Joe. It's Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher.
* George W. Bush: "I am not George Bush," Mr. McCain insisted during the final debate. Mr. McCain tried his best, but he couldn't run away from his fellow Republican - the most unpopular president in modern times. * Money: Unlike Mr. Obama, Mr. McCain accepted federal matching funds, thereby limiting how much he could spend through much of the campaign. Figures through mid-October showed Mr. Obama has spent roughly $240-million on television and radio ads. That compares with a combined $195-million by the McCain campaign and the Republican National Committee.
Even though his White House bid is over, Mr. McCain won't be leaving Washington. He'll continue to sit as a senator. He isn't up for re-election until 2010.

After stopping by the Mocca Moose for a cup of coffee after voting yesterday in her hometown of Wasilla, Alaska, Ms. Palin told a local reporter that if she got involved in national politics again it would not be "so much partisan," according to Politico.com.

Financial ties of ratepayer, environmental groups revealed

Author: Rusk, James

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/financial-ties-ratepayer-environmental-groups/docview/382721265/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "He [Kimvar's owner Earl Rumm] won. As far as we are concerned, we are out of there," Mr. [Murray Brasseur] said. "We really want to be left alone, and do our little thing, and let Mr. Rumm do his thing."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Financial+ties+of+ratepayer%2C+environmental+groups+revealed&amp;author=Rusk%2C+James&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-04&amp;spage=A.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Financial+ties+of+ratepayer%2C+environmental+groups+revealed&amp;author=Rusk%2C+James&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-04&amp;spage=A.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Members of a ratepayers group fighting a controversial resort development on Lake Simcoe have poured tens of thousands of dollars into a charitable organization that helped it fight the project.
Four members of the Innisfil District Association, including three members of the board of directors, gave money to Environmental Defence Canada, whose staff lawyer in turn acted on behalf of the IDA last year during a 24-day Ontario Municipal Board hearing on the proposed Big Bay Point Resort.
The challenge was rejected by the OMB and the developer, Kimvar Enterprises Ltd., is set to proceed. But Kimvar has returned to the OMB in an effort to force its opponents to cover its legal costs, which the company estimates at $3.2-million. The main arguments in the costs case concluded last week, with another hearing set for next month.
In the meantime, the Innisfil District Association has become the poster child in a campaign for legislation to protect local groups and individuals from potential financial ruin if they oppose a development and lose.
But the evidence presented at a six-day Ontario Municipal Board hearing on Kimvar's cost claim against the IDA suggests a more complex picture than a simple David-and-Goliath battle.
Not only were the legal costs of the IDA's participation in last year's hearing picked up in part by the EDC, the IDA's legal bills from the law firm it hired for the hearing to work with the EDC were sent directly to the First Canadian Place office of entrepreneur Murray Brasseur.
Mr. Brasseur, who heads investment and real estate management firm Middlefield Group, is part of a group that owns two properties adjacent to the proposed resort, which it wants to use to expand a nine-hole golf course that was founded in 1924.
Apart from the bills for July and August, 2007, that went to Mr. Brasseur, no other legal bills were submitted as evidence, and the only hearing cost that the IDA has entered in its evidence to the OMB was a bill of about $29,000 for expert reports.
Mr. Brasseur said in an interview that, while the bills were sent to him, he did not pay them personally, but directed a fundraising effort among IDA members to cover them.
He said that, in round figures, the initial bill from the law firm Gilbert's LLP was about $300,000. It was cut to about $150,000, which the IDA paid.
He also said that he does not understand why Kimvar is asking the IDA for costs.
"He [Kimvar's owner Earl Rumm] won. As far as we are concerned, we are out of there," Mr. Brasseur said. "We really want to be left alone, and do our little thing, and let Mr. Rumm do his thing."
Much of the evidence at the cost hearing was about the relationship between the Innisfil District Association and Mr. Brasseur, who is a shareholder in two companies that, along with the IDA, opposed the resort at the OMB.
The two companies, Nextnine Ltd. and 2025890 Ontario Inc., worked so closely with Environmental Defence that Rick Smith, the group's executive director, said in his testimony that he "never perceived any daylight between these entities."
The Big Bay Point project calls for a 240-hectare resort with an 18-hole golf course, 1,000-slip marina, 1,600 residential units and 400 hotel rooms to be built on Lake Simcoe, just south of the mouth of Kempenfelt Bay.
The company that would build it, Kimvar Enterprises, is a subsidiary of Geranium Corp., a company owned by Mr. Rumm, a developer with 25 years experience in Southern Ontario.
Mr. Brasseur said that there were discussions with Mr. Rumm that might have produced an agreement to make an expanded golf course part of the resort, but no deal was ever reached.
After discussions fell apart, Mr. Brasseur became an opponent of the project, Michael Miller, Kimvar's lawyer, told the OMB.
Separately from the OMB matter, Kimvar and Mr. Brasseur are engaged in a lawsuit over Big Bay Point, Mr. Rumm's spokesman, Jim Maclean, confirmed in an e-mail.
Mr. Brasseur said he joined the board of Environmental Defence Canada "about a year and half ago" after he encountered the organization because he was active in an environmental coalition that was campaigning to clean up Lake Simcoe.
According to EDC's annual report for the year ended March 31, it received donations of more than $10,000 from Mr. Brasseur last year.
He said in the interview that he has probably given a further $10,000.
EDC also received a donation of more than $10,000 from Middlefield Financial Services Ltd., a subsidiary of the Middlefield Group, the company founded and still chaired by Mr. Brasseur.
EDC also reports receiving tax-deductible donations of more than $10,000 from Roger Parkinson, the current IDA president and a former publisher of The Globe and Mail, as well as a donation in the $5,000-to-$9,999 range from IDA board member Patrick Mulqueen and $1,000-to-$4,999 from Don Avery, a former IDA president who now chairs its board.
In an interview, Dr. Smith, EDC's executive director, defended his organization's links with the Innisfil District Association.
"Raising money for work on important environmental causes is what every environmental organization does, and if Mr. Rumm does not like that, then tough," Dr. Smith said.

Trump gets green light to go for the green in Scotland

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/trump-gets-green-light-go-scotland/docview/382668049/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Real estate tycoon Donald Trump won approval from the Scottish government yesterday to build what he says will be "the world's greatest golf course" on a stretch of Scottish coast, over the objection of local officials and environmentalists.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Trump+gets+green+light+to+go+for+the+green+in+Scotland&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-04&amp;spage=B.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Trump+gets+green+light+to+go+for+the+green+in+Scotland&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-04&amp;spage=B.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The Donald has trumped his Scottish opponents.
Real estate tycoon Donald Trump won approval from the Scottish government yesterday to build what he says will be "the world's greatest golf course" on a stretch of Scottish coast, over the objection of local officials and environmentalists.
The $1.6-billion (U.S.) resort project was rejected by local authorities in Aberdeenshire last year, because part of a golf course is to be built on habitat of rare birds and other wildlife.
After the local council's decision, the Scottish government took the unusual step of agreeing to review Mr. Trump's application.
Issuing the government's final decision yesterday, Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney said the resort was of "great economic and social benefit" to the country.
Mr. Trump, whose mother was born in Scotland, said that the resort would be a "tremendous asset and source of pride for both Aberdeenshire and Scotland."
"As I have often said, because of the quality of the land we are given to work with, we will build the greatest golf course in the world," he said.
The resort is expected to have two championship courses, a 450-room hotel and 500 luxury houses.
The Aberdeenshire Council rejected the resort late last year after local residents and conservationists said a course should not be built on a stretch of shifting sand dunes that are home to some of the country's rarest wildlife, including skylarks and otters.
But business leaders, tourism agencies and Scotland's First Minister, Alex Salmond, supported the development.
"The economic and social benefits for the northeast of Scotland substantially outweigh any environmental impact," Mr. Salmond said yesterday.
Credit: Associated Press

The Canadian TV racket: It's all about your money

Author: Doyle, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/canadian-tv-racket-all-about-your-money/docview/382670747/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: This didn't go over well with the Canadian Association of Broadcasters. In a sulky announcement on Friday, the CAB said, "The decision is fundamentally deficient in its effort to recalibrate the system for the ailing OTA sector." The gist, if you remove all the stuff about "recalibrate" and "fundamentally deficient" is that the broadcasters are so mad they could spit. Both CanWest and CTV would kinda like to see money come to them without much effort.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+Canadian+TV+racket%3A+It%27s+all+about+your+money&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-03&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+Canadian+TV+racket%3A+It%27s+all+about+your+money&amp;author=Doyle%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-11-03&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   First this: Cindy McCain, wife of Republican presidential candidate John McCain, appears on Larry King Live (CNN, 9 p.m.). That's all. That's your U.S. election fix for today.
I hate to do this to you. But, today, we're going to touch on the Canadian TV racket, a dark, menacing place, alive with obsessive, destructive desires. To make money, that is.
Oh yes it is. And we're going to take a pause from pondering the really, really big events in the United States (no, not Madonna's alleged tryst with A-Rod at Jerry Seinfeld's house) to consider the local TV racket. While you weren't looking, it's been a hive of activity.
The other day, the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission roused itself to issue a decision and a proclamation. The regulatory body denied an appeal by major broadcasters to allow them to charge cable and satellite companies to carry their signals. If allowed, this would have meant everybody paying more for cable or satellite, and the over-the-air broadcasters getting tens of millions of dollars in fees.
This didn't go over well with the Canadian Association of Broadcasters. In a sulky announcement on Friday, the CAB said, "The decision is fundamentally deficient in its effort to recalibrate the system for the ailing OTA sector." The gist, if you remove all the stuff about "recalibrate" and "fundamentally deficient" is that the broadcasters are so mad they could spit. Both CanWest and CTV would kinda like to see money come to them without much effort. That's just the way it is. Don't blame them for trying.
Meanwhile, in a few years, you the consumer won't have to pay for seven cable channels if you just want one. This is good. But, inevitably, some cable channels will suffer and will probably be whining at the CRTC to pry more money from the system. It all goes around and around. It's all about your money.
And then there's the matter of the Gemini Awards.
The awards thing for Canadian TV has now spread to four - count 'em, four - nights of handing out prizes, spread out over several months. The climax will be the Broadcast Gala, coming on Nov. 28 and broadcast on the E! network and Showcase. This is beyond ridiculous.
Thing is, see, a lot of people who work in Canadian television - producing, writing, directing and acting in Canadian-made TV - spend a lot of time complaining about the lack of attention they get. They complain about Canadian broadcasters making money from simulcasting U.S. network shows. They complain about everything. Yet, in the case of their own awards program, they are happy to let the thing roll out in relative obscurity. It seems to me that they're perfectly happy talking to each other, reading each other's blogs, whining and telling each other how great they are.
Here's a piece of advice - get out of the house, stop blogging and reading blogs for a while. Leave the Facebook pages alone for a few days. Go talk to people who watch TV, not just the ones who make it. You'll probably find that very few of them have heard of your shows. You might also find that they're willing to watch if they hear that the show is really great. And they know it's great if it gets awards and attention. So get cracking on fixing your awards show.
Corner Gas (CTV, 9:30 p.m.) is a repeat, but one of the more crazy episodes of the series. See, Hank has an idea to increase tourism to Dog River but this has consequences nobody could have foreseen. Oscar also has an idea but is afraid to bring it forward for fear of being labelled a crazy old man. Stuff happens and the newfound popularity of Dog River causes a business boom at Corner Gas and the Ruby Café. Next thing you know, Wanda is getting a weekly guest spot on a popular Canadian news program. Oh yeah, Seamus O'Regan and Beverly Thomson, co-hosts of Canada AM , make an appearance and even Hair in the Fridge Harper visits Dog River, to insert himself into a debate about prairie dogs and gophers.
Samantha Who? (ABC, A, 9:30 p.m.) is one of those sitcoms that just keeps going, without getting much attention. ABC recently decided to keep it on the air through the rest of this season, so it must be popular with a few million people. It has a good concept, and was partly created by romance novelist Cecilia Ahern, daughter of the former Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern, by the way. Christina Applegate plays Sam, a young woman who awakens from a coma suffering from amnesia and knowing nothing about herself and her family. To her chagrin, she comes to realize she wasn't a very nice person before the accident. She's still on the long road to niceness. Tonight, Samantha starts a real-estate business, but her handsome first client (guest star James Tupper, the hunky Jack from Men in Trees ) causes things to go awry. If that sounds like your bag, enjoy.
Check local listings.
***
Also airing tonight
Frontline: The Choice 2008 (PBS, 9 p.m.) is a repeat of Frontline 's two-hour, exhaustive look at the careers, backgrounds and policies of Barack Obama and John McCain. It being a Frontline production, it's totally even-handed but suffers a bit from being made before the recent financial turmoil changed the U.S. presidential race.
SNL Presidential Bash 2008 (NBC, Global, 9) has all the best bits from Saturday Night Live 's political coverage over the last few months. Maybe even a few new jokes. That is if it's even possible to create new Sarah Palin jokes.
Mr. and Mrs. bin Laden (Newsworld, 10 p.m., on The Passionate Eye ) is a BBC program about "a strange tale of love and lust." It's the story of the fourth son of Osama bin Laden and his marriage to a British grandmother twice his age. Yes, apparently a 51-year-old grandmother and five-time divorcee from Cheshire married a 26-year-old Saudi man who already had a wife and child himself. He is also the son of the world's most-wanted terrorist. J.D.

Modernism amid the mangroves

Author: Leblanc, Dave

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/modernism-amid-mangroves/docview/382743560/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Also photoworthy, and just down the block, is Mr. [Paul Rudolph]'s Umbrella House of 1953. Ironically, the umbrella itself - a sheltering steel-and-wood frame superstructure that extended past the house to cover a patio and pool - blew off in a tropical storm just a few years after construction. (Plans may be in place to rebuild this; check www.umbrellahouse.com for updates.) Leaving Lido Shores for the mainland and passing condominiums and a Ford dealership by Mr. [Tim Seibert], a bank by Mr.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Modernism+amid+the+mangroves&amp;author=Leblanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-31&amp;spage=G.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Modernism+amid+the+mangroves&amp;author=Leblanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-31&amp;spage=G.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The Architourist takes a self-guided tour through Sarasota's 'Disneyland' for fans of houses built in the mid-20th century
Mouse ears, outlet malls and gated, Spanish-style retirement communities coated with stucco. It's what usually comes to mind when 21st-century Canadians think of Central Florida.
The Central Florida of 50 and 60 years ago, however, was anything but. As in California, Florida's subtropical climate and open-minded attitude combined to create an elixir that was too tempting for modernist architects to resist.
One that succumbed early was Kentucky-born architect Paul Rudolph, after he graduated from Walter Gropius's Harvard graduate school of design in 1947. First partnering with Sarasota's Ralph Twitchell and then striking out on his own in 1952, Mr. Rudolph would design many small, sophisticated vacation homes, which, ultimately, would lead to bigger commissions and finally to his appointment as chairman of the department of architecture at Yale in 1957.
Thirty years later, in the 1980s, this early work and that of his Sarasota contemporaries - Mr. Twitchell, Victor Lundy, Tim Seibert, Jack West, Gene Leedy, Philip Hiss and others - would become known as the Sarasota school of architecture.
Parked in front of Mr. West's 1967 Sarasota City Hall in my rental Mustang a few weeks ago with my trusty navigator-wife, all thoughts of lime green golfing pants and talking mice were quickly dispelled. A muscular composition of rectilinear forms, city hall is the first stop on a self-driving tour created by local real estate agent and mid-century-modern aficionado Martie Lieberman.
Since I'd be staying a mere 45 minutes north of Sarasota for a little sun-and-fun vacation near St. Petersburg, I decided to e-mail Ms. Lieberman prior to my arrival to obtain a copy of her tour in PDF form, in order to print it out and pack it with my luggage. (Visit www.modernsarasota.com to request it for yourself.) Featuring approximately 100 properties that take about three hours to cover, it's a hefty tour for such a small city. While a lunch break and a few bottles of water are required, it's worth the effort, however, to witness how modernism moulded itself to the mangrove-rich landscape and dealt with hot, sticky temperatures before the widespread use of air conditioning.
Full-wall jalousies, large trellis-like shading systems (some bigger than the houses themselves!), bug-screened swimming pool enclosures (called "pool cages") and gigantic sliding window walls to allow Gulf winds to whisk away stale air were some of major techniques employed by the group.
Many of these can still be seen immediately following the city hall stop in the barrier island community of Lido Shores, which Ms. Lieberman writes is "a living museum of modern architecture." It is indeed, since dozens of examples of the school's early work remain. On Morningside Drive are homes by Hiss Associates, Seibert Architects, Mr. Rudolph, and more recent work by Carl Abbott (the 1986 Putterman Residence).
Unfortunately, very recent houses in this once untainted and secluded enclave usually take the form of McMansions. For instance, where the modernist house once occupied by Mr. Hiss and his family once stood on Westway Drive there are now two faux-château speculative homes that look alarmingly out of place. Luckily, across the street is the Hiss Studio/Library, preserved and ready for architourist eyes and cameras.
Also photoworthy, and just down the block, is Mr. Rudolph's Umbrella House of 1953. Ironically, the umbrella itself - a sheltering steel-and-wood frame superstructure that extended past the house to cover a patio and pool - blew off in a tropical storm just a few years after construction. (Plans may be in place to rebuild this; check www.umbrellahouse.com for updates.) Leaving Lido Shores for the mainland and passing condominiums and a Ford dealership by Mr. Seibert, a bank by Mr. West and Mr. Rudolph's much-ballyhooed 1958 Sarasota High School, we crossed the water again onto Siesta Key and arrived at two more landmark homes.
First is the Revere Quality House, designed by the Twitchell-Rudolph partnership in 1947 to showcase the products of Revere Copper and Brass Co. While the one-storey home has just undergone a massive restoration by new owners (who purchased it from Ms. Lieberman), the sacrifice is that it now lies buried under the weight of a massive three-storey addition that makes it look more like a breezeway or a garage.
One street over, we found Mr. Rudolph's 1955 Cohen House. Its ordered, slender columns and mathematically precise massing tries, unsuccessfully, to play down the tumultuous last half-dozen years it has endured. Despite two separate restorations (one by Ms. Lieberman), it still sits unsold.
After the tour, we met Ms. Lieberman at her own home, which, while not included in the tour, is another excellent example of the school's work. It's a long, sexy Seibert design built originally as a vacation home for Toronto economist and writer Tex Mitchell in 1960. (Any Globe Real Estate readers know anything about him?) Ms. Lieberman is part of a rare real estate breed - not only does she specialize in mid-century modern, she will go so far as to buy a place - as she did with the Cohen House - to save it from demolition and then look for the right buyer afterward.
Glossy informational cards for homes she represents often state: "Seller reserves right to reject offers with intent to destroy house."
We could use a few like her up here, where heritage protection laws often feel, frankly, rather Mickey Mouse.
Credit: daveleblanc@globeandmail.com

Full text:   Waterscapes
LOCATION: Etobicoke
BUILDER/DEVELOPER: Monarch Corp.
SIZE: 480 to 1,605 square feet
PRICE: $189,990 to more than $1-million
CONTACT: To register, phone (416) 495-3544 or visit www.monarchgroup.net
With three towers built and a fourth under construction at its Waterview condo development in south Etobicoke, Monarch Corp. is set to unveil the fifth and final phase this month.
Completing the site on Marine Parade Drive, just south of Lake Shore Boulevard, the new elliptical-shaped, 30-storey building called Waterscapes will give residents views of Lake Ontario and downtown Toronto. It also will put them close to waterfront attractions such as marinas and the Martin Goodman Trail.
"We kept the best for last," says Linda Mitchell, high-rise sales and marketing vice-president for Monarch. "[Waterscapes] truly is the closest to the water of any of the projects you see on the market."
As the site is close to the Gardener Expressway and public transit, residents also will enjoy relatively easy access to the city core.
"It really is a great site in that it's only ten minutes from downtown," Ms. Mitchell says. "You're away from it all - out of the hustle-bustle - and you've got the best views the city has to offer."
In addition to the local collection of shops and other amenities, there will be retail and resort-style recreation facilities in Waterscape's four-storey, U-shaped podium.
A courtyard, eco-friendly green roof and rooftop retreat with a barbecue area are among the outdoor features.
Indoors, there will be a party room with a caterer's kitchen, bar and patio access; a theatre with cinema-style seating and surround sound; and a lounge with a billiards table.
The fitness facility will offer residents an indoor pool, hot tub, saunas, a gym with commercial-grade equipment, and areas for yoga and aerobics.
Amenities also includea 24-hour concierge, a business room, guest suites, a pet wash room and car wash bay.
Many of the features and finishes offered in the building's 345 units are showcased in a 1,090-square-foot model suite with two bedrooms and a den.
"The whole building is elliptical-shaped, so ... the living and dining room has ... curved floor-to-ceiling windows," Ms. Mitchell points out.
Ceilings are be nine feet high, flooring includes plank strip laminate as well as ceramic or porcelain tile, and balconies are six feet deep.
Contemporary kitchens will feature stainless-steel appliances, granite countertops and backsplashes in mosaic glass, ceramic or porcelain tile. Pantries, breakfast bars and islands with temperature-controlled wine fridges are also included.
Even the 480-square-foot, one-bedroom units will contain walk-in closets.
"The spaces have become smaller, but much more efficient," Ms. Mitchell explains. "It's a good opportunity for a first-time buyer to get into the home-buying market."
Energy-efficient features include double-glazed, low-E windows; individually controlled heat-pump systems for on-demand heating and air conditioning; Energy Star appliances; and paint with a low emission of volatile organic compounds.
Units come with parking. The monthly fee is 43 cents a square foot; hydro will be individually metered.
The tentative occupancy date is April, 2012.

Full text:   The Grand Residences at Parkside Village
Location: Mississauga
Builder/developer: Amacon
Size: 560 to 1,730 square feet
Price: $199,900 to the low $700,000s
Sales centre: 465 Burnhamthorpe Rd. West, at Confederation Parkway. Open Monday to Thursday, 1 to 7 p.m.; weekends, noon to 5 p.m.
Contact: (905) 273-9333 or www.lifeatparkside.com
Amacon is developing a 30-acre site in downtown Mississauga that will eventually include 18 high-rise towers and a handful of low-rise buildings.
Despite its size, the project at Burnhamthorpe Road and Confederation Parkway will be far from a concrete jungle, according to the builder.
Amacon says it aims to create a pedestrian-friendly community. Among other things, it will allot 2.5 acres for parkland and establish wide walkways.
To generate a vibrant street life, cafes and restaurants with patio seating, banks, salons and other commercial outlets will be incorporated into the base of the buildings.
"It's all the essentials of day-to-day life," says Debbie Cosic, a principal of In2ition Realty, which is handling marketing and sales for the project, called Parkside Village.
Nearly all of the 292 units in the first high-rise, a 36-storey tower launched in June, have been sold. The 45-storey second tower, called the Grand Residences, contains 450 suites, roughly 60 per cent of which have been purchased.
"[The] recreation of this urban village in a 905 neighbourhood has been phenomenally well received," Ms. Cosic says. The site is close to shops, restaurants and entertainment venues, GO Transit service, as well as Highway 403 and the QEW.
"It's a premier location for an urban lifestyle, and we really don't have that in the suburbs," Ms. Cosic says.
Residents within the first three towers - the third will be unveiled next year - will have access to 50,000 square feet of private amenities. There will be a show kitchen, wine bar and cellar, a "grand celebration" room, a music room, an Internet lounge and theatre, as well as a gym, indoor pool, hot tub and sauna.
The rooftop patio will feature a lounge with fireplace, barbecue and dining areas, gardens with trellis-covered seating, a playground, an area for dogs to run free and a large lawn.
"We also have green roofs, so when you look down onto a lower building or amenity area, you see expanses of green," she adds.
Units still available in the second tower measure between 560 and 1,020 square feet. Layouts range from one bedroom and two bedrooms with a den. Prices include a parking space and locker.
Models typically have balconies, combined living and dining areas and open kitchens with breakfast bars, granite countertops and appliances.
Among the other features are nine-foot ceilings in the principal rooms, engineered hardwood and porcelain tile flooring, Berber carpeting, imported marble bathroom countertops and deep soaker tubs.
Most penthouses - sized from 1,330 to 1,730 square feet - will have three bedrooms, and come with two parking spaces. They will feature 10-foot ceilings, electric fireplaces and stainless-steel appliances, including side-by-side refrigerators and a wall oven.
Construction waste will be kept to a minimum and local materials will be used, according to the builder. Utilities will be individually metered.
The monthly fee is 47 cents a square foot.
Occupancy is scheduled for spring, 2012.

The British are coming ... to play and invest

Author: Belford, Terrence

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/british-are-coming-play-invest/docview/382683214/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We already have approval for 650 residential units at Port McNicoll and 1,000 at Horsehoe, but we are also looking at hotels, a commercial centre at Horseshoe Valley and the creation of four private clubs," says Gil Blutrich, Skyline's president who is also chairman of real estate firm Mishorim Group in Israel. Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+British+are+coming+...+to+play+and+invest&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-28&amp;spage=B.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+British+are+coming+...+to+play+and+invest&amp;author=Belford%2C+Terrence&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-28&amp;spage=B.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Resort operators strive to have a year-round focus to attract clientele that increasingly is international in origin
Year-round recreation-based communities have started a slow but certain rise across Canada. And it's not just places for big-city folk to own a weekend getaway either. Canada's growing crop of ski, golf, boating and relaxing-surrounded-by-nature destinations are gaining favour with the international crowd - investors and holidayers alike.
In Newfoundland, there is the Humber Valley Resort, a 2,200-acre property being developed by British-based Newfound Property International . Regular flights into nearby Red Lake Airport ferry British tourists for a taste of rugged scenery enlivened by an 18-hole championship golf course, spa and gourmet restaurant.
In Quebec, the British have become the second-biggest group of buyers at Intrawest ULC's Mount Tremblant resort community. The Vancouver-based company also owns internationally recognized year-round resort communities at Blue Mountain, Ont., and Whistler, B.C.
Late this summer, Skyline International Developments Inc. of Toronto announced it too would be creating its own version of a resort and recreation community. The company already owns more than 800 acres on Georgian Bay at Port McNicoll and in August bought the nearby Horseshoe Valley ski resort. It plans to turn both into a single year-round destination.
"We are starting to see the emergence of Canadian destination-based, year-round resorts, which have great appeal to the British and Germans especially," says Joel Rosen, chairman of Horwath FTL, a leisure industries consultant, which has worked with some of the new communities.
"There now seems to be a number of new entrants that are modelling themselves after Intrawest, which has been enormously successful in that area. What they share is a primary appeal to a local market and then building on that to attract foreign buyers and vacationers."
The existing and planned communities can be split into two distinct categories, Mr. Rosen says. There are those such as Mount Tremblant and Whistler built on a well-established local destination - in both cases ski hills - and those trying to create a destination almost from scratch, such as Humber Valley in western Newfoundland and Skyline's venture south of Georgian Bay.
What sets them apart from standard cottage country developments is their focus on becoming a destination much like Orlando in Florida. These communities offer not only a broad range of winter and summer activities but throw in shopping, restaurants, hotels and sometimes even live theatre and a casino.
Mount Tremblant is a prime example, says Steve Lafave, director of sales for Intrawest at Tremblant.
"We acquired it in 1991 and started expanding in 1993. To date, we have built 2,800 housing units, 130,000 square feet of hotel space and 40,000 square feet of commercial and retail.
"We have also just added convention space and a $65-million casino. We get 2.5 million visitors during high season. The challenge now is to beef up shoulder season [spring and fall] traffic."
Mount Tremblant even has its own airport with daily flights from Toronto and regular flights connecting with New York. "Brits have become our second-biggest market," Mr. Lafave says.
At Skyline, the goal now is to decide how best to develop, market and integrate not just Port McNicoll, with its boating, fishing and water sports, and Horseshoe, with its ski hills and 35 kilometres of trails, but also the company's two five-star Toronto hotels and spas - the Pantages Suites and the Cosmopolitan.
"We already have approval for 650 residential units at Port McNicoll and 1,000 at Horsehoe, but we are also looking at hotels, a commercial centre at Horseshoe Valley and the creation of four private clubs," says Gil Blutrich, Skyline's president who is also chairman of real estate firm Mishorim Group in Israel. "We will have one for boating, one for skiing, one for horseback riding and we will turn one of Horseshoe's two existing golf courses into a private club as well."
One of the immediate goals will be to give each community its own sense of being a village with new commercial and retail development, hotels and other amenities, says Rob Spanier, senior business development manager at Live Work Learn Play LLP, the consulting firm Skyline has retained to help with planning.
"Once we have worked out the details of creating distinct communities, then the next task is deciding how to brand them as a single destination."
That may be a far more challenging task, Mr. Rosen says. "Unlike Mount Tremblant and Whistler, this is essentially a greenfields project. Few have ever heard of Port McNicoll. Branding Horseshoe and Port McNicoll as a single destination must also overcome geography; the two are at least a 20-minute drive apart."
It is, however, too early for predictions about success, he adds. "What I can say is I know Gil well and he is a very clever fellow and a canny businessman and the time may indeed be right for a recreation-based destination-style community like this."
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

A KICK IN THE SHINS FOR GULF STATES

Author: Verma, Sonia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/kick-shins-gulf-states/docview/382682516/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Echoing the optimistic outlook of other leaders, Sultan Nasser al-Suweidi, the UAE's central bank governor, said yesterday that the liquidity crunch in the region's banking system was easing and soon the region's economies would return to normal. "Things are getting better and stabilizing," he said.

Full text:   Oil-fuelled wealth proves to be only thin insulation against the effects of the global credit crunch
For British soccer fans, it seemed too good to be true: Zabeel Investments, a Dubai-based sovereign wealth fund, was looking to buy Charlton Athletic, a struggling soccer club mired in more than $30-million (U.S.) of debt.
But late last week, Zabeel suddenly pulled out, blaming the toxic economic climate in the West. The company had decided to focus on "domestic opportunities" instead.
If soccer fans in Britain were shattered, the mood in Dubai was shock. The deal's collapse was one of the most striking signs the party in this oil-rich region was over: State-owned investment vehicles had sobered up, suddenly shunning trophy assets like Charlton.
In the past few weeks, Persian Gulf states have been jolted by the realization that they are not immune to the financial turmoil gripping the globe. Oil-fuelled wealth proved to be only thin insulation against the effects of the credit crunch.
More than $50-billion of foreign deposits has fled the region's banks in recent weeks as investors pulled back.
The price of oil - this region's main export and source of income - plunged, and local stock markets sank to new lows.
Gulf states have had to retrench, with Kuwait moving to prop up its central bank and Saudi Arabia extending special credit to its neediest citizens over the weekend.
The United Arab Emirates has already acted to guarantee bank deposits, and injected billions of dollars into its domestic money markets to encourage interbank lending. Qatar and Kuwait have used their sovereign wealth to buy up stakes in ailing banks and slumping stock.
"It feels a little like we've all woken up in the Twilight Zone," said Jason Goff, head of treasury sales at Emirates NBD.
"People are scared. Nobody in a million years predicted this would happen here," he added.
Economists are scaling back growth forecasts, and the Gulf's once-giddy property market is showing signs of shakiness, with developers now openly talking about construction delays and cancellations as fear spreads, paralyzing buyers.
Property developers have scaled back recruitment, with some companies imposing unprecedented hiring freezes until the economy stabilizes. Credit Suisse said market turmoil and negative sentiment would likely dent property demand in Dubai and Abu Dhabi, while Morgan Stanley predicts a market downturn of at least 10 per cent by 2010.
"These economies are no longer islands unto themselves," said Dr. Henry Azzam, chief executive officer of Deutsche Bank, Middle East and North Africa, and a former economics professor at Beirut University.
"Economic integration with the West brings with it a level of exposure. It forces a certain degree of reflection on how to move forward."
For the region's rulers, the need to take drastic steps to stabilize markets is unprecedented. Gulf leaders tend to view themselves as mavericks, building skyscrapers in the middle of the desert and man-made islands in the middle of the ocean, all in an effort to attract foreign investment and diversify their economies away from oil wealth.
The strategy has so far worked in countries like the United Arab Emirates, which has boasted double-digit growth in the past five years. Only in the past month have the hidden costs of that progress been revealed.
As Gulf states refocus their resources domestically, there is dwindling interest in acquiring assets in the West, even at fire sale prices.
"Anything in the West is seen as toxic," Dr. Azzam said. "They are not going to be the ones to bail out the banks any more. It's just not worth it," he said.
Foreign assets of Gulf Co-operation Council states were estimated to top $1-trillion last year. Some funds have seen their existing investments suffer massive losses.
The Kuwait Investment Authority's investment in Citigroup last January shows a $270-million loss.
To be sure, Gulf states are in a far better position to survive financial turbulence than the West.
Even though oil prices have dropped, countries including Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi and gas-rich Qatar have deep reserves of savings to cushion their countries from any real devastation.
Dubai is still viewed as a refuge for worried professionals, whose jobs are quickly evaporating in Western financial capitals. Some recruitment companies have reported a tenfold jump in applications in the past two months with bankers and estate agents leading the charge.
Gulf leaders and central bankers remain self-assured, arguing that their economies are fundamentally sound and able to withstand the current turmoil.
Echoing the optimistic outlook of other leaders, Sultan Nasser al-Suweidi, the UAE's central bank governor, said yesterday that the liquidity crunch in the region's banking system was easing and soon the region's economies would return to normal. "Things are getting better and stabilizing," he said.
But confidence alone won't calm markets, analysts say, and some suggest a co-ordinated action plan among Gulf states is needed to address the region's problems.
For now, leaders appear to be waiting to see if things get worse.
"If there is a need, we will do more," Mr. al-Suweidi said.
*****
Gimme shelter
As the financial crisis creeps into the Middle East, here's what others countries did yesterday to shore up battered markets.
The U.S. Treasury Department started moving $125-billion (U.S.) to nine major banks by buying ownership stakes, the first big transfer since the $700-billion bailout was passed this month.
Australia's central bank took the rare step of buying Australian dollars twice in the past few days to limit their plunge.
Crisis-hit Iceland said it needs another $4-billion in loans on top of the $2-billion it wants from the IMF .
Japan's Prime Minister Taro Aso told senior officials to draw up steps to calm volatile markets and to fend off further fallout.

Full text:   MacDonald Dettwiler and Associates Ltd. says it has signed a contract worth more than $6-million with space company EADS Astrium for a satellite antenna system.
The Vancouver area company, also known as MDA, said it will provide EADS Astrium, Eutelsat KA-SAT's prime contractor, with four transmit and receive antennas, which will provide the satellite's multiple gateway and user beams.
Eutelsat is one of the world's leading satellite operators.
It will use KA-SAT for consumer broadband services across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East as well as for local, regional and HD broadcast services.
Earlier this month, MDA said it signed a $10-million contract with EADS Astrium to provide a high-power satellite antenna feed for the Alphasat spacecraft, one of the world's largest telecommunications satellites.
It also received more than $10-million (U.S.) in contract amendments from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration to upgrade its Instrument Procedure Development System, which modernizes flight route design practices and harmonizes military and civilian air navigation.
In May, Ottawa blocked MDA's proposed sale of its space division, which includes the Radarsat-2 satellite, to Alliant Techsystems Inc. for $1.325-billion in cash.
The federal government said the proposed deal would not benefit the country.
Critics of Ottawa's decision said the sale was necessary because space spending in Canada had dried up, and in part blamed the federal government.
MDA said publicly that it wanted to sell the division to focus on expanding its faster-growing information products business, which makes software for the real estate sector.
Last month, MDA warned earnings will be lower as a result of the uncertain housing and lending environment in Britain.

Global crisis roils Gulf

Author: Coker, Margaret; Cummins, Chip

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/global-crisis-roils-gulf/docview/382683567/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Much of the Gulf has budgeted for much lower oil prices. Gulf states, on average, need prices above $47 a barrel to keep from running budget deficits. But some states are more vulnerable than others: Bahrain's so-called breakeven price is $75 a barrel, compared with Saudi Arabia's $49 and Kuwait's $33, according to the International Monetary Fund.

Full text:   Kuwait bails out one of its largest banks in sign oil-rich region not immune from harm
The global financial storm rolled across the Persian Gulf yesterday, as Kuwait's central bank guaranteed bank deposits and cobbled together a hasty bailout for one of the country's largest banks.
The Kuwait intervention is the first bank rescue in the oil-rich Gulf, which until now had seemed relatively immune to the current crisis. It came as local markets across the region continued their steep selloffs. With oil prices down more than 50 per cent from their July highs, the explosive, petroleum-fuelled growth of the Gulf now looks suddenly vulnerable at the same time as international and local investors are pulling back sharply.
Saudi Arabia, in an apparent bid to ease the fallout of the global credit crisis on its citizens, said it would funnel some $2.3-billion (U.S.) in loans to low-income borrowers. And in Dubai, real estate brokers in the Mideast boomtown said they are seeing signs of price weakness for the first time in years, as financing dries up and speculators bow out of the once red-hot market.
For months, the Gulf appeared largely immune to some of the worst fallout from the housing, credit and banking crisis that has rippled from the U.S. across Europe and Latin America and into parts of Asia.
Several governments even took dramatic pre-emptive moves, funnelling billions of dollars of cash into their relatively small but liquidity-starved banking systems. Earlier this month, Saudi Arabia promised $40-billion in lending facilities to banks that needed cash. The United Arab Emirates pledged a sweeping three-year guarantee on domestic bank accounts.
None of the moves reassured the region's equity investors. In recent weeks, they have followed international investors out of the Gulf's handful of stock markets, which earlier this year were some of the best-performing among emerging markets. Sharp falls in the price of oil have also rattled confidence here.
While prices are still high enough to provide generous budget surpluses for most of the Gulf's petroleum-dependent governments, the prospect of further falls has spooked investors.
Much of the Gulf has budgeted for much lower oil prices. Gulf states, on average, need prices above $47 a barrel to keep from running budget deficits. But some states are more vulnerable than others: Bahrain's so-called breakeven price is $75 a barrel, compared with Saudi Arabia's $49 and Kuwait's $33, according to the International Monetary Fund.
The speed of crude's tumble has unnerved officials despite the apparent cushion. At an emergency meeting on Friday, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries hastily decided to cut output by 1.5 million barrels a day, the biggest single cut in almost eight years.
Weeks of sliding equity prices have wiped out billions of dollars of wealth for the region's influential clique of local retail investors. Saudi Arabia's main stock-market index is down by more than 50 per cent year to date. The fall has wiped some $205-billion of value off the region's biggest exchange by market capitalization since June.
Yesterday, Kuwaiti traders staged their second stock exchange walkout in as many trading days. (Kuwait's market is closed on Fridays and Saturdays.) They demanded more state intervention in the markets to prop up share prices. The chief executive officer of the National Bank of Kuwait, Ibrahim Dabdoub, called on authorities yesterday to close the exchange altogether.
High oil prices have allowed state and private investors across the Gulf to funnel billions of dollars into red-hot property markets, infrastructure projects and, more recently, foreign-exchange speculation. In particular, many foreign and local investors earlier in the summer made speculative currency trades, betting that regional governments would drop their currency pegs with the greenback to help tame rising domestic inflation.
International investors rushed out of those trades late in the summer and early last month when it was clear governments weren't going to act.
That left many banks strapped for cash, so they scrambled to make new loans. When international borrowing seized up last month, the region found itself stuck in its own credit crunch.
But it was currency trades - not bad loans - that plunged Kuwait into a banking bailout yesterday. Gulf Bank said defaults by counterparties on bad euro-dollar derivatives contracts forced the bank to seek government intervention.
Gulf Bank, which has assets of $18-billion, and the government declined to disclose the size of the bank's trading losses, but industry estimates in Kuwait were above $700-million. The government yesterday appointed a state supervisor for the bank's operations, suspended trading in the bank's stock and opened an investigation.
