Someone's in the kitchen with Maisie

Author: Brown, Ian

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/someones-kitchen-with-maisie/docview/382680372/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Well, I don't know," [Maisie Wallace] said in a faintly exasperated tone. "That much." She tossed a piece of white packaged pork fat onto the table - an inch thick, three inches by six inches in area. It looked disgusting. "It's not good for you. But I keep it frozen, because it's easier to cut that way."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Someone%27s+in+the+kitchen+with+Maisie&amp;author=Brown%2C+Ian&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-11&amp;spage=F.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Someone%27s+in+the+kitchen+with+Maisie&amp;author=Brown%2C+Ian&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-11&amp;spage=F.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Disclaimer: Newfoundland pork buns may increase the chance of a heart attack or stroke that can lead to death. Common side effects include drowsiness, intense pleasure and muscle and joint pain from fighting your way to the pork-bun plate before that guy in the down vest scarfs the last one. Side effects diminish with the cessation of consumption, which in turn can produce feelings of deprivation and sadness .
Behold the Newfoundland pork bun. That was my plan, anyway. Or to put it another, less alimentary way, so I can come across as an intellectual: How do you travel to an unknown land and discover its memorable secrets, in a ruthlessly competitive age when everything feels pre-discovered? How do you earn the confidence of the locals and take the true pulse of a place without coming across as a pushy, and in the case of pork buns, greedy come-from-away?
One trick, fellow traveller, is to follow the food.
Perhaps I should begin at the beginning. Your correspondent spent 11 days this summer attending the Writers at Woody Point arts festival. Woody Point, population 500, is halfway up the west, less-visited coast of Newfoundland, in Gros Morne National Park, home to fine hiking, Gros Morne mountain, the famous Tablelands (one of two places on the planet where the Earth's mantle has broken through its crust like an overstuffed pie), excellent fishing and kayaking and swimming (fresh and saltwater), and of course the festival itself, which featured a full net of performances by the likes of actor Gordon Pinsent and screenwriter and demon fiddler Des Walsh and a two-night reunion of Figgy Duff, the more-or-less famous band that kicked off a revival of traditional Newfoundland music in the 1970s.
As for the Newfoundland pork bun, there was an opening-night barbecue. An hour into the happiness, your correspondent noticed a commotion at the food table. Not one to shy away from food that attracts crowds, he battled his way into the melee, employing a leap-and-fall action he had seen a humpback whale perform that afternoon in nearby Bonne Bay. He beached in front of a plate of small, two-inch, cake-like things, evidently browned in the oven. They appeared to contain raisins. Your correspondent reached out and popped one in his mouth.
Time stopped. Or if it didn't actually stop, it slowed considerably, sat down, put up its feet and said, "Ah!" The bun was ... what was it? There was a savoury taste to it, set off against the sweetness of the raisins and the faintly caramelized surface. There was a crispness to it, and chewiness, and a bacony hint; it was cakey but not cake. It was unlike anything your correspondent had ever tasted. He heaved back into the fray for another, but by then they were gone.
"What were those?" he said to no one in particular.
"Those were Maisie Wallace's pork buns," someone said. " Were being the operative word."
Lardy cake's legacy
Most adventuresome eaters, when they hear the term pork bun, immediately think of cha siu bao , the famous Chinese delicacy - dough wrapped artistically around spiced pork, and either steamed (in which case they resemble tiny white clouds) or baked (in which case they are neat and brown and round). The Shanghai model, sheng jian bao , are pan-fried.
The Newfoundland pork bun is none of these. In fact, it isn't a bun at all, deriving as it does from a traditional English specialty, the lardy cake. In Suffolk, on the southeast coast of England (and where pig farming is a mainstay), lardy cakes are known as fourses, after the time of afternoon they were and still are eaten on holidays and feast days, with a side of tea.
Still, as a name for something you want someone to eat, even the faintly pornographic pork bun is a big improvement on lardy cake. Lardy cake sounds like something one might hear in the course of a bitter domestic argument, not that I'd know anything about that.
Half an hour later, having been introduced to any number of good and healthy Newfoundland talkers - they outnumbered the pork buns by a wide margin - your correspondent was introduced to a woman with blond hair who said her name was Maisie.
"Maisie?" Your correspondent perked up. "The Maisie who made those little cakes?"
"The pork buns. I did, yes."
"Can you give me the recipe?" I admit it was a daringly aggressive question right out of the gate. A stranger from Toronto asking that question in a small town is likely to get the answer "Not on your life, buddy," after which further conversation can be strained. But Maisie didn't look like someone who was easily offended.
"They're easy. You just - oh, look, I can't tell you. You'll have to come and watch me do it."
"And when will you be doing it next?" I admit I hoped the answer would be: "In 10 minutes."
"Oh, gosh. I don't know. I haven't really planned any."
"Well," I said, assuming my most casual and offhand manner, "if you were going to make them, and I wouldn't be in the way, I'd love to watch."
By now Maisie was eyeing me the way she might look at someone she suspected of being the new second-storey man in town.
"Because," I added hastily, "you know, they're very good." Then the full press: "We don't have anything like them in Toronto." Open, but not too eager; insistent, but not insane; flattering, but not fatuous. It's bad enough to be a tourist, much less a pushy, recipe-plundering tourist.
"I suppose I have to make some for Robert and Peter's party on Saturday afternoon," Maisie sighed, at last. "You'd better come over Saturday morning. About 9:30."
She left it to me to find out where she lived.
Talking through it
Days went by. I hiked up and down Gros Morne mountain, up and down the Tablelands, up and down the Green Gardens loop by the sea, up and down the Lookout. If there is a 10-foot stretch of Newfoundland that is flat and not pocked with stones, I did not find it. I ate pan-fried fresh cod and cod tongues and scallops every night, but never grew tired of them. I saw moose. (Ten people had died that summer running into moose on the roads.)
Mostly I listened to people talk. Newfoundlanders occasionally pretend to be immune to the rest of the world (west coast Newfoundlanders claim not to care even about goings-on in St. John's, on the other side of the island), but as far as conversation goes, Newfoundland is the Manhattan of Canada.
I met doctors who talked about recent neurological findings regarding serotonin uptake, and retired teachers who talked about rug-hooking and real estate. Randall Maggs, a professor of English literature at Sir Wilfred Grenfell College, had written Night Work , a book of poems about the troubled hockey goalie Terry Sawchuk; we chatted mostly about skiing. His son Dave, a PhD student (environmental sustainability), concert pianist and founder of the brilliant Gros Morne Summer Music quartet, recommended (among other things) Buzz Hollings's book Panarchy , which is about ... well, a new framework for understanding and restructuring evolving human-natural hierarchical systems, as a way of fending off the end of the natural world.
The point is, if you don't want to be intellectually bored while you quietly think about what you plan to eat next, you could do worse (no matter what Stephen Harper says) than attend an arts festival in the middle of nowhere in western Newfoundland.
'What are you doing here?'
Eventually Saturday rolled around. Maisie's house was a trim and elegant bit of work on four acres of oceanfront that she and her husband, Lou, a retired insurance man, picked up a few years ago for $10,000. I showed up at 9:30 a.m. to find her drinking blueberry wine with friends from Corner Brook, a town 45 minutes to the south. Gordon Pinsent was asleep upstairs in the guest room.
While Maisie ran off to see if he was stirring (very little about Gordon Pinsent is not), two of her guests, Elaine Brown and Ann Casey, a teacher and a nurse, cornered me on the wraparound deck.
"And what are you doing here?" Ann asked.
"I, um ... I've come to learn how Maisie makes pork buns," I said.
"Couldn't you have done that over the phone?"
"Well, yes," I said. "I could have. But you know how good cooks can be. I didn't want her to tell me the recipe and then leave out a crucial ingredient, the way some cooks do. My mother, for instance, is 93 and has yet to reveal the entire recipe for her bread sauce. And it only has four ingredients."
That got their attention. The two women immediately began to confer.
"Maisie's pork buns, are they fried out?" Ann said.
No," Elaine said. "Baked. They're some good."
I could be wrong, but I thought I caught a glint of disbelief in Ann's eye as to the brilliance of Maisie's pork buns, if only in relation to her own.
Then Elaine began a story about a Newfoundland aunt who made the most delicious, dark fruitcake. She asked for the recipe, and did what she was told, but it wasn't the same. "And I'm a good cook. When I grew up, baking was like breathing." It was only after an entire year of intense investigation that she discovered her aunt had neglected to mention she used gravy browning to lend the cake its colour and flavour . "Gravy browning! Who would have thought of that?" Elaine said.
"Hmmmph," said Ann, but I could tell she was tucking it away.
They left shortly thereafter, and suddenly Maisie and I were at it. It was a brilliant, shiny day outside, the sun skipping across the water like a school of mackerel waiting to be caught.
"You take the pork fatback," Maisie began.
"How much pork fat?" I countered. I wasn't letting her get away with any vagueness.
"Well, I don't know," Maisie said in a faintly exasperated tone. "That much." She tossed a piece of white packaged pork fat onto the table - an inch thick, three inches by six inches in area. It looked disgusting. "It's not good for you. But I keep it frozen, because it's easier to cut that way."
She proceeded to show me how to cut the pork fat in thin, eighth-of-an-inch slices, down to but not through the rind. Then she told me to do the same again across the first set of cuts, at right angles. "Here, you do it, because this is the part I don't like."
With a perfect grid in place, Maisie cut the pork fat off the rind and then placed the lard dice in a large bowl. I could see all the way down her property to her shoreside fishing shack, where Newfoundlanders like to dry the cod they're still allowed to jig for family eating.
"You set the oven for 400 degrees." She did this. "Then you put the kettle on to boil, with lots of water. It has to be boiling." She did this too. "Then you take flour - "
"How much flour?"
"I don't know," she said. "This much." I counted 6½ cups. For someone who didn't know how much flour, she certainly knew when, exactly, to stop - she could have been titrating nitro, she was measuring so carefully. The flour went into the bowl over the tiny dice of fat. "Then some raisins."
"How many rai - "
"I don't know, a packet's worth." I snuck a look at the packet: 250 grams, boyo.
"Now you mix the flour and the raisins and the fat up." She looked at me. "Go on, do it. You have to see how it feels. That's the only way to know."
I washed my hands and plunged them into the dusty, fatty stir. It felt, appropriately, like cellulite.
Meanwhile, Maisie was talking about an aunt visiting from Burgeo, on the south coast, where Maisie had grown up the youngest of 15 children. Five died right away and 10 survived. There was no road into Burgeo; the only contact the village had with the outside world was via the mail boat that stopped by twice a week.
We turned back to the buns. "Now into the oven?" I asked.
"No, you still have to grease the cookie sheet. Vegetable oil, though butter or shortening if you want."
This, I did. I like to think I did a good job, but I might have been slightly obsessive.
"Then what I like to do is, I cut the leftover pork rind into little pieces" - Maisie proceeded to slice the slippery, revolting rind into quarter-inch squares - "and put them out on the cookie sheet, as much as you have. Those are for special. People who know pork buns look for the extra square of fat underneath." This was the real McCoy, the sort of secret trick one does not normally learn unless one dares to dig for the most intimate culinary intimacies.
"They're really good," Maisie said. "Then you take the boiling water - it has to be boiling - and you stir it into the flour. That melts the pork fat. Go on. And you add more if necessary."
I was about to ask how much more, but I realized it might drive her over the edge. It was the crucial moment. Secretly, I measured: Two cups of boiling water. "But you still want it quite dry," Maisie said.
I stirred. It was quite dry. I felt like a 12th-century apothecary.
"Now comes the fun part. You have to butter your hands." I did so. "More than that." By now, I had half a cup of butter on my paws. "And then you make them into little patties."
I formed one.
Maisie shot me a look. "That's too big."
It was harder than it looked. The batter was sticky and gluey, and the dough didn't hold. I made a bun, then another. I placed them on the sheet. Maisie's buns seemed perfect, smooth little creations two inches across. Mine looked like small tantrums. "Look at yours," she said. "That's not very good."
I applied more butter. The problem was that I was urban: I was treating the pork buns like gourmet hamburgers, to be handled as little as possible. In Toronto, the big internationalized city, handling was bad. In Newfoundland, where they make their own rules, the more handling the better.
I refashioned every bun I made. We popped them in the oven for an hour at 400 degrees. Then we had to wait.
A matter of context
"Let me show you the shack," Maisie said, and we walked down a curving wooden walkway to the water. She was talking by then - making a meal together will do that.
I imagined coming from a big family somehow softened fate and bad luck: One sibling dies, but there are still nine left. But the problem with a big family is that when they start to go, they really go. Maisie's brother Clyde still lives in Woody Point, where he's the publisher of Breakwater Books. But they had lost three sisters, their mother and a brother-in-law in a single year. "But everybody has something, some grief," she said. "You just get through it."
Then she pointed out over the water to a spot where she had recently jigged a 20-pound cod. Her son Greg, who's a chef in Las Vegas, had cooked it up on his last visit.
We walked back to the house and Maisie heated up some leftover cod tongues, cod and halibut for my breakfast, served with her homemade tomato and onion pickle. Half an hour in, we flipped the pork buns. A half-hour after that, they were golden brown, and done. She let me have one - and only one - hot out of the oven.
I have to say: Good food is good food, but great food is always a matter of context. A hot dog from a stand on Fifth Avenue in New York, after a day of walking; lamb Wellington, after an afternoon of anticipation in Paris; a pork bun in Woody Point, after a morning of labour. They are the same glory.
The bun was still searing hot in my mouth when Gordon Pinsent came down from his nap. "Hurro," I said, breathing steam and incapable of closing my mouth. "Ah jus' luhnd ta ma' pok buhs."
"Ah well," the great actor said. "You haven't lived until you've had a pork bun."
I have to agree. Not that I've had one since. By the time I got to the party that afternoon, they were gone.
Ian Brown is a Globe and Mail feature writer.
Maisie Wallace's
Newfoundland
Pork Buns
INGREDIENTS
1 3-by-6-inch packet pork fatback, roughly 1 inch thick, semi-frozen
1 kettleful (at least two cups) of boiling water
61/2 cups flour
250 grams dark raisins
Vegetable oil, butter or shortening for greasing baking sheet and hands
INSTRUCTIONS
Turn oven on at 400 degrees (F).
While fatback is still semi-gelid, make a series of 1/8-inch wide parallel lengthwise cuts in the pork fat, down to, but not through, the pork rind.
Repeat crosswise, also at intervals of 1/8-inch, down to but not through the rind.
Carefully slice the pork fatback off the rind into a large mixing bowl, reserving the rind.
Cut the rind into quarter-inch squares and set aside.
Add flour and raisins to pork-fat dice, and with bare hands mix thoroughly until raisins and pork-fat dice are well coated.
Grease large cookie sheet generously with oil or butter or shortening.
(Optional) Place small squares of pork rind, as many as you have, on cookie sheet at two-inch intervals. (There will be space left over on the cookie sheet.)
Add two cups boiling water to flour/fat/raisin mixture. Stir with wooden spoon to thoroughly mix and melt pork fat, but keep mixture quite dry.
Grease hands liberally with butter and form dough into round patties 2 inches in diameter and a scant 1 inch high. Patties should be well formed.
Place patties on greased baking sheet an inch or two apart, one pattie on top of each square of rind, until the rind squares run out (remaining patties will have no rind square).
Bake at 400 degrees for one half-hour; flip the patties and bake for a half-hour more, or until pork buns are golden brown.
Serve warm or at room temperature.

VAUGHAN

Full text: 21 LITTLE HANNAH LANE
ASKING PRICE: $629,900
SELLING PRICE: $607,000
TAXES: $4,973 (2008)
LOT SIZE: 42 by 125 feet
DAYS ON THE MARKET: 52
LISTING AGENT: Mike Zafiris, Realty Toronto Inc.
This 2,560-square foot house is one of the few smaller properties in the prestigious Upper Thornhill Estates community in Vaughan, where homes average between 3,000- and 3,500 square feet of living space, but can go up 4,000 square feet, says local agent Mike Zafiris.
But aside from its comparatively small size, it has several redeeming qualities, such as a premium 42-foot lot in a family-filled neighbourhood.
"It widens to 45 feet, and one side is as deep as 125 feet," Mr. Zafiris says, explaining that the backyard seems even deeper because the property behind it sits on an even larger plot of land.
"Most of the 42-foot wide homes have a standard 42 by 110 [foot measurement]."
To the side of the double garage, double mahogany doors open to a foyer with hardwood floors and crown moulding that flows throughout, from the powder room to the living room.
The dining room features French doors and coffered ceilings, while a gas fireplace provides the focus of the family room.
The eat-in kitchen is outfitted with stainless-steel appliances, glass backsplashes and granite counters.
All but one of the four bedrooms upstairs has California shutters, and each has access to one of three full bathrooms.
"In most subdivisions you get fairly large master ensuite," Mr. Zafiris adds. "This one was probably the size of a bedroom."
The basement is unfinished.

An urban condo fermented in memories

Author: Flaxman, Kathy

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/urban-condo-fermented-memories/docview/382689248/se-2?accountid=14656

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=An+urban+condo+fermented+in+memories&amp;author=Flaxman%2C+Kathy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-10&amp;spage=G.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=An+urban+condo+fermented+in+memories&amp;author=Flaxman%2C+Kathy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-10&amp;spage=G.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The wine flowed easily in this Cabbagetown suite ripe for new owners
31 WINCHESTER STREET,
UNIT 201 B
WHAT: A stunning two-storey, two-bedroom plus den contemporary condominium suite, completely refurbished. It features a light filled atrium and includes a private walled terrace facing south.
ASKING PRICE: $849,000
MAINTENANCE FEE: $664.16
TAXES: $3,455.94 (2008)
AGENT: Richard Silver, Bosley Real Estate Ltd.
Would it be rude to call this the house that Fat Bastard built?
Perhaps, but if you're a wine enthusiast, you would recognize the provocatively-named Australian wine that some say changed the way that wine was marketed. You might also recognize this home's owners - Peter Whitney and Marnie Griffith - who first brought Fat Bastard to Canada.
The couple say they saw the potential for this suite to serve as both their home and the base for their successful business the minute they laid eyes on it, back in 2001.
"From the outside, it was not prepossessing; you wouldn't necessarily know what to make of it, but once we stepped inside, we fell in love," Mr. Whitney says. "The suite reminded us of apartments in New York and Sydney, Australia. It was filled with light and was a wonderful space for entertaining and living. I could visualize the long bar in the kitchen as an excellent spot for wine tasting."
The home has layers of history. According to Peggy Kurtin, Chair of the Cabbagetown Heritage Conservation District Committee, the building is a hybrid Edwardian structure, notable for its yellow brick construction, erected in 1913 by builder J. & L. McKnight. Always a multi-family dwelling, records show that by 1938 there were 26 people living in the building.
With incarnations as a rooming house and then in the '70s an apartment building, in the '80's a stunning renovation took place. The suite at 201 B made a splash with its striking decor featuring pink walls, extensive use of mirrors, a hot tub on the deck and a black kitchen with a long bar/island begging to be used for parties. The festivities are the stuff of local legend, and it became know as the Pink Party Palace.
"We also have had many, many fantastic gatherings here," Mr. Whitney points out. "We would invite wine writers and restaurateurs and have the kitchen bar top filled with bottles of wine for tasting. We might entertain up on the deck, or step out to a restaurant for dinner to continue the discussion of wines. We, through our company, introduced the Fat Bastard wines to Canada from our home and office here. You could say Fat Bastard built this house."
"Or helped to pay for the renovations," Ms. Griffith laughs.
In the years that they have owned and occupied 201 B Winchester Street, Mr. Whitney and Ms. Griffith have completed extensive refurbishing, spending in the range of $100,000. The first four months of 2006 found Mr. Whitney and Ms. Griffith embarked on a cruise and trip to Australia, while Toronto interior designer Grace Price undertook a large part of the extensive renovation which included redoing the hardwood floors and gutting the two bathrooms, including the installation of an invitingly deep oval tub in the master ensuite. "I think the concept was that there could be a chair in the bath area and while one person soaks in the tub, the other could be seated and both could enjoy a glass of wine and chat in a candle-lit atmosphere," Ms. Price says.
Today, the unit is imbued with contemporary elegance and the walls are painted in a warm taupe called Straw Hat, unifying the decor, which while no longer pink is nonetheless stunning. The main floor of the suite is sun-filled thanks to a domed skylight the full length of the atrium/hall and floor-to-ceiling windows, many of which open onto Juliet balconies. A two-sided gas fireplace gives heat and ambiance to the living room and to the dining room, while the kitchen's black cabinetry has been outfitted with new hardware.
A floating staircase leads to the second floor with a den and a guest bedroom with ensuite bath and wood burning fireplace. Further down the hall there is a grand master bedroom suite, large enough for a respite from gaiety should one be desired. "We like the wood burning fireplace because there is really nothing like the smell of wood," Ms. Griffith notes. "The master bedroom opens onto the deck, but it can be closed off, in case someone wants privacy," Mr. Whitney points out.
The deck is protected by a sun shade and has stucco walls, giving what the owners call a very Santa Fe feeling.
The home is also at the hub of Cabbagetown activity. There's a deli and a corner store steps away, with the Winchester Hotel, now a restored landmark, nearby. "This is an eclectic, urban and unusual area and we love it," Ms. Griffith says. "We both have dual citizenship and we're going back to Australia now: the climate is more forgiving - they have sun 365 days of the year - but we will miss our home here."
***
THE AMENITIES
This luxury unit in a small condominium building has been entirely renovated and refurbished. It features a light-filled atrium floor, with painted tubular railings matching those on the floating staircase. There are three fireplaces: two gas burning, in the living room and the dining room and one wood burning in the guest bedroom. Ceiling heights on the main floor are over 12 feet and the atrium soars to a domed skylight running the full length of the area. The kitchen features stained black cabinetry with new hardware and countertops and a Blanco sink.
The second floor terrace is a spacious room-like space with stucco walls and sun shade, and is accessible both from the master bathroom and the hall. The master bedroom suite is spacious and singularly well appointed with custom built bedside cabinets and lighting reminiscent of those found in the luxury hotels frequented by the owners.
The home's space and ambience lends itself to contemporary living and extensive entertaining, with a long island bar in the sun-drenched kitchen and ample storage for food preparation and dining essentials.
There is parking for one car.
The common outdoor front courtyard has a mature ash tree, attractive plantings and well-kept hedges.

A home built to a different code

Author: Rand-Watkinson, Elizabeth

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/home-built-different-code/docview/382688889/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: An avid believer in "localism", a way of life that promotes practices like "The 100 Mile Diet", Mr. [Henry Wiersma] thinks of his house as "A 100 Mile House." All materials being used to build it are local. The clay for the compressed earth blocks comes from the surrounding land - the same property on which Mr. Wiersma's century farm sits. The straw will come from neighbouring fields.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+home+built+to+a+different+code&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-10&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+home+built+to+a+different+code&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-10&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Over the next few months - likely into spring 2009 if all goes as planned - I'll be writing periodic instalments covering the building of a compressed earth block house in the Northumberland Hills east of Toronto. The house is the brainchild of Henry Wiersma, a builder who, for 20 years, built custom homes using conventional materials and methods. All that changed about four years ago when Mr. Wiersma's approach to building took a dramatic shift.
He'd been introduced to several books, among them The Ancient Secret of The Flower of Life by Drunvalo Melchizedec, and Places of the Soul: Architecture and Environmental Design as a Healing Art by Christopher Day. The books espoused a concept centered around geometric shapes and their affect on life and prompted him to look at design differently.
The concept that caught Mr. Wiersma's attention concerns ancient geometric forms such as those used to build the pyramids. He says it's about "sacred geometry" and "how shape affects how we live in spaces."
With this earth block house, the concept is first glimpsed in the shape of the foundation, a footprint formed by a circle within a square. The points of the square aim north, south, east, and west and the entry door will face east, in accordance with Native North American custom.
The intent of the design is to create a space that is healthy and in harmony with the materials used to create it. "All materials release energy," Mr. Wiersma says. "Highly processed and dense synthetic materials like plastic and vinyl off-gas the chemicals used to make them. This can affect us physically and psychologically." On the other hand, softer organic materials like clay and straw, because they're natural, are thought to release harmonious energy.
An avid believer in "localism", a way of life that promotes practices like "The 100 Mile Diet", Mr. Wiersma thinks of his house as "A 100 Mile House." All materials being used to build it are local. The clay for the compressed earth blocks comes from the surrounding land - the same property on which Mr. Wiersma's century farm sits. The straw will come from neighbouring fields. The wood that will make up the second floor, roof, and porch is reclaimed from a nearby barn. Windows and doors will be made by local craftspeople in pine or fir.
The blocks Mr. Wiersma has made to build the house shouldn't be confused with traditional sun-baked adobe bricks which have manure and straw mixed into the clay. Instead, Mr. Wiersma used only clay in his blocks, mixed with a small amount (5 per cent) of cement. He used a compressed earth machine, feeding the raw materials into one end, with the finished blocks - measuring about 10-by-4-by-4 - emerging at the other end.
The blocks have all been made, the straw bales have been acquired, and a dome has been constructed over the site to keep the emerging structure and workers dry. The next step is to lay the blocks. In the spring, the 18-inch-thick straw bales will be added to the exterior of the building which will then be clad with a natural earth plaster. The result will be finished walls that are 28 inches thick, forming a natural insulation against both heat and cold. A wrap-around wooden porch will finish the project. The plan is to then make a barn of the same construction.
In the coming winter months, Mr. Wiersma will concentrate on the interior which will offer a kitchen, bathroom, and sitting room and stairs leading to an open loft with sleeping and studio space. The home will be heated with a radiant in-floor heating system where hot water is pumped through plastic tubing laid under the floor. The power to heat and pump the water will be a combination of solar, wood, and waste heat from an on-site generator.
When the structure is finished, Mr. Wiersma plans to rent it and I'm sure he'll have plenty of guests. People will no doubt be drawn to the structure's construction and tranquil location overlooking rolling hills with Lake Ontario glistening in the distance.
*****
Get involved
Mr. Wiersma welcomes volunteer workers interested in learning about sustainable building practices. Some volunteers live with the Wiersma family in their century farm house, participating in building projects in return for room and board. For more information on how you can volunteer, visit http://www.planetfriendly.net/gwd.php?id=5586 or contact Mr. Wiersma at hjwiersma@airnet.ca. Plans are in the works for an on-site school in sustainable building practices.
For readers interested in learning more about sacred geometry, see www.world-mysteries.com/sar_sage1.htm.

'A lengthy recession'

Author: McKenna, Barrie; Erman, Boyd

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lengthy-recession/docview/382761865/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "The benevolent fist of government will now join hands with Adam Smith in a most visible manner," said investor Bill Gross, who manages the world's largest bond fund. "Because it will, expect a lengthy recession but not depression."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27A+lengthy+recession%27&amp;author=McKenna%2C+Barrie%3BErman%2C+Boyd&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-07&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27A+lengthy+recession%27&amp;author=McKenna%2C+Barrie%3BErman%2C+Boyd&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-07&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   THE ECONOMY: World leaders struggle to agree on solutions as markets plunge sharply
Global leaders faced stark divisions over how to tackle the spiralling financial crisis yesterday as their governments tried to come to grips with another worldwide stock market plunge and a series of body blows to currencies from Australia to Iceland.
Sharp stock market declines around the world, a swoon in oil and other commodity prices, panic in Brazil and Russia and more bank troubles in Europe prompted calls for greater government and central bank intervention - but few signs of a global response.
In Europe, governments rushed to match guarantees on bank deposits and prevent a cross-border run on the continent's financial institutions.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel called on Europeans to craft a more unified response after a chaotic weekend summit with her French, Italian and British counterparts, who disagreed on key elements of a joint plan.
"The Europeans must show coherent action because, of course, we belong to a common currency zone," the Chancellor said.
South Korean officials, meanwhile, called for an emergency meeting with Japan and China.
And in the United States, the U.S. Federal Reserve Board opened up its credit spigot, authorizing $900-billion in loans to troubled banks, many of which have virtually stopped lending to consumers, businesses and each other.
In the face of unco-ordinated government action, World Bank President Robert Zoellick urged the creation of a new, larger Group of Seven that would include China, Russia, Saudi Arabia and others to solve the world's economic problems.
"The G-7 is not working," Mr. Zoellick, a former top Bush administration official, said in an uncharacteristically blunt speech in Washington. "We need a better group for a different time."
G7 finance ministers, including Canada's Jim Flaherty, are scheduled to meet this Friday in Washington to address the crisis that now extends well beyond the U.S. real estate and financial markets.
Already, optimism is fading that a $700-billion rescue of U.S. banks is enough put a stop to the credit crisis and avoid a global recession.
"Confidence is such a critical element right now, that if they [policy makers] come up a little short, it really, truly could be catastrophic," said Peter Gibson, a strategist at Desjardins Securities.
Widespread panic and fear of global recession gripped financial markets yet again yesterday, wiping out $2.2-trillion (U.S.) of value.
After twice falling more than 1,000 points as oil slumped, the Standard & Poor's/TSX Index rallied at the end of yesterday's trading to finish 572.92 points weaker at 10,230.43, the lowest close since October, 2005.
The index has now shed 2,000 points in just the past six trading days, and its total decline since peaking in June stands at 32 per cent.
In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average finished below 10,000 for the first time since 2004, while British stocks had their worst percentage loss since the crash of 1987. The carnage spread to emerging markets because of their reliance on commodities, with regulators twice halting chaotic trading in Brazil.
So far, responses have been ad hoc as national governments try to put out local fires, but signs of co-operation are growing.
The Fed announced it will begin paying interest on commercial banks' reserves and pledged to take "additional measures as necessary." The Bank of Canada injected $2.4-billion (Canadian) into overnight money markets - the largest such injection by the Canadian central bank in the past year.
Those seeds of a global response by governments sparked some optimism.
"The benevolent fist of government will now join hands with Adam Smith in a most visible manner," said investor Bill Gross, who manages the world's largest bond fund. "Because it will, expect a lengthy recession but not depression."
The issue now is what policy makers, even working in unison, can do to salvage the world economy. The U.S. government's plan to purchase troubled assets can only be the first step, said Mr. Gibson.
Next, the United States must find a way to deal with the housing market's decline to stop a slowdown in consumer spending from becoming a full-blown crisis of its own. Then central banks can begin to try to restart the heartbeat of global commerce with a shock-treatment of co-ordinated interest rate cuts.
Yesterday, as markets sounded new depths, there were calls for emergency interest-rate reductions. Investors now expect a half a percentage-point cut when the Fed's interest rate-setting committee meets later this month, if not before. A reduction in the Fed's key rate would cause a corresponding drop in what commercial banks charge on loans to millions of consumers and businesses.
However, some analysts cautioned that a cut now could fan the panic.
"It sends the signal that things are worse than they anticipated or that they know something the market doesn't, and it sometimes can add fuel to the fire," said Dustin Reid, senior foreign exchange strategist at RBS Greenwich Capital Markets.

India's biggest industrial barrier? Farmers

Author: Chopra, Anuj

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/indias-biggest-industrial-barrier-farmers/docview/382690535/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "A fear psychosis is being created to slow down certain projects of national importance," said Mukesh Ambani, the chairman of Reliance Industries. "This will be counterproductive for the country's economic growth, its global image as well as India's ability to attract investments from across the world."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=India%27s+biggest+industrial+barrier%3F+Farmers&amp;author=Chopra%2C+Anuj&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-07&amp;spage=B.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=India%27s+biggest+industrial+barrier%3F+Farmers&amp;author=Chopra%2C+Anuj&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-07&amp;spage=B.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Kiran Mhatre, 33, ekes out a living growing rice, fishing in the village pond, rearing livestock and cultivating miswak, a shrub whose twigs are used to maintain dental hygiene.
His family has lived off a three-acre patch of land for generations. And so when Reliance Industries Ltd., a powerful business conglomerate, offered him $25,000 for his land - an astronomical sum for a peasant who typically earns $600 a year - he declined.
"The money they're offering will dry up some time or the other," Mr. Mhatre said. "But our lands will feed our families throughout our lives."
Along the coastal belt of the western Indian state of Maharashtra, where fertile farms and salt flats are encircled by low-lying marshes, Reliance aims to build India's largest Special Economic Zone (SEZ) - a Chinese-style tax-free industrial enclave to promote trade and exports - comprising over 25,000 acres of land that would displace thousands of farmers across 22 villages in Raigad district.
As the economy surges, India is whetting a large appetite for industrialization. The Indian government has approved the creation of 250 SEZs across the country. But it faces a major hurdle: land procurement in a huge country where agriculture is still the mainstay.
With cities congested, the only free land available is fertile farmland in rural India. In a country where nearly two-thirds of the population - some 600 million people - live on farms, according to the National Sample Survey Organization in New Delhi, the government faces a major dilemma in how to divert this land to industries.
It's not just Reliance Industries, but a slew of other companies that are in a similar quandary. Dogged by violent protests from farmers who lost their lands, Tata Motors Ltd., an Indian car manufacturing giant, said last week it was going to abandon its small car manufacturing plant in Singur, in the eastern state of West Bengal. This plant was being built over a sprawling 997 acres of farmland from where Tata planned to roll out the Nano, billed as the world's cheapest car, during Diwali, the Indian festival of lights. Tata now plans to build this pint-sized car, expected to cost about $2,500, in rural Sanand in the western state of Gujarat.
Likewise, steel giant Lakshmi Mittal's ArcelorMittal is keen to set up steel units on 7,000 acres of land in the iron-rich tribal areas in the states of Jharkhand and Orissa, but faces an inordinate delay in land acquisition owing to stiff confrontation from local farmers.
Betel leaf farmers have held up a $12-billion project of the South Korean steel giant Posco in Orissa, occasionally kidnapping their officials.
In many instances, the transfer of land between farmers and corporations has occurred without conflict, but a large number of projects continue to remain stalled. According to the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, of industrial projects worth 70 trillion rupees ($1.5-trillion) planned in India, projects worth 2.5 trillion rupees ($54-billion) are stalled because of resistance in acquiring land.
"A fear psychosis is being created to slow down certain projects of national importance," said Mukesh Ambani, the chairman of Reliance Industries. "This will be counterproductive for the country's economic growth, its global image as well as India's ability to attract investments from across the world."
Industrialization, some economists argue, is the engine of India's economic resurgence, and shouldn't be stalled. Industrial enclaves like SEZs are expected to create millions of badly needed jobs for India's teeming millions and brings billions of dollars in foreign investment.
"I am reasonably sure that agriculture cannot offer productive employment opportunities to India's growing labour force," says Prof. Suresh Tendulkar of the Delhi School of Economics. "Consequently, transition to non-agricultural activities is inevitable."
India's farm sector grew by just 2.3 per cent over the past three years and grain production remains stagnant. Low crop yields, high interest rates charged by unscrupulous lenders and competition from farmers employing more advanced methods have caused thousands of peasants to commit suicide in recent years in India's south and west.
Feeling the need for some change, a government panel suggested amending India's archaic Land Acquisition Act to settle issues of land acquisitions from farmers. It recommends that 70 per cent of land for SEZs be bought by companies at market rates, a move aimed at ensuring farmers are well compensated when their land is taken for industrial growth.
However, in Mr. Mhatre's dusty village in Raigad district, called Malegharwadi, dirt roads remain pitted with bone-jarring potholes, water shortages are common, the power supply is erratic, and the nearest hospital is 80 kilometres away. But farmers are turning down Reliance's plump sums for their lands, impassive to the argument that the industrial project might bring jobs and economic prosperity to their doorstep.
"Some officials come and rattle off promises in English of providing cash and jobs for my family," Mr. Mhatre said, referring to Reliance company officials trying to cajole farmers to sell them their lands. "But you must understand that my land is my livelihood. It's not just a piece of real estate."

Finally, an issue: Who's going to bring the blue-collar jobs back

Author: MacGregor, Roy

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/finally-issue-whos-going-bring-blue-collar-jobs/docview/382770414/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: NDP candidate Oscar (Oz) Cole-Arnal, a Lutheran minister with a dash of fire-and-brimstone to his delivery, says Canadian job losses - "55,200 lost in July alone" - have been particularly "devastating" to the blue-collar Canadians he hopes to represent.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Finally%2C+an+issue%3A+Who%27s+going+to+bring+the+blue-collar+jobs+back&amp;author=MacGregor%2C+Roy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=A.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Finally%2C+an+issue%3A+Who%27s+going+to+bring+the+blue-collar+jobs+back&amp;author=MacGregor%2C+Roy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=A.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Hey, Stupid - it's not the environment, though there is a connection.
It's not leadership, though there should be a connection.
It's the economy, Stupid, just as you were told back in 1992 during that nasty Bill Clinton-George H.W. Bush campaign for the U.S. presidency.
Maybe you remember that far back: stock market throwing up on itself, real estate rotting, jobs shaky ...
This Canadian election has, so far, been the most penny (pun intended) dreadful campaign in memory, but there have been signs this week that, finally, one single issue is emerging.
Finally.
You heard hints of it in the two leaders' debates, but it was far more in evidence recently out on King Street, where volunteers from the Ontario Coalition for Social Justice were handing pamphlets out to anyone attending the all-candidates meeting going on in the Canada room of the local daily newspaper.
"Feeling insecure?" the pamphlets asked those who live and will vote in the manufacturing heart of Southwestern Ontario.
"Does Harper really care?"
You could find it upstairs in the Canada room, where the charmer of the evening's event turned out to be - steady now! - running for the Communist Party of Canada, a tiny political movement that wants to nationalize the oil and gas industry, wants a 32-hour work week with no pay cuts - and two years notice required by any business seeking to lay off workers.
When all six candidates - Liberal incumbent, Conservative, NDP, Green, Independent and the Communist - were asked by a member of the audience how voters could have faith that the various promises would be kept, Martin Suter grinned like a Cheshire cat, took a few chews of his gum, and gave an answer that brought down the house:
"Vote for me - and find out."
In some ways, that is what this election is coming down to. Vote - and find out. No wonder there is such nervousness in those parts of Ontario and Quebec where the job losses, so many of them in the auto sector, are mounting by the week. The nearby Toyota plant has decided not to go to a second shift. "Volvo to cut 500 jobs" in nearby Goderich reads a headline on the free copies of the Record being handed out to the 100 or more who have come to this all-candidates' meeting for the riding of Kitchener Centre.
It is October now, the time of Oktoberfest, but the beer has gone rather flat from the optimism and affluence of the past decade and more in this region of so much German heritage.
"There is no doubt," says Liberal Karen Redman, who has held this urban riding for the Liberals since 1997, "there is real pain in this community."
NDP candidate Oscar (Oz) Cole-Arnal, a Lutheran minister with a dash of fire-and-brimstone to his delivery, says Canadian job losses - "55,200 lost in July alone" - have been particularly "devastating" to the blue-collar Canadians he hopes to represent.
Tory candidate Stephen Woodworth, a mild-mannered lawyer, isn't even the incumbent, yet he gets all the heckling. He is blamed for failing to act on native land claims, for failing in Afghanistan, for doing nothing about the economy.
As the evening goes on, the election itself seems to evolve into that one outstanding issue. Cheryl Yan, a 27-year-old recent graduate of nearby University of Guelph, asks the final question of the night. What are they going to do about the economy?
Woodworth, speaking for Stephen Harper's Conservatives, acts as if everything that needs to be done is being done, that the economy is in good hands and requires little touch.
Redman, on the other hand, says, "There is a role for government" in hard times - a point echoed by all other candidates, including the grinning Communist candidate, who says that role should include a guaranteed annual income.
Clearly flustered at one point, the Conservative candidate says it only stands to reason that the economy would be at the top of people's minds now - "As Don Cherry might have said, 'It's not rocket surgery, is it?' "
Yan listens politely to all the answers but is hardly assured. She may have a freshly minted master's degree in hand, but that is not all that describes her.
"I'm unemployed," she says.
A couple of weeks back in Toronto, former Liberal minister Ken Dryden gave a speech in which he brilliantly tagged this irritating election as Stephen Harper's " Seinfeld campaign."
Up until this week, it had indeed been about nothing.
The only difference between it and Seinfeld was the Canadian general election of 2008 lacked a laugh track.
"This campaign is not about Mr. Harper," a frustrated Dryden said. "It is not about him ... This is a campaign about BIG, IMPORTANT things."
It is now. It is a campaign caught in a whirlwind of financial confusion.
Where every single candidate could say, as Martin Suter so succinctly put it:
"Vote for me - and find out."

____________________________________________________________

Offsite shouldn't mean out of the loop

Author: Vermond, Kira

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/offsite-shouldnt-mean-out-loop/docview/382690453/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "But a taped session isn't really ideal viewing. It's often poor quality and they're an hour and a half. Who's going to sit through that?" Ms. Israel says.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Offsite+shouldn%27t+mean+out+of+the+loop&amp;author=Vermond%2C+Kira&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=B.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Offsite+shouldn%27t+mean+out+of+the+loop&amp;author=Vermond%2C+Kira&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=B.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   On paper, your company should be crowned employer of the year. It offers loads of personal days, on-site daycare, an on-site gym, a rolling drinks cart every Friday afternoon and there's a steady stream of expert speakers traipsing in during the lunch hour to help employees balance their overscheduled lives.
But, besides the personal days, you don't get to enjoy any of these perks. You don't work at head office, but one of the satellite branches or from home. And although you know your boss is swilling and chilling come Friday, it's a cup of old coffee for you.
"Far-flung employees feeling like second-class citizens? We have to make them feel like first-class passengers," says Roy Saunderson, president of the Recognition Management Institute in Kingsville, Ont., which has its head office in Montreal. Mr. Saunderson is a teleworker himself. "They're often saving the company money in real estate costs, so we can actually invest a little more in those employees who are offsite."
Don't get no respect
Maybe it's a simple matter of out of sight (and off site), out of mind.
"How many times have you had a virtual meeting and nobody's sent you the agenda? But guess what? Head-office folks have all got it because they're in the room," Mr. Saunderson says.
These little hiccups, leading to a general feeling of being disconnected, is exactly why Aimee Israel, chief executive officer of Toronto-based LifeSpeak Inc. - an organization that sends experts to companies to offer lifestyle seminars - recently started offering an online service. Employees who work for companies that have signed on can view 10-minute taped segments on their computers at work or at home about anything from what to do when their child has a fever to how to alleviate stress.
Before the online sessions launched, clients were asking to tape the speakers.
"But a taped session isn't really ideal viewing. It's often poor quality and they're an hour and a half. Who's going to sit through that?" Ms. Israel says.
One of her clients, Rajesh Uttamchandani, senior vice-president of human resources at CIBC Mellon in Toronto, agrees. Teleconferences and video conferences didn't succeed either.
"They were very expensive and they didn't seem to work as well. The employees still didn't feel like they were part of it," Mr. Uttamchandani says.
The virtual way
While high-quality taped sessions might be a start, Polly Pearson, vice-president of employment brand and strategy engagement for EMC Corporation in Hopkinton, Mass., says online virtual tools can make a real difference in helping employees connect, no matter where they are.
Last year the company launched an internal social networking site for all 40,500 workers around the world.
"It's all about knowledge and contribution, not about hierarchy or location," she says.
But Elaine Kunda, president and CEO of online local directory ZipLocal Inc. in Toronto, isn't convinced high-tech solutions can replace the good-old-fashioned face-to-face meeting or hanging around the lunch room with co-workers.
"It's the responsibility of the company to do whatever they can with the means they have," she maintains, "But it will never be the same. I don't believe that at all."
ZipLocal's own Montreal employees sometimes complain about feeling out of the loop, she says, even though she tries to send someone from head office there every three weeks, includes the employees in the company's newsletter and is setting up an employee blog. Still, in an era of multiple offices, turning to technology is the best any company can hope for.
Recognition rules
There are lots of ways to help remote workers feel like they're part of the team, however, Mr. Saunderson says. Bosses - not the company's HR department - need to keep track of these employees' anniversaries and other milestones and send a message on that day. Outlook and the like, with their automatic reminders, are a godsend.
"It's easy to forget when someone is out of sight," he maintains. "But we have to put this into the hands of managers and give them the tools and training on how to build these long-distance relationships."
Connection and recognition are everything to employees who feel left out. Supervisors can also leave a positive message on an offsite employee's voicemail overnight so when they arrive at work the next morning it's there waiting for them.
"No, this isn't a customer or a colleague. This is my boss, thanking me. Imagine the uplift that would create," he says.
The upside
It goes both ways. Sometimes absence makes the heart grow fonder. When you're at home you can actually feel stronger about your employer. You're not pulled into all of the politics. You also become an ambassador for that organization when you're out there doing your own thing.
Richard Davis, management psychologist for consultants RHR International Inc., Toronto
The downside
As soon as people are in a satellite office or working from home, they're never going to feel completely aligned with head office. I think you can do as much as you can to make it comfortable and make people as accessible as possible, but it's never going to be the same. They miss out on the camaraderie in the office and understanding the day-to-day.
Elaine Kunda, president and CEO of ZipLocal Inc., Toronto
Keeping connected
Employees who work offsite or in a satellite office may not be right where the action is, but here are a few ways to keep them from feeling like second-class citizens:
If the company offers localized benefits such as on-site daycare or gym facilities, make sure other employees receive a similar and related benefit, such as money earmarked for childcare or a gym membership.Stay connected. Managers need to call in from time to time just to see how the employee is doing. Don't just send e-mails.
Host regional events so far-flung employees can attend.
Offsite and satellite employees need recognition, too - and they're more likely to think they don't get it. Include their wins in the company newsletter or send a handwritten thank-you card. These small touches make a difference.
Credit: globecareers@globeandmail.com

Credit taps running dry in the U.S.

Author: McKenna, Barrie

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/credit-taps-running-dry-u-s/docview/382690322/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: That's because the rescue is intended to be as much a psychological boost as a liquidity injection. The program's success will depend to a large extent on peoples' "expectations" of what's happening, Prof. [Mark Loewenstein] said.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Credit+taps+running+dry+in+the+U.S.&amp;author=McKenna%2C+Barrie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=B.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Credit+taps+running+dry+in+the+U.S.&amp;author=McKenna%2C+Barrie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=B.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Businesses, consumers and even state governments left in the lurch
In the chaotic two weeks it took to get a monster bank rescue through the U.S. Congress, the credit crisis has spread like a virus, infecting people and companies far beyond its epicentre in U.S. housing.
Many Americans can't get car loans. Companies of all kinds are struggling to secure operating cash. Banks and brokerages are too afraid to lend to each other. And many state and local governments are facing financial ruin because they can't issue bonds to pay for roads, schools and other essential services.
California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former tough-guy actor, sounded like a frightened man as he begged U.S. Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson this week for a $7-billion (U.S.) emergency loan.
"Absent a clear resolution to this financial crisis, California and other states may be unable to obtain the necessary level of financing to maintain government operations and may be forced to turn to the federal treasury for short-term financing," the Governor wrote to Mr. Paulson. "California is so large that our short cash-flow needs exceed the entire budget of some states."
California is big, but it isn't alone. U.S. states are required by law to balance their budgets every year. So they typically borrow cash at the start of the year, paying off those loans when sales and property tax revenues come in later in the year. But with fear gripping lenders, that kind of arrangement isn't available at a reasonable cost, if at all.
The situation in the commercial paper market is particularly worrisome. Otherwise solvent companies risk going into default because they can't roll over their maturing debt.
Indeed, outstanding commercial paper fell by more than $97-billion in the week ended Oct. 1, the U.S. Federal Reserve said this week.
Commercial credit markets have begun to take on the atmosphere of a back-alley, loan-shark operation. On Thursday, nearly 100 corporate treasurers from across the United States joined in an emergency conference call to complain of problems renewing lines of credit, including exorbitant fees and interest rates, driven higher by fear as much as fundamentals.
"It is now clear that the U.S. financial system is in cardiac arrest," economist Nouriel Roubini of New York University warned ominously yesterday.
Some U.S. companies are now looking in unconventional places to avoid the less palatable alternatives in the dysfunctional credit market.
Without explanation, Xerox Corp. said yesterday it would tap into excess cash available in its Canadian subsidiary, Xerox Canada, to secure a $300-million (Canadian) loan.
U.S. authorities warned of economic Armageddon without a monster bank rescue. The danger now is that the worst-case scenario may happen anyway.
Compounding the problem, the world's largest economy is almost certainly in recession, and the rest of the planet may not be far behind.
The latest in a wave of grim economic news was a report yesterday that 159,000 jobs vanished in September - the most in five years.
"Beyond the attention-grabbing crisis in financial markets, the long-running crisis in the real economy continues," said Jared Bernstein, senior economist with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington.
U.S. factories are gearing down, consumers are pulling back and the housing market has yet to find a bottom. Consider that lenders in the three counties that make up South Florida have foreclosed on residential properties worth more than $14-billion (U.S.) so far this year, according to a new report by consultant Peter Zalewski of Condo Vultures, and that's just one of dozens of key U.S. real estate markets.
The theory, according to the bailout's boosters, is that if the Treasury can relieve financial institutions of toxic mortgage assets, like those in South Florida, banks will then have more capital to resume normal lending - to businesses, consumers and each other.
More importantly, the sheer size of the package is designed to re-establish confidence that the government is on top of the problem.
Not everyone is convinced.
Mark Loewenstein, an associate professor of finance at the University of Maryland, said the details of the proposed bank bailout remain as murky as its ultimate impact.
"I don't think anyone can say if this will work," Prof. Loewenstein said.
That's because the rescue is intended to be as much a psychological boost as a liquidity injection. The program's success will depend to a large extent on peoples' "expectations" of what's happening, Prof. Loewenstein said.
"By showing a lot of money up front, maybe people start participating in credit markets again," he explained. "But it's impossible to know whether all the other lending channels will unclog."
Billionaire investor Warren Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said the bailout provides "some tools" to deal with the country's economic woes, but he insisted the crisis isn't over.
"This is not a panacea," Mr. Buffett told CNBC after the vote. "This does not solve all our problems."
Mr. Buffett's behaviour, however, suggests the notoriously astute investor believes the bottom may not be far off. In recent weeks, Berkshire Hathaway has scooped up $8-billion worth of investment bank Goldman Sachs and industrial giant General Electric at fire-sale prices.
The program could help unleash a wave of capital that is poised to buy distressed subprime mortgage debt and other assets, bringing new liquidity to the system.
While the credit crunch has been sucking money out of the banking system, enormous pools of capital, including foreign pension funds, sovereign wealth funds, and private family institutions have been building up.
"These pools of capital are waiting on the sidelines and preparing to deploy," CIBC chief financial officer Gerald McCaughey said in an interview yesterday.
The U.S. bailout program could be one of the catalysts that tells them "it is time to get moving if they want to invest," he said.
Credit: With files from reporter Tara Perkins

Condo cash was going to save Regent Park. Kiss that idea (and others) goodbye

Author: Barber, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/condo-cash-was-going-save-regent-park-kiss-that/docview/382689851/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "These guys close their doors fast," said one. "It's common knowledge that even the most robust developers are having trouble getting financing. It's tough, tough, tough."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Condo+cash+was+going+to+save+Regent+Park.+Kiss+that+idea+%28and+others%29+goodbye&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Condo+cash+was+going+to+save+Regent+Park.+Kiss+that+idea+%28and+others%29+goodbye&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-10-04&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Toronto developers who weren't too busy this week searching for new bankers to finance their pre-sold but un-built housing projects passed time gossiping about which of them would fail first. The targets of anxiety varied, but the consensus was clear: No matter how orderly the eventual cleanup may or may not be, the party's over.
For some, the job is to replace financing promised by defunct Lehmann Brothers of New York, which until recently was active in the local condo market. Others are being forced to dig deeper into their own pockets to shore up the waning confidence of nervous bankers.
Pre-sales to willing buyers count for little in the new environment: Some industry veterans are now being asked to produce actual building permits before their banks will let them begin construction.
"These guys close their doors fast," said one. "It's common knowledge that even the most robust developers are having trouble getting financing. It's tough, tough, tough."
Whatever happens next week or next year, the late boom will be remembered as having transformed the central city, with tens of thousands of new apartments standing as evidence of dramatically renewed vitality. But outside the magic core, in older suburbs desperately seeking new investment, nothing will have changed.
In that respect, the most obvious victim of the credit crunch is the city itself, which has invested so much political capital in the promise of ever-increasing real-estate values. Sagging values clearly imperil such signature policies as waterfront renewal, the land-transfer tax, social-housing rehabilitation and even the vaunted Mayor's Tower Renewal program.
Barring a miracle, the new tower now rising at the corner of Dundas and Parliament will be the last evidence of the much-anticipated revitalization of Regent Park, Canada's largest public-housing project - and the city's most ambitious attempt to use condo sales to finance social policy.
There was a time it almost seemed possible. Senior governments had abandoned the housing business and land values were soaring. The solution was to sell off part of the site for market housing in order to rebuild public housing on the rest.
But even in the best of times, the city was unable to find a developer to take the risk. Undeterred, it self-financed construction of the first "market" building. With even the most prominent developers now struggling to finance construction on prime midtown sites, there seems little hope for Regent Park.
And Lawrence Heights, that other battered public-housing neighbourhood in a much more remote location, currently awash in talk of similar, bootstrap-style revitalization? Forget it. Without real money from government, nothing will happen.
Waterfront redevelopment is much less challenging in theory, but one look at the harbourfront shows what happens when policy-driven authorities attempt to surf against the waves, developing housing in a "negative equity" market. Their failure takes permanent shape on the skyline.
With its ambitious plans for the East Bayfront on the other side of Yonge Street, Waterfront Toronto has set the same trap for itself, promising all kinds of goodies that the real estate is supposed to pay for. It was a good plan yesterday.
Although still inchoate, the Mayor's Tower Renewal could emerge as the ultimate victim of the crunch.
Most of the magic money needed to finance this revitalization scheme is expected to come from energy savings. Presuming the same economics applies tomorrow, many old high-rises will get new winter coats over the next few years. But the big moves intended to revive distressed neighbourhoods as a whole depend on real-estate leverage that no longer exists.
While it lasted, the real-estate boom presented an interesting alternative to government-financed social policy. Significant revitalization occurred, but only in locations dictated by the market.
The rest of the city waited patiently for a turn, it now seems clear, that will never come.
Credit: jbarber@globeandmail.com
