'He was the real spirit of Cadillac Fairview'

Author: Martin, Sandra

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/he-was-real-spirit-cadillac-fairview/docview/382757973/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: That "opportunity" was the beginnings of Cadillac Fairview. Jack Kaiman, owner of Camesco Lighting Ltd., had business expertise and money. Joe Berman, also from an immigrant family and an engineer (with a degree from U of T) had become friends with Mr. Diamond in the navy when they were both posted to St. John's in 1944. He worked for Mr. Kaiman and had access to some family money. Mr. Diamond had no money and no financial assets other than a heavily mortgaged $14,000 house.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27He+was+the+real+spirit+of+Cadillac+Fairview%27&amp;author=Martin%2C+Sandra&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-20&amp;spage=S.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27He+was+the+real+spirit+of+Cadillac+Fairview%27&amp;author=Martin%2C+Sandra&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-20&amp;spage=S.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: As a CEO who ran one of North America's biggest real-estate enterprises, he was an electrical engineer who capitalized on the post-war building boom and then helped to change the face of urban Canada
Real-estate czar Eph Diamond was the antithesis of the cartoon image of a rapacious, ruthless, ostentatious developer, dripping in gold jewellery and smoking a stogie - except for the cigar part - especially in his younger years. A co-founder of Cadillac-Fairview, once one of the largest real-estate empires in North America, he was a key player behind Erin Mills, the Toronto-Dominion Centre, The Eaton Centre, Yorkdale Shopping Centre, Vancouver's Pacific Centre and dozens of other apartment and office complexes and shopping malls in Canada and the United States.
A smart boy from a poor immigrant family, he made millions transforming the postwar urban and suburban landscape. And yet, he lived a modest family-centred life according to a simple code: Honesty reaps more than its own reward. "If scoundrels were aware of the benefits of being honest, they would be honest out of pure rascality," was one of his trademark comments.
"Eph was one of those rare developers who cared about life's elegances and decencies, outside the bottom line. He was one of a kind - and had a sense of humour to boot," said writer Peter Newman, an archeologist of the Canadian business elite in books such as The Canadian Establishment and The Bronfman Dynasty .
"Eph Diamond was one of the finest people I ever met in my life," said Tom Kierans, a senior corporate director and a shrewd and tough observer of human nature and economic activity. "Integrity ... He reeked of it."
John (Jack) Daniels, who became a partner in Cadillac in the very early 1960s, said: "You couldn't wish for a finer human being. We spent more time together running the company than we did with our wives. I was the outside man and he was the inside man," said Mr. Daniels, explaining that he brought in new projects and Mr. Diamond ran the company.
"I knew him because in my former life [politics] the development industry was very interested in the economic growth of the province," said former Ontario premier Bill Davis. "He represented the best of the development industry ... and was one of the finest, most decent individuals that I met during my time in public life. He was the real spirit of Cadillac Fairview and I think I could safely say he was highly regarded by his contemporaries in the industry."
Business was far from Mr. Diamond's only preoccupation. "Almost from the inception of him working for Cadillac in 1953, I think he always felt a sense of community," said his son, Stephen Diamond. Although not a religious man, Mr. Diamond was heavily involved in the founding and building of Temple Sinai, a synagogue in North Toronto, because he wanted his sons to have an opportunity to learn about their religious and cultural tradition, according to Rabbi Michael Dolgin.
The rabbi described a rancorous meeting to elect the first president of the temple. "When there were some hard feelings, Eph got up and made a speech about how even the people who didn't get the votes needed to be treated with respect and welcomed as part of the community. People were so taken with what he had to say and how he said it, that when the person who had been running for president [and had lost] refused to be vice-president, they all nominated Eph," said Mr. Dolgin. Mr. Diamond became the second president of the temple and was a key player in building the synagogue. "He did business well because he didn't just do business. He saw what was right and talked regularly with his sons and others about the benefits of doing things in the honest, right way."
Allen Ephraim Diamond was born in Montreal after the First World War, the second of four children of Latvian immigrant and shoemaker Meyer Diamond and his wife, Alice (Chowsky). Times were tough, so the Diamonds moved to Brockville around 1925 because they thought a smaller town might offer better prospects. They left Eph, who was then four or five, with his grandparents in Montreal so that he could continue to attend the local yeshiva. When he was somewhere between 10 and bar-mitzvah age, he joined his parents and siblings in Brockville, where he attended local schools and, as a teenager, worked part-time in a store to help with family finances.
When Eph came home one day and told his parents that his boss had offered him a full-time job, his proud mother saw a rosy future for her son. At dinner, she suggested that Eph might one day aspire to the position of store manager, if he quit school and grabbed this opportunity. But his father had other ideas. Rattling his plate in anger, according to some versions of the oft-told tale, he roared: "And if he becomes a store manager, what is that?" Instead, the boy stayed in school and his father borrowed against a life-insurance policy, money that Eph combined with his summer earnings, to pay for tuition and board at Queen's University in Kingston, Ont. He studied electrical engineering and graduated cum laude with a bachelor of science in 1943.
He immediately enlisted in the Royal Canadian Navy, serving as a radar officer for the next three years - despite being chronically seasick - at postings in Newfoundland and Bermuda. On leave in August, 1945, he met Shirley Greenberg, a young woman from St. Catharines, Ont., who was holidaying with a couple of girl friends. He was immediately smitten, but she found him a bit too serious and stood him up on the last day. "It was the smartest thing I ever did," Mrs. Diamond said, "because he never forgot me." About a year later, after having been discharged from with the rank of lieutenant, he moved to Toronto and invited her to a Queen's versus University of Toronto football game and dance.
"I was a small-town girl and that sounded pretty nice to me," she said in an interview. More attracted by the occasion, than Mr. Diamond, she went looking for a good time and found "the person I knew I wanted to spend more time with," she said. "After that, I chased him until he caught me." Following a very rapid courtship - they lived in different cities - they married the day after her 21st birthday on Sept. 15, 1946. Eventually, they had four sons: Michael, Stephen, Carey and Mark.
After leaving the navy, Mr. Diamond was offered a job teaching engineering at a university in the Maritimes but turned it down because, as he liked to say, he had already met Ms. Greenberg. Instead, he got a job in construction as a project engineer at Principal Investments.
There had been almost no housing built during the war because most economic, construction and manufacturing activities were concentrated on the war effort, so when peace came, there was an enormous need for new housing stock and shopping facilities for returning veterans eager to start families and enjoy life after the horrors and deprivations of the previous six years. "He was the best friend of my brother-in-law Abe Berlin," said Avie Bennett, whose family owned Principal, explaining that the two men had been classmates at Queen's and then had joined the navy together. Mr. Diamond was put in charge of construction of Sunnybrook Plaza at Bayview and Eglinton - the first shopping centre in Toronto. After that success, Mr. Diamond was asked to supervise the construction of Lawrence Plaza, a much larger development.
After seven years with Principal Investments, he quit to go into business with two partners. Saying that his family had the "highest, highest" regard for Mr. Diamond, because he was "intelligent, industrious and very capable," Mr. Bennett added: "We were sorry to see him go, but happy that he had an opportunity to improve himself. I never met anybody who didn't like him."
That "opportunity" was the beginnings of Cadillac Fairview. Jack Kaiman, owner of Camesco Lighting Ltd., had business expertise and money. Joe Berman, also from an immigrant family and an engineer (with a degree from U of T) had become friends with Mr. Diamond in the navy when they were both posted to St. John's in 1944. He worked for Mr. Kaiman and had access to some family money. Mr. Diamond had no money and no financial assets other than a heavily mortgaged $14,000 house. However, he had construction experience. Specifically, he knew how to take a vacant piece of land, equip it with electricity and other services and put up houses and apartments. Mr. Kaiman knew Mr. Diamond as a customer who bought fixtures from him for his construction projects at Principal. When Mr. Diamond went to Camesco to buy fixtures for his own house, he insisted on paying in cash, despite Mr. Kaiman's offers to cut him a deal in return for all the business that Mr. Diamond had sent his way. "I thought, there's a guy I want to go into business with," Mr. Kaiman said later, explaining why he offered to lend Mr. Diamond $40,000 to invest in the company.
The three would-be partners met in Eddie Goodman's law office on Queen Street West to iron out the particulars and then repaired to the Town Tavern for a round or two of Cokes and more talk. "Picture four short guys who looked like construction workers in fancy clothes, guys whose collective idea of haute cuisine was corned beef on rye," is the way the editors of Canadian Business described them in Guts, Greed and Glory: A Visual History of Modern Canadian Business. The plan was to build apartments, use the rent for cash flow while building houses and then turn the profits back into the company to build equity in the apartment buildings. From the beginning, they adhered to the philosophy that if a property was enticing enough to build, it was good enough to keep. The word "flip" was not part of their lexicon.
What to call the new company was solved when the four men walked to Mr. Kaiman's car, looked at his 1951 navy-blue Cadillac sedan, and experienced the mental equivalent of switching on a light bulb. Of course, Mr. Goodman, the lawyer, pointed out the obvious - that General Motors might object - but they could not be dissuaded from naming their baby company Cadillac Contracting and Developments Ltd. and using a stylized drawing of a Cadillac as their first corporate logo. Mr. Diamond was president and chief-executive officer.
Six years later, the company had grown so exponentially that Mr. Diamond formed Whitecastle Investments Ltd. as a holding company for his own family.
From the early years, Cadillac was an integrated development company, with its own planners and labour force and separate divisions for residential, office buildings and shopping centres. This was especially true after the firm started working with CEMP Investments, the holding company for the children of Seagram's controlling shareholder, Samuel Bronfman, and had become involved in joint ventures with other real estate interests, including apartment developer John (Jack) Daniels.
By 1960, Cadillac was no longer a start-up company, and that took a lot of the fun out of it for Mr. Kaiman, one of the founding partners. He dropped out, selling his one-third interest to Mr. Daniels. Another partner, chartered accountant Gerald (Gerry) Shear, joined shortly thereafter. Under Mr. Diamond's shrewd direction, the company, which was reorganized as Cadillac Development Corporation Ltd. on Jan 1, 1964, acquired a large interest in Canadian Equity and Development Ltd., and its subsidiary, Don Mills Developments Ltd., from E. P. Taylor's massive real-estate holdings in Erin Mills and Mississauga. They formed a joint venture with CEMP to develop subdivisions. Four years later, Cadillac went public.
The company was land-rich and relatively cash-poor, so in 1974 Mr. Diamond began negotiating with Leo Kolber to merge with Fairview, a subsidiary of the Bronfman-owned CEMP Investments. By the time the deal was completed in 1976, the new conglomerate, Cadillac Fairview, comprised Cadillac Development, Fairview and Canadian Equity and Development. The Bronfman family was in control (with 35 per cent), but Mr. Diamond was the ultimate manager as president and CEO until he retired from running the company in 1979. He remained on the executive committee of the board of directors until the company was sold by the Bronfmans in 1987 to the JMB Realty Corp., a group of U.S. pension funds. The company was bought by the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan in 2000.
Meanwhile, Mr. Diamond had become more actively involved in Whitecastle, the family holding company, taking on the role of president and investing in real estate and private companies both on his own and in joint ventures with other investors. In 1989, he semi-retired, spending close to half the year in Florida with his wife. By then his third son, Carey Diamond, had joined Whitecastle and the firm had begun its transition away from real estate and into investing in emerging private companies. In the late 1990s, the elder Mr. Diamond became chairman and Carey Diamond assumed the roles of president and CEO of Whitecastle Investments. Further changes occurred in 2005 when they launched Whitecastle Private Equity Partners, a buyout fund with Eph Diamond as a member of the advisory board. Earlier this year they went back into real estate with the creation of New Urban Fund, a development fund managed by son number two, lawyer Stephen Diamond, again with Eph Diamond on the advisory board.
Mr. Diamond had one of his few management and negotiating failures when his friend Lotfi Mansouri, then general director of the Canadian Opera Company, persuaded him to become the founding chair of the Ballet Opera House Corporation in 1976. After a decade of frustration, he resigned in 1986, the year after David Peterson became premier of a Liberal minority government. Mr. Peterson questioned both the economics of the project and the choice of the site at Bay and Wellesley Streets in Toronto, a parcel of land had been promised to the Ballet Opera House Corp. in a letter written to Mr. Diamond by Mr. Davis early in 1985, just before he resigned as premier. Mr. Davis said, "I think if I had stayed as premier for another four-year term, and if those involved had come forward with something that was economically manageable, that site [which he still considers the best choice] might have been developed." The opera house, or more accurately, The Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts, was finally opened in 2006 -after what was often called "the 30 years war" - with a different architect, a different general director of the COC and a different site, and without the participation of the National Ballet Company.
Mr. Diamond also sat on the boards of Ontario Hydro, Mount Sinai Hospital, Baycrest Centre for Geriatric Care and several other organizations. A major player in the Canadian Friends for the Hebrew University, he set up a bursary fund that is awarded equally to Arab and Jewish Israelis. His last philanthropy was to raise money for Save a Child's Heart, an organization that brings children with heart problems, and their families, from African and Arab countries to Israel for corrective surgery. "It was a typical example of his philosophy," said Carey Diamond, that he would try to save children's lives, but in doing so it "was his hope" that it would promote "a greater understanding between people" by having the families meet and talk with each other.
In 1978, Mr. Diamond had a health scare when he developed problems in his carotid artery, presaging a potential stroke. He had preventive surgery to repair the artery in the early eighties and then a quadruple bypass several years later. While still active in Whitecastle, he was spending a great deal more time with his children and grandchildren, a retirement that was cut short when the graft on his carotid artery gave way, less than two weeks before the Diamonds were due to celebrate their 52nd wedding anniversary.
EPH DIAMOND
Allen Ephraim Diamond, M.C. L.L.D, was born in Montreal on March 1, 1921. He died in Toronto of heart disease at Toronto General Hospital on Thursday, Sept. 4, 2008. He was 87. He leaves his wife, Shirley, four sons, 13 grandchildren, his sister Marsha Gottlieb and his extended family.

In a key riding, Christine Innes takes on her husband's nemesis: Olivia Chow

Author: Preville, Philip

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/key-riding-christine-innes-takes-on-her-husbands/docview/382687336/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Ms. Chow applauds her opponent's decision to run. "It's not an easy decision to make, especially with four children," she says. "But when she says, 'It's my time' " - the words Ms. [Christine Innes] used when she kicked off her campaign on Sept. 5 - "I certainly know that feeling."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=In+a+key+riding%2C+Christine+Innes+takes+on+her+husband%27s+nemesis%3A+Olivia+Chow&amp;author=Preville%2C+Philip&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-20&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=In+a+key+riding%2C+Christine+Innes+takes+on+her+husband%27s+nemesis%3A+Olivia+Chow&amp;author=Preville%2C+Philip&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-20&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It may yet turn out to be Tony Ianno's last laugh.
Mr. Ianno, the four-time Liberal MP for Trinity-Spadina who beat the NDP's Olivia Chow in 1997 and again in 2004 before losing to her in 2006, always insisted that he would be back for yet another rematch.
But on the eve of the election call, Mr. Ianno says, he had a change of heart.
After spending more than a decade in Ottawa, away from his wife and children, he suddenly realized how much he was enjoying private life.
"I go to my kids' soccer games, and I just sit there," he says to his own astonishment - no double-booked agenda, no buzzing BlackBerry, no plane to catch back to Ottawa. And so, at the very last minute, Mr. Ianno decided to step aside, finally putting an end to the bitter, nasty Ianno-Chow feud.
It's a nice story; it may even be true. There's only one reason to doubt his sincerity: The candidate running in his place is as strategically shrewd a choice as any the Liberals could have made. Her name is Christine Innes, an Annex lawyer and mother of four, active in the community, and a lifelong Liberal volunteer. She also managed all of Mr. Ianno's campaigns.
And she happens to be his wife.
Ms. Innes's candidacy has made the campaign more civil, at least on the surface.
Ms. Chow applauds her opponent's decision to run. "It's not an easy decision to make, especially with four children," she says. "But when she says, 'It's my time' " - the words Ms. Innes used when she kicked off her campaign on Sept. 5 - "I certainly know that feeling."
Beneath the veneer, however, Ms. Chow also knows that, in one of the city's most competitive races, Ms. Innes will have the backing of Mr. Ianno's formidable election machine: a canvassing operation that can blanket the riding within two weeks, and a database built and refined over six campaigns, assigning each voter a bar code to better track address changes. "Tony has never lent his machine to anybody, and nobody else would have gotten it," says a Liberal insider.
"Anyway, it's her machine as much as his. A lot of people were really working for Christine, not Tony."
Incumbents always have an edge in any campaign, and that remains true here. Ms. Chow has a formidable machine of her own, and Ms. Innes, though beloved by local Liberals, can't match Ms. Chow's name recognition in every corner of the riding.
But there's another factor at play: Trinity-Spadina, long the archetypal Toronto riding with its mix of white- and blue-collar workers and its Portuguese, Italian and Chinese communities, has been radically transformed by the real-estate boom.
Resale prices have surged, particularly in the Annex but also throughout the riding. Census data show that average home values here have increased from $292,519 in 2001 to $408,585 in 2006, a 40-per-cent increase that has spurred many long-time residents to cash in and give way to young, affluent urban families.
And the rash of condominiums to the south, near the waterfront, are packed with new voters - young professionals with no attachment to any of the area's long-time local representatives, and no party affiliation. Traditional power bases are eroding as the riding gets younger and richer.
Trinity-Spadina no longer eats lasagna and spends its evenings on the front porch; it goes to the gym after work and eats vegetarian. This ain't your nonna's neighbourhood.
On one morning this week, the residents of the condominium tower at 18 Yonge St. streamed out the doors and turned north, walking beneath the railway tracks on their way to work downtown. There is a uniformity to them. They are young. They are nattily dressed in business attire: slim suits and ties for the men, knee-length skirts and heels for the women. They have sunglasses, iPods and BlackBerrys. They are diverse in skin colour, including people from South Asia and the Middle East, though they also sport the standard uniforms and accessories. And they are politically unaffiliated.
"I might vote Green," says Greg, a twentysomething resident who works in financial services. Greg says he is also considering the Liberals, and that he "probably won't vote NDP."
Syma, a law clerk in her early 30s, voted Liberal last time around, "but I'm not sure this time. I thought [Stephen] Harper was doing a good job. And Jack Layton has been running a good campaign. I might vote for either one."
These voters aren't merely undecided - they're wild cards, failing to occupy a reliable spot on the traditional left-right spectrum. And there's more than enough to swing the seat back into the Liberal fold.
The numbers are eye-popping. According to Jane Renwick, vice-president of the real-estate research firm Urbanation, since the last election in 2006, a total of 33 new condo towers have been completed in Trinity-Spadina, for a total of 8,888 new units.
"And we're not talking south Florida here," Ms. Renwick says, referring to that region's rash of fully built, utterly empty condo towers. "These units are selling, they are closing and people are moving in."
Using the industry standard of 1.2 residents per unit, Ms. Renwick calculates a total of 10,666 new residents. Ms. Innes's campaign has been assuming an average of 1.8 residents per unit, which totals nearly 15,998 new residents, though she expects an even higher tally.
Whatever the actual number turns out to be, it will dwarf the riding's typical margin of victory.
Last time around, Ms. Chow prevailed by 3,861 votes. In 2004, Mr. Ianno beat Ms. Chow in a squeaker: 805 votes.
These newcomers are only accelerating the trends captured by the most recent census data. From 2001 to 2006 the riding's population increased by 9,275 people.
They are nearly all single: the number of residents who have never been legally married rose by 8,690. All age groups increased in numbers, but those that increased most were between the ages of 20 and 45, with the fastest rise coming among women aged 20 to 29. And while visible minorities still make up more than a third of the riding's population, the number of residents who speak neither English nor French is actually going down, as is the number of immigrants in the riding - signs that, though the riding isn't actually getting whiter, it's getting more culturally homogeneous.
But while the wild cards could swing the riding back to the Liberals, it's far from a sure thing. "You might think that the increasing affluence and the rise in home ownership would push the riding to the right," says Alan Walks, a professor of geography with the University of Toronto's Centre for Urban and Community Studies, "but that's not necessarily true. The decline of the Italian and Portuguese communities may have contributed to the Liberal defeat last time."
For every new voter who works in a big bank or law firm, Prof. Walks says, there is another who works in the so-called creative class - TV producers, journalists and the like - and it's hard to generalize how any of them will vote. In consumer terms, these gadget-addled condo dwellers are often called "early adopters," and Prof. Walks thinks that the label might prove true in politics as well. "It will be interesting to see how the emergence of the Green Party plays out down there," he says.
Given that the wild cards could decide the outcome, Ms. Chow has already honed her message to them. "A lot of them are paying off their student debt," she says, "and they need help." She also makes an appeal to their cavalier side: "This country needs to do something bold," she says, casting the Liberals as middle-of-the-road blandness.
Ms. Innes focuses her pitch on the economy. "A lot of young professionals arrive here from across Canada," she says. "They have more of a national perspective on the issues." Now if only any candidate could get their message through. Canvassing is forbidden in most condo developments, keeping these voters out of easy grasp of the traditional campaign machines.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

New kid on the downtown shopping block

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/new-kid-on-downtown-shopping-block/docview/382686869/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: One-litre milk cartons trump four-litre bags. Even the grocery carts - think Smart cars instead of SUVs - are smaller. The in-house food magazine, Inspired, appeals to sophisticated foodies, as do visits by local chefs such as Massimo Capra and David Agee. Mr.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=New+kid+on+the+downtown+shopping+block&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-20&amp;spage=M.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=New+kid+on+the+downtown+shopping+block&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-20&amp;spage=M.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: At the new Sobeys store at Yonge and Balliol, the lunch crowd pays for its gourmet-to-go meals beneath a crystal chandelier sparkling above the cash register.
In their carts are organic peanut butter and Baratti & Milano chocolate, antibiotic-free meat and brandied marmalade by Compliments Sensations, the high-end in-house brand. It's Pusateri's-style products priced for the masses.
With the opening of the Balliol location in June, Sobeys now has 15 stores in Toronto, up from three in 1998. Five downtown locations have opened in the past 12 months alone, often in offbeat locations, such as the former Blockbuster Video store in the Annex. As the green-bannered label pops up all over town, some residents see themselves as the winners in the battle of the grocery stores.
"With Sobeys coming into the neighbourhood, there's now better prices," a woman named Sandra said as she shopped at the new Sobeys at Front and Princess, a converted Canada Post warehouse. "The Rabba and the Dominion next door have had to give the consumer better prices because of the competition."
Sobeys also is distinguishing itself by customizing its stores to suit Toronto's particular neighbourhoods. In North York, for instance, at the Clark and Hilda streets store, Sobeys holds the distinction of being North America's biggest kosher supermarket, with a rabbi on staff. At the much larger flagship Queensway Sobeys location, close to neighbourhoods stocked with Eastern European-style delis, the draw is imported cheese. There are more than 200 varieties.
"They seem to have stepped into a vacuum that the other traditional grocery stores haven't considered," says Toronto real-estate analyst Barry Lyon, of N. Barry Lyon Consulting Ltd.
The Balliol location is an example of the new wave.
At 8,000 square feet, it's boutique-sized, with only 10 parking spots. Designed for a neighbourhood filled with apartment buildings, its aisles are narrow and the tiered shelving is deep as a jeweller's.
One-litre milk cartons trump four-litre bags. Even the grocery carts - think Smart cars instead of SUVs - are smaller. The in-house food magazine, Inspired, appeals to sophisticated foodies, as do visits by local chefs such as Massimo Capra and David Agee. Mr. Lyon thinks Sobeys could own the downtown, because it understands the downtown shopper, who is often single and looking for prepared foods and takeout. "At Sobeys, the stores are smaller, and people shop three, four, five times a week, sometimes daily, to walk their groceries home," he says. Whereas in the older suburban model, such as "the Loblaws at Queens Quay and Jarvis, is where everyone drives and fills their car up once a week."
Rodney Lock is a case in point. "I'm a cook," Mr. Lock says, perusing the prepared-foods section inside the Sobeys at Front and Princess. "But sometimes late at night the last thing I want to do is prepare dinner.
"Sobeys has prepared pizza, and if I buy a few extras, like sausage and feta cheese, I get a feeling of a fresh product that I could have made myself," he says. "It's a lot better than Pizza Pizza."
Sobeys has been innovative in its presentation, rebranding the new stores with the hipper moniker "Urban Fresh," locating in underused properties and freshening up those older spaces with "designer" interiors (Italian lighting, custom wood-and-glass cabinets, granite-topped takeout counters, lime-green and black decor) - and structuring displays to make maximum use of smaller space.
"There's more produce on offer at Balliol than at the bigger Leaside store," says Mary Dalimonte, general manager of the Urban Fresh service format team.
"And that's because we've built up. We can offer lychee nuts, kumquats, dragon fruit, guavas, gooseberries, product that some of the other locations don't have, because we have been mindful of how we use our store space." Sobeys is "classing it up," says a shopper calling herself Anne.
The Sobeys invasion into Toronto continues into next year, with firm plans for locations at Bremner and Spadina and at One Cole, the new condo being built as part of the Regent Park redevelopment.
Other locations are being scouted.
"We know that to take the market share we have to first take Toronto," says Craig Gilpin, president of operation for Sobeys Ontario. "Forty per cent of Canada lives in Ontario; 40 per cent of Ontario lives in Toronto. It stands to reason.
"We are very competitive people," Mr. Gilpin continues. "We are serious about food. ... You won't find a golf ball in these aisles," he adds with a knowing smile.
As condos bloom and Toronto infill becomes the modern reality, Mr. Lyons says, "the suburban model [of a grocery store] - and, by that, I mean Loblaws - doesn't work downtown any more."
***
Metro rebranding
Goodbye, Dominion and A & P. These supermarkets will henceforth be known as Metro. The Montreal-based Metro Inc. is rebranding its grocery stores under a single banner, to be unveiled Thursday, at the Dominion at Bayview and Eglinton (A & P doesn't flip over to the Metro moniker until next year).
Deirdre Kelly

As Bay Street shakes and rolls, so do we all

Author: Barber, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/as-bay-street-shakes-rolls-so-do-we-all/docview/382756310/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The towers under construction are "substantially pre-leased" to solvent tenants, he said, and the developers in this cycle are not high-stakes gamblers but pension funds. "They're not worried about making their mortgage payments."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=As+Bay+Street+shakes+and+rolls%2C+so+do+we+all&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=A.14&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=As+Bay+Street+shakes+and+rolls%2C+so+do+we+all&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=A.14&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Wall Street, Bay Street, Main Street: One leads to another in an interconnected network, with no off-ramps available for the relief of motion sickness. Despite assurances from several Canadian bankers that their firms have little "exposure" to the current pile-up in Lower Manhattan, everybody is braced for the inevitable rear-ending. It's the way of the street.
Have you noticed Bay Street lately? There is a handsome new skyscraper rising at the intersection of Adelaide Street, where for more than a decade an unfinished concrete elevator core stood as grim witness to the last great blowout.
The official word this week, with the TSX down about 20 per cent since its peak only three months ago, is that we're all right, Jack. Good fundamentals and all. But when Bay Street is your Main Street, there's always reason to worry.
The nakedly obvious chain of causation in this disaster, beginning with an overheated market in residential real estate and culminating (so far) with a financial-services meltdown, cannot fail to impress all those who shop at Pusateri's - not to mention their many economic dependants.
Like it or not, Ma and Pa Toronto are uncomfortably connected to an ugly reality. Even if they have nothing more than a pension plan, they're already losers. On average, though, people who live in Toronto are twice as likely as other Canadians to have a direct stake in the financial-services industry or one of its kissing cousins, according to the 2006 census.
What's good for Bay Street is good for us - likewise, what's bad.
In the wake of the Wall Street carnage, the local office of real estate firm Colliers International forecast a "bumpy road ahead" for the Bay Street office market, predicting lower rents and rising vacancy rates through 2009 and beyond.
But everybody knew that was coming, with three new towers in the financial district soon opening their doors to tenants. It's the logical result of yesterday's good-news story: the revival of the core from a near-20-year coma.
What of tomorrow? The situation could worsen, according to Ian MacCulloch, Colliers vice-president of research, "as the collateral damage adds up, some of which we have seen coming and some not." But he ruled out the chance of the latest binge ending with another unfinished stump - and all that means for the local, indeed regional, economy.
The towers under construction are "substantially pre-leased" to solvent tenants, he said, and the developers in this cycle are not high-stakes gamblers but pension funds. "They're not worried about making their mortgage payments."
Suddenly, it seems, borders really do matter in global financial markets. The Wall Street rout will have minimal impact on Bay Street, according to Steven Sorensen, chairman of the Toronto Office Coalition.
"Our financial industry has built a foundation that has withstood the storm," said Janet Ecker, president of the Toronto Financial Services Alliance and former provincial finance minister.
Even Prime Minister Stephen Harper is comfortably assuring about the future of Bay Street, citadel of prudence and rectitude.
But maybe what all the same voices said yesterday about globalization really is true, and our comfortable insularity is just temporary dissonance. When senior economists begin using phrases like "predatory implosion" and "state of panic," the man on Main Street grits his teeth and gets ready for what's coming.
Credit: jbarber@globeandmail.com

Housing, in the discount aisles

Author: Templin, Neal

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/housing-discount-aisles/docview/382687984/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Are you sitting down?" [Gia Marshello] asked me. "They want to offer full price," or $429,900. Gia then went back to the first buyer to say we had a higher offer, in case he wanted to improve his bid. He didn't. We signed the $429,900 contract.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Housing%2C+in+the+discount+aisles&amp;author=Templin%2C+Neal&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=H.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Housing%2C+in+the+discount+aisles&amp;author=Templin%2C+Neal&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=H.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In a tough real estate market, a Dallas couple manage to sell their home and keep their marriage intact
When we put our Dallas house on the market for $490,000 (U.S.) in February, we thought it would sell in weeks with little discounting.
Talk about being delusional.
We ended up lowering the price five times before the house finally sold last month. We didn't get our first offer until late June, and it was $102,000 below where we had started.
All the uncertainty made us delay buying a new home near New York City, and we've been scrambling to find a place before the school year starts. During my 28 years as a journalist, I've moved 11 times for my job. This was in some ways the hardest one.
The whole experience made me a tiny part of a huge story - the collapse in housing prices - affecting millions of Americans. It was humbling for me, your typical know-it-all reporter, to find myself caught up in a situation where I had no ready answers.
In previous columns, I have waxed about my penny-pinching approach on everything from restaurant meals to vacations to buying new books. But all that pales in comparison to the stakes during a home sale. In our case, we needed to extract as much money as possible from our Dallas home so we could afford the higher prices in the Northeast.
My wife, Clarissa, and I were on the same page for some decisions. But we quarrelled early on about how much to spend fixing up the house - and later on how quickly to chop the price when it wouldn't sell.
Whereas Clarissa has always been the generous one, and I was the one who sweats every last dollar, she wanted to hold out for a higher price, convinced the house was worth it. I became haunted by the belief that the market was tanking, and that we needed to get our price down as quickly as possible and get the house sold now.
Our odyssey began last fall when The Wall Street Journal named me its personal finance editor, a New York-based job. For the previous three-plus years, I had been its Dallas bureau chief. The plan was that I would move the family to northern New Jersey in June when the school year ended.
It soon became clear that Clarissa and I had different visions for getting the house ready for sale. I simply wanted to paint it and correct obvious defects, such as exterior wood that rotted during heavy rains last year. Clarissa wanted to redo the kitchen, install new fixtures in at least one of the bathrooms and much, much more. I fretted we wouldn't get that money back when we sold.
So we compromised. We spent $2,000 putting granite countertops and a new sink in the kitchen, and we merely painted the bathrooms.
But Clarissa didn't stop there. She paid a carpenter to put inlaid patterns on the wooden mantle. She spent hundreds on plants. She put in new lighting fixtures and new curtains and replaced a tattered awning.
Periodically, l would try to get her to slow down the spending, and she would tell me to buzz off. I was the one forcing the family to move yet again, and this time she was going to do the things to get top dollar for her house so she could afford a decent one in New Jersey.
We had paid about $360,000 for the house in 2004. Now, with all the things we'd fixed or improved over the years, I figured our total investment was more like $390,000.
We had reason to believe we could come out way ahead. Our 1937 brick-and-stone house sat in a pretty neighbourhood of older homes and towering trees about eight kilometres from downtown Dallas. The city's real estate market had remained relatively strong, and we lived in one of the strongest submarkets.
Based on selling prices the previous fall, our agent, Gia Marshello of the local Coldwell Banker office, predicted our three-bedroom house would fetch $485,000. We put the asking price at $490,000, and waited for the buyers to line up. They didn't.
After a month, only 10 had visited our house, and I was beginning to panic. We had planned a March home-buying trip to New Jersey, but I put it on hold - indefinitely.
Gia suggested that we discount the house by $10,000 or perhaps $15,000. I pushed for the bigger discount. Clarissa reluctantly agreed, even though she saw comparable houses priced the same or higher in our neighbourhood. The problem was that they weren't selling either.
The feedback from people visiting our house was worrisome. Too many said the layout didn't work for them. Our house had two bedrooms and one bathroom upstairs, and one bedroom and one bathroom downstairs. Parents with small children wanted all the bedrooms on one floor.
A couple of buyers complained the kitchen wasn't open enough. I sputtered to Gia: "This is a 1937 house - they didn't make open kitchens back then. We're not getting the right buyers."
At one point, Gia left me a voicemail on the latest developments. She sent out postcards about our house to everyone in the neighbourhood and buried a statue of St. Joseph (the patron of carpentry) in our yard, which some believe brings good luck to home sellers. "Oh my gosh," I thought to myself. "This is our marketing plan?"
As the months stretched on, we kept lowering our price, first to $469,000, then to $455,000, then to $448,000 with another $4,000 in "credits." We thought we had a buyer with that last price. A young woman made three visits to the home and told us to let her know if any other offers came in. But her father was paying for the home, and he didn't like the house, and that was that.
Gia left no stone unturned to sell our house. She held open house after open house. Each time we lowered our price, she would contact anyone who had expressed interest in the house. Nothing worked.
I talked to a real estate agent friend of mine in New Jersey, and he advised us to cut the house to its bare-bones price. "If only three houses sell in your neighbourhood, you've got to make sure you're one of the three homes," he told me.
Gia advised the same. Clarissa finally caved in, and we priced the home on a Monday afternoon in late June at $429,900, putting it thousands of dollars below most comparable houses in our neighbourhood. Almost immediately, buyers flocked to check it out. Gia got word an offer was coming. On Thursday, she called me. The offer was for $388,000 - more than $40,000 below our last asking price.
How could this be, we asked ourselves. We just made this the best bargain in the neighbourhood, and now this guy wants another 40 grand off. Clarissa wanted to reject the offer, but I felt we had to make it work. After all, we'd had the house on the market for more than four months, and this was our first offer.
There was no guarantee there'd be another one.
So we exchanged a series of offers and counteroffers with the buyer. It was like pulling teeth. After three days, he offered $399,310.
Clarissa found this insulting and wanted to counter with $412,666 to send a message. "I don't think that's a good idea," I told her.
Finally, on Monday, the buyer raised his offer to $409,000. I got him up to $410,000, and I was resigned to sign a contract later that day. Clarissa, who had to sign off on any deal, was convinced that would be a big mistake and we ought to wait for another buyer. She called Gia to say, "Don't let him give away the house."
While all this was playing out, a new offer rolled in that afternoon from another buyer.
"Are you sitting down?" Gia asked me. "They want to offer full price," or $429,900. Gia then went back to the first buyer to say we had a higher offer, in case he wanted to improve his bid. He didn't. We signed the $429,900 contract.
We soon met the buyers, a young couple expecting their first baby. They said they were thrilled to get the house. And they seemed to appreciate the unusual plants Clarissa had picked out and all her touches inside the house. Her strategy had worked after all.
Our selling price amounted to a 12-per-cent discount from our starting price. I don't expect any violins for us. Some regions of California have seen home prices decline more than 30 per cent from their selling prices a year earlier. We got off very lightly by comparison.
Our house went on the market when there were few homes for sale in our neighbourhood. That's no longer true. When I took my last drive through my old neighbourhood, the streets were beginning to bristle with "for sale" and "open house" signs - though many were above our price range. I shudder to think.

Sky-high spinoffs

Author: Lorinc, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/sky-high-spinoffs/docview/382687480/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Things tend to go more predictably," Robert Freedman, Toronto's head of urban design, says of the Vancouver model. "It's less convoluted and not nearly as political."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sky-high+spinoffs&amp;author=Lorinc%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=B.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sky-high+spinoffs&amp;author=Lorinc%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=B.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A gleaming new vertical city has sprouted above Toronto's lower-scale buildings. The big question is whether all this condo construction will translate into sustainable economic growth
For Robert Whitfield, the eureka moment occurred when he realized his store was filled with customers trapped between drywall and a hard place.
It happened about four years ago, shortly after he opened an upscale furniture store in Liberty Village, a district of warehouse lofts on the west end of Toronto's downtown. Young couples were streaming into his shop, desperate to furnish new stacked townhouses and condo apartments with minuscule master bedrooms and other "spatial challenges."
"All of 10-by-11," recalls Mr. Whitfield, the principal of Casalife Inc., of one particularly constrained floor plan. "It just didn't have room for a bed and a dresser and a tallboy. Where are you going to put your socks?"
Where indeed? Within months, he had launched a queen bed with drawers cleverly tucked underneath, and a niche market was tapped. Today, Casalife specializes in furniture tailored to the cramped confines of the high-rise condos that proliferate in the city.
Mr. Whitfield now has several competitors and spends much of his time attending international trade shows searching for size-conscious items, such as the elusive 18-inch coffee table. "The reality is that this market is still neglected."
But there's no doubt it's a market. Indeed, Casalife's commercial success is directly attributable to Toronto's sustained condo boom, which traces its origins to some key land-use reforms made in the mid-1990s. A decade later, the market shows little sign of slowing, despite moribund real estate markets in the United States and Britain.
Between 1994 and 2007, the annual dollar value of residential building permits in the City of Toronto jumped more than three-fold, largely on the strength of the condo boom. It's as if a gleaming new vertical city has sprouted amid Toronto's lower-scale buildings.
Between 2001 and 2006, a staggering 17,000 residential units were built downtown, the vast majority of them high-rises. At the end of 2006, another 39,000 units, in 155 projects, were in the pipeline.
The result has been a remarkable 17-per-cent jump in the population of central Toronto - growth not seen since the early 1970s. Nor is the boom a downtown phenomenon: Clusters of condos have cropped up in traditionally low-rise suburban areas such as North York, Scarborough and Mississauga, with more on the way.
And the developments are growing not only in height, but also in scope. Vancouver-based Concord Adex, which is building CityPlace, a sprawling 20-building cluster near the downtown Rogers Centre, is also planning a 15-tower project on a 20-hectare former industrial site near Highway 401. To be built over the next decade, this new project is worth a staggering $2-billion.
The key to this growth, planners and economists says, is the fact that the population of Greater Toronto jumps by about 100,000 every year. All these new residents need housing and increasingly they are choosing high-rise condos.
This rapid transformation is not without its critics, including homeowner groups upset about tall towers and downtown artists who bemoan the loss of Main Street atmosphere in areas targeted by developers.
"Pumping a lot more people into the downtown core hasn't led to balanced growth," says Toronto Councillor Adam Vaughan, whose ward has the highest concentration of condo activity.
Yet even skeptics don't deny that the immediate, local spinoffs are substantial. Condos today represent 50 per cent of all residential development activity in Greater Toronto and 80 per cent in the City of Toronto proper - a trend that puts the region sharply at odds with most North American urban areas.
The direct investment for condos built since 2001, as well as those under development, likely exceeds $20-billion. And housing starts - whether high-rises or subdivisions - have always functioned like economic spark plugs. Between 2002 and 2007, residential construction as a proportion of GDP rose to 6.7 per cent from 5.5 per cent - a shift that has moved in lock-step with job creation, according to housing economist Will Dunning. "That's where it all comes from."
In the GTA, the most direct beneficiaries are construction workers. Mr. Dunning says $1-million of residential construction translates into nine "person-years" of construction employment, as well as another two person-years for consultants, architects and other professionals involved in planning such projects.
The other big winners are the local suppliers of building materials. Although non-residential construction consumes a larger amount of basic materials, residential development represents "a particularly important source of demand for producers of windows and doors, kitchen cabinets, gypsum and wallboard and heating and air conditioning," according to an analysis by Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp.
The wages and purchases of materials for Toronto's 2007's condo projects, in turn, triggered about $175-million in tax revenues. In terms of local taxes, city officials say that between 1996 and 2005), the 69,000 new condos completed in that period contributed about $113-million annually to municipal coffers.
Then there are the secondary spinoffs - the new supermarkets, dry cleaners, convenience stores, coffee shops, houseware and hardware stores that cater to thousands of residents now living near the financial district.
Stephen Dupuis, CEO of the Building Industry and Land Development Association, says the typical new home buyer purchases about $10,000 worth of goods after taking possession. But Mr. Whitfield, of Casalife, suspects the figure could be higher for condo residents, because of the small size of many suites: "They get their occupancy, they move in and then realize their furniture doesn't fit."
Like Casalife, many retail companies are moving to fill the needs of condo dwellers. General Electric Canada's Mabe appliance division recently launched Loft Kitchen, a collection of fashionable, small-scale appliances and stacked washer-driers suited to tiny condo kitchens. Working with developers, GE tailored the collection specifically to this market. "You need to get efficiency and space and hit the prices point," says general brand manager Philippe Meyersohn.
Unlike locally sourced construction materials, however, durable goods and appliances tend to be imported from Asia, Mexico and the United States, illustrating how the condo ripple effect can spread well beyond the GTA.
Planning consultant Barry Lyon also argues that the high-rise office boom in downtown Toronto (200 floors are currently under construction) is linked to the flourishing condo market. "A lot of the office construction wouldn't be happening were it not for the pool of highly educated technology workers the condos have brought into the city."
The big question is whether all this construction will translate into sustainable economic growth for Toronto.
Mr. Lyon, who describes himself as "a believer," says the condo boom essentially makes the city function more productively. Intensification gives rise to non-economic benefits such as more transit ridership, energy savings and greater efficiency in municipal services such as garbage handling.
Others aren't convinced. Pointing to an earlier generation of high-density towers, Councillor Vaughan says there's a risk that consumers may sour on the glut of tiny suites, leading to losses in market value and condo towers that come to be dominated by low-income tenants.
Douglas Young, co-ordinator of York University's urban studies program, points to another pressing issue: "The state of [the city's] infrastructure - physical, social and natural - is in pretty lousy shape." Yet planners continue to approve thousands of new condo units, he says. "You have these fabulous looking high-rises from a distance, but getting from them to somewhere else in the city can be a real pain in the backside."
Mr. Lyon counters that the $20,000-to-$30,000 per-unit fee imposed by the city (parks levies, development charges and so on) help underwrite the cost of municipal infrastructure improvements ranging from new transit service to libraries.
From his Liberty Village showroom, Rob Whitfield sees no end to the forest of condo towers rising around him, nor a lessening in demand for his products. Casalife recently opened a new outlet in Vaughan, north of Toronto, which has its own big plans to develop high-rise condos and offices in a city-centre to be served by a new subway extension. As he sees it, "I'm a bit of a pioneer."

*****
DEALING WITH DEVELOPERS
In April, 2007, Toronto launched a two-year pilot project to establish a "design review panel" to buff up the city's architecture standards, especially for large-scale towers that can radically alter streetscapes and the pedestrian realm.
The move was the city's response to growing concerns among neighbourhood groups that developers are building increasingly enormous condo towers with little regard to their look, especially at grade.
But the other source of inspiration was the City of Vancouver, which has relied for years on a design review panel, comprised of architects, engineers and planners, to vet development proposals. Projects that don't pass muster go back to the proverbial drawing board.
Vancouver's design panel is just one of a series of discretionary planning policies that sharply differentiate Toronto from the West Coast metropolis. Unlike in Ontario, Vancouver developers can't appeal planning decisions to a quasi-judicial body. City planners, in turn, encounter less interference from local councillors, meaning they can fast-track applications and increase site densities while demanding more from builders in terms of benefits to the public, such as day-care centres, arts facilities and landscaping.
"Things tend to go more predictably," Robert Freedman, Toronto's head of urban design, says of the Vancouver model. "It's less convoluted and not nearly as political."
There's an even more important dividend, however. Vancouver's approach, says that city's retired planning director, Larry Beasley, has created "a neighbourhood environment at high density that consumers find very attractive because it is not just housing they are purchasing but a complete residential/neighbourhood lifestyle. This has added huge value to private market projects."
Mr. Beasley says that developers, "after a period of watching the results on their bottom lines, have now generally become happy to make contributions ... to get through the Vancouver system."
The City of Toronto is not placid when dealing with developers who want to build above existing height or density limits. It levies fees, known as "Section 37" benefits, to help offset such projects.
Since 1998, the city has collected $48-million in Section 37 fees. The funds, another form of economic spinoff, go toward heritage protection, day care, public art and other community amenities.
John Lorinc
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

Title: Sky-high spinoffs

Publication title: The Globe and Mail; Toronto, Ont.

Pages: B.4

Publication year: 2008

Publication date: Sep 19, 2008

Section: Report on Business: Canadian

Publisher: The Globe and Mail

Want a vintage look? 'Oldify' your home

Author: Rand-Watkinson, Elizabeth

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/want-vintage-look-oldify-your-home/docview/382687404/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Floor heating grates present another opportunity to add subtle detail. A few years ago at an interior design show in Toronto, I saw heating grates that had been laser cut into intricate patterns using the finest of woods. They were small pieces of art that cost about $300 and up. Unfortunately, I couldn't afford even one and, more unfortunately, I've lost the artisan's contact information so I can't share it with you.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Want+a+vintage+look%3F+%27Oldify%27+your+home&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=G.18&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Want+a+vintage+look%3F+%27Oldify%27+your+home&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=G.18&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: There are lots of ways to add character to your house, and part of the fun of doing it is scouring architectural salvage stores
We diverted from form when we bought our current 15-year-old house. Usually, we gravitated toward older homes. But, despite its age, our house did have some of the character we craved: The rooms were large and gracious, ceilings were a good height, many rooms had hardwood flooring, and there were two fireplaces with the potential for a third. We wanted to add to this character, so we set about "oldifying" the house.
I'm not talking about selecting a certain style of furniture or decor when I say "oldify." We used that tactic, too, of course, but we also added some infrastructure features to achieve the feel we wanted, and we're happy with the results. Here's what you can do if you want your fairly new home to have more vintage character.
Add mouldings, whether it's crown mouldings, trim around doors and windows, or higher baseboards, bumping up the scale of your home's trim, or adding period-style trim where there isn't any, will give you an instant visual payback. And don't be stingy with scale. A skimpy crown moulding, for example, in a large, high ceilinged room is the visual equivalent to a pea sitting on a stack of mattresses.
If you have the budget, you could splurge on real plaster for your crown mouldings, but you don't have to break the bank. Many people prefer wood while others swear by composite wood products. Both are reasonably priced compared with plaster, which, while beautiful, requires skill - even artisanship - to install. I'm not arguing against plaster, just presenting some options depending on your budget.
Period mouldings were usually quite substantial, sometimes even elaborate, creeping into rooms by a foot or more on the ceiling as well as several inches down the wall. You don't have to go to that extreme to get the look. If you're adding a crown moulding, staying in the range of five to seven inches high should do the trick.
Baseboards often went as high as 18 inches so try a look that's at least two inches higher than the standard four-inch baseboard and consider building it outward slightly as well, perhaps with some door-stop trim added where the baseboard meets the floor. With any type of trim, play around with samples from your local hardware or lumber store (they're often free) to get the scale right.
Install a few ceiling medallions as well. They're inexpensive - depending on circumference, they're usually under $50 - and can be found at lighting and many of the bigger hardware stores. Install them as anchors for suspended ceiling light fixtures for an elegant detail. But don't limit yourself to light fixtures. For example, we don't have a ceiling fixture in our master bedroom so the medallion that was already there now contains the smoke detector. Just keep it to one medallion a room unless the space is huge.
Floor heating grates present another opportunity to add subtle detail. A few years ago at an interior design show in Toronto, I saw heating grates that had been laser cut into intricate patterns using the finest of woods. They were small pieces of art that cost about $300 and up. Unfortunately, I couldn't afford even one and, more unfortunately, I've lost the artisan's contact information so I can't share it with you. We opted for black metal grates with scroll designs from the hardware store. They're inexpensive (about $10 each) and come in a variety of finishes. Restoration Hardware carries a more upscale version that costs between $40 and $50.
Authentic or reproduction hardware is another good way to add historic detail. Lee Valley Tools is one good Canadian source for well-made reproduction hardware. Other great sources are architectural salvage stores.
In our area (near Cobourg, Ont.), Legacy Vintage Building Materials and Antiques has such a range of offerings it even draws designers from Toronto, a 90-minute drive away, looking for that special piece. Like many stores of this nature, Legacy sells everything from antique door knobs, cabinet latches, knobs and pulls to lighting, reclaimed flooring and stair parts.
You could oldify your staircase, for example, by swapping your existing newel post for a more elaborately carved antique version.
We found a carved wall shelf at Legacy for our powder room. By adding an anaglyptic wallpaper, installing moulding about 18 inches down from the ceiling, putting in the shelf below the moulding, and painting everything a metallic bronze colour, our powder room went from bland to full of character.
You can also take your oldifying efforts outside by installing reclaimed window shutters or adding an old iron fence to the yard or garden.
You're guaranteed to have fun oldifying, especially if you scour salvage stores for what tickles your fancy. Check out your region's business directory for architectural salvage stores near you. But, if you're seriously into oldifying like we are, be prepared to spend hours just browsing in awe through a plethora of beautiful and aged artifacts brimming with history. But empty your car trunk before you go. Better yet, bring a truck.
Check out the wares sold at Legacy Vintage Building Materials in Cobourg at their website, www.legacyvintage.com. See what Lee Valley Tools has on offer at www.leevalley.com.
Credit: erand-watkinson@globeandmail.com

Shopping without dropping

Author: Deck, Kelly

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/shopping-without-dropping/docview/382686272/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Now, the family-arrival scenario may send various feelings - anything from joy to pure, atomizing despair - coursing through you. Your emotional response doesn't much matter; if you want to get through the furniture and lighting selection, the painting, and the accessorizing before it's time for 'nog and carols, you have a heap of work to do. (By the way, I'm addressing myself here to the refurnishers; anyone with renovation plans definitely has to wait until the new year.)

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shopping+without+dropping&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-19&amp;spage=H.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 90 per cent of successful decorating is about being decisive and methodically seeing your project through from start to finish, clipboard in hand
It's 13 weeks till Christmas.
Okay, I said it. I'm sorry. It's not my intention to be a voice for the consumer culture that would have you begin Christmas shopping as soon as you're done Halloween shopping as soon as you're done back-to-school shopping. But those of you with refurnishing plans in your future may need the insistent beep of a distant early warning.
As a designer, autumn is one of the busiest times of year, and for one simple reason: Within the next month or so, many of you will be standing in your hallway, an evening glass of Pinot Grigio in your hand, overhearing your partner - gulp -inviting his or her family over for the holidays. All of which means that the decorating plans that have idled on the backburner all summer are now coming boiling and splashing to the fore.
Now, the family-arrival scenario may send various feelings - anything from joy to pure, atomizing despair - coursing through you. Your emotional response doesn't much matter; if you want to get through the furniture and lighting selection, the painting, and the accessorizing before it's time for 'nog and carols, you have a heap of work to do. (By the way, I'm addressing myself here to the refurnishers; anyone with renovation plans definitely has to wait until the new year.)
If you plan to do it yourself, here are three strategies for preventing stress ulcers over the next three months.
Start the work now
The best way to heighten the natural anxieties of the holiday season is to condense them.
If you're truly a glutton for punishment, I'd advise putting the newspaper down now and taking a lazy September-long mental nap. You can start thinking about the project again after Halloween.
The obstacles between this moment and your sitting in a newly finished living room are many. The biggest one to consider is the limit on your furniture-buying options. After Oct. 1 or so, you won't be able to buy chairs, sofas or tables manufactured outside North America: They won't arrive before Valentine's Day. Unless you get cracking, you'll likely have to forgo that buttery Italian sofa for something local that may require assembly with an Allen key.
Be prepared
If this suggestion seems boy-scouty and obvious, consider it a return to core principles. Your strategy for a refurnishing, which extends to space planning and budgeting, is necessarily complicated.
Only the foolhardy or super-wealthy among us will glance at their space and then head out, credit card in hand, to do battle with the furniture merchants.
Leave chaos theory to the particle physicists; you want order. Measure your space, create an inventory of your needs, and develop a budget to work from. What you're doing at this stage is editing, reducing the vast sweep of possibilities down to a few realizable goals. Not a sofa, table and light fixture, but the sofa, table and light fixture.
Some people seem to think that good interior design is an artistic pursuit, that is, something arrived at instinctively, ecstatically, in a hot blast of inspiration. It's not. There's no substitute for a good eye, but 90 per cent of successful design is about being decisive and seeing your project through from conception to completion.
In your preparations, take advantage of the user-friendly online catalogues provided by every decent housewares retailer. Print off specification sheets and images, and create a binder of colours, possible furniture combinations, and prices. This kind of planning has two major benefits:
1) You don't have to leave your house (all the information you need is available online).
2) When you're finally ready to shop, you can do it U.S. Navy SEALs-style, swooping in to hit tactical targets instead of wandering, cattle-like, through sprawling fields of floor models.
My suggestion? Take a Saturday, and dress in your comfortable clothes; there's no need to impress salespeople with chic duds. Plan for a long day of slogging in the shops, and don't plan to buy anything until later, no matter how great a deal it seems at the time. All you need are your binder of targets, clipboard for note-taking, measuring tape, and digital camera. Oh, and six or seven cups of coffee.
Seek deliverance
Once you've made your purchases, the best thing you can do is take your fate, as much as possible, out of the hands of the experts. However well deliverymen do their jobs, they operate on their own schedules and, as the holidays approach, their lives are complicated by the post-Halloween surge of last-minute home decorators. Scheduling your time around the deliveries is like attempting to sculpt water: The thing resists your hopes and demands, however ardent.
Delivery drivers are perverse creatures. They take delight in coming when they say they wouldn't, in forgetting pieces of your order, and in "accidentally" damaging the parts they do bring. Take your sanity out of their hands by anticipating the worst case and then planning around it. By cashing in some overtime from work and spending a day or two at home, you can co-ordinate the deliveries and installations. Instead of feeling stressed about time, you can resign yourself to homemade cabbage rolls, back issues of your favourite design magazine, and mid-afternoon mulled wine. Or perhaps that's just me.
Kelly Deck is the director of Kelly Deck Design, based in Vancouver, and the host of Take it Outside on HGTV.
Credit: kdeck@globeandmail.com
