In Vancouver, he's Mr. Condo

Author: Gold, Kerry

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/vancouver-hes-mr-condo/docview/382690554/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "That was the one that said, 'Wow, they can sell out a tower downtown,' " says Mr. [Bob Rennie]. "It said to the banks, 'These are bankable.' It said to the development industry, 'These are salable.' And it started to pave [Dan Ulinder] and I a career."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=In+Vancouver%2C+he%27s+Mr.+Condo&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-12&amp;spage=H.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=In+Vancouver%2C+he%27s+Mr.+Condo&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-12&amp;spage=H.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The veteran sells $2-billion worth of suites a year, helping to create the fastest-growing residential downtown in North America
Bob Rennie doesn't fit the mould of a big-shot real estate broker, much less one of the most successful in North America.
He shows up for a breakfast meeting in running shoes. He is addicted to his BlackBerry, but he doesn't own a computer at home or in his office. Ultimately, he'd rather be known for his international art collection than real estate. Granted, he eats almost all his three meals a day in restaurants, and takes the wheel of a flashy Bentley when his driver isn't around. But he is chatty, goofy and frank, given to hugs even if he hasn't met you before, and he has the youthful energy of a kid on a candy high.
Donald Trump he's not. But you'd be hard-pressed to meet a Vancouverite who doesn't know Bob Rennie's name. The 52-year-old's celebrity is more a statement about the character of the city than the man himself. With some Vancouver luxury condos now selling at more than $2,400 a square foot, real estate is sexy business.
And with sales of between $1.2-billion and $2-billion annually, Bob Rennie Marketing Systems represents Vancouver's biggest condo projects: the Woodward's building, the Shangri-La (in both Vancouver and Toronto), the Residences at the Ritz-Carlton, Fairmont Pacific Rim, and the Olympic Village. His company's projects have also spread to Edmonton, Dallas and Seattle.
Mr. Rennie has worked extensively with major Vancouver developers Peter Wall and Ian Gillespie. Businessmen, politicians and lobbyists want his ear. To consumers and developers alike, he is a name brand.
"But it's all about the consumer," he insists. "Without the consumer I'm out of business, my client is out of business. So as long as I keep delivering, then our brand gets insured, and that brand should help the developers."
Mr. Rennie, who lives in a 3,000-square-foot condo penthouse in the hip downtown False Creek neighbourhood, also personifies what distinguishes the Vancouver real estate market from other North American cities. Vancouverites have made urban condo living a way of life, not merely a means to owning property.
"We have been, for the last 10 years, the fastest-growing residential downtown in all of North America, regardless of size," says Larry Beasley, former director of planning for the city.
"And that in part is because of the realization of an extraordinary opportunity by people like Bob Rennie to create a residential downtown. And for me and him, that's condos and rentals and everything that comes together to get as many types of people downtown as possible."
Mr. Rennie sells entire buildings, which works out to between 1,000 and 2,000 condo units per year. He makes a point of buying a suite for himself in each building - a little something for his three grown children's inheritance.
"More than 80 per cent of all sales west of Main Street are condos, so I picked the right industry," he says with a laugh.
"Condos became socially acceptable quicker here than in other cities," he adds.
Hemmed in by ocean and mountains, rapidly growing downtown Vancouver has nowhere to go but up. And with 2.5 million residents in the Lower Mainland, and the 2010 Winter Olympics about to push Vancouver further onto the global stage, the city is quickly developing urban areas outside the downtown core.
Mr. Rennie has long maintained that the only other direction for development is eastward, which means making the beleaguered Downtown Eastside district livable.
"Larry Beasley and I stood on a pedestal back in 2000, 2002, and said, 'The city's moving east,' " he recalls. "It didn't take a genius. It had nowhere else to go."
Mr. Rennie believes the province and the city will revitalize the gritty, crime-ridden Eastside in time for the Games, and if he believes in something, the public is sure to follow. When he threw his name on the project to turn the historic Woodward's department store on Hastings Street into a condominium, for example, 356 units were presold in a single day - an event credited with sparking the real estate boom in that area of the city.
Mr. Rennie comes from a working-class background (his father delivered beer) and grew up in a modest bungalow on the east side. He dropped out of high school just before graduation and began selling houses at age 19. (He didn't finish high school until 2006, when the school gave him his final credit for career development and marketing: he earned an A.)
By 1989, Mr. Rennie was already a wealthy man, selling a house a day, when he was approached by Dan Ulinder, a University of British Columbia professor of urban land economics. Mr. Ulinder asked him to help sell units at a condo-conversion development in Burnaby.
"I sold it in two weeks to all my clients' children," Mr. Rennie recalls. "It just sold out and Dan and I never looked back. I changed his life, and he changed my life."
Their entry into the condo market was timely. In the late 1980s, the city had put together a plan and changed zoning to increase downtown housing. As well, the market was ripe. "[New-home] developers were starting to make very little profit on the homes. It seemed a shift was going to happen," Mr. Rennie says. "It seemed time to diversify."
By 1992, the two partners had formed a company. Their pivotal break came that year when they took on sales of a 189-unit condo tower at 1188 Howe St., the earliest example of a local Vancouver company doing presales. (Mainly a Hong Kong marketing method at the time, presales involve selling units before construction is complete; the buyer doesn't have to pay the mortgage until the project is completed, during which time the property usually increases in value.)
Mr. Rennie and Mr. Ulinder sold out 1188 Howe St. in four hours - setting a North American record and putting their company on the map for condo marketing.
"That was the one that said, 'Wow, they can sell out a tower downtown,' " says Mr. Rennie. "It said to the banks, 'These are bankable.' It said to the development industry, 'These are salable.' And it started to pave Dan and I a career."
The two men later set another North American record when they sold out the 493-unit Residences on Georgia in a single day.
By 1997, Mr. Rennie had bought out Mr. Ulinder and formed Rennie Marketing Systems. (Mr. Ulinder, who went on to become a senior vice-president with Concord Pacific Group, died in 2003.)
Today, with a staff of 26, Mr. Rennie has moved beyond sales. He acts as a developer's representative and is involved in many aspects of projects, including concept, zoning, architecture and design.
"People let me play in their sandbox, and I don't take it lightly - it's a huge privilege," he says. "I'm just a very, very, very high paid consultant."
But he's a creative, big-picture guy, too, says Mr. Beasley, who has worked closely with Mr. Rennie.
"What he's doing most directly for his clients is he's shaping projects, he's marketing projects, he's causing them to move, and that's great. It's making a lot of people a lot of money," Mr. Beasley says. "Bob continues to be one of the strongest supporters for a much more sophisticated idea of the city."
Experts like Mr. Rennie and Mr. Beasley predict that post-Olympics, owning property within Vancouver city limits will be beyond the means of most people.
"I think that there is a huge emerging issue of affordability for average folks to live in the city," says Mr. Beasley. "I don't think any part of Vancouver is going to stay easily affordable."
Mr. Rennie agrees: "I think between now and 2015, that I would buy today."
But his interests go beyond the ins and outs of developing and selling real estate. Perhaps his most important message is to developers: the fact that people need not only homes, but also communities complete with stores and services and developed infrastructure.
"In a lot of cities they throw in condos but they forget we can't shop at Neiman Marcus and Holt Renfrew every day," Mr. Rennie says. "You need drycleaners, and you need to be able to pick up a loaf of bread."
That commitment to community is reflected in his own actions. An ardent supporter of Vancouver's culture, he pushes for more art, dance and theatre. He is also building offices and a 20,000-sq.-ft. art gallery in Chinatown to house his collection of the works of about 40 international artists, one of Canada's largest private collections. He doesn't plan to open his gallery to the viewing public, at least for the first few years, but says the collection is the sole reason he continues to sell real estate.
"I have an addiction, a passion for the art collection. If we are going to continue to build the collection, I have to continue doing what I am doing," says Mr. Rennie, who sits on the main acquisitions board for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, as well as the American acquisitions board for the Tate Gallery in London.
He is also becoming more politically outspoken on social issues, giving speeches recently to developers and planners about the need for affordable housing. He cites working with the flagship Woodward's building as a personal and professional turning point.
"Woodward's came into an area with huge social problems and social housing issues," Mr. Rennie explains. "It's sort of my thing to try to figure out how to mix the people with jobs walking down the street, with the people without jobs. You can absorb the people without jobs by bringing balance to the neighbourhood," he says.
"A lot of people said, 'Don't do it, it will ruin your career.' Well, I think it's given me a new career."

Expect a long, costly convalescence

Author: DeCloet, Derek

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/expect-long-costly-convalescence/docview/382691110/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Right now, these U.S. banks have no ability to raise more capital; their share prices have been crushed, and confidence in them is close to zero. Some won't survive. But that will be of less concern to the next administration than the fact they won't lend. Don't be shocked if President Obama or President McCain sets up a taxpayer-funded corporation to absorb billions of dollars worth of bad loans. Like the Fannie and Freddie takeovers, it's a hell of a costly answer.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Expect+a+long%2C+costly+convalescence&amp;author=DeCloet%2C+Derek&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-09&amp;spage=B.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Expect+a+long%2C+costly+convalescence&amp;author=DeCloet%2C+Derek&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-09&amp;spage=B.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Dr. Hank Paulson, oncologist and chief surgeon at Holy Mother of Credit Crises Hospital in Washington, D.C., removed the twin tumours of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Sunday morning. The patient, U.S. Economy, came through the procedure and awoke several hours later, complaining of pains in the wallet region.
The prognosis? Odds of a full recovery are good. But further invasive procedures are not only possible, but likely. Expect a protracted convalescence. In the long run, major lifestyle changes will be required - a debt diet, if you will.
Don't send cards, tulips or credit card applications, please (especially not that last one). Well-wishers, if they're so inclined, are encouraged instead to buy U.S. Treasury bills offering meagre rates of interest.
The good Dr. Paulson would greatly appreciate this, because as a creature of Wall Street, he surely knows this is not the end of the Street's calls on the U.S. Treasury. The nationalization of Fannie and Freddie may have been a necessary step - better now than to wait for their failure to precipitate a global financial panic - but it's still only a step. To get America's economy going again, its banks will have to begin lending again.
To persuade them to do so, the next U.S. treasury secretary, Republican or Democrat, may have no choice but to draw up a savings-and-loan-type bailout plan, to clean out the financial system. The last one, by the way, cost U.S. taxpayers more than $120-billion (U.S.).
This may seem too gloomy, but consider the history. The U.S. is hardly the first industrialized country to endure a modern-era housing bubble and collapse. Sweden, Norway and Finland all went through one in the late 1980s or early '90s. In each case, they got their economies upright only after the government had taken a grip on the financial sector, "in some cases seizing the assets of large commercial banks."
Those countries had small, relatively simple banking systems. The U.S. system is huge and complex. It's also a mess. Most of the problems are not in the big, troubled banks like Citigroup that have received so much bad press; they're in smaller regional or local banks. Gerard Cassidy, the veteran bank analyst who now works for the Royal Bank's U.S. brokerage unit, predicts 300 bank failures in the next three years.
Mr. Cassidy bases his forecast in part on something called the Texas ratio, a simple - but quite accurate - measure of how close a bank is to a financial cliff. It takes a bank's delinquent loans and divides it by the sum of its tangible capital and its allowance for loan losses. In English, that means: how much bad stuff is there on the balance sheet compared with what's set aside to absorb it? The healthiest banks have Texas ratios of less than 10 per cent. When the bad stuff equals the good stuff - a ratio of 100 per cent - history shows the bank is likely to fail.
No large U.S. bank is at that point yet. But a few are moving closer, and quickly. As of late July, 12 of America's 50 largest commercial banks had ratios of more than 25 per cent. In 2006, only one did. The list of the dirty dozen includes some important names. SunTrust Banks of Atlanta, which once had a bigger market value that Toronto-Dominion Bank, has a Texas ratio of 31 per cent. Wachovia, the seventh most valuable U.S. bank, has a ratio of 28 per cent.
So there's a lot of junk on those balance sheets, and while the feds' move on Fannie and Freddie will probably lower mortgage rates, it won't undo the bad decisions of the past. One side-effect of having so much competition - the U.S. has more 7,200 commercial banks - is that smaller banks tend to specialize. Pushed aside in the mortgage market by the likes of Countrywide Financial, they lent money to home builders or commercial developers, and that's where the next wave of losses is coming from.
Take Cincinnati-based Fifth Third Bancorp, a one-time starlet that's now No. 2 on Mr. Cassidy's list of banks with rough balance sheets. Mortgages and home equity loans are part of its problem. But Fifth Third also has 27 per cent of its loan portfolio tied up in construction, land development or commercial real estate projects, according to data compiled from various sources by National Bank Financial.
Fifth Third is by no means an anomaly; several other regional banks, such as New York's M & T Bank, have more than 30 per cent of their loans to real estate companies. Compare that to a better-diversified Canadian bank like RBC, where just 8 per cent of the loan book is business real estate loans. RBC's got residential mortgages up the wazoo, of course. It's just that most are lower-risk loans to Canadian customers who will pay the money back.
Right now, these U.S. banks have no ability to raise more capital; their share prices have been crushed, and confidence in them is close to zero. Some won't survive. But that will be of less concern to the next administration than the fact they won't lend. Don't be shocked if President Obama or President McCain sets up a taxpayer-funded corporation to absorb billions of dollars worth of bad loans. Like the Fannie and Freddie takeovers, it's a hell of a costly answer. Only the alternative seems worse.
Credit: ddecloet@globeandmail.com

Putsch comes to shove

Author: Barber, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/putsch-comes-shove/docview/382694052/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The current law says council "must approve" such appointments. Indeed it must, and will do so by the usual lopsided vote. Despite the hopes and claims of reactionary saboteurs, grabbing hold of "new powers" to do such things without consulting a compliant council is not part of the revolutionary agenda. The Mayor would like the right to meet with his executive in private prior to public sittings, cabinet-style, as recommended by all and sundry.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Putsch+comes+to+shove&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-06&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Putsch+comes+to+shove&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-06&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   As predicted, the victory of the revolution has removed the need for politics. The usual cacophony of the giant clam is stilled, debate forestalled and dissension packed off to a designated "protest corner" on AM radio, where it mingles with the electrical noise of streetcars.
The great victory took two elections and the better part of five years to accomplish, during which interval messy politics erupted regularly, but none can doubt the result today. The revolution that took so long to gain traction is now digging in. Apart from the workaday implementation of long-promised policy, there is nothing to report.
Remember that, every time you hear the words "Rob Ford." They are the touchstone of irrelevance, and these days you hear them all the time.
What you don't hear much any more, though, are the words "George Smitherman." The question of whether or not Mr. Smitherman will run against Mayor Miller is less important today than the question of why he - or any other popular figure - would do so. The revolution has monopolized the centre-left sweet spot of local politics, pushing its enemies to the margin where there is never more than 30 per cent of the votes available.
Thus the protest zone serves the revolution by creating a semblance of opposition. None but the losers play along, one of whom will almost certainly favour Mayor Miller by running against him in 2010.
Let a hundred flowers bloom and a thousand schools of thought contend. Just don't get your hopes up.
The real action is the implementation of dozens of initiatives launched in peril but now entrenched - climate change, priority neighbourhoods, streetcars and subways, tax policy and the waterfront. Such activity is confined almost entirely to council's "consent agenda" - legislation adopted without comment or debate, except when TV cameras and Rob Ford are present.
The most characteristic initiative is "Mayor's Tower Renewal," a plan to rehabilitate largely suburban high-rise neighbourhoods. Coming from outside the bureaucracy but now personally branded by Mr. Miller, the program is ambitious, inspiring and so diffuse as to be unknowable.
Remembering the tax-vote beating they laid on the Mayor last summer, opposition councillors are preparing for another battle over his expected demand for the new executive powers that the McGuinty government and two expert panels think he should have. They struck their colours, dug in - and disappeared.
They're still there, waiting for the Mayor to show himself. The problem is that he is too busy using his new powers to waste time and political capital fighting for them in public. Consider the recommendation that the Mayor gets the right to hire and fire the city's chief administrator. It's still a recommendation, but he just hired a new chief, former city treasurer Joseph Pennachetti - unilaterally.
The current law says council "must approve" such appointments. Indeed it must, and will do so by the usual lopsided vote. Despite the hopes and claims of reactionary saboteurs, grabbing hold of "new powers" to do such things without consulting a compliant council is not part of the revolutionary agenda. The Mayor would like the right to meet with his executive in private prior to public sittings, cabinet-style, as recommended by all and sundry. Just don't expect him to spill any blood.
If there is any drama in upcoming months, it will likely focus on Queen's Park, where fellow travellers in the McGuinty government could still cause trouble despite an otherwise solid alliance with the revolutionary regime. The Toronto Mayor continues to smile while Queen's Park delays fiscal relief promised a year ago, but that will change as the fiscal year winds down.
Gaining a "new deal" from the province - or at least the promise of it - was the revolution's definitive accomplishment. Without it, everything falls apart, beginning with hope for another so-called balanced budget.
Contract talks for city workers also threaten to disturb the peace. A new contract for the police is currently in arbitration, reducing its potential political impact even though the result will almost certainly be unaffordable. Negotiations with outside workers could help reveal more clearly who owns whom: labour-loving Mayor Miller or Miller-loving union boss Brian Cochrane. More likely, they will end with a friendly settlement.
It's the dialectic, don't you know, ruthlessly exposing internal contradictions while ensuring everyone can enjoy a good night's sleep.
Slate of issues
Toronto city council's first meeting of the new political season begins Sept. 24. The fall agenda includes:
* The Mayor's power push: David Miller wants greater sway over the bureaucracy and the ability to meet behind closed doors with his executive committee.
* Labour talks: Arbitration is already under way with the police and TTC unions. The inside and outside workers' contracts expire at the end of the year.
* Garbage changes: More trash angst is expected as the pay-as-you-throw trash regime officially kicks in Nov. 1.
* Union Station: The city is expected to select the real-estate arm of a pension fund to help finance a makeover for the transit hub.
* Transit battle: Metrolinx is set to officially release its long-term transportation plan.
Kelly Grant

Design with a West Coast edge

Author: Deck, Kelly

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/design-with-west-coast-edge/docview/382775214/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The third influence on West Coast design is so pervasive it almost escapes notice: our cool grey light. It's the end of summer now, and our season of complaint about shortening days is just beginning. But it's not so much the amount of light we receive that designers need to correct for, it's more the tone and colour.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Design+with+a+West+Coast+edge&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-05&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Design+with+a+West+Coast+edge&amp;author=Deck%2C+Kelly&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-05&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The landscape, weather and cool, grey light are all factors in a style that's reshaping Canadian homes
I grew up on the Prairies, in Saskatchewan and Alberta, but the flatlands never really had traction in my imagination. From the age of seven, I'd importune relatives on the West Coast to take me in for the summer holidays. Those days, all I wanted was to feel beach sand underfoot. Today, as I look out at a Vancouver socked in steel-grey rain clouds, it seems a devil's bargain.
This is my first column for The Globe and Mail, so my editor suggested that, by way of introducing myself, I talk about a home that exemplifies West Coast design.
I was immediately worried. It's something like being asked to name a starlet who epitomizes Hollywood. You could point to Marilyn Monroe, who was of course a paragon of beauty, glamour and sensuality. But she was also, in her way, a sad, inadequate and avoidable cliché.
The Marilyn Monroe of West Coast design is a post-and-beam cedar home with soaring ceilings, fir-clad windows, slate floors and a granite fireplace - all located on a forested bluff overlooking the ocean, where from behind a cup of Lemon Zinger you can watch the sun set over tankers and seine boats plying the Pacific. But to focus on stereotypes is to miss a great deal of worthy detail.
In Vancouver architecture, for instance, that means the work of the firm Battersby Howat, whose modern concrete homes are unapologetically boxy. Instead of blending into the landscape, as is often prescribed on the coast, their structures jut out defiantly, creating a discord as intriguing as it is jarring.
Then there are the crafts-
man-style homes, whose sloping roofs, cedar shakes, and front porches hold great nostalgic appeal here, although there's little uniquely West Coast about them. The homes' origins are in the British (and then the American) arts and crafts movement, although local builders and architects are riffing interestingly on the classic design with signatures such as exposed cedar shake and white trim around black doors.
It's a mixed bag out here in the West, for sure. But if our designs aren't of a piece, at least I can point to three unique and immutable factors that give rise to the many variations we see.
The first is the landscape. The product of the grinding and buckling of tectonic plates and crashing of water, there is nothing gentle about the West Coast. It's a vista of violence, not of quietude and soft curve. Our topography is domineering, and, not surprisingly, everything in design orients itself toward the view.
The result is that a home's interior must be understated; it must make an effort to coexist with rather than confront the tumult of the view outside. For me, this means drawing on the colour palette of the surrounding landscape - its warm greys, dark browns and dirty greens, its ivories and myriad blues, rendered in limestone, concrete, walnut and oak.
A designer preserves the spirit of non-contention by sticking to tailored, simple forms. Bigger pieces such as sofas and tables make a statement with strong lines, enabling the curvature of accent pieces and chairs to soften the feel. I prefer to use things made from local materials and furnishings, wall pieces or sculptures by North Vancouver artist Brent Comber are my favourites. These originals, rendered in reclaimed lumber, speak to a distinctly West Coast ethic of refining the raw and elemental - but only slightly.
The second influence on design here is the weather. With our rain and mild winters, designers feel less compelled to define a rigid boundary as a bulwark between the living space and the out-of-doors.
The world beyond our window is always lush and green, and so we're freer to experiment with living spaces that fuse the natural and the domestic. One common way is stone floors that run seamlessly from interior to exterior, creating dining rooms that spill out to patios that give on to gardens.
The winter isn't as harsh for Vancouverites as it is for Winnipeggers or Torontonians, but the wet, in its way, can be as formidable an opponent as the cold. When the January damp sets into your bones, it stays there for weeks. So while West Coasters may not demand that their domiciles be bunkers from the elements, they require interiors that are tactile, sensuous and cozy.
From a design remove, this means liberal use of textured fabrics, window finishes, and bedding in inviting wools, linens and velvets.
The third influence on West Coast design is so pervasive it almost escapes notice: our cool grey light. It's the end of summer now, and our season of complaint about shortening days is just beginning. But it's not so much the amount of light we receive that designers need to correct for, it's more the tone and colour.
One mistake I see too often, even in Vancouver's most prestigious neighbourhoods, is bold, vibrant colours in interior and exterior applications - homes smeared in terracotta, ochre and canary yellow. These Mediterranean-inspired villas, which look wonderful in the penetrating glare of strong sun, look in Vancouver like some displaced daydream of a hotter climate. Our West Coast light is inhospitable to the lustre of deep colours - the flat grey of our atmosphere makes them look sickly and forlorn.
That's not to say colour has no place here, only that it be used subtly. Grey, brown and green form the foundation of the our palette, but there is a wide range of corals, purples, oranges and blues with which to accent and adorn.
I'm glad to have the opportunity to be your correspondent on the West Coast, and I'm excited to set to work, interrogating the people and exploring the ideas that inform design in this part of the world. I hope you'll check in from week to week, to see how the conversation is developing.
Kelly Deck is the director of Kelly Deck Design, based in Vancouver, and the host of Take it Outside on HGTV.
Credit: kdeck@globeandmail.com

School's out forever

Author: Perreaux, Les

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/schools-out-forever/docview/382772076/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Some advocates argue boards are short-sighted to close schools. "Across Canada in 2005, we saw the highest birth rate we've seen in 15 years," said Jessica Van der Veen, a Victoria-based advocate who is fighting B.C.'s large-scale school closings and land sales.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=School%27s+out+forever&amp;author=Perreaux%2C+Les&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-01&amp;spage=A.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=School%27s+out+forever&amp;author=Perreaux%2C+Les&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-09-01&amp;spage=A.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   A steady long-term decline in enrolment is closing schools across Canada, devastating communities and throwing the country's youngest students - and their parents - into turmoil
Katherine Randell already tears up as she looks ahead to tomorrow, when her eight-year-old son will rise at 6:45 a.m., eat breakfast, brush his teeth and catch a bus for his new 90-minute daily commute to school.
Instead of running home for lunch across tiny Woodstock in the northern reaches of Newfoundland, shy Kameron will eat a packed meal in a school gymnasium 35 kilometres away in Baie Verte.
Instead of the intimate school of five that allowed the Grade 3 student to excel at reading, he will study with 250 strangers.
When school is over for the day, the boy will take the bus instead of playing or walking home for a snack and homework. He'll arrive just in time for dinner and when he's finished eating and his assignments are complete, he'll go to bed.
"It's a big adjustment for him. We ask our kids to give up so much of their freedom. But I think it'll be an even bigger adjustment for me," Ms. Randell said.
"I'll be doing a lot of crying when I see him on the bus. I just wish I didn't have my baby going up there. I'm scared for him."
With only five students enrolled last year, regional officials may have had little choice but to close the Grades 1 to 4 primary school in Woodstock.
But the tiny school is on the leading edge of an anticipated cross-Canada wave of closings that promises to devastate small communities and throw the country's youngest students into turmoil.
Every province except Alberta is struggling with long-term declines in enrolment as the population ages and birth rates remain among the lowest in the world.
At least 53 schools closed in Canada this year, but advocates say that's just the beginning.
British Columbia and Saskatchewan lead the way, as they have for years, accounting for 19 and nine closings, respectively.
Most other provinces, including Ontario, have delayed some of the agony in recent years by putting a brake on closings as they figure out what to do next.
"In 2009, we're going to see a big surge of school closings right across the country," said Annie Kidder, executive director of People for Education, a parent-led research group based in Ontario.
"Everybody is dealing with declining enrolment, everybody is struggling with it. There's a kind of reality where some schools just have to close. But some provinces like Quebec and Saskatchewan are much better than others at looking for alternatives."
Thirteen schools closed in Ontario in 2008, but 77 schools are on a list recommended for closing. Most of them will be gone in June, Ms. Kidder predicted.
Canada is experiencing steady long-term decline in enrolment. The number of school-aged children dropped to 5.2 million in 2005-06, down 3 per cent from 1999.
Local school authorities and experts in most provinces say the decline will continue through 2013 and beyond.
With little national debate, the country is walking into an irreversible process that will leave dozens of communities in tatters, Ms. Kidder said.
"We have to decide as a society whether we're going to say, 'Oh well' and just keep emptying all these parts of the country," she said.
"It's a big public policy issue and it's a national one."
Migration within provinces from city cores and rural areas toward the suburbs is adding to the dislocation.
Even Alberta, with the only growing school population in Canada, closed 11 schools this year while opening 13 others to accommodate shifting populations.
Alberta plans to open 54 new schools through 2012.
Quebec has lost about 20,000 students each year for several years running. Enrolment last year was 872,384, down from nearly a million in 1994.
Denis Pouliot, a spokesman with the Quebec association of school boards, said few schools were shut down in 2008 after 37 of 2,744 schools closed in 2007. (A provincewide 2008 count of closed schools isn't done until this month.)
Quebec has likely experienced a lull in 2008 after the province imposed new rules demanding school boards look harder for alternatives and give a 12-month warning to local communities.
"People in these areas will do anything to keep their schools alive," Mr. Pouliot said. "The school is an important symbol for many communities and the government has tried to the extent possible to keep as many as they can open."
There is a downside to small schools, Mr. Pouliot said, listing off the psychologists, social workers, specialized teachers and socialization that are sometimes missing there. Quebec law demands all of these factors be measured before a school is closed.
While local authorities usually make the final decision to shut down schools, provinces set the rules.
Manitoba and Nova Scotia have moratoriums on school closings as they draw up new plans. Ontario recently emerged from a moratorium and about 125 schools are under review. Saskatchewan's rural depopulation has made the province a national leader in the field. It has closed 468 schools since 1970.
Helen Horsman, Saskatchewan's assistant deputy minister of Education, says closings may finally become a rare event rather than an annual source of anguish in her province.
After 23 schools closed in 2007 following a moratorium backlog, Saskatchewan introduced a new two-year process to fund communities fighting to keep their schools - provided they can show potential for economic growth.
"What we want to do is give communities every opportunity to demonstrate that they may be able to have a turnaround and encourage young families to move in," Ms. Horsman said.
"But even some areas with exceptional economic growth can't draw those demographics."
Ms. Horsman's former school in her hometown of Chaplin, west of Moose Jaw, is on this year's chopping block.
"Closing schools is one of the hardest things we ever do in a community," she said.
In recent years, B.C. has moved more aggressively to close schools than most provinces, with 177 shutting down in the past eight years.
It's ultimately a local decision, B.C. Education Minister Shirley Bond said in a written response to an interview request.
She stressed B.C. has boosted education funding and is pushing school boards to find alternatives to school closings and real estate sell-offs.
Some advocates argue boards are short-sighted to close schools. "Across Canada in 2005, we saw the highest birth rate we've seen in 15 years," said Jessica Van der Veen, a Victoria-based advocate who is fighting B.C.'s large-scale school closings and land sales.
"Any idiot can tell you the echo boomers are turning 30 this year and they're all going to start making babies immediately.
"The lack of planning is mind-boggling."
Quebec has been part of a recent small baby boom, but Mr. Pouliot said it's not nearly enough to make up for enrolment decline.
Ms. Van der Veen also points to the damage school boards are doing to vulnerable youngsters, some of whom spend 10 hours a week or more on a bus.
"In the B.C. Interior, some are busing three hours a day in all kinds of weather including snow and sleet because of this, and it's happening all over the province," she said.
"These communities have just been shattered."
Down the street from Ms. Randell's house in Newfoundland, Jonas Sacrey worries that the school closing may mark the beginning of the end for Woodstock.
Though the town's population has frequently fluctuated between 150 and 250 for the past 100 years and the school closed once before in the 1960s, he's pessimistic this time.
Mine closings and the dwindling fishery have left the town with retirees, unemployed people, seasonal workers who disappear for half the year, and almost no children.
Mr. Sacrey says local scuttlebutt is the four-classroom school, complete with gymnasium, will be sold at a bargain basement price. It would make a nice workshop, Mr. Sacrey said.
"We got a quaint community here, we got a nice draft from the ocean and a beautiful view," said Mr. Sacrey, 73, who raised two children in the village with his wife, Evelyn.
"We just don't have young people, and now, no school."

What's clogging your home's arteries?

Author: Holmes, Mike

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/whats-clogging-your-homes-arteries/docview/382784830/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Every municipality has a minimum flow rate that depends on where you live and the water source. (This applies to water taken from a municipal source, not a well.) That minimum rate is the flow that is delivered to your home, at the main water intake. After that point, all water pressure problems are yours - between the main intake and the street, it's the municipality's responsibility. So you may also have to call your local government and have it do a test.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=What%27s+clogging+your+home%27s+arteries%3F&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-29&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=What%27s+clogging+your+home%27s+arteries%3F&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-29&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Not all water is created alike, and the difference could be damaging your system
Most homeowners only think about their water pressure when it suddenly drops - like when they're in the shower and someone flushes a toilet. Low water pressure is a common problem, and there are a lot of reasons for it - some small, some big.
If it's just at one tap, it might be that some debris and corrosion has flaked off inside your pipes and clogged up the faucet aerator. That's a quick fix that any handyman could do. But, if the problem is throughout your home, you should call in a licensed plumber to test your water pressure and check your plumbing.
Test the flow
Every municipality has a minimum flow rate that depends on where you live and the water source. (This applies to water taken from a municipal source, not a well.) That minimum rate is the flow that is delivered to your home, at the main water intake. After that point, all water pressure problems are yours - between the main intake and the street, it's the municipality's responsibility. So you may also have to call your local government and have it do a test.
Narrow supply line
In older houses, the supply lines from the municipality are smaller in diameter than today's standard, which will cause low water pressure. If the main water intake is only ½-inch pipe, you won't have good water supply throughout your home.
Undersized piping can't handle the flow demands of a modern household. You should have the supply line upgraded to ¾-inch minimum.
Corroded piping
A lot of piping is galvanized steel, not copper, and this is the reason for a loss of water pressure in older homes. Galvanized piping corrodes on the inside and deposits build up that block and can severely reduce the water flow.
It's a good idea to remove galvanized piping and upgrade to copper or Pex flexible plastic pipe. But this can be a very expensive job - and one for the professional plumber only.
Bad Plumbing
Another common reason for low water pressure is bad plumbing jobs in the past. Renovations or additions that altered the plumbing lines, or even some badly done repairs can create flow restrictions, and pressure drops.
An amateur or bad plumber can make a mess of your lines - using inadequately sized piping, with too many elbows, bad joints or supply lines taken off other lines incorrectly - creating what I call spaghetti plumbing.
Maybe it's in the water
Depending on where you live, the water that is supplied to your house could also be a problem. Some water is highly acidic or has a lot of dissolved minerals in it that can affect copper piping.
With galvanized piping, the problem is often "hard" water. Hard water contains higher levels of mineral content than "soft" water. Two of the most common minerals in water are calcium and magnesium.
Hard water from your municipal water system is perfectly safe to drink, but it can cause problems in pipes, appliances and fixtures.
Minerals can accumulate and look ugly - like a stain on a sink, for example, or something that looks like soap scum left in a tub. It's hard to clean, and it could indicate deeper, and more expensive, problems.
Hard water can leave a hard scaly surface that clogs the arteries of your pipes and inhibits water flow.
This can be a real problem for any appliance through which household water flows. Scaling and mineral build up can damage everything from taps to sinks, dishwashers and toilets. Eventually, scaling can interfere with the function of each of these things, and they have to be replaced.
Electric water heaters are especially vulnerable because hard water can build up on their heating elements, making them inefficient or burning them out completely. Even if you have a natural gas water heater, hard water scaling can reduce efficiency and force you to replace the water tank prematurely.
Hard water can also reduce the flow in showerheads and tap aerators. You can fix that problem by regularly removing the showerhead or aerator and cleaning out the minerals.
Water softeners
A simple remedy for hard water problems is to install a water softener. These appliances use sodium salt to help neutralize the minerals. The up-front cost can be a bit high, and there's the continuing cost of salt, but in the long run, it's going to be cheaper than replacing a dishwasher, a washing machine, water heater and faucets before their expected lifetimes are up.
Mike Holmes is the host of Holmes on Homes on HGTV. For more information, go to www.holmesonhomes.com
Credit: mikeholmes@holmesonhomes.com

Germinating towers set to bloom

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/germinating-towers-set-bloom/docview/382778650/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: One of Toronto's most fashionable avenues in Victorian times, Jarvis Street suffered badly 100 years ago, when its wealthy residents decamped to nearby Rosedale. Great Gulf Group's X condominium, at the corner of Jarvis and Charles streets, will be a good tonic for its historically dilapidated neighbourhood.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Germinating+towers+set+to+bloom&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-29&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Germinating+towers+set+to+bloom&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-29&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Among the many new condominium buildings now poking their heads above street level, six are worthy of special note
A work of architecture begins its real-world career (as opposed to its life in the designer's mind and studio) as a hole in the ground. Downtown Toronto nowadays sports many of these muddy pits in the urban fabric. But not all holes are created equal. Here are a few important ones that deserve watching in the weeks and months to come.
590 JARVIS ST.
One of Toronto's most fashionable avenues in Victorian times, Jarvis Street suffered badly 100 years ago, when its wealthy residents decamped to nearby Rosedale. Great Gulf Group's X condominium, at the corner of Jarvis and Charles streets, will be a good tonic for its historically dilapidated neighbourhood.
The great modern master Ludwig Mies van der Rohe inspired the design by Peter Clewes and the late Adrian di Castri of the Toronto firm architectsAlliance, and the radical spirit of Mies is invoked in every crisp line and strict angle of the tower.
JARVIS AND ADELAIDE STREETS
Like X up Jarvis, Aspen Ridge Homes's Vü - its podium is now peeking out of the ground - is a piece of solid city-building. This dense complex of high-ceilinged lofts, townhouses and condominium apartments will be situated on the long-neglected east side of downtown. Or at least the district was neglected through much of the 20th century. Since the turn of this century, condominium blocks have been going up in the neighbourhood at a fast clip, and Vü will add substantially to the momentum of this residential revival.
The design is by David Pontarini, founding partner in the Toronto firm Hariri Pontarini Architects.
183 WELLINGTON ST. WEST
The luxurious Ritz-Carlton hotel and condominium tower is at a stage of construction that delights architecture aficionados: poking up above street level a few storeys, with all its massive concrete bones showing, and no cladding to obscure the craftsmanship of engineers and technicians.
Designed by the U.S. firm Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates and Toronto's Page + Steele Architects, the project will feature an urbane glass podium lifted smartly off the street by concrete columns. Behind this entry pavilion will rise the tower proper, its outer walls tilting outward with attractive flair.
330 KING ST. WEST AT JOHN
Just a few steps north of the Ritz-Carlton, the Bell Lightbox will be another tall tower in what's becoming a big cluster of them along King. It has been designed by Bruce Kuwabara of the well-known Toronto firm Kuwabara Payne McKenna Blumberg Architects, and it will house the famous Toronto International Film Festival Group and many condominiums up top.
If architects' renderings are anything to go on, the building will be bright and lively, and crowned with a glowing box illuminated from within by light-emitting diodes - "a vertical city of film," Mr. Kuwabara has poetically called it.
1 BEDFORD RD.
Out of this hole in the ground will emerge a tower with 32 residential floors that will likely add a touch of suave to the unsightly north side of Bloor Street, west of University Avenue. The scheme, also by Mr. Kuwabara, has had its share of tribulation.
A couple of years ago, you may recall, the muscular local citizens' group attacked H & R Developments and Lanterra Developments, whose project this is, arguing that grannies would be plunged into darkness by the tower, and so forth. The upshot was a decision by the city to shrink the building a little -not enough, thankfully, to blunt the contribution this tower will make to the streetscape.
When this building was being designed, I was bothered a bit by the architect's bowing to the preservationists and incorporating some scraps from the studio of beaux-arts designer John M. Lyle (the Royal Alexandra Theatre, Union Station), which once stood at 1 Bedford. It now appears that these bits and pieces will be integrated elegantly into Mr. Kuwabara's modernist etude.
325 BAY ST. AT ADELAIDE
When it's finished, Toronto architect Eberhard Zeidler's 60-storey Trump International Hotel and Tower will make this address in the financial district one of the swankiest in Canada.
The people living there will have access to all of the luxuries of the five-star hotel on the building's lower storeys. Cars will be parked by valets. For those who can't be bothered to own a car, the management will provide round-the-clock use of two chauffeured Mercedes. And there will be lots of room at the top: The penthouses will be a lavish 4,300 to 7,400 square feet in area.
I like the idea of this big dollop of ritz in the heart of the city. Along with many of the other holes in downtown Toronto, the one at 325 Bay will soon be filling up with residential architecture that adds value to being and living here.
Credit: jmays@globeandmail.com

____________________________________________________________

Canadiana cabin with a Group of Seven tilt

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/canadiana-cabin-with-group-seven-tilt/docview/382778581/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Mies van der Rohe had one motto - keep it simple - and that's how I live," Mr. [James Mathias] says. "I really can't stand clutter. I need room for my collections to breathe."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canadiana+cabin+with+a+Group+of+Seven+tilt&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-29&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canadiana+cabin+with+a+Group+of+Seven+tilt&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-29&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Scugog summer house is a thing of beauty created by a man who believes that 'there's already too much ugliness in the world'
In James Mathias's summer house, Canadiana meets art moderne.
"It's a glorified cabin in the woods, but a cabin that I've tried to make glamorous," says Mr. Mathias, a Canadian artist who specializes in underwater photography from his home base in Fiji, where he lives much of the year.
Located in Scugog Township, less than an hour's drive northeast of Toronto, the modernist one-storey retreat with three bedrooms and two bathrooms is decorated with vintage Scandinavian furniture and Canadian antiques that Mr. Mathias chose for their natural materials and sculptural shapes.
Landscaped with lush flower gardens and boardwalks that wind through marshland where otters, deer and snapping turtles are in abundance, the house sports walls of picture windows that frame the natural beauty teeming outside.
Originally built in the 1930s as a fishing and hunting camp for members of Toronto's elite, the 90-acre property is dotted with elegant eastern white pines and artesian spring-fed ponds teeming with rainbow trout. (Mr. Mathias stocks the ponds but considers the fish pets.)
A typical vista brings to mind the elemental grandeur of a Group of Seven painting. Interestingly, the property does have an indirect association with that famous artistic fraternity.
Mr. Mathias is the adopted son of Gordon MacNamara, a painter who was a friend of Group of Seven member Lawren Harris. Father and son purchased the property in 1968 from Mr. MacNamara's sister, Dorothy Stark, who also was a friend of Mr. Harris and early patrons of the famous group.
The summer house contains furniture that once belonged to another Group of Seven member, J.E.H. MacDonald. The pieces include an old wooden painting table that Mr. Mathias has converted into a coffee table and put in the home's light-saturated sunroom.
A large Harris landscape painting dating to 1922 dominates a wall. The house also boasts artwork by David Milne and Mr. MacNamara, who died in 2006.
"It's not another world, but it's certainly a different experience," Mr. Mathias says of his country house.
"This is the one place I've created in Canada where I can relax, entertain and be with myself, alone and without the incessant noises of the city."
While its removed from urban life, the cabin exudes an air of urbanity, thanks to Mr. Mathias's unfailing eye for colour, form and texture in the way of home furnishings and art work.
"It's my only claim to fame," says Mr. Mathias, a natural-born aesthete who comes from inherited wealth and who has spent almost all of his 65 years pursuing the artistic life in North America, Europe and the South Sea Islands.
"I am always creating artistic environments for myself. I go into hotel rooms and rearrange the furniture. If I'm not comfortable, I'm not happy, and for me to be comfortable I have to be surrounded by beauty. There's already too much ugliness in the world."
He grills lamb chops in his spic-and-span 1940s kitchen with jazz music playing in the background.
He collects 1950s ceramics and sculptural Dansk ice buckets that he showcases on vintage teak tables, some of them scores from the local Salvation Army store. Over the years, he also has amassed an impressive collection of West Coast native argillite carvings, as well as historic Persona prints and traditional painted Tapa cloth from Fiji that he has framed for display.
His environment is richly artistic, but carefully edited to show off any given object in the best possible light.
"Mies van der Rohe had one motto - keep it simple - and that's how I live," Mr. Mathias says. "I really can't stand clutter. I need room for my collections to breathe."
To get it, he created an addition to the house in 1994 that now serves as a living room with a walkout to a terrace.
Crafted almost entirely by hand by local artisans, the addition is made of pine, with the walls painted a neutral colour. Dramatic hits of colour come from hand-woven kilims and Mexican rugs on the wood floors, and from Mr. Mathias's vibrant underwater photos that he has mounted on Plexiglas and inserted in some of the floor-to-ceiling windows.
He loves colour and loves his house as a result. "I will never let it go," he says. "There's something about a man owning land in Canada that makes him feel proudly and fully Canadian."
But while he has made an artistic statement on the interior, it is the exterior joys that really get his creative juices flowing.
"What turns me on about the house is just the peace and quiet," Mr. Mathias says.
"Listen to it. You can hear the fish jump in the water. You can hear the birds sing in the morning. For me it's not just a house, it's the outdoors. That's why the Harris looks so nice on the wall. It looks like it was painted here."
The studio building
Gordon MacNamara was an artist who was probably better known in his lifetime as the owner of the Group of Seven studio building on Severn Street in Toronto's Rosedale Valley.
He bought the Eden Smith-designed building in 1948 from his friend, Lawren Harris, who lived and worked there along with J.E.H. MacDonald and A.Y. Jackson. Tom Thomson, a marginal member of the group, once had a cabin in the backyard.
Upon his death in 2006 at age 95, Mr. MacNamara, a former lawyer, bequeathed the building to James Mathias, his adopted son, who now uses it as a pied-a-terre.

DAVE FREEMAN, 47: WRITER AND WEBMASTER

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/dave-freeman-47-writer-webmaster/docview/382689969/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The book's recommendations ranged from the obvious - attending the Academy Awards and running with the bulls in Pamplona, Spain - to the more obscure - taking a voodoo pilgrimage in Haiti, the Australian Night Nude Surfing championships and "land diving" in Vanuatu, which Mr. Freeman called "the original bungee jumping."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DAVE+FREEMAN%2C+47%3A+WRITER+AND+WEBMASTER&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-28&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DAVE+FREEMAN%2C+47%3A+WRITER+AND+WEBMASTER&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-28&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: His book told mortal readers that time was limited
Dave Freeman was an advertising-agency executive who co-wrote 100 Things to Do Before You Die , a travel guide and ode to odd adventures that inspired readers and imitators,
"This life is a short journey," the book says. "How can you make sure you fill it with the most fun and that you visit all the coolest places on Earth before you pack those bags for the very last time?"
Raised on the eastern outskirts of Los Angeles, Dave Freeman was one of two children to a father who made his career in packaging and a mother who worked in real estate. After high school, he attended the University of Southern California in downtown Los Angeles. In 1983, he graduated with a degree in urban planning and briefly working for an ad agency in Newport Beach before moving to New York to work for Grey Advertising.
In New York, he joined forces with a Neil Teplica, a like-minded friend. In 1996, they started the website whatsgoingon.com, which they ran until 2001. The 100 Things book, which wassubtitled Travel Events You Just Can't Miss , arose from their work on the website.
The book's recommendations ranged from the obvious - attending the Academy Awards and running with the bulls in Pamplona, Spain - to the more obscure - taking a voodoo pilgrimage in Haiti, the Australian Night Nude Surfing championships and "land diving" in Vanuatu, which Mr. Freeman called "the original bungee jumping."
Another event high up on his own personal list was Las Fallas, a festival in Valencia, Spain, where the locals make large, satirical papier-mâché and plaster likeness of politicians and celebrities and then set them on fire. "Secretly, they're full of fireworks and dynamite," he said on U.S. National Public Radio. "At the stroke of midnight, they light them all on fire in a huge, loud pyromania display."
The book also included goofy graphics with each entry, indicating that some activities were "down and dirty," and others "grandma friendly."
The success of 100 Things inspired dozens of like-minded books, with titles such as 100 Things Project Managers Should Do Before They Die and 100 Things Cowboys Fans Should Know and Do Before They Die .
For Mr. Freeman, everything changed on Sept. 11, 2001. He was eating breakfast at his New York apartment when an airliner crashed into the World Trade Center, just blocks away. He climbed up to the roof of his building and from there watched another aircraft plunge into the second tower. Devastated by the collapse of the buildings and what he had witnessed, he later moved back to Southern California to be closer to his family.
In Los Angeles, he was hired by TBWA/Chiat/Day, an advertising agency where his job was to help clients take a fresh approach to their accounts. He also lectured on lifestyle trends. "[He was] amazingly fabulous at what he did, which was living big, but also as a business strategist and cultural anthropologist," friend Cyndi Yee told the Los Angeles Times.
Over the years, Mr. Freeman visited about half the places on the list, and either he or his co-author had been to nearly all of them.
"He didn't have enough days, but he lived them like he should have," Mr. Teplica said. this week
DAVE FREEMAN
David Stewart Freeman was born Feb. 21, 1961, in Whittier, Calif. He died Aug. 17, 2008, after hitting his head in a fall at his home. He was 47. He is survived by father Roy Freeman and stepmother Barbara. He also leaves sister Virginia. His mother, Anne, died in 1995.
Credit: Associated Press

Bank of Scotland targets niche markets

Author: Perkins, Tara

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bank-scotland-targets-niche-markets/docview/382688308/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "That's the point," he said. "People aren't going silly. They're focusing on specific tangibles - tangible deals and tangible loans - that can stack up mathematically and will work. In this market, that's the name of the game."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bank+of+Scotland+targets+niche+markets&amp;author=Perkins%2C+Tara&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-28&amp;spage=B.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bank+of+Scotland+targets+niche+markets&amp;author=Perkins%2C+Tara&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-28&amp;spage=B.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: While other foreign players in corporate finance head for the exits, Edinburgh-based lender seeks to expand fledgling presence
Bank of Scotland is in the midst of setting up a corporate finance business in Canada, at a time when a number of foreign banks are scaling back or pulling out.
The Edinburgh-based bank, which is the second-largest in Britain measured by assets, plans to apply to the Minister of Finance for permission to establish a foreign bank branch in Canada.
Roughly a year ago, Bank of Scotland dispatched Andrew Darling, its European head of corporate finance, to Toronto to establish a beachhead in Canada.
From a tiny office of a couple of people, it has grown to a team of nearly 20, with ambitions to specialize in public infrastructure projects, some areas of commercial real estate, oil and gas, and mergers and acquisitions.
It has worked with real estate investment trusts such as Calloway on property investments, and with contractors such as EllisDon Corp. in bids for infrastructure projects. It has also partnered with other banks on financings.
But it has still barely made a ripple in Canada's corporate banking market, and isn't shy about admitting that it will likely be some time before it does.
"It really is from humble beginnings - building up some contact with local people, working very closely with local banks, Canadian banks, in partnership arrangements, and starting to do some modest amounts of local deals in the corporate finance area," said Mark Elliott, a spokesman for HBOS PLC, the bank's parent firm.
While the company's balance sheet exceeds $1-trillion, "in Canada, obviously, we're going to be very small, niche, targeted," Mr. Elliott said. "That smallness, it allows us the ability to stay there and to quietly do our thing. And that's what we did when we moved into markets like Germany and France in the mid-90s, when markets went soft then. And we just put two, three, five, six people on the ground. And now we have something like 200 people in mainland Europe working on corporate finance."
The bank has modest corporate finance operations in Germany, France, Spain and Holland. It has a presence in New York, and a sizable corporate bank in Australia.
Asked whether it wants to bulk up its Canadian team, Mr. Elliott replied: "I think in due course. I'd be lying if I said we didn't have that ambition." But, when the bank looks to a new location, it builds in increments, he said. "We really don't throw hundreds of people at a growth plan."
Bank of Scotland's Canadian expansion comes at a time when many foreign banks are retreating from North America as a result of the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis, and the infection it has spread through global lending markets.
Bank of America cut its Canadian corporate lending team in January. A number of banks, including Wachovia Corp., are evaluating Canadian businesses and deciding whether to part with them. And earlier this month, Netherlands-based ABN Amro Bank NV, which is now a part of Royal Bank of Scotland PLC, sold its Canadian commercial leasing division to Royal Bank of Canada, less than two months after ABN sold its asset-based lending business to Toronto-Dominion Bank. Royal Bank of Scotland is among the global banks that have been walloped by the credit crunch.
But Mr. Elliott said there is still intense competition in Canada, from both domestic and foreign banks.
"Even though there's been some uncertainty in the world economy, that doesn't mean that people aren't engaged in the Canadian market. They are. And, even in times like this, a bank like the Bank of Scotland is interested in trying to create some sort of niche place."
The key is that it will stick to its areas of specialty.
"That's the point," he said. "People aren't going silly. They're focusing on specific tangibles - tangible deals and tangible loans - that can stack up mathematically and will work. In this market, that's the name of the game."
Credit: FINANCIAL SERVICES REPORTER

Woods's $1-billion Dubai course plan 'on track'

Author: Schreck, Adam

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/woodss-1-billion-dubai-course-plan-on-track/docview/382691624/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "The [Tiger Woods] Dubai is catering toward a niche market," al-Gurg said, adding that the developers were in no hurry, but were "focused on quality" to attract potential residents to the 197 exclusive housings.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Woods%27s+%241-billion+Dubai+course+plan+%27on+track%27&amp;author=Schreck%2C+Adam&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-26&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Woods%27s+%241-billion+Dubai+course+plan+%27on+track%27&amp;author=Schreck%2C+Adam&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-26&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Tiger Woods Dubai will be surrounded by 197 palaces and mansions, part of a massive theme-park complex known as Dubailand
Tiger Woods is already the world's top-ranked golfer and best-paid athlete. And if all goes according to plan, he'll soon be sporting his biggest trophy yet: a luxury golf course amid the sands of the Arabian desert.
The ambitious project, touted as the first course in the world designed by the 2008 U.S. Open champion, remains a work in progress on the outskirts of this Middle Eastern boomtown - much like the rapidly growing city itself.
But the project's chief said yesterday that the first phase of the development, which among other unlikely features promises five million square feet of locally grown grass and more than 30,000 full-grown imported trees, is on target for completion in the last three months of 2009.
"Our schedule is currently on track," Abdulla al-Gurg said in an interview with The Associated Press.
However, al-Gurg did leave the Dubai-based developer, Tatweer, some wiggle room in case the city's notorious work delays snag one of its most high-profile projects by adding, "Our key criteria is adherence to excellence."
Tatweer is a division of Dubai Holding, owned by the emirate and its ruler, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum.
The golf course project, known as the Tiger Woods Dubai, will be part of a massive theme-park complex known as Dubailand the company is building on desert along the edge of the city.
Gurg said the company is spending four-billion dirhams ($1.09-billion U.S.) to build the course and the surrounding housing development.
He wouldn't say how much Woods was being paid.
Gurg spoke after an event to showcase the project at a glitzy beachfront hotel just down the road from a man-made marina surrounded by dozens of skyscrapers, many still under construction.
Full-page advertisements in Emirates newspapers have been trying to entice local buyers to consider one of the 197 palaces, mansions and villas that will flank the course.
The project's first stage will consist of the 18-hole, par-72 course, as well as a golf academy and a driving range. A hotel and most of the gated housing community should be finished by the second or third quarter of 2010, al-Gurg said.
Yesterday, Woods paid his first visit to the construction site since knee surgery in June sidelined him for the rest of the 2008 season. He said he didn't know when he might return to play next year.
"It's frustrating for me," he said when asked about the injury.
Woods didn't rule out defending his Dubai Desert Classic title, adding he plans to "be hitting golf balls at the beginning of the year."
Despite its dry, desert climate - the temperature yesterday hovered near 38 - Dubai is rapidly becoming a major golfing destination.
The city, which is banking on tourism to diversify its economy, hosts the Dubai Desert Classic and Dubai Ladies Masters each year.
Woods said he drew inspiration for his first course from clubs in the "sand-belt" golfing region near Melbourne, Australia.
"We want this golf course to play fast, quick," he said, while remaining appealing to a broad range of players.
Woods is not the only golfer laying out links in Dubai.
An 18-hole course designed by Colin Montgomerie was launched in 2006, and one by Ernie Els opened this year. Greg Norman, Sergio Garcia, Pete Dye and Vijay Singh are also working on courses scheduled to open this year or next.
Dubai developers have tapped other marquee names as well as they struggle to make their projects stand out in an increasingly crowded real-estate market.
Actor Brad Pitt has signed on to help design a hotel, while clothing maker Giorgio Armani is outfitting apartments in the unfinished Burj Dubai, already the world's tallest building.
Plans for Woods's course were made public more than a year and a half ago. But as the project and a number of other high-profile developments near completion, fears are growing that Dubai's soaring property market may be due for a correction.
But al-Gurg said he wasn't worried Dubai market concerns could make it difficult to fill the high-end houses around the golf course. After all, he said, it's not everywhere homeowners can say their backyard has been designed by Woods.
"The Tiger Woods Dubai is catering toward a niche market," al-Gurg said, adding that the developers were in no hurry, but were "focused on quality" to attract potential residents to the 197 exclusive housings.
Credit: Associated Press

B.C.'s blueberry blues

Author: Brethour, Patrick

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/b-c-s-blueberry-blues/docview/382759426/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The only reason that the Juliet Creek development stands a shot at all is its success in allying itself with one of the local native bands, the Coldwater. Westscapes Development and the Coldwater have moved beyond the typically tired dance of business-native discussions - how much shall I pay to build a cultural centre? - arriving at what looks to be a fully formed partnership. The band will get a 10-per-cent equity stake, a seat on the board and a share in whatever real estate parcels are developed.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=B.C.%27s+blueberry+blues&amp;author=Brethour%2C+Patrick&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-22&amp;spage=B.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=B.C.%27s+blueberry+blues&amp;author=Brethour%2C+Patrick&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-08-22&amp;spage=B.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The huckleberries and blueberries on the slopes of the Nicola Valley are hitting their juicy peaks this month, making it prime picking time for the Indian bands up and down the undeveloped stretches that gird the modern Coquihalla Highway running to the B.C. Interior.
Those succulent berries are much more than a sweet treat. They are ripening into a point of conflict between those bands, and companies yearning to develop the valley's tourism potential.
Drive the mountain motorways of the Coquihalla - a spectacular trip in summer, however nerve-wracking in winter - and two things are striking, beyond the spectacular vistas. One is the swaths of dead red pine, the carnage left behind by the pine beetle. And the second is the complete lack of any significant enterprise that can make up for the economic devastation caused by the beetle, and resulting evisceration of the forestry industry.
Enter the resort industry, and seemingly common-sense plans to build a skiing and golf complex, the Juliet Creek Resort, near the Coquihalla Summit. Westscapes Development Inc. of Vancouver is proposing a facility with a base area of 200 hectares, able to handle 7,000 skiers a day, and for summer, an 18-hole golf course. There would also be a village, including 2,500 dwelling units. All told, the project would cost $2-billion, and create hundreds of construction jobs, not to mention the permanent jobs at the resort and associated retail businesses.
The complex would be just a two-hour drive from the Lower Mainland, assuming astonishingly nasty mountain winters aren't slowing down the trip. The location is superb, the economics make sense. The problem? Those huckleberries and blueberries.
The area in which the resort is to be built also happens to be among the best areas for picking berries, as well as a spiritually important region. In British Columbia, those kinds of claims are typically a death sentence for economic development. The lack of any broad progress on settling land claims has created a legal miasma that aboriginal bands have deftly turned to their advantage time and again, aided by a string of Supreme Court decisions. No court has yet granted natives a veto over economic development, but they are exercising it nonetheless.
The only reason that the Juliet Creek development stands a shot at all is its success in allying itself with one of the local native bands, the Coldwater. Westscapes Development and the Coldwater have moved beyond the typically tired dance of business-native discussions - how much shall I pay to build a cultural centre? - arriving at what looks to be a fully formed partnership. The band will get a 10-per-cent equity stake, a seat on the board and a share in whatever real estate parcels are developed. In return, the company gets the support of the band most affected by the resort and, more important, the ability to fend off the demands of other bands. Despite the Coldwater band's agreement, several other bands are not dropping their opposition, including the Shackan, who live 70 kilometres from the proposed site - 25 kilometres farther away than the Coldwater.
Grand Chief Percy Joe of the Shackan says his people have used that site for centuries to harvest berries and to perform spiritual ceremonies, and don't want to see the area despoiled. His demands are stark. No resort, of any size, now or ever. No deal with Westscapes, even if the project is ultimately approved. "I don't want anything from them and I'm not giving them anything," he says.
Contrast that with the stance of the Coldwater, who say they proceeded in their negotiations with Westscapes as if they owned the land that will be the site of the future resort. They do not have legal title, but claim the area as traditional lands - as do the Shackan, and others. The resulting thicket of land claims, counterclaims and questionable assertions makes the tangle of a huckleberry bush seem positively tidy.
Will the support of the Coldwater allow Westscapes to avoid the development limbo that other proposed resorts in the B.C. Interior have drifted in for years, even decades? The band's backing combined with the economic pressures of the pine-beetle disaster could make the difference, and tilt the balance toward jobs and growth, instead of a month of berry-picking.
And that would only be fair. After all, it was the first wave of economic development in the Nicola Valley - decades of logging - that cleared the way for all those luscious berry patches.

Title: B.C.'s blueberry blues

Publication title: The Globe and Mail; Toronto, Ont.
