____________________________________________________________

He helped build Tilden Rent-a-Car into a thriving, all-Canadian concern

Author: Martin, Sandra

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/he-helped-build-tilden-rent-car-into-thriving-all/docview/382700062/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: [Ted Tilden] expressed publicly a frustration that many anglophone businessmen felt privately when he criticized Quebec's French-only language policy in a speech to the Montreal Chamber of Commerce in February, 1982, calling Bill 101 "darn fool language legislation" and "crock of lard," while accusing a "nationalist elite" of "committing suicide - theirs and ours." In retaliation, the province's largest teacher's union terminated its contract with Tilden,...

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=He+helped+build+Tilden+Rent-a-Car+into+a+thriving%2C+all-Canadian+concern&amp;author=Martin%2C+Sandra&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-30&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=He+helped+build+Tilden+Rent-a-Car+into+a+thriving%2C+all-Canadian+concern&amp;author=Martin%2C+Sandra&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-30&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: With his brother, he ran the family firm. 'Walter was the financial man in the company and Ted was the advertising and promotional guy. They got along very well, so it worked out'
Walter Tilden might have succeeded in the military, professional sports or business. Born in the generation that was reared in the Depression and came of age too late to fight in the Second World War, he was a successful businessman and dedicated volunteer in the expansionist postwar boom in tourism, travel and the car-rental business.
His story, which is ineluctably intertwined with the saga of the feisty, nationalist Tilden Rent-a-Car Co., is a tale of hard work, canny salesmanship and bad luck. Both their fortunes began with a scrappy American immigrant named Sam Tilden, who parlayed a Hertz franchise in Montreal into a lucrative rental and leasing operation with outlets across the country and affiliates around the world. The end came after a fiery New York crash involving a Tilden rental car brought a threat of massive litigation. The company was later sold to National Car Rental in the United States.
Walter Benedict Tilden, the third of four sons of Samuel (Sam) and Sylvia (nee Dorken) Tilden was born in Montreal the year before the Crash. Three years earlier, Sam Tilden, a shoe salesman, had bought the Hertz franchise for Montreal after answering an ad in the Saturday Evening Post. He went into the car-rental business with three Chryslers and a loan from his father.
Walter's older brothers Sam and Robert (Rob) called him "Squealer" when he was a small child, because he could be guaranteed to complain to their parents when they set upon him. "The more we teased him, the more he would fight back. Ultimately, of course, he became a determined, formidable competitor both in business and the sports world," Robert Tilden said in a eulogy at his younger brother's funeral. "Walter was the most all-rounded guy I have ever known," he added in an interview. "He did a tremendous amount of social work and won all kinds of awards for it."
Walter's father was a scrapper and an canny entrepreneur. Hertz wrenched its franchise back, thinking it could squeeze more money out of the car-rental business in Montreal itself, so Mr. Tilden went into the miniature-golf business in 1929, then sold off his golf properties before the Depression crippled the economy. By 1932, Mr. Tilden had his franchise back, several valuable pieces of property and a comfortable house in Westmount atop Mount Royal. His sons went to Roslyn School and then Westmount High School.
Like his father, Walter was a natural athlete. An avid skier and sailor, he wanted to follow his brother Rob into the navy during the Second World War. He applied to Royal Roads Military College in Victoria and won a sea-cadet scholarship, but by the time he arrived, in September, 1945, the war was over. Near the end of his first academic year, he was diagnosed with glandular tuberculosis and prescribed the "rest cure," a common treatment at the time. After resting all summer, he was not deemed well enough to return to Royal Roads. Instead, he enrolled at McGill University in Montreal, where he was forbidden to engage in any sports or extracurricular activities. He returned to Victoria in September, 1947, and although disappointed to be a year behind his original classmates at Royal Roads, he distinguished himself in sailing and golf and was named cadet captain of Rodney Division. He remained an active alumnus for the rest of his life; Royal Roads awarded him an honorary degree in 1993, the same year that he and brother Ted were inducted into the Canadian Business Hall of Fame.
After Royal Roads, he went back to McGill, which gave him two years of academic credit. He won letters in golf, rugby, skiing, squash and water polo, graduating with a bachelor of commerce degree in 1950. He had plenty of job offers, but turned them all down to work for his father in the car-rental business.
At the time, Tilden had three outlets - Montreal, Hamilton and Ottawa - with Walter heading up the Ottawa franchise. Sixteen months later, on Sept. 22, 1951, he married Jane Brenchley, a McGill graduate (1951) and the sister of one of his classmates at Royal Roads. By then, the Ottawa franchise boasted a fleet of eight cars. Mrs. Tilden can still remember pushing her son, Bruce, in a baby carriage up to the gas station at Somerset and Bronson, where the Tilden franchise was located, to look at the first truck they bought. "It really was a grassroots operation," she said. "And it grew and grew."
The 1950s was an expansionist time in business travel and car rentals, and being independent of car manufacturers gave Tilden a competitive edge. In 1952, Paul Edward (Ted), the youngest of Sam Tilden's sons, joined the company and moved to Victoria with his wife, Pixie, to run the newly acquired Tilden franchise there. A year later, Sam Tilden and several other Hertz franchise owners, who were fed up with the American company's onerous cancellation policy (which allowed Hertz to take back a franchise without cause on 60 days notice) and its insistence that advertising copy written south of the border applied equally well in Canada, formed The Tilden Rent-a-Car System. Within a year, they had more than 100 locations in Canada, although not in Toronto, which remained with Hertz. A decade later, with Canadians and Americans heading abroad in droves, Mr. Tilden made a deal with National Car Rentals, out of Minneapolis, to establish a 50/50 network of independently owned outlets in Europe called Europcar. Later, Mr. Tilden made the same kind of deal with Nippon Rent-A-Car in Asia.
By the mid 1960s, the family-owned Tilden Corp., had three main companies: Tilden Rent-a-Car Co., of which Walter was president; Tilden-Rent-a Car Ltd., of which Ted was president; and Tilden Drive Yourself (Hamilton) Ltd. Sam, the patriarch, was chairman. All of these companies, and their approximately 2,000 vehicles, were part of The Tilden Rent-a-Car System, which also included about 2,500 cars belonging to independent franchise operators in various spots across the country. The system had about 200 outlets in Canada - the most airport and downtown locations of any car-rental operation in Canada - and affiliates in 35 other countries. They spent close to $10-million a year buying new cars for the rental fleets and grossed about $10-million in revenues in Canada alone.
Sam Tilden died of a heart attack in June, 1973. He was 76. Walter succeeded his father as chairman. The next year, Walter and Ted Tilden bought the elusive Toronto franchise from Hertz and moved head office from Montreal to Toronto - a headquarters shift they almost certainly would not have made while their father was alive. Walter and his family moved to Toronto from Ottawa while Ted and his family stayed in Montreal.
"Walter was the financial man in the company and Ted was the advertising and promotional guy. They got along very well, so it worked out," said their surviving brother, Rob. Although he was supposed to be the communications guru for the company, Ted Tilden could be flamboyant and outspoken. It was a volatile combination - especially in Quebec, where politics had heated up in the aftermath of the formation of the Parti Quebecois in 1968, the October crisis in 1970 and the election of the PQ in 1976.
Ted Tilden expressed publicly a frustration that many anglophone businessmen felt privately when he criticized Quebec's French-only language policy in a speech to the Montreal Chamber of Commerce in February, 1982, calling Bill 101 "darn fool language legislation" and "crock of lard," while accusing a "nationalist elite" of "committing suicide - theirs and ours." In retaliation, the province's largest teacher's union terminated its contract with Tilden, and Treasury Board president Yves Berubé said that Quebec civil servants would in future have to show "good reason" for renting Tilden cars.
The 1990s were both troubling and celebratory times for Walter Tilden. On the positive side, he was heavily involved in volunteer work with Scouts Canada, fishing and hunting, and collecting Canadian art - especially works by the Group of Seven. Then Ted Tilden died at the Royal Victoria Hospital after suffering a heart attack on the squash court at the Montreal Athletic Association on March 6, 1991. He was 60 and had owned 50 per cent of the operation.
There was a second disaster in the offing. Two months after Ted Tilden's death, a Toronto couple and two friends from Mississauga were burned to death when the Tilden car they had rented in Canada was hit by a gasoline tanker shortly after midnight at an intersection in the Bronx area of New York. The tanker rolled on top of the car, spilled half its 4,000 gallons of gasoline and exploded. The fireball killed the driver, engulfed a row of nearly a dozen stores, including a pet store, and set off a series of explosions in parked cars. More than 200 firefighters worked for three hours to bring the blaze under control. A spokesman for Island Transportation Corp., the owner of the fuel truck, claimed the traffic lights weren't working properly when its driver hit the Tilden car broadside.
Meanwhile, the deep recession of the early 1990s and bitter competition in the car-rental markets were hurting the company's bottom line. In March, 1992, the company took on a new name, Tilden InterRent, to play up its global connections by sharing customer information, branding and travel-rewards programs with a network of international partners at 4,000 locations and 1,1000 airports in 124 countries.
Ominously, the nearly two dozen claims, including suits for wrongful death, that had come out of the 1991 traffic accident were wending their way through the U.S. legal system at a time when juries were awarding vast amounts of money in personal-injury lawsuits. The truck company did not have enough insurance to cover the potentially colossal costs and a local law allowed plaintiffs to seek redress from Tilden.
In June, 1995, Mr. Tilden, by then 67, entered into serious negotiations to sell the company for "estate planning reasons." He stipulated that he wouldn't sell to a competitor. "We are trying to protect everybody's jobs," although not necessarily his own, he told The Globe and Mail. He was willing to stay on to ensure an orderly transition. "If they want me, I'm there to help," he said.
A month later, Newcourt Credit Group Inc. bought Tilden's leasing operations. Tilden's long-time American associate, National Car Rental, was an obvious purchaser for the rest of the company. It had no outlets in Canada, but was Tilden's international partner in InterRent. The talks stalled in February, 1996, (about the time that Walter Tilden retired and was succeeded by his niece Patricia Tilden as president and chief executive officer of the family company) when the 17 lawsuits from the 1991 accident were consolidated, causing Tilden's bankers to become twitchy. Tilden tried to cap its potential liability by seeking protection under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement from the Ontario Court of Justice late in April, 1996, about a month before the lawsuits were expected to go to trial.
"The Bronx litigation and the recent experience of the Loewen Group Inc. at the hands of an American jury [a tiny American competitor sued the Canadian funeral-home operator and was awarded $500-million (U.S.) in November, 1995] have made potential investors extremely leery of investing in Tilden, until the amount of the damages - if any - the company faces, can be quantified," Patricia Tilden said in an affidavit.
Early in June, 1996, a U.S. judge ruled that Tilden could be liable for part of any awards made by a jury, although Walter Tilden's son, Bruce, says the claims were eventually tossed out of court. Within a week, National had paid $115-million for Tilden's fleet of vehicles. It accepted 95 per cent of Tilden's employees and agreed to operate in Canada under the name National Tilden. Tilden retained its $4-million worth of real-estate assets. "In hindsight, our timing couldn't have been better because of 9/11 and the economy and everything that has happened since," Patricia Tilden said in an interview.
By then, Mr. Tilden had been diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. He refused to let it slow him down, and carried on dealing with the Tilden real-estate interests, his volunteer work with Scouts, his passion for collecting Canadian landscape art and helping two friends set up and promote a fishing lodge in the Queen Charlotte Islands. In his last five years, he surmounted heart disease and prostate cancer, only to be diagnosed in late spring with liver cancer.
Late in June, a delegation of Scouts came to Mr. Tilden's house to make a special presentation honouring him with his 45-year service pin. At his funeral, Mrs. Tilden said, "there was a whole row of scouts wearing their blazers and ties," including a nephew who had run a huge Scout jamboree in Quebec last year. He turned up in his scout uniform and said "he had been inspired by Walter."
WALTER TILDEN
Walter Tilden, C.M., was born May 23, 1928, in Montreal. He died July 9, 2008, in Toronto. He was 80. Predeceased by his infant son, Andrew, and brothers Sam and Ted, he is survived by his wife Jane, six children, four grandchildren, brother Robert, many nieces and nephews and his extended family.
Credit: smartin@globeandmail.com

Down Under, landscape art meets deco style

Author: Frangou, Christina

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/down-under-landscape-art-meets-deco-style/docview/382699800/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: LOCATION Depending on which way you head when you walk out its door, The [Tim Storrier] sits in one of the most sophisticated areas of Sydney or one of the shabbiest. It's located at the south end of Potts Point. Just a few streets north, you'll find mind-blowing sushi, eclectic galleries, avant-garde theatre, boutiques and some of the city's most expensive real estate. Walk south and seedy strip joints abound.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Down+Under%2C+landscape+art+meets+deco+style&amp;author=Frangou%2C+Christina&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-30&amp;spage=R.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Down+Under%2C+landscape+art+meets+deco+style&amp;author=Frangou%2C+Christina&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-30&amp;spage=R.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: THE STORRIER
15 Springfield Ave., Sydney;
61 (0) 2 8988 6999; www.thestorrier.com
ROOMS AND RATES
Seventy rooms from $195 for a superior room (one double bed); the executive twin suite (with kitchenette) is $780.
Sure, you can follow the guidebooks and go gallery-hopping around Sydney's Potts Point. Or you can take things up a notch and check in for a stay at the The Storrier, which calls itself Australia's first "art hotel." This sleek hotel-cum-gallery takes its cues from the work of Tim Storrier, a Sydney-born, internationally renowned artist known for quirky images of the Australian landscape.
Every element of the hotel is based on Storrier's work. Original works adorn the public areas and some guest rooms. Even the hotel's colour palette - neutral with burnt-orange highlights - draws on Point to Point (Evening Blaze) , the artist's painting of a giant burning rope across a night sky. And if guests just can't get enough of Storrier, they can purchase a pair of flip-flops emblazoned with the burning rope image.
The brainchild of wealthy Australian art collector Will Deague, The Storrier is the first of seven art hotels scheduled to open in Sydney and Melbourne over the next three years.
LOCATION Depending on which way you head when you walk out its door, The Storrier sits in one of the most sophisticated areas of Sydney or one of the shabbiest. It's located at the south end of Potts Point. Just a few streets north, you'll find mind-blowing sushi, eclectic galleries, avant-garde theatre, boutiques and some of the city's most expensive real estate. Walk south and seedy strip joints abound. But it's central; The Storrier lies less than three kilometres from Sydney's opera house, Royal Botanic Gardens and the Rocks, the city's oldest neighbourhood.
DESIGN The Storrier draws inspiration from two sources: the building's art deco heritage and Point to Point (Evening Blaze) , the painting that dominates the lobby. The hotel has a vaguely old-Hollywood feel with contemporary paintings and black-and-white photos on beige walls. High marks for the finishing touches: black-and-white striped parlour chairs in the bedrooms, a swan-shaped spout in a bathroom and an ornate Moooi chandelier made of paper in the dining room.
CLIENTELE If our eavesdropping is any indication, many guests are repeat visitors. They tend to be stylish Australians, generally couples or business types in their 30s and 40s who appreciate art and red wine.
AMBIENCE Coolly artsy; guests are happy to sit for hours with a latte and the morning newspaper. Don't expect maids in uniforms to bring you bedtime chocolates.
ROOMS Because of the building's curious proportions (it's a three-sided structure with a curved front), no two rooms are alike. Each room has luxurious queen-size beds topped with a black faux-fur blanket and high-end linens, plasma television screens and iPod docking stations. Many have a fully equipped kitchenette, original Storrier works and access to a rooftop terrace. The bathrooms, however, are very small, with no bathtub or space to place a toiletry bag by the sink. On the flip side, they have marble surfaces and come with sweet-smelling Molton Brown products.
SERVICE Friendly and efficient. All our requests were carried out by exquisitely attractive staff. When we decided to extend our reservation at the last minute, the front desk worked a bit of magic so we didn't have to change rooms. Gym and spa services are not available onsite, but are nearby.
FOOD AND DRINK The neighbourhood suffers no shortage of bars or restaurants. But it's difficult to walk past without nipping into the hotel's Red Belly restaurant, with its marble bar and flamingo motif wallpaper. The restaurant offers extensive à la carte and "grazing" menus for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Dinner service includes Aussie-isms such as "cockles and chorizo" and oven-baked coconut with sea scallops. Twenty-four-hour room service is available.
Warning: Beware the $90 bottle of wine in the room. We didn't receive a mini-bar menu in our room and very nearly popped the cork. Turns out wines aren't affordable quite everywhere in Australia.
THINGS TO DO Sit on the rooftop terrace and watch the sun set behind the Opera House. Check out the 10,000 plant species in the nearby Royal Botanic Gardens. Scope out the nearby Ferrari, Lamborghini and Maserati dealerships. Or you could browse boutiques, bookstores and galleries in Potts Point.
Don't miss Martin Browne Fine art, a popular gallery that showcases Australian and international modern artists (57-59 Macleay St., www.martinbrownefineart.com). Wander next door into the Yellow Bistro & Food Store, a tiny restaurant and grocery that is a favourite of local foodies.
BOTTOM LINE: Original and comfortable space at very good rates for central Sydney.
*****
Hotel vitals
Top Draw
Creative digs in a colourful neighbourhood just outside the centre of Sydney. The Serene Sleep Beds deserve special
mention.
Needs Work
Some of the streets close to the hotel are dodgy, day or night.

He survived the battle of Hong Kong and four years as a PoW in Japan

Author: Kelly-Anne Riess

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/he-survived-battle-hong-kong-four-years-as-pow/docview/382702244/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: After finishing high school, Mr. [Bernard Jesse] went to Sudbury, where [Reynold] was working in a mine. Once there, Mr. Jesse decided mining wasn't for him and decided to enlist in the Royal Canadian Air Force. Even though the Second World War had started, the air force wasn't recruiting, so Mr. Jesse signed up with the Winnipeg Grenadiers, a woefully equipped infantry regiment that was still using old uniforms and rifles from the First World War.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=He+survived+the+battle+of+Hong+Kong+and+four+years+as+a+PoW+in+Japan&amp;author=Kelly-Anne+Riess&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-29&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=He+survived+the+battle+of+Hong+Kong+and+four+years+as+a+PoW+in+Japan&amp;author=Kelly-Anne+Riess&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-29&amp;spage=S.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Poorly trained and ill equipped, he was among Canadian soldiers sent to protect the British colony. Later, he returned home and prospered, but remained forever haunted by his wartime experiences
A meteorologist, businessman, politician and writer, Bernard Jesse was a pillar of his community in Estevan, Sask. Despite his successes, Mr. Jesse was haunted by a dark past, having been a prisoner of war in Japan, where he was beaten regularly and forced to do slave labour in a coal mine.
The son of a Michigan couple who had settled in Western Canada under the Dominion Lands Act that promoted settlement, he grew up on the family farm near Wordsworth, Sask., a small village about 200 kilometres southeast of Regina. The third of seven children, he was a competitive lad who enrolled at the local one-room schoolhouse a year earlier than usual. He had insisted on an early start to his education because he didn't want to be outdone by his sister Violet, who was a year older.
When the Depression hit, the Jesses weren't affected as much as other farm families on the Prairies. While his father worked as a foreman for the railroad, Bernard and his older brother, Reynold, would ride the rails to Manitoba in the summer, picking up work as farmhands where they could. The boys would earn a few cents for a 14-hour day of hard manual labour and used the money to buy new school clothes in the fall, dickering with shopkeepers to get a good price.
After finishing high school, Mr. Jesse went to Sudbury, where Reynold was working in a mine. Once there, Mr. Jesse decided mining wasn't for him and decided to enlist in the Royal Canadian Air Force. Even though the Second World War had started, the air force wasn't recruiting, so Mr. Jesse signed up with the Winnipeg Grenadiers, a woefully equipped infantry regiment that was still using old uniforms and rifles from the First World War. His training was minimal - he learned how to march and assemble and disassemble weapons, but there were no bullets for shooting practice. But his pay was 75 cents a day, a lot more than he could make farming.
In early 1940, the regiment was sent to Jamaica to perform garrison duty and guard German prisoners of war. Mr. Jesse worked as a motorcycle scout, keeping a watch on islanders who were thought to be sympathetic to the enemy.
By September, 1941, the unit was back in Winnipeg - but not for long. To discourage sabre-rattling by the Japanese, Britain figured it should send soldiers to protect Hong Kong. Since British troops were at a premium, Canada was asked to contribute, and in October, the Grenadiers and the Royal Rifles from Quebec set sail for the colony. Neither regiment had much experience, but few were overly concerned, since Japan was not yet at war. Following a zigzag pattern to avoid targeting by German submarines, their ship took 33 days to reach Hong Kong. On Nov. 16, they marched ashore to the beat of a military band.
Three weeks later, the Japanese struck - just hours after the attack on Pearl Harbor. The Canadians were entirely unprepared. Outnumbered and outgunned - their artillery and machine guns had been mistakenly sent to Manila - they fought bravely with little more than rifles, grenades and side arms.
Mr. Jesse was stringing up a telephone wire when he saw the Japanese planes overhead. Over the next several days, he was involved in a number of minor skirmishes, but did not appreciate the severity of the situation until the pill boxes the men were holed up in were hit by mortar fire. Out of 14 men in his unit, only Mr. Jesse and three others survived.
The four men were then sent to guard a bridge, where they encountered a truck with loudspeakers that announced the fighting was over. Skeptical, Mr. Jesse and the others held their position and later retreated to headquarters. It was there, on Christmas Day, that they were told they were prisoners of war. Their fighting days were over. For others in Hong Kong, the situation only became worse. In what became known as "Black Christmas," Japanese soldiers went on a rampage of looting, attacking hospitals and schools and terrorizing civilians. Hundreds of men were murdered at random and an estimated 10,000 women were raped.
After packing up as much food and clothing as they could carry, Mr. Jesse and his comrades were marched to an old building where living conditions proved to be poor. An outbreak of diphtheria hit the camp, throwing Mr. Jesse into a state of delirium. The illness eventually caused him to lose his sight.
Nursed back to health by fellow prisoners, his vision returned and he was sent to Japan to work in a Tokyo shipyard, cutting steel. That came to an end when the site was attacked by U.S. bombers. Everyone ran to the safety of bomb shelters except Mr. Jesse. The diphtheria had left his legs permanently crippled and he could move no faster than walking pace.
After the shipyard, the men were sent to work in a remote coal mine where conditions were primitive and dangerous. They were expected to continually dig while standing in hot water and sulphur. Month after month they were beaten, starved and denied contact with the International Red Cross. The only reason Mr. Jesse's parents knew he was alive was because the Red Cross had earlier been allowed to record greetings from him and some of the other soldiers. The recording made it to Canada and onto the radio waves, which gave them hope that they might see him again.
In the mines, little changed from day to day, and the PoWs were beginning to give up when they woke up one morning to discover that all the guards had disappeared. Some of the prisoners ran into the bushes to see if they would draw any fire, but nothing happened. Thin, hungry and underweight, they stole chickens and eggs from a farm and figured out what to do next.
The question was answered when an American plane dropped food and supplies. It seemed the war was over.
They found a road, which led to some train tracks. Upon coming to a train station, Mr. Jesse and a group of 10 men decided to storm it and kidnap an engineer, whom they had to beat in order to convince him to fire up a locomotive. Their destination was Tokyo.
They didn't know what would happen to them once they got there. There was the possibility they could be killed, but they hoped the enemy would be merciful in acknowledgment that the war had ended.
When they arrived, they were met by an Allied soldier. At last, they were in safe hands. They were soon transferred to a hospital on Guam in the mid-Pacific, and Mr. Jesse was finally able to phone home. Sadly, they left behind thousands of comrades - one in four Canadian PoWs had died in captivity, a vastly higher ratio than those who had been held by the Germans.
When he arrived back in Saskatchewan, an article in the Regina Leader-Post celebrated his homecoming. But he still wasn't out of the woods. Doctors worried he might have tuberculosis and would not let him see his parents until he submitted to an X-ray.
He was cleared, but the reunion remained brief. He was sent away to be treated for an ailment called beriberi, a vitamin deficiency caused by prolonged malnutrition that caused foot pain for the rest of his life.
After getting out of hospital, he felt well enough to attend a dance, where he met a young woman named Marcella Grimes. They fell in love and married in 1946. A year later, he and Reynold started Jesse's Meat Market in Estevan. But Mr. Jesse's career as a butcher wouldn't last long. The job was physically demanding and required long hours of work that aggravated his war injuries.
Instead, Mr. Jesse trained as a meteorologist and got a job with the department of transport, where he worked for 30 years. On the side, he and his wife owned and operated an insurance and real-estate company. They also raised five children.
Over the years, Mr. Jesse spent one term as a city councillor in Estevan, served on the local Catholic school board and was active in the Canadian Legion and in the Knights of Columbus.
Like many veterans, he never talked about what had happened to him during the war. Privately, he suffered unrelenting nightmares about the experience. He finally had a nervous breakdown and found himself back in hospital. He was treated by a doctor who urged him to tell his story.
Taking the advice to heart, he approached a neighbour named Norm Park, a newspaper columnist for the Estevan Mercury, for help. Initially, the project was intended to be read only by Mr. Jesse's children and grandchildren. However, as the story unfolded, Mr. Park realized it was too important and asked Mr. Jesse if he would consider writing a book with him.
The result was Seared in My Memory , which flew off the shelves and is now in its second printing. Surprised by its success, Mr. Jesse joked that he might have to be imprisoned a few more years so he could write another book.
BERNARD JESSE
Bernard Jesse was born Oct. 28, 1917, near Wordsworth, Sask. He died Mar. 23, 2008, at St. Joseph's Hospital in Estevan. He was 90. He is survived by daughter Marion and sons Warren, Colin and Howard. He was predeceased by his wife, Marcella, and by daughter Ferne.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

____________________________________________________________

Towns seek review of forestry decision

Author: Hunter, Justine

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/towns-seek-review-forestry-decision/docview/382712098/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "And there is a huge volume of wood being left behind; what impact that has on water quality and jobs forgone is anybody's guess," Mr. [Ben Parfitt] said, "but it's not likely to be good."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Towns+seek+review+of+forestry+decision&amp;author=Hunter%2C+Justine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-28&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Alliance of municipalities says province 'playing with fire' by not consulting them before deregulating private timberlands on Island
A series of private land-use deals between the province of B.C. and forestry companies, already under fire from environmentalists, has triggered a battle between Gordon Campbell's government and an influential alliance of local governments.
In a letter obtained by The Globe and Mail, a group representing 48 municipal and regional governments is calling on the Premier to review his government's decision to significantly deregulate forestry on 20,000 hectares of private timberlands on Vancouver Island by removing them from the tree-farm licence system.
"Local governments on Vancouver Island have expressed profound concerns that these lands were removed without adequate consultation," states the July 17 letter from Barry Janyk, president of the Association of Vancouver Island and Coastal Communities.
Mr. Janyk, who is also the mayor of Gibsons, said the issue is generating anger well beyond the affected communities.
"The provincial government ignores local government at their peril," he said. "An attack on one constituency is an attack on everyone. ... They are playing with fire."
Earlier this month, B.C. Auditor-General John Doyle found the most recent deal, worth $150-million to Western Forest Products, was made without due regard for the public interest.
Mr. Doyle said the government should have examined the impact of previous changes before granting the request of Western Forest Products, paving the way for an ambitious real-estate project around Jordan River despite opposition from the regional government. Jordan River is a tiny community between Sooke and Port Renfrew.
The largest of the previous changes took place four years ago in the Port Alberni valley, where almost 90,000 hectares of land were removed from managed tree-farm licences.
Port Alberni Mayor Ken McRae said the change, which he learned of only after the deal was signed, has had an impact on the city's water supply and on jobs.
He's disturbed by the amount of waste wood being left on the privately managed forest lands, which he sees as lost jobs for his struggling community.
As well, the city last year had to issue boil-water advisories that he believes can be tied to logging activity near the China Creek water intake.
Warren Lauder, the forest resource manager of the Hupacasath First Nation, also sees the private forestry operations around China Creek as a menace to fishing, hunting and sacred sites in his community's traditional territories.
Standing on a forestry road in the watershed last week, he laughed bitterly as he pointed out a couple of lonely fir trees, naked except for some tufts of green at their tops, left behind in a wide clear-cut.
"There's a wildlife-management stand for you."
The land used to support elk, deer and black bears. On this day, there is little sign of life in the exposed landscape.
The Hupacasath have been in court fighting to regain some control over what happens on the private timberlands around Port Alberni, and a ruling on consultation is expected from the B.C. Supreme Court in September.
The lands have been privately owned by various logging interests since 1887, but a large portion were under tree-farm licences that gave the timber companies access to public timber in exchange for a higher standard of regulation on their private lands.
Darshan Sihota, president of Island Timberlands, said the removal from the TFLs frees his company to respond to market demands without government dictating how much they can cut each year or where it can build logging roads. But he said the company is still committed to good logging practices.
Forestry analyst Ben Parfitt said the lack of regulation makes it hard to measure the true impact of private logging in watersheds.
His research does suggest the level of harvest has gone up considerably on private lands when they've been removed from TFLs.
"And there is a huge volume of wood being left behind; what impact that has on water quality and jobs forgone is anybody's guess," Mr. Parfitt said, "but it's not likely to be good."
Pat Bell, B.C.'s new Forests Minister, said in interview he doesn't believe government can undo past deals, but is considering whether private forest lands that have been removed from TFLs should be returned to his ministry for some degree of oversight.
And, he promised local government will have a say in future requests to delete private lands from TFLs.

Author: Barnes, Thomasina

Abstract: "Fishing in Port Renfrew can be a casual day experience," Mr. [Ben Mycroft] notes. "You can drive there from Victoria or [Duncan] in the morning and be at your cottage and on the water by the afternoon."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cottage+getaways+on+Vancouver+Island%27s+%27forgotten+coast%27&amp;author=Barnes%2C+Thomasina&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Wild Coast Cottages
Location: Port Renfrew Developer: Three Point Properties
Price: Lots begin at $99,000; cottages start at $200,000
Size: Lots from 5,000 square feet to ½ acre
Sales centre: N/A
Contact: Phone 250-413-2164 or visit www.wildcoastcottages.com
***
As demand for recreational property in British Columbia continues to rise, so do prices. Three Point Properties hopes to have created an affordable solution with its West Coast Cottages, a release of 30 fully serviced lots in Port Renfrew, on Vancouver Island.
"Part of our concept for the first phase of development in Port Renfrew is to create a product that is not prohibitively expensive," says project manager Ben Mycroft.
By combining the smallest cottage plan from the development's preferred builder, Citta Group Construction, interested buyers can purchase a home-and-lot package for less than $300,000.
Citta Group has created a selection of house plans which range from two to four bedrooms between 1,180 square feet and 1,900 sq. ft.
"The entire process has been made very simple," Mr. Mycroft says.
"Financing has been arranged by a local Vancouver Island credit union. Purchasers are able to select from a variety of complementary West Coast contemporary cottage plans, and Citta Group Construction is mobilized to build cottages when the buyers are ready."
Purchasers are also free to use a builder of their choice, so long as their dwellings adhere to design guidelines to ensure consistency with neighbouring cottages and the surrounding wilderness.
Located on what is often called Vancouver Island's "forgotten coast," Port Renfrew offers an outdoor lifestyle that rivals Tofino, with great surf breaks, ocean and river fishing, boating and hiking. It is the starting point of the West Coast Trail and the end point of the Juan de Fuca Marine Trail.
While the development's location on the island's southwest coast offers a remote feel, Wild Coast Cottages is just a two-hour drive from Victoria or Duncan.
"Fishing in Port Renfrew can be a casual day experience," Mr. Mycroft notes. "You can drive there from Victoria or Duncan in the morning and be at your cottage and on the water by the afternoon."
Before offering the cottage lots to the general public, Three Point Properties released the project locally and met with "great" support, Mr. Mycroft says.
"Generally, local residents realize the benefits that will accrue to the town from investment in community infrastructure and amenities."
Several residents bought lots in the development, he say. "We attracted attention from local recreational home buyers and residents of Port Renfrew, who wanted to transition from their current home to a new home in a lovely area. Now, we're taking the project out to the wider world."

Full text: Enclave on Park Lane

Keep your home's biggest energy hog on a leash

Author: Holmes, Mike

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/keep-your-homes-biggest-energy-hog-on-leash/docview/382705383/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The fact is, bigger is not better. An AC unit that's too big is a waste of money to purchase, inefficient to operate, and isn't comfortable. An oversized unit will turn on and off more often, which is annoying and wasteful. So how do you make sure you don't get sold more cooling capacity than you should have?

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Keep+your+home%27s+biggest+energy+hog+on+a+leash&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=G.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Keep+your+home%27s+biggest+energy+hog+on+a+leash&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=G.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Getting a high-efficiency unit is important, but they have to be installed properly and maintained regularly
Every summer the heat and humidity drives homeowners to turn up their air conditioners. If you've got an older unit, maybe it's time to think about replacing it with a new, more energy-efficient one.
Older air conditioners - both central and room - use 30- to 70-per cent more electricity than newer energy-efficient models, driving up peak demand and costing you more. In addition, older units can corrode or rust, leading to refrigerants, HCFCs and CFCs leaking and causing environmental damage and pollution. Air conditioners contain refrigerants like freon, that create the cooling effect. These are ozone-depleting substances and have global restrictions to ensure they are not released into the atmosphere.
BIGGER ISN'T ALWAYS BETTER
Window and portable units are effective for cooling small spaces, and cost a lot less than central AC, which cools the entire home.
The size of the air conditioning unit you need is entirely dependent on your home. Contractors bidding on central AC installation jobs often incorrectly estimate the tonnage needed. Some HVAC contractors over-estimate their clients' need to make absolutely sure their client has "plenty of cooling capacity," or sometimes simply to sell whatever unit they happen to have sitting on the truck or back at the shop.
The fact is, bigger is not better. An AC unit that's too big is a waste of money to purchase, inefficient to operate, and isn't comfortable. An oversized unit will turn on and off more often, which is annoying and wasteful. So how do you make sure you don't get sold more cooling capacity than you should have?
Make sure your HVAC contractor performs a load calculation using industry-recognized methods, to determine the proper size unit. It's important to take more than just household square footage into account. It's total home air volume that counts. The calculation also needs to take into account local climate conditions, and conditions unique to the house - such as the number of south-facing windows.
Remember, too, that newer houses are more energy-efficient. They have better insulation, quality of windows and greater air tightness, which all greatly affect the amount of cooling power you need.
ARE DUCTS BEING CHECKED?
There should be enough ducts, and they should carry enough air to ensure an adequate supply of cool air to every room - and, just as important, to ensure enough warm air gets back to the air conditioner. Also, the ducts should be as air tight as possible.
The ducts should flow through the conditioned space in your house. If they go through the attic, they should be insulated.
EFFICIENCY IS IMPORTANT
Once you figure out how big an AC unit you need, you'll want to get the most efficient unit you can. This is measured in something called SEER - Seasonal Energy Efficiency Rating. The higher the number, the more energy efficient the unit is.
Old units might have a SEER of 5. You want to go as high as you can - 16 or 18 is great. A SEER 10 will use half the electricity of a SEER 5 unit, and you'll pay for the price difference in energy savings in a few years.
SAVE ENERGY
Air conditioners are one of the biggest consumers of energy in your home, so you want to make sure yours is the most energy-efficient it can be. But even a very high-efficiency air conditioner will perform as badly as an inefficient one if it isn't installed correctly.
TIPS:
* Keep your blinds closed to avoid passive solar heating that will make your AC work harder.
* Close your windows and doors when the AC is on.
* Do laundry and run dishwashers - which create heat - in the evening when it's cooler to avoid peak hours.
* Make sure the condensing unit of your central AC is placed where it will be shaded from the sun.
* Keep the outdoor condensing unit clear of leaves and debris it will cause the unit to work extra hard and wear out sooner. Make sure there is enough space around the outdoor unit to avoid airflow restriction through the coils. Keep landscaping away from the AC unit.
* Try to place the condenser in a place that won't disturb you or your neighbours - they can be noisy.
* Use a programmable thermostat and set it to turn on your AC before you come home, so you're saving energy while you're at work during the day.
Mike Holmes is the host of Holmes on Homes on HGTV. For more information, go to www.holmesonhomes.com
Credit: mikeholmes@holmesonhomes.com

The gilded cottage

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/gilded-cottage/docview/382703513/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Come in, come in," Mr. [Salah Bachir] says. "You don't mind using the servant's entrance do you?" He is grinning ear-to-ear, aware of the impact his so-called "cottage" has on those seeing it for the first time.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+gilded+cottage&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+gilded+cottage&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Salah Bachir's vacation home is a silk purse of a house, astonishing onlookers with its old-world grandeur, Deirdre Kelly reports
With impish understatement, Salah Bachir calls his vacation home in Paris, Ont., a "country house," conjuring up the bucolic vision of a thatched-roofed cottage - an image he takes no pains to correct. Which is what makes the property so hard to find for a first-time visitor from Toronto.
You drive in circles around the town, expecting to find a cutoff that will take you to a log cabin in the woods. Then, believing you are lost, you stop to ask for directions. You are surprised when the person on the street immediately knows the address you're talking about: "You mean the mayor's house? Why, it's right over there."
Craning your neck in the direction of the pointed finger, you see an enormous gated fence. You blink because there's a sculpture you'd expect to find only in the other Paris. You push a button on the intercom, ready to apologize for being in the wrong place. But the gate swings slowly open, and then you see him: not the mayor, but the next best thing - the new lord of the manor, living a life of relaxed elegance.
"Come in, come in," Mr. Bachir says. "You don't mind using the servant's entrance do you?" He is grinning ear-to-ear, aware of the impact his so-called "cottage" has on those seeing it for the first time.
On occasion, Mr. Bachir has heightened that element of surprise by deliberately driving guests up the wrong path to a true rural abode, sinking verandah and all.
"They tell me how charming it is, thinking to be polite," says the well-known Toronto business executive and philanthropist, relishing the tale. "And then I tell them that if they tire of it, they can meet me up at the house, which, when I finally take them to it, they stare at in disbelief."
Quaint it isn't. At more than 9,000 square feet, the sheer scale of the place - not to mention its many rooms filled to the rafters with museum-worthy art - make anyone visiting it for the first time think they've arrived at the real centre of civilization.
Toronto and its gold-tinted condo towers, located less than an hour's drive to the east, seems crass in comparison.
A silk purse of a house, it astonishes all onlookers, including drivers who slow down as they pass, enchanted by its suggestion of old-world grandeur.
"When I'm here, I feel as if I'm really away from it all," Mr. Bachir says. "It's my retreat and my spa, where I surround myself with beauty, where I completely relax."
The former home of Charles Whitelaw, first mayor of Paris, it was built in 1842 in a melange of Tudor, Victorian and Georgian architectural styles borrowed from Mr. Whitelaw's native England.
The mayor was friends with Alexander Graham Bell, the inventor of the telephone who lived in nearby Brantford, and was a frequent visitor to the house in Paris. (In 1876, he received the first long-distance call - from Brantford - in a telegraph office a short walk away at 91 Grand River St. North.)
In those days, the 17-room house featured five bathrooms, and nine fireplaces whose mantels were made of hand-carved Carrara marble. Six remain in the house that today boasts 21 rooms, including five bedrooms and six remodelled bathrooms.
Despite an extensive renovation in which Mr. Bachir created a Zen-inspired, second-floor spa with a steam room, whirlpool tub, walk-in shower and soaring skylight, the house seems like it belongs to another place, another world. A feeling of stateliness remains, even in the renovated basement where the video game Wii dominates a large flat-screen TV.
Made of solid brick with pointed fretwork gables, the home still has such original details as etched-glass windows and ornamental plaster mouldings inside. Carved into a series of window frames in the front foyer are trilliums, the floral emblem of Ontario, a reminder that this was once home to the highest-ranking man in the town.
Giving the home its due, Mr. Bachir has decorated it with hand-cut Murano chandeliers that he purchased in Venice, and antique furniture and rugs bought in part at Jonny's Antiques in nearby Shakespeare, and Stanley Wagman & Son Antiques in Toronto.
Some of the more remarkable pieces include an 18th-century Chinese opium bed in the foyer, and a pair of large wooden angels in the dining room. Once part of a Baroque church in France, the angels adorn the red walls of the dining room, which also features a gold-leaf ceiling. The dining room table, dating from 1870, once belonged to Roland Michener, a former governor-general of Canada. Sitting on an antique carpet from Iran, the table can seat as many as 14 people.
Other rooms have a more contemporary feel, among them a front sitting room with adjoining sunroom, for which Toronto's LA Design created sage-coloured couches. Mr. Bachir encourages his guests to sprawl out on them, in order to better watch the sports channel.
"It's about creating the ultimate in comfort," he says. "I want everyone who comes here to feel that there are no airs, no ceremony. It's about kicking off your shoes, laying back, and feeling like you've come home."
That said, it is a weekend house. Mr. Bachir lives and works in Toronto, where he is president of Cineplex Media, which provides cinema advertising. He is also publisher of the in-theatre magazines Famous, Famous Quebec and Famous Kids.
He also serves as vice-chairman of the Canadian Foundation for AIDS Research, as well as chairman of the 519 Church St. Community Centre capital campaign, to which he personally donated $1-million.
As an arts patron and collector, he specializes in contemporary art, and has one of the world's largest private collections of Andy Warhol, in addition to many works by Canadian artist Attila Lukacs, many of which have never been shown publicly.
In addition to works by those two, his Paris house contains art by dozens of other artists, such as Keith Haring, Betty Goodwin, Frida Kahlo, General Idea (a collective that included Canadian artists Felix Partz, Jorge Zontal and AA Bronson), David Hockney, Robert Mapplethorpe and Jim Dine.
Bronze animal sculptures by Tom Dean, Canada's representative at the 1999 Venice Biennale, and pieces by other sculptors dot the immense, landscaped garden, which offers the fragrances of orange blossoms, roses and hydrangea flowers. This is where Mr. Bachir's beloved Tibetan terrier, Ella - named for jazz singer Ella Fitzgerald, whom Mr. Bachir knew and admired - chases the many chipmunks who freely roam the manicured lawns.
Martin Kohn of Kohn Shnier Architects executed much of the renovation of Mr. Bachir's Paris house, converting a first-floor breezeway into a contemporary entranceway featuring cherry wood, slate and glass, and a new window through which natural light floods.
"I wanted to mix the old style with a modern look," Mr. Bachir says, underscoring his appreciation for the here-and-now. "You can't copy something built 160 years ago and pretend it was built at that time. The trick is to make something that goes and flows and complements the architecture of the time, like the I.M. Pei pyramid at the Louvre, for example, which I think is a perfect blend of old and new."
Working in collaboration with local architect Paul Dowling, Mr. Kohn also executed the conversion of an upstairs bedroom into a spa-like retreat that, while it was being built, was the talk of the town.
"I was stopped in the local IGA by a woman who was scandalized that I would even dare to update the plumbing in such a historic home as this," Mr. Bachir recalls. "I turned to her and said, 'If Queen Victoria could have had heated floors in her day, she would have installed them, too.' "
Friends of Mr. Bachir quip that he bought the country house because he needed more wall space for his magnificent art collection. But Mr. Bachir says he just wanted to get away from the hectic pace of the city.
"I was travelling so much, and wanted to get away from downtown," he says, relaxing into the gentle sway of a rocking chair in his kitchen.
He hatched that plan 16 years ago, while sitting in a Toronto traffic jam.
Wishing for an escape, he flipped open a newspaper lying on the front seat of his car, where he saw an image of the house listed for sale. He noted it was stately.
"I asked a friend if he knew anything about Paris, Ontario," recalls Mr. Bachir. (He eventually discovered that the town, first settled in 1829 along the banks of the Grand River, was named for its nearby deposits of gypsum, the material used to make plaster of Paris.)
The friend did, and coincidentally, was going to a dinner party there the next day. He asked Mr. Bachir to come along.
As fate would have it, the dinner party took place in the very house he had just seen in the newspaper.
Mr. Bachir remembers every detail of that first encounter.
"I was sitting in the living room, admiring the mouldings, the high ceilings, the astonishing architectural detail, and I thought, wow, what I could do with a place like this." The rest, as they say, is history.

Fleeing urbanites feed town's growth

Author: Laidlaw, Katherine

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/fleeing-urbanites-feed-towns-growth/docview/382703473/se-2?accountid=14656

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fleeing+urbanites+feed+town%27s+growth&amp;author=Laidlaw%2C+Katherine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=G.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: For those who are unfamiliar with it, Parry Sound may conjure up the image of a sprinkling of cottages along Georgian Bay. In fact, it's a long-thriving town that's currently experiencing a major boom, according to Perry Harris, president of the local Chamber of Commence.
With a population that goes from about 18,000 in the winter to about 60,000 in the summer, the town and its surrounding area are "diverse," Mr. Harris says. It offers a range of professional, business and recreational opportunities for everyone from young parents to retirees.
The boom is being fuelled mostly by urbanites who are relocating there. They may already have a cottage in the area, he adds, also noting that some may start a small business or seek employment in the town.
The increasing development of the area, which is about 225 kilometres north of Toronto, is attracting more young people, Mr. Harris explains, and changing the plus-50 demographic that has been predominant.
"We have new stores coming in. Home Depot is coming in; Starbucks is coming in," he says. "We have a Lick's restaurant opening up. That's a nice nod to the town.
"We're just a hidden gem up here."
*****

AGENT: Holly Cascanette, HomeLife-Al Boucher Real Estate Ltd., Parry Sound
THE PROPERTY: A detached, three-storey house with five bedrooms and 2½ bathrooms.
DESCRIPTION: This stately, 100-year-old manor home is surrounded by perennial gardens with a pond. The stone and brick, 3,350-square-foot dwelling has a large, covered front porch that opens to a front parlour with hardwood flooring and original stained-glass windows. The main floor includes a large country-style kitchen with wooden cabinetry, formal dining room, living room, family room with gas fireplace, library with another fireplace, two-piece bathroom and laundry room.
Upstairs are four large bedrooms, one of which opens to a long balcony overlooking the front yard.
The third floor contains a 21- by 31-square-foot master bedroom suite with a three-piece bathroom.
NOTABLE: The main floor includes a screened-in sunroom that opens to a wooden deck with a hot tub.

Low-rise suites nestled against Stratford Park

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/low-rise-suites-nestled-against-stratford-park/docview/382702828/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We've attracted some buyers from the other neighbouring buildings because they didn't have the outdoor space that they were looking for," Ms. [Maria Athanasoulis] notes. "You can't barbecue at some of the other buildings."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Low-rise+suites+nestled+against+Stratford+Park&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=G.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Low-rise+suites+nestled+against+Stratford+Park&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-25&amp;spage=G.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Stratford
Location: Lawrence Park
Builder/developer: Cresford Developments
Size: 1,550 to 4,275 square feet
Price: $1.2-million to $4.6-million
Sales centre: 2130 Bayview Ave., south of Lawrence Avenue East. Open by appointment.
Contact: (416) 971-7888 or www.stratfordresidences.ca
*****
Stratford in Lawrence Park is one of city's few developments that features low-rise buildings with large suites and high-end appointments, and that is set amid gardens and mature trees, according to its builder, Cresford Developments.
It's a package - complete with 1,550- to 4,275-square-foot models, private elevators and 11-foot ceilings - that has attracted locals who live in historic mansions as well as empty-nesters accustomed to upscale properties in Florida, Cresford says.
"[Buyers are] coming from a house in Toronto or have had experience with condominiums down south, so they're expecting certain details," explains Maria Athanasoulis, Cresford vice-president of sales and marketing. "They love all the luxuries."
Located off Bayview Avenue, south of Lawrence Avenue, the project will include 60 units within two four-storey residences. A mid-rise building with just seven suites and 17 detached houses will be released in the coming months.
Two well-known companies - J.F. Brennan Design/Build Inc. and Gluckstein Design Planning Inc. - were recruited to give the community a classic, Georgian-style appearance that will blend in with homes in the affluent neighbourhood.
Stratford will be nestled against the park of the same name, and be minutes from Sherwood Park, Sunnybrook Park and the Rosedale Golf Club. On the site itself, the builder is preserving the natural surroundings by relocating mature trees from the construction site to the perimeters. Courtyard gardens will also be created on the grounds.
Mainstays in the area are the Granite Club, Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre and York University's Glendon campus. Bayview shops, restaurants, gourmet grocers and cafes are also nearby.
Residents will have exclusive use of a gym, pool and party room with a fireplace, bar and kitchen. Other amenities include a guest suite, 18-hour valet service and 24-hour concierge.
Key-operated elevators will shuttle owners and guests directly to suites. "The fact they don't have to walk down a long corridor is a big selling feature," Ms. Athanasoulis says.
Designed much like detached homes, models have large principal rooms. Most units will have family rooms, guest suites with private bathrooms, and master bedrooms with sitting rooms and his and hers closets.
Residents will be able to enjoy the outdoors from balconies, patios and gardens with barbecue hookups. An optional feature in penthouse units is a kitchen that opens to a rooftop terrace.
"We've attracted some buyers from the other neighbouring buildings because they didn't have the outdoor space that they were looking for," Ms. Athanasoulis notes. "You can't barbecue at some of the other buildings."
Kitchens will be stocked with Downsview cabinetry and Sub-Zero, Wolf and Miele appliances.
Among the other interior features are gas fireplaces, decorative columns, and master bathrooms with heated floors. Countertops will have granite, marble or CaesarStone finishes.
Units will be equipped with central vacuum systems and high-efficiency washers and dryers.
Underground parking and a locker are included.
The monthly maintenance fee is 51 cents a square foot, not including utilities.
Occupancy is slated for fall, 2010.

District warns forestry firm over clearing land

Author: Hunter, Justine

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/district-warns-forestry-firm-over-clearing-land/docview/382706067/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "What may not be clear to them is, they cannot alter the land without permits," Robert Lapham, general manager for the CRD's planning department, said in an interview yesterday. "If they aren't prepared to comply, we would have to seek an injunction."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=District+warns+forestry+firm+over+clearing+land&amp;author=Hunter%2C+Justine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-24&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=District+warns+forestry+firm+over+clearing+land&amp;author=Hunter%2C+Justine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-24&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In ongoing battle, Capital Region demands Western Forest Products seek permits for preparatory work on disputed development
While lawyers prepare for a court battle over Western Forest Products' attempts to sell off timberlands for real-estate development, company employees were still clearing land yesterday to stake out its proposed subdivision boundaries.
But even that work could soon be stalled. The local government has issued a warning letter as a prelude to seeking an injunction against the forest company's preliminary work on its private lands.
The former timberlands on the west coast of Vancouver Island have been at the centre of controversy since the provincial government agreed to lift forestry restrictions from the properties last year.
The Capital Regional District, the regional authority for land-use issues in and around Victoria, sent Western Forest Products a written demand that the company obtain permits to do even preparatory work on the subdivisions.
"What may not be clear to them is, they cannot alter the land without permits," Robert Lapham, general manager for the CRD's planning department, said in an interview yesterday. "If they aren't prepared to comply, we would have to seek an injunction."
The CRD has made no secret of its opposition to the forest company's real-estate plans - it has already tried to block the development by changing the zoning throughout the rural, waterfront strip of the island between Sooke and Jordan River. In April, it changed the zoning bylaws to allow properties to be subdivided into lots no smaller than 48 hectares.
That move elicited a weighty response from Western Forest Products, in the form of a 412-page petition in B.C. Supreme Court seeking to quash the zoning changes.
The company is set to appear in court on Sept. 15. Court documents filed by the company argue the CRD "exceeded its authority, exceeded its jurisdiction, committed an error of law or acted unreasonably" in its bid to slow development on the former timberlands.
The CRD argues that its official community plan for the region calls for limited growth in the area, and the lands were expected to remain "renewable resource working landscapes."
That vision changed when Western Forest Products listed some of its waterfront properties with realtor Colliers International, hoping to relieve some of its debt pressures. The 2,550 hectares put on the block included valuable south-facing waterfront and were provisionally sold to a developer who wants to create a new town of 10,000 at Jordan River.
In order to develop the lands, the company needed the Ministry of Forests to remove restrictions from its private forestry lands, an agreement it won early last year.
Last week, B.C. Auditor-General John Doyle criticized the government's handling of that decision, saying then-forests minister Rich Coleman failed to consider the public interest when he agreed to delete the lands from the Tree Farm Licence program.
The change was worth an estimated $150-million to the company, but the province sought no compensation.
Duncan Kerr, chief operating officer of Western Forest Products, said yesterday the company is carrying on its preparation of the subdivisions according to the old zoning bylaws that allow for smaller lots. It has until April, 2009, to obtain development approval from the provincial Transportation Ministry, a process that is still under way.
Mr. Kerr said the company is reviewing the latest demands from the CRD, but said he would have preferred to work with the local government without resorting to litigation.
"We think that's far from optimal," he said. "We're very disappointed that we have been unable to engage with the CRD, local planners and local communities. Instead it has become this provincial political issue with groups getting involved who have nothing to do in the local region."
A coalition of environmentalists yesterday called on Premier Gordon Campbell to reverse the Forest Ministry decision.

Lounging lakeside in Whistler

Author: Silverstein, Jeff

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lounging-lakeside-whistler/docview/382707031/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: FOOD AND DRINK Jordan's Crossing, the hotel's lakeside restaurant and outdoor patio, evokes the fine dining rooms of first-class rail travel. Overlooking the lake, it offers a year-round prix-fixe menu featuring the chef's favourites, along with an à la carte menu. Executive chef Julian Owen-Mold, fresh from his last gig at Vancouver's Opus Hotel, has developed a fine locally-sourced menu. Line-caught salmon was sublime, as was the olive oil-poached lamb and Pacific sablefish.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lounging+lakeside+in+Whistler&amp;author=Silverstein%2C+Jeff&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-23&amp;spage=R.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lounging+lakeside+in+Whistler&amp;author=Silverstein%2C+Jeff&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-23&amp;spage=R.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: NITA LAKE LODGE
2131 Lake Placid Road, Whistler, B.C.; 1-888-755-6482 or 604-966-5700; www.nitalakelodge.com.
ROOMS AND RATES
Studio suites start at $149, one-bedroom suites from $189, and two-bedrooms at $259. The hotel also has two extra-large suites, tucked away from the action on top of the train station: The two-bedroom Hudson Suite starts at $1,499, while the one-bedroom Pacific Suite starts at $1,249.
With all the hotels in Whistler, you'd think there was already something for everyone. But until Nita Lake Lodge opened earlier this year, a cozy lakeside lodge wasn't an option. Five years in the building, the lodge has a coveted location overlooking Nita Lake and it's just a five-minute stroll from Creekside village, the quieter half of Whistler.
Guests can avoid the pre-Olympic construction and traffic along the Sea to Sky Highway by hopping on the Whistler Mountaineer from Vancouver, a spectacular train journey that crosses canyons that can't been seen from the highway. The luxury train pulls up at an elegant arts-and-crafts-style station next door to the hotel.
LOCATION That old real estate adage - location, location, location - holds equally true for hotels. Either you want to be in the centre of the village where everything is happening or you're looking for a peaceful retreat. In the case of Nita Lake Lodge, you get the best of both worlds. If you are craving a little action, the hotel's shuttle is always at the ready to take you to the main village and smaller Creekside. Lift access to the mountain, is just steps away.
But there's serenity, too: Half of the 77 suites look out over the lake and the other half look out at Whistler Mountain, which will be home to the men's and women's 2010 Olympic downhill race.
AMBIENCE Lots of stone and a generous use of rich, dark wood make for a grand lobby, with well-chosen local artwork and elegant furnishings. The two-sided fireplace in the lounge is a prime gathering spot for après-activity drinks, and the natural palette of moss, coffee brown and sienna is easy on the eyes.
DESIGN Think arts and crafts meets the great outdoors. Lead architect Peter Lang worked hard to make the hotel feel like it belongs here. Shed dormers hark back to the original fishing lodge that was located here and lend the lodge a rustic, hand-hewn feel. Over-scale beams and columns evoke that golden era of "parkitecture," when travelling to majestic alpine settings demanded buildings of a similar grandeur.
ROOMS All the suites have comfy king size beds that sit fashionably low to the floor, with expansive floor-to-ceiling sliding doors that open up to patios with spectacular views of Nita Lake and Whistler Mountain. Like all suites, our one-bedroom featured a 42-inch plasma television over the fireplace and an oversized ensuite bathroom with a huge soaker tub. Stand-alone glass showers are easily big enough for two, and the slate floors with radiant heating will be welcome in winter.
FOOD AND DRINK Jordan's Crossing, the hotel's lakeside restaurant and outdoor patio, evokes the fine dining rooms of first-class rail travel. Overlooking the lake, it offers a year-round prix-fixe menu featuring the chef's favourites, along with an à la carte menu. Executive chef Julian Owen-Mold, fresh from his last gig at Vancouver's Opus Hotel, has developed a fine locally-sourced menu. Line-caught salmon was sublime, as was the olive oil-poached lamb and Pacific sablefish. For breakfast and lunch, JC's Café and Deli is the best place in Creekside to grab a coffee and something nutritious before heading for the hills. If a more decadent breakfast is in order, try Owen-Mold's orange-scented waffles, topped with fragrant strawberries and fresh cream. A selection of fresh-baked muffins stacked in beautiful wooden baskets are irresistible.
THINGS TO DO As a four-season resort, Whistler offers up just as many (if not more) activities in the summer as in the winter. You can arrive in style on the Whistler Mountaineer train (604-606-7200); hook up with Zip Trek Ecotours (604-935-0001) and fly along one of five steel ziplines; go on a pedal-paddle trip with Whistler Eco-Tours (604-935-4900).
*****
Hotel vitals
TOP DRAWS
With the new train station integrated into the project, Nita Lake has become a gateway to Whistler. Considering the hotel's mountainside ski storage, shuttle service and easy access to the ski hill via the Creekside gondola, guests can do without a car.
NEEDS WORK
The Valley Trail, used by cyclists, joggers and skateboarders alike, is steps away from the lodge, so a fleet of bikes would be a welcome addition to hotel amenities.
