Full text:   Butternut Village
Location: Uxbridge
Builder/developer: Alliance Homes
Size: townhouses, 1,170 to 2,023 square feet; detached, 1,489 square feet
Price: townhouses, $263,900 to $340,900; detached, $340,900
Sales centre: Brock Street, east of Sixth Concession Road in Uxbridge. Open Monday to Wednesday, 1 to 7 p.m.; weekends, noon to 5 p.m.
Contact: (905) 852-5254 or www.alliancehomes.ca
Buyers at Butternut Village in Uxbridge will be able to move into the last 11 freehold townhouses by mid-winter. They represent the last phase in Alliance Homes' community about 40 kilometres northeast of Toronto.
The development will include 80 homes in total, situated on Brock Street, just east of Sixth Concession Road.
For those looking to move in sooner, some inventory homes from previous phases - including a 1,489-square-foot bungalow with a loft on a 50-foot lot - are at the drywall stage and can be ready within six to eight weeks.
According to the builder, the setting and location of the project have been strong selling points with buyers, including locals and people from other parts of the Greater Toronto Area. The site is situated amid green spaces, and includes a park and pond. As well, it's near amenities such as a shopping plaza, schools, community centre and golf courses.
"Uxbridge is a beautiful community," says Kathryn MacFarlane, director of sales and marketing for Alliance. "There's greenspace that comes up the back of our subdivision where a walking trail hooks up with downtown."
Models range from a 1,170-square-foot plan with two bedrooms and two bathrooms to a 2,023-square-foot design with three bedrooms and three bathrooms.
Every plan has the master bedroom on the main floor.
The Blackberry showcases many of the features that can be found in other plans. The 1,178-square-foot, two-bedroom model can have either a standard or alternate layout.
In both versions, the garage can be reached directly from the house via a laundry room, and the rear master bedroom has an en suite and walk-in closet.
The standard layout comes with an eat-in kitchen and combined living and dining area. The alternate contains a second bedroom/den near the front door, and a kitchen with breakfast bar that adjoins a great room in the rear.
Interior details include solid oak handrails and balusters on the main staircase, 40-ounce broadloom in the living room and bedrooms, and imported ceramic tile flooring elsewhere.
For a limited time, buyers will get upgraded features such as granite countertops and maple cabinetry in the kitchen, pot lights in the living room, and hardwood flooring in the principal room.
Brick facades will feature precast stone, vinyl or wood accents, as well as gables.

Consider new products for that new deck

Author: Holmes, Mike

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/consider-new-products-that-deck/docview/382707236/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Cedar is naturally resistant to insect damage and rot, so it needs less maintenance than PT wood. Unless your cedar deck comes into direct contact with the ground - and it shouldn't if it's built properly - you won't need to treat it with preservatives at all. Cedar can be allowed to weather to a grey colour, or you can stain it. But once you stain it, you'll have to maintain it regularly.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Consider+new+products+for+that+new+deck&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-04&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Consider+new+products+for+that+new+deck&amp;author=Holmes%2C+Mike&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-04&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Now that summer's here, many homeowners are thinking about new decks, which are great additions to any living space.
Before you start looking for a contractor, however, you need to make a call to your local building authority.
There's a good possibility you will need a permit for your deck - especially if it's attached to your house or above a certain height.
And, obviously, you don't want to put out the money for a new deck and then have to take it down.
If you don't get a permit and you're found out, that's what can happen. Don't take a chance.
There are lots of things you need to be clear about in order to build a safe and well-constructed deck. Do you need railings? Are they tall enough? Is the spacing correct? What about the stairs - are the risers correct?
You also need to think about the material you'll use. There are lots of options.
PRESSURE-TREATED WOOD
This is a popular choice for decks and fences because it's usually the least costly. Pressure-treated (PT) wood is impregnated with chemicals that help it resist rot and insects, making it ideal for exterior projects.
There was a lot of controversy about PT wood in the past because arsenic was used to treat it. But that product was taken off the market in Canada about four years ago. A copper compound is now used instead of arsenic, and it's perfectly safe if you work with it properly and don't burn it.
With copper-treated wood, your contractor has to use the correct fasteners. If the screws and joist hangers aren't specifically labelled for use with PT wood, they will corrode when the wood gets wet. Aluminum and copper don't mix and regular galvanized nails and screws won't hold up for long. Initially, this will cause staining on your deck around these screws and hangers, and then structural failure when they corrode away.
PT wood needs to be maintained because it is not water resistant. You should clean it annually to remove dirt or moss, then apply a sealer to protect against moisture damage and splintering. You can also paint or stain the wood.
CEDAR
I love the look of cedar, but it is more expensive than PT wood, no question. One way of saving money if you like the look of cedar is to build the structure and supports out of PT wood, and use cedar for the planks and rails.
Cedar is naturally resistant to insect damage and rot, so it needs less maintenance than PT wood. Unless your cedar deck comes into direct contact with the ground - and it shouldn't if it's built properly - you won't need to treat it with preservatives at all. Cedar can be allowed to weather to a grey colour, or you can stain it. But once you stain it, you'll have to maintain it regularly.
You should wash your cedar deck every year with a mild detergent and water, but don't use a pressure washer on it. Cedar is too soft and can be damaged this way.
COMPOSITE WOOD
Composite wood is made of a variety of materials, usually polyethylene or polypropylene mixed with wood fibre or wood flour. It can look a lot like real wood, with embossed wood-grain patterns and texture. Composite wood comes in a variety of colours, is UV-resistant, won't fade, stain, twist, split or warp, and it's resistant to insects.
When this product first came out, I wasn't really enthusiastic about it, but it has been improved and I'm starting to like it. Composite wood is as much as five times more expensive than PT wood, but over the long term you'll save a lot on maintenance.
A lot of composite wood material is somewhat softer than real wood, and isn't available in long spans, so your contractor will have to place the joists closer together.
RESIN DECKING
This has no wood in it at all, so it definitely won't absorb moisture. It's lightweight and durable, is resistant to mould, won't splinter or crack, and it comes in a variety of colours.
In general, make sure your contractor has lots of experience building decks.
Just because the project is outside your house doesn't mean you should be casual about who you hire. A lot of guys start out in the business by building decks and fences; make sure the contractor you hire knows what he's doing. Check references and get lots of quotes.
Some people say a deck "should be" built for an average of $5 a square foot (labour and materials for the deck surface and structure only). There is no average - every situation is different, depending on materials, access, details, size, and the experience and skill of the contractor.
Mike Holmes is the host
of Holmes on Homes on HGTV.
For more information, go to www.holmesonhomes.com

The neighbourhood goes to pot

Author: Evans, Suzanne

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/neighbourhood-goes-pot/docview/382696427/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: As soon as she opened the door the stench of mould engulfed us. It smarted in the eyes and left an acrid taste at the back of the tongue. No wonder the police had gone in with masks. It was like walking into the set of a horror film. "The kind of film" my older daughter said, "where as soon as the kids go into the abandoned house all the doors swing shut and lock."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+neighbourhood+goes+to+pot&amp;author=Evans%2C+Suzanne&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-03&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+neighbourhood+goes+to+pot&amp;author=Evans%2C+Suzanne&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-03&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Who could have guessed with such a clever cover-up: pull dandelions outside, propagate weed inside
'Ijust feel silly," said my next-door neighbour, a young military man. "I had no idea there was a grow-op across the street."
If the two retired cops on the block were aware of anything, they had kept mum.
I asked our local garbage picker what he knew. Chancy, as he likes to be called, lives in the well-kept duplex just past the stop sign. He has a great facility for sizing up people based on what they put out on garbage day. Yet he too knew nothing. "The garbage on this street is boring," he said.
I can only wonder what Psychic Diana, working in her shop around the corner, saw in her crystal ball.
For the rest of us the tip-off was the unmarked police cars crowding the street in front of the little stone bungalow. A quorum of well-fed, ponytailed "undercover" policemen were hanging about outside.
The rumble of questions began. What had been going on in that house since it had been sold four years ago?
A new For Sale sign now stands on the lawn. We've had a lot more traffic on the street because of it. I doubt the passersby even know about the crime scene. Nothing on the outside suggests a nefarious deed.
No, the handsome little house covered in flagstone attracts people with its good looks alone. I expect they don't even notice the quiet, two-block street's other attributes. The educational possibilities, for example, are hard to match. At one end of the road we have a library and at the other a driving school offering Bible studies.
Few house hunters pass through at night, so they would never know we are blessed with an everlasting red sunset from the glow of a Canadian Tire sign, appropriately to the west.
What does a grow-op nestled in a small neighbourhood look like? I wanted to see the evidence of the crime. The police had cleared out the place but I thought the walls might talk. A friend in the real-estate business promised to take me for a tour.
The house had been a project of love and renewal for a previous owner. Built in 1947, it had been in good shape when she bought it, yet she found lots of things that needed improving. She got particular joy out of working on the wooden floors and doors. She was mindful of the nature, age and grain of the resource in her hands.
Her workroom in the basement felt safely cocooned from the world. She organized it with precision - something one might expect of a military nurse. She had enlisted years ago and gone on a peacekeeping mission to Bosnia. Like so many others, she had returned with demons in her head. Having her hands on wood in the winter and in earth in the summer helped.
She nurtured the irises, peonies and roses in her garden and hovered protectively around the baby tree that promised one day to shade her south-facing house. She left in haste out of restlessness, and many of us are sad we didn't do more to persuade her to stay.
The young couple who moved in kept mostly to themselves. They rented the house from absentee landlords whose prime concern was receipt of their monthly cheque.
I only saw the couple occasionally, saying hello when they were gardening. Now I'm kicking myself for not asking more questions - or any at all. But who could have guessed of the crime with such a clever cover-up - pull dandelions outside while secretly propagating weed inside? And this wasn't their only grow-op. Another neighbourhood in town got to witness the excitement of their arrest.
My real-estate friend came over after dinner, and the curious - my husband, two teenaged daughters and me - followed her across the street.
As soon as she opened the door the stench of mould engulfed us. It smarted in the eyes and left an acrid taste at the back of the tongue. No wonder the police had gone in with masks. It was like walking into the set of a horror film. "The kind of film" my older daughter said, "where as soon as the kids go into the abandoned house all the doors swing shut and lock."
The humidity necessary to grow marijuana wept black streaks of mould from ceiling to floor. The once cream-coloured paint was death grey. All the grates on the vents had been pulled out of the floor and walls to allow for a freer flow of warm air to keep the plants happy.
The tenants had kept their electricity use at a reasonable level by removing all the appliances. The back bedroom had a sheet of plywood holding up the ceiling, supported by a lone two-by-four in the middle of the room.
The scent of marijuana was only evident in the basement, where it saturated the beams and hung densely in the air. To survive a wrecking crew, this house would need money and imagination.
Our suburb was swallowed by the growing city years ago. Surrounded by old blood on one side, new immigrants on the other and a commercial base searching for an identity, we lack built-in cohesiveness. But maybe the unearthing of the grow-op will give us an opportunity to grow better neighbours instead of pot.
Suzanne Evans lives in Ottawa.

Saskatoon grapples with boomtown pains

Author: Hutton, David

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/saskatoon-grapples-with-boomtown-pains/docview/382695306/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We think we've learned from Alberta's experience before us," said senior city planner Alan Wallace. "But what we've learned is that it's impossible to keep up. You're basically reacting continuously."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Saskatoon+grapples+with+boomtown+pains&amp;author=Hutton%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-03&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Saskatoon+grapples+with+boomtown+pains&amp;author=Hutton%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-03&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   After a lifetime in Alberta, Don Evernden sold off his charter aviation business and moved to Saskatchewan, drawn by the kind of economic boom he has witnessed in his home province.
Mr. Evernden, 73, bought a farm last year northwest of Saskatoon, cashing in on the growing agriculture sector, and went looking for another opportunity.
The investment that caught his eye was McNab Park, a rundown former military base bordering the Saskatoon airport where old barracks have been used for decades as low-income housing for about 400 people. Some city officials consider the neighbourhood an "eyesore" at the gateway to the city and have longed to redevelop it. Mr. Evernden had the same idea when he bought the land in January for $17-million.
His plans, however, have pitted him against the area's residents, in a struggle that has become a symbol of the tension created by the rapid growth of the city.
"We believe in this project," Mr. Evernden says. "It just might take longer than we first expected."
The unprecedented boom in the commodities Saskatchewan produces, ranging from oil and gas to uranium, potash and agricultural crops, is forcing local business to adjust.
Michael Grace, the president of Kingsmere Capital Corp., a local investment firm, says Saskatoon has many strengths but has been caught off guard by the pace of growth and is spinning its wheels to catch up. The challenges facing investors are the labour and housing shortages. Major companies have been reticent to relocate to the city because there's a lack of housing for their employees, which has slowed investment, he said.
On the other hand, local businesses find themselves delivering an unfamiliar pitch to potential hires, notes David Williams, a professor at the University of Saskatchewan's Edwards School of Business. No longer do they trumpet the region's cheap housing and cost of living; instead, they are talking up what a great place it is to relocate to and invest in real estate.
"We're a humble people here and we're not used to all this attention. We're all looking at each other and thinking 'how did this happen?' "
It may just be getting started. There's a building boom in houses and condominiums, industrial traffic crowds the streets, old, rundown apartment buildings are being rebuilt into big-city condos, and the population of 208,000 is growing at a rate not seen in a century. Cranes and traffic jams, once rare, are now part of everyday life.
Mr. Evernden plans to turn McNab Park into a high-end business park. He believes the development will attract major hotel chains and some of the country's big resource players who are looking to gain proximity to an expanding airport, he says.
The intense growth, however, is creating many of the problems that still plague Alberta, where the inflow of workers and money sent the housing market climbing to record highs, and made it nearly impossible to find affordable accommodation, even on a good wage.
"The high prices are eating into the working poor," Mr. Williams said. "It's the people who are working two or three part-time jobs who have seen their rents skyrocket that are being hurt."
In Saskatoon, housing prices were up more than 50 per cent last year alone, a leap on top of a market that had already been ticking up. The city's industrial vacancy rate is below 2 per cent for the first time in its history, while construction costs have more than doubled in the past three years. The industrial market continues to grow, with the number of building permits rising 64 per cent last year.
Many of the city's poor are struggling to find housing, and shortages of labour and materials have caused major construction delays and cost overruns. Contractors from as far away as Detroit have had to fly in their own work crews.
"We think we've learned from Alberta's experience before us," said senior city planner Alan Wallace. "But what we've learned is that it's impossible to keep up. You're basically reacting continuously."
For Mr. Evernden's Calgary-based project management team, this has meant a public battle with McNab Park's 400 tenants, many of whom see their neighbourhood disappearing and have nowhere to go in a rental market that still lacks low-income options.
City councillor Pat Lorje says the McNab Park development has become a symbol of the people being left behind as the rest of the city moves forward.
"We are creating the conditions for an incredible amount of social unrest. They're shutting down the equivalent of a small town," she said. "It's going to be difficult for these people to find accommodation let alone afford accommodation."
Mr. Evernden's group has come up with one solution to the housing problems created by his plans for McNab Park. It has teamed up with a local developer, Innovative Assets Inc., that is literally moving many of the neighbourhood's rundown houses and apartment buildings across the city, then refurbishing them in their new locale.
Ms. Lorje said the city is implementing several affordable housing initiatives and working with the province to implement measures to help keep up with the growth. The city has struck what it calls a "future growth team" to come up with a strategy to cope with the boom.
The province, for its part, has moved to ease the labour shortage by beginning to develop programs to encourage aboriginal people to train for the skilled trades, where demand is soaring. It has reached arrangements with countries such as the Philippines to recruit workers for areas of high demand.
It has also invested $400-million more in infrastructure than it did last year, pouring money into roads, schools and hospitals, drawing a lesson from the experience in Alberta, where such facilities were overwhelmed.

Anger over a bridge to 'heaven'

Author: Hunter, Justine

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/anger-over-bridge-heaven/docview/382709989/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: David Boehm remembers when it cost $2.50 to ride the ferry to the island. People here are angry with significant fare hikes and service disruptions. On Sunday night, service was suspended because of a crew shortage. "We are hostages of B.C. Ferries," he said. But he opposes a bridge. "It would dilute the flavour of the island."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Anger+over+a+bridge+to+%27heaven%27&amp;author=Hunter%2C+Justine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-01&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Anger+over+a+bridge+to+%27heaven%27&amp;author=Hunter%2C+Justine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-07-01&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Mudge, Gabriola islanders stirred up again as ferry rates soar
His handle in real estate is "Mudge Maguire," and there was a time when the concept of a bridge across Mudge Island didn't strike him as an awful idea.
Today, the realtor and water-taxi operator is unapologetic about his reluctance to open up his island community to traffic and visitors.
"We are being selfish," Fred Maguire said yesterday, referring to the remote lifestyle that he and fellow islanders - all 70 of them - have adopted.
The decades-old bridge debate was reignited last week after B.C. Ferries president David Hahn floated the idea of building a fixed link in response to complaints about rising ferry fares.
Currently, the corporation operates a route linking Gabriola Island to downtown Nanaimo on Vancouver Island. It's just a 20-minute sailing, but it effectively serves as a gateway, restricting access to the island of 4,500 souls. The round trip for a car and driver costs $28.80, though commuters can get a discount that brings the price down to about $18.00.
With its tiny population, Mudge Island doesn't rate a ferry service, but if a fixed link were to be built, the island would be in the path of progress. A bridge across Dodd Narrows would tie Mudge to Vancouver Island at the community of Cedar, just south of Nanaimo. A second bridge would then take traffic through to Gabriola.
"It would destroy both islands," Mr. Maguire said.
He moved to Mudge in 1971, where he lived in a cabin. Today, he has his dream home, where last weekend he entertained the grandchildren, who were free to wander down to the beach without supervision. "We have a piece of heaven over here."
B.C. Ferries' Mr. Hahn, who has fielded numerous complaints about recent rate increases, saw an opportunity to end the grumbling over fares and service by agreeing with one critic's suggestion to test support for replacing ferry service with a fixed link.
The idea came from Gabriola resident Jeremy Baker, although he wasn't planning to go public with his suggestion. The subject is too hot to debate with his neighbours.
In an interview, Mr. Baker defended the notion, saying a fixed link would mean the end of dependence on B.C. Ferries. He is no newbie; he has lived on the island for 36 years. But he also runs a courier service and feels the rate increases more acutely than residents who rarely venture off their island.
He feels demographics on Gabriola could be swinging his way. Older people are leaving the island, which has limited health services, and rising real-estate prices are attracting a new breed of islander.
"What's wrong with checking people's attitudes? If B.C. Ferries is going to keep whacking us over and over again [with fare increases], some new way of dealing with this issue should be looked at."
Mr. Hahn has handed the contentious issue to the island's local ferry committee, a reluctant participant in the debate. He said he is willing to fund a survey of residents to see whether they want to end their reliance on the ferry service that links them to Nanaimo.
He said he is not advocating a bridge in lieu of ferry service, but is simply giving the islanders a chance to have their say. "People are looking at us to be creative."
A fixed link wasn't a viable concept eight years ago, when a study pegged the cost of building it at $50-million. Construction costs would drive the price higher now, but Mr. Hahn believes an alternative to ferry service could be feasible given today's fuel prices. "You look at everything differently at $142 a barrel of oil."
On Gabriola, however, the debate seems toxic.
"The bloody bridge," said Jerry MacLeod, sitting at a patio table at a local café, Raspberries. "I went through the last round of this," she said.
"We had fathers not speaking to sons, lifelong friendships ended. It was like the referendum in Quebec."
David Boehm remembers when it cost $2.50 to ride the ferry to the island. People here are angry with significant fare hikes and service disruptions. On Sunday night, service was suspended because of a crew shortage. "We are hostages of B.C. Ferries," he said. But he opposes a bridge. "It would dilute the flavour of the island."
Antony Holland, an 88-year-old actor, leaned over the patio rail to chime in: "We don't want one. We might as well go live in the suburbs of Vancouver."
Gabriola is busy at this time of year with tourists and summer residents. Ken Capon, another long-time resident, said he and his wife left Vancouver to embrace the island pace of life. "You put in a bridge and it's no longer an island."
Kathy Ramsey owns Gabriola Artworks. The island boasts one of the highest concentrations of artists in the country, she said, people who could be driven out if the island becomes too accessible. "A bridge is a conduit for what we try to keep away from here."
One resident, Terry, sitting in his beat-up GMC pickup, said he supports the bridge. But he didn't want to give his last name.
That didn't surprise Andre Lemieux, head of the local ferry committee. It agreed yesterday to go ahead with the survey, provided B.C. Ferries provides a clear business plan so people know what they are voting on. People on Mudge Island will be included in the survey, he said.
He said the issue is hugely contentious on the islands, and while many residents are opposed, he said there are many people in favour - but supporters tend to be reluctant to speak up.
Gisela Sartori believes a bridge would end the lifestyle she enjoys on Gabriola. Sitting on the ferry with her dog Chinook, a husky, she said is a relative newcomer, with less than three years on the island. The former Yukon resident cherishes the simple lifestyle she has now.
"I spent 22 years without running water and having to wash every diaper by hand," she said of her last home. "Now I am paying $550 a month in rent for a place overlooking the ocean. It's heaven on earth."

____________________________________________________________

An inconvenient truth for fishing communities

Author: Leung, Wency

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/inconvenient-truth-fishing-communities/docview/382707582/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: I spoke to one Gloucester fisherman - when they first put in quotas ... it was something like 500 pounds a day - and so he went out and caught 1,500 pounds and he came back and he said to the regulators, "Okay, here's three days' fishing." And they said, "No, that's one day's fishing and you have to throw 1,000 pounds away."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=An+inconvenient+truth+for+fishing+communities&amp;author=Leung%2C+Wency&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-30&amp;spage=L.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=An+inconvenient+truth+for+fishing+communities&amp;author=Leung%2C+Wency&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-30&amp;spage=L.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Overfishing, climate change and pollution aren't just damaging the world's fish stocks. These issues are also threatening a way of life for fishing communities that have existed for generations, according to New York author Mark Kurlansky, writer of the bestselling culinary and cultural history books, Cod , Salt and The Big Oyster .
Mr. Kurlansky's latest book, The Last Fish Tale , delves into the history of America's oldest fishing port, Gloucester, Mass., and examines why the future of the port concerns coastal towns and cities around the world.
In the book, Mr. Kurlansky explains there are fish tales and Gloucester stories. Fish tales have happy, if exaggerated, endings. Gloucester stories end in tragedy.
Mr. Kurlansky spoke to The Globe and Mail from Seattle, where he was promoting his new book.
You describe the rise of coastal tourism as a loss for maritime towns and cities. Why?
Once the tourism comes in, it just prices out the commercial fishing. Mooring space becomes unaffordable to fishermen, real estate becomes unaffordable to fishermen, and more and more of the town loses the culture that drew tourism there in the first place. ... In places like Gloucester, you see people who move there and they want to close down the fish plant because it's smelly and they want to dock their yacht in the harbour and get the bottom-draggers out.
You mention that fishermen
believe if they just hang in there, the fisheries will eventually return. What's at stake
if they're wrong and this is,
indeed, the last fish tale?
Then we're all in a lot of trouble. If we start talking about marine life completely vanishing, this planet is in a lot of trouble. And culturally, places like New England and Canada lose their primary culture and a sense of who they are.
In the book, I go to Newfoundland ... [where] some of the old fishermen are staying around and crabbing, but there's nothing for young people. They're all in British Columbia or Alberta. So what is the future of the place?
You say government fisheries management programs - and Canada's in particular - have
actually contributed to overfishing. How so?
In the 1970s, when the 200-mile limits were established [to enforce exclusive fishing zones], the idea should have been that now the government could manage their own fisheries. ... But in the case of Canada and the U.S., the government viewed it as an opportunity to just expand fisheries so that local fishing could take the place of the foreign fishing they kicked out.
In Canada, the government directly participated in building up their fishing fleets and built a very destructive fleet for the Grand Banks - more destructive than the foreign fishing they had been complaining about.
Why are quotas wasteful?
Most fish, when they're caught, are dead. And so if you throw them out, it's just a complete loss.
I spoke to one Gloucester fisherman - when they first put in quotas ... it was something like 500 pounds a day - and so he went out and caught 1,500 pounds and he came back and he said to the regulators, "Okay, here's three days' fishing." And they said, "No, that's one day's fishing and you have to throw 1,000 pounds away."
Why does commercial fishing seem bent on destroying itself?
The short answer is it isn't. There are two separate problems that need different solutions. One is long-distance fleets - where governments from rich countries and rich companies make deals with poor countries, like Peru and Senegal, and go down and strip their fishing grounds. That's an international problem that needs a lot of diplomacy and international co-operation.
The other problem is just maintaining the fisheries. How does the U.S. maintain fisheries in U.S. waters and how does Canada maintain fisheries in Canadian waters? There, they have been under very heavy, strict regulations and have worked very hard to make fishing sustainable. In many cases, they have failed but that failure hasn't been a lack of trying, but a failure to find the right formula.
In Gloucester, you have several competing forces - a need to preserve fish stocks and the
environment, and a need to
preserve fishing culture and keep people employed. How
do you strike a balance?
The feeling is that what's important is that [Gloucester's] central harbour remains marine industrial, and out on the edges, you can have other stuff. They're looking for ways to survive and they're happy to have tourists, but they're trying to keep them out of the space that belongs to fishermen. ...
We live in a time when ways of life and cultures, and even languages, are disappearing at an alarming rate, and I think this is something that should be of tremendous concern.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

For whom the bell tolls

Author: Hunter, Justine

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/whom-bell-tolls/docview/382793102/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We have taken, recently, a more hands-on approach, looking at what's happening with those buildings," she said in a telephone interview from Beijing, where she is meeting with educators to showcase B.C.'s education services. "We need to be prudent in the disposal of those assets."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=For+whom+the+bell+tolls&amp;author=Hunter%2C+Justine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-28&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=For+whom+the+bell+tolls&amp;author=Hunter%2C+Justine&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-28&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   For more than a century, Mount Benson school had served generations of local families. But this week, to the tears of students past and present, it became the latest casualty of a policy that has seen boards across the province shut schools and sell land. The province, though, is reconsidering the wisdom of this action
There is a manic glee in that Alice Cooper line "School's out forever," a perennial favourite of students since the 1970s pop song first hit the airwaves.
But school's final day was a gloomy affair marked by four generations of one Nanaimo family who walked the halls of Mount Benson Elementary this week for the last time.
Misty Duifhuis's grandfather first showed up on the school roll here in 1919. Her mother still recalls the names of her teachers, good and bad. Ms. Duifhuis looked into the cloakroom where she had been sentenced to time outs for laughing too much.
This week, her son Joshua, 7, attended the 134-year-old school's final assembly.
Mount Benson is a casualty of the school district's business plan. Like school districts across the province, squeezed by declining enrolment and funding shortfalls, the Nanaimo Board of Education's had to raise cash for needed projects by liquidating the only assets it has.
Mount Benson was among those closed so it could be prepared to go on the block.
Even before classes finished this week, crews were getting ready to tear out portables. Inside, the library was in a forlorn state, books already packed away in cardboard boxes. The band room was bare, never to hear the clamour of instruments again.
"It was sad, there is so much history here that is going to stop at my children," Ms. Duifhuis said. "It's like a chunk of the community is being broken up and spread out, it's not the centre any more. We are all being displaced."
Mount Benson, judged on its architecture alone, is less than endearing. It's been razed by fire twice, and the current building has spread in an ungainly fashion with half-a-dozen additions.
But it is nestled in a family community, surrounded by a generous expanse of playing fields. Many pupils here can find parents and grandparents in class photos on the wall that date back to 1894.
Joshua Duifhuis will go to another elementary school in September, but he doesn't expect to see any of his current classmates there. The 175 pupils who finished classes this week will be heading to at least four different schools.
Mount Benson is just one of 171 schools closed due to declining enrolment since the B.C. Liberal government took office in 2001. Six more are to close this year, while 26 new schools have been built in fast-growing communities.
It has brought tremendous upheaval to an estimated 22,000 pupils and their families.
Now the province is reconsidering the wisdom of selling off schools.
In an interview this week, Education Minister Shirley Bond said she wants to take a careful look at school closings and sales to ensure there are enough spaces left to meet future needs. The apparent change of heart comes as the province studies the feasibility of kindergarten classes for children as young as 3.
Ms. Bond said the school sales are not her ministry's doing; school boards make the decisions, she noted.
"We have taken, recently, a more hands-on approach, looking at what's happening with those buildings," she said in a telephone interview from Beijing, where she is meeting with educators to showcase B.C.'s education services. "We need to be prudent in the disposal of those assets."
That hands-on approach, school districts say, amounts to an informal moratorium on the sale of schools. Sales that were driven, they note, by criteria Ms. Bond's government imposed.
Shortly after the Liberals took office, schools became assets subject to multicriteria analysis that forced boards to sell "surplus" to get capital funding from the Education Ministry for maintenance and construction of other schools.
Here's how Mount Benson, Home of the Bobcats, became surplus:
Following ministry guidelines for facilities renewal, the school district produced a business plan identifying its needs, mainly a new high school. The ministry agreed to provide capital funding if the district would bring to the table almost half of the money.
"This money would come from ... the proceeds of the future sale of surplus assets," Ms. Bond wrote the school board last fall.
The board had its schools appraised and came up with a list of properties to sell. Four, including Mount Benson, were valued at a total of $8-million.
Jamie Brennan, chair of the Nanaimo Board of Education, said the school district had little choice. "We had to adapt, the ground was shifting under us."
Mr. Brennan doesn't think fewer, bigger schools is bad for education - so long as parents and teachers work to make it a good experience for the pupils, and that hasn't always happened in the emotional debate over school closings. "I've seen kids pushed up to the microphones," he said with distaste.
However, he also called the ministry's funding criteria "ridiculous" and short sighted.
"I guess the minister has felt the heat about the alienation of all these public assets," he said. "And quite rightly."
Even though the policy that led to the demise of Mount Benson is being reconsidered, Ms. Bond said the closings that have already happened were justified. The total student body in B.C. has shrunk by 50,000 since 2001, a trend that is mirrored in other jurisdictions.
"Many parents will tell you that at the end of what is a very painful, personal process - and I would recognize that - they will say their children are being very well served in their new circumstances."
David Murchie isn't convinced. His youngest son was due to start kindergarten in September, and Thomas would have known just about everyone in his class from his neighbourhood. His older son is distraught over the move to a new school.
"It makes me feel sad," said seven-year-old John Murchie. "I'm not going to be with all of my friends." He can name two girls from his class who will be joining him at Rock City Elementary next year.
Irene Lanzinger, president of the B.C. Teachers' Federation, said the closings hurt pupils who can least afford it.
"It is harmful to vulnerable children who have special needs, or who live in poverty." The closings also result in bigger, more crowded schools and that's not good for anyone, she said. "Smaller schools are better for children. There is less violence, less bullying."
Ms. Lanzinger welcomed the ministry's newfound caution about school closings and sales, but added, "They are 175 schools too late."
Jessica Van der Veen has emerged as a champion in the battle against the school closings. Although her teenaged daughter hasn't been directly affected, Ms. Van der Veen believes the public school system is being undermined.
The declining population of school-aged children is a flimsy excuse for cost-cutting, she said.
"In the year 2005, we had the highest birth rate in Canada in seven years. Those children will be coming into the system in just two years," she noted. In B.C., Statistics Canada shows the birth rate climbing in the consecutive years as well, another echo of Canada's baby boom.
"It seems so crazy. They are selling schools because of a temporary, 7-per-cent dip in enrolment," she said.
But the future of Mount Benson is looking a little brighter even as contractors pick off the pieces. What changed was a visit two months ago from the deputy minister of education, who advised against calling in the real estate agents. No "for sale" sign is up, and the district is negotiating with community groups to keep the school as some kind of public facility.
"The selling off of those public assets is probably not going to happen," Mr. Brennan predicted this week.
What about the business plan, the one that required cash from Mount Benson and others to pay for a new high school? "That was then," he said.
It may be too late to keep the school open, but Mount Benson has another chance to rise from the ashes.
'IT'S THE CANARY'
The realtor's advertisement offered three hectares of "prime development land" in an upscale neighbourhood near Victoria. It was such an unusual property that it didn't include an asking price. But when Patricia Mamic spotted the ad, she jumped at the opportunity to build a new subdivision in her own community.
The site included an elementary school that had closed in 2003. "I used to walk my kids through the schoolyard in their baby buggies and it was boarded up," she said this week. "It was a little haunting; there was kids' art still up on the walls."
Her family company, Mamic Development, won with a bid of $4.3-million. What they were unprepared for was the emotional, anti-privatization campaign against the sale of Fairburn Elementary School that dogged their project.
Linda Travers, of Friends of Fairburn, helped pack community planning meetings to fight the sale.
"It's the canary in the coal mine," she said of the first school sale in the Greater Victoria school district, which has closed seven schools due to declining enrolment.
The parents' group argues the schools should be held as public property for the inevitable day that enrolment comes back up. They also fought to keep the school's playing fields in public hands.
After a lengthy battle, Saanich council approved a scaled-down housing project on the old school grounds last month. Thirty per cent of the site will be reserved for parkland. Mamic sold the building itself and it reopened as a private Montessori school last fall.
Later this summer, the developers expect to begin constructing 18 compact luxury homes that are expected to sell for about $750,000 each.
Justine Hunter

The divided way

Author: Campbell, Matthew

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/divided-way/docview/382708473/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: With the emotional peak of this month's meeting behind them, UWO's staff and board are determined to make amends and move on. Ann Mulvale, a popular figure who was Oakville's mayor from 1988 until 2006 and will be running the next United Way campaign, is relentlessly optimistic that the damage can be repaired. "We've had excellent relations with labour" over all, she said, even though "... some things could have been executed with greater precision or clarity."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+divided+way&amp;author=Campbell%2C+Matthew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-28&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+divided+way&amp;author=Campbell%2C+Matthew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-28&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The battle for the future of Oakville's United Way exposes a chasm between the town's wealthy and its working class
A United Way annual general meeting, particularly in a place as quietly affluent as Oakville, is typically a staid affair. That's why it was so shocking when the United Way of Oakville's June 17 meeting erupted into a raucous spectacle of angry denunciations and denials, complete with an unsuccessful attempt to sack the fundraising agency's entire board of directors.
Willie Lambert, the burly United Way board member, Oakville Transit bus driver and labour leader who tried to get himself and the rest of the board fired, seems an unlikely candidate to lead an insurrection - least of all one targeted at such an uncontroversial charitable organization.
Yet for half a year, Mr. Lambert has been the public face of an insurgent coalition of labour and social activists furious that UWO has cut funding to some social-service agencies. The activists' grievances have nearly torn the local United Way apart, and the fight may say a lot about the politics of poverty in one of Canada's wealthiest communities.
According to its own figures, the UWO cut funding this year to 23 of the 31 social-service agencies it funds, by amounts ranging from $1,050 (for the Oakville Literacy Council) to more than $37,000 (for Big Brothers Big Sisters of Halton and Community Development Halton).
Eight other agencies have seen their funding increased by comparable amounts, including an almost $35,000 boost to the Halton Trauma Centre and $33,934 in additional cash for Halton ADAPT, an addiction counselling service.
All of this is the result of an attempt by UWO to restructure the way it allocates grants, putting recipient agencies through an "outcomes measurement" process in which many of them were judged to have performed poorly.
Also this year, UWO stopped allowing disgruntled social-services agencies to appeal funding cuts. The situation has left officials at some of the disappointed agencies "in tears and outraged," according to Dr. Joey Edwardh, the executive director of Community Development Halton, a research and planning organization that assists other non-profits.
Tying social-service-agency grants increasingly to performance assessments is not unique to Oakville. Many other United Way chapters have introduced similar measures.
In Oakville's case, however, the funding cuts landed in the midst of a simmering dispute between the Oakville and District Labour Council, of which Mr. Lambert is president, and UWO, over the firing of Rose Bisson, its union liaison, late last year.
Ms. Bisson said she was dismissed for trying to raise the profile of organized labour within UWO against its management's preference that, in Ms. Bisson's words, unions "just give the money, and go away."
The reference is to the close relationship the United Way has with organized labour; payroll deductions from unionized workplaces typically account for a significant portion of local chapters' annual revenues. Mr. Lambert claimed that, in Oakville, union donations account for 65 per cent of the funds the United Way rakes in. Bruce Felstead, UWO's director of finance and administration, called that figure "totally false." Mr. Felstead said about 10 per cent of the charity's revenue comes from union sources.
In any event, UWO chief executive officer Barbara Burton said there was "no truth" to suggestions that Ms. Bisson had been targeted for her labour advocacy, but she confirmed that "lawyers are talking to lawyers" about her departure.
Whatever the rights and wrongs of Ms. Bisson's firing, it made for a tense relationship between UWO and Oakville's labour community - even before this year's funding cuts were unveiled. When social-service agencies began hearing that their grants had been reduced, they found a ready ally in the Labour Council.
A series of meetings between labour officials and angry agency staff followed, culminating in Mr. Lambert's bid to replace the entire UWO board, which was ruled out of order by its outgoing chair, Gordon Ross.
Mr. Lambert and his supporters did, however, succeed in getting three new allies voted into the 20-member governing body. With their election, Mr. Lambert estimates that he can now count on five votes in addition to his own.
It's hard to separate the rancour at UWO from the peculiar context of the town of Oakville. It boasts some of the country's most expensive real estate, a heavily gentrified downtown and a median household income $32,000 above that of the province.
But Oakville is also home to a 3,500-employee Ford plant and a strong labour movement. Although UWO officials and Oakville Mayor Rob Burton said they did not think issues of class had played a role in the dispute, it has undoubtedly pitted union members and social workers against some of the town's elite. That, at least, is the way Mr. Lambert feels. "There definitely is a hostility and animosity in the United Way for the labour movement and working class," he said.
Ms. Bisson had a similar impression of UWO. "I felt," she said, "in that office there were individuals from very wealthy backgrounds" who were too far removed from the recipients of United Way funding.
With the emotional peak of this month's meeting behind them, UWO's staff and board are determined to make amends and move on. Ann Mulvale, a popular figure who was Oakville's mayor from 1988 until 2006 and will be running the next United Way campaign, is relentlessly optimistic that the damage can be repaired. "We've had excellent relations with labour" over all, she said, even though "... some things could have been executed with greater precision or clarity."
Mr. Lambert seems willing to work within UWO to address his concerns. He warned, however, that "we will try [to unseat the board] again at the '09 [annual general meeting] if things don't improve. We're going to win."

Back at the eco-deco mansion

Author: LeBlanc, Dave

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/back-at-eco-deco-mansion/docview/382711742/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: On the porte-cochere's roof, where once there stood a dilapidated old potter's shed, a modern, glassy guesthouse now sits, which connects to the main house by an equally modern umbilical cord of a bridge. "It was one of the first conceits when we first started talking about the house," says Mr.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Back+at+the+eco-deco+mansion&amp;author=LeBlanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-27&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Back+at+the+eco-deco+mansion&amp;author=LeBlanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-27&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   We check on progress as a 1935 home gets a state-of-the-art, green technology retrofit
The thing about massive renovation projects is that they always look their worst just before they start to look better.
With that in mind, I visited for the second time the future home of David Daniels - once the home of Major-General Donald M. Hogarth - after first reporting on the project in November, 2007. Designed by Toronto architect Mackenzie Waters in 1935, the 8,000-square-foot, sturdy art deco brick box is slowly, methodically being brought into the 21st century - spatially, sustainably and otherwise - by architect and green expert Paul Dowsett of Scott Morris Architects.
Punctuated by the squeal of power saws, our tour began just outside the home's formal front door, where deliveries were occurring so frequently a turnstile might be more appropriate.
Here, in the wall of the porte-cochere, a large, original metal window has been installed for decorative purposes rather than being sent to landfill; surrounding brick has been salvaged from other areas of the house and the colour and texture of the new mortar has been painstakingly matched.
On the porte-cochere's roof, where once there stood a dilapidated old potter's shed, a modern, glassy guesthouse now sits, which connects to the main house by an equally modern umbilical cord of a bridge. "It was one of the first conceits when we first started talking about the house," says Mr. Daniels about the bridge idea, "and it's actually come true, out of all the crazy ideas that I've had throughout the last few years, and I think it's better than I imagined it."
In a way, the porte-cochere can be seen as a microcosm of the entire project: Old parts have been salvaged and repurposed; efforts have been made to duplicate original work; and there is the marriage of old and new architecture.
In the backyard, stacks of cedar from a demolished sauna await new life as partition walls in the pool house. Underfoot is a rich, creamy "Algonquin stone" from Owen Sound - "as local as we could get," chuckles the architect - that will spill out into the rest of the yard; above our heads is the new, pre-patina'd copper flashing with a folded "three-part detail" to echo the banded (and very deco) lines of the brickwork.
Despite the construction storm before the calm, there is much to see inside the house. Mr. Dowsett is conducting tests of art deco moulding styles for the ceiling, because, as he puts it, "in drawing you can only do so much." The jury is still out on whether these will feature curves, hard angles or a combination of both.
The entire "east wing" addition has now been clad in the high-tech, triple-glazed pale green curtain wall that adorns the other modern additions (in my first report this wing was just a skeleton), and it is here that I got my first glimpse of the much-ballyhooed walnut shell flooring by Granular Hardwood Technologies Ltd., which simulates the look of expensive terrazzo by using waste walnut shell pieces as the aggregate after they've been used to clean jet engines.
Here, too, in what will become a chef's delight of a kitchen is another interesting feature: a remotely activated, large sliding glass door - not unlike the kind at the local grocery store - that Mr. Daniels predicts will become the home's principal entrance. "I think your family is going to live in this room," confirms Mr. Dowsett. "This is the view, it's just stunning."
Not only is the view stunning, so is the performance. The curtain wall system has proven so effective an insulator, an earlier plan to install solar blinds has been scrapped. "Some of this stuff actually works," laughs Mr. Daniels. "As a consumer, you're inundated with it every day now; every day you turn on the TV, you pick up a newspaper or magazine and all you hear about is this green material, that green material, and thank God some of it works!"
Upstairs, awaiting refinishing are original hardwood floors that have been patched with pieces from other areas. Cuts to this three-quarter-century-old wood were done so precisely, says project manager Nick Egizii, the flooring contractors said it was "easier working with this than working with new wood."
Reflective high-albedo paint isn't the only thing covering the roof this time. Lined up like a giant's fallen dominos are massive solar panels that will supply the home with its entire hot water supply. Not only that, says Mr. Dowsett, they do double duty by helping to shade the roof. Popping up here and there are electrical goosenecks that will eventually connect to solar-electric panels: "At one point in time, we imagine that it will be cost effective to install solar-electric," says Mr. Daniels.
Until then, green pioneer Mr. Daniels is having a blast doing nightly research into sustainable technologies with a low-cost/high-benefit ratio, and Mr. Dowsett and Mr. Egizii are busily making it all happen.
And I, your humble Architourist (who can see past the mess) will bring you the finished project some time in late 2008 or early 2009. "We're as on schedule as you can be in a renovation," finishes Mr. Daniels.
Credit: daveleblanc@globeandmail.com

____________________________________________________________

House not selling? New design shows can help distract you

Author: Ryan, Andrew

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/house-not-selling-new-design-shows-can-help/docview/382711056/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: In each of the 13 episodes, Dekora's resident stagers - either [Matthew Finlason] or the combative mother-daughter team of Maureen Powers and Bridget Savereux - is allotted five days or less to spruce up a slow-moving listing.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=House+not+selling%3F+New+design+shows+can+help+distract+you&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-27&amp;spage=R.27&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=House+not+selling%3F+New+design+shows+can+help+distract+you&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-27&amp;spage=R.27&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The real-estate market has turned medium-cool lately. The mortgage crisis south of the border, a slowdown in new-home sales and general North American economic malaise have expectedly reduced the volume of buyers and sellers in the housing market. With daily reports of a semi-recession and gasoline prices reaching new highs, fewer people are looking to change their address.
The market value of home and design TV shows, meanwhile, booms away. The renovation and design genre does not require permits to make additions; most often the new shows simply appear on television and immediately connect with some segment of the viewing audience, whether on a mainstream scale ( Trading Spaces , various Martha Stewart incarnations) or to a more select viewership ( World's Greenest Homes or the curiously popular Colin and Justin's Home Heist ).
The niche category expands slightly for the launch of four new shows on HGTV, the cable mother ship of home and design television. And in a very rare occurrence, each new arrival is of Canadian origin.
The hottest new listing: The Stagers (Tuesday, HGTV at 10 p.m.) focuses on a handful of experts who transform average-looking homes into posh showroom spaces, with the express intent of driving up the price, of course. Even in the fussy TV design field, home staging is an extremely specialized craft.
"What we do does not fit into the standard equation of interior design," asserts Matthew Finlason, the wired lead stager on the Canadian-made series. "We're in the business of creating first impressions. When I do a home staging, I feel like I'm painting a beautiful picture with sofas and carpets."
However esoteric, the process apparently works: In some instances, home staging has been credited for tacking $100,000 and upward onto the asking price of a home.
Filmed in and around Vancouver, where the real-estate market seemingly remains quite healthy, The Stagers goes behind the scenes at Dekora, a design firm that has built its reputation on professional home staging. With locations in Vancouver and Calgary, the company's stockrooms are stocked to the rafters with furniture and accessories; artwork is regularly rented or borrowed from local galleries. "Each piece of art must inspire a positive emotion," Finlason says.
In each of the 13 episodes, Dekora's resident stagers - either Finlason or the combative mother-daughter team of Maureen Powers and Bridget Savereux - is allotted five days or less to spruce up a slow-moving listing. The fast turnaround naturally produces moments of high TV drama. "It can be a very intense process," says Finlason, who previously worked as a production designer and set decorator. "Besides the tight time constraints, we're always on a limited budget and usually fighting for the best lamps and sofas. Most home stagers believe they're crashing and burning on every job."
The tension is palpable in one early outing of The Stagers, in which Finlason is summoned to a sprawling Vancouver estate. With more than 8,000 square feet, the home is estimated to be in the $5-million range but has been on the market for more than a year.
As the five-day deadline looms, the situation is compounded by the presence of another hotshot stager named Jay, who has already started the job. There are immediate clashes of personal taste. "Each stager has his or her own unique style," Finlason says.
But the two creative minds eventually come together on the project and the subsequent grand unveiling results in renewed interest and a quick sale. Even when executed by committee, the home-staging concept works. "It only takes a minute for two people to fall in love with the vignette you've created," Finlason says, "and then it's game over."
Other homestyle arrivals in the week ahead: Dirty Business (Tuesday, HGTV at 8 p.m.) follows the workings of a high-end landscape design firm in Toronto. In the opening show, renowned greenery artist Joel Loblaw draws up elaborate plans to turn a dreary backyard into a stunning outdoor living space, replete with a functional patio and reading nook.
The hitch: The work crew's only access to the backyard involves tromping through the recently redesigned front yard.
Also new: The Property Shop (Wednesday, HGTV at 8 p.m.), which follows the efforts of feisty real-estate-agent-turned-broker Tatiana Londono to open her own agency in the competitive Montreal market. Her co-workers refer to Ms. Londono as "the Gordon Ramsay of real estate," which may not necessarily be intended as a compliment.
Finally, The Fix (Thursday, HGTV at 9 p.m.) brings elements of MTV's Punk'd into the design world. The format: Irreverent Brit contractors Neil Davies and Jay Purvis confer with people who believe they're getting a free makeover. They are in for a rude surprise.
The ensuing design work takes the homeowner's wishes very literally: One young Toronto couple's desire for a French country-inspired bedroom results in an over-the-top transformation - with billowing drapes, burgundy wallpaper and a massive headboard better suited to Louis XIV. The only thing missing is a stand for powdered wigs.
Once everyone has had a good laugh, and the couple recover from the shock, the cheeky TV designers wisely revert the space to their original wishes. You never know who might be a future client.
*****

CBS is expanding its plans for Million Dollar Password ; the network has announced it will order six additional episodes of the game-show remake hosted by Regis Philbin. Million Dollar Password garnered nearly 10 million U.S. viewers for each of its first four broadcasts, making it one of the few breakout hits of the early summer TV season. The original Password , which aired on CBS from 1961 to 1967, was hosted by Allen Ludden and rarely exceeded $500 in winnings; the new version boasts a grand prize of, yes, $1-million (U.S.). Celebrities appearing so far on Million Dollar Password have included Neil Patrick Harris, Steven Weber and
Rachael Ray.

Devotees of The Sopranos will need to make room on the shelf for an upcoming DVD box set. Weighing more than 4.5 kilograms, the package retails at $400 (U.S.).

What architects build for themselves

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/what-architects-build-themselves/docview/382710769/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: If Mr. [Charles Gane]'s Georgian Bay architecture reminds us of post-war America, Mr. Eslahjou's $1.2-million, 7,500-square-foot villa, slated to rise in Southern Ontario's wine-making region, recalls the stringent, elegant residential modernism of Le Corbusier in the 1920s. A series of bone-white concrete boxes, raised on a stone base and arrayed on a long axis, are penetrated by strips of black-framed windows.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=What+architects+build+for+themselves&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-27&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=What+architects+build+for+themselves&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-27&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Freed from client constraints, two of the city's top architects unveil plans for their own cottage country dream homes
Ever since Victorian factories made Hogtown smoggy, right down to our post-industrial present, many Torontonians have dreamed about building perfect houses in the countryside. What such a place should look like, of course, has always been a matter of very varied opinion.
New country-seat designs currently on offer from architects around Toronto run the gamut from pompously baronial mansions and pumped-up suburban - obviously not among my first choices - to finely tuned contemporary updates of such old favourites as the Muskoka cottage and the Ontario farmhouse.
Because the taste of clients is so wide-ranging, and because designers can always be found to satisfy every yen (however dotty or downright bad), the new architecture of getaway country will always be - alas! - a schmozzle of styles.
But what happens when architects find themselves in a position to ignore the opinions of clients and make art with no one but themselves in mind? I got some interesting answers to this question last week. At the downtown Toronto offices of core architects, principals Charles Gane and Babak Eslahjou are at work on schemes for rural retreats for themselves and their families. Each man's building is different in manner and atmosphere from the other, but both are rooted firmly in the legacy of the last century's architectural avant-garde.
Which can be a problem.
When fully built out, Mr. Gane's 2,850-square-foot dwelling of stone, glass and wood will run long and low across a four-acre, exposed outcrop of mainland rock on Georgian Bay. (The $400,000 first phase of construction is expected to begin next year.) The terraced building's floor-to-ceiling glass walls are sandwiched between two horizontal slabs, though the dead-flat roofline is occasionally interrupted by massive, boxy stone chimneys, a ceiling lift over the living room and other shifts in height.
The site is tight, with a rattlesnake precinct crowding in on one side - I don't have much sympathy for these nasty creatures, but I suppose we must protect them - and a shallow marsh encroaching on the other. Despite these geographical restraints, Mr. Gane has fashioned a holiday abode with the low-slung sweep typical of modernist residential styling in Canada and the United States, circa 1950.
Is Georgian Bay ready for the summer residence of this kind? The answer you give depends on your position in a long-standing architectural quarrel.
Those who believe that all new refuges up north should always look like traditional cottages won't like this proposal. They have a point, if not a very powerful one. Long before architects began to busy themselves in escape country, local craftsmen had established a solid tradition of practical, handsome building that accorded well with the harsh climate and splendid terrain of the north - a vernacular tradition that some thoughtful latter-day architects have learned excellent lessons from.
Then there are critics - I am one of them - who argue that architects should design, everywhere and always, according to the best lights of our present age. But, here again, Mr. Gane's building does not fit. Its inspirations come from what modernism was some time ago, not what it is today: His structure brings to mind the prairie houses of Frank Lloyd Wright, and (more vividly) the mid-century California residences by Richard Neutra and Rudolph Schindler. And like these precedents, Mr. Gane's retreat is suave, urbane - too chic by half, or so it seems to me, for its delightfully savage natural surroundings.
If Mr. Gane's Georgian Bay architecture reminds us of post-war America, Mr. Eslahjou's $1.2-million, 7,500-square-foot villa, slated to rise in Southern Ontario's wine-making region, recalls the stringent, elegant residential modernism of Le Corbusier in the 1920s. A series of bone-white concrete boxes, raised on a stone base and arrayed on a long axis, are penetrated by strips of black-framed windows. A central pavilion, which separates the building's two principal volumes, is open to the elements and views on both sides.
Set down in an orchard on a 14-acre property, Mr. Eslahjou's building is intended to be a rural gathering place for his large Iranian-Canadian family, which comprises three generations.
Hence the ample appointments for luxurious relaxation by people ranging in age from patriarchs down to teenagers and infants: a pool, screening room, Turkish bath and steam room, nanny suite and party room, six bedrooms, a dining room for 14 and so on.
There is no question here of an awkward fit between house and context. Like Corbu's country homes in rural France, this highly civilized project is a good match for the old, civilized agricultural landscape round about.
We might have hoped that Mr. Eslahjou had put his energy into a more contemporary remodelling of venerable modernist country-house ideas - but never mind. As it stands, his design is a potent restatement of certain modern moves - clean, long lines, taut and unadorned solid geometry, the bold contrast between stark white walls and verdant orchards - that will probably remain stylish forever.
Credit: jmays@globeandmail.com

Ballymore targets first-time buyers

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ballymore-targets-first-time-buyers/docview/382710703/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "The majority of the homes being built are on a cul-de-sac," says Mr. [Mark Hansley]. "It makes it a lot safer."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ballymore+targets+first-time+buyers&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-27&amp;spage=G.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Homestead Park
Location: Scarborough
BUILDER/DEVELOPER: Ballymore Homes
SIZE: 1,717 to 1,953 sq. ft.
PRICE: $269,900 to $357,900
SALES CENTRE: Homestead Drive and Lawrence Avenue. Open Monday to Wednesday, 1 p.m. to 8 p.m.; Thursday and Friday by appointment; weekends and holidays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
CONTACT: Phone (416) 287-8676 or visit www.ballymorehomes.com
In the West Hill community in the east end of the city, newer single-family houses range from $400,000 to $500,000, prices that are out of reach for first-time buyers, says a local sales representative for Ballymore Homes.
As a more affordable alternative, the builder's infill project still has a handful of executive freehold townhouses left for between $269,900 and $357,900.
"It's an easy way to get into the housing market without having to be house-poor," says Mark Hansley, who runs the sales office for the development, called Homestead Park.
Furthermore, interested buyers can move in as soon as the end of this month, since construction is under way on the site at Homestead Drive and Lawrence Avenue, just east of Morningside Avenue.
The community will have 39 townhouses, six semi-detached residences and one detached house, along with sidewalks and a small park that some residences will be adjacent to.
"The majority of the homes being built are on a cul-de-sac," says Mr. Hansley. "It makes it a lot safer."
The site is next to Heron Park, a community centre and recreational facilities, as well as public schools that can be accessed via a path.
More parks can be found along the waterfront to the south.
Down the street, the Morningside Mall is being redeveloped with new stores, a Goodlife Fitness centre and a Starbucks.
"There's a little bit of everything for everyone, from first-time buyers to empty nesters, where they have the convenience of being able to walk to anything that they really need," Mr. Hansley says.
Also nearby is 24-hour bus service, a GO Transit station and Highway 401.
Two- and three-storey models will be available. Most will have 1,731 square feet with three bedrooms.
"You can fit a queen-sized bed in all three bedrooms," he says, noting that bedrooms in many newer homes have been shrinking.
Plans can be modified to incorporate a fourth or fifth bedroom, a third full bathroom upstairs or lower level family rooms with walkouts, bathrooms and fireplaces.
The main floors will have open or traditional principal rooms and eat-in kitchens with breakfast bars, pantries and rear decks, depending on the plan, Mr. Hansley adds.
Standard finishes will include imported ceramic tile floors and 35-ounce broadloom carpet.
The exteriors will display heritage-inspired brick facades with vinyl shakes, stone sills and steeply pitched roofs. Two-storey townhouses will have front garages, while three-storey units will have rear ones.
