Coming clean on cool Copenhagen

Author: Forman, Janet

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/coming-clean-on-cool-copenhagen/docview/382717492/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Maria Peterson agrees. The owner of Tea Time, a velvet-draped parlour offering delicate pink and yellow cupcakes, maintains that there would be no "princess" pastries here without the gritty streets. "In a nice neighbourhood, there would be no tension," she says. "My other shop is in Vesterbro."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Coming+clean+on+cool+Copenhagen&amp;author=Forman%2C+Janet&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-21&amp;spage=T.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Coming+clean+on+cool+Copenhagen&amp;author=Forman%2C+Janet&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-21&amp;spage=T.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In the bohemian neighbourhoods of Vesterbro and Norrebro, restaurants and shops thrive on the local vibe, Janet Forman writes
There's a golden moment in gentrifying city districts - the period just before the local bohemian communities, with their eccentric shops and cheap coffee, are pushed out by their fellow travellers, real-estate developers. Such is certainly the case now in the Copenhagen neighbourhoods of Vesterbro, once a mustering point for prostitutes, and Norrebro, formerly the destination of choice for protest-hungry students.
"A few years ago, Vesterbro was one of the worst areas in Denmark," says 29-year-old Rune Jochumsen, one of the chefs/co-owners of area restaurant formel B. "People would have to take a 50-krone cab to get here."
The angriest screeds in Norrebro these days are on the walls of an espresso bar, and in most parts of Vesterbro you can shop for a lovely pair of pumps without being aggressively propositioned.
"It's cleaner now, but a little more boring," says Jonas, looking up from his book on the steps of Bang and Jensen, an old Vesterbro pharmacy that has been transformed into a trendsetters' gathering place. It's the middle of the afternoon and already the moth-eaten couches and rows of old cinema seats are filled with locals sipping craft beers and devouring muesli-based cuisine.
For a little excitement, perhaps Jonas could put down his book and head to the neighbourhood rock palace, Vega, whose mahogany floors and flamboyant friezes were a beehive of union offices a generation ago. Now, the building houses the soignee Ideal Bar, Vega Lounge and two concert halls that host headliners such as David Bowie, the Foo Fighters and Canadian star Feist, progressive groups like the Danish metal band Volbeat and ripping DJs like Fatboy Slim.
A few blocks away near the suburb of Frederiksberg is Meyers Deli, a café and artisanal grocery store at the centre of a culinary revolution known as the New Nordic cuisine. At square communal tables, fashionistas and toddler-toting parents sample the region's unique style of gastronomy in the form of brown ale ice cream, the oddly tropical sea buckthorn juice and a jam made of rare Arctic brambles. Some drop strawberries into a glass of birch juice, a barely sweet liquid that makes the fruit explode with flavour.
At formel B, meanwhile, Jochumsen and his 28-year-old partner, Kristian Moller, employ a shadowy local icon known as the Master Forager, a bike-riding countercultural elder statesman in his 70s who sometimes pulls lamb's lettuce and wild mushrooms straight from the ground of Vesterbro.
Danish style
Denmark's designers are attracting as much attention as its chefs these days, and design devotees should set their sights on Norrebro, where some of the country's most unconventional craftspeople are alighting on the quarter's pinwheel lanes.
On Elmegade, spirited clothing designers light up the racks at Funf, the lingerie at Missekat is dangerously flirty, and the neon-hued bicycles at Cykelmageren look like pop sculpture.
On adjacent Faelledvej, LLLP carries gem-coloured scarves and a respectable catalogue of cutting-edge Scandinavian jeans, from high-end Acne to Cheap Monday for the frugal.
The shop's fanciful lampshades, which pack flat for travel, illuminate one of Norrebro's liveliest - and cleanest - gathering spots, the Laundromat Café. Nirvana for the traveller who wants a good spin cycle with his cappuccino, the bistro is equipped with washers and dryers, as well as 4,000 used books, chess and backgammon sets, wireless Internet service and clued-in English-speaking locals.
"We opened here because Norrebro is a neighbourhood of designers," says Icelandic born owner Fridrik Weisshappel Jonsson, "the kind of people open to new things" - not because he felt the area needed a cleanup.
Maria Peterson agrees. The owner of Tea Time, a velvet-draped parlour offering delicate pink and yellow cupcakes, maintains that there would be no "princess" pastries here without the gritty streets. "In a nice neighbourhood, there would be no tension," she says. "My other shop is in Vesterbro."
Of course, compared with its firebrand era, Norrebro is counterculture lite these days. A political café has been transformed into one of Copenhagen's hottest music spots, Rust; a gathering place called Gefährlich, German for "dangerous," delivers underground trends via vinyl records and T-shirts; and a bit of raunch remains at concert venue Stengade 30, where the Rub a Dub Sundays promise to "waste" your Mondays.
But even now that the agent provocateurs have decamped for more affordable locales, parts of the neighbourhood remain untouched by sushi bars and shoe shops. A few metres from the chaotic second-hand stores on Ravnsborggade, the pierced and tattooed brush shoulders with hijab -clad women, Muslim kids lift their robes to kick a soccer ball and shawarma stands outnumber smoked-fish shops.
Gentrification still seems a long way off.

Where history and affordability go hand-in-hand

Author: Laidlaw, Katherine

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/where-history-affordability-go-hand/docview/382719981/se-2?accountid=14656

Full text: Kingston seems to have something for nature lovers, history buffs and theatre aficionados.
The city, which according to its official website has a population of about 113,000, also boasts two universities and a college.
"We're not a significantly large population, so the atmosphere is very friendly and very open," says Larry McDowall, president of the Kingston and Area Real Estate Association.
Besides being a major port from which to cruise the 1000 Islands, the city offers Fort Henry, built in the 1830s, and the Rideau Canal, both designated world heritage sites, Mr. McDowall notes.
In addition, there are plenty of theatres, galleries and museums.
According to Mr. McDowall, the average resale price of a house in the Kingston area is $231,992 as of April.
991 SYDENHAM RD.

AGENT: Kim Treleaven, Royal LePage ProAlliance Realty, Kingston

DESCRIPTION: This red brick home, built about 150 years ago, is entered through a spacious foyer with a walk-in closet and wide baseboards. All of the rooms have red pine flooring.

____________________________________________________________

'Feel-good' towers not wanted, form-fit is

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/feel-good-towers-not-wanted-form-fit-is/docview/382719937/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Local pundits have lavished praise on the project, hailing it as a "landmark" akin to the Eiffel Tower, a "magnificent structure," and so on. Mr. [Daniel Libeskind] himself says of it: "The Ascent at Roebling's bridge is a living, breathing work that stirs the soul and lifts the spirit." It's a tall building designed quite obviously to knock the socks off Cincinnati and Covington residents.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Feel-good%27+towers+not+wanted%2C+form-fit+is&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Feel-good%27+towers+not+wanted%2C+form-fit+is&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Libeskind's Ascent is out of place, but van Berkel's Five Franklin borrows from its neighbours and hits the right note
Browsing the international architectural press recently, I came across a couple of American tall buildings from which local designers and we skyscraper fans can learn a thing or two. I thought you might be interested, so here they are.
One is Daniel Libeskind's typically (for him) eccentric Ascent in the Cincinnati suburb of Covington, Ky., near the Roebling Suspension Bridge over the Ohio River. It is the architect's first tall residential structure in the United States.
Rising and flaring from 14 to 22 storeys in a broad curve, this condominium tower is the kind of thing Toronto needs in very sparse amounts, if at all.
A note about the aesthetics. The building is clad, on two elevations, with large plank-like slabs of precast concrete interrupted by blue glass. The upthrust prow of this theologically named building has balconies, which, according to one report, are intended to open to views of downtown Cincinnati.
Local pundits have lavished praise on the project, hailing it as a "landmark" akin to the Eiffel Tower, a "magnificent structure," and so on. Mr. Libeskind himself says of it: "The Ascent at Roebling's bridge is a living, breathing work that stirs the soul and lifts the spirit." It's a tall building designed quite obviously to knock the socks off Cincinnati and Covington residents.
I have argued elsewhere that look-at-me towers occasionally have a place in the urban fabric and in architectural thinking. The Toronto-area city of Mississauga, for example, could probably use a few marquee condo buildings to lend aesthetic spark to its humdrum expanse of rootless suburban sprawl. Beijing architect Yansong Ma's much-touted, curvaceous "Marilyn" towers, now under construction, may just do the trick.
While I won't presume to tell Cincinnati or Covington what they need, I wonder whether Ascent is it.
Most old, well-rooted American communities, especially in the vast heartland of the country, could stand much vigorous repair and restoration. Crowd-pleasing "icons" in such places can distract public attention from the difficult, serious work of city-building, or rebuilding. Flashy eye-poppers like Ascent are usually all about tourism, and contribute little or nothing to the mending of the frayed urban tapestry. As I suggested, they may have a small part to play in lending identity to a quick-built suburb like Mississauga. I don't see what good Ascent can do for elderly, self-possessed Cincinnati, other than make the city briefly feel better about its "progress" than perhaps it should.
Another American high-rise that deserves attention, this one exactly because of its city-building potential, will soon go up in the heart of New York's Tribeca neighbourhood.
The 20-storey luxury condominium building is called Five Franklin Place, and is the first important American project by architect and theorist Ben van Berkel, of the Dutch firm UNStudio. The structure will be situated among older neighbours on a recently restored 19th-century laneway. If renderings are anything to go on - the ones I found seem honest enough - Mr. van Berkel's project will be an excellent instance of sound, sensitive urbanism.
Interesting new architectural schemes destined for well-established areas in every city usually take one of two forms: appropriation of the best moves in the more mature architecture round about or a delineation of vivid contrasts between the new and old. Either approach can produce a fine building.
It's all to the good, however, if the architect can figure out a way to meld the two strategies into a single instrument of design.
Which is what Mr. van Berkel has accomplished in his proposal for Five Franklin Place. With a bow to the Victorian cast-metal facades for which Tribeca is famous, the architect has wrapped his building in horizontal metal straps that vary in width, creating a handsomely sculpted, urbane and lively front elevation. The edifice fits into its place in the city, reinforcing such admirable things about lower Manhattan as the streetscapes of building fronts pressed tight against sidewalks and the business-like atmosphere that has survived from the district's former career as a zone of workshops and warehouses.
At the same time, Five Franklin Place will be entirely a building of our era. The metal bands will alternate with expanses of glass, and step-backs in the facade respond to contemporary concerns about the need for sunlight at street level.
The whole composition is unmistakably modern, in the best sense of the word: efficient, serious, open-handed.
In its freshness and serene grace, and in its mindfulness about its new-kid-on-the block status in an enormously complex urban environment, Mr. van Berkel's design provides a model of architectural citizenship that architects in Toronto, Cincinnati and every other North American city would do well to adopt in their own work.
Credit: jmays@globeandmail.com

Another dip in home sales recorded, but prices continue to increase

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/another-dip-home-sales-recorded-prices-continue/docview/382719882/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: In a press release, TREB president Maureen O'Neill pointed out that 2007 was "a particularly strong year" in the local real estate market and that, when compared with the first half of June, 2006, this month's sales are up 7 per cent.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Another+dip+in+home+sales+recorded%2C+but+prices+continue+to+increase&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Another+dip+in+home+sales+recorded%2C+but+prices+continue+to+increase&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The recent trend of sales declines coupled with modest price gains in the resale housing market continued into the first half of June, the Toronto Real Estate Board said this week.
The average price for a home in the Greater Toronto Area rose to $398,542 in the first two weeks of June, up 4 per cent from the $384,576 average for the same period a year ago, and an increase of 11 per cent from the $358,648 recorded at mid-June, 2006.
In the city of Toronto, the current average price is $439,469, up 3 per cent over the $424,888 a year ago, and 14 per cent higher than the $386,960 average in the first half of June, 2006.
In the 905 region, the average price is $371,686, up 4 per cent from the $357,359 average a year ago and an increase of 10 per cent from the $338,578 recorded at mid-June 2006.
A total of 4,374 homes were sold in the first half of June, a 14-per-cent decline from a year ago.
However, in a press release, TREB president Maureen O'Neill pointed out that 2007 was "a particularly strong year" in the local real estate market and that, when compared with the first half of June, 2006, this month's sales are up 7 per cent.
In the city of Toronto, 1,733 sales were recorded in the period, representing a 15-per-cent decrease, compared with the 2,045 properties sold a year ago, but a 2-per-cent increase over the 1,690 transactions in the first half of June, 2006.
In the 905 region, 2,641 properties changed hands, a 13-per-cent decline, compared with the 3,029 homes sold in the first half of June last year, but an 11-per-cent increase over the 2,384 properties sold at mid-June, 2006.
The neighbourhoods of Riverdale, West Agincourt, Caledon and Richmond Hill South all experienced particularly strong activity in the first half of this month.
In Riverdale, sales increased 28 per cent from the first half of June, 2007, driven by strong condo resales. Condos also pushed up sales in West Agincourt by 24 per cent from the same period a year ago.
In Caledon, strong detached home sales led to a 9-per-cent increase over the same period a year ago. In Richmond Hill, similar strength in sales of detached homes resulted in a 5-per-cent increase from mid-June, 2007.
Credit: Staff

Is the horse the 'new golf'?

Author: Gold, Kerry

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/is-horse-new-golf/docview/382719329/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "He said, 'I bought this piece of property and I don't know what to do with it," recalls Ms. [Carolyn Lair]. "I fell in love with it."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Is+the+horse+the+%27new+golf%27%3F&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Is+the+horse+the+%27new+golf%27%3F&amp;author=Gold%2C+Kerry&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: With interest in horse-related activities on the rise, builders are planning projects with stables and indoor riding facilities
There was a time when the horsy set brought to mind pampered gentry who wore jodhpurs and attended things like coming out balls. Tracy Lord in The Philadelphia Story , for example - she would have been a horse rider. English style, of course.
Considering that practically every girl around the age of eight years old falls hard for the idea of owning a horse, it was just a matter of time until the horsy set adjusted itself to middle-class demands. As well, the horsy lifestyle occupies a natural spot within the green movement, where a ride through the wilderness on a non-gas-guzzling beast is the epitome of back-to-basics leisure.
Developers have taken notice, responding with equestrian communities, with shared stables and horse care that means savings for horse owners. It also means a pastoral setting for those who might just want to live among the horsy set, without ever having to mount a horse.
The horse, says developer Michael Goodman, is the "new golf." Statistics do show growth. Horse-related businesses have steadily grown 7 per cent in the past 15 years, according to the Horse Council of B.C. In Langley, the High Point Equestrian Estate is luxury living for the horsy set.
Mr. Goodman, owner of Richmond's Tri City Group, is in the process of delivering a green, affordable equestrian community to the outdoorsy city of Squamish. Squamish, as British Columbians know, is the playground for outdoor enthusiasts, connected to Whistler by the Sea-to-Sky Highway. If Mr. Goodman has his way, the locals will soon count horseback riding among their leisure activities.
"There is a ton of people interested in just buying around a horse community - they don't necessarily ride horses themselves," says Mr. Goodman.
Mr. Goodman purchased 140 acres of undeveloped property that runs alongside the Cheakamus River and is criss-crossed with old logging trails. His Paradise Trails proposal calls for the low-density development of 82 lots, including a smaller adjacent site that's currently crown land. If his purchase of the crown land goes through, the project would total 167 acres. Each lot will average two acres and have access to stables and an indoor riding facility with "world-class teachers" to give lessons. As well, the community would have access to stable hands, a vet, a tack shop, coffee bar and banquet facility. Of the horse stalls, 25 per cent would be reserved for Squamish residents to use.
The sustainable community would include buildings with LEED certification, on-site composting and a self-contained tertiary water treatment system.
With the greater Squamish community in mind, Mr. Goodman proposes a development that would dedicate 15 kilometres of trails to the public. He proposes reforestation of the previously logged site, with a public pathway along the river.
The lots would be priced at around the $400,000 range, which, says Mr. Goodman, is fairly typical for Squamish.
"The lots will be the upper middle class kind of price range," he says. "And people will decide what types of houses they want to build themselves. We will have a quality standard, and a restricted size. But we're going to leave it up to people to use their own creativity."
Susan Balcom saw the market for the new horsy set when she quit her day job to open a tack store in Langley. Business has been so steady that she's opened a second tack shop, in Vancouver's Southlands flats. Ms. Balcom says the majority of her customers are women with extra cash flow.
"I think that while a lot of their husbands are out playing golf, today's professional woman would like to go out and ride," she says. "A lot of these women are independently successful, so they are choosing to spend a lot of money on an activity they truly enjoy."
She estimates that it costs about $1,000 a month to own a horse and ride it, including about $700 a month for boarding and maintenance costs such as shoeing and lessons.
"I think that's why these equestrian communities are going to be successful," says Ms. Balcom. "One of the big draws is that between neighbours, you could share some of the workload and the cost."
Before Mr. Goodman embarked on the equestrian idea, he consulted Carolyn Lair, a community development specialist with whom he'd worked on marina projects.
"He said, 'I bought this piece of property and I don't know what to do with it," recalls Ms. Lair. "I fell in love with it."
Ms. Lair did extensive conservation research before deciding the land was compatible with horses. Ms. Lair, who moved to B.C. from California, comes from a family hard-bitten by the horse life. She has two sisters who train horses, a niece who makes a living as a horse braider and a brother who's a farrier.
"The lands traditionally used for equestrian activity are all being developed," she says. "We felt that it would be a good match and a way to keep the trails on our land public and a link to municipal trails.
"I think it's very unusual," she adds. "As far as I know, we're the only ones pulling together the notion of the equestrian club with sustainability practices."

A graceful glazier gives a touch of glass to Toronto homes

Author: Leblanc, Dave

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/graceful-glazier-gives-touch-glass-toronto-homes/docview/382716614/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Almost. But don't confuse enthusiasm for a lack of grace: [John F. Wilcox], the award-winning owner of Vitreous Glassworks, has gobs of grace and the delicate touch needed to be around all of this beautiful glass. It's just that he's got a lot of things he wants to show off - "Oh, you're a fan of Vitrolite? Follow me!" or "Oh, sure, we did the windows at the Sharon Temple; here's a picture!" - and not a lot of time.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+graceful+glazier+gives+a+touch+of+glass+to+Toronto+homes&amp;author=Leblanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+graceful+glazier+gives+a+touch+of+glass+to+Toronto+homes&amp;author=Leblanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-20&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: John F. Wilcox has travelled the world to stoke his passion
You'd almost be inclined to call him a bull in a china shop the way he's bouncing around the 1,500-square-foot studio.
Almost. But don't confuse enthusiasm for a lack of grace: John F. Wilcox, the award-winning owner of Vitreous Glassworks, has gobs of grace and the delicate touch needed to be around all of this beautiful glass. It's just that he's got a lot of things he wants to show off - "Oh, you're a fan of Vitrolite? Follow me!" or "Oh, sure, we did the windows at the Sharon Temple; here's a picture!" - and not a lot of time.
And then there's that booming laugh that waggles his bushy beard. It's a laugh born out of confidence, not braggadocio, and it punctuates a fascinating conversation ranging from glassy things local to far-flung, modern to historic.
"We may have the largest collection of Victorian bird windows in the world!" he says, his chuckle ricocheting off the cinderblock walls. "It's something that we can always say because it's up to another city to try and say otherwise."
He's holding up an example from Parkdale right now, which he's going to restore along with a bunch of others in the room.
He's such an expert craftsman, even if half of that gorgeous stained glass was missing - including the part with the little painted bird - he could recreate it.
Before I can get him talking about his own history, he's bouncing again - to the invention of glass as told by Pliny the Elder, to Britain's "window tax" of the 1700s and 1800s, to modernist architect I.M. Pei's urgent call for glass that was less green (the colour, not the movement) for his pyramid at the Louvre, and, finally, to where Toronto's glass factories once stood.
"It's a fascinating history, the history of glass," says the 43-year-old, sweating a little after all that running around.
But no less fascinating than the story of how he became one of Toronto's top glaziers. An early love of stained glass led him to a leading Toronto ecclesiastical studio for an apprenticeship in the 1980s. It was the perfect time to learn, he says, because many of the masters that had been working since the Second World War were basking in the glow of impending retirement ... and feeling charitable as a result.
"They weren't threatened by me," he begins. "I heard years later that they were all very secretive with their techniques before and there were rivalries and stuff like that."
Next, he started to "augment" that knowledge with his own study, first with a course in glass-forming at the Ontario College of Art, glass-blowing at Sheridan College and, finally, the architectural technology program at Ryerson, which "gave me the language," he says simply.
He also bought a "one way ticket to Paris" to ogle medieval churches, then ended up in Egypt studying ancient Islamic stained-glass windows, in which plaster rather than lead is used because "they don't have the rains that would ruin them." Along the way, he visited as many glass-restoration studios as possible to observe local technique.
In 1992, he founded Vitreous Glassworks and, after working mostly as a subcontractor for larger companies, began to get big commissions of his own. He did restoration work on windows at Massey Hall; the Massey mausoleum at Mount Pleasant Cemetery; the Ontario government's Whitney Block; the ultra-hip West Queen West bookends, the Gladstone and Drake hotels; and, perhaps most impressive, the three long windows over the former main entrance to the Royal Ontario Museum, for which he won an award.
He also cast small glass blocks mimicking the old aluminum grills that once graced the ROM's original wooden doors before they were reinstalled: "I did this basically for free because it's such an honour," he says.
But that's not to say he's gotten too big to do little residential projects, whether it's restoration of some stained glass for a grand Annex lady or the creation of something brand new and minimalist for a modern abode or business. (If you're ever in the neighbourhood, check out the amazing non-denominational birch tree window he created for the chapel at the Wexford senior's residence.)
Although he understands that "glass is very alluring" to the general public, it's also incredibly fickle and delicate. The average homeowner, he cautions, should leave removal and restoration to the professionals: One wrong move and what may have been a quick cleaning and reputtying for a few hundred dollars will become a few thousand.
"Somehow the glass knows," he says with a hint of mystery. "If you're afraid of it, you transfer that emotion to the glass somehow and you can break it."
Those with questions about how to keep their heritage windows healthy would be wise to visit the Lillian Smith Library at College and Huron streets tomorrow at 2 p.m. The Toronto branch of the Architectural Conservancy of Ontario has invited the excitable Mr. Wilcox to leave his pen to give an illustrated talk, "Glass in Architecture," on the history of glass and his own work around town. Admission is free, and I guarantee you'll leave with a newfound or rekindled love for glass.
And that's no bull.
Credit: daveleblanc@globeandmail.com

Did someone say the R word? Not in Toronto

Author: Barber, John

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/did-someone-say-r-word-not-toronto/docview/382706406/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Ontarians may wail about being victimized by an overvalued "petro-dollar," but Bay Street doesn't mind. The Toronto Stock Exchange is heavily weighted in favour of resource stocks, boasting that it and its junior affiliate list more oil and gas companies than any other exchange in the world. Mining finance is another Toronto specialty that is thriving in the era of high commodity prices.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Did+someone+say+the+R+word%3F+Not+in+Toronto&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-17&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Did+someone+say+the+R+word%3F+Not+in+Toronto&amp;author=Barber%2C+John&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-17&amp;spage=A.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Is Toronto recession-proof? Judging by the well-publicized agonies Central Canada is now going through - the so-called Dutch disease made feverish by $140-a-barrel oil, compounded by endless global financial crises - it might seem rash even to suggest such a thing. But so far, it's true.
Every developer fears the worst. In the meantime, they are all scrambling to meet insistent demand for new places to work and live.
The vacancy rate for top-quality downtown office space "went into freefall" in the first quarter of 2008, according to Cushman & Wakefield Lepage, dragging down vacancy rates for all kinds of commercial space in central Toronto.
Rental rates rose correspondingly: Companies scrambling to find a good address in the financial core drove up rents by the annual equivalent of 14 per cent in the first three months of this year, according to Cushman, leasing almost one million square feet of space over the same time.
That's why so many new office buildings are going up downtown, with 3.4 million square feet - the equivalent of the entire Toronto-Dominion Centre - coming to market next year. If the captains of Canadian commerce are concerned about the disappearance of Canadian manufacturing, they're doing their best to hide it. Locally, it appears to be a non-issue.
One reason is that manufacturing already left the city, with a giant sucking sound, after the advent of free trade in the 1990s. A recession that the rest of the country barely noticed brought Toronto to its knees, wiping out an incredible 200,000 jobs. Local employment has still not reached the level it attained in 1989, but the theory is that the newer jobs that have appeared since then are better adapted to the global economy.
Any manufacturing jobs that haven't left Toronto already, must have a good reason to stay. In the meantime, high-value service industries are all but booming.
It's safe to say that few if any experts expect that to continue as global financial losses mount. But there is some hope that the consequences will be much less severe locally than elsewhere in the so-called heartland. Although no city is an island, some are more securely connected than others.
Ontarians may wail about being victimized by an overvalued "petro-dollar," but Bay Street doesn't mind. The Toronto Stock Exchange is heavily weighted in favour of resource stocks, boasting that it and its junior affiliate list more oil and gas companies than any other exchange in the world. Mining finance is another Toronto specialty that is thriving in the era of high commodity prices. What's bad for General Motors continues to be a source of considerable wealth for local Porsche dealers.
In that context, Toronto is closer to Alberta than Oshawa. As for a Florida-style housing crash, that's further away than either. The border might as well be an iron curtain when it comes to real-estate value. Although the local market is softening, rampant new construction shows little sign of abating.
You could have said the same thing in 1990 as the city economy soared over an unforeseen cliff. People forget that the Bob Rae government inherited a balanced budget. Things change fast. For the time being, however, rose-coloured glasses are indicated.
Credit: jbarber@globeandmail.com

Lights, cameras ... investments

Author: Mitham, Peter

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lights-cameras-investments/docview/382704548/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "They can't be out in the sticks, they have to be within 20 minutes of downtown Vancouver," Mr. [Jason McLean] says, emphasizing the importance of convenience to tenants. "You've got certain above-the-line talent that aren't going to stay in a Motel 6, they're going to be in a downtown hotel."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lights%2C+cameras+...+investments&amp;author=Mitham%2C+Peter&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-17&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lights%2C+cameras+...+investments&amp;author=Mitham%2C+Peter&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-17&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Vancouver's film industry is enjoying a sequel: Big investors are keen to sink money into studios
The high-flying loonie and the lingering effects of the Hollywood writers' strike have broadsided the Vancouver film sector in recent months, despite the city's reputation as a hangout for film stars in town working on the next blockbuster.
But the city has also become a hangout for investors, whose interest in local film studios is spotlighting a sector that's proving action-packed in an otherwise lacklustre British Columbia commercial real estate market.
The past two years have seen Lions Gate Entertainment Corp.'s North Vancouver studios sold to Bosa Development Corp. of Burnaby and the province's sale of its Bridge Studios facility in Burnaby to Larco Investments Ltd. of Vancouver.
More recently, General Electric Co.'s GE Real Estate has stepped in with the biggest investment yet - a $50-million financing of McLean Group's Vancouver Film Studios complex in East Vancouver.
The financing consolidates various loans McLean obtained in the late 1990s to support the development of 11 buildings on a 15-acre site as Vancouver rose to prominence among U.S. film companies.
Over all, the industry spends about $1-billion on production annually in the province, according to the B.C. Film Commission. Hollywood features and television shows dominate the spending, with the typical production worth in excess of $20-million. That's better than in Ontario, which logged nearly $800-million in projects last year, but a greater volume of domestic projects - 164 versus 138 for B.C.
The investment by Connecticut-based GE reduces borrowing costs and positions Vancouver Film Studios for future growth, says Jason McLean, McLean Group's president, adding that a 30,000-square-foot soundstage is among the projects under consideration at its 15-acre campus in East Vancouver.
"The data, historically, is that people still want to watch films, and they want to go to movies and they want to watch TV as much as they do in a buoyant economy as in a challenged economy," Mr. McLean says. "It's an industry where we want to be if the real estate market slows down."
A tight market for industrial space in Metro Vancouver has created favourable conditions for McLean and other studio operators, including Bosa, Larco and Canada Motion Picture Park, industry observers say.
When McLean became involved in the studio business in the 1980s, many stages were set up in warehouses and other industrial properties where production companies made use of excess space.
"We started renting warehouses to film productions that would come in and pay us way more than we were getting from long-term commercial tenants," Mr. McLean says. "We thought to ourselves: 'If we could figure out a way to reduce our vacancy numbers, we're making far more off these short-term users than our long-term commercial tenants.' "
Today, demand for industrial space has pushed vacancies to historic lows - about 2 per cent region-wide and 1 per cent in Vancouver, according to Colliers International.
At the same time, a technological shift has boosted the space demands of production companies. A high-profile program, such as The X-Files , for example, required just three stages for filming; today, a more modest cable offering such as Eureka requires four.
The result has been a boom in demand for space at purpose-built studios, which Colliers vice-president John Boer likens to hotels or mini-storage facilities rather than traditional industrial real estate. "When you've got three- or four-month requirements competing with five-year leases in the industrial sector, the five-year guys are always going to win. So you need the specialty product just to respond."
Mr. Boer, who with colleague James Glen brokered the province's sale of Bridge Studios to Larco in a heated bidding process last year, said demand for film studios remains strong, despite the high Canadian dollar reducing a competitive advantage for productions north of the border.
"I think it's a huge endorsement to the industry that it remains as strong as it does given that it [the dollar] remains at par. And if I were GE, I would get a lot of confidence out of that," he said. "There's still great demand for the product here. The studios are staying pretty full, so, from an investment standpoint, I think it's still a pretty good product."
A number of potential lenders expressed interest in the McLean Group financing; GE was chosen in part because of its interest in the long-term direction of Vancouver Film Studios, observers say.
Indeed, GE's financing of the development of Toronto's Filmport, a $50-million facility boasting 260,000 square feet of production space, is making it a major player in Canada's film business.
Alexandre Sieber, GE's Montreal-based vice-president and general manager of business property, says it's not so much the glamour of the film industry that attracts GE but the opportunities that will add value to its portfolio. GE booked about $7.5-billion in new business in Canada last year primarily in the office, industrial and multifamily sectors.
"The industry is attractive, particularly in provinces like B.C., Quebec and Ontario. We have to realize that the film industry has an impact of about $1-billion on the economy of B.C.," Mr. Sieber said. "Vancouver is strategically placed to attract a lot of attention from California, for many reasons."
Those include being in the same time zone as Hollywood, and being close enough to Los Angeles that crews can go home on weekends. The proximity of the studios to the airport and a vibrant downtown are also part of Vancouver's appeal.
"They can't be out in the sticks, they have to be within 20 minutes of downtown Vancouver," Mr. McLean says, emphasizing the importance of convenience to tenants. "You've got certain above-the-line talent that aren't going to stay in a Motel 6, they're going to be in a downtown hotel."
Mr. Sieber added that the relative youth of Vancouver Film Studios' assets also made it attractive, mirroring the overall growth that has taken place in Western Canada over the past decade - both in its own right and on the balance sheets of investors such as GE. Western Canada accounted for a quarter of the $5-billion of new investment GE made in Canada last year.
"We follow opportunities," Mr. Sieber said. "We go where there's great investments to be done on the GE balance sheets. So the Western Canada part has increased faster than Central and Eastern Canada."
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

Title: Lights, cameras ... investments

Publication title: The Globe and Mail; Toronto, Ont.

____________________________________________________________

Vancouver strikes a fashionable pose

Author: Taylor, Timothy

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/vancouver-strikes-fashionable-pose/docview/382725794/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Of course, Las Vegas never ranks on any of these lists. Its 40 million visitors a year beat Venice (or Vancouver for that matter, by about 34 million), but that's just it. People visit. I'll bet even [Richard Florida]'s "creative classes" visit. Or they do if they like to gamble, or eat, or maybe just like being reassured by street vendors that a prostitute can be delivered to their room in no more than 20 minutes. But they don't stay.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vancouver+strikes+a+fashionable+pose&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Timothy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-16&amp;spage=L.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vancouver+strikes+a+fashionable+pose&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Timothy&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-16&amp;spage=L.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It's been named one of the world's most livable cities by Monocle magazine, but all things popular end up being punished
Some of you may have stifled a yawn the other day, reading that Tyler Brûlé's magazine Monocle published a "most livable cities" list in their most recent issue. Once again, Vancouver has been included in the glittering firmament of the world's most desirable urban places.
We are praised this time in particular for green eco-density initiatives, tolerance and cultural diversity. Our role as a Cantopop and Bollywood feeder system is also noted.
It's getting almost predictable though, isn't it? I worry we'll soon be spoiled. But the ranking also makes me wonder if Vancouver won't ultimately be punished for all this attention, just as all things fashionable are ultimately punished for their popularity. (Mustaches, for example, which I'm confident are going to get punished again if this most recent comeback continues even a single season longer.)
No doubt the compilers of these lists would dispute that fashion has anything to do with it. Monocle actually takes pains to point out their list "has not been developed as a guide for ex-pats looking for their next plummy posting." Instead, the magazine assures us that scientific and subjective data have been gathered allowing editors to identify cities that prioritize the "happiness and well-being" of their residents.
That certainly sounds well-intentioned. And in fairness, diversity and tolerance are precisely the qualities that urban studies guru Richard Florida has told us are sought out by those coveted, mobile "creative classes" that all the world's most successful cities are able to attract and hold.
Still, I can't shake the sense of Vancouver just recently having vaulted up the high-school pecking order, now hanging at the front table in the cafeteria with the popular kids (Kyoto, Barcelona, Paris), and choosing to forget about all that time spent in the east stairwell with the fringe players, the nerds and wonks and industry towns (Calgary, Regina, Cincinnati).
Certainly some of this impression derives from Mr. Brûlé himself. The Winnipeg-born founder of the hugely successful 1990s fashion-and-design magazine Wallpaper*, Mr. Brûlé has made a career out of identifying what's in and out for readers. Monocle may not concern itself explicitly with fashion, but it responds to a similar impulse. A magazine about monied cosmopolitanism for monied cosmopolitans, Monocle is a globalist stylebook.
I was actually in Las Vegas on a food-related assignment when the Monocle rankings were published, which may have sharpened my response to the whole issue. I had something like an out-of-body experience reading about Vancouver while sitting in Mario Batali's B & B Ristorante at The Venetian, accordion music wheezing in from the "Grand Canal," and tucking into my lamb's brain francobolli . Notions of greenness and cultural diversity, not to mention authenticity, are pretty much scrambled to incoherence in such environments.
Of course, Las Vegas never ranks on any of these lists. Its 40 million visitors a year beat Venice (or Vancouver for that matter, by about 34 million), but that's just it. People visit. I'll bet even Richard Florida's "creative classes" visit. Or they do if they like to gamble, or eat, or maybe just like being reassured by street vendors that a prostitute can be delivered to their room in no more than 20 minutes. But they don't stay. And that leaves Las Vegas virtually off the grid of urban spaces on which monied cosmopolitans might choose to even semi-permanently invest their lifestyles.
Understanding a city's current place in such a contiguous and competitive grid is central to Richard Florida's writing. In his new book Who's Your City? , he speaks of a "spiky world" in which two distinct tiers of places may be found. The spikes are "globally oriented" cities in which the creative classes will choose to live (and which, presumably, would warrant coverage by Monocle). The rest are "local," anonymous urban and semi-urban regions where, among other things, real estate values will always underperform.
I find the two-tier model persuasive, since there's no arguing with the reality of a newly mobile class of people out there. I have numerous university friends who have never been back to the cities of their youth. But I wonder about this repudiation of the local, right at the same moment in history when other fashion cycles (in food, notably) have swung hard in the other direction.
Maybe jet-setting will never truly go out of style, and will even enjoy a surge in prestige as the cost rises with soaring fuel prices. But perhaps cities would fare better in the end, contributing more to the "happiness and well-being" of their residents, by completely ignoring these lists.
In the meantime, it seems relevant to Vancouver what other cities joined us near the top of Mr. Brûlé's listing, cities such as Copenhagen and Helsinki, Stockholm and Munich. Each may have its scientific and subjective reasons for being selected (even if those don't include cultural diversity and tolerance). But each, like Vancouver, also has a sense of freshness about it. Each is a city as yet unpolluted by the sort of mega-popularity that immediately puts the visitor in the midst of an uncool throng of 40 million. Each is a city ready to be fashionable: for Monocle readers, for the creative classes, for however long it lasts.
Timothy Taylor is a novelist and journalist based in Vancouver. His latest book is the novel Story House.
Credit: ttaylor@globeandmail.com

____________________________________________________________

A contrarian yuppie snob - moi - returns to her roots

Author: McLaren, Leah

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/contrarian-yuppie-snob-moi-returns-her-roots/docview/382727342/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: So I guess you've heard the news: McDonald's, that glorious bastion of all things disgusting and bad for you, has come out with an Angus burger. This is not to be confused with a burger named after a Scotsman, but one made from "one-third pound of juicy 100 per cent Angus beef," according to the sandwich's official website.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+contrarian+yuppie+snob+-+moi+-+returns+to+her+roots&amp;author=McLaren%2C+Leah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-14&amp;spage=L.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+contrarian+yuppie+snob+-+moi+-+returns+to+her+roots&amp;author=McLaren%2C+Leah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-14&amp;spage=L.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: So I guess you've heard the news: McDonald's, that glorious bastion of all things disgusting and bad for you, has come out with an Angus burger. This is not to be confused with a burger named after a Scotsman, but one made from "one-third pound of juicy 100 per cent Angus beef," according to the sandwich's official website.
My beef-inhaling sources tell me that the sandwich is "actually pretty good," which is, in my view, a great disappointment.
While the commercial for the Angus burger features two hungry male thirtysomething roomies, news of the launch put me in mind of the cranky old lady from the famed Burger King ad. In my mind's eye, I lifted the bun, scrunched up my nose and hollered, "Where's the crap?!"
I miss the days when bad things could just simply be bad. Why is it these days we must dress everything up as new, improved, upgraded or purified? I'm all for fresh white asparagus and imported Italian bathroom faucets, but sometimes you just want a crappy burger from a low-end burger joint. What ever happened to shameless crummy convenience?
When I was a kid growing up in small-town Ontario, everything was crap. It was the eighties, decade of designer shoulder pads, Gucci loafers and home espresso makers, but the style memo never made its way to my hometown. In Cobourg, everyone I knew spent those years eating Cheez Whiz, wearing jelly shoes, watching their parents get divorced and rocking out to Debbie Gibson and the MiniPops.
By the time I hit puberty, moved to the city with my (newly single) mother and encountered anything qualitatively good, I was accustomed to a diet - both figurative and literal - of such pure, unfiltered crap, I wouldn't have recognized a free-range organic Cornish hen if it landed on my face.
Eventually, of course, I felt the need to eradicate all traces of McCain curly fries and The Love Boat from my life. I became a snob. First a music snob. Then a book snob. Eventually a food, wine, shoe, car, garden, architecture, holiday-destination and houseware snob. I subscribed to the Utne Reader. I brought my own milk fluffer to brunch. I was insufferable! But that's what your 20s are for. How was I to know my own taste revelation would coincide with the turn of the century and the decrappification of the English-speaking world? First came Starbucks, then came H & M and the next thing I knew real-estate agents in Ajax, Ont., were sipping green-tea lattes in Stella McCartney frocks.
I did the only thing any self-respecting born-again contrarian aesthetic yuppie snob would do: I returned to my roots and learned to love crap all over again.
I went to Wal-Mart and bought plastic patio furniture. I served KD and frozen peas to dinner guests. I filled my iPod with Kylie, Britney and late Elton John.
All of these choices are hard to defend, especially if you happen to move in fashionable circles - and I'd like to make it extremely clear: I DO.
Just last week, for instance, I was at a cocktail party when I happened to find myself caught in the verbal crossfire in an exchange between a well-heeled vegetarian and an even weller-heeled omnivore.
After being gently chided for chowing down on bite-sized beef carpaccio, the omnivore declared that she was not so much a meat eater as a "goodetarian," meaning, in her words, "I only eat things that are good quality, good-tasting and good for me."
I felt a stabbing pang of envy, for I immediately wanted to become a goodetarian too. And no wonder. We live in an era where, more than ever before, our consumer choices are not just a reflection of, but actually seem to determine, who and what we are. Good stuff equals good character. Hence the Angus burger: Even the meat-eating masses long to be goodetarians.
But I will not be swayed by such consumer temptations. Thank god we are entering cottage season, a.k.a. the annual festival of crap. While many people like their summer getaways right out of the pages of Dwell, I prefer a distinctly more down-market approach to Canadian holiday-making. Give me a wagon-wheel coffee table, a can of Wild Cat and a radio tuned to the local headbanger station and my inner small-town hick kicks up her jelly shoes with joy.
Because here's the thing: Without the bad, there is no good. Cast the KD out of your life and pretty soon the beef carpaccio tastes about as special as Happy Meal. McDonald's might be trying to sell me an Angus burger, but that doesn't mean I have to buy one.
Let other people have their fancy white slipcovers and $50 chardonnays this summer. I'm quite happy as a born-again crap-lover.
Credit: lmclaren@globeandmail.com

A DHL founder asks $32-million (U.S.) for ranches

Author: Christina S.N. Lewis

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/dhl-founder-asks-32-million-u-s-ranches/docview/382793671/se-2?accountid=14656

The property was renamed Little Eva Plantation after the novel's main character, and the cabin of fictional slave Uncle Tom was said to have been on the site.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+DHL+founder+asks+%2432-million+%28U.S.%29+for+ranches&amp;author=Christina+S.N.+Lewis&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-13&amp;spage=G.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: William Armsted Robinson, a founder of DHL Worldwide Express delivery, is asking for $17-million (U.S.) for his horse ranch and $15-million for a fishing property, both in Idaho.
The reclusive businessman, one of California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger's big donors, breeds the exotic Lusitano show horse. The 940-acre horse ranch includes indoor and outdoor pens and arenas, a veterinary clinic, a breeding room and stables.
There's a 10,000-square-foot main house, a roughly four-acre man-made pond and an airstrip and hangar for a small aircraft. About 180 acres can be developed; the rest are under a conservation easement. The property borders a national forest. The 70-odd Lusitanos on the property aren't included in the offer.
About 30 kilometres north, Mr. Robinson's 600-acre fishing ranch has a four-bedroom house along the Falls River, plus a separate guest house. There's a four-stall barn and several kilometres of trails, and Yellowstone and Grand Teton national parks are close by.
Mr. Robinson, who sold his stake in the express-delivery company in 2003, bought the properties vacant in the 1990s and built all of the infrastructure and facilities, according to agent Roger Brink of Alta Realty.
Property may be linked
to Uncle Tom's cabin
In Louisiana, a property that's been linked to the 19th-century classic Uncle Tom's Cabin is on the market for $6-million.
The 2,000-acre property was part of a much larger cotton plantation owned in the mid-19th century by Robert McAlpin, whom local legend calls the inspiration for the novel's chief villain, Simon Legree. The property was renamed Little Eva Plantation after the novel's main character, and the cabin of fictional slave Uncle Tom was said to have been on the site.
State tourism and real estate websites both claim the connection to the book, which helped galvanize the antislavery movement leading to the American Civil War.
"The truth is much less definitive than the real estate declaration, but there may be some connection," says Joan Hedrick, a biographer of author Harriet Beecher Stowe and a history professor at Trinity College in Hartford, Conn.
There are seven ponds and three houses, including a roughly 6,000-square-foot main house. The property, in Natchitoches Parish about 450 kilometres northwest of New Orleans, includes 200 acres of pecan-tree farms, and other parts are leased to farmers. T-shirt mogul lists
Miami Beach lot
Seth Gerszberg, a founder of the Ecko fashion brand, has listed a nearly three-acre waterfront lot in Miami Beach for $13.9-million.
The unusually large, vacant parcel, on Pinetree Drive with about 300 feet on the water, is zoned for as many as three houses and has potential for deepwater dockage.
Mr. Gerszberg paid $9-million for the land in 2004. He plans to donate the net proceeds to Tikva, a home for abandoned Jewish children in Ukraine.
In 1993, Mr. Gerszberg and designer Marc Ecko helped found a hip-hop-inspired T-shirt company, Ecko Unlimited, whose expanded operations now include a full menswear line and a magazine.

Paint makers unveil some spring surprises

Author: Rand-Watkinson, Elizabeth

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/paint-makers-unveil-some-spring-surprises/docview/382786510/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: ICI offers five colour themes for 2008: "Growing respect" gives a nod to the environment with key descriptors such as "sustainable," "natural" and "botanical." "Ebb and flow" is "inspired by the molecular aspects of water" and features translucent and reflective blues. "Art form" leans toward the influence of the Bauhaus with a collection of warm lemons, mustards, and dusty greys. "Hidden beauty" goes sensual with reds, corals,...

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Paint+makers+unveil+some+spring+surprises&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-13&amp;spage=G.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Paint+makers+unveil+some+spring+surprises&amp;author=Rand-Watkinson%2C+Elizabeth&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-13&amp;spage=G.12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Vastly improved web sites make consumer choices a lot easier
For many homeowners, spring means getting into spruce-up mode, and that often includes painting something somewhere along the way. Luckily, today's paint lines have never been greater in breadth.
Para Paints, based in Brampton, Ont., is a good example. It just launched 2,000 new colours. While a few hundred of their tried and true classics and their Heritage line are still available, it's a brand new world at Para.
The new colours are categorized under the thematic headings "Retreat and unwind," "Escape to the tropics," "Weekend in the country," "Night on the town," "Continental getaway" and "Coming home," and feature cheeky names such as "Who needs the headache" and "Spiked heels."
The company's much-improved website, www.parapaints.com, offers consumers several different ways to explore colour. The "2008 trendsetting style" feature spotlights colours that are hot this year, interpreted as those inspired by nature and exotic locals. Two additional features, "Collections" and "Inspiration," make it easy for buyers to select a colour scheme, print it, and take it to the paint store with them.
At Benjamin Moore, they've been inspired by nature as well. Its 2008 colour trends flow from "Modern tranquility" where neutrals that are "gossamer" and "hushed" reign, to "Organic comfort" where the keywords are "earthen," "sunlit," and "fresh sprig," to "Pure opulence" where you'll find rich mineral and gem-like hues that make a dramatic style statement.
In terms of environmental stewardship, Benjamin Moore goes beyond the latest organic colour trends. This spring, it introduced "Aura," which it describes as "a 100-per-cent acrylic interior super premium paint" that uses water-borne colorants resulting in extremely low emissions of VOCs (volatile organic compounds) of 50 grams a litre. "Aura" is also a one-coat formulation that really does cover in one coat.
While a gallon of it costs slightly more than most other paints, in the long run, consumers will save money on product and labour when only one coat is required.
"Eco spec" is another Benjamin Moore paint that is low in VOC emissions because it is only tinted to pastel and mid-tones. See www.benjaminmoore.ca for more information.
At ICI Paints, the company that brings us Dulux, Glidden, and Colour Your World, you'll find inspiration as well. When developing new palettes, the company's colour and design experts analyze current trends in fashion, art, architecture and media. They also select a "colour of the year," producing a book entitled "ColourFutures" that you can download from the company website, www.icipaints.ca.
ICI offers five colour themes for 2008: "Growing respect" gives a nod to the environment with key descriptors such as "sustainable," "natural" and "botanical." "Ebb and flow" is "inspired by the molecular aspects of water" and features translucent and reflective blues. "Art form" leans toward the influence of the Bauhaus with a collection of warm lemons, mustards, and dusty greys. "Hidden beauty" goes sensual with reds, corals, sand and skin tones. And "Explorer" is, as the name would suggest, exciting and youthful, with exotic hues from every section of the colour wheel.
Sico takes a rather different view of what's hot for 2008. They see a trend toward extreme contrasts from "dark" and "punchy" to very pale. It also predicts a move away from simple neutrals to "full chroma, vibrant colours." This is illustrated on their website, www.sico.ca, where one featured interior is dark and dramatic with midnight and peppercorn hues, the next energetic and vital with hot yellows, sky blues and clover greens, and a third is all pale and peaceful mushrooms and champagne mousse.
All of these major paint suppliers offer tools to make colour selection easy. Some sell small tester pots or packets of paint to try out in your home - a great idea because natural and artificial light affects how colour "reads."
Some, such as Benjamin Moore, provide large-scale paint sheets that usually cost around $5 each and are so much better to work with than tiny paint chips. (Not all Benjamin Moore retailers carry the larger paint sheets so call around to find one that does.) And several have colour previewer features on their websites that allow you to see different interiors in various colour schemes.
For homeowners who want to pull together their homes' colour palette themselves, my advice is to troll manufacturer websites. Use the tools they provide and browse the "inspiration" pages. Keep in mind that with palettes that suggest five or six colours, not all are paint colours; some come from fabrics, furnishings and accessories.
Through this process you'll start to get a feel for what colour trend is speaking to you the loudest. That usually translates to a resonance on an emotional level, an important consideration because, like it or not, colour does affect us emotionally. With thousands of colours out there to wade through, I say make use of every tool you can find to streamline the process!
Additional sources
Other paint manufacturers whose websites offer information about the latest trends and tools:
* Sherwin-Williams at www.sherwin-williams.com
* Cloverdale Paint at www.cloverdalepaint.com
* Ralph Lauren at www.ralphlaurenhome.com
* Valspar at Lowes, www.valsparatlowes.ca.

____________________________________________________________

Hive draws buzz for novelty, not content

Author: J. Kelly Nestruck

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/hive-draws-buzz-novelty-not-content/docview/382729647/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Ultimately, it's the novelty of Hive2 that makes a great night out, rather than the content, most of which was forgettable. Adopt a Fringe festival-style devil-may-care attitude and you'll have a wonderful time. You can take stock with beer or wine in the atrium between shows and there's music and dancing afterward. With so many Canadian theatre artists in town for Magnetic North, Hive's clever concept will pollinate across the country.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hive+draws+buzz+for+novelty%2C+not+content&amp;author=J.+Kelly+Nestruck&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-13&amp;spage=R.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hive+draws+buzz+for+novelty%2C+not+content&amp;author=J.+Kelly+Nestruck&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-13&amp;spage=R.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: HIVE2
By various artists
At the Magnetic North festival
in Vancouver
***
At Hive2 , the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Eleven theatre companies from Vancouver and Victoria have taken over a warehouse space behind the Centre for Digital Media on Vancouver's Great Northern Way Campus and turned it into a carnival of short plays and performance art.
Upon arrival, ticket holders are given a yellow tasting menu listing the various shows on offer and instructions on how to become part of their audiences. You may have to don an orange armband, win a lottery, carry a sign that reads "The End of the World is Nigh" or fill out a job application to gain access. No show is longer than 20 minutes; none plays to more than 18 people at a time. One tiny, delicate piece plays to an audience of just one.
No matter how quick you are, you're going to miss out on something. I got to a slightly above-average eight shows - nine, if you count the hot-dog man, who insisted that he was a star act himself.
The first work I stumbled into was an untitled piece by Radix Theatre. After a brief interview with Barb from Human Resources, six of us were hired on at the Xidar Corporation, which seems to be an offshoot of Amazon.com, located in purgatory. We were trained on an otherworldly assembly line to ship soup, CDs, books, fruit and flowers to the recently deceased - and think about the consumer choices that make up an individual personality.
There was less voluntary participation in Theatre Conspiracy's Rendition , which aimed to give a taste of life in Guantanamo Bay. If you are wearing an armband, an army officer may grab you from Hive2's atrium and make you put on an orange jumpsuit. Blindfolded and dressed in the jumpsuit, I was led to a series of cages and holding facilities where I heard recordings of politicians rationalizing torture. A fellow audience members was held in a different cell and watched my frightened reactions on closed-circuit television.
The Only Animal's You and the Moon in a Very Small Room was even more intimate - performed for just me. Blindfolded and fitted with headphones again, I was led to the start of the show. Following the instructions played to me after I was allowed to open my eyes, I walked upstairs and into a little, white room. There, I watched the story of my unrequited love affair with the moon through a microscope and projected onto a picture book in front of me. A lovely children's story for adults, this multimedia show was full of moments of delight and jump-out-of-your-skin surprise. It will stay with me.
While Hive2 is mostly experiential and participatory, some of the shows are more traditionally conceived. Rumble Productions The End is Here! is a spoof of such monster movies as Cloverfield . Theatre Replacement's WeeTube project audience-selected viral videos (Little Richard talking about Jimi Hendrix, a rabbit on the attack) on the wall of a couple's apartment, while two actors (Maiko Bae Yamamoto and a special guest star, Hive2 producer Camyar Chai) acted out the comments left by YouTube users as if they were having a normal conversation. A funny reuse of Internet detritus, accompanied by free popcorn. This was a highlight.
Other playlets I saw: Neworldtheatre's Open House mocked Vancouver's pre-Olympics property madness as three real-estate agents named Derek Johnston (one I recognized as playwright Marcus Youssef) tried to sell the audience a patch of concrete for the reasonable asking price of $670,000. Theatre Skam's Dollhouse 2000 mocked earnest Fringe theatre, corporate sponsorship and itself.
Two years ago, the first Hive took place at an old Downtown Eastside funeral parlour and was a great local success. This second edition takes place in a less immediately intriguing location, where sound bleeds from one mini-venue to another and often takes away from what you are watching. Only Rumble, Radix and Neworldtheatre truly took advantage of the space they were playing in. It's the matching of the location to the show that makes site-specific work exciting.
Ultimately, it's the novelty of Hive2 that makes a great night out, rather than the content, most of which was forgettable. Adopt a Fringe festival-style devil-may-care attitude and you'll have a wonderful time. You can take stock with beer or wine in the atrium between shows and there's music and dancing afterward. With so many Canadian theatre artists in town for Magnetic North, Hive's clever concept will pollinate across the country.
The final (sold-out) performances are at 7 tonight and tomorrow, magneticnorthfestival.ca.

REAL ESTATE: HOW THE DEAL WAS (ALMOST) DONE

Author: Seguin, Rheal

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/real-estate-how-deal-was-almost-done/docview/382729230/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: In the fall of 2006, Public Works Minister Michael Fortier called for tenders on the construction of a building in Quebec City to house more than 700 federal civil servants in the same location. The original plan was to build a 200,000-square-foot development project in Quebec City's lower town in the newly revitalized Saint-Roch district. Kevlar's land-development arm owned a large parcel of land in the area, worth $1.5-million.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=REAL+ESTATE%3A+HOW+THE+DEAL+WAS+%28ALMOST%29+DONE&amp;author=Seguin%2C+Rheal&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-06-13&amp;spage=A.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The Quebec City real-estate deal that has focused renewed attention on Julie Couillard was a major federal government project worth an estimated $30-million. Recruiting Ms. Couillard to help turn the project in the Kevlar Group's favour appeared like a logical choice.
Ms. Couillard got her real-estate licence in Apri of 2007, and "hitched" it to Kevlar president André Bellerive's real-estate broker licence in an effort to promote the company's bid. The road would eventually lead to a relationship with Bernard Côté, a federal Public Works adviser, and then to Maxime Bernier, the federal industry minister at the time.
Kevlar president René Bellerive and co-president Philippe Morin had done business in Montreal and Quebec City for years. Since 2001, the company had invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the construction, renovation and acquisition of major properties in the two cities.
The company contributed money to the Parti Quebecois and the Quebec Liberal Party as well as the federal Liberal Party and a Conservative Party riding association in Montreal. But Kevlar was not well known in federal Conservative circles.
In the fall of 2006, Public Works Minister Michael Fortier called for tenders on the construction of a building in Quebec City to house more than 700 federal civil servants in the same location. The original plan was to build a 200,000-square-foot development project in Quebec City's lower town in the newly revitalized Saint-Roch district. Kevlar's land-development arm owned a large parcel of land in the area, worth $1.5-million. But city officials, including late mayor Andree Boucher and local business leaders, urged the federal government to consider a location outside the city centre in the Estimauville district. The city owned the land and was prepared to sell it at a cut-rate price of $5 a square foot for a total of $350,000 to whoever won the bid to build the federal project. Last winter, newly elected Mayor Regis Labeaume's chief of staff contacted Mr. Côté to ask whether there were any tenders presented for the city's preferred Estimauville site. According to the mayor's press secretary, Paul-Christian Nolin, Mr. Côté confirmed there were a few proposals, including one from Kevlar - which now had two projects on the table, one for the land it owned in the lower-town location and the other for the city's preferred site. Kevlar was taking no chances in its bid to obtain the development contract. A decision on the contract remains pending.
