Who knows Canada now? Not these three

Author: Richler, Noah

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/who-knows-canada-now-not-these-three/docview/382732821/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: [Mel Hurtig]'s indigestible screed is laced with infantile references to the National Post, the C. D. Howe Institute and other right-wing organizations as "Neanderthals," or people peddling "baloney" and "B.S.," and promises that if the reader is not already outraged, then to "wait until the last paragraphs in this chapter ..." This exhortation is made again and again, but oh, my, that is hard to do.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Who+knows+Canada+now%3F+Not+these+three&amp;author=Richler%2C+Noah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-24&amp;spage=D.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Who+knows+Canada+now%3F+Not+these+three&amp;author=Richler%2C+Noah&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-24&amp;spage=D.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WHO OWNS CANADA NOW
Old Money, New Money and the Future of Canadian Business
By Diane Francis
HarperCollins, 495 pages, $34.95
THE TRUTH ABOUT CANADA
Some Important, Some Astonishing, and Some Truly Appalling Things All Canadians Should Know About Our Country
By Mel Hurtig
McClelland & Stewart,
396 pages, $34.99
OH, OH, CANADA!
A Voice from the Conservative Resistance
By William D. Gairdner
BPS Books, 195 pages, $16.95
A few years ago, I stood on the corner of College and Spadina, in Toronto, with writer Barry Callaghan. We'd been discussing a prior incarnation of the city in which the shadow of the Family Compact still asserted itself in a staid, Presbyterian class arrangement - the Irish, Jews and blacks who used to animate the local jazz clubs on the bottom and, at the top, a handful of families controlling the banks, retail and factories. Callaghan derided what he called the city's "Massey Culture" and wondered why its new polyethnic nature was not yet reflected on Bay Street.
"If you're a businessman," he said, "the way you tell your story is, you take over things, so why are the boards of directors of the banks still all run by the same people? Why aren't there Italians on those boards, why aren't there Portuguese?"
Today, many of Canada's new business paragons are Italian- and Portuguese-, but also South Asian-, Iranian- and Chinese-Canadians, though they do not yet control the boards. (In Toronto, old Canada persists in two places: in the boardrooms, and also in the numbers of the city's homeless, predominantly white.) Although the new financial order has no decent novelist as witness yet, it has had its documentarians. Peter Newman, of course, was one. Diane Francis, editor of the Financial Post before she became a National Post columnist, is another.
In Who Owns Canada Now , Francis has updated her 1986 assessment of Canadian business, Controlling Interest: Who Owns Canada? The new book offers an appropriately changed picture from the pinstriped, risk-averse world that Canada was, in which the Free Trade Agreement (FTA) did not yet exist, the dollar was at par without the punishing benefit of the Athabasca tar sands, and its major players were likely to convene at the Vancouver Club or Winston's, in Toronto, and keep the Jewish, Asian and other upstarts at the door.
The substance of the book lies in the fleeting portraits Francis provides of 75 business tycoons, operating from coast to coast (and sometimes offshore), who have excelled in various sectors of the economy: real estate, banking, agribusiness, mining, high technology, entertainment etc. The chosen are mostly men, of course (this is the truth she is plumbing here), and deferring to our present "off-the-island" sensibility, Francis lists 16 of the 35 families from the original book that no longer cut it: the Molsons, the Eatons, the Steinbergs, the Websters, Edward and Peter Bronfman, Conrad Black.
It is no mystery why Winston's long ago shut its doors. As tends to be true of societies where inherited position counts for too much, a lot of these former players were just too stupid to keep pace with the new entrepreneurs, mostly self-made, at their heels. "Handing down inheritances is like putting on the Olympic team the children of all the former gold medalists," Francis says, paraphrasing Warren Buffet. "It makes no sense."
Who Owns Canada Now? is a formulaic, albeit unpretentious book that will please the 75 in it and the hoi polloi who think there may be guidance in the shallow axioms Francis's subjects offer. These magnates profess to their scribbling acolyte, not about to endanger her own position, that it's not the money that matters; they love giving it away, built their fortunes by working hard, averting debt and knowing what their talent was and pursuing it.
None of these tycoons made their fortune by screwing their rivals, suppressing a few locals, hiring Russian thugs, making friends with a Domi or handing a few hundred thousand dollars in a paper bag to someone in government. No, here the order for several malls or one in Israel is casually made because a mayor, blithely unaware of legal tenders, says, "I want you to do a shopping centre," pats his old chum on the back and away we go. Although one B.C. mining magnate admits to having taken out bank loans to buy his own stock, no one comes close to saying, "I made my fortune because I build crap housing that looks great on first inspection," "I make sure to keep plenty of councillors on my party list," or, "I hate my children, which is why I give all my money away."
A different book, you say? Well, a more enquiring one, certainly. As it is, Francis's book is a bestseller, so she need not worry if such harmless chronicling is all she is
capable of, though I suspect an account of what she really knows about Canadian business would be fascinating. Instead, she offers a de rigueur homily to the multicultural nature of our society, suggests that further economic integration with the United States is the sine qua non for our future prosperity, and blames a tax regime that is onerous on corporations.
If our taxes are high, it is because we offer safety nets and social programs that many other countries envy, or used to envy, and it is a lament for this version of Canadian society that arch-nationalist Mel Hurtig offers in The Truth About Canada . According to Hurtig, Canada has become a haven of easily made corporate profits, where the gap between the rich making ever more money at an obscenely climbing rate while the poor become even more so, continues to widen as our schools and health systems deteriorate and extraordinary numbers of our children live in poverty.
It is possible for the patient reader to glean from this unstylish and exasperating text some of this information, as well as more bad news about the media, energy and other sectors of Canadian life in which Hurtig sees no hope. This is not so much a book as a spewing of figures from Statistics Canada, the UN and various newspaper and magazine reports.
I offer up, at random, one of about 1,500 paragraphs, one after another, identical in style:
"Where to begin? Let's start with GDP per capita. In the 17 years before the FTA [Free Trade Agreement], 1972 to 1988, GDP per capita increased by $9,365. During the first 17 years of the FTA, 1989 to 2005, the per-capita increase fell only to $8,354. In the 17 years before the FTA, Canada's overall GDP increased at an annual rate of over 3.66 per cent. During the first 17 years of the FTA, it increased at an annual rate of only 2.63 per cent. Quite a difference!"
Hurtig's indigestible screed is laced with infantile references to the National Post, the C. D. Howe Institute and other right-wing organizations as "Neanderthals," or people peddling "baloney" and "B.S.," and promises that if the reader is not already outraged, then to "wait until the last paragraphs in this chapter ..." This exhortation is made again and again, but oh, my, that is hard to do. Hurtig offers no real analysis, and no real effort at readability - no characters, for instance, who might have animated his tedious rant. What information is here would have been infinitely more interesting, and more easily retained, in the graphs and tables in which most of it, I suspect, originated. The Truth About Canada is a botched opportunity to convey facts that, in some more communicative form, might have undermined Diane Francis's fawning world of platitudinous multi-millionaires.
William D. Gairdner, the libertarian author of Oh, Oh Canada! , is, presumably, one of Hurtig's "Neanderthals." Gairdner argues for the (traditional) family, against homosexuality, abortion and atheism and - as did Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, after he repatriated the forlorn English navy squad Iran had seized from the Straits of Hormuz - Gairdner pities a nation that sends women such as Nichola Goddard to fight its wars. Of this country, "filled with strong and vital men," he asks: "Why has every Canadian man worth his name felt an inner twinge of conscience over her death?" Oh, please!
Gairdner's's tone is glib and trite, and if his essays had any real intellectual contribution to make (the author being fond of pat lessons in philosophy), they would not be just irritating. They are hard to take seriously except that, I suppose, brethren such as Charles McVety, president of the Canada Family Action Coalition, are having an impact on our current government.
This interesting country, with its singular history, achievements and challenges, will find more astute witnesses.
Noah Richler's This is My Country, What's Yours? A Literary Atlas of Canada won the 2007 B.C. Award for Canadian non-fiction. He is currently at work on a book about the effects of globalization on rural communities.

Builder markets compact units

Author: Yu, Sydnia

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Builder+markets+compact+units&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=G.16&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Nouvelle
LOCATION: Mississauga
BUILDER/DEVELOPER: Pemberton Group
SIZE: 600 to 945 square feet
PRICE: $194,900 to $284,900
SALES CENTRE: 2475 Eglinton Ave. West at Erin Mills Parkway. Open Monday to Thursday, noon to 7 p.m.; Friday to Sunday, noon to 6 p.m.
CONTACT: (905) 603-6300 or www.pembertongroup.com
Pemberton Group wants to tap into the demand for smaller accommodations in the Erin Mills community of Mississauga. Earlier this month, it launched an 18-storey building called Nouvelle in the largely low-rise neighbourhood.
The fourth and last tower in the master-planned community called Papillon Place, Nouvelle will be linked to the third tower, which is now under construction. The first two buildings are already occupied.
Located off Eglinton Avenue, east of Winston Churchill Boulevard, the site is across the street from several retail outlets and restaurants, as well as the Erin Mills Town Centre. In the other direction are local parks and, in the distance, Lake Ontario. Other nearby amenities include schools, the Credit Valley Hospital and highways 403 and 407.
Residents of the 196-unit Nouvelle will have services of a 24-hour concierge, as well as recreational amenities that are located in a new two-storey building at the centre of the complex. The 13,000-square-foot centre includes a fully equipped gym, aerobics room, indoor pool, hot tub and a virtual golf theatre. The new tower, as with the other, will have underground access to the facility.
Also available are a boardroom, two party rooms with kitchens and bars, and a large lounge with several billiard tables, card tables and multiple walkouts to a rooftop terrace and barbecue area.
As in the previous phase, there will be one- and two-bedroom layouts with combined living and dining rooms, open kitchens with breakfast bars and, in some cases, media rooms. Each unit will have its own balcony off the principal room.
Larger suites will feature traditional eat-in kitchens and master bedrooms with walk-in closets and ensuite bathrooms.
Reintroduced in this phase is an 800-square foot model with two bedrooms and two bathrooms. It was first offered in the first phase.
Flooring options include laminate, 40-ounce carpeting and imported porcelain or ceramic tile. Kitchens will include granite countertops and stainless-steel appliances. Stacked laundry machines are also part of the package.
Buyers will get a parking space and locker. The monthly maintenance fee will be 42 cents a square foot, and hydro will be individually metered.
Move-ins are expected to start in November, 2010.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

Before the flood, make sure your home is properly insured

Author: Cullen, Terri

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/before-flood-make-sure-your-home-is-properly/docview/382737958/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Flood insurance is relatively inexpensive for people who don't live in high-risk areas. Average premiums run about $600 a year, though homeowners in high-risk areas can pay as much as $5,400 a year. Renters in low-risk areas can protect their belongings for about $200 a year, or $2,200 for high-risk zones. [Gerry] and I have decided it's worth our peace of mind to buy flood insurance - at an additional cost of $348 a year.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Before+the+flood%2C+make+sure+your+home+is+properly+insured&amp;author=Cullen%2C+Terri&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=G.23&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Before+the+flood%2C+make+sure+your+home+is+properly+insured&amp;author=Cullen%2C+Terri&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=G.23&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Many homeowners turn their thoughts to spring cleaning this time of year. But my thoughts are usually drawn toward making sure the contents of our home remain safe and protected. That's because our homeowners insurance policy is up for renewal every June.
The renewal process is usually pretty painless: Check to see whether we need to update our policy to reflect any upgrades or new purchases. If no changes are needed, I then check the rate quote by doing some comparison shopping on the Web. (www.kanetix.ca and www.insurancehotline.com are two such sites.) Once satisfied that our current insurer is still offering the best deal, I typically pay our annual premium in full online and print out my payment confirmation. Generally, it takes no more than 20 minutes.
But this year, my policy renewal required a bit more attention to satisfy me that our home and its contents are being properly protected. For the past five years, my husband, Gerry, and I have been gradually making improvements to our home that have added to its value - and our enjoyment - and I wanted to make sure that our coverage has increased sufficiently to protect us in the event of a disaster.
Plus, a wild card was thrown into the mix: The U.S. government recently updated the flood-zone maps for our area for the first time in nearly 20 years. Though our home is still not designated as being in a flood zone, we're now within 16 kilometres of one.
Gerry and I haven't added any new rooms or increased our home's square footage, but we have made material improvements in our kitchen and family room that would increase the cost of rebuilding.
This year, we're planning to upgrade our siding and windows with top-quality energy-efficient replacements. We'll need to update our home's replacement-cost coverage limit to reflect the improvements.
One way to estimate a home's replacement cost is to get an estimate from a local contractor; a formal estimate of your home's replacement cost will cost you between $100 and $250 (U.S.).
Steve, a family friend who's also a building contractor, gave us a free estimate. He suggested we raise the replacement-cost coverage of our home (the building itself, not its contents) to $250,000 from $189,000. The increase in coverage boosted our premium to $800 from $750.
Gerry and I insure our home for replacement cost, which means our policy pays to repair or replace damage to our home with materials of similar quality. What our current policy doesn't cover is "demand surge," or post-catastrophe inflation. Demand surge often occurs after large disasters, such as wind damage or flood, strike a wide area. When many homeowners and businesses are in need of rebuilding after a disaster, material and labour costs can skyrocket.
Our insurer does offer "extended replacement cost" coverage, which will cover an additional 20 per cent of the cost of rebuilding the home over our policy limits. The cost: an additional $50. (That raises our annual premium to a total of $850.) After checking over our limits on liability insurance and replacement costs for the contents of our home, I was satisfied we were adequately insured - except in the event of a flood.
Flood insurance is relatively inexpensive for people who don't live in high-risk areas. Average premiums run about $600 a year, though homeowners in high-risk areas can pay as much as $5,400 a year. Renters in low-risk areas can protect their belongings for about $200 a year, or $2,200 for high-risk zones. Gerry and I have decided it's worth our peace of mind to buy flood insurance - at an additional cost of $348 a year. We already had minor water damage in our home after a severe storm the year we bought the home. With the threat of flood increasing, it's foolish to keep pressing our luck.
© 2008 Dow Jones & Co. Inc.
Credit: Wall Street Journal

SOCIAL STUDIES

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/social-studies/docview/382737915/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Some employers claim meaningful work as being in their gift [of employment]. Maybe you've heard your chief executive talk of 'commitment,' 'discretionary effort,' 'buy-in' and the 'fulfilment of potential' - it makes 'meaning' seem only a short jump away. But even the best-led and most well-intentioned employers cannot create meaning for people. They can treat people well, but that's no guarantee of meaning.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=SOCIAL+STUDIES&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=SOCIAL+STUDIES&amp;author=&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A DAILY MISCELLANY OF INFORMATION BY MICHAEL KESTERTON
CARBON CAPTURE
Parts of the Australian seabed will be offered for tender for carbon capture and storage ventures as early as December, The Australian newspaper reports. Resources Minister Martin Ferguson said he would complete the world's first legislative framework for carbon sequestration within months, clearing the way for greenhouse gases collected from coal-fired power stations to be injected through the seabed and captured in geological formations. The minister said calling for tenders this year would encourage investment and commercialization of the technology, which he described as a safe way to allow continued carbon-based power generation.
CHARISMATIC BOSS? BEWARE
"The idea of charisma may be stronger than its actual effects," Carlin Flora writes in Psychology Today. "Rakesh Khurana, associate professor of organizational behaviour at Harvard Business School, finds that when American companies look for new leaders, they seek charisma above all other qualities - but the bottom-line results of this hiring practice are often disappointing, even disastrous. Under uncertain market conditions, charismatic CEOs are good for one thing: They temporarily boost their company's stock prices. But the improvement is usually short-lived. That's because charisma may have more to do with a person's image than with his or her innate abilities."
MARRIAGE FRESHMAN
After six months of marriage, "I seem to be in danger of coming around to the idea that perhaps not all women are such bad chaps," Martin Deeson writes in the British edition of GQ magazine. Some of his hard-won knowledge about living with women:
* Get them their own television.
* Say yes to everything.
* When you say no, make sure your wife is in the other room.
* Get a hobby. It's cheaper than a mistress.
* Get married on the first of the month so it's easy to remember your anniversary.
SQUATTER SCAMS
Across the United States, squatting is on the rise as house foreclosures surge, eviction notices mount and homes sit unsold for months, Reuters reports. In some regions, squatting is taking on new twists that include real-estate scams in which thieves "rent out" abandoned homes they don't own. Others involve "professional squatters" who move from one abandoned home to another posing as tenants and seeking cash from banks as a condition to leave the premises - known by real-estate brokers as "cash for key."
GHOST-BIKE MEMORIALS
In Chicago, a bicycle spray-painted white has been chained to a streetlight pole where a bicyclist was struck and killed by a car last month. It joins at least eight other such monuments in the city, the Chicago Tribune reports. Some notes about "ghost bikes" and their growing appearances:
* The concept originated in St. Louis in 2002, when Patrick Van Der Tuin, an employee at a bike shop, witnessed a car swerve into a bike lane and severely injure a young woman. In response, he took a junk bike, smashed it with a sledgehammer, spray-painted it white and installed it at the scene of the crash. "I wanted it to be as shocking as possible," he said.
* Today, ghost bikes are found in major cities throughout North America, according to ghostbike.org. They have also appeared elsewhere in the world.
* "The hope is that by placing visual reminders, it will cause people to stop and think, 'Oh, a cyclist got hit here,' " Morgan Ress, a member of the local advocacy group Bike Pittsburgh, told the Pittsburgh Tribune-Review last year.
WORLD O' TASTE BUDS
Recent notes:
* "Why is it that after I eat a salad, I want something sweet - in particular, chocolate?" asks a reader of Women's Health magazine. Columnist Lisa Drayer replies that this craving could be habit, or it "could be a phenomenon we in the biz call 'taste-specific satiety.' You experience the highest flavour sensation of a certain food in the first few bites; after that, you taste it less intensely, and that can trigger cravings for a drastically new flavour."
* The appearance of a drink can affect how happy we are with it: Our brains make a pleasant association between the colours of ripening fruit and increased sugar content, Roger Highfield writes in The Daily Telegraph. "Such colours, particularly bright reds, are especially powerful visual cues," says British psychologist Charles Spence. "When incorporated into a drink, they can dramatically change the perceived flavour, as well as increasing the perceived sweetness by as much as 12 per cent." French researchers tested this by using an odourless dye to colour white wine red. The wine tasters who tried the result used typical red-wine descriptors, suggesting that its colour played a significant role in how they thought of it.
THOUGHT DU JOUR
"Some employers claim meaningful work as being in their gift [of employment]. Maybe you've heard your chief executive talk of 'commitment,' 'discretionary effort,' 'buy-in' and the 'fulfilment of potential' - it makes 'meaning' seem only a short jump away. But even the best-led and most well-intentioned employers cannot create meaning for people. They can treat people well, but that's no guarantee of meaning. Meaning is something workers find or don't find on their own."
- Stephen Overell, author of
Inwardness: The Rise of Meaningful Work

This detached, two-storey residence in North York has all the essentials needed by first-time buyers or locals looking to move into a larger home from neighbouring townhouses, according to agent Bill Thom.

From their house to the White House

Author: Christina S.N. Lewis

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/their-house-white/docview/382734904/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "They've made very wise real estate investments," says Gregory Hague of Hague Partners, an Arizona real estate firm that wasn't involved in the McCain purchases. With their multiple residences and seven children (three from Mr. McCain's first marriage), Ms. McCain paid $273,000 for household help in 2007, according to their recently released tax returns.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=From+their+house+to+the+White+House&amp;author=Christina+S.N.+Lewis&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=H.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=From+their+house+to+the+White+House&amp;author=Christina+S.N.+Lewis&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=H.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: McCain, Clinton are property millionaires; Obama also profited
Like millions of Americans, the three presidential candidates rode the real estate wave. But for them there's been no hard landing, and well-timed home purchases in prime neighbourhoods have left two of them - senators John McCain and Hillary Clinton - with millions in real estate gains.
The McCain family owns at least seven properties, including a spread in rural Arizona. In the past four years, the Republican's wealthy wife, Cindy, has spent roughly $11-million (U.S.) on real estate, buying three condos in Phoenix and two in California, across the bay from San Diego.
Ms. Clinton and former president Bill Clinton likely own the most expensive property among the three candidates: a stately home in the Observatory Circle neighbourhood of Washington that cost $2.85-million in 2001 and now is worth about $5-million. (Value estimates are based on an averaging of property-valuation websites, local broker assessments and real estate listings and records; the candidates' campaigns were contacted about the findings.)
But the Clintons also once owned the most modest property, their first home together: a tiny house in Fayetteville, Ark., that cost $20,500 in 1975. It has since been converted into a Clinton museum.
Meanwhile, Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, paid $1.65-million for their Chicago house in 2005 - the rough market peak - and have seen its value stagnate, if not decline slightly. The purchase came after the success of Mr. Obama's best-selling memoir, Dreams From My Father . That same year, the couple sold their Chicago condo for $415,000 - $137,500 more than they paid for it in 1993.
But the Obama campaign has faced questions about whether the house purchase was subsidized by Chicago developer Antoin "Tony" Rezko.
Mr. Obama bought the house for 15 per cent less than its $1.95-million asking price - equal to the price the sellers had paid for it in 2000, when neighbourhood values were lower. On the same day as his purchase, Mr. Rezko paid the full $625,000 asking price for an adjacent lot being sold by the same owners - 51 per cent more than the sellers had paid for the vacant land in 2000.
Some have asked whether the price paid by Mr. Rezko for the vacant land made the owners willing to sell Mr. Obama the house for less than its fair market value. The sellers declined to speak to a reporter and Mr. Rezko's lawyer didn't return a call.
Mr. Obama has categorically denied he received any discount from the fair market value. The Obama campaign says he was the home's highest bidder and that the sellers required the purchases to close on the same day. Real estate records indicate the house purchase price was roughly consistent with sales of similar-sized homes in the area around that time. (Mr. Obama later also purchased a narrow strip of the vacant land from Mr. Rezko, for roughly $100,000.)
The McCain homes all are owned by Ms. McCain, heir to a beer-distributor fortune, or by trusts for her benefit. The McCains bought luxury properties in the 1980s and 1990s and have seen dramatic gains from the real estate boom. In 2006, the family sold their long-time Phoenix house for $3.2-million, nearly 29 times what it cost 20 years earlier, when Ms. McCain bought it from her father.
Their Arizona getaway is along a creek - rare in the desert - and is worth $4-million, nearly four times what it cost to assemble the three parcels in the 1990s.
"They've made very wise real estate investments," says Gregory Hague of Hague Partners, an Arizona real estate firm that wasn't involved in the McCain purchases. With their multiple residences and seven children (three from Mr. McCain's first marriage), Ms. McCain paid $273,000 for household help in 2007, according to their recently released tax returns.
The Clintons also have created wealth through property. Near the end of Mr. Clinton's presidency, they bought two expensive homes, the Washington house and one in Chappaqua, N.Y., a wealthy suburb north of New York. That has resulted in big paper gains, though the values have fallen recently.
In the 1970s and early 1980s, the couple owned a series of relatively modest houses in that state but didn't own a home at all during Mr. Clinton's eight years as president.
© 2008 Dow Jones & Co. Inc.

BARACK OBAMA
HOUSE IN CHICAGO

JOHN MCCAIN

GETAWAY IN SEDONA, ARIZ.

Due diligence: Sedona's climate, recreational options and new-age vibe sent property prices tripling during the boom. But prices have dropped 20 per cent or more in the past 18 months, brokers say, which means the McCain property, worth perhaps $5-million at the peak, might now fetch $4-million.
CONDO IN CORONADO, CALIF.
What: A three-bedroom, eighth-floor, ocean-view condo of 1,750 square feet, plus a 2,250-square-foot, three-bedroom bay-view apartment six floors below.
Amenities: Coronado Shores is next to Hotel Del Coronado. The 10-building complex has four pools, eight tennis courts and sits on the beach.
Purchase price/dates: Eighth-floor unit, $2.6-million in September, 2004; second-floor unit, $2.1-million in February, 2008.
Annual property taxes: About $41,000 for both units.
Tour: Ms. McCain bought the first apartment as a vacation home. The newly purchased apartment has four bedrooms and was listed at $2.875-million, but Ms. McCain paid $2.1-million.
Due diligence: Prices haven't tumbled in Coronado Shores, a desirable spot across the bay from San Diego. But Ms. McCain paid about $1,500 a square foot for her first apartment, a record for that type of unit, and the market still has not quite caught up.
*****
HILLARY CLINTON
HOUSE IN CHAPPAQUA, N.Y
What: The couple's main residence, a five-bedroom, white Dutch colonial revival house dating to 1889 on a little over one acre. Vetted by the U.S. Secret Service, the home is at the end of a cul-de-sac in this prosperous northern suburb of New York City, in Westchester County.
Purchase price/date: $1.7-million (U.S.) in December, 1999.
Annual property taxes: About $47,000.
Tour: Ms. Clinton needed to establish a home in New York to run for the Senate. The couple paid just over the $1.695-million asking price, making a $350,000 down payment and using a bank loan of $1.35-million secured by Terry McAuliffe, former head of the Democratic National Committee and current chairman of Ms. Clinton's campaign. As the last president to receive lifetime Secret Service protection, Mr. Clinton created live-in quarters for his security detail. The couple also added an octagonal breakfast-room extension. While on the campaign trail it hasn't been unusual for Ms. Clinton to fly to Chappaqua to spend the night in her own bed, campaign reporters say.
Due diligence: The home's current value is about $2.6-million, say brokers and property-valuation sites, some 50 per cent more than the Clintons paid for it.
CLINTON PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY PENTHOUSE
What: A 2,000-square-foot, modernist-style apartment atop the William J. Clinton Presidential Center in Little Rock, Ark. The apartment is an amenity for the Clintons in the 152,000-square-foot building, which opened in October, 2004.
Tour: A private apartment is a common feature of presidential libraries, but this glass box drew attention because of its unusual design. Its style is also in stark contrast to the Clintons' other homes.
HOUSE IN WASHINGTON, D.C.
What: A six-bedroom, single-family home of 5,150 square feet built in 1951. Trees hide the property from the street.
Purchase price/date: $2.85-million in 2001.
Annual property taxes: $43,612.
Tour: The large home is on a quiet, one-block street off Observatory Circle, a residential neighbourhood in northwest Washington near the vice-president's house.
Due diligence: . Brokers and property-valuation sites say this house is worth about $5-million, roughly equal to its current assessed value. In 2006, its assessed value more than doubled, but for 2009, the city is proposing to trim the assessment by 1 per cent.

This city suffers from too much noise

Author: Cole, Stephen

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/this-city-suffers-too-much-noise/docview/382732359/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: [Carol], however, is a mystery, and [Caroline Cave] wisely plays the part tentatively, as if she's working through a maze. At one point, Carol takes [Peter] to the roof of his apartment building and demands that he step onto the ledge. She wants him to feel alive, for his next step to mean something. "I used to love this city," she says, baffled. "Now it's just dinner parties and avoiding questions about children."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=This+city+suffers+from+too+much+noise&amp;author=Cole%2C+Stephen&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=R.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=This+city+suffers+from+too+much+noise&amp;author=Cole%2C+Stephen&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-23&amp;spage=R.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: This Beautiful City
Written and directed
by Ed Gass-Donnelly
Starring Kristin Booth,
Caroline Cave, Stuart Hughes, Noam Jenkins and Aaron Poole
Classification: 18A
**
This feature debut from playwright Ed Gass-Donnelly is a scathing though not unfeeling depiction of West Queen West, the slowly gentrifying Toronto neighbourhood that real-estate agents would generously describe as an "artist community."
Yuppies Harry and Carol live here in an antiseptic, modern condo. As the film opens, they're hosting a dinner party. Harry makes a few funny remarks at his wife's expense. Later, she sneaks out on their balcony and feels strangely, momentarily exalted. Succumbing to a high, religious mood, Carol steps off the ledge and plummets 60 feet, ruining both the evening and her Holt Renfrew ensemble.
She is discovered and saved by an off-duty detective, Peter. The policeman didn't just happen by; he is searching the area for his hooker-drug-addict daughter. Peter eventually becomes involved with Carol. Harry, meanwhile, befriends a local prostitute, introducing her to restaurants and imported wines in an
attempt to save her from
herself.
Both are obviously risky adventures. And so the unhappy inhabitants of West Queen West thrash about like dangerously severed power wires, causing misfortune whenever they snake
together.
This Beautiful City is the work of an immature but not untalented director. Too many scenes are cranked up to 11. A junkie couple, Pretty (Kristin Booth) and her psychotic boyfriend, Johnny (Aaron Poole), are either sky high or strung out. There isn't a light moment in the film. Fateful coincidences abound. Nearly everyone in the ensemble winds up dead.
And yet the film contains one very good performance and one brilliant scene. Caroline Cave ( The L Word ) brings a startled anger to the role of Carol. She is the only character here that Gass-Donnelly hasn't made his mind up about. Carol's husband (Noam Jenkins) is a jerk. Peter (Stuart Hughes), the cop who saved her, is a burnout - empathetic, but in the end, useless.
Carol, however, is a mystery, and Cave wisely plays the part tentatively, as if she's working through a maze. At one point, Carol takes Peter to the roof of his apartment building and demands that he step onto the ledge. She wants him to feel alive, for his next step to mean something. "I used to love this city," she says, baffled. "Now it's just dinner parties and avoiding questions about children."
Later, they're in bed. Peter, for once, is bold, asking Carol to stand atop him as if she's on a ledge. She drops her bed-sheet robe, begins crying. But then a car horn from the street - the beautiful, dangerous city - startles her, and she steps back from commitment.
The scene works, where so much of This Beautiful City fails, because for once the filmmaker allows the viewer to participate in creating the scene. For once, no one is shouting. The meaning isn't clear. Like Carol, we have to put together what's happening. There is drama here. Alas, too much of the rest of the film is bombast and street noise.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

Moving mountains in China

Author: McLeod, Lori

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/moving-mountains-china/docview/382742087/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The mountain's sole hotel was located just far enough from the base that it couldn't be reached on skis, and its floor was speckled with dead bugs. Things weren't much better on the slopes, where snow conditions were patchy and the grooming machine was held together with duct tape.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Moving+mountains+in+China&amp;author=McLeod%2C+Lori&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-22&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Moving+mountains+in+China&amp;author=McLeod%2C+Lori&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-22&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Developer is forging a new business model while transforming ski hills into North American-style resorts
When Graham Kwan first laid eyes on the Sun Mountain Yabuli ski resort in northeast China, his impression was that it was "an absolute pig."
The mountain's sole hotel was located just far enough from the base that it couldn't be reached on skis, and its floor was speckled with dead bugs. Things weren't much better on the slopes, where snow conditions were patchy and the grooming machine was held together with duct tape.
But what the property did have was turnaround potential, exactly what Mr. Kwan, a former executive at Vancouver-based ski resort developer Intrawest Corp., was looking for.
His new venture, Melco China Resorts , bought Yabuli, along with four other fixer-upper ski hills in northeast China.
The firm, which will tap the capital markets with a listing on the TSX Venture Exchange next week, is now transforming the properties into North American-style ski resorts using a model similar to Intrawest's Whistler-Blackcomb in British Columbia and Mont Tremblant in Quebec.
It's a bet on the appetite of China's growing middle and upper classes, and a task Mr. Kwan acknowledges won't be easy.
"Most of the resorts are terrible. They have terrible old lifts, not very good snow making, safety is an issue, there's no accommodation and the food is marginal. That's pretty typical," he said.
In addition to winning over Chinese skiers, the handful of developers trying to "Westernize" the industry there face hurdles including government restrictions and a shortage of natural snow, said Tom Tillotson, an American who heads travel company China Ski Tours LLC.
"This model has yet to be tried in China. It has two main structural challenges; namely, providing top-notch skiing, and the Chinese government's concerns about real estate development, including sales to foreigners," Mr. Tillotson said.
Despite these challenges, Melco China sees an opportunity in the growing disposable income of many Chinese and their huge appetite for new experiences, said Lawrence Ho, co-chairman and chief executive of Hong Kong-based conglomerate Melco International Development Ltd., which owns a 45-per-cent stake in Melco China.
"There are plenty of beautiful places in China for scenic tours and golf, but for winter activities, there is not that much for the Chinese to do," said Mr. Ho, who grew up in Canada and is the son of Macau gambling tycoon Stanley Ho.
"Our strategy is to keep people there as long as possible, whether it's in a casino or on the ski slopes," Mr. Ho said in an interview from Hong Kong.
Last year, local travel in China soared to 1.6 billion vacation trips, a 123-per-cent increase from the year before, according to the Pacific Asia Travel Association (PATA). However, most of that travel involved visits to friends and relatives, and, as far as locals are concerned, skiing isn't even on the map in China, said Oliver Martin, associate director of PATA's The Strategic Intelligence Centre, based in Bangkok.
Melco China's goal is to win a piece of the domestic travel pie by creating decent places for the Chinese to ski relatively close to home.
It expects its bread and butter to be real estate development around the mountain bases, a model employed with great success by Mr. Kwan's former employer and a business Melco China believes could end up supplying the bulk of its revenues.
With the exception of Star Mountain, a learn-to-ski facility near Beijing, each of the company's four other ski hills will include residential development. This will range from hotel condos at Adventure Mountain Changchun, which is geared to younger visitors, to luxury homes at the members-only Lotus Mountain Club.
Under Melco China's current model, it can build 6,300 residential units across its business, but that could rise as high as 7,500 units, Mr. Kwan said.
At Yabuli, which is the most developed of its properties, Melco China is in the process of launching presales of its first 50 to 100 vacation homes. A typical unit will be a 3,000-square-foot ski-in home that will sell for around $750,000.
By year's end, Yabuli will also have numerous hotels, shops and restaurants, a spa and a conference centre.
Melco China expects the resorts to be popular year-round destinations for local business people looking to ski in winter and escape city heat and smog in summer, said Ermanno Pascutto, a lawyer and board member who helped put the company together and a former executive director of both the Ontario and Hong Kong securities commissions.
Mr. Pascutto said it's uncertain whether foreigners, himself included, will be allowed to buy homes at Melco China's resorts.
However, he says the company's problem probably won't be moving the units, which he expects will sell out very quickly. Instead, the challenge will be filling them with people who want to spend time at the resorts instead of those who want to buy numerous properties as investments, he said.

Winnipeg emerges from winter dormancy

Author: Taylor, G A

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/winnipeg-emerges-winter-dormancy/docview/382748995/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We remain cautiously optimistic that the market will continue to keep vacancy rates at or near present levels for the balance of the year," a Cushman report states. "Going forward, demand will depend largely upon growth in public sector office requirements and the financial services sector."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Winnipeg+emerges+from+winter+dormancy&amp;author=Taylor%2C+G+A&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-20&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Winnipeg+emerges+from+winter+dormancy&amp;author=Taylor%2C+G+A&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-20&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Office vacancy rate rebounds smartly from dire predictions at year-end as various firms play musical chairs
When Meyers Norris Penny LLP set out to accommodate an expected spurt in staffing levels, it did what a few local companies have opted to do this spring in Winnipeg - play musical chairs in the city's downtown office market.
The chartered accounting firm has agreed to sublet nearly 40,000 square feet in the 33-storey CanWest Global Place tower, taking up some of the space that had been vacated by Agricore United last year when it merged with Saskatchewan Wheat Pool to become Viterra Inc., a global agri-business.
"We need the additional space because of the rapid expansion of people in our firm," said Meyers Norris partner Dan Trotter, adding that the company expects to increase to about 200 people from about 160 over the next year and a half. The new office will also bring the company closer to many of its clients, he added.
The move, planned for this October, is one of several by local companies that have helped create a remarkable turnaround in the fortunes of Winnipeg's downtown office market this spring.
Just five months ago, industry observers had a bleak outlook: A surplus of sublease space had threatened to slow the city's traditionally stable market. By the first quarter, however, the picture had changed considerably. Now, analysts are predicting a more balanced market for the remainder of the year.
CB Richard Ellis had pegged the vacancy rate for class A property at 9 per cent at the end of 2007 but that had recovered to 6.4 per cent in March; class B space improved to 5.6 per cent from 8.9 per cent at the end of the year.
Cushman & Wakefield LePage, meanwhile, reported the class A market vacancy rate was 7.7 per cent at the end of the first quarter, down from 9 per cent at the end of 2007. The change was more muted for the class B market, falling to 7.3 per cent from 8 per cent at the end of the year.
Avison Young Commercial Real Estate (Manitoba) Inc. reported a much more modest change, but an improvement nonetheless: It had recorded a year-end vacancy rate of 7.6 per cent for class A and B properties, and that fell to 6.9 per cent at the end of the first quarter.
(Real estate companies track the numbers in their own ways, resulting in discrepancies in how they report the vacancy rates.)
Paul Kuzina, an office leasing specialist with CB Richard Ellis, said its figures represent the lowest downtown vacancy rate for Winnipeg in the past five years, helped by the absorption of about 225,000 square feet in the first quarter, thanks to "above-average leasing activity."
He attributed the more bullish demand to a strong Manitoba economy. "What we've seen over the years is that the public sector is playing a large part in the Winnipeg economy, and provincial and federal government departments have been expanding. There's an increased need for more space," Mr. Kuzina said.
As well, he said, companies headquartered in Winnipeg, such as Great-West Life Assurance Co., have experienced growth and, as a result, have leased larger blocks of space downtown.
Some of the transactions in early 2008 have included 4,000 square feet of space in the Commodity Exchange Tower going to a Calgary firm, and 68,000 square feet of space in cityplace, an office and retail development, being filled by the federal government, Manitoba Public Insurance and the City of Winnipeg. And, in a separate deal, the federal government leased 25,000 square feet of space in the downtown Grain Exchange Building.
Mr. Kuzina predicted the above-average absorption in the first quarter would ease in the following months and vacancy rates would remain around the March levels for a good portion of the year.
Last December, Avison Young had predicted a tenant's market would occur in 2008 with large chunks of lease and sublet space coming on to the market, including 77,000 square feet to be vacated by Manitoba Hydro when it moves into its new downtown tower and 73,000 square feet formerly occupied by Agricore United in CanWest Global Place. But much of this space has since been absorbed.
"There has been an upswing, particularly in the class A numbers," said Catherine Stoyko, marketing and research co-ordinator for Avison Young and author of its market summary. She expressed surprise by the turnaround of the downtown office market, but couldn't say if this was a long-term trend.
Cushman & Wakefield reported that the "big story" in the class B market was the leasing by Great-West Life of almost all of the soon-to-be vacated space of Centra Gas, a subsidiary of Manitoba Hydro.
"We remain cautiously optimistic that the market will continue to keep vacancy rates at or near present levels for the balance of the year," a Cushman report states. "Going forward, demand will depend largely upon growth in public sector office requirements and the financial services sector."

Not Mr. Gehry's neighbourhood?

Author: Houpt, Simon

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/not-mr-gehrys-neighbourhood/docview/382749981/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Last Thursday evening, in a cultural contrast as stark as they come, the anti-Atlantic Yards organization Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn held a benefit concert at the Park Slope club Southpaw, while across the river - in Manhattan, that is - Forest City Ratner used the publicity over the new designs to kick off the sale of the arena's 130 luxury boxes with a splashy party on the 38th floor of the New York Times building.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Not+Mr.+Gehry%27s+neighbourhood%3F&amp;author=Houpt%2C+Simon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-19&amp;spage=R.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Not+Mr.+Gehry%27s+neighbourhood%3F&amp;author=Houpt%2C+Simon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-19&amp;spage=R.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A Frank Gehry-designed arena complex in Brooklyn is a target in New Yorkers's favourite blood sport - real estate
By now, surely, Frank Gehry is inured to the revulsion of others. After wrestling with the Spanish over his whimsical Guggenheim Bilbao museum, with Angelenos over his blindingly reflective Walt Disney Concert Hall, with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology over leaks in a $300-million complex he designed there, and with his own neighbours over his chain-link-fence-adorned house in Santa Monica, the 79-year-old Canadian-born architect is now one of the primary targets of community activists over the gargantuan Atlantic Yards development in downtown Brooklyn, of which he is the chief architect.
Conceived more than four years ago when developer Bruce Ratner purchased the New Jersey Nets and announced his intention to move them to Brooklyn, Atlantic Yards was envisioned as an instant neighbourhood: a 16-building, nine-hectare complex that would throw down an 18,000-seat basketball arena, thousands of luxury condos, low-income housing, and eight office towers.
The only problem was, there was already a neighbourhood there. And though Flatbush and Prospect Heights had seen better days - more than a thousand manufacturing jobs left in the mid-1990s - and local fans were psyched about the return of professional sports to the borough, others weren't keen on being evicted or having the low-slung character of their area altered in a blinding flash of outside money. Others complained that the development would bring "instant gentrification."
The tallest office tower, dubbed Miss Brooklyn, was a 185-metre edifice of undulating glass better suited to the canyons of Manhattan.
Still, Gehry's designs were well received by architecture critics who were seduced by his vision of an arena, adorned with massive sails, that would hide within a huddle of angular buildings to provide a
"peekaboo" effect from the street. And despite community objections, especially to the government invocation of eminent domain (a.k.a. expropriation) to help Ratner acquire the land, the state finally gave the go-ahead to the development at the end of 2006, along with hundreds of millions in subsidies.
Since then, however, progress at Atlantic Yards has been about as speedy as construction at Ground Zero. And opponents have grown more vocal and better organized. Last month, when the Brooklyn Museum held its spring gala, the black-tie crowd had to push its way past a line of placard-wielding protesters upset that the museum - which otherwise has a very good relationship with its constituency - had chosen to use the occasion to honour Ratner, one of its benefactors. (Some opponents have a problem with perspective: One commenter on a blog account of the gala compared Ratner to Charles Manson and Hitler.) And last week, when the Observer published its list of the 100 Most Powerful People in New York Real Estate, Ratner was number eight, Gehry number 51, and the anti-Atlantic Yards blogger Norman Oder landed at number 77.
But then, real estate in this city is a blood sport and nothing ever gets built without some of the little people being crushed. Ratner has already defeated 18 lawsuits, and he obviously believes he can kill the remaining handful, including one that challenges the legitimacy of the state's environmental review. But while he has to wait for the courts to deal with those cases before he can build, another foe already has him on the ropes: the collapsing credit market.
When Atlantic Yards was first announced, it had an estimated price tag of $2.5-billion; that has since ballooned to $4-billion, almost one-quarter of which, an eye-popping $950-million, is allocated to the arena alone. This spring, when Forest City Ratner, the developer's company, admitted it was considering radical changes to help get the project back on track, the Times' influential architecture critic Nicolai Ouroussoff, who had initially been a champion, suggested Gehry was being reduced to the role of a name-brand fig leaf and should walk away rather than compromise on his vision.
But Gehry isn't the type to quit, and two weeks ago, in a bid to re-ignite civic interest in the project, the company unveiled some radical new designs: The arena has lost its sails and is now apparently wrapped in titanium folds and flanked by only four buildings, one of which looks like a series of bird cages stacked precariously atop one another at a dangerous diagonal. The now dubbed B1 replaces the former Miss Brooklyn and promises to rise to only about 160 metres. B2, which will be built first, is a red-and-pink agglomeration reminiscent of a hillside shantytown.
Last Thursday evening, in a cultural contrast as stark as they come, the anti-Atlantic Yards organization Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn held a benefit concert at the Park Slope club Southpaw, while across the river - in Manhattan, that is - Forest City Ratner used the publicity over the new designs to kick off the sale of the arena's 130 luxury boxes with a splashy party on the 38th floor of the New York Times building. (The Times new headquarters was developed by Forest City Ratner, which has frequently caused Brooklynites to be skeptical of its coverage of Atlantic Yards.)
The admission fee for the Southpaw event, which featured a screening of the anti-Atlantic Yards documentary Brooklyn Matters and music by John Wesley Harding, was $15. The average annual lease fee on the luxury suites is $300,000; if you're feeling flush - say you work at JPMorgan rather than Bear Stearns - you could pony up $540,000 a year for one of 12 "elite" boxes, which, in an illustration that rich people operate in a different sphere of logic, are actually bunkers, located under the bleachers, with no view of the action (though they do each come with eight courtside seats).
Atlantic Yards isn't the only large-scale development in trouble. At the end of March, the developer Tishman Speyer was granted the rights to build office space, parklands, and residential towers on Manhattan's West Side Railyards. But two weeks ago, when it couldn't change the terms of the billion-dollar deal it had just agreed to, it walked off like a spoiled child. The Bloomberg Administration now has two failures to its credit in that one spot, after its ill-fated plan for a football stadium died with its Olympic bid.
Still, the administration, which doesn't seem to grasp that New York is a city of people who live at street level, continues to push these sorts of high concept developments. Up in Harlem, city council has just approved a rezoning that will see skyscraping office buildings and luxury condos consume historic 125th Street. The local community was opposed to it, of course. Not that it mattered.
Credit: shoupt@globeandmail.com

Joy to the world

Author: Macdonald, Gayle

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/joy-world/docview/382736184/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "I had to tap down deep to play this role. They padded me up here," she says, pointing to one breast. "And taped me down here," indicating the other, "to look like I'd had a masectomy. It was so real, it made me feel ill. I can't imagine what it must be like for these women who are grateful to be alive but still traumatized by what has happened to their bodies. I had horribly torn feelings."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Joy+to+the+world&amp;author=Macdonald%2C+Gayle&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-19&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Joy+to+the+world&amp;author=Macdonald%2C+Gayle&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-19&amp;spage=R.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Sunny Australian Helene Joy talks to Gayle MacDonald about her path to Toronto, and her role in the intensely dark Durham County
The Australian-born actress Helene Joy is well named.
Impossibly upbeat - with an infectious laugh that echoes (often) through the lounge in Toronto's Drake Hotel - it's tough at first to identify this sunny creature with the angst-ridden character she portrays in the brooding drama Durham County , to be broadcast starting tonight on Global TV.
In the six-part miniseries, Joy plays Audrey Sweeney, one of the least troubled, relatively uncomplicated characters in this critically lauded program.
"There's no question, the show is pretty grim," says Joy, who was born in Perth and moved to Canada about six years ago with a Canadian boyfriend she'd met in Queensland filming an episode of, of all things, Flipper .
"When I read the opening scene of Durham County , I wasn't sure I could do this role. But, as I kept on, I thought the script was absolutely brilliant," adds the redhead. "And even more, I was fascinated that something this dark and disturbing was the concoction of a creative team that is basically all women."
Durham County is the brainchild of Back Alley Film Production partners Adrienne Mitchell and Janis Lundman. It was written by Laurie Finstad-Knizhnik, and was directed by Holly Dale and Mitchell. It initially aired on the pay channels Movie Network and Movie Central last May. It's getting its second window on conventional television, on Global.
A warning to anyone remotely queasy: In the first five minutes, two teenage girls are murdered, brutally and onscreen, while "an eye" watches through the bushes. The peeping sociopath then has his way with one of the apparently dead girls after the killer leaves a clearing in the woods. "We were all a little nervous about the whole thing," says Joy. "But we thought Durham County would excite more people than it would disturb. And it has done that."
The show is anything but the typical cop-versus-killer drama. The story is deliberately ambiguous. The characters are even more so. At the crux is Detective Mike Sweeney (Audrey's husband, played by Hugh Dillon), who moves his family to the suburbs only to become obsessed with hunting a serial killer (turns out there are two) who he is convinced is his neighbour, Ray Prager (Justin Louis).
"My character is one of the relatively stable ones," Joy says, chuckling. "I play a neglected wife who has just survived a harrowing bout of breast cancer, and has lost a breast. In the meantime, my whole family has torn itself apart. My children are dysfunctional and have turned against me because they thought I was going to die. My husband has fallen out of love.
"I had to tap down deep to play this role. They padded me up here," she says, pointing to one breast. "And taped me down here," indicating the other, "to look like I'd had a masectomy. It was so real, it made me feel ill. I can't imagine what it must be like for these women who are grateful to be alive but still traumatized by what has happened to their bodies. I had horribly torn feelings."
Joy hopes that Global/TMN/Movie Central will go ahead with a second season of a show that challenges its actors and its viewers equally: "It's looking 90-per-cent positive that Durham County will go again. If it does, I couldn't be happier. The acting - by Hugh, and the others - is fabulous."
A green light, however, will also make Joy's already hectic schedule even crazier. "If we start in September, I'll be shooting Durham County in Montreal and The Murdoch Mysteries in Toronto. Don't get me wrong: I'm not complaining. I love the work, which is far more plentiful here in Canada than it was at home," says Joy.
In CITY-TV's Murdoch Mysteries , she's the female lead, Dr. Julia Ogden. And recently on CBC-TV's short-lived hockey drama, MVP , she played the team doctor, a role she loved for one very specific reason. "I got to play most of my scenes with Peter Miller, who's gorgeous. He was half-naked most of the time, which was great fun." MVP , recently picked up by Disney's SOAPnet, premieres June 19 in the United States.
Trained at the Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts, Joy says the only thing she doesn't like about Canada - besides the cold weather - is the people who bash Canadian-made television.
"Australians watch their own shows," she says. "And we do that because there are laws in place that require much larger amounts of spending content to be indigenous. Most people at home still only have five channels, so they know their talent."
The youngest daughter of a single mother (now a successful real-estate agent in Perth), Joy says her spare time is spent biking around Toronto, learning French, the guitar, and sewing things for her friends. For at least six weeks a year, she dons a backpack and heads to warmer climates, often South and Central America.
"I haven't taken a traditional path. That's never been the case with me. But I'm glad I met that nice Canadian boy," Joy says with a smile, referring to her Flipper cast-mate who is still a good friend. "It started a whole new tangent of my life that I never expected."
Durham County airs at 10 tonight on Global (Check local listings).

No trespassing allowed (millionaires excepted)

Author: Kelly, Deirdre

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/no-trespassing-allowed-millionaires-excepted/docview/382752685/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "If [Mr. [Marc Hewitt]] had his way, it would be a highly desirable and exclusive community. I can understand why he'd want to do that," she continues, speaking from her Oakville home. "But it's not in the community's best interest or the town's."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+trespassing+allowed+%28millionaires+excepted%29&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-17&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+trespassing+allowed+%28millionaires+excepted%29&amp;author=Kelly%2C+Deirdre&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-17&amp;spage=M.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The man behind a luxe condo project on Oakville's splashiest estate wants the property's shoreline to stay closed to the public
From inside Edgemere Estate, the largest private property on Oakville's "millionaires' row," there is a stunning view of Lake Ontario sparkling in the bright afternoon sun.
For a century, this view and Edgemere's 300 metres of shoreline have been the exclusive preserve of the five-hectare estate's wealthy proprietors - and if Edgemere's newest owner wins a looming battle with Oakville town hall, it will stay that way.
A consortium led by veteran developer Marc Hewitt wants to tear down the 32,000-square-foot mansion built by Edgemere's previous owner, Mattamy Homes president Peter Gilgan, and replace it with a community of 10 2½-storey luxury condominiums with three units each.
Most controversially, Mr. Hewitt would like the property's shoreline to remain closed to the public, setting the stage for a potential challenge to Oakville's policy of forcing developers to turn over a 15-metre strip of lakefront land when a waterfront estate is redeveloped.
The reclamation policy, a bedrock of planning in Oakville, has helped the town open about one-third of its shoreline to the public in the past 45 years. Town officials would like to add Edgemere's lakefront land to their collection; they are already looking at reclaiming a treed area on the property's western boundary that would help them to connect the estate's shoreline to an existing public pathway, said Oakville Councillor Keith Bird.
Mr. Bird and other members of Oakville council are working to kill Mr. Hewitt's application to change the property's zoning. The application has been submitted to the town's planning staff, who are expected to give the plan the thumbs up or down by this fall.
"[Our] plan is to have a linear trail," said Mr. Bird, who has already gathered more than 400 signatures from residents opposed to Mr. Hewitt's plan. "A condo-style development, with private cobblestone roads, what I understand would be a gated community, would cut off public access to waterfront land."
However, Mr. Hewitt said he and his partners insist it would be "inappropriate" to make Edgemere's shoreline public. Mr. Hewitt has yet to sit down and hash out his differences with the town - it's still too early in the process - but when he does, the developer plans to offer the town cash to spruce up other public spaces in exchange for an exemption from the reclamation policy.
"We acknowledge that the town has a right to acquire a 5-per-cent conveyance under the planning act. But our point is we're not sure that's appropriate given the isolated character of the property. It is disconnected from any pathway, so what purpose would it serve?"
If planning staff and Oakville council turn down his rezoning request, Mr. Hewitt can appeal their decision to the Ontario Municipal Board - a process he would be familiar with as a big player in the development game in greater Toronto.
(He also knows a thing or two about development worldwide: Mr. Hewitt is the former head of development for Emaar Properties, a Middle Eastern real-estate behemoth best known for erecting the Burj Dubai, the glittering condo and office building that last year surpassed the height of the CN Tower.)
In what is a common strategy in the development industry, Mr. Hewitt assembled a new company last year specifically to buy and develop the Gilgan property at 1502 Lakeshore Rd. E. The company, Edgemere Estate Ltd., bought the property in September for a reported $35.5-million after it had been languishing on the market for 18 months.
(When the property was put on the market for $45-million in 2006, it was the most expensive residential listing in Canadian history.)
The consortium is a limited partnership composed of four partners. The board of directors includes Mr. Hewitt, T. James Tadeson, the chief executive officer of InStorage real estate investment trust, and Peter Carver, a principal with Carttera Private Equities Inc., a Toronto-based equity management company. Mr. Hewitt would not say, and the company's partnership documents don't divulge, who the four partners or partner companies are and what financial stake they have in the Edgemere project.
But it is clear the consortium is, at the least, aiming to triple its initial investment. The proposed luxury condo units, ranging in size from 3,000 to 6,200 square feet, and designed by acclaimed Toronto architect Peter Clewes, will cost from $3-million to more than $6-million apiece.
"But this isn't about making money," Mr. Hewitt says. "This is about doing the right thing."
Mr. Hewitt warns the alternative to his plan could be much worse. The land is zoned for as many as 17 single-family homes in a traditional subdivision. If he were to go this route, much travelled in Oakville, then most of the 420 trees that dot the property would have to be cut down to make way for the houses.
As well, property lines would run through many of Edgemere's historic buildings, meaning they would have to be demolished. These include a trellised teahouse, the old Keeper's Lodge and a wall made from lake stones pulled from the shallow waters close to shore.
"We want to maintain the spaciousness of the property, not cover the property," says Mr. Hewitt. "We want to preserve the idea of a grand estate. If we subdivide, then a whole piece of local cultural history will be lost."
If Oakville's planning policies stipulate that Edgemere's waterfront must be returned to the public upon redevelopment, how likely is it that Mr. Hewitt's blueprint for a walled condo community will be approved as submitted?
The case hinges on a technicality. Mr. Hewitt's proposal envisions putting all 10 three-unit luxury condos on the site of the Gilgan home and swimming pool, with no new lots being created. When Mr. Gilgan built his new home on the property in 1995, the town did not reclaim any part of Edgemere's waterfront.
"That is key, that they are not creating new lots," says Councillor Mary Chapin. "The dedication of the waterfront is triggered when a property is redeveloped and some will interpret that to mean subdivide and because he is not subdividing he may feel he does not need to dedicate the waterfront." Unlike some of her council colleagues, Ms. Chapin thinks Mr. Hewitt's proposal could be positive. It fills a niche. Oakville does not have any high-end condos today. But she is more concerned for the common good.
"If [Mr. Hewitt] had his way, it would be a highly desirable and exclusive community. I can understand why he'd want to do that," she continues, speaking from her Oakville home. "But it's not in the community's best interest or the town's."
An historic jewel
Some sprawling estates on Oakville's "millionaires' row" have been redeveloped as suburban subdivisions. But the Edgemere property, which boasts a rich history, has remained relatively untouched.
In 1907, James Ryrie (partner of jeweller Henry Birk) bought the land, eventually erecting a vacation home on it.
Later owners include John E. Hammell, a Canadian prize-fighter-turned-mining magnate, in the thirties. Mr. Hammell had an art collection that included works by Titian and Rembrandt.
In the mid-1990s, Mattamy Homes president Peter Gilgan tore down the original arts-and-crafts-style residence to make room for a nine-bedroom, 17-bathroom home for his family of eight.
Historic elements, such as the boathouse, stables and Japanese sculpture garden, have largely remained intact over the years.
Deirdre Kelly
