Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=News%2C+news+everywhere+-+but+not+enough+time+to+think&amp;author=Salutin%2C+Rick&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-10&amp;spage=F.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=News%2C+news+everywhere+-+but+not+enough+time+to+think&amp;author=Salutin%2C+Rick&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-10&amp;spage=F.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Media watcher Rick Salutin makes a pilgrimage to the Newseum, Washington's highly touted, $450-million temple to journalism, and finds it entertaining but also full of distractions - much like the media it enshrines
If you're a bit obsessed with news, as many of us are - or have even written a column, largely on the news media, as I have - then it's a privilege to wander through the recently opened Newseum, in Washington, D.C., trying to figure out what that obsession is really about. Museums (and newseums) help you think, by highlighting their subject matter and putting it on display. It doesn't have to be old and exotic, like mummies.
The Newseum, sponsored mainly by news organizations, occupies the last major frontage on Pennsylvania Avenue, just down from the Capitol and right beside (abutting, as real-estate agents say) the Canadian embassy. The façade is covered with six floors' worth of the U.S. Constitution's First Amendment, the one about free speech and a free press, written (literally) in stone, bold and black.
That's the D.C. style: utterly monumental. Originally, a local journalist says, the amendment was sandblasted into the wall, but that was deemed too understated, so it was overlaid by the imposing letters.
Other cultures may do their newseums differently. Free speech, Gandhi could have said: It would be a good idea. Toronto's Honest Ed, who covered his garish bargain house with signs, might have posted: Don't just stand there, mythologize something!
In fact, there's lots Canadian in the Newseum. It draws on satires of news like Saturday Night Live that reflect the influence of a Canadian sense of familiarity yet distance toward U.S. culture. It has splendid displays on the rise of print - a topic brilliantly explored by Canadian historian Harold Innis, who was one of the founders of modern media theory, and by his (IMHO) lesser successor, Marshall McLuhan.
A Toronto firm, Kubik, even built the countless Newseum displays. Kubik's Sam Kohn explains that three modules make up the building: The first looks out on Penn Avenue. The two behind it fold into each other like pages in a newspaper. Once he points this out, it really feels that way. I'm inside a newspaper, writing about the news, for a newspaper. Weird.
A filmed "orientation" starts with the most godlike voice of my youth: Walter Cronkite. "The world comes to you. We call it the news." Well, that's totally murky. Another voice says, "War is news" - though only some wars are. "Peace is news ... Life is news ... Death is news ... Hate is news." The only thing that's clear so far is they haven't given us a clue what news is. Maybe we're supposed to know it when we see it. That's okay. Definitions are overrated. The displays proper start on the top floor and work on down.
There's some creaky "early history" of news, "from smoke signals to sagas." Homeric epics, yeah, right. "Arrival of language" in 100,000 BC. This kind of fluff is now common in museums. Over at the International Spy Museum, they include Moses sending spies into the Holy Land.
But it gets better. There's a real page from a Gutenberg Bible, which takes my breath away, and then, a level below, a model of an early printing press. Now, it seems to me, we're really talking about the Birth of the News.
The battle between
oral and written
I've been obsessed with the role of print since I first read Mr. Innis's thoughts on the crucial divide between the oral and written traditions. For millennia, he says, civilizations teetered productively between the two very different ways of exploring reality - a little of this, a little of that - but with the invention of the printing press, the balance swung decisively toward the written and has never been restored.
I've devoured books about this, taught courses on it, written of it (probably far too often) when I had a media column in The Globe and Mail, and even pondered my choice to become a writer in its light. But nothing ever clarified for me the power and nature of print like the displays in the cavernous "history of news" gallery at the Newseum.
A timeline runs the full length of one module and doubles back up the other side, from Gutenberg's first press in 1450 through to the present. Beneath the timeline, on sliding glass trays stacked three high, are examples of news sheets, news books, newspapers, circulars - mostly American from centuries past. They weren't just sold, they were posted in public places, laid out in coffee houses.
Why this stress on "news" back in print's early days? Well, how were printers going to justify their heavy fixed investment in printing presses once they had published the Bible and a few other classical texts? There were relatively few books left, it took time to generate new ones, including "novels," reading was still difficult for most people, and journals (as in journalism) was a clever solution. They had handy content: the events of the day and thoughts about those events. They weren't written for "the public." Rather, they created a public for the first time. Before that, there were elites, at the court, and mobs, which came and went sporadically. But printed material gave the public a continuity, and a subject to focus on - the "news" about matters that affected them, and which they could in turn affect, i.e., through mass politics. By 1814 with steam presses, The Times of London could print 1,100 copies an hour. Before print, there were no journalists; ever since, they've been "the press."
So, in a way, journalism created politics in the modern sense as well as creating the public: Through it, a newly aware, interested public became a player, alongside the court or the mob. You can sense the excitement about this new element of influence when John Adams, America's second president and some-time journalist (with his own HBO series this year), wrote: "It is curious employment cooking up paragraphs, articles, occurrences and working the political engine." Like a new kitchen device, a stove or Cuisinart, but historically potent. You could use it to break free of an empire, or abolish slavery. Without it, how would you have mounted campaigns against entrenched power like the British monarchy or the Southern landed aristocracy?
If you then ensconce that power and protect it - through declaring it a sacrosanct right, like freedom of religion - you've made yourself and your political projects hard to undermine or even criticize. Freedom of the press amounts to about the same thing as power of the press. This kind of journalism was politics. It wasn't about information, it was about opinion and action: creating a public to act on things in a desired direction.
Nothing has ever given me so full a sense of the force in that early moment of print and the way it transformed the world as those pullout drawers. When you read about early journals and papers in history texts, they're just examples in a book. The book looms over them. It can't make the moment present like these actual oversized artifacts, which predate most books. It's the perfect use of a museum.
But then what about information, which we associate so strongly with news? Where does that come in? The orientation film says, "Information is where liberty starts." Al Neuharth, founder of the Freedom Forum, the foundation that created and runs Newseum, says (right on the wall) that visitors will come as tourists but leave as better-informed citizens. It's the premise of the place and of most journalism. And yet, just as the exhibits on early print give a real insight into that topic, the rest of the displays of news seem to underline its oddly uninformative quality.
Sex, crime, scandal
- embed or in bed?
Everything whizzes by so swiftly and disconnectedly, as you follow the "flow" from level to level. There's a reference to public broadcasting, a display case on "Sex, crime, scandal" with a copy of Weekly World News (R.I.P.). Another called "Embed or in bed?" about reporters' relationship with the military in war zones. The dilemma isn't concealed, but there's no space or means to ponder it either. There's an "ethics table" where you can dabble in quandaries about anonymous sources and doctored photos. Here's a display on women in the news, one on ownership, press barons, "Mergers and takeovers create multimedia giants ..."
Whoa, that could be worth a linger. It may be the key component in modern media: corporate control. But it whips past exactly like clips from The Colbert Report or Ali versus Foreman and Matt Drudge. Nothing is suppressed, but there's no integration into any overall sense-making process. In fact, it's exactly the same kind of jumble you find on the pages of any newspaper, which may not disorient or bother us but only because we're so used to it. Here in the Newseum - and I consider this a good thing - that chaotic disconnectedness stands out in a way it doesn't in the paper or on a newscast - everything is displayed in a case. But how can you contemplate the news the way you can a statuette from Crete or a suit of medieval armour for a while and then move on? Surely the news should be more urgent, present and connected to us. This is the kind of experience that makes you think about something you took for granted.
My man Innis understood this sporadic, disconnected character of news. He said it came with the nature of print, what he called its bias. Print is good for snippets of info, he argued, but bad for inquiring in depth into "the subject matter of human action and feeling"- like ethics, politics or religion. The laborious oral tradition was better in those areas, he grumbled.
By oral, he didn't mean radio or TV. He meant face-to-face live discourse on serious issues, as used to happened in ancient Athens, or the Talmudic academies or the Iroquois confederacy. Depersonalized in print, disconnected from living human interaction and response, such issues were doomed to devolve into sensationalism, on haughtier or grottier levels, from presidential politics to movie stars, everything trivialized and fragmented, that was print's destiny along with its broadcast offspring.
I don't mean the Newseum isn't fun. It is, in a madcap, newsy way. The kids seem delighted by a display of old newsreels that announce "the coming of TV." Imagine, a time when TV wasn't already here. They love the sonorous voiceover, the thundering music and the closing shot of the world spinning. "I knew they'd do that," they say.
And it's beautifully done. There's a feeling of openness throughout the building as you tramp the ramps, the sun streaming through the windows of module one, like the openness of the free press itself (at least in the mythic version). The endless displays may overwhelm but they don't abuse or assault you; it's more like being tickled and overstimulated. The music is bouncy, there's goofy alongside morbid, a traffic helicopter hovers above the atrium. In the end, nothing really penetrates, as if that's the nature of news too: to shut you off from yourself and focus you outward, on stuff, on the world. It's slick and feel-good, like most American culture, like Hollywood films, even those with "serious" themes: war, for instance, or disease.
So you get Vietnam, with the horrific visuals but it's still a feel-good story because, after all, the press broke through to the truth and the whole nightmare ended, so you don't really have to reflect on why it happened or how it's happening again in other places like Iraq or Afghanistan. And eventually there's 9/11, which you cover to exhaustion but don't really contemplate; instead, put up a 9/11 gallery in the Newseum and celebrate it in a sombre, ceremonial way. Commemoration replaces contemplation making further disasters and galleries in their honour probable.
Better informed makes
us better citizens?
Mr. Neuharth wants the tourists to leave as better-informed citizens. Well, they may be better informed. But that doesn't necessarily make them better citizens. What does a citizen need? Not endless information but space and time in which to contemplate the information they have and formulate a response. That may not be journalism's responsibility, maybe its task is the inform component. But in a place like Newseum, and in journalism generally, there's so much information that it's almost impossible for citizens to reflect, and rarely a hint of a hint that they ought to. The sheer bulk of information tends to render them mute and vulnerable. There are times when less (informed) may be better.
What the museum-ish atmosphere of Newseum lets you do is ponder these problematic aspects of news and information. The experience suggests that news isn't just information, it's also distraction. I'm not saying it's intentional. It doesn't really matter, that's the result. News sucks you in because you care about things like politics, history and social justice; then news distracts you by yammering about them so divertingly that you can easily forget about dealing with them. And what a clever way to distract you from the world and the parts of it that affect you fatefully: with tales and images from the world itself. The way news distracts people from thinking about the information they've just been given is by giving them more. There's always more, as there is in the Newseum, where signs say: "Attention, news junkies" - and then direct you to the shops. Being there really is like wandering around a colossal newspaper.
Then, next morning back at the hotel, USA Today is outside the door, with Harrison Ford and Sarah Jessica Parker and a footballer pointing in your face, along with "Iraqi forces lacking" and "Video games under fire." It's not that some of it is trite and some heavy; it's that absence of opportunity to reflect. Is it a surprise that Al Neuharth also created USA Today, whose owner, Gannett Corporation, is Newseum's big funder?
There is one section of the Newseum, where Pulitzer Prize-winning photos are displayed, that does clear a little space for contemplation. A Buddhist moment. Maybe it's because they're stills, in black and white. "Lost Child" - a couple stares forlornly from the beach into the brutal ocean. "Fatal Fire" - a fire fighter holds a dead kid. There's no real push to move on from these, they invite consideration and stillness. Maybe it's just because they're tucked into an odd, unadorned corner of the place, out of the relentless flow.
What if the Newseum gave you that kind of space to contemplate all its busy doings? Then it wouldn't be the Newseum, it would be the News and Space museum (to go with the Air and Space museum over on the mall, ho-ho). What about strategically placed alcoves, halting the flow, where you could sit and think about what you just saw, judge and absorb it? Maybe after the news on TV, there should be a mandatory period of silence and blank screen so people can think about what's going on. And papers should have empty pages inviting you to ponder what you read, or scribble your own responses.
I don't think more analysis or opinion are required along with the "straight" news. There's already plenty of that in the press and I don't believe it assists citizenship in the way the Newseum says it wants to do. Mr. Innis would have said journalism and the print tradition are democracy's enemies because democracy (in the classical, Greek sense) requires the oral process, with its slowness, complexity and human interaction. That's where citizenship takes root, not by imbibing vast gobs of information.
Papers defined news
but won't outlive it
We live at a time when newspapers are panicky, if not about their actual extinction then at least about maintaining their previously normal, abnormal levels of profit. So it's a suitably anxious time to embalm the species in a mausoleum. But news will also persist, with or without the papers, which long ago set the parameters for any versions of it to come in the future. Either way, it seems like an apt time for a Newseum.
Playwright and novelist Rick Salutin writes weekly for The Globe and Mail's Comment section and has been nominated for two National Magazine Awards this year.
TIME LINE FROM WOODBLOCK TO FACEBOOK, THE MORPHING OF THE MEDIA
687-705 Printing is one of ancient China's four great inventions. Oldest known example is a woodblock-printed Buddhist scripture.
1309 Europeans first make paper.
1453 Johannes Gutenberg uses his press to print the Bible.
1556 First monthly newspaper Notizie Scritte published in Venice.
1605 Relation, the first weekly newspaper, begins in Antwerp.
1620 First newsbook (or coranto) is printed in English (in Holland).
1631 The first French newspaper is published as Gazette.
1645 Post-och Inrikes Tidningar, now the world's oldest newspaper (online only), launches in Sweden.
1690 The first newspaper to be printed in America is called Publick Occurrences.
1702 A periodical since 1621, the Courant becomes England's first daily newspaper.
1704 Britain's Daniel Defoe, considered the world's first journalist, publishes the Review.
1825 First permanent photograph is taken.
1830 Telegraphy is independently developed in England and the United States.
1846 Richard Hoe invents cylinder press, able to print 8,000 sheets an hour.
1870 Paper is mass-manufactured from wood pulp.
1876 First telephone call made by Alexander Graham Bell.
1878 Thomas Alva Edison patents the phonograph.
1890 Telephone wires are installed in Manhattan.
1894 Thomas Edison patents the Kinetograph and Kinetoscope, which were invented in his laboratories by William Kennedy Laurie Dickson.
1895 Cinematograph invented by Auguste and Louis Lumiere, based on Edison's patented Kinetograph.
1896 American Herman Hollerith founds the company that's to become IBM.
1897 Guglielmo Marconi patents the wireless telegraph.
1898 Loudspeaker is invented.
1903 The Daily Mirror, the first tabloid-style newspaper, is published in London.
1904 First comic book appears.
1909 Passenger liner RMS Republic uses the Marconi wireless to call for help after being in a collision - the media's first "breaking news" story.
1913 Edison switches from cylinder recordings to more easily reproduced discs, and the portable phonograph appears.
1916 Tunable radios appear.
1919 Short-wave radio is invented.
1920 KDKA-AM in Pittsburgh becomes the world's first commercial radio station.
1922 BBC begins broadcasting.
1926 NBC is formed.
1927 The first electronic television system is unveiled.
1928 Teletype is introduced for long-distance transmission of the news.
1932 BBC begins rudimentary TV broadcasts.
1933 FM radio joins AM and a media war breaks out as newspapers try to force Associated Press to cut off radio stations.
1936 The CBC is born.
1939 Western Union introduces coast-to-coast fax service, electronic TV broadcasts begin in the U.S., and the wire recorder is invented.
1940 First commercial TV station launches in New York.
1947 Phototypesetting (cold type) becomes practical.
1948 Cable television becomes available in the U.S.
1951 The first colour televisions go on sale.
1952 CBC-TV begins broadcasting.
1959 Xerox makes the first copier.
1963 Audio cassette is invented by Philips for use with dictation machines.
1965 Vietnam War becomes first war to be televised.
1967 Newspapers, magazines start to digitize production and use computers.
1970s Arpanet, ancestor of the Internet, is developed.
1971 Intel introduces the microprocessor, and use of offset presses becomes common.
1972 Pong becomes the first popular video game.
1973 The first home video-cassette recorder is introduced in Europe.
1975 The MITS Altair 8800 becomes the first pre-assembled desktop computer on the market.
1976 JVC introduces VHS, which is to become the standard videotape format.
1977 The Globe and Mail offers the world's first public access to an electronic archive.
1979 First mobile phone service is commercially launched in Japan
1980 CNN launches in the USA. New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones put news databases online.
1981 The IBM personal computer is introduced and MTV launched.
1982 Philips and Sony introduce the compact disc in Japan; it reaches North America early the next year.
1984 Apple pits its Macintosh against the PC.
1985 CD-ROMs and laptop computers appear, as does pay-per-view TV.
1991 World Wide Web is made public at CERN in Switzerland.
1993 The first Web ads appear.
1994 Netscape precursor Mosaic becomes first popular Web browser.
1996 First DVD players and discs are available in Japan.
1999 Napster sparks the rise of audio file sharing.
2000 First camera phones appear in Japan.
2001 The Blackberry launches in Canada.
2003 My Space ushers in the commercial age of social networking, to be eclipsed a year later by Facebook.
2004 Howard Dean is the first presidential candidate to create a blog. "Citizen journalism" appears in South Korea. Google becomes a public company then worth $23-billion.
2005 Media formats begin to converge. First news ticker feed appears on mobile phone in Japan.
2008 Microsoft tries to buy Google's much smaller rival Yahoo for $47.5-billion and is rebuffed.

A luxury home built to suit Lawrence Park's evolving tastes

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/luxury-home-built-suit-lawrence-parks-evolving/docview/382724361/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Another example of this is the home's covered terrace with a wood-burning fireplace. "People want to relax in the summer night outside and have a fire going," Mr. [Tony DeCaria] says. "It feels like they're at the cottage."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+luxury+home+built+to+suit+Lawrence+Park%27s+evolving+tastes&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-09&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+luxury+home+built+to+suit+Lawrence+Park%27s+evolving+tastes&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-09&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   41 STRATHEDEN RD.
WHAT: A newly built home in Lawrence Park, complete with professionally designed interiors
LIVING SPACE: more than 4,800 square feet
LOT SIZE: 65 by 135 feet
ASKING PRICE: $4,895,000
TAXES: not yet assessed
AGENT: Sam Tassone, Royal LePage West Realty Group Ltd.
In upscale neighbourhoods such as Lawrence Park and Forest Hill, it's more common than it used to be for builders to complete infill homes right down to the decor without having a buyer, according to real estate agent Sam Tassone.
One of those builders is Tony DeCaria, principal of Gallery Homes, who is just putting the finishing touches to this more than 4,800-square-foot residence on Stratheden Road in Lawrence Park. The house, listed by Mr. Tassone, will go on the market in mid-May.
Mr. DeCaria says he incorporated elements in the dwelling that previous clients have most requested - everything from a mix of formal and open-concept layouts to theatre seating in a lower level media room.
"You drive to the community, see what's going on in the area, and try to site a building that will complement not what's old, but what is evolving," Mr. DeCaria adds. "Because we're building in these areas - and have been for at least 10 years - we see what the improvements are.
Mr. DeCaria, who continues a family tradition of building that began when his grandfather arrived at Ellis Island from Italy in 1909, has about 800 homes in his portfolio, including several luxury homes for prestigious clients.
On a job a few years ago - a $3.29-million property in Forest Hill for a former Toronto Maple Leafs goaltender (which sold about two years later to an award-winning Canadian musician for $4.2-million) - he met interior designer Halina Catherine.
She has dressed about 10 residences done by Gallery Homes since then, including this one.
Mr. DeCaria says he always approaches locals for feedback on his plans.
"We've got to take their thoughts into consideration ... but we don't always come to an agreement."
At 41 Stratheden Rd., there was some opposition to the house's size, he says, though it takes up only about a third of the 65- by 135-foot lot.
Most new homes cover about 65 per cent of the property, more than twice what was traditionally permitted, he points out.
"We built to what the city will allow."
This home, like many Mr. DeCaria has built, has a limestone facade with a cedar shake roof, frieze-board details, as well as solider coursings above arched windows. For variety, there also are round and oval windows.
Inside, the eat-in kitchen in the rear opens to the family room. "The kids are playing and chatting while you're cooking, so it's a nice family environment," Ms. Catherine says.
Upstairs, a large master retreat along the back of the house includes a dressing room and an ensuite bathroom that rivals the size of the other bedrooms.
The basement, which adds another 2,740 square feet to the living space, features a 20-seat theatre, kitchenette, spa and gym - all high-demand features these days, according to Ms. Catherine.
"[People] want the privacy of an in-home gym and being able to wake up and have a personal trainer coming to the home," she explains. "Because of [limited] time, people are needing more luxuries at home."
Another example of this is the home's covered terrace with a wood-burning fireplace. "People want to relax in the summer night outside and have a fire going," Mr. DeCaria says. "It feels like they're at the cottage."
Because people are entertaining more at home, the design incorporates a music room between the spacious living and dining rooms, as well as a sunken wine cellar on the lower level.
Ms. Catherine picked out everything from furniture and artwork to window treatments and lighting.
Black and white Carrera marble tiles with a traditional pattern were chosen for the foyer, and quarter-sawn white oak flooring with an intricate herringbone pattern for the kitchen and family room.
Seen throughout the house is elaborate millwork - custom trims, ceiling mouldings and full-height panelling on the main floor and upper hall, and dark-stained, cherry panelling in the library.
To maximize the decor's appeal, Ms. Catherine kept her designs "simple and clean," but she pairs antique pieces with modern ones or combines traditional and art deco elements. For instance, the living room features art deco chairs paired with a traditional sofa and cocktail table, along with black crystal art deco lamps on a traditional sofa back console.
In the dining room, traditional upholstered seats are placed at a simple art deco dining table. Above the table is a traditional tiered Georgian crystal chandelier with quartz accents, creating a simple yet formal look.
"You don't want something coming in and out of fashion," Ms. Catherine says. "If you can put a twist on things to give it current feel, but stay traditional, it's timeless really."
If a buyer wants to make any changes, Mr. DeCaria will do so after the sale.
Mr. Tassone adds: "For the price point we're going to list it at - with all the craftsmanship and quality of workmanship that is involved - it's a bargain compared to other homes on the market."
The amenities
This two-storey stone house contains four bedrooms, seven bathrooms and five custom-crafted fireplaces with marble surrounds.
Ceilings are 10 feet on the main floor, where there is a library, piano room, dining room, and a living room with one of four gas fireplaces.
A family room is located off the eat-in kitchen, which includes luxury appliances, a walk-in pantry and island. It opens to a covered terrace with a stone fireplace.
The built-in double garage has direct access to a mud/laundry room.
Upstairs, there are three bedrooms with private bathrooms and walk-in closets. The master bedroom has a fireplace, dressing room and an ensuite with twin sinks, glass shower stall and freestanding tub.
In the basement, there is a recreation room with a two-way fireplace shared with a gym, as well as a spa with a sauna and steam shower. Rounding out this level is a sunken wine cellar, kitchenette, theatre and a nanny suite with a bathroom, plus an exit to the backyard.
The landscaping will be finished in June. Elements include fencing, deciduous hedges and side gates to a south-facing backyard with a terraced garden.
The driveway is radiant heated.

Bungalows, two-storeys located on ravine site

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bungalows-two-storeys-located-on-ravine-site/docview/382723393/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Called the Pride of Stonehaven, it will consist of 97 semi-detached houses and single-family residences on 36-, 50- and 55 feet lots at Mulock Drive and Leslie Street, about 30 minutes north of Toronto.

Full text:   Garden Homes has launched a development of large, luxury homes in Newmarket that the builder says will be the most prestigious master-planned community in town.
Called the Pride of Stonehaven, it will consist of 97 semi-detached houses and single-family residences on 36-, 50- and 55 feet lots at Mulock Drive and Leslie Street, about 30 minutes north of Toronto.
Treed streets will be lined with bungalows and two-storey houses, including some beside or backing on to a forested ravine.
There will be a variety of brick, stone and stucco exteriors available, with garages, porticos and multiple window styles, including round and Palladian.
The homes will have three- and four-bedroom designs with open concept layouts on the main floor.
Various plans will contain dens, combined or separate living and dining rooms, and eat-in kitchens that open to rear family rooms.
Laundry rooms will be situated on the main or second floors.
Architectural details include coffered and cathedral ceilings, decorative columns on half-walls and art niches.
Green features will be incorporated throughout to meet Energy Star standards. Low-E argon windows and increased insulation in areas such as walls and attics are expected to make the homes less drafty, and reduce utility bills. These houses will be 30 per cent more energy-efficient than conventional ones, according to the builder.
To commemorate 25 years in business, the builder has made updated features such as granite countertops with undermounted sinks, plaster cornice moulding in combined living and dining room and oak hardwood floors on the main floor standard in detached models.
Similarly, in semi-detached plans, five appliances, a gas fireplace with a marble surround or laminate flooring on the main level will be considered standard.
In addition, purchasers will get up to $7,000 in bonus upgrades.
Move-ins are expected to start in December.
Visitors to the site will find an established area, with schools, parks and local theatre.
Continuing development, however, has brought new amenities to the community, including the Magna Centre, which houses an Olympic-sized and three NHL-sized ice rinks, an aquatic centre and a gym.
It is a quick drive from the site to the historic downtown centre, big-box stores and malls in the Yonge Street and Davis Drive area, a GO Train station and Highway 404.

Full text:   Bremont Homes has completely finished an infill project in a wooded setting in Maple and is offering buyers closing times of between 60 days and four months.
The collection of 19 luxury freehold townhouses, called Dreamwood, is selling quickly, however. About 75 per cent have already been snatched up.
Located off Keele Street, north of Major Mackenzie Drive, the development has three decorated model homes that show the available floor plans, but potential buyers can tour any unit prior to purchasing one.
Units either face or back on to ponds, and they are situated along a private court so there is no through traffic.
Building with only four to six units feature brick facades with extra-large windows, as well as garages, double-door entrances, and, in some cases, covered balconies.
The open-concept layouts contain great rooms adjoining eat-in kitchens. Larger end units have central dining areas with three-sided fireplaces shared with a family room.Upstairs, there are laundry rooms with extra-tall cabinetry, as well as the bedrooms, including master suites with walk-in closets and private bathrooms.
Cold cellars and roughed-in three-piece bathrooms are included in the basement. Selected units have walkouts.
There are nine-foot ceilings and pot lights on the main floor, electric fireplaces, and natural oak staircases. Flooring materials include ceramic tile and 35-ounce carpeting.
The builder has installed upgraded features in many units - in some cases up to $30,000 worth, including such things as hardwood flooring in the principal rooms, appliances and wrought-iron railings.
There will be a monthly condo fee of $125 to cover snow removal and street maintenance, but it will be waived for the first two years as a bonus.
Local amenities include shops and services at Vaughan Mills, a Colossus multiplex theatre and Canada's Wonderland. The site is also close to schools, golf courses and highways 400 and 407.

Look west for higher-end higher density

Author: Raymaker, Derek

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/look-west-higher-end-density/docview/382722801/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Oakville, however, is where you'll find the highest concentration of luxury high-rise and townhouse developments in Greater Toronto, on a per-capita basis. It's also where you'll find condominium products far beyond your average suite, such as at Memoirs, currently under construction by Moldenhauer Lifestyles.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Look+west+for+higher-end+higher+density&amp;author=Raymaker%2C+Derek&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-09&amp;spage=H.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Look+west+for+higher-end+higher+density&amp;author=Raymaker%2C+Derek&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-09&amp;spage=H.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Halton Region is often overlooked by the broad base of condominium buyers and doesn't grab the attention of high-density market gurus focused on Greater Toronto.
Burlington and Oakville can largely claim to have delivered nicely on the great suburban promise of the 1960s and 70s: tight-knit, affluent communities with good schools and plenty of recreational amenities nearby, mostly oriented around the Lake Ontario shore. Most importantly, they have remained free of the big-city hassles of traffic and overcrowding. While that's the Chamber of Commerce line, there's a considerably high degree of satisfaction and civic pride among current Burlingtonians and Oakvillians, and no shortage of low-rise buyers who view the two cities on the western frontier of Greater Toronto as their first choice in terms of desired location.
Add to this highway access and GO Train service to and from Toronto and Hamilton. Though not entirely free of highway congestion along the Queen Elizabeth Way, Oakville and Burlington are seamlessly hooked into the alternative toll road Highway 407 in a way that its equivalent bedroom communities on the east side of Greater Toronto - Whitby and Oshawa - simply aren't.
The new housing market has shifted away from low-rise tract housing toward more high-density development over the past two years, spurred on by the increasing number of residents who are downsizing from their current low-rise homes and affluent single professionals with an affinity for a more easy-going lifestyle on the lakeshore.
There's also hardly any vacant land that can reasonably be expected to accommodate the tract low-rise development. Those appear to have gravitated north toward the once small but now sprawling Milton. There are some high-density developments aimed at first-time home buyers looking for affordability, but this is more of a niche market in Halton Region as opposed to the core of the market in central Toronto. Condominium and townhouse developments here are unique for tilting toward the high end of the market.
On the affordable side of the market is The Mosaic by veteran Halton Region developer Branthaven Homes. The Mosaic consist of 98 townhouses, including 16 live-work units, ranging in price from $250,000 for 1,069 square feet to $470,000 for 2,181 square feet. Located on Plains Road on Burlington's west end, Mosaic is one of several Burlington-area high-density projects that feature a live-work component with an open area on the ground floor for a small business and a living area upstairs.
On the high end of the Burlington market for new high-density dwellings is Freure Homes's Brant's Landing East, an eight-storey tower recently completed with 43 suites.
Prices here start at $712,000 for 1,442 square feet and go up to $1.033-million for 1,830 square feet, all on a prominent lakeshore perch just west of Burloak Drive. There are still more than a dozen suites for sale here, with sales that can be closed in as little as 60 days.
Oakville, however, is where you'll find the highest concentration of luxury high-rise and townhouse developments in Greater Toronto, on a per-capita basis. It's also where you'll find condominium products far beyond your average suite, such as at Memoirs, currently under construction by Moldenhauer Lifestyles. On sale here are two-storey detached homes along the lakeshore near attractive downtown Oakville, with common amenities that include access to a quarter-acre English garden, and maintenance fees covering all outdoor upkeep.
Prices range from $1.29-million to $1.59-million for up to 3,300 square feet, with the residences to be modelled after historic English garden homes built around the restored residence of Rev. George Washington.
The most sought-after new luxury project in Oakville is One Eleven Forsythe, a 12-storey condominium project perched along 16-Mile Creek currently under construction by The Daniels Corporation.
One Eleven Forsythe endured rancorous objections from local residents fearing height and a wave of condo development when it was initially unveiled, but since its approval and groundbreaking it's been a hit with buyers. About eight suites of a total of 68 remain for sale, ranging from $1.28-million to $2.105-million for between 1,700 and 2,300 square feet.
Credit: draymaker@globeandmail.com

____________________________________________________________

Old neighbourhoods never die - do they?

Author: LeBlanc, Dave

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/old-neighbourhoods-never-die-do-they/docview/382722196/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Since they did not, they had their digital photograph taken "while still in the stream." These were "sent to the video encoding suite" where employees tried to make sense of the address. Any that were still undecipherable at that point would have then been "kicked out of the mechanized process" to be handled manually.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Old+neighbourhoods+never+die+-+do+they%3F&amp;author=LeBlanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-09&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Old+neighbourhoods+never+die+-+do+they%3F&amp;author=LeBlanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-09&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Canada Post keeps Don Mills, Mimico, Weston alive, but Wexford, Leslieville and Baby Point don't fare as well...
Are there ghosts in the machines at Canada Post? More specifically, ghost towns or even ghost neighbourhoods?
About a year ago, I was sitting on the patio of the Wexford Restaurant at Lawrence and Warden avenues with Scarborough Historical Society member Jeremy Hopkin. He remarked that a letter addressed to a street in the area followed by "Wexford, Ontario" would arrive at its destination.
I'm not sure he meant that this was because the Wexford name has a long history - it was one of many "crossroads communities" that made up Scarborough township, and even had its own post office as of 1865 - or because you could cheat a little by adding the postal code, which would pretty much guarantee delivery.
Regardless, the conversation stayed with me, and I began to fixate on whether a letter would get to Wexford without a postal code. If it did, it would prove, in a romantic sort of way, that Wexford still existed as an independent place. If it didn't, well, although it wouldn't wipe it off the map, it would be kind of sad.
I wondered, too, about other places. How about towns that were swallowed up when Metropolitan Toronto was created in 1953, such as Mimico, Leaside, New Toronto or Weston? How about Don Mills, which although called a "new town" by its planner, Macklin Hancock, never was self-governed.
I decided to find out.
In a completely non-scientific experiment, I wrote letters - without including postal codes - to eight people I knew in some of those places to see if they'd arrive, be returned (and yes, I did put the postal code on the return address) or end up in postal limbo.
The pre-1953 town names were covered via people in Mimico, New Toronto and Weston. One went to a friend in Don Mills. My parents were my Wexford guinea pigs.
To make things interesting, I tried place names that I knew were long shots: Leslieville (Queen Street East between Carlaw and Coxwell), Baby Point (an area west of Jane Street, north of Bloor) and, to be really silly, "The Pocket" (a recent nickname for a little area south of Danforth Avenue, near Jones Avenue). I sent two batches of letters, changed slightly, to see if this would affect the outcome.
Before going further, I should mention that Monica Verma, a GTA spokeswoman for Canada Post, says that omitting postal codes is not advisable.
"We'd really like to promote proper addressing, proper postal code and proper postage," she says.
While it's a point taken, at 12:40 p.m. on March 17, I brought the first batch of eight "improper" letters to a postal outlet at Yonge and St. Clair.
These were business-sized envelopes addressed in 20-point Arial typeface. The return address was my name written by hand over my business address in small print. The second batch went to the same place at the same time two weeks later, on March 31, this time using smaller, invitation-sized envelopes addressed with a black ballpoint pen in my own hand approximating a 20-point size. The return address was my home address, also written by hand.
Had these letters had postal codes, Ms. Verma says, they would have whipped right through the "multiline optical character reader" at Canada Post's south-central letter-processing plant on Eastern Avenue and arrived at their intended destination within two business days.
Since they did not, they had their digital photograph taken "while still in the stream." These were "sent to the video encoding suite" where employees tried to make sense of the address. Any that were still undecipherable at that point would have then been "kicked out of the mechanized process" to be handled manually.
"Our employees will use local knowledge, information on the envelope and computer software to try and get an address," Ms. Verma explains.
For both batches, the flat-out winner was Don Mills. I got excited e-mails from my friend Paul Zanettos confirming delivery each time after just two days. As for those to Wexford, it took three weeks for the first letter to be returned to me after being sent to the Prescott, Ont., area ("K0E" was hand-written on it). The second came back after two weeks with the "address incomplete" box ticked.
Ms. Verma cautions, however, that this outcome was more a matter of the Don Mills name being familiar to Canada Post employees because of the large letter-carrier depot there. In other words, they were identified via their digital picture and not removed from the mechanized stream, hence the fast delivery.
Placing second were the two letters to my wife's friend Marion Traynor in New Toronto: The first arrived in just three business days, but the second took until April 9.
My co-worker Katherine Cott in Weston got her first letter in three days as well, but not the second. Similarly, another of my co-workers, Joe Middleton in Mimico, received the first letter, which took a whopping 29 days and had "try M8V" written on it (which is the correct beginning of his postal code), but he did not receive the second.
Like Wexford, both Baby Point and Leslieville were unknown to Canada Post (not at all surprising). Interestingly, while both Baby Point letters were returned, the Leslieville letters are either still bouncing around out there (and for that I apologize to Canada Post) or have come to their final resting place, the "undeliverable mail office" at 1680 Midland Ave. Here, one last-ditch attempt is made to get useful information to assist with delivery by physically opening the mail.
Most surprising of all was the e-mail I received on April 16 from my friend Mark Wigmore in "The Pocket": "Fun game!" he wrote, confirming he'd received my first letter the day before, 29 days after being sent.
"It actually doesn't surprise me," Ms. Verma says matter-of-factly. "We have very knowledgeable employees who really care about getting the mail out and they'll go to great lengths to make it happen."
So, with the autonomy of "The Pocket" validated by Canada Post, if residents ever decide they want custom street signs, streetlight banners or anything else to brand their neighbourhood, city officials will have no choice but to listen.
I wish I could say the same for Wexford.
Credit: daveleblanc@globeandmail.com

Housing, labour woes push city to bankruptcy

Author: Marois, Michael B

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/housing-labour-woes-push-city-bankruptcy/docview/382719437/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "Nobody wants bankruptcy, but there doesn't appear to be a whole lot of options left," said city councillor Joanne Schivley. "We are going to be out of money by June 30. It's all a numbers game now."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Housing%2C+labour+woes+push+city+to+bankruptcy&amp;author=Marois%2C+Michael+B&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-08&amp;spage=B.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Housing%2C+labour+woes+push+city+to+bankruptcy&amp;author=Marois%2C+Michael+B&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-08&amp;spage=B.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Vallejo, Calif., officials voted to file for bankruptcy late Tuesday night because the San Francisco suburb isn't able pay its bills after costs for police and firefighters soared and the housing market's slide cut into tax revenue.
The city council's unanimous decision will make Vallejo the largest California city to file for bankruptcy and the first in the state to seek protection from creditors because it ran out of money to pay for basic services. The decision came after it failed to win salary concessions from labour unions.
The city of 117,000 is facing ballooning labour costs and declining housing-related tax revenue that have left it with a $16-million (U.S.) deficit forecast for the year starting in July. In bankruptcy, creditors will be kept at bay while officials devise a plan to balance the books. City services would still operate.
"Nobody wants bankruptcy, but there doesn't appear to be a whole lot of options left," said city councillor Joanne Schivley. "We are going to be out of money by June 30. It's all a numbers game now."
Cities and towns rarely go bankrupt. Since 1937, there have been 543 municipal bankruptcies, two-thirds of which were small tax districts established to sell municipal bonds for projects, according to James Spiotto, a municipal bankruptcy specialist at Chapman and Cutler LLP in Chicago.
The last California city to file was Desert Hot Springs, a town of 20,000 that was hit with a legal judgment it couldn't afford. Orange County filed in 1994 amid bad bets on derivatives.
Vallejo's plight stems from rising pay for police and firefighters under current labour contracts. The problems were compounded by plunging home values, declining retail sales, and a slowdown in new housing development that cut $5-million from the city's revenue projections between June and February.
City and labour union officials have been meeting since January to revise the existing contracts. The unions have balked at pay cuts.
The fiscal strains afflicting Vallejo are reverberating across the U.S., as a housing slump and slowing economy curb revenue for states and local governments.
The area has since been one of the hardest hit in Northern California by the housing market slump. Home prices in Solano County, where the town resides, dropped 19 per cent in January from the year before, according to DataQuick Information Systems.
There are currently 1,214 "real estate owned" homes in Vallejo, meaning that the homeowners have been foreclosed and their lenders now own the houses, according to Irvine, Calif.-based RealtyTrac. Another 1,014 properties are in the foreclosure process, and 464 houses are scheduled to be auctioned.
Credit: Bloomberg Business News

CFL on the verge of construction boom

Author: Naylor, David

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/cfl-on-verge-construction-boom/docview/382716793/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: There must be some opposite to the phrase, "If you build it, they will come." Maybe it's "If you don't fix it, they won't come." But [Jeff Hunt]'s group in Ottawa faces the same challenge as several other CFL markets where local and provincial governments are wary about investing in pro sports facilities of any kind, much less for a league that hasn't always managed its affairs in the best possible way.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=CFL+on+the+verge+of+construction+boom&amp;author=Naylor%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-07&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=CFL+on+the+verge+of+construction+boom&amp;author=Naylor%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2008-05-07&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Five CFL teams are aggressively pushing plans to build new stadiums or drastically alter and refurbish old ones
Over the past quarter-century, North American sports facilities have undergone a revolution in design, followed by building booms that have swept through every level - from junior hockey and minor-league baseball through the NBA, NHL, NFL and Major League Baseball.
All of which has left the CFL looking a little like the league left behind as it continues to make do mostly with stadiums built for another era.
But after years of Band-Aid solutions to stadium up-keep, the CFL could be on the verge of a construction boom that could change the look of the league and dramatically improve its economics as well.
Five CFL teams - the Montreal Alouettes, Winnipeg Blue Bombers, Hamilton Tiger-Cats, Saskatchewan Roughriders and the ownership of a conditional Ottawa franchise - are aggressively pushing plans to build new stadiums or drastically alter and refurbish old ones.
Factor in the anticipated makeover of Vancouver's B.C. Place Stadium, which could add a retractable roof to the facility, and a potential redesign of Toronto's BMO Field to accommodate the Argonauts, and the CFL could be looking at well over a half-billion dollars invested in stadium infrastructure during the next five years.
Many would suggest it's long overdue.
"This is a league that is primarily driven by ticket sales, so the weakness is when you have older stadiums it's harder to attract people," CFL commissioner Mark Cohon said. "You can have a great product on the field, but when people go to a stadium where it's not a nice experience to be in - the washrooms are gross, they don't have a seat back, there's limited parking - then they go down to the street to an NHL game with beautiful suites, great concessions and easy to get in and out of, that creates a hard operating environment for our teams."
The reason so little has been invested in CFL stadiums over the years comes down to simple economics.
For starters, football stadiums have a more challenging economic model than large hockey arenas since outdoor venues in Canada are only fully usable during some months of the year. In addition, the number of events that require 30,000 seats is relatively few.
That's why the only three CFL stadiums built since the early 1960s were constructed primarily for other purposes: Edmonton's Commonwealth Stadium (Commonwealth Games, opened 1978), B.C. Place (World's Fair or Expo '86, opened 1983), and Toronto's Rogers Centre (home of the Toronto Blue Jays, opened 1989).
Though most CFL stadiums have lacked modern amenities for some time, the league's often insecure financial footing has put stadium redevelopment on the back burner. But by doing so, CFL teams have deprived themselves of the revenue streams that teams playing in more modern facilities enjoy - from such things as suites, better concessions and premium seating, plus the possibility of creating more better demand for tickets and higher prices.
"[Surviving in outdated stadiums] I think is a testament to the fans and the strength and importance of our sport," said David Asper, the Winnipeg businessman who is promoting a plan in which he would pump $65-million of his own money into a new stadium for the Blue Bombers in a partnership with governments.
"But the dominoes are starting to fall and there's several places around the country where people are coming to that realization."
In three cities - Ottawa, Hamilton and Winnipeg - the matter isn't so much one of upgrading stadiums to improve the fan experience as it is about ensuring there is a suitable place to play CFL football.
In Ottawa, part of the stadium was condemned last fall. And both the Bombers and Ticats are arguing it makes no sense to patch up their respective stadiums, and the time has come to look to the future with a new facility.
"Our stadium was built in 1930, and there are going to be big issues with it in the next 24 months," Tiger-Cats president Scott Mitchell said. "The question is: Do you want to bury your head in the sand and pretend there isn't an issue, or do you want to be progressive about it and look at something new that's good for the community?
"It's ironic that all those other leagues have done it and it's been a great boon for them, but the league that really needs it is the CFL where 70 to 80 per cent of revenue is from the gate. In Hamilton, our bottom line is being challenged by the extreme limitations of how much we can bring in because of the stadium. We're losing opportunities of between $1.5- and $3-million a year because of the limitations of our facility."
Jeff Hunt, who heads the group that was awarded an Ottawa franchise in March on condition that Frank Clair Stadium is rebuilt, has seen firsthand what a series of new buildings can do to a league. As owner of the Ottawa 67's of the OHL, Hunt has watched the values of teams in that league skyrocket as new buildings were being built, one after another.
And it is the prospect of a new team playing in a refurbished stadium that drove Hunt's interest in bringing Ottawa back to the CFL.
"[Being in an older stadium] just gives you such a handicap," he said. "It's like trying to have a five-star restaurant in a strip mall. You're just at such a disadvantage because the stadium is such a huge part of the experience. You should walk in there and feel like you're in a special place in a pro sports environment."
There must be some opposite to the phrase, "If you build it, they will come." Maybe it's "If you don't fix it, they won't come." But Hunt's group in Ottawa faces the same challenge as several other CFL markets where local and provincial governments are wary about investing in pro sports facilities of any kind, much less for a league that hasn't always managed its affairs in the best possible way.
That's why Asper's plan - similar to the ideas under consideration in Hamilton and Ottawa - calls for a mix of private and public money with year-round recreational use and commercial development of surrounding real estate.
"Governments are increasingly less interested in paying the freight, so that's the challenge," Asper said. "But the real estate part of it creates a different business model that takes some of the pressure off the public to build it.
"You wind up with a facility that gives the fans all the aesthetics and can have year-round use. And by intelligent use of contiguous real estate, you can give the private investor a hope of a return."
***
WHAT'S AHEAD FOR EXISTING STADIUMS
Of the nine cities with a CFL franchise, or conditional franchise, seven are considering upgrades or replacement of their existing stadiums:
MONTREAL
Percival Molson Stadium
Built: 1919.
What's ahead: Proposed $24.4-million expansion of 5,000 seats, bringing capacity to roughly 25,000.
OTTAWA
Frank Clair Stadium
Built: 1908, 1960 (south stands), 1967 (north stands).
What's ahead: Proposed demolition of the south-side stands, to be replaced with a new structure.
HAMILTON
Ivor Wynne Stadium
Built: 1930.
What's ahead: Team is exploring replacing current facility with a new structure tied to local development and investment by governments.
TORONTO
Rogers Centre
Built: 1989.
What's ahead: The team is staying put for now, but will get feedback on whether relocating to an expanded BMO Field (currently a 20,000-seat soccer-specific facility) is worth consideration.
WINNIPEG
Canad Inns Stadium
Built: 1953.
What's ahead: Proposed $165-million stadium and retail project, funded by private and public money, would develop commercial space and include year-round stadium use.
SASKATCHEWAN
Mosaic Stadium
Built: 1927, expanded in late 1970s.
What's ahead: The team is considering options for an onsite overhaul of the existing Regina stadium.
VANCOUVER
B.C. Place Stadium
Built: 1983.
What's ahead: Stadium refurbishment will take place before the 2010 Winter Olympics, but addition of a retractable roof unlikely until afterward.
David Naylor
